description: To the Editor:

title: Research Scientists to Use Network Much Faster Than Internet
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A series of ultra-high-speed fiber-optic cables will weave a cluster of West Coast university laboratories and supercomputer centers into a network called the Pacific Research Platform as part of a five-year $5 million dollar grant from the National Science Foundation.

title: Illegal Activity at Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising vs. Reporting
description: To the Editor:

title: Specialty Pharmacies
description: To the Editor:

title: Are Artificial Sweeteners Safer Than Sugar?
description: To the Editor:

title: Inmates Suit Over Abortion Denial Ends With Her Decision to Have Child
description: FLORENCE, Ala.  A lawsuit brought by a pregnant Alabama inmate seeking access to an abortion was dismissed by a federal judge on Friday after the woman said she had changed her mind and would carry the child.

title: Lawmakers on Azerbaijan Trip Cleared
description: The House Ethics Committee announcedFridaythat it had cleared 10 lawmakers and 32 House employees of any wrongdoing associated with a trip they took in May 2013 to Azerbaijan, even though investigators found inconclusive evidence suggesting that the approximately $200,000 worth of airfare and other bills were improperly paid for by the Azerbaijan government. Six lawmakers were ordered to return rugs and other gifts they received during the trip. And the investigators urged the Department of Justice to examine possible criminal efforts to mislead the lawmakers about who actually paid for the travel.

title: Jerome Kohlberg Jr., Pioneer of the Private Equity Industry, Dies at 90
description: Jerome Kohlberg Jr., a veteran financier who pioneered the $2.6 trillion leveraged-buyout industry but later rejected its hunger for huge and aggressive deals, died on Thursday at his home in Marthas Vineyard. He was 90.

title: Food Program Gets Emergency Cash
description: The anti-hunger agency of the United Nations said Friday that it had averted an imminent suspension of food aid to 440,000 Syrian refugees in Jordan after the United States provided a $65 million infusion. In a statement, the agency, the World Food Program, said the American money would enable it to maintain, albeit at a reduced level, food voucher assistance to the refugees, who all live outside camps in Jordan. This timely contribution has helped us avoid major cuts, but unless other donors step up to the plate, it will be only a matter of months before we face the same situation again, Muhannad Hadi, the agencys regional director, said in a statement. The agency, which assists 80 million people in 80 countries, has been vexed by recurring financial travails as humanitarian crises have expanded in the Middle East and Africa.

title: Maine Court Considers Vetoes by Gov. LePage
description: PORTLAND, Me.  The contentious standoff between Gov. Paul R. LePage of Maine and the State Legislature moved to the courts Friday as the two sides battled over whether the governor vetoed 65 bills within the proper time frame.

title: For Prisoners, a Path to Society
description: Conservatives and liberals who clash on just about everything else agree that the harsh drug sentencing laws that swept the country starting four decades ago have been wholly counterproductive, driving up prison costs to bankrupting levels, undermining confidence in justice and decimating communities. But as Congress seeks to reform federal sentencing policies, it should revisit other outdated policies that trap people with criminal convictions at the margins of society  and indeed have driven many of them back to jail  by denying them jobs, housing and education.

title: New York City to Reroute Garbage Truck Ramp Planned on East Side
description: Score one for the neighbors.

title: Lynn Anderson, Singer of Rose Garden, Dies at 67
description: Lynn Anderson, who skyrocketed to country music stardom in 1970 singing her signature song, (I Never Promised You a) Rose Garden, died on Thursday in Nashville. She was 67.

title: Republicans Audition for Big Money
description: A definitive event in the plutocratic spending binge now engulfing presidential politics is taking place in Orange County, Calif., this weekend. The Koch brothers and 450 of their most affluent allies are auditioning a select group of Republican candidates, who are vying to get a share of the whopping $889 million pledged by these donors for the presidential race next year.

title: Third Person Dies of LegionnairesDisease in the Bronx
description: A third person died of Legionnaires disease in the Bronx on Friday, health officials said, part of an outbreak of the airborne illness that has emerged during the hottest weeks of the year as many seek relief with air-conditioning systems that help spread the bacteria.

title: Samuel DuBoses Death in Cincinnati Points to Off-Campus Power of College Police
description: CINCINNATI  Six years ago, with crime creeping upward in the tree-lined, if slightly downtrodden, neighborhoods encircling the University of Cincinnati campus, the city and the university quietly signed an agreement giving the 72-member campus police force authority to patrol nearby residential streets.

title: New Meningitis Strain in Africa Brings Call for More Vaccines
description: Meningitis may be poised for a ferocious comeback in Africa, international aid organizations are warning, and vaccine manufacturers must step up production if the outbreak is to be averted.

title: Contenders Use Late Deals to Pad the Margins of Their Rosters
description: The shelves were not exactly empty for general managers on Friday, but the snazziest items were already gone. The flurry of deals in the final hours before the nonwaiver deadline mostly helped contenders at the margins of their rosters.

title: The Glow of the Special Olympics
description: Athletes from around the world competed in Los Angeles this week.

title: Special Olympics and the Burden of Happiness
description: When Special Olympics athletes get their medals  and the competitions are designed so that many, many do  the music swells, they pump their fists and their parents and teammates clap and yell. At the 2015 Special Olympics World Games across Los Angeles this week, the medals ceremonies went on for hours, a cascade of triumphant moments, one after another after another.

title: Woman Arrested After Jumping Over White House Barricade
description: WASHINGTON  A woman was arrested on Friday evening after she jumped over a barricade in front of the White House fence, a spokesman for the Secret Service said.

title: Emails Expand on Mosaic of Hillary Clintons Days as Secretary of State
description: WASHINGTON  A new batch of emails released on Friday portray Hillary Rodham Clinton when she was secretary of state, dealing with everything from political unrest in Honduras and a freeze on Israeli settlements in the Palestinian territories to minor details of her schedule and even a shipment of apples to her office.

title: Concern Mixes With Trust Issues for Sheldon Richardson
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The first eight minutes of Coach Todd Bowless news conference on Friday were devoted to a subject he had thought he would not have to address again. Willie Colon answered questions about it, as did Brandon Marshall and Damon Harrison.

title: Should We Charge Patients for Medical Research?
description: A FEW months ago, we got a call from a former oncology professor of ours. He had developed an experimental precision diagnostic test that he thought would be able to determine which chemotherapies would be most effective against a patients cancer. He wanted to conduct a research trial to evaluate the effectiveness of the new test. But there was one big problem: The research had no funding.

title: Super PACs Spent Millions Before Candidates Announced, Filings Show
description: Acting as shadow campaigns, the political committees backing the major presidential candidates supported them with tens of millions of dollars in chartered planes, luxury hotel suites, opposition research, high-priced lawyers and more, spending reports showed Friday.

title: American Pharoah Arrives in New Jersey
description: American Pharoah, the first Triple Crown winner in 37 years, received a warm welcome upon arriving at Monmouth Park in New Jersey. He is preparing to race on Aug. 2 in the Haskell Invitational.

title: Works of Childlike Simplicity
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  One of the nice things about puzzle constructing is that it can be done by anyone of mostly any age who happens to have the urge to construct and enough masochism to want to pursue it as a hobby (very few people actually make a living at it.)

title: New York City Questions English, Math and Science Taught at Yeshivas
description: The New York City Department of Education plans to investigate whether roughly three dozen private yeshivas are providing an adequate education in secular subjects like English, math and science, in response to a letter from parents, former students and former teachers expressing concerns, the department said this week.

title: Cosmopolitan Magazine Covers to Be Shielded by 2 Retailers
description: Is Cosmopolitan so racy it needs to be covered up?

title: Revenge of the Ideologues: Killing the Export-Import Bank
description: Idiotic, sputtered Heidi Heitkamp, the Democratic senator from North Dakota. Mind-bogglingly idiotic.

title: Giants Sign James Jones to Shore Up Receivers
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Coach Tom Coughlin confirmed Friday that the Giants had signed James Jones, the former Green Bay and Oakland wide receiver.

title: 2022 Olympics Leave China Beaming From Its Growing Clout
description: HONG KONG  Dong Jianguo, 25, a vegetable farmer from the hills outside of Beijing, cannot afford to ski, snowboard, play hockey or luge.

title: Can Chinas Games Help Human Rights?
description: The Timess Nicholas Kristof, who covered China in the 1980s, explains how Beijings Olympic win can also help improve the countrys tarnished human rights record.

title: Yankees Bypass A-List Trades, Content With Pitchers for Now and Later
description: CHICAGO  For all the hype surrounding the Yankees top prospects, the nonwaiver trading deadline was an opportunity to test the patience and resolve of a franchise that has rarely been known for either.

title: Roddy Piper, a Master Villain of Professional Wrestling, Dies at 61
description: Rowdy Roddy Piper, a professional wrestler whose athleticism and antics in the ring helped raise the profile of World Wrestling Entertainment in the 1980s, has died, his agent said on Friday. He was 61.

title: Wilmer Flores Swaps Tears for Cheers With Walk-Off Home Run
description: It was around11 p.m.Fridaywhen Terry Collins predicted the future.

title: Cover Letter of St. Louis Family Court Report
description: The Justice Departments Civil Rights Division has completed a 20-month investigation.

title: Summary of Findings in St. Louis Family Court Report
description: The Justice Departments report is based on data on nearly 33,000 cases over three years.

title: Justice Department Report on the St. Louis County Family Court
description: The department said Friday that the juvenile justice system in St. Louis County, Mo., treats black youths far more harshly than whites.

title: Department of Justice Civil Rights Reforms in Juvenile Justice
description: The Justice Department has released findings in four juvenile justice administration cases.

title: Justice Department Investigation of St. Louis County Family Court
description: The department said Friday that the juvenile justice system in St. Louis County, Mo., treats black youths far more harshly than whites.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) BIRDMAN OR (THE UNEXPECTED VIRTUE OF IGNORANCE) (2014) Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton, in an Oscar-nominated performance), a washed-up Hollywood superhero, floats down to earth to deliver himself from his past by staging a Broadway adaptation of a Raymond Carver short story. Then a pompous theater actor (Edward Norton) comes along and threatens to steal the show. Riggans fresh-from-rehab daughter (Emma Stone) has taken on the role of his assistant. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called this best-picture winner a funny, frenetic, buoyant and rambunctiously showboating entertainment in which the director Alejandro G. Irritu himself rises high and then higher still. Riggan, Mr. Scott added, isnt the only man on the move: So is Mr. Irritu, who has staged and shot the movie so that it looks like everything that happens, from airborne beginning to end, occurs during one transporting continuous take. The camera doesnt just move with the story and characters, it also ebbs and flows like water, soars and swoops like a bird, its movement as fluid as a natural element, as animated as a living organism. Mr. Irritu won the Oscar for best director, and Emmanuel Lubezki for cinematography.

title: Tibetan Who Called for Dalai Lamas Return Is Said to Be Freed From Chinese Prison
description: BEIJING  A Tibetan man who was imprisoned for eight years after calling for the Dalai Lamas return to Tibet at a popular festival has been released, according to overseas Tibet advocacy groups.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: But maybe everything that dies someday comes back. Maybe Asbury Park is back?

title: Corrections: August 1, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Mark Karpeles, Chief of Bankrupt Bitcoin Exchange, Is Arrested in Tokyo
description: TOKYO  Since the collapse last year of Mt. Gox, the exchange that served as the largest hub for storing and trading the virtual currency Bitcoin, law enforcement officials and angry clients have been asking what happened to nearly half a billion dollars in Bitcoins that the company said had vanished from its computer systems.

title: Turning Point: Hilary Swift
description: Hilary Swift, a photography intern with The New York Times, has previously worked for the Reno Gazette-Journal in Nevada and The Free Lance-Star in Virginia. Ms. Swift, 22, participated in the 2014 Eddie Adams Workshop and the 2015 New York Portfolio Review. Her conversation with Elijah Walker has been edited.

title: Im Not Mad. Thats Just My RBF.
description: I didnt think much about it at the time: I was appearing in a short television segment and had quickly brushed my hair, then slapped on some concealer. I figured my glasses would cover the circles under my eyes.

title: My Dinner With Longevity Expert Dan Buettner (No Kale Required)
description: Dan Buettner and I were off to a good start. He approved of coffee.

title: Censure and Clashes After West Bank Attack
description: JALAZOUN REFUGEE CAMP, West Bank  Palestinian youths clashed with Israeli forces while thousands of Israelis flocked to rallies, all of them protesting an arson attack that killed a Palestinian toddler  a rare instance of mutual shock in a land attuned to bitter violence.

title: A Late Summer Nights Dream on Michigans Mackinac Island
description: New at Mission Point Resort on Mackinac Island in Michigan will be a Shakespearean-themed two-night package from Aug. 27 to 31 called Stratford on the Straits.

title: 120 Degrees and No Relief? ISIS Takes Back Seat for Iraqis
description: BAGHDAD  In the Iraqi summer, when the temperature rises above 120 degrees Fahrenheit, electricity becomes even more of a political issue than usual. This past week, at the top of Iraqis agenda, it has even eclipsed war with the Islamic State.

title: U.S. Declassifies FISA Court Documents about the Protect America Act
description: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit filed by The New York Times, the Obama administration has declassified and released documents related to the Protect America Act in late 2007 and early 2008. The documents fill in a gap in the historical record regarding the evolution of the Bush administrations post-9/11 warrantless surveillance program.

title: Hot Hot Hot
description: TIMES INSIDER  Its hot outside. You want to be either poolside or, lacking a pool, somewhere in air-conditioning with a cool beverage and a crossword puzzle. So lets get to it: We have four puzzles that may or may not take your mind off the heat.

title: When the Super Has a Drinking Problem
description: A Belligerent Superintendent

title: Joe Biden in 2016: What Would Beau Do?
description: WASHINGTON  A PATTERN of cutting corners, a patina of entitlement and inevitability, has led to this.

title: New Orleans Hospital Is Replaced, With Hope of Preserving Its Mission
description: NEW ORLEANS  After Hurricane Katrina, the shrunken medical staff of the state-owned Charity Hospital worked out of tents, an abandoned Lord & Taylor department store and eventually a cramped interim hospital with scaled-back services. As best they could, they continued Charitys centuries-old mission of caring for poor and uninsured residents, mostly black, whom other hospitals typically turned away.

title: Farhad and Mikes Week in Review: Twitter Problems
description: We are trying something new. Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, will review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe even a few jokes about the most important developments in the industry.

title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  For those of you just joining us, the deal here is that this particular variety puzzle looks like a crossword and it smells like a crossword (seriously; put your nose right against the paper or screen), but it is only a crossword in the sense that it crosses words.

title: Small Pool of Rich Donors Dominates Election Giving
description: Fewer than four hundred families are responsible for almost half the money raised in the 2016 presidential campaign, a concentration of political donors that is unprecedented in the modern era.

title: Joel S. Marcus on Taking the Ego Out of Leading
description: This interview with Joel S. Marcus, chief executive of Alexandria Real Estate Equities, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Providing the Soundtrack for Lifes Last Moments
description: Ive been called an angel more times than I care to admit. Thats what happens when you walk down hospital hallways with a harp and have a job that primarily serves people who are dying.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: The Treat That Could Bite Your Dog Back
description: The Haggler chatted recently with a woman named Muriel Mateer, who did something in late July that nearly had disastrous consequences: She gave her dog a bone. Specifically, she gave her dog a Real Ham Bone, a shrink-wrapped canine treat that is, in fact, a real pork femur, made by Dynamic Pet Products of Washington, Mo.

title: Mets Relationship With Yoenis Cespedes? Its a Rental
description: The Mets union with Yoenis Cespedes seems certain to be brief. Cespedes, the slugging outfielder acquired for two prospects on Friday, is a free agent after this season. The Mets have three other outfielders signed for 2016 and an aversion to the kind of lavish deal Cespedes will command.

title: Dr. Stephen Klasko: Where Einstein, Jobs and Yoda Join Strategy Sessions
description: Dr. Stephen Klasko is the President and C.E.O. of Thomas Jefferson University and Jefferson Health, Philadelphia.

title: Converse Treads Carefully in Updating Well-Worn Chuck Taylor Brand
description: Nike came out with a new product last Tuesday, an updated and  for my feet  more comfortable version of an old canvas basketball sneaker known as the Converse Chuck Taylor All Star.

title: Flooding Spurs Disaster Zones in Myanmar
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Myanmars president on Friday declared four rural regions to be disaster zones, as floods and landslides continued to cause severe damage and the government faced criticism for its slow response to the emergency.

title: Former White Sox Organists Offbeat Approach Resonated for Decades
description: In 1970, just before she was hired as the organist for the Chicago White Sox, Nancy Faust received a letter from a team official.

title: Vah Alaverdian
description: Vah Alaverdian is a master falconer whose company, Falcon Force, has a staff of more than 30 raptors, which are used to scare off, but not kill, nuisance birds (starlings, gulls, pigeons, etc.) at vineyards, farms, airports, historical sites and amusement parks.

title: Hamilton and the Republican Hopefuls
description: HOW fitting that the Republican presidential candidates will hold their first debate this Thursday on the same night as the Broadway opening of Hamilton, the groundbreaking new musical about the founding fathers. At a time when so many American politicians are sanitized, cautious, even boring, the characters on the debate stage and the Broadway stage are remarkably in sync: brazen, unpredictable, even outrageous.

title: Republican Hypocrisy on Iran
description: The exaggerations and half-truths that some Republicans are using to derail  President Obamas important and necessary nuclear deal with Iran are beyond ugly. Invoking the Holocaust, Mike Huckabee, a contender for the Republican presidential nomination, has accused Mr. Obama of marching Israelis to the door of the oven. Tom Cotton, a senator from Arkansas, has compared Secretary of State John Kerry, who helped negotiate the deal, to Pontius Pilate.

title: How to Fight Doping in Sports
description: FEW sports performances are regarded without suspicion these days. Nowhere was this more evident than in the recent Tour de France, where the winner, Chris Froome of the British Team Sky, spent three weeks responding to skeptics about his exceptional performances, which rivaled those of doped champions, including Lance Armstrong.

title: Is New Orleans Safe?
description: New Orleans  THIS city always had a different rhythm. It was the opposite of New York: After a stevedore was overheard saying, If you cant make it in the Big Easy, you cant make it anywhere, the phrase The Big Easy made its way from the African-American community into Newsweek, and spread. For decades, the citys ambitious young men and women loved it yet fled, while those who did move here found places for themselves in existing spaces, slipping into its crevices, embracing it.

title: President Obamas Racial Renaissance
description: WE finally have the president we thought we elected: one who talks directly and forcefully about race and human rights.

title: Palm Oil Company Is Accused of Exploiting Liberias Ebola Crisis
description: KABADA, Liberia  Standing in his garden, Alex Wloh wistfully cradled a few ears of corn in his hands. A mile or so away, field workers had been planting palm seedlings where he and his fellow villagers used to grow crops like rice, cassava and vegetables.

title: Congress Should Look Beyond the Gas Tax
description: Lawmakers in Washington are so scared of raising the inadequate federal gas tax that they keep passing short-term bills to move money from other taxes to fund transportation projects. They should develop the kind of courage legislatures in red states like Utah, Nebraska and South Dakota have shown and raise the gas tax.

title: Why the Economy Is Not Ready for an Interest Rate Increase
description: The Federal Reserve talked up the economy last Wednesday, in a statement that emphasized improvements in employment, housing and consumer spending. Unfortunately, the optimism is misplaced.

title: A New Abortion Furor
description: Readers discuss the videos of officials at Planned Parenthood discussing fetal tissue.

title: Joe Biden Said to Be Taking New Look at Presidential Run
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his associates have begun to actively explore a possible presidential campaign, which would upend the Democratic field and deliver a direct threat to Hillary Rodham Clinton, several people who have spoken to Mr. Biden or his closest advisers say.

title: Our Sex-Crazed Congress
description: TO appreciate the dumbing down of American politics, consider this: Conservative Republicans, indignant about abortion, are trying to destroy a government program that helps prevent 345,000 abortions a year.

title: The Tortured Tale of Hillary Clinton and The Times
description: The history of the Clintons and The New York Times over the decades is like an airport baggage carousel  with a difference. New pieces keep barreling down the chute, but none of it ever seems to get removed.

title: The Donalds Gifts for Jeb Bush
description: THE most important question of the moment, as the Republican Party prepares for the first of 1,162 or so presidential primary debates, isnt really what Donald Trump will say or do on stage.

title: Grand Jury Indicts Texas Attorney General, Ken Paxton, on Felony Charges
description: HOUSTON  Ken Paxton, the Republican attorney general of Texas and a former state legislator, has been indicted by a grand jury on charges of securities fraud and of failing to register with the state securities board, officials said.

title: Giants Undertake Major Renovation Projects on Both Sides of the Ball
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  There are still four Super Bowl trophies in a shimmering case just inside the front door of the Giants offices and training complex. Thirty-foot banners commemorating those defining victories dominate the indoor practice grounds.

title: Taliban Leader Urges Unity, Playing Down Peace Talk
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two days after acknowledging that its supreme commander, Mullah Muhammad Omar, was dead, the Taliban released an audio recording said to be from the groups new leader.

title: Ohio States Ascent Reinvigorates the Big Ten
description: CHICAGO  In January, the Big Ten felt united as perhaps never before. After years of perceived decline in its signature sport, football, the conference had seen its champion  Ohio State  become the first league team to play for the national title since the 2007 season, and the first to win one since the 2002 season.

title: Aja Zanova, Top Czech Skater Who Defected to West, Dies at 84
description: Aja Zanova, a world champion figure skater whose defection from Czechoslovakia as a teenager in 1950 made headlines around the world, died on Thursday in Manhattan. She was 84.

title: In Case You Missed It: Top Articles of the Week
description: Catch up with the most-read sports stories in The New York Times from July 24 to July 30.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Missing the Point in a Biological Controversy

title: Bronx Residents Anxious After 4th Death From Legionnaires Disease
description: The largest outbreak of Legionnaires disease in New York City in at least three years has claimed its fourth victim, health officials said on Saturday, reinforcing concerns among some residents and elected leaders that the city had not adequately prepared to combat the airborne illness.

title: Highly Coordinated
description: When dont look down isnt an option.

title: A.& P. Bankruptcy Means New York, Chains Birthplace, Will Lose Last Store
description: Linda Fisch stopped at the A.&P. on Riverdale Avenue in the Bronx on Thursday and bought eight prepackaged containers of cottage cheese and fruit. She did not realize the store had become a footnote to history.

title: In Compromise, Pro Football Hall of Fame Offers to let Junior Seaus Daughter Speak at Ceremony
description: Sydney Seau may speak after all  sort of.

title: Inflation Paranoia as a Tribal Marker
description: Derp  views that just keep being repeated in the face of overwhelming contrary evidence  has always been with us, but the derp quotient has really soared since the crisis of 2008, which made nonsense of doctrines too dearly held to be reconsidered. This is especially true of inflation derp: has any prominent figure who warned of runaway inflation from the Feds efforts admitted having learned anything from being wrong year after year?

title: Dr. James Jude, Who Helped Develop Use of CPR, Dies at 87
description: Dr. James Jude, a thoracic surgeon whose recognition that external manual pressure could revive a stalled heart, and who used that insight to help develop the lifesaving technique now known as cardiopulmonary resuscitation, or CPR, died on Tuesday at his home in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 87.

title: Literally Speaking
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  A very literal puzzle today from Matt Ginsberg, where the circled squares do exactly what the entire phrase describes. I do love an obedient crossword puzzle.

title: After Deal, Europeans Are Eager to Do Business in Iran
description: PARIS  Before the ink was even dry on the Iran nuclear deal, European leaders and executives were heading to the airport to restart trade with an Iranian market described in almost feverish terms as an El Dorado and potential bonanza.

title: Dry Days Bring Ferocious Start to Fire Season
description: WALLA WALLA, Wash.  Another summer of record-breaking drought and heat has seized the West, setting off costly and destructive wildfires from Southern California, where a single blaze burned more than 30,000 acres of national forest east of Los Angeles, to Montana, where a fast-moving fire in Glacier National Park recently forced tourists to flee hotels, campgrounds and vehicles.

title: Laos, Destination in Illegal Ivory Trade, So Far Eludes Global Crackdown
description: BANGKOK  When the authorities in Thailand recently intercepted huge stashes of ivory stuffed inside shipments of beans and tea leaves, the seizures were described as groundbreaking international police work.

title: Bay Areas Disjointed Public Transit Network Inspires a Call for Harmony
description: SAN FRANCISCO  There is much to relish about the Bay Area, from the intoxicating landscape to the blissful lack of humidity.

title: Inquiry Faults Huma Abedin, Close Aide to Hillary Clinton
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department inspector general has determined that Huma Abedin, the close confidant of Hillary Rodham Clinton, must return more than $9,000 for alleged overpayments made to her during her time working for the department when Mrs. Clinton was secretary of state, according to her lawyer and Senate documents.

title: Jets Offer Support and Tough Love to Sheldon Richardson
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The first few days of Mike Maccagnans first training camp as the Jets general manager had been largely quiet  except for Sheldon Richardsons latest off-the-field infractions, Muhammad Wilkersons simmering contract dispute and Devin Smiths broken ribs.

title: Medical Marijuana Dispensary Plan in the South Bronx Stirs Anxiety and Hope
description: The Hunts Point neighborhood in the South Bronx has struggled to clean up its act for years. Prostitution is still a problem, but it is far less prevalent, residents say, than it once was.

title: Enigmatic Cespedes Is Charged With Lighting Up New York Again
description: The first time Yoenis Cespedes walked through the Mets clubhouse, he made an impression, intentional or not. He gave firm handshakes, looked his new teammates in the eye and introduced himself. He wore a necklace with a pendant the size of a baseball that showed his number, 52.

title: Buddy Emmons, Virtuoso of the Steel Guitar, Dies at 78
description: Buddy Emmons, the inventive musician who reimagined and popularized the pedal steel guitar in jazz, country, and western swing bands beginning in the mid-1950s, performing with many of musics biggest stars, died on July 21 in Hermitage, Tenn., near Nashville. He was 78.

title: Training Officers to Shoot First, and He Will Answer Questions Later
description: WASHINGTON  The shooting looked bad. But that is when the professor is at his best. A black motorist, pulled to the side of the road for a turn-signal violation, had stuffed his hand into his pocket. The white officer yelled for him to take it out. When the driver started to comply, the officer shot him dead.

title: Preparing for Debate, Republicans Test Themselves Against Donald Trump
description: Jeb Bush is spending hours in sessions from Florida to Maine preparing policy answers for Thursdays first Republican debate  but he is also being mindful to avert any display of disdain for the man he will stand beside, Donald J. Trump, who has infuriated Mr. Bush by criticizing Mexican immigrants. (Mr. Bush is married to one.)

title: Yoenis Cespedes Makes His Presence Felt, Indirectly, in a Win
description: The Citi Field crowd leapt from its seats and threw up its hands and roared in anticipation, watching a screaming line drive jump off Yoenis Cespedess bat. The second-largest crowd in the parks history, 42,996 fans, had come to watch his Mets debut. He had been heralded as their offensive savior, and a home run would tie the score in the sixth inning.

title: Stepping From Class AAA to Majors, Young Yankees Pitchers Cant Deliver
description: CHICAGO  When General Manager Brian Cashman decided he did not want to trade his top prospects for the starting pitchers his first-place team needs at the moment, it was a show of faith in the farm system, particularly the pitchers he will be counting on now.

title: Obama to Unveil Tougher Environmental Plan With His Legacy in Mind
description: WASHINGTON  In the strongest action ever taken in the United States to combat climate change, President Obama will unveil on Monday a set of environmental regulations devised to sharply cut planet-warming greenhouse gas emissions from the nations power plants and ultimately transform Americas electricity industry.

title: Bianca Kaprielian, Deborah Koski
description: Bianca Lynn Kaprielian and Deborah Anne Koski were married Saturday at the Headlands Center for the Arts in Sausalito, Calif. Alison Hurwitz, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Xela Herridge-Meyer,  John Okrent
description: Xela Herridge-Meyer, a daughter of Tamie J. Herridge and Dick L. Meyer of Olympia, Wash., was married Saturday to Dr. John L. Okrent, the son of Rebecca L. Okrent and Daniel Okrent of South Wellfleet, Mass. The brides father, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the home of the brides friends, Abigail Rueb and Rolland Rueb, on Orcas Island, Wash.

title: Stephanie Langdon, Taishon Black
description: Stephanie Marguerite Langdon, a daughter of Crystal Langdon and George Langdon IV of Selkirk, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Taishon S. Black, the son of Victoria B. Washington of Las Vegas and Mark S. Black of Uniondale, N.Y. The brides father, a minister of the International Apostolic Ministries, officiated at Gotham Hall, an events space in Manhattan.

title: Rachel Newman, Adir Glick
description: Rachel Beth Newman, a daughter of Marian Gitlin Newman and Dr. Michael A. Newman of Bethesda, Md., is to be married Sunday to Rabbi Adir Nathaniel Glick, a son of Nomi Jones Glick and Rabbi Yoel Glick of Clara, France. The grooms father will officiate at Robinswood House, an event space in Bellevue, Wash.

title: Trang To and Wilson Tong
description: Trang Thuy To, a daughter of Chau T. Tran and Son V. To of Springfield, Pa., was married Saturday to Wilson Karkin Tong, a son of Yim Fong Yu and Hon Chung Tong of Cheltenham, Pa. The couple were married under Pennsylvanias self-uniting marriage statute at the Union League of Philadelphia.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: The question is whether we are in a new Gilded Age or well beyond it  to a Platinum Age.

title: Corrections: August 2, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Why Some Start-Ups Are Called Tech Companies and Others Are Not
description: After Charles Lindbergh flew across the Atlantic in 1927, a company called Seaboard Air Line Railroad attracted an unusual amount of attention from investors who thought it was in the aviation business.

title: Copwatch vs. Cops: After Freddie Gray
description: In a year of violent police encounters, a 25-year-old movement to document law enforcement has new urgency. This is the story of Copwatch as told by Michael Browns neighbor and Freddie Grays friend.

title: Six Things Google Remembers About My Parenting That Id Almost Forgotten
description: Ive been a parent for six years. That is six short years full of long days. Our children are born tiny, helpless, things, then we blink and theyre fully formed human beings, and we can hardly remember what it was like when they didnt sleep, pee or pretty much do anything the way we thought they should. Or at least, we cant remember what it is they used to not do the way we thought they should, because we are so caught up in whatever it is theyre doing or not doing now.

title: The Rising Cost of Manufacturing
description: A look at the (mostly) rising costs to manufacture goods by country and a breakdown of the cost to make yarn.

title: Along With Babies, Hairstylists Are Arriving in Hospitals
description: When Donna Yip, a lawyer who lives in the financial district, went into labor with her second child in June, she had more than just her husband and medical team in her room at NewYork-Presbyterian Morgan Stanley Childrens Hospital.

title: Chinese Textile Mills Are Now Hiring in Places Where Cotton Was King
description: INDIAN LAND, S.C.  Twenty-five years ago, Ni Meijuan earned $19 a month working the spinning machines at a vast textile factory in the Chinese city of Hangzhou.

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here are the weeks top stories.

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Catch up on the weeks top stories.

title: A Peek Inside Universal Studios
description: At theme parks, thousands toil behind the scenes and after hours to produce the fun and the foam they hope their guests will consider magic.

title: Comcast Invests by the Billion in Theme Parks, Hogwarts and All
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The Universal theme park chain was the last thing Comcast was interested in when it bought NBCUniversal four years ago. Endless upkeep? Endless spending on new rides? Endless anxiety about public safety?

title: Suicide Attack by Kurdistan Workers Party Members in Turkey Kills 2 Soldiers
description: ISTANBUL  Kurdish militias carried out a suicide attack on a military police station in eastern Turkey on Sunday, killing two soldiers and wounding 31 others, the local authorities said.

title: 1940: Freemasonry to Be Outlawed by Ptains Regime
description: A news report, produced by the Vichy government, shows an anti-Freemasonry exhibition in Paris in 1940. The video has no sound. INA.fr.

title: Getting to the Sky
description: The extreme sport of skyrunning combines mountaineering and running, sometimes over long distances, but almost always at or above 6,500 feet.

title: 9 Injured in Shooting in Brooklyn
description: Under the drooping backyard willow tree, relatives and friends gathered. Soon scores of neighbors and others in search of a place to party filled the backyard of the two-story, brick-front Brooklyn home.

title: Copwatch vs. Cops: After Freddie Gray
description: In a year of violent police encounters, much of the conversation has been about cameras: Who should have them, what can they achieve and how can they improve the broken relationship between the police and African-American communities?

title: Stephen Harper of Canada, Hoping to Extend Conservatives Hold, Calls Elections
description: OTTAWA  Prime Minister Stephen Harper of Canada called federal elections on Sunday, hoping to extend his Conservative Partys decade-long hold on power despite questions about its ethics and a struggling economy.

title: 1965: Fists Fly in Athens Assembly
description: ATHENS  In its second attempt in three days, Premier George Athanasiades-Novass government tonight got the quorum it has been seeking to submit itself to a confidence debate in Parliament. But it did so in a session marked by fist fights and efforts to drag Foreign Minister George Melas down from the rostrum where he had been speaking. Police were called in to protect the minister from anti-government deputies who claimed he had abused one of their members.

title: Hannibal Recap: Always Room for a Few More Scars
description: Season 3, Episode 9: And the Woman Clothed With the Sun

title: Iran Capitalizing on a Taste for Americas Biggest Brands
description: TEHRAN  Despite the smiling clown, a symbol of the Great Satans love for meat, buns and fries, there were no angry mobs punching fists in the air, shouting Death to America; nor did the smell of burned American flags permeate this Tehran neighborhood.

title: Tiny Island of Runion Awash in Intrigue Over Vanished Malaysian Plane
description: ST.-DENIS, Runion  Ever since Johnny Begue and his friend stumbled on a barnacle-encrusted airplane wing flap last week  one that appears to be from the same kind of plane as Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared without a trace more than a year ago  just about every piece of flotsam kicked up along the shores of this island in the Indian Ocean has attracted scrutiny.

title: Martin OMalley Calls for Criminal Justice Overhaul Amid Racial Tensions
description: When Hillary Rodham Clinton took aim at Jeb Bush in her speech at the National Urban League conference in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Friday, it overshadowed a noteworthy address by one of her rivals.

title: A Peek Inside Universal Studios
description: At theme parks, thousands toil behind the scenes and after hours to produce the fun and the foam they hope their guests will consider magic.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 12:30 P.M. (13) LA DONNA DEL LAGO Joyce DiDonato, above, sings Elena, the lady of the lake, and Juan Diego Flrez is Giacomo, the king of Scotland, in Paul Currans staging of this Rossini melodrama, based on the poem by Sir Walter Scott and conducted by Michele Mariotti. The wondrous Ms. DiDonato and Mr. Mariotti, the fast-rising young Italian conductor, seemed almost in competition to see who could make music with more delicacy, Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times of this production from the Metropolitan Opera and the Santa Fe Opera, presented here by Great Performances at the Met. Ms. DiDonato sang Rossinis beguiling phrases with soft yet penetrating richness, subtly folding ornaments and runs into the long melodic arcs. And Mr. Mariotti drew hushed gentle and transparent playing from the inspired Met orchestra.

title: Poster Child for New Yorks Paid Sick Leave Law Failed to Follow It
description: Shiv Puri embraced New York Citys paid sick leave law last year and was heralded as a trailblazer among employers. At City Hall, Mayor Bill de Blasio praised him as a great example to business owners all across the city.

title: Animals on the Empire State Building
description: The artists Louie Psihoyos and Travis Threlkel projected digital images of endangered species onto the Empire State Building in an event meant to draw attention to the creatures plight.

title: 2 Proud Daughters of the Bronx Share More Than a Name
description: The sounds of summer drifted through the air on the Bronx side of the High Bridge, from the squeals of children running along sun-dappled paths to the slaps of flip-flops hitting the pavement as boys with towels slung over their shoulders walked to the public swimming pool on the Manhattan side. Two women chatting on a bench stopped midsentence as two other women, smiling and familiar looking, ambled past.

title: Kerry Warns Egypt Human Rights Abuses Can Hurt Fight Against Terrorism
description: CAIRO  Secretary of State John Kerry told Egyptian officials on Sunday that they would not be able to defeat terrorism at home unless they showed greater respect for human rights.

title: France and Britain Seek Help on Calais Migrants From E.U.
description: LONDON  In a letter published on Sunday, the interior ministers of Britain and France called on other European Union countries to help solve the underlying causes of the migrant crisis at the port of Calais, where thousands of people have been trying to force their way onto trucks and trains bound for Britain through the tunnel linking the two countries.

title: Eric Schlosser to Publish Book on American Prison System
description: Eric Schlosser, author of the best-selling expos of the fast food industry, Fast Food Nation, will publish a new book that investigates Americas expanding prison system and explores how rising incarceration rates are intertwined with social factors like growing inequality.

title: Donald Trump Campaign Fires Adviser Linked to Racially Charged Facebook Posts
description: Donald J. Trump has fired a campaign adviser after racially charged Facebook posts under his name emerged last week, Mr. Trumps campaign manager said.

title: Review: The Economics of Inequality, by Thomas Piketty
description: Back in 2001 two French economists, Thomas Piketty and Emmanuel Saez, circulated a seminal research paper (formally published two years later) titled Income inequality in the United States, 1913-1998. They used data from income tax receipts to do two things that you cant do with standard data on the distribution of income, which come from household surveys. First, they gave us a portrait of the economic stratosphere  the incomes of the now-famous 1 percent. Second, they gave us historical depth, reaching all the way back to the late Gilded Age.

title: Freshwaters Wrong Turn (Wonkish)
description: Paul Romer has been writing a series of posts on the problem he calls mathiness, in which economists write down fairly hard-to-understand mathematical models accompanied by verbal claims that dont actually match whats going on in the math. Most recently, he has been recounting the pushback hes getting from freshwater macro types, who seem him as allying himself with evil people like me  whereas he sees them as having turned away from science toward a legalistic, adversarial form of pleading.

title: Puerto Ricans Brace for Crisis in Health Care
description: MAYAGEZ, P.R.  The first visible sign that the health care system in Puerto Rico was seriously in trouble was when a steady stream of doctors  more than 3,000 in five years  began to leave the island for more lucrative, less stressful jobs on the mainland.

title: Political Consultant for Uber to Advise Other Start-Ups
description: Uber, the ride-hailing app, seems capable of the impossible: fighting City Hall and winning.

title: Dr. Dre to Release Compton A Soundtrack, His First Album in 16 Years
description: Dr. Dre will release his first album in 16 years  but it wont be the much anticipated Detox. The album is titled Compton A Soundtrack by Dr. Dre, and will be available Aug. 7 on Apple Music.

title: South Street Seaports Culture District Converts Stores to Art Galleries
description: Out with Wendys, and in with art.

title: Jerry Berrigan, a Catholic Peace Activist, Dies at 95
description: Jerry Berrigan, a Roman Catholic peace activist who, like his better-known brothers Philip and Daniel, was arrested frequently for protesting the Vietnam War and other conflicts, died on July 26 at his home in Syracuse. He was 95.

title: Zimbabwe Officials Say Another American Illegally Killed a Lion in an Authorized Hunt
description: A prominent American gynecologist illegally killed a lion in an authorized hunt this year in Zimbabwe, wildlife authorities there said Sunday.

title: D.E.C. Commissioners Email to Adirondack Council
description: Joseph Martens, commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation, wrote to Brian Houseal, executive director of the Adirondack Council, urging the group to reconsider its opposition to the proposed amendment.

title: Letter From D.E.C. Commissioner
description: The Department of Environmental Conservation commissioner, Joseph Martens, wrote to Brian Houseal, executive director of the Adirondack Council, to emphasize that the state would receive far more acreage from NYCO than the 200 acres the amendment would give it access to.

title: Adirondack Council Opposes Proposed Constitutional Amendment
description: Brian Houseal, executive director of the Adirondack Council, wrote the Department of Environmental Conservation to voice his organizations opposition to the proposed constitutional amendment.

title: Board of Elections Email
description: Board of Elections staffer John Conklin emailed Associated Press reporter Michael Gormley, explaining that the Department of Environmental Conservation asked for changes to two different 2013 constitutional amendments.

title: D.E.C. Position Paper on the Land Swap
description: The Department of Environmental Conservation outlined the potential economic cost of not moving forward with the amendment.

title: A Thank You Email for Helping With the Amendment
description: Mark Behan, working on behalf of NYCO Minerals, thanked a number of staffers at the Department of Environmental Conservation for their help in getting the Adirondack Council to change its position on the amendment.

title: Pikettys New Book
description: Harvard University Press has released what looks like a new book by Thomas Piketty, but isnt. My unhappy review.

title: A Thank You Email From NYCO Minerals
description: Peter Goodwin, the chief executive of NYCO Minerals, thanked two senior Department of Environmental Conservation officials for the agencys support of the proposed constitutional amendment.

title: NYCO Minerals Blasts the Ballot Language
description: NYCO Minerals complained to the Department of Environmental Conservation about the proposed ballot language. The agency was quick to respond, we are doing what we can on this.

title: Giants G.M. Says Heart Goes Out to Jason Pierre-Paul
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Addressing reporters for the first time since the Giants training camp opened last week, General Manager Jerry Reese offered support on Sunday for Jason Pierre-Paul, the defensive end who is absent from camp because of a fireworks accident.

title: Review: Garth Fagan Dance Honors Geoffrey Holder Along With Carmen de Lavallade
description: The prodigious dancer, choreographer, painter, designer and actor Geoffrey Holder, who died in October  but not before reportedly dancing on his deathbed  would have been 85 on Saturday. Lincoln Center Out of Doors hosted a day of events in his honor, culminating in a performance by Garth Fagan Dance at Damrosch Park, with a prelude by Mr. Holders partner of 59 years, Carmen de Lavallade.

title: Review: Jeremy Denk in a Full-Blooded Performance at Mostly Mozart
description: A Google search for scores written for one hand alone reveals a considerable repertory for each hand. The best-known works are for the left hand, like the concertos by Ravel and Korngold, composed for the pianist Paul Wittgenstein, who lost his right arm in World War I. Injury is often a motivating factor behind such compositions; Scriabin wrote for left hand after an injury to his right. Brahms dedicated his transcription for left hand of the Chaconne in D minor (from Bachs Partita in D minor for solo violin) to Clara Schumann, who had injured her other hand.

title: Talking to the Taliban
description: Fledgling peace talks between the Afghan government and the Taliban have been postponed indefinitely.

title: R-Rated Comedies, Vacation Among Them, Continue to Struggle
description: LOS ANGELES  Raunchy comedy is having a rough run at the box office.

title: Review: Cecilia Bartoli Has Dramatic Depth as Norma at Salzburg Festival
description: SALZBURG, Austria  During the mid-1990s, when Cecilia Bartoli was known for scintillating performances of roles like Rossinis Cenerentola (Cinderella), the suggestion that this light-voiced mezzo-soprano might take on the daunting title role of Bellinis Norma someday would have seemed absurd. Maria Callas had defined the role for late 20th-century audiences as a supreme test for a fiercely intense, formidable soprano. Some powerhouse mezzo-sopranos, like Shirley Verrett and Grace Bumbry, had made the leap. But a perky Cinderella singing Norma? No way.

title: Review: Karen Oberlins His Aim Is True, a Tribute to Elvis Costello
description: Karen Oberlins extensively researched, beautifully executed tribute to the music of Elvis Costello answers a question that has been gnawing at me for years: Why have so few of Mr. Costellos songs achieved the status of modern standards? For all this time, I had assumed that his raw, unwelcoming voice, with its strangulated diction, was the reason. Surely, a better-equipped singer could untangle his knotty lyrics and sharpen the melodic profiles of songs that Mr. Costello presented as impassioned downbeat mystery stories.

title: Review: Significant Mother Puts a Son in an Awkward Situation
description: When is progress the opposite of progress? When its Significant Mother, a new comedy on CW that tried for the cutting edge but ended up dull and dimwitted.

title: Review: Beats of the Antonov Examines Sudans Civil Wars
description: In a recent series of opinion columns filed from the Nuba Mountains in southern Sudan, Nicholas Kristof of The New York Times decried the lack of attention paid to the Sudanese governments brutal daily bombing of its own people. As if in response, on Monday PBSs POV documentary series presents Beats of the Antonov, a film shot on the front lines of Sudans continuing civil wars.

title: Seattle Art Fair Receives a Boost From Techs Big Spenders
description: SEATTLE  Paul Allen came ready to shop. Mr. Allen, a billionaire co-founder of Microsoft and one of this citys major cultural patrons, strolled the aisles of the inaugural Seattle Art Fair on Thursday, looking to add to his formidable art collection.

title: Review: License and Restriction in a Work by La Monte Young at Dia Chelsea
description: Some kind of tension, real or metaphorical, is primary for the life force of any music. La Monte Youngs music can have lots of tension with very few notes, and the performance of one of his early pieces at Dia: Chelseas Dream House on Friday had it in every aspect of its experience.

title: Robin Phillips, Director, Dies at 75; Revitalized Canadas Stratford Festival
description: Robin Phillips, a British theater director who helped rejuvenate Canadas best-known theater, the Stratford Festival, as artistic director from 1975 to 1980, died on July 25 in Woodstock, Ontario. He was 75.

title: Finland Unnerved by Trial of Police Detective on Drug Charges
description: Members of Finlands National Bureau of Investigation were working to crack a drug smuggling ring, when they intercepted phone calls and text messages between a suspected supplier and buyer emanating from Pasila, a district of Helsinki.

title: American Pharoah Wins Haskell Invitational
description: OCEANPORT, N.J.  Victor Espinoza was curious as he gave American Pharoah his head and let the colt slingshot around the far turn at Monmouth Park, a charming racetrack on the Jersey Shore. Espinoza peeked beneath one shoulder, glanced over the other, then narrowed his eyes between his colts ears and stared down the stretch.

title: Toward the Back of a Ship
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Ladies and gentlemen, I beg of you: We need to find David Steinberg a girlfriend. Somebody nice, who appreciates a young man who has a way with words. Because if you read his notes, they are infused with an ACHE and a LONGing that, frankly, are starting to make me weep. So if you have a lovely niece or daughter who is single and of college age, please let me know.

title: A Resurgent Didi Gregorius Helps the Yankees Pound the White Sox
description: CHICAGO  As the baseball season advances further into August, the Yankees surprising ascent to the top of the American League East can be primarily traced to the turn-back-the-clock performances of Alex Rodriguez and Mark Teixeira, an offense that has scored the most first-inning runs and a bullpen that is among the most reliable in the majors.

title: For Rohingya, Fear and Forced Marriages
description: As thousands of Rohingya women flee persecution and peril in Myanmar, many end up trapped by smugglers, vulnerable to exploitation and forced into prostitution and arranged marriages.

title: Dr. Donald L. Rasmussen, Crusader for Coal Miners Health, Dies at 87
description: Dr. Donald L. Rasmussen, who was lured to Appalachia as a fledgling physician by a help-wanted ad and set off a grass-roots movement that won benefits for coal miners afflicted with black lung disease, died on July 23 in Beckley, W.Va. He was 87.

title: Memphis Police Seek Man in Death of Officer
description: A suspect was being sought Sunday night in the killing of a Memphis police officer who was shot after he interrupted a drug deal the night before, the police said.

title: John Gibbons, 86, Clinton Science Aide, Dies; Pushed Cooperation in Space
description: John H. Gibbons, a physicist who argued for more efficient cars, a ban on nuclear tests and global cooperation in space while serving as a longtime science adviser to Congress and President Bill Clinton, died on July 18 at a retirement home in Crozet, Va. He was 86.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Aug. 3
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Tiger Beat Magazine Is Revived With a New Vision
description: Tiger Beat, the magazine whose flattering photographs of young pop stars and actors made it a favorite of teenage girls, has found its Prince Charming. A few of them, actually.

title: Jeb Bushs Camp Sees an Upside to Donald Trumps Surge in the G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  It may be the Summer of Trump, but the publicity-hungry real estate magnate is not the only Republican presidential candidate relishing all his attention.

title: New York City Starts Moving Tenants From Three-Quarter Homes, but Others Are Left Behind
description: The Sleep Inn in Brooklyn is newly built, featuring rooms with tasteful flower pictures, mini-refrigerators and fresh towels. Many of its first patrons have never stayed in such a nice place. One said he felt as if he was in the sitcom The Jeffersons, movin on up, as the shows theme song says. Another said it felt like the Trump Plaza.

title: Verbatim: Ted Cruzs Crystal Ball Reveals No Insight on Donald Trump
description: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, asked on Sunday at a Koch brothers conference in Dana Point, Calif., how he expects Donald Trump will fare in the first Republican primary debate on Thursday.

title: Bigger May Be Better for Health Insurers, but Doubts Remain for Consumers
description: Deals among the nations largest health insurers in recent weeks have been almost head-spinning. But whatever the details, if the combinations are finalized, the result will be an industry dominated by three colossal insurers.

title: Donald Trump Attacks as Republican Rivals Court Donors at Koch Retreat
description: As five of the 2016 Republican presidential candidates descended on an exclusive donor conference hosted by the oil-billionaire brothers Charles G. and David H. Koch, Donald J. Trump had a message for his rivals.

title: Israeli Justice in West Bank Is Seen as Often Uneven
description: JERUSALEM  The how-to manual in Hebrew reads like a chilling premonition.

title: Cool Influencers With Big Followings Get Picky About Their Endorsements
description: Ricky Dillon, 23, who is known for creating quirky online videos, has millions of followers on Instagram and Twitter. His YouTube channel has more than 2.5 million subscribers.

title: Ramu Tokashiki, a Japanese Rookie, Blossoms in the W.N.B.A.
description: UNCASVILLE, Conn.  The first English word the Japanese forward Ramu Tokashiki learned from her Seattle Storm teammates is unprintable here. Used in jest, it has become Tokashikis favorite saying. But another favorite English word is confidence, something she has built during her first W.N.B.A. season. Tokashiki has become one of the leagues best rookies and a blooming fan favorite, while hoping to change the perception of womens basketball in Japan.

title: Documents Reveal New York State Agencys Role in Adirondacks Mining Proposal
description: ALBANY  In 2013, New York voters were asked to consider an unusual constitutional amendment that could allow a private company, NYCO Minerals, to clear the middle of a forest in the Adirondack Mountains and create an open pit for mining.

title: Need a Reason to Celebrate? Check Online, Where Social Media Fills the Calendar
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Most Instagram users share their photos instantly. Leila Khan sometimes waits six weeks. That is how long she has held off on posting a photo of her eating a spoonful of watermelon.

title: Rohingya Women Flee Violence Only to Be Sold Into Marriage
description: GELUGOR, Malaysia  The young woman had been penned in a camp in the sweltering jungle of southern Thailand for two months when she was offered a deal.

title: New York Reaches Accords With Sellers of Toy Guns
description: In New York, toy guns must walk a fine line: Be convincing enough for a child, but not convincing enough for an adult.

title: Probation May Sound Light, but Punishments Can Land Hard
description: BALTIMORE  On Christmas Day in 2013, Donyelle Hall and her husband, Roland Jr., gave a party for friends and family at their apartment. Mrs. Hall, a nurses aide for the severely disabled, had recently taken a college course in medical terminology to improve her earning potential. Mr. Hall worked as a kitchen manager. The two had married the year before.

title: Year After Heartbreak, Happiness in the Stable and the Cradle
description: OCEANPORT, N.J.  It was late May, and a little more than a week stood between American Pharoah and his date with destiny in the Belmont Stakes. The morning media crush had dissipated at Bob Bafferts barn at Churchill Downs in Kentucky, where the colt, the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes champion, was free from the crowd already assembling at Belmont Park in New York.

title: Missing Below Ground (Amen)
description: Dear Diary:

title: Obama Policy Could Force Robust Climate Discussion From 2016 Candidates
description: WASHINGTON  The issue of climate change played almost no role in the 2012 presidential campaign. President Obama barely mentioned the topic, nor did the Republican nominee, Mitt Romney. It was not raised in a single presidential debate.

title: In a Sport of Beautiful Animals, Ugliness Is Unavoidable
description: OCEANPORT, N.J.  Outside the paddock before Sundays William Hill Haskell Invitational, the crowd angling for an up-close look at American Pharoah was, in some places, more than 20 people deep. The fans held their camera phones high. Some stood on their tiptoes, even if the reward was to catch just a glimpse of the colts shiny bay coat.

title: Onetime Allies Rajaratnam and Gupta Have Uneasy Prison Reunion After Insider Trading Trials
description: In their heyday, Raj Rajaratnam and Rajat K. Gupta were business partners who lent each other a helping hand.

title: Officials Seek Source of Legionnaires Outbreak in the Bronx
description: As the number of people sickened in an outbreak of Legionnaires disease in the South Bronx climbed to 71 on Sunday, health officials were still piecing together where the illness, a form of pneumonia spread through airborne water droplets, might have originated.

title: A Maryland Town Fires Its Black Police Chief, Exposing a Racial Rift
description: POCOMOKE CITY, Md.  Kelvin Sewell figured he had landed his dream job in 2010, when he retired as a Baltimore police officer to help run the tiny 16-member force in this little riverfront city, which calls itself the friendliest town on the Eastern Shore. A year later he became its first African-American police chief.

description: Read in Chinese |

title: Jen Welter Is Teaching Men, and Girls, as N.F.L.s First Female Coach
description: As the owner of a minor league indoor football team, Tommy Benizio is always looking for ways to draw fans to his arena, especially because he operates north of Dallas, home to more gold-plated alternatives like the Cowboys.

title: Shadow of Doping Is Never Far From Pool
description: KAZAN, Russia  The first autograph Katie Ledecky signed Sunday after winning the 400-meter freestyle by four seconds was on a piece of paper attached to a clipboard carried by a doping control agent.

title: Review: Summer Shorts at 59E59, With Love Letters and a Couch Potato
description: Stella (Colby Minifie), a young Southerner adrift in upstate New York, adopts an unusual pen pal. She worries he wont write back as hell be occupied with ordering people around, or eating lobster on silver plates or getting a massage, that kind of thing. But Kim Jong-il responds. He even sends an autographed photo.

title: Rolling Stone Appoints a New Managing Editor
description: Jason Fine, the editor of Mens Journal, will take over as the managing editor of Rolling Stone as part of what the magazines publisher, Jann S. Wenner, described as a shake-up.

title: New Jersey Transit Expects Big Bills for Offering Alternatives During Delays
description: New Jersey Transit has had a tough few weeks.

title: For Once, the Mets Arent Swooning, and Their Fans Are
description: This is usually when the Mets disappear on us, in spirit, if not in body. The season continues, but the hope dies. Other teams stay relevant while the Mets fade away, their story lines an afterthought to all but the die-hards.

title: Greeces Market Reopens, European Banks Report Results, and Tesla Announces Earnings
description: The Athens Stock Exchange reopened on Monday after a five-week closure that followed a decision by the Greek authorities to shut Greek banks and impose capital controls. The banks reopened two weeks ago, though restrictions on cash transactions remain in place to avert a run on the banks deposits. To prevent capital flight, a mass sell-off of holdings and a market crash, there is a cap on stock fluctuations and restrictions on local traders, though foreign investors will face no constraints when stock trading resumes. The reopening of Greeces market comes as government officials and representatives of the countrys international creditors enter a second week of difficult negotiations on a multibillion-euro bailout, Greeces third in five years. Niki Kitsantonis

title: Washington: First in War, Peace and, for What Its Worth, the N.L. East
description: The Washington Nationals completed a three-day swing through New York on Sunday, and for a team hoping to end one of the most phenomenal championship droughts in baseball history, this was not a happy visit.

title: Hillary Clinton to Start Airing Ads in Iowa and New Hampshire
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton will begin a $2 million television advertising buy in Iowa and New Hampshire on Tuesday, an effort that her campaign aides say is aimed at defining her candidacy ahead of a crush of Republican attack ads.

title: Huge Mexico City Rally Over Killing of Journalist
description: MEXICO CITY  A crowd of several thousand people gathered Sunday in the capital to denounce the death of a Mexican photographer killed early Saturday morning, the seventh journalist killed in Mexico this year.

title: Picky Eating in Children Linked to Anxiety, Depression and A.D.H.D.
description: For the last several months, my 3-year-old daughter Annika has been on a steady diet of waffles, yogurt sticks and milk. Before that, she ate mainly hot dogs and milk. And for many months before that, she ate almost nothing but fruit-and-yogurt squeezers and, you guessed it, milk. While I havent exactly been thrilled with her eating habits, I recognize that in life, and in parenting, we need to pick our battles. And the food battle is one I had chosen not to fight in full force. I had purposefully avoided putting too much pressure on Annika to eat a wider variety of foods because I thought that might backfire and make things worse. I also figured she would branch out eventually, as my older daughter had. But a new study, published in the journal Pediatrics, made me wonder if I should rethink my strategy.

title: Word of the Day | disabuse
description: disabuse  \dis--byz\  verb

title: With Ballpark Rocking, Mets Keep Rolling, Pulling Into a Tie for First
description: Lucas Duda watched the ball soar into the night, his mouth agape, listening as the Citi Field crowd reacted. The fans had shot out of their seats, throwing their arms up as if they were on a roller coaster. As the ball ricocheted off the facing of the second deck, they roared.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 10 A.M. (TMC) HAPPY-GO-LUCKY (2008) The irrepressible optimism of a 30-year-old London schoolteacher (Sally Hawkins, above) grates on those whose days shes intent on brightening up  among them, her driving instructor (Eddie Marsan), flamenco teacher (Karina Fernandez) and sister (Caroline Martin)  in this character study directed and written by Mike Leigh, which earned him an Oscar nomination for best original screenplay. Ms. Hawkinss portrayal is glorious, a gurgling, burbling stream of gasps, giggles and words, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Mr. Leigh has a documentarians eye for unadorned reality  his people and places look equally lived in  and his dialogue has the ebb and flow, the swells and eddies and logjams of ordinary conversation, she added. But the dramatist in Mr. Leigh is always hard at work, aligning his characters for maximum narrative effect and emotional pow.

description: Rian Dundon had to go back to high school for nine months last year. Mind you, he was already a working photojournalist. His assignment was to create a visual narrative for the Common Core, the educational initiative that has generated as much controversy as it has expectations.

description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Banco Bradesco of Brazil has agreed to buy all of HSBCs operations in the country for about 17.6 billion reais, or $5.2 billion, the companies said.

title: The Iran Deals Dangerous Precedent
description: HAD anyone believed President Obamas mantra that all options are on the table to deal with Irans nuclear weapons program, the Vienna agreement might have emerged less advantageously for Tehran. But no one took Mr. Obamas threat of military force seriously  a credibility gap that Israel still fears and Iran still exploits. Even so, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is still trying to reassure nervous Democrats in Congress that the Vienna agreement does not preclude Americas use of force.

title: A Health Care Safety Net the Public Loves
description: Recent public surveys show that Americans strongly support Medicare and Medicaid, the twin pillars of the health care safety net, and that approval of the Affordable Care Act, President Obamas health care reform law, is steadily rising. The popularity of these three government programs is a stiff warning to critics, mostly Republicans, who seek to radically change or demolish them.

title: Teenagers, Medication and Suicide
description: IS our culture of relentless achievement and success driving our young people to suicide? You would certainly think so, given the prevailing narrative in the media about the recent spate of suicides on college campuses: one high-achieving student after another succumbing to the toxic social pressure for perfection.

title: Indias Inverted Abortion Politics
description: IN America, many state governments have tried to curb abortion by placing severe restrictions on providers and clinics, purportedly for womens protection, despite opposition from the American Medical Association and other groups. If the limits are allowed to stand, self-induced abortions are expected to rise, leading to an escalation of health dangers to women, particularly those who cant afford to travel for help.

description: HONG KONG  Tujia, Chinas equivalent of the property-rental site Airbnb, has raised $300 million in its latest round of funding, valuing the start-up at more than $1 billion, the company said on Monday.

title: RBF Redux: Readers Discuss Facial Expressions
description: Last weeks article Im Not Mad. Thats Just My RBF, about the struggles associated with having a face that, when at ease, seems to others angry, irritated or simply expressionless, inspired over 2,200 comments on nytimes.com/styles and on Facebook. Readers shared their own experiences with being told to smile, wondered about RBFs cultural context and expressed frustration with the inherent sexism of such a term. Below are some of the highlights, edited for space.

title: HSBC Profit Falls 4% in Second Quarter as Bank Retrenches
description: LONDON  HSBC said on Monday that its second-quarter profit fell 4 percent from a year earlier as the bank overhauled its operations in an effort to cut up to $5 billion in annual costs by the end of 2017.

title: Patter and Patois
description: I am what you might call a grandchild of Louisiana. My father was born there as were many of his friends and relatives. Most of my neighbors in Los Angeles came from there too  black rural folk who had traveled west through southern Texas on their migration to escape the Souths heavy hail of racial hatred. They came to California for the tattered shelter of mocking freedom that the Golden State had to offer people like them, poor people willing to work hard.

title: Hillary Clinton Campaign Weighs Implications of Potential Joe Biden Challenge
description: For months, Hillary Rodham Clinton has been telling crowds, the news media, and anyone else who will listen that she always thought this would be a competitive race.

description: A group of researchers traveled to St. Lawrence Island in Alaska and withstood difficult conditions to study pollution caused by military sites from the Cold War days.

title: Cleaning Up a Legacy of Pollution on an Alaskan Island
description: ST. LAWRENCE ISLAND, Alaska  Americas Far North cherishes its image of wild purity in a landscape so vast it can sometimes seem barely touched by people. But the roughly 600 military installations across Alaska  some dating from World War II, others built during the Cold War  tell a different story, in polluted sites that were never fully cleaned up, and in the related health problems that have lingered and festered.

title: Stocks Plunge in Greece as Athens Exchange Reopens
description: ATHENS  Investors issued a vote of no confidence in Greeces economy on Monday, dumping stocks as trading on the Athens exchange resumed for the first time in five weeks.

description: Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Pregnancy Is the Best Time for Some Vaccines
description: On Dec. 20, 1968, I was in Minnesota for a family wedding and got the flu; what I didnt get, to my surprise, was my period. With a fever of 104 degrees, I was too sick to eat or even go to the bathroom unaided for 10 days. Returning to New York on Sunday night of New Years weekend, I was struggling to breathe and too weak to walk.

This week, the trail leads past one of its first significant markers, the initial Republican debate. But first

title: Dont Blame Medicaid for Rise in Health Care Spending
description: Health care spending growth has moderated in recent years, but its still putting tremendous strain on state and local governments. A recent analysis by The Pew Charitable Trusts revealed that it consumed 31 percent of state and local government revenue in 2013, nearly doubling from 1987.

title: Morning Agenda: Health Care Deals Raise Doubts for Consumers
description: HEALTH CARE DEALS RAISE DOUBTS FOR CONSUMERS | The recent frenzy of mergers among health insurers promised big savings, but not everyone is convinced that consumers will see that, Reed Abelson reports in The New York Times. The tie-up between Anthem and Cigna and the deal for Aetna to join its smaller rival Humana would create two behemoths. Along with UnitedHealthGroup, they would control nearly half of the American commercial health insurance market.

title: Saving Tunisia From ISIS
description: Who lost Tunisia? This question may well haunt future European leaders. As Herv Morin, a former French defense minister, recently warned, Europe  and France in particular  cannot afford to wait until the black flag of the Islamic State is hoisted above the presidential palace in Tunis.

title: Police in Calais Try to Deter Migrants
description: Some of the migrants trying to cross into Britain from the French coastal town said it was difficult to do so with the police deployed to prevent them gaining access to the Channel Tunnel.

title: The Migrant Crisis in Calais Exposes a Europe Without Ideas
description: Europe is caught between those who want to get in, those who want to get out, and those who want to destroy it. The incomers are desperate, the outbound are angry and the destroyers are brandishing flags.

title: Exor Triumphs in Battle for Bermuda Insurer PartnerRe
description: LONDON  The Italian investment company Exor said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire PartnerRe for $6.9 billion in cash, ending a months-long pursuit and a battle with Axis Capital Holdings for the Bermuda insurer.

description: How some United States presidents, past and present, and their families got away for summer relaxation and fun.

description: LONDON  The Irish drug maker Horizon Pharma said on Monday that it would seek a special shareholder meeting to replace the directors of Depomed, its smaller American rival, as it continued to pressure the company to engage in takeover talks.

description: As we face another week of hot weather across the country, cool down with a look at how some United States presidents, past and present, and their families got away for summer relaxation and fun.
