description: Apparently, where theres a will, theres a day.

title: Cap and Trade and Polarization
description: One of the most obvious facts about the U.S. political scene is also a fact most pundits refuse to acknowledge: the extreme polarization we now experience, the complete disappearance of any kind of political center, is not a two-sided phenomenon. Democrats havent moved drastically to the left  if anything they inched right for a couple of decades, and are only now shuffling slightly back toward a more robust liberalism. But Republicans have barreled off to the right.

title: When Will Fashion Discover Ronda Rousey?
description: For a sector that has suddenly discovered its love of all things athleisure (Tory Sport, anyone? Stella McCartney for Adidas? Kerings Sport & Lifestyle division?)  not to mention its love of all things celebrity  fashion has been extraordinarily slow to embrace female sports stars.

title: No Sanity Clause
description: Just in case you had any illusions about the state of US governance, and the sanity of the party that now controls Congress, the estimable Stan Collender now tells us that there is a better-than-even chance of a government shutdown this fall. And the issue that will bring us to the brink? Republican demands that we defund Planned Parenthood.

title: Report on Wall Street Consulting Firm
description: A New York regulator unearthed internal emails between Promontory Financial and the British bank Standard Chartered that call the firms independence into question.

title: New York Regulator Moves to Suspend Promontory Financial
description: The Promontory Financial Group occupies a position of trust in the global financial system, acting as a consultant to big banks, foreign nations and the Vatican. Its influence has soared over the years, positioning it as a sort of shadow regulator that provides government authorities with a window into bank misconduct. And the firms political ties run deep, thanks to its founder and chief executive, Eugene A. Ludwig, a former top banking regulator and a law school friend of Bill Clinton.

title: Crews in California Fight to Contain 21 Wildfires
description: National Guard forces dropped water along the edges of a raging wildfire over the weekend as more than 2,000 firefighters in Northern California tried to contain a blaze that has already scorched 60,000 acres.

title: Cleveland Orchestra Announces Andr Gremillet as Its Next Executive Director
description: Another major American orchestra has turned to Melbourne, Australia, for leadership: the Cleveland Orchestra announced Monday that its next executive director would be Andr Gremillet, who is currently the managing director of the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra.

title: Katie Ledecky Breaks World Record, Almost by Accident
description: KAZAN, Russia  Out of the water, Katie Ledecky does little to draw attention to herself. She dresses demurely, wears her hair in a relaxed bob and is quiet in a crowd, content to leave the performing to others. When she does talk, she speaks the way she writes: succinctly, with nary a run-on sentence.

title: Ex-Justice Dept. Officials Argue Against Federal Prosecutors in Supreme Court Brief
description: WASHINGTON  An extraordinary brief filed last week in the Supreme Court has put the Justice Department in an awkward spot.

title: Osama Bin Laden Raid May Be an Issue in a Joe Biden-Hillary Clinton Contest
description: With Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. deliberating on whether he will run for president, some of the differences between him and Hillary Rodham Clinton Clinton are sure to come into a sharper focus.

title: A Tribute to Bill Withers at Carnegie Hall
description: Bill Withers, who had indelible hits in the 1970s like Lean on Me, Aint No Sunshine and Use Me, has been a rare sight in public since his last album in 1985.

title: Searching for Signs of Lingering Pollution in Alaska
description: A group of researchers traveled to St. Lawrence Island in Alaska and withstood difficult conditions to study pollution caused by military sites from the Cold War days.

title: Garbage Collection, Without the Noise or the Smell
description: In New York, the sound of trash may be as familiar as its smell.

title: Former Citigroup and UBS Trader Convicted in Libor Case
description: LONDON  Tom Hayes, a former trader at Citigroup and UBS, was convicted Monday on eight counts of conspiring to manipulate a global benchmark interest rate known as Libor, bolstering efforts by prosecutors here to pursue financial wrongdoing.

title: 1890: Murder After Match Broken
description: St. Ouen is in a tremendous state of excitement over a murder in cold blood committed in the large colony of Italian workmen who inhabit that Suburb. For some time past a young Italian workman named Deborogo had been engaged to Virginia del Greco.

title: Millions in Premiers Accounts Didnt Come From State Fund,Malaysian Antigraft Body Says
description: HONG KONG  Malaysias anticorruption body said Monday that nearly $700 million deposited into accounts controlled by Prime Minister Najib Razak did not come from a government-owned development fund now under investigation.

title: As New York Rents Soar, Public Housing Becomes Lifelong Refuge
description: Esther Swan grew up in public housing, graduated from college and has thrived professionally, most recently as a talent director for an entertainment company.

title: In London: Food With a Heaping Side of Gimmick
description: In London, the most innovative new places to eat arent exactly putting their foodiest feet forward. Theres a hot tub restaurant, a packed eatery run by young tattooed twins that only serves cereal, a cocktail bar packed to the gills with Victorian artifacts and a cafe overrun, intentionally, by cats.

title: Footage of East New York Shooting
description: Surveillance video released by the New York Police Department shows gunmen opening fire at a party in East New York in the early hours of Sunday, injuring nine people.

title: Police Discuss Memphis Shooting
description: The Memphis police director, Toney Armstrong, said on Sunday that the person who killed a police officer who interrupted a drug deal was a coward.

title: American Pharoah Steers Clear of Route of Past Triple Crown Winners
description: American Pharoah won the Haskell Invitational with ease Sunday. He was a 1-9 favorite and is the reigning Triple Crown winner, so few were surprised. He may race two or three more times at the most, then he will be retired. Few are surprised by that decision either.

title: China Seeks Businessman Said to Have Fled to U.S., Further Straining Ties
description: LOOMIS, Calif.  China is demanding that the Obama administration return a wealthy and politically connected businessman who fled to the United States, according to several American officials familiar with the case. Should he seek political asylum, he could become one of the most damaging defectors in the history of the Peoples Republic.

title: Baby Name Change Could Reduce Hospital Errors
description: More than 80 percent of neonatal intensive-care units, or NICUs, use temporary first names for patients  Babygirl Jackson or Babyboy Goldsmith, for example  a convention that may lead to errors in prescribing medicines. A new study has found that a simple change in this procedure can significantly reduce such errors.

title: Review: Le Nozze Di Figaro Gets an Update in Salzburg
description: SALZBURG, Austria  For a director, conductor and cast, it must be intense pressure to present a new production of Mozarts Le Nozze di Figaro amid the high expectations of the Salzburg Festival here in the composers hometown. But, if those involved in this summers new Figaro are feeling burdened, it did not come through during Sunday afternoons performance, the second of seven, at the intimate Haus fr Mozart.

title: Kraft Recalls Some Cheese Products Over Choking Concerns
description: The Kraft Heinz Company has recalled some of its individually wrapped cheese products over concerns that the plastic packaging could stick to the slice after being removed and cause a potential choking hazard.

title: Joe Domanicks Blue Examines the L.A.P.D.
description: Being fired in New York and moving to Los Angeles is usually a smart career move. For William Bratton, the former New York City police commissioner under Mayor Rudy Giuliani, it was a no-brainer.

title: Kerry Speaks On Iran Deal in Qatar
description: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke on Monday in Doha, Qatar, about the Iran nuclear deal. Mr. Kerry traveled to the Middle East in an attempt to get the Arab states to endorse the accord.

title: Chilly at Work? Office Formula Was Devised for Men
description: Summers are hot in Omaha, where heat indexes can top 100 degrees. But Molly Mahannah is prepared.

title: A Day at the Haskell
description: Over 60,000 fans visited Monmouth Park on Sunday to enjoy a sunny day on the Jersey Shore and to see American Pharoah race for the first time since he won the Triple Crown.

title: Hannah Kirshner of Sweets & Bitters and Her Omelet Pan for the Backyard Bounty
description: Chickens were always my thing, said Hannah Kirshner, the founder and editor of Sweets & Bitters, a hybrid magazine-cookbook the size of a personal diary. And once people know that.

title: John Kerry Wins Gulf States Cautious Support for Iran Deal
description: DOHA, Qatar  Persian Gulf monarchies issued a cautious endorsement on Monday of the accord Secretary of State John Kerry negotiated last month to constrain Irans nuclear program.

title: Roger Viviers Summer Capsule Collection, a Recipe App with Playlists and a Pinterest Inspired by Jealousy
description: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

title: John Horton Conway, the Genius at Play
On the Heat Beat
description: How best to illustrate an impending snowfall or heat wave? The question arises at least once a year in most newsrooms, before a very snowy or a very hot day, and is usually met with a collective groan. Year after year, it gets tougher to come up with new ways to dramatize the story.

title: Whats Your Greatest GIF Moment?
description: You text, you email, you tweet. We want to know how you use GIFs to communicate.

title: The Challenges of Fighting Money Laundering
description: The Watergate credo to follow the money is the reason for a number of laws that require banks, credit unions and money-transmission businesses to keep track of who their customers are and report suspicious transactions. These financial firms are the first line of defense against money laundering, and recent cases highlight just how difficult it is for the government to police the tidal waves of cash that wash through the banking system.

title: Trend of New York Gun Violence Has Flattened Out, Police Statistics Show
description: Despite a wild burst of gunfire that wounded nine people at a party in Brooklyn over the weekend, the number of shootings across New York City was sharply lower last week compared with the same week in 2014, bringing the city effectively even with last year in total amount of gunfire.

title: For Mobile Messaging, GIFs Prove to Be Worth at Least a Thousand Words
description: Lucy Dikeou, a 21-year-old senior at Stanford University, has long used English and the pictorial images known as emoji to text on her iPhone. A few months ago, she started messaging in a third language: GIFs.

title: Jason Pierre-Paul Is Talk of Giants Training Camp. And He Isnt Even There.
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Every day since Giants training camp opened last week, the team has printed a roster of players by number, which includes this line: No. 90, Pierre-Paul, Jason, DE, 6 feet 5, 278 pounds.

title: Celebrating Basque Heritage in Idaho
description: A Basque street party called Jaialdi takes over downtown Boise, celebrating the legacy of Basque immigrants who mostly came as shepherds in the early 20th century.

title: 1965: Draft Call Is Biggest Since 1951
description: WASHINGTON  The Defense Department, carrying out President Johnsons military manpower demands, today ordered the highest draft quotas since the Korean war. The new figures were 27,400 for September, all for the Army, and 33,600 men for October, including 4,600 for the Navy. The original draft call for September was 17,000. The September and October quotas were the highest since 80,000 youths were called in March of 1951.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 4, 1965

title: Auto Sales Jumped in July; G.M. and Fiat Chrysler Were Up 6%
description: The auto industry began the second half of the year with a jolt that totaled more than 1.5 million vehicles sold in July, a 5.3 percent increase from the previous year.

title: First Came Summer Camp Marriage, Then Came a More Mature Love
description: They met when they were 17 and 19 years old, and a week later, they were married  in a play.

title: Who Gets Into the Republican Debate: Rounding Could Decide
description: This article has been updated. Read the new version here.

title: I Am Cait Episode 2 Recap: You Know Nothing, Caitlyn Jenner
description: Season 1, Episode 2: The Road Trip: Part 1

title: Summery, Sweet-Smelling Hair Perfumes
description: During the summer, its tempting to skip the shampoo and go an extra day (or two) without washing ones hair. But to keep it smelling fresh, theres hair perfume: small, portable bottles that protect and hydrate hair while serving up a dose of white rose or gardenia. Here, a mix of recent launches and classics.

title: What Is Our Attention Really Worth?
description: Pay attention!

title: The Internet of Things and the Future of Farming
description: The Internet of Things  the vision of a world brimming with communicating sensors and digital smarts  occupies the peak of Gartners most recent hype cycle. And a report released two months ago by the McKinsey Global Institute laid out the potential multitrillion-dollar payoff from the emerging technology.

title: Investment Consortium Buys Germanys Tank & Rast
description: LONDON  A group of investors led by the private equity arm of German insurer Allianz agreed to acquire Autobahn Tank & Rast Holding, the German motorway service area operator, its owners said on Monday.

title: Alpha Natural Resources, a Onetime Coal Giant, Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: Alpha Natural Resources, once a powerhouse of the American coal industry, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Monday so it may emerge from the grip of a $3 billion debt at a time when utilities are switching to natural gas and coal prices are plummeting.

title: Theory on Lithium in Stars May Be Confirmed
description: Astronomers believe that the metal lithium was created during the Big Bang 13.8 billion years ago. Yet old stars often have less lithium than might be expected, while young stars seem to have much more. Some scientists have speculated the source of extra lithium in young stars may be stellar explosions, or novae, expelling matter into space. Now lithium has been found in material ejected by the younger star Nova Centauri 2013, which may confirm the theory. The observation was made by telescopes at La Silla Observatory, the European Southern Observatorys site in Chile, and at the Observatory of the Pontificia Universidad Catolica de Chile near Santiago.

title: India Blocks 857 Pornography Websites, Defying Supreme Court Decision
description: NEW DELHI  Without warning or explanation, the Indian government this weekend ordered Internet service providers to block access to 857 pornography websites that had been singled out by an anti-pornography activist.

title: Dispense With the Jokes Now: Pez Candy Gets Its Own Film
description: In what could be viewed as a sign (but almost certainly isnt) that the era of toy-themed movies is nearing its end, a Hollywood production company announced Monday that it would be making a film about Pez.

title: Miscelanea NY Brings Mexico to Manhattan
description: Guillaume Guevara considered his options. A restaurant? New York had enough Mexican places. But a market selling chiles, Oaxaca cheese, masa and Mexican sweets may make a difference, he thought. There could be some takeout food, but definitely not more tacos. What was needed, he believed, were tortas (sandwiches), like egg and chorizo. His inventory also tempts with jams infused with tequila and mezcal; paletas (ice pops) from Fany Gerson; coffee; and less common Mexican items like sweet maguey syrup and Mayan clay (for cosmetic use). He also sells lime presses, cookbooks and personal-care products from Mexico. And if he suggests iced coffee with the rice-milk drink horchata, take him up on it, especially when the sidewalk is steaming: Miscelanea NY, 63 East Fourth Street (Bowery), 212-253-0277, miscelaneany.com.

title: British Government to Begin Partial Sale of R.B.S. Stake
description: LONDON  The British government said on Monday that it would sell a 5.2 percent stake in Royal Bank of Scotland, its first sale since the bank received a huge bailout seven years ago.

title: Soylent Announces New Version of Its Nutrition Drink
description: The makers of Soylent, the powdered drink that has developed a following in Silicon Valley as an easy meal replacement for busy workers, has created a follow-up version called Soylent 2.0.

title: Collegiate Chorale, Under a New Name, Is Teaming Up With City Center
description: The Collegiate Chorale, which was founded in 1941 by the conductor Robert Shaw, announced Monday that it was changing its name to MasterVoices and beginning a new partnership with City Center to give concert performances there of operas and operettas in English.

title: John Kerry Abroad, Malaysia Airlines Investigation and Hiroshima Anniversary
description: Whats going to generate headlines this week in international news? Were experimenting with offering readers a tip sheet. Let us know if you find it useful or what youd like to see here. Contact hanna.ingber@nytimes.com.

title: Massive Sandstorm Hits Jordans Capital
description: Flights were disrupted in Amman, Jordan, on Sunday after the city was hit by a sandstorm and strong winds.

title: Womans Death in Mount Vernon, N.Y., Holding Cell Will Be Investigated by State Attorney General
description: The New York State attorney generals office said on Monday that it would investigate the death of a woman who was found dead in a holding cell in Mount Vernon after she was arrested on shoplifting charges and then fell ill.

title: Jeb Bushs Note to His Brother, the President, About BBQ and Tax Cuts
description: It was playful banter between brothers. But these were not just any brothers  and the subject of the joke was not garden variety humor. It was federal taxes.

title: Live and Kicking: Games to Watch This Week
description: The long international soccer nightmare that is the 10-week Premier League summer break ends this weekend with 10 games. Schedule accordingly.

title: Wild Uganda Chimpanzees Using Clay as Food
description: Wild chimpanzees in Uganda have begun eating clay, which furnishes dietary minerals to them, a new study reports.

title: The Promise and Limits of Obamas Clean Power Plan for Limiting Global Warming
description: Over the weekend, in a Memo to America and lots of details released to the press, President Obama set the stage for todays release of the Environmental Protection Agencys final Clean Power Plan, aimed at meeting the administrationspledgesto reducecarbon dioxide emissions.

title: After Killing of Cecil the Lion, Delta Joins Airline Ban on Game Trophies
description: The recent killing of a popular lion named Cecil by an American dentist in Zimbabwe sparked considerable outrage on social media and elsewhere against safari hunting. The event has also brought to light the role that airlines play in transporting trophy kills as cargo, and may have contributed to changing airline policy.

title: If You Were the Boss, Would You Raise the Minimum Salary to $70,000?
description: Three months ago, Dan Price, the chief executive of Gravity Payments, a credit card processing company, decided to raise the salary of his lowest paid workers to $70,000. Almost overnight, he represented a swashbuckling blow against income inequality. He also drew no small amount of criticism.

title: A Baseball Habit Begins to Feel the Pinch
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Most days he is at work at AT&T Park here, Giants pitcher Madison Bumgarner can be seen with a clump of smokeless tobacco lodged in his lower lip. Bumgarner, a World Series hero and the face of the team, grew up in small-town North Carolina, where, he said, nearly all men dipped. He has been doing it since he was in fifth grade.

title: British Police to Review Sex Abuse Claims Against Ex-Premier Edward Heath
description: LONDON  Britains independent police watchdog agency said on Monday that it would investigate an allegation that the police in Wiltshire had dropped a criminal investigation in the 1990s when the subject threatened to go public with accusations that the former Conservative prime minister Edward Heath had sexually abused children.

title: Canopies and Umbrellas, Gifts That Shelter the Glowing Couple
description: The gift of protection for newlyweds who love the sun, from a funky canopy to a high-tech umbrella.

title: Gwyneth Paltrows Beachy Floral Dress
description: The Star: Gwyneth PaltrowThe Moment: Paddle & Party for Pink Charity Event on August 1.

title: Chris Christie Softens Tone on Minimum Wage Increases
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has ardently opposed raising the minimum wage in New Jersey, but on Monday he hinted that his opposition might not be absolute.

title: Obama Takes a Crucial Step on Climate Change
description: President Obamas Clean Power Plan has rightly been hailed as the most important action any president has taken to address the climate crisis.

title: Al Sharpton Accepts Apology From Donald Trump Aide Who Was Fired Over Racial Posts
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton is known for his fiery oratory and excoriating those who cross him.

title: Jury Rejects Mental Illness Argument for James Holmes in Aurora Theater Rampage
description: DENVER  A Colorado jury on Monday moved an important step closer to sentencing James E. Holmes to death for carrying out a massacre inside a suburban movie theater in July 2012, rejecting defense arguments that his mental illness should remove the death penalty from consideration as a potential punishment.

title: Cranes Collapse on Houses in Netherlands
description: Emergency rescue crews inspected on Monday the area where two cranes carrying a bridge segment collapsed onto houses and stores in a central Dutch town.

title: Obama Unveils Plan on Climate Change
description: The president formally unveiled on Monday his administrations plan to cut future carbon emissions from power plants.

title: Effects of Solitary Confinement
description: Inmates at Pelican Bay State Prison discuss the detrimental effects of long-term solitary confinement.

title: Solitary Confinement: Punished for Life
description: In 1993, Craig Haney, a social psychologist, interviewed a group of inmates in solitary confinement at Pelican Bay State Prison, Californias toughest penal institution.

title: Jill Scott Tops Chart With Woman
description: Jill Scotts latest album, Woman, has opened at the top of the Billboard chart in a slow week of music sales.

title: Travel Diary
description: Richard Christiansen and Vanessa Holden share images from Marrakesh, the first stop in their three-week trip around the world.

title: Do Israelis Still Care About Justice?
description: TEL AVIV  This isnt everyone, my son said Saturday as we stood on the steps of the Tel Aviv City Hall, in Rabin Square. There are more people coming, right?

title: Flooding and a Landslide Kill Dozens Amid India Monsoons
description: NEW DELHI  At least 73 people have died in India since Friday amid flooding and a landslide linked to heavy rains in two states in the countrys east, disaster management officials said.

title: Good Timing for Britain to Shed Its R.B.S. Stake
description: Britain shouldnt obsess about losing money on its Royal Bank of Scotland stake. George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer, is about to get cracking on reducing the governments 79 percent holding, which will mean a short-term loss on the 46 billion pounds handed over by taxpayers in 2008 and 2009. That hit needs to be put into perspective.

title: Pentagon Chief Ashton Carter Adds Secretary of Reassurance to His Portfolio
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas defense secretary, Ashton B. Carter, has become the secretary of reassurance.

title: Move to Fight Obamas Climate Plan Started Early
description: WASHINGTON  In the early months of 2014, a group of about 30 corporate lawyers, coal lobbyists and Republican political strategists began meeting regularly in the headquarters of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, often, according to some of the participants, in a conference room overlooking the White House. Their task was to start devising a legal strategy for dismantling the climate change regulations they feared were coming from President Obama.

title: Chuck and Amy Schumer Team Up to Fight Gun Violence
description: The poster evoked a family law practice, or perhaps an Off Broadway act, announcing the gatherings hosts inside the overstuffed Midtown office of New Yorks senior senator.

title: Puerto Rico Defaults on Bond Payment
description: Puerto Rico defaulted on a $58 million bond payment on Monday, a risky move that seemed to intensify the pressure on creditors for broader debt renegotiation, but might also make future borrowing far more difficult.

title: Effective Ovarian Cancer Treatment Is Underused, Study Finds
description: In 2006, the National Cancer Institute took the rare step of issuing a clinical announcement, a special alert it holds in reserve for advances so important that they should change medical practice.

title: Review: China Mivilles Three Moments of an Explosion
description: Even when he is orbiting somewhere in a galaxy too far away for normal human comprehension, the genre-subverting English novelist China Miville is dazzling. His latest collection of short stories, Three Moments of an Explosion, crowds virtuosity into every sentence.

title: Wylie Dufresne Is Closing Alder
description: The innovative chef Wylie Dufresne will close his bistro, Alder, in the East Village, at the end of the month. The restaurant confirmed the news, which Mr. Dufresne announced in a message on Twitter that added, The search for a new home begins. He did not give a reason for the closing and has not returned calls.

title: Dr. Forrest Bird, Inventor of Medical Respirators and Ventilators, Dies at 94
description: Dr. Forrest M. Bird, an eccentric aviator and inventor who studied high-altitude breathing problems of World War II pilots and later created medical devices that saved lives and aided thousands of people with respiratory ailments, died on Sunday at his home in Sagle, Idaho. He was 94.

title: Schumers Launch Push For Gun Control
description: The comedian Amy Schumer is teaming up with her cousin Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York, to push for new legislation limiting gun access for the mentally ill.

title: Judge Delays Retrial in Etan Patz Case Until Feb. 22
description: A judge on Monday delayed the retrial of a man accused of murdering Etan Patz until Feb. 22 to give a newly appointed prosecutor more time to prepare in one of the countrys most infamous child-abduction cases.

title: Hedwig Takes a Dip With Taye Diggs in Title Role
description: Taye Diggs is off to a wobbly start in his new heels.

title: Behind the Scenes of Copwatch
description: Following the unrest in Baltimore after Freddie Grays death, I found myself inside the Gilmor Homes housing project there, listening to three men in an impromptu rap battle.

title: Gawker Discloses Donald Trumps Cellphone Number
description: Donald J. Trump was trumped.

title: A Comedy Family in Myanmar
description: With private shows, comics in Myanmar try to avoid crackdowns.

title: Expert Panel Withholds Support for Early Autism Screening
description: For years experts have urged physicians to screen infants and toddlers for autism in order to begin treatment as early as possible. But now an influential panel of experts has concluded there is not enough evidence to recommend universal autism screening of young children.

title: Review: In Dear Evan Hansen, Teenage Angst Grows Complicated
description: WASHINGTON  The quirks of fate prove both kind and cruel in Dear Evan Hansen, a sweet, sad and quite moving new musical making its premiere here at Arena Stage. The title character, a friendless teenager crippled by the depression that only being a friendless teenager can bring, is caught up in the whiplash of web fame when a note he wrote finds its way into the hands of another troubled kid, with complicated consequences.

title: Hillary Clinton to Appear on Al Sharptons Radio Show
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton will appear on the Rev. Al Sharptons syndicated radio show on Thursday, the 50th anniversary of the Voting Rights Act and the day of the first widely broadcast Republican debate.

title: 5 Questions About Puerto Ricos Debt Troubles
description: Q. How does Puerto Rico compare to Greece?

title: The Flip Side of Optimism About Life on Other Planets
description: If you dream of close encounters of the alien kind, this has been a hopeful summer.

title: Scene City: Surfing for a Hamptons Party
description: Lena Dunham, Gwyneth Paltrow, Laird Hamilton and others at annual Hamptons Paddle & Party for Pink.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
description: Russia and More  Pictures of the Day

title: German Officials Suspend Treason Inquiry of Bloggers, but Public Still Seethes
description: BERLIN  Not since the reunification has Germany raised serious allegations of treason against a journalist, so it shocked many here when two leading digital rights bloggers found themselves under official investigation on that charge for publishing secret government documents.

title: Review: In Freight, a Black Man Follows the Script for Five Incarnations
description: Abel Green arrives out of breath from running for the train. It is the 1910s, and he is an actor hopping a boxcar on his way to a minstrel show. But performing is something hes done since long before he ever was paid for it.

title: To Some, Beijing Olympics Song Is Suspiciously Similar to Ballad From Disneys Frozen
description: BEIJING  China lacks enough snow for the 2022 Winter Olympic Games, environmentalists said. China is too repressive to hold the Games, detaining hundreds of lawyers just in the past month, rights campaigners said. On Friday, despite those complaints, the International Olympic Committee awarded the Games to Beijing.

title: August 3, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Russia, Libya, Macedonia and Afghanistan.

title: Richard Christiansen and Vanessa Holdens Trip to Morocco
description: Richard Christiansen, the founder of Chandelier Creative and Vanessa Holden, former senior vice president of West Elm, document their three-week trip around the world searching for creative inspiration exclusively for T.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Drenchcam
description: A TV reporter, up close and personal with flooding.

title: Playing House Begins Its Second Season a Little More Grown-Up
description: The USA comedy Playing House lived to see a second season only after an extended lobbying effort by its few but vocal fans. With that season beginning on Tuesday night, the almost 100 percent of Americans who didnt get on board for Season 1 need to ask themselves: Should they give the show a second chance?

title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: What Yahoo Paid for Polyvore: More Than $200 Million
description: It has been some time since Marissa Mayer, chief executive of Yahoo, has spent big to add a promising start-up to her companys portfolio. On Friday, she broke out the checkbook.

title: An Extraordinary Humpback Whale Sighting in Alaska
description: The whale, whom the researchers named Old Timer, was first seen in Lynn Canal in southeast Alaska. It is the longest string of sightings of a humpback.

title: Fragile Burundi Casts a Wary Eye on Rwanda
description: KIGALI, Rwanda  Burundi and Rwanda can seem deceptively like conjoined twins. They share a common history, geography and language, and their populations are divided ethnically between Hutu and Tutsi. Both were devastated by some of the worst mass slaughter of the 20th century.

title: Boston Symphony Extends Andris Nelsonss Contract Through 2022
description: LENOX, Mass.  The honeymoon was a success, and the flirtation with a would-be home wrecker from overseas ended without infidelity, so now they are renewing their vows: The Boston Symphony Orchestra  said on Monday that it had extended Andris Nelsonss contract as its music director through 2022.

title: Review: Carl Safinas Beyond Words Doesnt Mince Any on Animal Abilities
description: Given the subtitle of Carl Safinas fascinating and expansive new book, Beyond Words: What Animals Think and Feel, its no surprise that Dr. Safina frequently discusses animal cognition.

title: Great Men (Mostly) Through History
description: Making composite portraits of national leaders  layering dozens of them, sometimes, into a single frame  one photographer explored the aesthetic of power and sameness.

title: Bobby Jones Gospel and Its Strongest Voice Prepare to Say Farewell
description: WASHINGTON  Some folks skipped church on Sunday in hopes of getting to BETs headquarters here in time for the final taping of Bobby Jones Gospel. Many were turned away, though, as the studios chairs runneth over, filled with gospel stars who trace their careers back to their debuts on the show and retired network executives who did not want to miss the chance to say goodbye to a legend.

title: Review: The Dreamer Examines His Pillow Talks of Love, Lust and Lots More
description: In its current revival by the Attic Theater Company, The Dreamer Examines His Pillow,an early John Patrick Shanley work, is an intermissionless 90 minutes, but its really a play in three parts. From the audiences perspective this particular productions three parts are: Not buying it, Just got more interesting and, Ah, now it all makes sense.

title: Review: Nao Zumbi Returns to Central Park SummerStage
description: A great band can sound even better when propelled by a great thesis: an endlessly renewable idea big enough to encompass music, history, philosophy, politics and the daily grind.

title: A Fencer Strives to Crack a Saber Ceiling
description: Daryl Homer secured his spot in United States fencing history last month by becoming the first American man to claim a medal in saber fencing at the world championships, winning silver in Moscow. But for a broader scope of the legacy he has been building, look no further than his home fencing club in Midtown Manhattan.

title: The Little Orchestra Society Limits Schedule and Aims for Younger Audience
description: The Little Orchestra Society is getting littler, at least for now.

title: In Case You Missed It: Julys Top Real Estate Stories
description: Catch up on the most popular stories of the month.

title: Yankees Pitching Prospect Luis Severino Draws Raves Before Debut Against Red Sox
description: CHICAGO  When Dellin Betances was at the Yankees minor league complex in Tampa, Fla., at the end of the 2012 minor league season preparing to head to the instructional league, there were about 20 young pitching prospects working out.

title: Toy Guns Can Be Dangerous, for Real
description: A toy gun is supposed to look like a toy  not a gun. In New York, it cannot be black, blue or silver. It should have bright neon colors in New York City, and a strip of orange around the barrel in the state. Thats the law. Yet, the office of New Yorks Attorney General Eric Schneiderman found that retailers had sold more than 6,400 toy guns to New York families in the last three years that looked all too real.

title: Vigilante Effort After a Childs Death Underlines Stark Change in West Bank
description: DUMA, West Bank  Early one recent morning, a few residents of this sleepy hilltop hamlet heard that Jewish settlers were hurling rocks at a house. Almost instantly they started posting messages on Facebook, rousing neighbors  then somebodys brother called a friend, who called his cousin, who called the Muslim preacher, who rushed to the mosque, flicked on a megaphone rigged to the minaret and shouted:

title: Runway Report
description: The white button-down shirt.

title: The Moon, Going Through a Phase
description: Is there such a thing as a half moon?

title: Review: Turandot and Les Contes dHoffmann, Spectacle and Substance at Bregenz Festival
description: BREGENZ, Austria  Opera at its best has always been spectacle with a brain. And nowhere is that marriage of seriousness and showmanship pursued more openly than at the Bregenz Festival.

title: Review: Heritage Sunday and Ache: Lavagem da Rua Maintain Culture Through Dance
description: Lets hear it for Congress!

title: Garbage In, Garbage Out, Garbage Around
description: O.K., so the compromise is small in the global scheme of things. It is not a two-state solution and it does not involve the sovereignty of tiny islands claimed by China and Japan. But it does loom hugely for citizens of the Upper East Side of Manhattan, where conflicts over land use can  and do  take on geopolitical proportions and urgency.

title: Pimco May Face S.E.C. Action Over a Fund
description: A Pimco exchange-traded bond fund that once tracked the performance of a much larger fund formerly managed by the firms co-founder, William H. Gross, may have violated federal securities laws.

title: Legionnaires Disease Death Toll in Bronx Rises to 7
description: An outbreak of Legionnaires disease in the South Bronx has claimed three more lives, bringing the death toll to seven, New York City officials said on Monday amid calls for tighter regulation of water-cooling towers, which are thought to be the origin of the illness.

title: Planned Parenthood Is Defended as Senate Democrats Block Bill to End Funding
description: WASHINGTON  As president of Planned Parenthood, Cecile Richards tries to keep perspective while the group faces one of its biggest political crises. After all, she said on Monday, the founder, Margaret Sanger, was arrested 99 years ago for pamphleteering about birth control.

title: Richard S. Schweiker, Former Senator and Reagan Confidant, Dies at 89
description: Richard S. Schweiker, a former United States representative and senator from Pennsylvania who was the secretary of health and human services during the first term of President Ronald Reagan, died on Friday in Pomona, N.J. He was 89.

title: Bodegas Declining in Manhattan as Rents Rise and Chains Grow
description: Jos Alvarrado saved for more than a decade to buy 3 Brothers Mini Market, a bodega at 169th Street and Audubon Avenue.

title: Hitchhiking Robot, Safe in Several Countries, Meets Its End in Philadelphia
description: After an international adventure that included spending a week with a heavy metal band, cruising through the canals of Amsterdam and participating in a wave at a Boston Red Sox game, a hitchhiking robot met a brutal demise in a Philadelphia alley on Saturday. It was 1 year old.

title: The Failed Attack on Planned Parenthood
description: Senate Republicans latest ploy to choke off all federal funding to Planned Parenthood failed, as expected, on Monday afternoon in a 53-46 procedural vote. The measure fell short of the 60 votes needed to move it forward.

title: Trans-Pacific Partnership Session Ends With Heels Dug In
description: WASHINGTON  Tokyo was ready to extend major concessions on American truck tariffs but was blocked by Mexico, which wanted less competition for its own trucks in the United States market.

title: Trial Opens for Charlotte Officer Who Fatally Shot Black Motorist Seeking Help
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  A Charlotte police officer fired eight shots at the fallen body of an unarmed former college football player who had knocked on the door of a house in an unfamiliar neighborhood seeking help after a car crash, a prosecutor said in opening arguments Monday in the trial of Officer Randall Kerrick on voluntary manslaughter charges.

title: Obama Administration Urges States to Cut Health Insurers Requests for Big Rate Increases
description: WASHINGTON  Hoping to avoid another political uproar over the Affordable Care Act, the Obama administration is trying to persuade states to cut back big rate increases requested by many health insurance companies for 2016.

title: Suspect in Memphis Police Officers Death Turns Himself In
description: An ex-convict wanted in Tennessee for the murder of a Memphis police officer turned himself in to the authorities on Monday, law enforcement officials said.

title: United Nations Members Establish 15-Year Global Development Agenda
description: In what the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, described Monday as the organizations to-do list for the next 15 years, its 193 member states have agreed on an agenda for global development that aims to eliminate poverty and hunger, protect the environment from climate change, achieve gender equality and raise living standards. The agreement, known as the  2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, was finalized over the weekend after negotiations that began a few years ago. It will be formally adopted at a United Nations summit meeting next month. The agenda supersedes and broadens the eight Millennium Development Goals set in 2000, which Mr. Ban has credited with helping to raise more than one billion people out of abject poverty.

title: Kentucky Officer Handcuffs Third Grader
description: The video released by the A.C.L.U. shows a deputy sheriff in Kentucky handcuffing a third grader to a chair. An A.C.L.U. lawyer said the handcuffing was traumatizing, and in this case illegal.

title: A.C.L.U. Sues Over Handcuffing of Boy, 8, and Girl, 9, in Kentucky School
description: WASHINGTON  The American Civil Liberties Union, seeking to spotlight the use of handcuffs to restrain young children who act out in school, filed a federal lawsuit in Covington, Ky., on Monday alleging that a school resource officer there shackled an 8-year-old boy and a 9-year-old girl, both with disabilities, causing the children pain, fear and emotional trauma.

title: A Climate Plan Businesses Can Like
description: WITH the release of President Obamas Clean Power Plan, a flood of legal challenges will begin. Already, opponents have denounced the new rule limiting carbon pollution as unconstitutional. Behind the rattling sabers, however, theres a quieter story worth noticing. Many big players in the electric power industry will gain more with the rule in place than if the courts strike it down.

title: New Polls Show Donald Trump Widening His Lead and John Kasich Holding His Own
description: Less than 24 hours before the candidates deadline to qualify for Fox Newss debate, two polls released on Monday show Donald J. Trump with a statistically significant lead over the rest of the field and Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio squeaking into the top ten.

title: Securities Fraud Charges Bring Texas Attorney General, Ken Paxton, to County Jail
description: McKINNEY, Tex.  Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general, was arrested on felony charges Monday and booked at the county jail in this Dallas suburb after a grand jury indicted him last week for securities fraud, the start of a criminal case that could complicate and even jeopardize his tenure as the states top lawyer.

title: Syria: U.S. Sets New Sanctions
description: The United States sought to broaden its economic pressure on Syrias government on Monday, imposing sanctions on a far-flung network of seven overseas companies and four individuals for actions to evade American and European Union restrictions on fuel imports. The Treasury Departments Office of Foreign Assets Control, which oversees enforcement of American sanctions, said seven commercial ships owned or controlled by one of the newly penalized companies had been blocked by its action, cutting off a potential source of fuel to President Bashar al-Assads military. The affected companies operated in Syria, the United Arab Emirates, Turkey, Lebanon, Panama, St. Kitts and Nevis and the Marshall Islands, the Treasury said in a statement, asserting that many of these entities are front companies that the government of Syria and its supporters have used in an attempt to evade U.S. and E.U. sanctions. Any sanctioned individuals and entities risk seizure of assets under American jurisdiction, and are barred from commercial dealings with the United States.

title: Vincent Marotta Sr., a Creator of Mr. Coffee, Dies at 91
description: Vincent Marotta Sr., who as a creator of the Mr. Coffee machine helped send the percolator the way of the one-horse shay, died on Saturday at his home in Pepper Pike, Ohio. He was 91.

title: David Price Electrifies Torontos Fans With Debut for Blue Jays

title: Shiri Appleby and Constance Zimmer on the UnREAL Season Finale
description: The first season of Lifetimes UnREAL, a drama that takes place behind the scenes of a Bachelor-like show, has tackled bulimia, domestic violence, suicide, mental illness, blackmail and the grimy aspects of how reality television sausage gets made. But even with all that darkness, it still found a way to shock in its first season finale.

title: Christie Proposes Raising Retirement Age
description: The New Jersey governor and Republican presidential candidate proposed increasing the retirement age by two years over the next quarter-century.

title: A Refreshing Cocktail Recipe, Featuring Icelands Newest Export
description: Ever since I had come back from London, I have always been looking for how I could get this stuff, says barman Matt Piacentini. Its a sentiment that has continuously informed choices for his bars, from Clyde Common in Downtown Portland to his latest venture, the Up & Up, on New Yorks Macdougal Street. This stuff is Piacentinis shorthand for the goods he found easily accessible back in Europe that he wants to bring stateside: everything from William Morris wallpapers and Italian amari to Scandinavian aquavit.

title: One-Thing Shops: Herbs in Athens
description: Among a generation of young Greeks scattered around the more prosperous cities of Europe, Evangelia Koutsovoulou is an anomaly: an migr who last year returned to Athens with opportunity on her mind. The sage- and mint-perfumed islands of her Mediterranean homeland are rich in herbs, unchanged and mostly uncultivated since ancient times with a world of unique flavors not found elsewhere, even in her adopted country of Italy. Greek herbs were something very special but no one else had paid any attention to them, says the former journalist, who opened her tiny headquarters below the Acropolis in the midst of the countrys economic crisis and created Daphnis and Chloe, a brand of wild-bred culinary herbs named after a second-century Greek tale of predestined love.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 11:40 A.M. (Starz) WHIPLASH (2014) Andrew (Miles Teller), an aspiring jazz drummer at a highly selective Manhattan music school, falls in thrall to Fletcher (J. K. Simmons, in an Oscar-winning portrayal), a charismatic and terrifying instructor whose teaching methods include browbeating, humiliation and cymbal throwing in this second feature from Damien Chazelle. And a blood bath, literal and figurative, ensues. For all its dexterity and assurance, the movie has its share of false notes and rhythmic stumbles, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. A few plot twists test the limits of credibility. And there is something a little dispiriting  if sadly unsurprising  about the way Mr. Chazelle turns a historically African-American art form into the existential arena for a couple of white guys. Still, he added, the battle of master and disciple is exciting and terrifying to witness, and, at its best, the film can feel as wild and spontaneous, as risky and precise, as a live jam session.

Or something like that. Carlyle had his contemporary critics, of course, but confronted with images from Portraits of Power, a fine art photo project by Alejandro Almaraz, he might have reconsidered his theory.

Trump has been schooling us for some time, but the Iran nuclear deal has touched off a new race to the bottom. Mike Huckabee said the agreement with Iran would take the Israelis and march them to the door of the oven. Ted Cruz called the Obama administration the worlds leading financier of radical Islamic terrorism. Lets not even get started on the Affordable Care Act, which Ben Carson once called the worst thing that has happened in this nation since slavery.

title: Obamas Flexible Fix to Climate Change
description: For many years, I used to spend at least part of the summer in the gorgeous Laurentides region of Quebec, an hour northwest of Montreal. By the mid-1980s, with each return trip, I could see a growing environmental threat to the areas beauty: More and more trees were dying. When I asked people what was happening, the answer was simple: pluie acide, or acid rain, a form of pollution caused by sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides that were spewing from coal-fired power plants in America.

description: When America is growing and happy, the country is sort of like a sprinters track. As Robert H. title: Whose Culture Is It, Anyhow?
Pakistan Hangs Inmate Said to Have Been Tortured Into Confessing
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A man whose lawyers said he had been tortured into confessing to murder, and who they said was a minor at the time of the crime, was hanged early Tuesday, despite pleas from rights groups in Pakistan and overseas.

title: News Qs | Wildfires Blaze in California
description: Note: Weve updated 6 Qs About the News for the new school year. This feature, now known as News Qs, will be a daily mini-lesson, with both Before Reading and After Reading questions, and a suggested activity for going further. Let us know what you think.

title: Walker Percys Theory of Hurricanes
description: Walker Percy had a theory about hurricanes. Though science taught that good environments were better than bad environments, it appeared to him that the opposite was the case, he wrote of Will Barrett, the semi-autobiographical title character of his second novel, The Last Gentleman. Take hurricanes, for example, certainly a bad environment if ever there was one. It was his impression that not just he but other people felt better in hurricanes.

title: The Beautiful Bureaucrat, by Helen Phillips
description: In the opening pages of Camuss The Stranger, a nurse warns Meursault to keep a steady pace during his mothers funeral procession: If you go slowly, she says, you risk getting sunstroke. But if you go too fast, you work up a sweat and then catch a chill inside the church. Meursaults response conveys his overwhelming, and baffling, sense of imprisonment: She was right. There was no way out. Its an illustrative moment of the paralysis  damned if I do, damned if I dont  that characterizes so much of existential literature: Vladimir and Estragon, waiting for a God who never shows; the man from the country in the parable told by the priest in Kafkas The Trial, inert, cursing his fate and praying to fleas, waiting for the doorkeeper to admit him into the Law; Gregor Samsa, trapped between identities, unable to leave his house or return to his human condition. This existential paralysis emerges, in part, from spiritual crisis: If God is dead, what is the individuals role in an essentially meaningless universe? Are we pawns in the thrall of bureaucratic (Kafka) or totalitarian (Orwell) systems? Or are we, in fact, the ones with ultimate power; the arbiters  even unknowingly  of life and death?

title: ISIS or Al Qaeda? American Officials Split Over Top Terror Threat

title: English Club Shuts Out Journalists With New Kind of Defense

The manager of Swindon Town F.C., the citys professional soccer club, was appearing at the function, and the reporter planned to write it up. Some handshakes, some smiles, a quick word between the writer and the manager, and a nice picture in the next days paper: It was the sort of thing that happened in small towns everywhere.

The neighborhood, once ridden with gangs and crime, now attracts stylish tourists, many staying at the new Ace hotel, which employs a number of former gang members as part of a rehabilitation of the neighborhood.

description: Lei Feng may be dead, but he lives on in print. The selfless soldier who became a propaganda icon in 1960s China has been revived in a cramped office in western Beijing, where a new monthly magazine supervised by the Communist Partys Peoples Publishing House was started in July.

title: What Its Really Like to Be an Airline Pilot
description: Mark Vanhoenackers new book, Skyfaring: A Journey With a Pilot (Knopf), isnt exactly a memoir. Its a meditation on flying, on the physical act of soaring through the air in a giant metal tube, and on the foreign-to-most experiences of the pilot behind the yoke. I am occasionally asked if I dont find it boring, to be in the cockpit for so many hours, he writes. But Ive never had the sense that there was any more enjoyable way to spend my working life, that below me existed some other kind of time for which I would trade my hours in the sky.

title: Morning Agenda: Puerto Rico Defaults

It made a payment on the interest of about $628,000, but it said it lacked the funds to pay the full amount. This has increased pressure on its creditors to renegotiate debt, but also makes it harder for Puerto Rico to borrow in the future.

title: The Tough Love of Austerity
description: Austerity, diet of our lives, girder of our loins. At the moment, the word brings to mind the continuing crisis in Greece and, by extension, the power of the Germans holding the purse strings. Austerity has become the catchall word for the cost-cutting a government enacts in order to balance its books: Cut pensions, cut the public payroll, cut social services  cut whatever and wherever. Shrink spending, shrink debt, shrink deficits. The idea is to inspire confidence and make the place more attractive to investors, who prefer a government thats tough and lean to one thats marbled and tender.

description: The singer Rufus Wainwright and the novelist Jay McInerney, among others, discuss their personal style at the chic Watermill Center benefit.

title: The Misadventures of Issa Rae
description: Somewhere, during the elaborate choreography leading up to my initial meeting with Issa Rae, a miscommunication between her publicist and me led to my asking Rae how the filming of her pilot was going. Rae pressed her chin to her chest and rolled her eyes upward, making the universal face for: Are you kidding me? Actually, she explained, the show had no director attached, no pit crew, not even the slightest inkling of a cast. She was nowhere near filming. All she had was a finished script and a charged cellphone.

description: While riding a recumbent bike from Siberia to Beijing, Tim Cope kept getting stuck in sand. Forced to push his bike through the tracks, he watched enviously as nomads would materialize on horseback and gallop off with great freedom.

title: 1915: Peace Mission Fails in Haiti
description: NEW YORK  A special cablegram to the Herald from Port-au-Prince says the mission of the Peace Committee has completely failed. The Cape army refused to fight. Governor Blot and his staff secretly fled during the night aboard a Haitian gunboat, while the population shouted Vive Bobo. The garrison of 1,500 was disarmed. Later the American warships Eagle and Nashville landed 250 sailors. Bobos army then tried to force the city gates despite the interdiction of the United States naval commanders. The Eagle then shelled the army.  The New York Herald, European Edition, August 5, 1915
