title: Free Puerto Rico, Americas Colony
description: PUERTO RICO has begun to default on its bond payments, for the first time since it became part of the United States, 117 years ago. If it fails to make interest payments on its $72 billion public debt, pension funds across the United States may be unable to meet their payment obligations. But if it were allowed to file for Chapter 9 bankruptcy protection, as cities and counties have done, every state will want that right.

title: Making Life Harder for Pimps
description: In the long struggle against sex trafficking, we finally have a breakthrough!

title: Howard Schultz: America Deserves a Servant Leader
description: FROM the earliest days of Starbucks, Ive been captivated by the art of leadership. I was mentored over three decades by Warren G. Bennis, the eminent professor and scholar on leadership. Ive gathered insights from peers, and Ive drawn inspiration from our 300,000 employees. But nothing Ive read or heard in the past few years has rivaled the power of the image I viewed on my cellphone a few years ago: Pope Francis, shortly after his election, kneeling and washing the feet of a dozen prisoners in Rome, one of them a young Muslim woman, in a pre-Easter ritual.

title: Why the Voting Rights Act Is Once Again Under Threat
description: IN his opinion for the majority in the Supreme Courts 2013 Shelby County decision, which struck down a major section of the Voting Rights Act, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. wrote that history did not end in 1965. But the sad truth is that voter-suppression efforts did not end, either.

title: The Supreme Courts Gap on Race and Juries
description: There are so many troubling issues surrounding race and the criminal justice system these days that it is easy to forget a longstanding problem: the exclusion of African-Americans from juries. After all, it was nearly three decades ago that the Supreme Court took what was seen then as a major step toward solving that problem. In Batson v. Kentucky, decided in April 1986, the court ruled that prosecutors could be required to provide a race neutral explanation when their use of peremptory challenges to strike black potential jurors raised an inference of discrimination.

title: A Long Time Coming, Sunlight on the Executive Pay Gap
description: After years of delay, the Securities and Exchange Commission approved a sensible final rule on Wednesday  that will force publicly traded companies to reveal how the pay of chief executives compares with that of typical employees.

title: Greeces Refugee Crisis and Europes Failure
description: As if Greece didnt have enough on its hands after its European creditors forced it to accept a damaging bailout deal last month, it is also trying to cope with more refugees crossing the Mediterranean to its shores than to any other country in Europe. It is unconscionable for Europe to expect Greece to shoulder this burden, yet that is exactly what is happening.

title: Why We Cry for Cecil the Lion
description: To the Editor:

title: The Challenges That Millennials Face
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Me, Trade Me Not
description: WILMER FLORES had an eventful week.

title: Darren Wilsons Quest for Distance
description: Leading up to the first anniversary of the shooting death of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo.  and the cultural convolutions that followed  The New Yorker has published an article including extensive interviews with Darren Wilson, the police officer who pulled the trigger.

title: The Next Phase of the G.O.P. Race Starts Now
description: Most of the important action in the Republican presidential race has been out of sight, as candidates have courted donors and party leaders before formally jumping into the race.

title: State Department Cautions Americans Considering Travel to Iran
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The Obama administration hopes that the nuclear deal it negotiated with Iran may one day lead to broader cooperation. But the State Department has some cautionary words for Americans who think the reconciliation is already underway.

title: Albino Sea Cucumbers, a Delicacy, Could Become a Lot Less Rare
description: Sea cucumbers, sluglike creatures that hug the seafloor, have long been a prized delicacy at Chinese banquets, the mark of a special occasion. And no variety of sea cucumber is more valued, or costlier, than the exceedingly rare albino. Just a few years ago, five white sea cucumbers sold at auction in the city of Jinan for 160,000 renminbi, or nearly $26,000 at todays exchange rate.

title: A Brooklyn Rental for Sisters and Their Families
description: Four years ago, Lisbeth Kaiser and Alex Rappaport bought a condo with two bedrooms, two baths and almost 1,000 square feet on Fourth Avenue, the busy thoroughfare on the edge of lively Park Slope, Brooklyn. For $640,000, they got a terrace, a washer-dryer, a roof deck, a storage unit and even a parking spot.

title: Junes Book Club Pick: The Fifth Season, by N.K. Jemisin
description: Fantasy novels often provide a degree of escapism: a good thing, for any reader who has something worth escaping. Too often, though, that escape comes through a fictional world that erases rather than solves the more complex problems of our own, reducing difficulty to the level of personal struggle and heroism, turning all obstacles to monsters we can see and touch and kill with a sword. But N.K. Jemisins intricate and extraordinary world-building starts with oppression: Her universes begin by asking who is oppressing whom, what they are gaining, what they fear. Systems of power stalk her protagonists, often embodied as gods and primeval forces, so vast that resistance seems impossible even to contemplate. When escape comes in her novels, it is not a merely personal victory, or the restoration of a sketchy and soft-lit status quo. Her heroes achieve escape velocity, smashing through oppressive systems and leaving them behind like shed skins.

title: Ursula K. Le Guin: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of the updated Steering the Craft: A 21st-Century Guide to Sailing the Sea of Story, avoids fiction about dysfunctional urban middle-class people written in the present tense.

title: Cuban Youth See New U.S. Embassy, but Same Old Drab Life
description: HAVANA  Wedged between a construction site and the shells of once grand colonial homes, a basketball game was underway, the neighborhood pouring into the rubble-strewn street for some evening entertainment.

title: The Tale of an Anxious Economic Recovery, Told by a Revived Textile Mill
description: Founded 150 years ago, the Faribault Woolen Mill in Minnesota survived the Great War and the Great Depression, not to mention World War II. But it almost did not make it through the Great Recession.

title: As Coaches Come and Go, Arsne Wenger of Arsenal Just Keeps Going
description: LONDON  It is often said that no job in sports is less secure than that of an N.F.L. player. With no guaranteed contracts, incredible pressure for immediate results, a steady influx of new talent from college football and the constant threat of serious injury, it is hardly surprising that the average players career lasts about three years.

title: News Qs | Hitchhiking Robot, Safe in Several Countries, Meets Its End in Philadelphia
description: Note: Weve updated 6 Qs About the News for the new school year. This feature, now known as News Qs, will be a daily mini-lesson, with both Before Reading and After Reading questions, and a suggested activity for going further. Let us know what you think.

title: Cuban Youth Wait for Change to Filter Down to Their Lives
description: There is an air of cynicism among Cuban young people, who see the ideals of Fidel Castros revolution as dated as the battered cars on Havanas streets.

title: Roman Totenbergs Stolen Stradivarius Is Found After 35 Years
description: The label inside the violin said Stradivarius, but plenty of fakes claim that, too. So after a California woman asked Phillip Injeian, a violinmaker and dealer, to appraise the instrument, he met her at a Manhattan hotel in late June and examined every inch of it, from its nicks to the somewhat pointy curve of its F-holes to its distinctive wood grain, before delivering his verdict.

description: Our weekday morning digest that includes information about cruises, resorts and theme parks, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

description: This feature looks at some of the earliest mentions of famous names or terms in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Leave a suggestion in the comments section.

title: Contraceptives May Lower Endometrial Cancer Risk Long-Term
description: Studies have shown that the use of oral contraceptives lowers the risk for endometrial cancer, and now a new study has found that the protection continues for many years after women stop using them.

description: Good morning on this sparkling Thursday.

Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 to Continue Off Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The search for a missing Malaysian jet in waters off Australias western coast will continue as planned, Australias prime minister said on Thursday, hours after his Malaysian counterpart announced that a wing part found thousands of miles away was the first confirmed debris from the Boeing 777.

title: U.S. and Russia to Back U.N. Vote on Chemical Attacks in Syria
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The United States and Russia will support a United Nations Security Council resolution to identify the perpetrators of attacks using chlorine and other chemical agents in Syria, Secretary of State John Kerry said Thursday.

title: Morning Agenda: Activist Investors Build Their Stakes
description: ACTIVIST INVESTORS BUILD THEIR STAKES | William A. Ackman has built up a $5.5 billion stake in Mondelez International, the maker of Oreo cookies and Cadbury chocolate, Alexandra Stevenson reports in DealBook. His $20 billion hedge fund, Pershing Square Capital Management, is betting on consolidation in the food industry with its 7.5 percent stake.

title: Today in Politics: Republicans Gather Under the Lights to Talk Amongst Themselves
description: Good Thursday morning from Washington as Cleveland bustles with preparations for the first debates of the 2016 election season. Fox News moderators are looking to keep the top 10 candidates on their toes as they wrangle in prime-time, while the seven other candidates will have their say hours earlier. For each group, the preseason is over.

title: Major Issues for Chinese Leaders to Tackle in Beidaihe, if They Meet
description: Read in Chinese |

title: Ice Cube Might Have Dinner With the President
description: In a trailer for Straight Outta Compton, the N.W.A. biopic that you co-produced, you say a lot of people dont realize that your music was a form of nonviolent protest. Is that because the nonviolent part wasnt very clear? I think its very clear. We put our frustrations on a record, and we were creative. We didnt make a Molotov cocktail; we didnt loot no buildings or burn em down or none of that. All we did was make music.

title: Suez Canal Upgrade May Not Ease Egypts Economic Journey
description: CAIRO  Egypt Rejoices, the television networks and newspapers declared, announcing Egypts gift to the world. Businesses were closed, the streets of Cairo were empty, and the airwaves were full of patriotic songs and music videos  all featuring adoring images of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi interspersed with footage of cargo sailing toward the sea.

title: Letter of Recommendation: The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock
description: My first hours with the spiky words of T.S. Eliots The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock are fixed in a precise location: the cluttered space of my teenage bedroom floor. Its 1982. The light is low. The parquet tiles are coming unglued. Album covers  Talking Heads, David Bowie, the Clash  fan out around me, and an array of paperbacks sprawl among a weeks discarded clothes. I begin to read: Let us go then, you and I,/When the evening is spread out against the sky/Like a patient etherized upon a table  and, with a 17-year-olds sense of imminent upheaval, feel the stirrings of a new language in me, connected to my own language but having passed through fire. I cant say whether the voice the poem puts in my head as it extends its opening invitation is stiffly formal, smarmy or seductive. Spread yourself out on the floor, it seems to whisper, and prepare to be turned inside-out.

title: Out of the Woods
description: Several years ago, David Withers, a zoologist with the Tennessee Department of Environment and Conservation, was digging for crayfish in some creek beds on the edge of DeKalb County, in an area that can plausibly be described as nowhere at all, when he spotted an unmarked road. He had never noticed it and decided to see where it led; after a short drive, he found himself amid a strange encampment. Withers stepped out of his truck and looked around. Cheerful, rickety houses sprouted from the ground like unclassified fungi, or something dreamed up by Lewis Carroll, but what appealed to him most was the barn; on the side, in large yellow letters, someone had written Welcome Home. Withers walked up to a shack that appeared to be inhabited and  overtaken by curiosity  he knocked. The woman who came out looked surprised. She told him that he was on a commune for gay, lesbian and transgender people and suggested politely that he leave. Later, Withers called his friend Neal Appelbaum, the openly gay director of the arts center in neighboring Cannon County, and told him about what he saw. Appelbaum explained that Withers had stumbled into Ida, a commune for queer vegetarians; the entire region was home to maybe a dozen rural planned communities for L.G.B.T.Q. people, a kind of sexually nonconforming Amish country. He also pointed out that the fading sign on the barn didnt say Welcome Home. The last letter was not an e but an o.

title: Victims of Hiroshima Bombing Honored
description: Cicadas shrilled and a peace bell rang as a crowd near the Peace Memorial remembered those who died after the atomic bombing of the city 70 years ago.

title: CF Industries to Acquire Businesses From OCI for $8 Billion
description: LONDON  The American fertilizer maker CF Industries said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire several European and North American operations and a global distribution business from OCI of the Netherlands for $8 billion, including debt.

title: 4 Palestinians Are Killed by Leftover Explosive in Gaza Wars Rubble
description: GAZA CITY  Four Palestinians from one extended family were killed and more than 40 others were wounded on Thursday after military ordnance exploded in Gaza as residents cleared the rubble of their homes a year after the war with Israel.

title: Review: The Gift, a Stalker Thriller That Isnt What It Seems
description: Even if The Gift, the Australian director Joel Edgertons creepy stalker thriller, didnt make a dramatic U-turn at around the halfway point, it would still rank as a superior specimen. This movie doesnt foam at the mouth like Fatal Attraction. No bunnies are boiled. But fish are poisoned, a family dog goes missing and the soundtrack is tricked out with the sudden jolts dear to the genre. Any revenge is more pitiable than cathartic.

title: At Katmai National Park in Alaska, Bears Rule
description: Katmai National Park sprawls over four million acres in southern Alaska. So why does its only established campground allow for just 60 people per night  a limit that leads to an online booking fray every January? The answer is also one of the parks main draws, and its primary claim to national fame: bears. Lots of them  about 2,200 at the National Park Services last count, with 60 or so regulars that hang around Brooks Camp every summer. In theory, you can camp elsewhere in Katmai, but the campground has an electric fence and constant activity, making it an unlikely place to find a bear too close to your tent for sleeping comfort.

title: 1965: Voting Rights Act Passed
description: WASHINGTON  President Johnson today [Aug. 6] signed into law federal voting rights legislation which he said will fuse and blend  the Negro story and the American story. He said his administration will move immediately to enforce it in the Deep South. After his address, Mr. Johnson walked to the ornate Presidents Room in the Senate, where 104 years ago Abraham Lincoln signed a law freeing slaves impressed into war service by the Confederacy.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 7, 1965

title: Broadcasting From the Bedroom

title: Three Coca-Cola Bottlers in Europe Agree to Merger
description: LONDON  Three Coca-Cola bottlers in Europe said on Thursday that they had agreed to combine their businesses to form the worlds largest independent bottler of Coca-Cola products.

title: New York Times Co. Reports $16 Million Profit
description: The New York Times Company reported net income of more than $16 million for the second quarter on slightly lower revenue, as digital growth and cost declines offset a continued drop in print advertising across the industry.

title: Malaysias Declarations on Flight 370 and Plane Debris Further Dent Its Credibility
description: HONG KONG  Malaysias handling of the discovery of a wing part that apparently came from the missing Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 has worsened frictions with its partners in the investigation, rekindled frustrations among the families of people who were aboard the plane and further dented the countrys battered credibility.

title: At Least 15 Die at Saudi Mosque from Suicide Bomber
description: ISTANBUL  A suicide bomber killed at least 15 people on Thursday, including 12 members of a Saudi police force, when he detonated explosives in a mosque in southern Saudi Arabia, the state news agency there reported.

title: Press Play
description: Press Play is the place where The New York Times debuts noteworthy new music.

title: The Uber-ization of Activism
description: The nasty battle between Uber and the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio over New York Citys proposed cap on livery vehicles has ended, at least for now, with the city and the ride-hailing giant agreeing to postpone a decision pending a traffic study. Theres no doubt who won, though. The mayor underestimated his opponent and was forced to retreat.

title: A Small Kansas Town Relishes Its History
description: Families return to Nicodemus each year to reconnect with their ancestors and with one another, in a town established by freed slaves in 1877.

title: Descendants Keep Alive Legacy of 1877 Black Settlement in Kansas
description: NICODEMUS, Kan.  Riding a red lawn mower down Washington Avenue in her hometowns annual parade, Bertha Carter, 82, shielded herself from the sun with a white cowboy hat, and dispatched giant mosquitoes with an electronic swatter.

title: WME-IMG Unveils a New York Fashion Week Makeover
description: Its going to be logos-a-gogo at New York Fashion Week come September.

title: Johanna Quandt, Matriarch of Family That Controls BMW, Dies at 89
description: FRANKFURT  Johanna Quandt, the matriarch of the family that controls the automaker BMW and one of the wealthiest people in Germany, died on Monday in Bad Homburg, Germany. She was 89.

title: Young Conservatives Press Republican Presidential Debaters on Energy Policy
description: A few hundred yards from the Cleveland arena where Fox News invited the top-ranked Republican presidential candidates to debate, several hundred young conservatives will gather for an unusual party  an epic Republican evening celebrating and promoting energy policy reforms that are anathema to most of those wholl be onstage.

title: Afghan Army Helicopter Crashes, Killing All 17 Aboard
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  An Afghan National Army helicopter crashed in southern Afghanistan on Thursday, killing all 17 people aboard, government officials said.

title: Daily Report: Google and the Spread of the Right to Be Forgotten
description: If you thought the so-called right to be forgotten was limited to Europe, think again.

title: Everyone Wants to Hit Something
description: People are boxing for fitness  without ever taking a punch  in increasing numbers. Follow three men through their workouts at three New York City gyms.

title: The New Workout: Boxing Without the Bruises
description: For the last two years, Raymond Wilburg, 27, has been training hard at Gleasons Gym in Brooklyn. At first, it was for fitness. Its therapeutic, he said. All of the worlds problems, whatever I have outside of the boxing gym, it just falls away.

title: No Comment Necessary: A Debate and an Anniversary
description: On August 6, 1965, Lyndon Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act, which barred states from enacting any provision aimed at restricting citizens right to vote on the basis of race.

title: Think Like a Doctor: A Knife in the Ear
description: The Challenge: Can you figure out why a middle aged man developed an earache and pupils of different sizes?

title: Jon Stewart, From Parody to Politics
description: As Mr. Stewart nears the end of his 16-year tenure on the Daily Show, here is a look back at how he has transformed it into a satirical mainstay that is now part of the political establishment.

title: Sisi Unveils Suez Canal Extension
description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt traveled on the Suez Canal on Thursday to the city of Ismailia, where he unveiled a new extension to the canal.

title: At Hiroshimas 70th Anniversary, Japan Again Mourns Dawn of Atomic Age
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan  Every year on Aug. 6, Hiroshima becomes a city of mourning. And one full of reminders  some delivered politely, some pointedly  of the most extreme dangers of modern warfare.

title: The Choreographer Matthew Neenan of BalletX Nears the Stratosphere
description: PHILADELPHIA  A few weeks back, the lobby of the Wilma Theater here took on the aspect of a cheap Hawaiian resort. Polynesian music twanged from speakers. Everyone who entered was offered a paper-flower lei. This was not a visit from a hula troupe. This was a gala performance of the Wilmas resident contemporary ballet company, BalletX. And yet the atmosphere made complete sense, if only in combination with a more incongruous fact: The ballet on the program was about a signal incident in the history of airmail.

title: Teenagers Leading Happy, Connected Lives Online
description: Where is the doom and gloom?

title: Relaxed Parisian Style
description: Select pieces from the brand Cristasaya.

title: Cinemark Rejects Paramounts Plan to Rush Movie Releases
description: LOS ANGELES  Paramount Pictures has failed to get two of the nations three largest theater chains on board with an effort to shorten the length of time it takes for new wide-release movies to become available to watch at home.

title: Bartenders Whip Up Fringe Cocktails
description: Del Pedro, the managing partner of Tooker Alley, a bar in Brooklyn, pours an ounce and a half of tequila into a glass. He follows that with some genever, the malty Dutch gin. Then it really gets weird.

title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Looking for something fun to do?

title: Stage Scenes: Sherie Rene Scott
description: A look at some of the actresss past stage roles, from Rent to Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown.

title: In Whorl Inside a Loop, Prisoners Fingerprints in Tales of Inmate Lives
description: In the spring of 2011, the librettist Dick Scanlan and the Broadway actress Sherie Rene Scott woke up early and drove a few hours upstate to the Woodbourne Correctional Facility in New York, a medium-security prison in Sullivan County. Theyd already been fingerprinted and tested for tuberculosis. Theyd selected clothing that wouldnt trigger the metal detectors.

title: Apple Music Attracts 11 Million Users in Trial Period, Executive Says
description: Apple Music, the companys new streaming service, attracted 11 million people for its trial period in a little more than a month, a top executive said.

title: Teenagers Keep and Make Friends Online, Pew Says
description: Researchers say they have discovered something that teenagers already know: Young people use the Internet to maintain friendships made at school or work, but also to forge entirely new ones with peers they meet while browsing social networks like Instagram or playing a game like Call of Duty.

title: Czech Company, Pressing Hits for Years on Vinyl, Finds It Has Become One
description: LODENICE, Czech Republic  He was a businessman, not a clairvoyant. Zdenek Pelc did not really foresee, a generation ago, that vinyl records would one day make a return from near extinction.

title: Among the States, Self-Driving Cars Have Ignited a Gold Rush
description: Whether it is fuel savings, safer commutes or freed-up time behind the wheel, motorists have many reasons to embrace self-driving cars.

title: Making Every Vote Count
description: The Voting Rights Act, which marks its 50th anniversary this week, was meant to end one of the quieter ways black people have been held back from equal participation in American life. If half a century later, new laws are still being passed intended to create arcane impediments to their voting, its still a landmark of the civil rights movement worth celebrating  and one thats still vitally important to explain to children. Two new picture books do that through moving narratives of an older generations struggles.

title: Detroit Boy, 11, Charged With Manslaughter in Shooting of 3-Year-Old
description: An 11-year-old Detroit boy has been charged with manslaughter in the fatal shooting of a 3-year-old, the first such case that a prosecutor could recall involving a suspect so young.

title: 1940: Ministers Ponder Actors Trip
description: LONDON  Parliament today [Aug. 6] buckled down to discussing Noel Coward and Miss Gracie Fields and how they got away to America. Coward, actor and all-round entertainer, was the subject of a question put by a Conservative. On what mission, he asked, was Mr. Coward engaged by his majestys government? Harold Nicolson, Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Information, replied that Coward had gone with the approval of Prime Minister Winston Churchill. Another member said feeling was rising that if a man has a certain amount of publicity value and money he can get out of this country when the country is going through a period of great stress and anxiety?  New York Herald Tribune, August 7, 1940

title: Brooklyn Getting a New Jazz Festival at BRIC House
description: A new jazz festival will take root in downtown Brooklyn this fall. The first BRIC JazzFest will take place Oct. 11 to 16 at BRIC House, the recently renovated contemporary arts center in Fort Greene. The festival will be a highlight of fall programming for BRIC, which also presents Celebrate Brooklyn! at the Prospect Park Bandshell.

title: A Parisian Lifestyle Brand That Combines Art With Slouchy Sweaters
description: We are against the fashion system  we were bored with fashion and trends and the change every season, says Cristina Casini, co-founder of the Parisian lifestyle brand CristaSeya. Instead, Casini and her partner, Keiko Seya, release editions  of 12 to 15 items  every six months. We wanted to do something that would be timeless, using the best materials  pieces that you can keep for a long time, Casini says.

title: Tougher Standards Set for U.S. Visa Waivers, Citing Militant Threat
description: WASHINGTON  The Department of Homeland Security has toughened air travel requirements on foreign governments in response to what it believes is the growing threat from fighters who have gone to Syria and Iraq to join the Islamic State and other groups, senior American officials said Thursday.

title: Police Video From N. Carolina Shooting
description: A portion of the dashboard camera video released by the Charlotte Police Department on Wednesday shows Jonathan Ferrell moments before he was shot by Officer Randall Kerrick.

title: IBM Adds Medical Images to Watson, Buying Merge Healthcare for $1 Billion
description: IBM is adding medical images to the health data its Watson artificial-intelligence can mine to help doctors make diagnoses.

title: Natalia Molchanova Was Teaching Divers When She Vanished, Son Says
description: The champion free diver Natalia Molchanova was giving private instruction to at least two inexperienced divers Sunday when she failed to surface from a dive, her son said Thursday.

title: The Weitz Brothers Help Each Other Through Hollywood Hits and Misses
description: LOS ANGELES  The filmmaking brothers Paul and Chris Weitz, who have had their movie hits and misses since breaking through with the blockbuster 1999 teen sex comedy American Pie, had childhoods that resemble something out of a movie made by their friend Wes Anderson.

title: Pennsylvania Attorney General, Kathleen Kane, Charged in Leak Case
description: A prosecutor filed criminal charges on Thursday against Pennsylvanias attorney general, Kathleen G. Kane, in a convoluted tale of political maneuvering and retribution that threatens the career of an official who was seen until recently as one of her states rising stars.

title: Whats That Bubble? A Dying Stars Glowing Remains
description: A new picture of the Southern Owl Nebula was captured by the Very Large Telescope in Chile.

title: Viacoms Weak Results Pile On More Bad News for TV Industry
description: It is no more than a coincidence that Viacom announced weak earnings and suffered a sharp plunge in its stock on the same day that one of its biggest stars, Jon Stewart, exited the stage.

title: Texas Watchdog Group Calls Another Political Titan to Account
description: McKINNEY, Tex.  When Attorney General Ken Paxton of Texas was booked at the county jail here Monday on felony fraud charges, he joined some pretty high-powered company, including Tom DeLay, the former House majority leader, and former Gov. Rick Perry, as powerful Texas officials indicted while in office over the last decade.

title: Review: In The Diary of a Teenage Girl, a Hormone Bomb Waiting to Explode
description: Minnie Goetze, the 15-year-old heroine of The Diary of a Teenage Girl, is a would-be cartoonist who, despite her first name, is closer in lusty spirit and scratchy pen to Robert Crumb than to Walt Disney. When, partway through this gutsy, exhilarating movie, she draws her first cartoon, its of a bodacious female colossus striding across San Francisco. As this inky giant keeps on trucking, she evokes the 50-foot-woman of cult film fame, if one that has received a Crumb makeover, with thighs as mighty as giant sequoias and a bottom that rolls like a ship in a storm.

title: What We Learned From German Prisons
description: EARLIER this summer, we led a delegation of people concerned about the United States criminal justice system to visit some prisons in Germany and observe their conditions. What we saw was astonishing.

title: Russia Destroys Piles of Banned Western Food
description: MOSCOW  Ramping up enforcement of a ban on European food imports, the Russian authorities on Thursday destroyed hundreds of tons of foodstuffs they said violated the proscription, instituted a year ago in retaliation for Western sanctions over Ukraine.

title: Form for Drug Dealers to Snitch on Competitors Results in an Arrest
description: When the sheriff in Franklin County, Ky., posted a flier on Facebook asking local drug dealers to snitch on their competition, the response was more than a little incredulous.

title: Salesforce Ventures and Microsoft Join Informatica Buyout
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As Informatica closes its $5.3 billion sale to private equity on Thursday, the enterprise software maker will count two of its big technology partners as new investors as well.

title: Hiplife, a Sound Imported From Ghana, Arrives on a New York Stage
description: When Evans Appiah moved to the Bronx from Ghana at age 8, he was teased for his accent. As a way of fitting in, he learned to rap. By the time he got to Middle School 391 on Webster Avenue, his friends were calling him Lighter because he rapped so fast and furious in English that it sounded as if he were spitting fire.

title: A Millennials Guide to Kissing
As China Reduces Local Spending, Cities Woo Private Investors
description: HONG KONG  The wide new boulevards that cut across parts of Weifang in eastern China are largely free of traffic, a quiet reminder of the coastal citys big ambitions.

title: Charges Announced Against Kathleen Kane
description: Risa Vetri Ferman, the district attorney for Montgomery county, Pa., said on Thursday that the states attorney general, Kathleen G. Kane, is being charged with leaking information to the media.

title: Welcome, Small Pigs
description: Demonstrating once again that the only things more appealing than charismatic megafauna are miniature charismatic megafauna, the Prospect Park Zoo has added three adorable faces to its menagerie.

title: Facebook Joins the Live-Streaming Crowd With a Service for Celebrities
description: Facebook has joined the live-stream-video scene  but so far, its only for famous people.

title: What Dad Should Do About the Brat Pack
description: I am a 65-year-old man, vigorous and still working. I divorced 20 years ago when I came out as a gay man. After years of dating, I find myself in love with a man in his early 20s who loves me back. We have been dating for a couple of years. I do not support him financially; he is not in my will. But my three adult children, all married, find the age difference impossible to accept. I was their primary caretaker, and we have always been close. I dont want a rift. How to proceed?

title: California Burning: Photographers Notebook
description: The Rocky fire is the largest of several fires currently burning in California. It has consumed 68,000 acres, or an area of a little more than 106 square miles, forcing thousands of residents from their homes. It has burned 91 structures including 39 homes in a very rural area near Clearlake that encompasses parts of Lake, Yolo and Colusa Counties. Since the fire began last Wednesday, about 3,500 firefighters have battled it. As of 7 a.m. on Aug. 6, it was 40 percent contained and the cause of the blaze was unknown.

title: For Vaccines Needed in an Epidemic, Timing Is Everything
description: Last year, scientists launched a trial of an experimental vaccine against Ebola in Guinea. On Friday, they reported great news: The vaccine works well, providing remarkable protection just 10 days after injection.

title: Fox Failed Statistics in Explaining Its G.O.P. Debate Decision
description: Will Rick Perry miss the main Republican debate Thursday night because hes unpopular or because hes unlucky? This turns out to be a far more difficult question that you might realize, and its one that apparently eludes the Fox News decision desk.

title: Jemera Rone, Investigator Who Bared Human Rights Abuses, Dies at 71
description: Jemera Rone, who abandoned a legal career on Wall Street in her 40s to focus instead on exposing and redressing human rights violations in El Salvador and Sudan, died on July 29 in Washington. She was 71.

title: The Hosts Are Wild, So Keep Your Distance
description: About 2,200 bears reside at Katmai National Park in Alaska, with 60 or so regulars that hang around Brooks Camp every summer.

title: Ledecky Gains Relay Gold; Lochte Wins 200 I.M.
description: KAZAN, Russia  For four days at the world championships, Katie Ledecky hauled the weight of the United States sterling swimming reputation by herself. While New Zealand, Chile, Jamaica and Iceland put athletes in individual finals, the American team, which had won 182 gold medals in the previous 15 world championship meets, saw only Ledecky rise to the very top.

title: The Speech That Defined the Fight for Voting Rights in Congress
description: Fifty years ago today, on Aug. 6, 1965, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act, which effectively ended centuries of black disenfranchisement by banning barriers to minority voting like the poll tax and the poll test, as I detailed in the magazines Aug. 2 cover story. At the signing ceremony, Johnson called the Voting Rights Act a triumph for freedom as huge as any victory that has ever been won on the battlefield.

title: Follow Debate Day Coverage on The Timess Live Blog
description: Times reporters are posting on the Republican debates and the runup to the events on the live blog.

title: Does America Still Believe in Diplomacy?
description: President Obama has never seemed so sure-footed on foreign policy as now, when he is battling against determined opponents to persuade the American public and Congress on the merits of the Iran nuclear deal.

title: Lively Morgue Tumblr 549  553
description: Lively Morgue Tumblr 549  553

title: King Coal, Long Besieged, Is Deposed by the Market
description: In April 2005, President George W. Bush hailed clean coal as a key to greater energy independence, pledging $2 billion in research funds that promised a new golden age for Americas most abundant energy resource.

title: Rebuilding Around Tina Charles Puts Liberty in Playoff Hunt
description: A Liberty season that began with an off-court to-do over the hiring of Isiah Thomas as team president has turned into a great one on the basketball court. The Liberty sit on top of the W.N.B.A.s Eastern Conference at 13-6. If the team maintains that .684 winning percentage over its final 15 games, it will finish with the best record in franchise history.

title: Review: Fantastic Four, the Reboot (Wanted or Not)
description: The opening scenes of Fantastic Four  20th Century Foxs reboot of its Marvel superhero franchise  take place in 2007, which happens to be the year that the second movie in the prerebooted franchise (Rise of the Silver Surfer) was released. Ben Grimm and Reed Richards (played as children by Evan Hannemann and Owen Judge, later by Jamie Bell and Miles Teller) dont mention that fact, because if they did the cinematic universe would collapse on itself and all light would be extinguished from the cosmos. Also, the thoughtful people at Fox probably dont want to remind anyone of those earlier movies.

title: Soul-Searching in Israel After Bias Attacks on Gays and Arabs
description: JERUSALEM  On one edge of the Zion Square gathering, an Orthodox yeshiva student was in heated debate with a secular couple over the hierarchy of sin. On the other, young men wearing skullcaps rocked back and forth, reciting the evening prayer. In between, people sat cross-legged on the cobblestones amid an array of memorial candles and banners decrying violence, promoting love, demanding change.

title: In South Sinai With One-third of Three as Four
description: The Israel-born designer Adi Gil remembers family trips to South Sinai in the 70s, before Egypt secured the area. Recently, shes started spending time there again  though the present-day peninsula bears little resemblance to the crowded South Sinai from her childhood photo albums. Still, it remains beautiful and surreal, says Gil, one-third of the brand Three as Four. It all depends on how you look at it  and who is looking at it. When it comes to the Middle East, sometimes I feel that the media likes to magnify the negative. We know there are issues in North Sinai. But next door there is beauty, and no one is talking about that.

title: Video Is Released From 2013 North Carolina Police Shooting of Jonathan Ferrell
description: A police dashboard camera video from the shooting death of a black man in North Carolina in 2013 has been made public as part of the trial of the police officer accused of killing him.

title: 18-Year-Old Sentenced to Five Years for Robbing Man, 84, She Met on Dating Site
description: A teenager who with her twin sister robbed an octogenarian they met on an Internet dating site was sentenced on Thursday to five years in prison.

title: In North Dakota, Boom, Bust and Oil
description: On U.S. 2 in North Dakota, just west of the turnoff for Tioga, you will spot two little brown highway signs pointing left:

title: Chenin Blanc Makes an Audacious U.S. Return
description: After 20 years in which the repertoire of American winemakers seemed to have dwindled to a half-dozen grapes, endlessly repeated, the last decade has been one of intrepid exploration. Myriad grapes once deemed unworthy or too esoteric have been rediscovered and revived by winemakers seeking to make fresh, lively wines that are simply delicious to drink nightly, rather than ponderous wines aiming for trophies.

title: Boom, Bust and Oil
description: On the byways of northwest North Dakota, a richly historic past meets the oil-fueled present.

title: Review: We Believe the Children, on Child Abuse Hysteria in the 1980s
description: From 1987 to 1990, in the longest criminal trial in American history, prosecutors tried to prove that Virginia McMartin, who owned a preschool in Manhattan Beach, Calif., and other school employees, including her daughter and grandson, had raped or abused 13 children, taken pornographic pictures of them and forced them to watch the mutilation of animals.

title: Macedonia Arrests 9 Suspected of Having Ties to ISIS
description: SKOPJE, Macedonia  Macedonian officials announced Thursday that nine people had been arrested and that 27 more were being sought in a crackdown on citizens who traveled to the Middle East to fight alongside the Islamic State group or who helped recruit fighters for it.

title: In Chicago, Lincoln, Copernicus and Shakespeare Have Something to Say to You
description: If a public sculpture in a large American city could talk, what would it say, besides complaining about pigeons and benign neglect? In Chicago, beginning Thursday, residents are finding out with the help of prominent writers and performers, as part of a program started by the British arts organization Sing London, and supported in Chicago by the Richard H. Driehaus Foundation.

title: Humpty Dumpty Deal-Making
description: Some of the finest minds in finance seem to have missed the lesson of the nursery rhyme Humpty Dumpty: All the kings horses and all the kings men couldnt put that character together again.

title: Pakistan Army Helicopter Crashes, Killing 12
description: PAKISTAN  At least 12 people aboard a Pakistani Army helicopter were killed Thursday in northwestern Pakistan, a military spokesman said. They included a team of army doctors, paramedics, two pilots and crew. Officials said they were trying to determine the cause of the crash and suspected weather conditions to be responsible. The helicopter, carrying medical supplies, took off from Rawalpindi and was headed toward Gilgit, which has been affected recently by floods.

title: Crucible Revival, With Whishaw and Okonedo, Sets Broadway Opening
description: As the 100th anniversary of Arthur Millers birth approaches, Broadway is doubling down on two of his most produced plays this season.

title: In Papua, Indonesia, a Visit to the Welcoming Dani People
description: The thatched-roof homes of Wesagalep lay at cloud level, high above the Baliem Valley in Papua, the Indonesian side of the island of New Guinea. They are built on about six terraced levels of the mountain, with startling views of the valley and down to the rushing river below.

title: With Deadline Deals, Blue Jays Load Up on Optimism
description: TORONTO  Paul Molitor rounded the bases just ahead of Joe Carter on that electrifying night of Oct. 23, 1993. He felt the roar that pulsated inside the Skydome when he scored the winning run on Carters homer, giving the Toronto Blue Jays their second consecutive World Series title.

title: Creator and Fans Hit It Lucky With Hamilton
description: Three hours before the5 p.m. Broadway opening night of his hip-hopmusical Hamilton, Lin-Manuel Miranda paid emotional tribute to the biography, and the life, that inspired his work.

title: A Home of Ones Own in Notting Hill
description: The West London district of Notting Hill famously attracts visitors to its pastel-colored rows of houses, sprawling Portobello Road Antiques Market and Europes biggest street festival  and yet has always, until now, lacked sumptuous places to stay. On the south side of the secluded Pembridge Gardens, just seconds from Notting Hill Gate station (and a mere 15-minute hop to the hubbub of Soho), a row of five stucco Victorian mansions have recently been transformed into what is now the Laslett hotel.

title: New York Ordering Tests of Water-Cooling Towers Amid Legionnaires Outbreak
description: New York City buildings with water-cooling towers must assess and disinfect the units within the next two weeks under an order issued on Thursday by health officials in response to the outbreak of Legionnaires disease in the South Bronx.

title: Syrian Officials Visit to Oman May Signal a Diplomatic Opening
description: Syrias government sent a high-level delegation on Thursday to Oman, the Persian Gulf state that historically has helped broker negotiations in regional conflicts.

title: Wait, He Plays for Them Now?
description: While Arsne Wenger never seems to go anywhere  he will begin his 20th season at Arsenal on Sunday  a host of prominent players joined, left or switched Premier League teams over the summer. Among the more notable moves you will notice starting this weekend:

title: Top Hillary Clinton Donor Comes Out Against Iran Deal
description: A top donor to Hillary Rodham Clinton expressed his opposition Thursday to the Obama administrations agreement with Iran to curtail its nuclear program, calling it a very bad deal.

title: For Mets Fans, First Is a Surprise. For Yankees Fans, Its About Time.
description: After three emotion-filled days with the Mets at Citi Field last weekend, I was looking forward to going to the Bronx this week and watching the first-place Yankees during a six-game homestand against Boston and Toronto.

title: Living With Cancer: Alone and Ghosted
description: When my husband, incapacitated by knee surgery, was placed in a rehabilitation facility, I lost my caregiver. Don can no longer drive me to the cancer center or undertake the chores he used to do for both of us, and he must consider his own overriding physical problems, not mine. With the good luck of my relatively stable physical condition, I struggle to meet our basic needs. However, an unluckier member of my support group found herself in dire circumstances after her partner traveled overseas on a business trip.

title: 1945 | Witnessing the A-Bomb, but Forbidden to File
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, Aug. 9 to 15, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Movie Review: Diary of a Teenage Girl
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Diary of a Teenage Girl.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | The Gift
description: Joel Edgerton narrates a sequence from The Gift, featuring Rebecca Hall and Jason Bateman.

title: The Gift (With Movie Trailer): Joel Edgerton Narrates a Scene
description: For the The Gift, the actor Joel Edgerton goes behind the camera to direct a twist on the thriller genre, while also using some of its conventions. Jason Bateman and Rebecca Hall play Simon and Robin, a couple who have moved to a new town and are greeted and befriended by Gordo (Mr. Edgerton), an old classmate of Simons. The relationship the couple maintains with Gordo is uncomfortable at best.

title: Shipping News
description: An old canal gets a new channel.

title: The Coolest Look This Season: All That Came Before
description: From 70s floral-print suits to 40s-era net hats, from oversize shearlings to logo sweatshirts, the current, decade-spanning style of today alludes to the past.

title: Things to Do in Westchester, Aug. 9 to 15, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Reducing Skyscraper Sway
description: Mass dampers are added to slender skyscrapers to reduce their sway in high winds.

title: An N.W.A. Biopic Heads Straight Into Mainstream
description: N.W.A., the group that brought gangster rap to the mainstream, angering conservatives and the F.B.I. along the way, burned hot and fast. The core group as its remembered today  Dr. Dre, Ice Cube, Eazy-E, MC Ren, DJ Yella  was together for only about two years, and in total the group lasted for maybe five, from the late 1980s to early 90s.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Aug. 7
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of a projection on the Empire State Building, closing parishes and a wet walk with dry cleaning.

title: Movie Review: The Fantastic Four
description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews The Fantastic Four.

title: Back-to-Work Must-Haves and Summer's Last Hurrah
description: Elegant classics, a capsule collection from Nick Wooster, a minimalist bathing suit and more.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, Aug. 9 to 15, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Revisiting Ferguson and the Death of Michael Brown
description: Whitney Curtis returned to Ferguson, Mo., to see what has changed, and hasnt, since police shot the teenager, setting off vigils and volatility.

title: An Ecuadorean Horseman at Bemelmans Bar
description: Luis Serrano grew up in Ecuador with a love for horses and the idea that he would become a veterinarian. He ended up wearing the crisp red jacket at Bemelmans Bar, the Carlyle hotels elegant drinking spot on the Upper East Side, where he is currently the longest-tenured bartender, having served drinks there for 22 years.

title: Review: Holden Explores the Distance That Killing Requires
description: Holden, a new play written and directed by Anisa George, occupies a claustrophobic realm: a one-room cabin into which four intense men are crammed, bounded by slowly growing walls of chopped firewood.

title: Review: In Sneaky Pete and Casanova, a Fast Talker and a Smooth Talker
description: Judging Sneaky Pete, which stars Giovanni Ribisi as a con man and recent ex-con hiding out in upstate New York, has a lot to do with context. As an Amazon pilot  its one of two, along with Casanova, going up on Friday  it looks kind of ordinary, surprisingly like a broadcast network drama. Semi-episodic, slightly procedural, light dusting of dark humor.

title: Isabella Rossellini on Her Mother Ingrid Bergmans Enduring Style
description: This is how I look, take it or leave it, said the Swedish film star Ingrid Bergman, perhaps the first natural actress of the Golden Era. (When the film producer David Selznick suggested a Hollywood makeover  change her name, pluck her eyebrows and fix her teeth  right before her debut in 1939, she refused.) This year, Bergmans legacy will be honored in a centennial celebration opening at the Museum of Modern Art on her bittersweet birthday, Aug. 29, which is also the day she died at age 67 in 1982. The 14-film retrospective spans Bergmans 50-year career, including her starring roles in Casablanca and Hitchcocks Notorious.

title: Why Hamilton Has Heat
description: Whats the story behind a show thats become a Broadway must-see with no marquee names, no special effects and almost no white actors? Erik Piepenburg explains, in six snapshots, why Hamilton has become such a big deal.

title: Short Game
description: Whether theyre Boy Scout cargo-style or fashion-designer formal, nothing exposes a man to more judgment and ridicule than wearing shorts.

title: Why Putting a Number to C.E.O. Pay Might Bring Change
description: It is a confounding truth about outsize executive pay  all past attempts to rein it in have failed.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, Aug. 9 to 15, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Disorderly Conduct
description: James Draplins favorite things.

title: By the Sea Trailer Is Released, Featuring Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie Pitt
description: In the new Angelina Jolie Pitt film, there seems to be a lot less combat, but still plenty of suffering. After directing two tense movies set in wartime, Ms. Pitt has now written and directed the drama By the Sea, for which the teaser trailer was released today. She stars in it with her husband, Brad Pitt  their first on-screen pairing since Mr. and Mrs. Smith in 2007.

title: The Jeter of Yankee Stadium Cameramen
description: As soon as Eric Capstick appeared in an upper deck of Yankee Stadium, camera on his shoulder, the fans began clamoring as if Derek Jeter had suddenly returned from retirement.

title: A Design Gurus Work Lair
description: Aaron James Draplin

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Theater Listings for Aug. 7-13
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Studies of Nepal Quake Raise Concern About Skyscrapers
description: In April, as email alerts ricocheted with the news that a large earthquake had shaken Nepal near its capital, Kathmandu, experts somberly expected a toll comparable to the roughly 85,000 who died in 2005 when a smaller earthquake struck a more sparsely populated area in the Kashmir region.

title: Review: Ricki and the Flash Puts Meryl Streep Behind a Telecaster
description: Ricki and the Flash, a gentle-hearted baby boomer guilt-trip family drama directed by Jonathan Demme and written by Diablo Cody, is bookended by two musical performances from the rock n roll bar band that gives the movie its name. It would be a spoiler to say too much about the number that ends the movie, a Bruce Springsteen cover, but the opener, sung to a sparse, appreciative audience at a scruffy club in Tarzana, Calif., is a competent version of an old hit by Tom Petty. (If that name doesnt ring a bell, go ask your dad.) Ricki, the lead singer, sporting a blue Telecaster, heavy eyeliner and half of Bo Dereks haircut from 10 (ask your dad about that too), belts out the lyrics with perfect credibility, landing somewhere between Chrissie Hynde and Bonnie Raitt on the spectrum of available reference points.

title: A Steve Jobs Opera Is Up Next for the Santa Fe Company
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  Just dont call it iOpera. The Santa Fe Opera has announced that its next commissioned work will be The (R)evolution of Steve Jobs, with music by Mason Bates, known for combining electronic sounds and traditional instruments, and a libretto by Mark Campbell.

title: Review: Cold Mountain, at Santa Fe Opera, Recounts a Separated Lovers Arduous Journey
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  Its quite a ways from here to western North Carolina, where Charles Frazier set his 1997 novel, Cold Mountain. And its quite a different landscape out there, too.

title: Movie Review: Ricki and the Flash
description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews Ricki and the Flash.

title: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
description: France and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Brooks Brothers Discontinuing Black Fleece Collection
description: Devotees of Black Fleece, Thom Brownes collection for Brooks Brothers, should hurry to stores to stock up. Claudio Del Vecchio, the Brooks Brothers chief executive, confirmed in a phone interview on Thursday that the Black Fleece line will be discontinued following the fall 2015 season, though he did not rule out the option of reviving it, potentially without Mr. Browne, in the future.

title: August 6, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from France, United States, Macedonia and El Salvador.

title: This Weeks Movies | August 7, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Ricki and the Flash, Diary of a Teenage Girl and Fantastic Four.

title: Review: Drawing Waves and Borne Frieze, a Robin Rhode Twofer
description: For the South African artist Robin Rhode, drawing is never enough. He draws on gallery walls, then throws his body against the images hes made, or drags his hands through the fresh chalk or charcoal. He draws in public places, in choreographed acts or in improvised, highly physical exertions. Drawing is not a stand-alone artistic medium; it forms part of a constellation of techniques, from performance to photography and video, which in turn informs a larger cluster of concerns, from his own childhood to the politics of urban space.

title: A Facebook for Watch Geeks
description: Kevin Rose, the Digg founder and Silicon Valley wunderkind, remembers the pushback he got in young-tech circles when he started wearing his late fathers Rolex a few years ago.

title: At Givenchy in Paris, Toughness and Light
description: The Givenchy mens store in Paris shows off its mix of haute history and sharp detailing.

title: 25 Years After Gardner Museum Heist, Video Raises Questions
description: BOSTON  In 1990, Richard Abath was a 23-year-old self-described hippie and guitarist for a rock band named Ukiah who, while moonlighting as a security guard, allowed two thieves posing as police officers to enter the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum here.

title: How Cats Took Over the Internet at the Museum of the Moving Image
description: WHILE its not true that 15 percent of all Internet traffic is cat-related, as the Friskies cat food company asserted in 2013, it does make a convincing urban legend.

title: Review: Paintings by George Stubbs Travel to the Met
description: New York should be grateful that the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven is closed for renovations. As a result, eight canvases by the inimitable English painter George Stubbs, one of the great artists of the 18th century, have been lent to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Works by Stubbs are scarce in this town: The Met has one painting, and theres a drawing at the Frick Collection. This makes Paintings by George Stubbs From the Yale Center for British Art a rare and thrilling treat.

title: Elaine de Kooning and Andreas Gursky in Close-Up in the Hamptons
description: Decades before the East End in Long Island became a crowded mecca for summertime vacationers, the Hamptons and their neighboring villages were quiet, rural getaways for artists, from the American Impressionists of the late 19th and early 20th centuries to the Pop artists of the 60s. Visual art still has a lively presence in the area, as viewers can discover at two of the regions pre-eminent destinations.

title: Heavy on Top
description: To keep skinny skyscrapers from swaying when high winds blow, giant counterweights are placed at the top. To get an idea of how much heft is required, consider the following equivalents.

title: Review: Call Me Lucky, About the Comedian-Activist Barry Crimmins
description: Call Me Lucky, Bobcat Goldthwaits documentary portrait of his professional mentor, the political comedian Barry Crimmins, is an earnest homage that also honors Mr. Crimminss crusade to drive child pornography off the Internet.

title: Review: Mostly Mozart, Highlighted by Sol Gabettas Haunting Vocalise
description: It was a good night Wednesday for avid followers of the Mostly Mozart festival. The main event was the concert of the festival orchestra in Avery Fisher Hall, featuring the New York debut of the young German conductor Cornelius Meister and the Mostly Mozart debut of the Argentine cellist Sol Gabetta. It was preceded by a recital from the piano duo Anderson & Roe in the hall and followed by a Little Night Music recital in the Kaplan Penthouse, performed by Ms. Gabetta and the pianist Ilya Yakushev.

title: Daily Show Fans on Jon Stewarts Legacy
description: Fans of the Daily Show waiting for the taping of Jon Stewarts final episode share their thoughts on the hosts 16 years, and the legacy he leaves.

title: As Egypt Unveils Its New Suez Canal, Dissenters Make Voices Heard Online
description: As Egypts government congratulated itself on Thursday at the very grand opening of a new side channel to the Suez Canal, the reaction on social networks to the televised pageantry was divided between praise for President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi from his supporters and jeers from his critics.

title: At Givenchys Mens Shop in Paris, the Two Sides of Riccardo Tisci
description: There is a certain, redoubtable logic to fishing where the fish are. Thus, the Marais  Pariss gay mecca, the rough equivalent in demography (if not style) of New Yorks Chelsea or West Hollywood in Los Angeles  has lately been filling with designer stores catering to the stylish men who fill its streets. Along the Rue des Archives are mens boutiques from Gucci, Fendi, Moncler and, at No. 13, Givenchy.

title: Review: In Cop Car, a Joyride by 2 Runaway Boys Takes a Wrong Turn
description: When the 10-year-old heroes of Cop Car first see the cruiser in question, its parked unattended in a field, ready to be plucked like a daisy. Travis (James Freedson-Jackson) and Harrison (Hays Wellford) make a fine pair of pipsqueaks, and theyre on a great journey when they find the car, having run away from home that same day. They have no real reason or complaint or plans, just a single piece of beef jerky and a boys own sense of adventure.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Aug. 7-13
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for Aug. 7-13
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events. Ben Allison Quintet (Tuesday through Aug. 15) Mr. Allison is a resourceful bassist, bandleader and composer, and for this run he celebrates the great jazz guitarist Jim Hall, who died in 2013. Hell have excellent personnel for the task: the guitarist Steve Cardenas, the trumpeter Jeremy Pelt, the pianist Frank Kimbrough and the drummer Rudy Royston. At 8:30 and 11 p.m., Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, 212-581-3080, birdlandjazz.com. (Nate Chinen)

title: Men's Swimwear Gets a Slimmer Silhouette
description: Mens fashion designers trade in the baggy board shorts look for shorter, tailored swim trunks.

title: Classical & Opera Listings for Aug. 7-13
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Memories of Tanglewood on Its 75th Birthday
description: LENOX, Mass.  The conductor Andris Nelsons was coaxing the students in the Tanglewood Music Center Orchestra into a Mahlerian frenzy: crouching low during quiet passages, leaping at fortissimos, exhorting them to play with meaning and passion and fervor.

title: Comedy Listings for Aug. 7-13
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.
