description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: Franoise Grossen, a Fabric Artist Inspired by Other Fields
description: FRANOISE GROSSEN

title: Review: Kahlil Gibrans The Prophet Turns Essays Into a Family Movie
description: The burning question during my freshman year in college was whether The Prophet, a slim volume of poetic essays by the early-20th-century Lebanese writer and artist Kahlil Gibran, was more spiritually profound than Captain Beefhearts seminal album, Trout Mask Replica. I still havent decided.

title: Review: The Last Party Celebrates New York Club Culture
description: THE LAST PARTY

title: Review: In No Two Alike, George Ohrs Pottery Plays on Convention
description: GEORGE OHR POTTERY

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Aug. 7-13
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: The Most Important Audience in the G.O.P. Debate? Its Not the Voters
description: There are four audiences for the G.O.P. debate Thursday night  voters, donors, party leaders, media members  and they are not equal in importance.

title: Theodore Roosevelt on How You Kill a Lion
description: 106 YEARS AGO

title: Spare Times for Aug. 7-13
description: Museums and Sites

title: Great Jazz on the Great Hill, and Club Fare in Harlem and the Village
description: Jazz is as synonymous with New York City as the Empire State Building or the Statue of Liberty. On any given night, live jazz options abound for nearly all preferences and budgets.

title: Review: God Bless the Child Follows Neglected Siblings at Play
description: Directed by Robert Machoian and Rodrigo Ojeda-Beck, God Bless the Child poignantly illustrates what busy, tired parents have told bored offspring for years: You have to make your own fun. This extraordinary movie immerses us in the playtime of five California siblings abandoned to their own devices.

title: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 7-13
description: Captain Marys Story Hour

title: The Green Book Legacy, a Beacon for Black Travelers
description: Starting in 1936, Victor Hugo Green, a letter carrier who lived in Manhattan, published the Negro Motorist Green Book, listing hotels, restaurants and other businesses where African-Americans would not only be welcome but also safe. The Green Book series rather diplomatically described Jim Crow-era experiences with racist business owners as painful embarrassments suffered which ruined a vacation or business trip.

title: Antique Lacquered Furnitures Odd Ingredients
description: Scientists have detected some surprising ingredients in pieces of lacquered furniture that will soon go on view at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston and the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam.

title: Before Main Republican Debate, Bottom 7 Contenders Put On Brave Faces
description: CLEVELAND  They called it the undercard. The kiddie table. The happy hour debate.

title: Buccaneers Offer Women a Modern N.F.L. Lesson Out of the 50s
description: Well, this must be a relief for all the women out there who lose sleep during football season wondering, What delicious snack can I whip up for this weekends N.F.L. games, and what is the appropriate (and possibly color-coordinated) handmade centerpiece to accompany it?

title: Review: Homme Less Follows a Homeless Middle-Age Model-Photographer
description: Poignancy and pathos distinguish Thomas Wirthensohns polished documentary, Homme Less, a portrait of Mark Reay, a former model struggling as a photographer. The New Jersey-born Mr. Reay had a moment more than 20 years ago, posing for shoots in Europe. Now in his 50s, he entreats Marc Jacobs for work by leaving a photo of the designer at his office; talks women into posing for him on the street; and works as a day player on movie sets. But the title derives from Mr. Reays nightly shelter: an East Village rooftop, where he sleeps under a tarpaulin.

title: Final Biker Is Sentenced in Assault on S.U.V. Driver
description: A state judge sentenced the last of the motorcyclists convicted of attacking a driver in Upper Manhattan to three and a half years in prison on Thursday after the defendant gave a tearful apology in court.

title: The Washington Hostess Who Nurtured Warhol
description: Ina Ginsburg, the Washington patron of the arts and fund-raiser who died in November at 98, befriended some of the most powerful politicians and celebrities of her era. Famously, in 1975, she held a dinner for Andy Warhol at her house in Washington, despite warnings from some of her friends.

title: Review: The Runner Stars Nicolas Cage as a Politician After an Oil Spill
description: In The Runner, a political drama without much drama, Nicolas Cage plays a Louisiana congressman, Colin Pryce, whose personal choices  too much alcohol, an affinity for extramarital affairs  make him thoroughly unlikable and a walking clich. Its difficult to feel the sympathy for him that Austin Stark, who wrote and directed, wants us to feel.

title: Hamilton
description: Scenes from the Broadway musical about the founding fathers.

title: Review: Assassination, With Twists and Hired Guns in 1930s Seoul and Shanghai
description: ASSASSINATION

title: Review: In Sneakerheadz, an Obsession Over Something More Than Footwear
description: Footwear enthusiasts left wanting by The Rise of Sneaker Culture, an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum this summer, can continue exploring that snug niche in Sneakerheadz, an unrelated, fans-only documentary.

title: Excerpt: Hamilton
description: The cast of the Broadway musical performing the number The Schuyler Sisters.

title: Review: Hamilton, Young Rebels Changing History and Theater
description: Yes, it really is that good.

title: Missouri Governor Calls for Improved Police Training
description: Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri called on Thursday for improved training for law enforcement officers in his state, including more education on fair and impartial policing and helping mentally ill residents.

title: Ackman Bets on Mondelez Going on Sale
description: By putting $5.5 billion into Mondelez International, a hedge fund billionaire is wagering that the company, which makes Oreos, Cadbury chocolates and Trident gum, could be prodded into selling itself.

title: On the Town to Close on Broadway
description: The Tony Award-nominated revival of the musical On the Town will end its Broadway run at the Lyric Theater on Sept. 6, the producers of the show announced on Thursday. The musical will go out with a big ballet bang: the ballerina Misty Copeland, who this summer became the first African-American woman to be named a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will make her Broadway debut in the show for two weeks beginning on Aug. 25, replacing Megan Fairchild, for 12 performances through Sept. 6.

title: 200 Migrants Are Believed Drowned in Capsizing Off Libya
description: CAIRO  About 200 migrants are believed to have drowned off the coast of Libya when their boat capsized, the United Nations refugee agency said Thursday.

title: The Never-Ending Lawsuit Against 2 Former A.I.G. Executives
description: Charles Dickens invented the interminable estate dispute Jarndyce v. Jarndyce for Bleak House, his 1853 novel. In real life, the Federal Trade Commission once took 16 years to force Carters Little Liver Pills to drop the word Liver. And antitrust regulators spent 13 years on a case against IBM before the Reagan administration dropped it abruptly.

title: As Temperatures Rise in Phoenix, Hikers Embrace Heat on a Grueling Ascent
description: PHOENIX  Summer has a smothering presence here, with its punishing triple-digit temperatures that turn parked cars into ovens so hot one can bake cookies on the dashboard. (Yes, it happens.) It triggers a modified hibernation  it is heat that keeps people indoors.

title: George Cole, 90, British TV Star, Dies; Played a Young Scrooge in 51 Film
description: George Cole, a British actor who as the young Scrooge foreshadowed Alastair Sims aging, coldhearted moneylender in a celebrated film version of A Christmas Carol, and who later developed a following as British televisions favorite rogue, died on Wednesday in Reading, England. He was 90.

title: Letters: The Rediscovered Manuscript
description: To the Editor:

title: Life or Death for Colorado Theater Gunman Now in Jurors Hands
description: CENTENNIAL, Colo.  After 15 weeks in court and testimony from more than 300 witnesses, lawyers in the trial of James E. Holmes rested their cases on Thursday. A jury will now decide whether to sentence him to death or to send him to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

title: President Reflects on Voting Rights Act
description: At a White House event commemorating the 50th anniversary of the Voting Rights Act, President Obama said there were still too many ways in which people are discouraged from voting.

title: Obama Urges Restoring Voting Rights Provisions
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama used the 50th anniversary of the Voting Rights Act on Thursday to urge Congress to restore key elements of the law, arguing that court decisions and state statutes that discourage certain kinds of folks from voting are threatening to erode the fundamental promise of the civil rights-era bulwark.

title: A Troubled Jockeys Full Legacy Is on Display
description: Natalie Jowett Antley does not know what she will say about her late husband, Chris Antley, when she speaks at the National Museum of Racings Hall of Fame on Friday. She has been worried more about how her daughter will hold up when the father who died before she was born will be recognized as one of the greatest jockeys of all time.

title: $25,000 Fine Proposed in Taxi Drivers Snub of Black Family
description: The taxi lurched away from the curb in Midtown Manhattan, leaving behind a black family of three who had flagged it down on their way to a birthday dinner 10 blocks away. The driver, Baqir Raza, told them he had to go off duty to use the bathroom, the family said, and then picked up two white women nearby and drove away.

title: Connecticut to Require All 11th Graders to Take the SAT
description: Connecticut announced on Thursday that all 11th graders in the states public schools would soon be required to take the SAT college admissions tests, replacing an existing statewide exam amid widespread concern that the nations students are tested too much.

title: The Republican Candidates Onstage
description: The 10 leading contenders for the presidential nomination held their first debate, in Cleveland.

title: Seeing California Through Agns Vardas Lens, in a Criterion Set
description: Agns Varda is often associated with the French New Wave, but this paradoxical filmmaker, tough-minded yet whimsical, is more a one-woman vanguard. Eccentricity is her norm.

title: Trial Starts for Argentine Ex-President in 94 Bombing of Jewish Center
description: BUENOS AIRES  Argentinas labyrinthine investigation into the suicide bombing of a Jewish community center here two decades ago began a new chapter on Thursday with the start of a trial in which Carlos Menem, a former president, is accused of trying to derail the case.

title: Giants Jameel McClain Hurt
description: Middle linebacker Jameel McClain, who had a serious neck injury three years ago but came back to lead the Giants in tackles last season, will be sidelined indefinitely with a new neck injury that he sustained in a training camp practice on Wednesday in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: New York City Initiative Aims to Help Mentally Ill People Who Get Violent
description: Mental health experts will fan out to New York Citys homeless shelters, into the streets and to other places to treat mentally ill people who exhibit violent behavior, as part of an initiative announced on Thursday by Mayor Bill de Blasio.

title: Put in a Solid Effort
description: Administrivial Win Valuable Prizes Alert! Just a reminder that Lollapuzzoola 8 is Saturday, and I highly recommend attending if you plan to be in New York City. Even if youre not, theres still time to sign up for the play at home division. Click here for more information.

title: Carol Brown Janeway, Translator and Executive, Dies at 71
description: Carol Brown Janeway, a Scottish-born publishing executive, editor and award-winning translator who introduced American readers to dozens of international authors, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 71.

title: Weinstein Company Announces Promotions to Replace Departed Executives
description: LOS ANGELES  Next year, the Weinstein Company is expected to release a comic film caper called Army of One.

title: Tentative Labor Pact Reached With New York Firefighters Union
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a tentative agreement on Thursday with the New York City firefighters union for a seven-year labor pact that includes retroactive raises for firefighters, new disability pension protections and increased staffing for 20 of the Fire Departments roughly 200 engine companies by 2019.

title: Chuck Schumer Opposes Iran Nuclear Deal, Shaking Democratic Firewall
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Chuck Schumer, the most influential Jewish voice in Congress, said Thursday night that he would oppose President Obamas deal to limit Irans nuclear program.

title: Mission: Impossible, The Man From U.N.C.L.E and How They Diverge
description: The two TV espionage shows, now both on big screens, share pages from the spy-movie playbook.

title: C. C. Sabathia Is Back to Vintage Form as Yankees Edge Red Sox
description: The scene grew tense at Yankee Stadium, or at least as tense as the fifth inning of a tie game against a last-place team can seem in early August. The Yankees were facing their archrivals, the Boston Red Sox, and the bases were loaded for David Ortiz.

title: Readers Share Their Essential Jon Stewart Moments From The Daily Show
description: In anticipation of Jon Stewarts final night behind the Daily Show desk, we picked nine essential moments from his 16-year run.

title: NBC Sports Group Adds Premier League Games to USA Networks Lineup
description: Just as it is trying to keep its English Premier League rights, the NBC Sports Group said Thursday that it will carry 40 weekend games on the USA Network, adding to the matches that will continue on NBC and NBCSN. The first match on USA will be Saturday between Everton and Watford at 10 a.m. Eastern, the time that most USA games will compete against a game on NBCSN.

title: Iran: Jewish Newspaper Was Granted Visa in Rare Move
description: Iran granted an unusual short-term reporting visa last month to The Jewish Daily Forward, one of the most widely read and respected newspapers among American Jews.

title: News Coverage After Debates Matters More Than You Might Think
description: Can debates like the one tonight move poll results? Yes, but not in the way you might think.

title: A Foxy, Rowdy Republican Debate
description: The first question to Chris Christie was about the nine credit downgrades that New Jersey had suffered since he became its governor.

title: Two Large Puerto Rico Bondholders Demand Full Payment
description: Two mutual fund companies that hold Puerto Ricos bonds have written to senior officials on the island, demanding full payment on bonds that defaulted early this week.

title: Rivals Jab at Donald Trump as Republican Debate Becomes Testy
description: Shedding any pretense of civility and party unity, Donald J. Trump overwhelmed the first Republican presidential debate on Thursday night by ripping into his rivals and the moderators alike, but also drew fire from Jeb Bush and others who are seeking to stop his breathtaking surge.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Alice Waters
description: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The latest installment in the series comes from Alice Waters chef, author, restaurant owner and slow-food pioneer  who shares her picks exclusively with T.

title: From an Unfussy New Orleans Cafe, a Summer Cobbler
description: Back in 2003, the Southern-born pastry chef Kelly Fields approached her boss, the beloved blue-eyed New Orleans chef and James Beard Award-winner John Besh, about opening a bakery. Then Hurricane Katrina hit, putting Fieldss plans on hold while the city picked itself back up again. At Beshs urging, she traveled the world in the meantime, gathering culinary inspiration in Italy, Egypt and throughout the Middle East before settling back in New Orleans and holding the title of executive pastry chef at his culinary empire there. And finally this week, over a decade after she first conceived it, Fields opened the doors to Willa Jean, an unfussy corner bakery and cafe in the up-and-coming South Market District.

title: Jon Stewart Signs Off From Daily Show With Wit and Sincerity
description: After 16 years of taking satirical aim at the hypocrisy of politics and the fatuousness of the news media, Jon Stewart said goodbye to The Daily Show on Thursday evening with a farewell broadcast that mixed wry parting shots with earnest displays of emotion and with a passionate speech urging his audience not to accept falsehoods and misinformation in their lives.

title: Jon Stewart Cements His Legacy in Daily Show Finale
description: As late-night talk show finales go, Jon Stewarts wasnt exactly a knockout, but it did have two moments that will stand the test of time.

title: Word of the Day | imperious
description: imperious  \im-pir-e-s\  adjective

title: Winners at the G.O.P. Debate Did Not Include Bush and Trump
description: Winning a primary debate isnt about having the best one-liners or drawing the biggest applause.

title: Donald Trump Steals the Show,Mixing Politics and Pizazz
description: Donald J. Trump was outrageous. He was demeaning. He was even somewhat menacing, warning a female moderator that he could turn on her at any moment.

title: Trump Wins the Airtime Contest in the Republican Debate
description: Donald J. Trump had more airtime than any other candidate, and twice as much time as Senator Rand Paul.

title: Whats On TV Friday
description: 10 P.M. (Starz Edge) FROZEN (2013) Warm up your vocal cords: This Disney movie musical produced Let It Go, the Oscar-winning power anthem written by the married songwriters Kristen Anderson-Lopez and Robert Lopez. Chris Buck and Jennifer Lee directed this fable about Elsa, above (the voice of Idina Menzel), an ice princess cursed with a frigid touch, and Anna (Kristen Bell), her younger sister and best friend. When Anna falls for a prince (Santino Fontana), Elsa forbids them to marry, casting their Scandinavian kingdom into eternal winter with a wave of her hand. Horrified, she retreats to an ice palace, but sibling love sends Anna plowing through drifts and up glacial ridges in search of Elsa, confident that she can reverse the spell. Allegorically, Frozen lacks the purity and elemental power of a classic myth like Beauty and the Beast, but at least its storytelling is fairly coherent, and its gleaming dream world of snow and ice is one of the most visually captivating environments to be found in a Disney animated film, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this blockbuster, inspired by Hans Christian Andersens The Snow Queen.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Is this going to be a tearing apart, or a pivot point of people trying to understand each other, trying to live together?

title: Corrections: August 7, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The Republicans Take the Stage in Cleveland
description: Seventeen candidates gathered in Ohio to take part in two separate debates hosted by Fox News.

title: U.N. Security Council Adopts Measure to Identify Chlorine Bomb Users in Syria
description: The United Nations Security Council took a major step on Friday in holding chemical weapons users in the Syria war accountable, adopting a resolution to create an investigating panel to identify them.

title: Moments From the First G.O.P. Debate
description: The Times reporter Adam Nagourney analyzes key moments from the first Republican presidential debate on Thursday.

title: Taiwan Braces for Arrival of Typhoon Soudelor
description: Taiwan prepared on Friday for the arrival of a typhoon, which had weakened somewhat but was still likely to batter the islands eastern coast with heavy rains and powerful winds.

title: Back to Ferguson, a Year After Michael Brown
description: Whitney Curtis has covered Ferguson, Mo., for The New York Times since the day Michael Brown was shot and killed by a local police officer a year ago. Her photos of the protests that followed were published on the front page of The Times, and in many other publications around the world. And theywere featured on Lens.

title: Student Crossword | The American Revolution
description: Test your knowledge of the American Revolution by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Missing the Warnings on Legionnaires Disease
description: The recent outbreak of Legionnaires disease in the Bronx, the largest in New York Citys history, shows how little is known about the cooling towers for air-conditioning systems that are the main incubators of the disease-causing bacteria. Even more dismaying has been the citys sluggishness in responding to early-warning signs of a potential health problem.

title: As the Arctic Thaws, New Temptations
description: Russia made a formal claim to a vast stretch of Arctic territory on Tuesday before the United Nations committee that oversees sea boundaries. The move is, in itself, neither surprising nor threatening.

title: From Trump on Down, the Republicans Cant Be Serious
description: This was, according to many commentators, going to be the election cycle Republicans got to show off their deep bench. The race for the nomination would include experienced governors like Jeb Bush and Scott Walker, fresh thinkers like Rand Paul, and attractive new players like Marco Rubio. Instead, however, Donald Trump leads the field by a wide margin. What happened?

title: The Real Voter Fraud Is Texas ID Law
description: For years, voter identification laws have been sold as a sensible antidote to fraud at the polls. Many people, including Supreme Court justices, have bought that fallacious line, even though in-person fraud is essentially nonexistent.

title: 3 U.S. Defeats: Vietnam, Iraq and Now Iran
description: The purpose of war, military or economic, is to get your enemy to do something it would rather not do. Over the past several years the United States and other Western powers have engaged in an economic, clandestine and political war against Iran to force it to give up its nuclear program.

title: How Joe Biden Is Already Running for President
description: Is Joe Biden running for president? Effectively yes, even though he is not yet a declared candidate.

title: Afghan Wars Convenient Myth: A Living Mullah Omar
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban, it turns out, had been sending the world messages from a dead man. And the world kept answering him.

title: Kerry Tells Vietnam That U.S. Ties Will Deepen if Human Rights Are Protected
description: HANOI, Vietnam  Secretary of State John Kerry told a group of Vietnamese officials and business leaders on Friday that improvements in human rights here would lead to deeper ties.

title: Waves of Suicide Attacks Shake Kabul on Its Deadliest Day of 2015
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A barrage of deadly suicide attacks killed at least 65 people and wounded hundreds more in Kabul on Friday, ending a two-month lull in major terrorist strikes in the capital, according to Afghan officials. It was the deadliest day in Kabul so far this year.

title: Keeping Skyscrapers From Blowing in the Wind
description: Fueled by a scarcity of land and by demand from multimillionaires willing to pay record prices for helicopter views of Central Park and beyond, Manhattan developers are building ever taller, ever thinner apartment buildings on ever tinier lots. Clustered mostly in and around West 57th Street, these skinny skyscrapers are reaching heights of more than 1,000 feet.

title: Do the Democrats Understand Americas New Racial Politics?
description: Last Friday, during a speech before a virtually all-black audience at the National Urban League Conference, the presidential candidate Hillary Clinton lauded the young African-American protesters who have taken to the streets, dignified and determined, urging us to affirm the basic fact that black lives matter. Clintons two Democratic opponents, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and former Gov. Martin OMalley of Maryland, spoke at the same event; they, too, invoked the hashtag slogan.

title: Job Growth Steady in July, Possibly Easing Path for Fed Action
description: The American economy delivered pretty much what was expected last month in terms of hiring, giving the Federal Reserve one more piece of evidence that conditions are strong enough to support an increase in the interest rate.

title: Wanted: A Driver in Brooklyn. Must Use Care in Icy Conditions.
description: An ad posted online last month said that Barclays Center was looking to hire an assistant manager of arena operations to help with planning and implementation of associated work tasks.

title: Petrobras Oil Scandal Leaves Brazilians Lamenting a Lost Dream
description: Alberto Youssef, a convicted money launderer and former bon vivant, sat in a Brazilian jail cell in March of last year, getting ready to tell his lawyers a story. It was about an elaborate bribery scheme involving Petrobras, the government-controlled oil giant. He opened with a dire prediction.

title: How the Republican Candidates Fared in the First Debate
description: The rambunctious presidential debate Thursday night left some Republican candidates shining and others stung. Here are some highlights and low lights from the prime-time showdown.

title: Its Time to Compensate Kidney Donors
description: Second of two articles

title: Flight 370 Victims Families Voice Anger
description: Relatives of passengers on the missing Malaysia Airlines flight criticized Malaysias handling of the case in Beijing.

title: Fridays News: A Run Around Kilimanjaro, and Other Outdoor Travel News
description: Our weekday morning digest that includes information about outdoor activities and events, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Walking vs. Elliptical Machine, Redux
description: Question:

title: The Book That Became the Little House Books
description: There is no better get for the true Little House geek than a hard-to-find copy of Pioneer Girl: The Annotated Autobiography by Laura Ingalls Wilder, edited by Pamela Smith Hill.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: New York Today: Urban Jungle
description: Good morning on this sun-dappled Friday.

title: Fox News Moderators Bring a Sharpened Edge to the Republican Debate Stage
description: CLEVELAND  Dredging up old misstatements. Questioning someones temperamental fitness to be president. Suggesting that someone else might let a woman die rather than allow her to have an abortion.

title: Teenagers in The Times | July 2015
description: Moth Collective animation from A Kiss Deferred by Civil War, part of The Timess Modern Love series of weekly reader-submitted essays that explore the joys and tribulations of love.

title: North Korea to Move 30 Minutes Backward to Create Its Own Time Zone
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea, a hermetic country stuck in the Cold War and obsessed with its long-dead founder, now wants to turn back time.

title: News Qs | Rivals Jab at Donald Trump as Republican Debate Becomes Testy
description: Note: Weve updated 6 Qs About the News for the new school year. This feature, now known as News Qs, will be a daily mini-lesson, with both Before Reading and After Reading questions, and a suggested activity for going further. Let us know what you think.

title: Today in Politics: Debates Give Those Fighting for Traction a Chance to Gain a Footing
description: Good Friday morning from Washington. It has been only a few hours since 17 Republicans gathered in two debates in an effort to stand apart. As expected, the big names remained big, but a few lesser-known candidates found a way to rise above the crowded field, at least for a night.

title: The 7.26.15 Issue
description: RE: CHRISTIANS

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Berlin

title: How to Project Power
description: Keep your limbs away from your body, says Deborah H Gruenfeld, a social psychologist who teaches at Stanford University. Some research shows that people posed in expansive postures feel more powerful, exhibit higher testosterone levels and have lower levels of the stress hormone cortisol  all characteristics of high-ranking social status. Make eye contact while youre talking, but feel free to look away when others do. This is what scientists call having a high look-speak to look-listen ratio, which is common for dominant members of groups.

title: Written by Himself
description: There is so much to pay attention to in this poem: the rich and varied allusions; the use of repetition at the beginnings and endings of its sentences; the rhythm in the making and breaking of its pattern; and the idea of a personal mythology, a song of the self that, in its expansiveness, might stand for us all.

title: Hes Got Legs
description: Up above the hems of a proper pair of trousers  above the ankle-baring ends of high-waters and clam-diggers, above the shin-skimming edges of pants named for the isle of Capri and for the gauchos of the Pampas  are the knees. Bared by shorts, they point us toward a few truths about social standards. Womens legs are tangled in their own sex-segregated history of social control and gender politics; shorts are, first off, short pants, and it was not so very long ago that women were told wearing pants of any length was prima facie evidence of moral turpitude. The man in shorts, meanwhile, occupies a space that is more subtly strange. Year after year, as surely as tender spring yields to scalding summer, a season of dress-code controversies gives way to a running conversation about the unwritten rules of urban spaces, with arbiters of taste cringing at mens legs in shorts as if wincing at a comedy of embarrassment.

title: Starring Vermouth
description: A few years ago, my brother asked me where I would like to spend my 40th birthday. I chose Spain, and he generously presented me with a plane ticket to Barcelona. I booked a sunny apartment with an abundance of colorful tiles. I got a ticket for an FC Barcelona match at Camp Nou. But in the weeks leading up to my birthday, my mothers health declined precipitously. I couldnt leave New York under the circumstances, and canceled the trip.

title: Off the Road
description: I never thought I was a car guy until the day my little blue Toyota truck died. In fact, on some level, I had contempt for guys who cared too much about what they drove. Proof that I didnt share their affliction, in my mind, was the fact that I had been driving the same beat-up base model Toyota pickup, with camper shell, for 23 years, ever since my father sold it to me for $4,000 in 1992.

title: Yankees C. C. Sabathia Grows Older, Wiser and, at Least for a Night, Stronger
description: In his first few years with the Yankees, when his fastball hummed as reliably as it did on Thursday against the Boston Red Sox, C. C. Sabathia made pitching sound so easy. All he did, he would say after starts, was pound the zone.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 9 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: Our Summer Reading Contest is now in its ninth, and penultimate, week. To participate, post a comment here by 7 a.m. Eastern on Aug. 14 and answer the question What interested you most in The Times this week?

title: Morning Agenda: Ackmans Bet on Mondelez Sales
description: ACKMANS BET ON MONDELEZ SALES | By building up a $5.5 billion stake in Mondelez International, William A. Ackman is wagering that Mondelez could be persuaded to sell itself, Michael J. de la Merced and Alexandra Stevenson write in DealBook. The investment that Mr. Ackmans Pershing Square Capital Management has made also highlights the widespread belief that the food sector is ripe for consolidation.

title: China Detains Lawyer Who Accused Police of Torture, His Wife Says
description: BEIJING  A Chinese lawyer who defied the authorities by speaking publicly about being tortured in police custody and who had become a vocal critic of a continuing government crackdown on human rights lawyers has been detained by the police, his wife said on Friday.

title: A Call to Cry Out Against Cross Removals in China
description: Over the past year and a half, the government of Zhejiang Province has forcibly removed hundreds of crosses from churches, part of a campaign by the local authorities to lower the profile of Christianity in a region where it has made deep inroads. The campaign has long met with protests by parishioners, but now it is also being denounced by government-approved Christian organizations. In early July, official Protestant and Catholic associations issued open letters questioning the campaigns legality.

title: Presidential Debate Fashions: Windows Into a Candidacy
description: On Thursday night voters got their first look at the 10 current leading Republican candidates in comparison to one another  literally. Ever since Richard Nixon met John F. Kennedy on the small screen in 1960, theres been little doubt that while its the substance of presidential debates that matters most, image and appearance can play a potentially significant role in swaying voter opinion (consciously or not). As a result, different schools of thoughts have developed on the best approach to the situation. The two most popular were on view last night, and like the candidates themselves, proved to have varying degrees of success.

title: Donald Trump Says Again He Remains Open to Independent Run
description: One of the more contentious moments of the first Republican presidential debate was when Donald J. Trump refused to rule out the possibility of a third party bid.

title: Gao Yu, Jailed Chinese Journalist, Is Said to Be Receiving Good Medical Care
description: Read in Chinese |

title: Suicide Blast Kills 8 in Afghanistan
description: The attacker detonated a deadly truck bomb near an army camp in the eastern part of the capital, Kabul, on Friday, officials said.

title: Video Reviews of Ricki and the Flash, Diary of a Teenage Girl and Fantastic Four
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Ricki and the Flash, Diary of a Teenage Girl and Fantastic Four. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Mike Huckabee Adds Levity to Debate, and Signals More to Come
description: Former Gov. Mike Huckabee hinted that he might ramp up his happy warrior act as his presidential campaign moves forward.

title: Verbatim: Hold Your Nose and Vote
description: Senator Lindsey Graham, promising on MSNBC to support whoever the Republican Party nominates for president.

title: Review: Compton, Dr. Dres First Album in 16 Years
description: Dr. Dre doesnt surface often  since N.W.A. disbanded in the early 1990s, hes released just two albums and supervised one compilation  but when he does, he exudes what feels like decades worth of tension.

title: A Brooklyn Grocerys Last Night
description: Dear Diary:

title: 1890: Electrical Execution Botched
description: NEW YORK  From one end of the country to the other there is nothing but expressions of indignation and horror at the method of Kemmlers execution and a demand from all classes that it should be the last scene of such horrors. Two curious points have been developed. It is supposed that 1,700 volts were applied to Kemmler, but twenty incandescent test lamps were by mistake left burning, consuming fifty volts each, leaving only 700 volts for the death of Kemmler, which was not enough to cause instant death.

title: In Katie Ledeckys Amazing Feats, Echoes of a Swimmer From the 1970s
description: KAZAN, Russia  The 5-foot-11 teenage freestyler with the reserved personality and the swimming range of an albatross won every final at the world championships from the 200 meters through the 1,500, thrilling the crowds inside the stadium while gun-toting soldiers patrolled outside.

title: The Republican Scrum Begins
description: My fantasy of the 2016 G.O.P. primary debate, regular readers may remember, involved a serious clash of ideas between Marco Rubio and Rand Paul, the two candidates who seemed as of six months ago, at least to be chartingthe most creative and interesting paths forward for a Republican Party thats lost the popular vote in five of the last six presidential contests. My worst-case scenario, on the other hand, basically involved a replay of 2012  an establishment candidate playing it as safe as possible while a group of would-be populists fought one another noisily but emptily for the chance to finish second.

title: The Doormans Dilemma: What to Do With All Those Packages?
description: As president of the board of his Midtown East co-op, Dennis Paget has reason to walk a little faster when a particular fellow resident comes into view. To do otherwise would mean enduring yet another stern lecture about the buildings supposedly dilatory parcel delivery service.

title: Kitchens of the Great Midwest, by J. Ryan Stradal
description: Larger than life is usually a clich, but in the case of Eva Thorvald  the 6-foot-2 mighty Aphrodite who strides through the pages of J. Ryan Stradals appealing first novel  the description is literally as well as metaphorically accurate. Born with a once-in-a-generation palate, Eva is a food prodigy. At 3 months old, she destroys a vegetable stand in pursuit of a perfect heirloom tomato; at 10, she runs a cottage industry from her bedroom closet, growing chocolate habanero peppers so incendiary that her client, the citys best Mexican restaurant, is forced to post a warning label on the menu; at 11, she earns extra cash from bar bets by consuming quantities of blistering chili and Circle of Hell chicken wings. Yet despite a life pockmarked by poverty and other adversities, Eva has an equally outsize heart. A warring mass of desires, talents and imperfections, shes an attractively flawed, completely likable demigoddess.

title: What Steve Jobs Taught Me About Being a Son and a Father
description: A couple of months ago, right after my first son was born, I thought about the lessons I wanted to pass along to him that I had learned a little late in life. Among the morals I scribbled down in my mind one that stood out began with a story involving Steve Jobs and ended with the serving of my mothers last meal.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Spicy Food, Running Shoes and Legionnaires Disease
description: Take the Quiz

title: Folk City: New York and the American Folk Music Revival
description: How New York City and specifically Greenwich Village came to be at the epicenter of an American folk music revival between 1950 and 1965 is the subject of Stephen Petrus and Ronald D. Cohens Folk City. This handsome book, which includes rarely seen photographs, reminiscences of participants and a lively narrative, adds depth to an exhibition of the same name on view at the Museum of the City of New York until January.

title: Why a Boring Jobs Report Is Great News for the Fed
description: Here is how to think about the July jobs numbers that the government released Friday morning: Whatever you thought about the economy, or financial markets or the proper course of Federal Reserve policy at 8:29 a.m., just before the numbers were released, you have every reason to have also believed it at 8:31 a.m., just after.

title: Hugh Thomass World Without End: Spain, Philip II, and the First Global Empire
description: When did the modern age begin? There is no shortage of contenders  from the fall of Constantinople to Columbuss arrival in the Americas to (my candidate) Vasco da Gamas projection of European power into Asia. In World Without End, Hugh Thomas stakes a claim for one more: an obscure 1559 peace treaty between Philip II, the Hapsburg king of Spain, and Henry II, the Valois king of France, that concluded a decades-old struggle for control of Italy.

title: Since Katrina
description: Ten years after Hurricane Katrinas historic devastation, we review several books this week about New Orleans. Over the course of that decade, David G. Spielman, a photographer in the Crescent City, has been recording the storms effects, collected in The Katrina Decade: Images of an Altered City.

title: Runner Nick Symmonds Faces Ban Over Gear
description: Nick Symmonds is a six-time outdoor national champion at 800 meters. He finished fifth at the 2012 London Olympics, in a personal best of 1 minute 42.95 seconds. And he has been named to the United States team for the world track and field championships this month in Beijing.

title: Daily Report: A Peek at the Future of Artificial Intelligence and Human Relationships
description: Two possible glimpses into the future arrived on Thursday, if you were looking for them.

title: Priceless Violin Found After 35 Years
description: Roman Totenbergs rare Stradivarius violin, stolen after a performance in 1980, was returned to the authorities this June.

title: Baby Dies After Fall From 4th-Floor Window in Queens, Police Say
description: Mazol Ilyayeva had just fed her baby before sunrise on Friday when she stepped out of her apartment in Queens to get some air. Then, she heard a thump.

title: Digging for Trashed Pictures in Macs Photos App
Inside the List
description: Carbon Footprints: The thriller writer C.J. Box (whose initials stand for Charles James, dashing your hopes that his full name was Cracker Jack Box) is best known for his series of gritty mysteries about the Wyoming game warden Joe Pickett. But in Badlands, a stand-alone suspense thriller new at No.5 on the hardcover fiction list, Box shifts his attention to North Dakota and the fracking boom; the book, set in the fictional oil town of Grimstad, N.D., is about a 12-year-old boy who witnesses a car accident on his paper route and makes off with the bundle of drugs and money he finds at the scene. As a child, Box had relatives who worked blue-collar jobs in the energy industry  The house I grew up in didnt have a single bookcase except mine, he once told a website devoted to crime fiction  and in this novel he pokes some fun at journalists who reflexively condemn big oil. They fly all the way here from the East Coast burning up jet fuel, the town sheriff grouses at one point, then rent cars and fill em with gasoline to drive all the way to Grimstad just so they can trot me out to say, Oil is bad. I wont play their game anymore. Box has observed reporters up close: He used to be one. My first job was working for a small Wyoming weekly newspaper, he told the same website, The Rap Sheet, in 2010. In retrospect, it was spectacular training in the real world for what was to come. I learned so much, and met so many people in all walks of life. Much of what Ive since written came from those days as a starving reporter.

title: Sea Lovers: Selected Stories, by Valerie Martin
description: Among the many potent themes that weave in and out of the stories in Sea Lovers  the stark realities of the artists path; the proximity of death to life; the complexities of the relationship between humans and animals  are a number of seemingly ordinary yet revelatory images. For Valerie Martins characters, something as simple as drinking a glass of water can yield a moment of reflection and clarity.

title: All That Followed, byGabriel Urza
description: Stories are shape-shifters in All That Followed, Gabriel Urzas strange and ambitious debut novel. Set in Spains Basque Country, the book revolves around the assassination of Councilman Jos Antonio Torres, as recounted by three characters: Mariana, his dubiously grieving widow; the American teacher Joni Garrett, who came to Muriga in 1951 and wound up staying for his entire life; and Iker Abarzuza, serving time for murder in an island prison, where he listens to the cries of shorebirds and receives the occasional letter from Mariana.

title: Opposing Iran Nuclear Deal, Chuck Schumer Rattles Democratic Firewall
description: WASHINGTON  The decision by Senator Chuck Schumer of New York to oppose the Iran nuclear deal has rattled the Democratic bulwark around the accord, emboldened the deals opponents in both parties, and set off a wave of condemnation from liberals for the man who hopes to lead Senate Democrats in the next Congress.

title: In a First, a Sudanese Migrant Nearly Crosses the English Channel on Foot
description: LONDON  For one African migrant, there was nothing left to lose.

title: Crooked Heart, by Lissa Evans
description: Show of hands: Was anybody here an odd-looking, precocious, misunderstood child? Oh. ... Everybody? Maybe thats why so many of the novels we love most, from Bronts Jane Eyre to Rowlings Harry Potter series, feature some version of this small person. We are gutted not by Scout or Jem in To Kill a Mockingbird, but by Dill, the fatherless fantabulist; we may admire Sara Crewe when shes a kind little heiress, but shes truly a princess when she loses both her money and her dad. Ill read anything that features an invisible, unloved child, an orphan either in reality or spirit, more resourceful than any wee one should have to be. Bonus points if the child finds ways to skirt the law. (Im looking at you, Addie Pray.)

title: Joy: Poet, Seeker, and the Woman Who Captivated C.S. Lewis
description: Even if Joy, Abigail Santamarias life of C.S. Lewiss wife, were a bad book, Lewiss zealous admirers would read it, eager for another way to finger his shroud. Joy Davidman married Lewis, author of the beloved Chronicles of Narnia, at 41, and her late entrance into his bachelor existence is a cherished part of his legend. She soon died of bone cancer, but she had made him a husband and stepfather, adding an intimate touch to the genial but distant self-portrait that emerges from his grown-up books, tracts like Mere Christianity. Her death was also the subject of A Grief Observed, his classic book on mourning and how faith can survive it.

title: The Economy Vanishes
description: There was almost no discussion of the economy in last nights debate, which is actually weird if you consider the Republican self-image. These guys portray themselves as high priests of growth, the people who know how to bring prosperity. And remember all the crowing about how Obama was presiding over the worst recovery ever?

title: Robin Williamss Underrated Roles Help Illustrate His Major Talents
description: This summer brings in close proximity two sad milestones for fans of Robin Williams: July 21 would have been the 64th birthday of this inventive comedian and Academy Award-winning actor, and Aug. 11 is the one-year anniversary of his death. It is a bittersweet occasion to reflect on the range of work that Williams created, as he bounded from classically trained stage actor to stand-up comedian, and from a star of sitcoms to a leading man in movies. While a full consideration of Williamss career would naturally gravitate toward his sympathetic serio-comic roles in films like Good Morning Vietnam, Dead Poets Society and Good Will Hunting, these performances overshadow other, more idiosyncratic but equally vivid efforts  some from a time when his on-screen persona hadnt completely coalesced, and others he was able to sneak in once his fame was assured. Here are five of Williamss less celebrated performances.

title: Marco Rubio Clarifies His Position on Abortion
description: Senator Marco Rubio surprised some viewers on Thursday night when he said that he never supported exceptions that would allow for abortions if conception occurred from rape or incest.

title: The Man Who Gave Air Force One Its Aura
description: Next time you see an image of Air Force One taking off, think Coca-Cola and Lucky Strike. The look of todays presidential plane, emblazoned with United States of America on the blue-and-white fuselage, originated with a quiet collaboration between President John F. Kennedy and Raymond Loewy, who was perhaps the most accomplished commercial image and design expert of the post-World War II era.

title: Donald Trumps Remarks Feed Into Charges of Sexism
description: Donald J. Trump kept his vow to remain unbeholden to political correctness after Thursday nights debate, continuing to criticize the Fox News anchor Megyn Kelly for asking him questions that were too tough while he was on stage.

title: The Next G.O.P. Phenom
A Product of Tunisias 1960s Resistance Continues to Protest
description: TUNIS  WhenFathi Ben Haj Yahia seeks to explain Tunisias troubled transition since its revolution overthrew nearly 60 years of dictatorship four years ago, he offers a parable.

title: She Answered His Ad for a Roommate, Moved In and Never Left
description: Kerry Ryan needed a new place to live; her crazy Yugoslavian roommate had become unbearable. So, as people did in 1991 in New York City, she turned to the classified ads in The Village Voice.

title: How to Approach the Generation Gap in the Workplace
description: A generation gap is widening in the workplace. As baby boomers (ages 51 to 69 or so) express reluctance about retiring, so-called millennials (roughly ages 18 to 34) have become the single largest demographic in the American labor force. Because of this, more older workers have found themselves being hired and managed by people much younger than they are.

title: Stuff We Liked: How Cats Took Over the Internet
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Don Browns Drowned City, and More
description: Ten years have passed since Americans were glued to their televisions, watching the catastrophic results of Hurricane Katrina. Yet much of the drama happened after the storm pummeled New Orleans. For readers too young to remember, three new books revisit those troubled days and offer a clear view of that notorious storms impact.

title: The Little Brother, by Victoria Patterson
description: Victoria Patterson is a capable and canny writer, and she would have to be to take on the subject of her newest novel, The Little Brother, and produce so arresting and haunting an experience. To say the book is about a rape is true, but thats only part of it  in many ways, the least interesting part. The real subject is the conditions that allow that rape to happen.

title: A Missed Opportunity: G.O.P. Debate Avoids Family Policy Issues
description: I watched the first 2016 Republican debate with four children, aged 14, 11, 9 and 9. That meant juggling pizza off the grill while juggling questions about immigration (But why does it matter if they come here? Were all on the same continent.); foreign policy (We have enemies? Who? China?); and Donald Trumps hair. It meant introducing my oldest son to Politifact and its Pants on Fire GIF and teaching my suddenly very worried youngest daughter (America is under attack?) about the concept of exaggerating for dramatic affect (just like your sister does).

title: Lauren Foxs Days of Awe
description: Whats wonderful about reading a novelists books in back-to-back sequence is that you witness the writer grow not gradually, but seemingly overnight. In Lauren Foxs first novel, Still Life With Husband, an unhappily married woman who works for a journal called Male Reproduction (complete with, yes, a boss named Dick) satisfies her seven-year itch with a hunky but sensitive writer she meets in a cafe. Fox furthers these themes with a more mature voice in her delightful Friends Like Us  a story of relationships made all kinds of confused when the protagonists best friend as an adult falls for her best friend from adolescence.

title: Paperback Row
description: PANIC IN A SUITCASE, by Yelena Akhtiorskaya. (Riverhead, $16.) The boundaries between the Old and New Worlds blur in this debut novel, which follows a Ukrainian family adjusting to Brighton Beach, Brooklyn. Spanning 15 years of their lives, the resulting story is, as Karolina Waclawiak wrote here, a rewarding biography of displacement, where those left behind are often as disconnected as those who flee for an elusive better life elsewhere.

title: Editors Choice
description: LET ME TELL YOU: New Stories, Essays, and Other Writings, by Shirley Jackson. Edited by Laurence Jackson Hyman and Sarah Hyman DeWitt. (Random House, $30.) Insights into the vagaries of Jacksons ruminant, generous mind.

title: Men and Women Team Up and Face Off in New Mixed Relays
description: KAZAN, Russia  The gun went off for the medley relay final at the swimming world championships, and it quickly seemed that Russia was in deep trouble. Its backstroker rapidly fell behind the other seven swimmers and, by the end of the leg, was more than seven seconds behind the leader and nearly six seconds behind the next slowest swimmer.

title: After the Storm
description: SHOTS ON THE BRIDGEPolice Violence and Cover-Up in the Wake of KatrinaBy Ronnie Greene240 pp. Beacon, $24.95.

title: Most Railroads Wont Meet Deadline for Safety Controls, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  A majority of freight railroads and passenger trains will not be able to meet a year-end deadline to install technology that prevents trains from exceeding speed limits and helps avoid collisions, the Federal Railroad Administration said Friday in a report to Congress.

title: Navigating Tougher I.R.S. Rules for Family Partnerships
description: THE Internal Revenue Service is about to toughen the rules on a type of investment vehicle that has been abused by some very wealthy families to avoid millions of dollars in taxes.

title: Readers on Cecil the Lion
description: The first time #CeciltheLion popped up on Twitter, I wondered, Who would name a lion after Cecil John Rhodes?, the colonial founder of Rhodesia, now Zimbabwe.

title: Swiss Identify Remains of Japanese Climbers Missing for 45 Years
description: Two Japanese mountain climbers caught in a snowstorm and buried under nearly half a century of Alpine ice have been identified, the police in Switzerland announced this week.

title: Political Scandal Consumes Malaysia at Time of Flight 370 Inquiry
description: HONG KONG  It was a breakthrough in one of the biggest mysteries in aviation history. When a wing part belonging to a Boeing 777 was found last week on the remote Indian Ocean island of Runion, the world took notice, echoing the intense news media coverage that followed the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 on March 8, 2014.

title: Busy September Looms for Obama, but First: Two Weeks of Golf
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.  President Obama slipped out of Washington on Friday afternoon for his annual Marthas Vineyard vacation, just in time for the political spotlight to swing firmly away from the White House and toward the 2016 presidential campaign after the first Republican debate on Thursday night.

title: 1940: Stewardess Says Man Hit Her
description: A mysterious attack on a pretty twenty-two-year-old stewardess on a New York to Dallas, Tex., sleeper plane was being investigated yesterday by American Airlines officials. The girl swallowed a baggage compartment key after she was struck by an unidentified man thirty minutes before the plane landed at 11:40 p.m. Wednesday at Nashville, Tenn. The stewardess, Miss Rosemary Olive Griffith, who was taken to a hospital in Nashville after the plane landed, suffering from a bruised head and scratches on her legs and arms, told the story of the assault to C.R. Smith, president of the American Airlines, yesterday from her hospital bed. She was struck on the head just after entering the womens lounge to get her bag, and fell to the floor unconscious after first swallowing the key which the intruder had demanded.  New York Herald Tribune, August 8, 1940

title: Success or Excess: Whats Behind Manhattans New Residential Sales Record?
description: The average price for a residence was reported to have hit $1.7 million, proof that the real estate market has bounced back from the 2008 recession.

title: Duck in Summertime, Spicy and Fruity
description: You dont have to go to a restaurant to have duck for dinner. Many home cooks leave duck cooking to the professionals, but once you know the technique, cooking a large Muscovy duck breast is no more difficult than cooking a steak.

title: Review: A Divisive Fidelio Draws Boos at Salzburg
description: SALZBURG, Austria  Whats a summer at the Salzburg Festival without at least one opera production that provokes vociferous booing on its opening night? That requisite rite took place here on Tuesday, at a new staging of Beethovens Fidelio, when the German director Claus Guth and his production team appeared during curtain calls at the Grosses Festspielhaus.

title: Army Ranger School a Test for Women in Combat Roles
description: CAMP JAMES E. RUDDER, Fla.  Wearing a cap, sunglasses and a 75-pound rucksack and carrying a 17-pound machine gun, the young, buzz-cut Army officer quickly traversed a muddy river, pulling on a rope stretched between trees on either bank.

title: SoulCycle: You Say Cult. I Say Loyal Customer Base.
description: When young, trendy companies prepare for initial public offerings, their financial statements often show rapid growth but little profit. Investors are expected to take a leap of faith and bet that todays expanding popularity will lead to sustainable earnings down the road.

title: Potash Corporation Again Approaches K&S About Takeover
description: LONDON  K&S, the German potash and salt mining company that owns Morton Salt, said on Friday that the Potash Corporation had made another unsolicited takeover approach for the company.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Katrina: After the Flood
description: This week, Gary Rivlin discusses Katrina: After the Flood; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Joe Domanick talks about Blue: The LAPD and the Battle to Redeem American Policing; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: The Long Shadow of Bill Gross
description: Pimco may not have emerged from the shadow of its larger-than-life co-founder Bill Gross, who left the worlds biggest bond fund abruptly in September 2014. But Allianz, its German owner, can take Pimcos fall from grace in its stride. The companys half-year results suggest its insurance division and a growing in-house asset manager are taking up the slack.

title: Norwegian Youths Return to Camp on Utoya, the Site of a 2011 Massacre
description: UTOYA, Norway  With songs, volleyball games and defiant displays of summer languor, more than 1,000 Norwegian youths on Friday joined the secretary general of NATO and other dignitaries on the island of Utoya, reclaiming the bucolic summer retreat from the horrors of a 2011 attack by a right-wing extremist that killed 69 people.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Katrina: After the Flood
description: This week, Gary Rivlin and Joe Domanick.

title: Activist Protests Fourth Bloggers Death
description: Imran H Sarker, head of the Blogger and Online Activist Network in Bangladesh, spoke out against the killing of Niladri Chaterjee in Dhaka on Friday. Mr. Chaterjee, who wrote under the name Niloy Neel, became the fourth secular blogger slain in the country this year.

title: Six Days in North Korea
description: Six Days in North Korea

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are located on the Upper East Side, in Midtown East and Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: Drakes Bully Pulpit
description: Jon Caramanica, Minya Oh and Rawiya Kameir discuss Drake and OVO Fest.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include five-bedroom homes in Montville, N.J., and Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Bad Decision by Senator Schumer
description: New Yorks senior senator, Chuck Schumer, has cast his lot with Republican presidential candidates, other hardliners and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in declaring his opposition to the nuclear agreement that President Obama and five other world leaders negotiated with Iran. Given Mr. Schumers wrong-headed and irresponsible decision, Democrats may want to reconsider whether he is the best candidate to be their next leader in the Senate, a job he desperately wants.

title: Book Review Podcast: Katrina: After the Flood
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Nathaniel Rich reviews Gary Rivlins Katrina: After the Flood. Mr. Rich writes:

title: Lee Daniels: Empire Spinoff Coming Without Question
description: Empire fans know Cookie Lyon is an outsize character. Now it appears that shes become too big for one show to contain her.

title: Lenny Kravitz-Gate, a Zoolander 2 Teaser and Idris Elbas Cover
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: Fried Eggplant With Chickpeas
description: In this gently spiced vegetable dish, baby eggplant slices are first fried until golden, then braised with chickpeas, tomatoes and garam masala until soft, velvety and richly flavored.

title: The Great Eggplant Question: To Fry or Not to Fry?
description: To fry or not to fry?

title: Trump Sells His Penthouse for $21.38 Million
description: Donald J. Trump, the real estate developer and presidential hopeful, sold one of the two penthouses he owned at the Trump Park Avenue to the founder of the Fresh Market, a supermarket chain, for $21,383,250, a transaction that was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Big Ticket | 502 Park Avenue
description: Donald J. Trump sold his full-floor penthouse on the 24th floor of the Trump Park Avenue.

title: China Philharmonic Orchestra to Play in Tehran
description: As the world focuses on the accord to limit Irans nuclear capabilities that was reached last month, the China Philharmonic Orchestra, a major ensemble from one of the six nations that negotiated the deal, is planning to play two concerts in Tehran next week.

title: We Need Brain: Songify the G.O.P. Debate
description: The Gregory Brothers present a musical mash-up video of the first Republican presidential debate of 2016.

title: Colin Quinn: A Most Charming Complainer
description: The comedians recent successes have not prevented him from offering amused resignation about the state of the world.

title: Psychologists Approve Ban on Role in National Security Interrogations
description: TORONTO  The American Psychological Associationon Fridayoverwhelmingly approved a new ban on any involvement by psychologists in national security interrogations conducted by the United States government, even noncoercive interrogations now conducted by the Obama administration.

title: Colin Quinn Can Find the Dark Cloud in a Silver Lining
description: The comedian Colin Quinn, it turns out, likes to bicker and complain. A lot.

title: Capitalists, Arise: We Need to Deal With Income Inequality
description: IM scared. The billionaire hedge funder Paul Tudor Jones is scared. My friend Ken Langone, a founder of the Home Depot, is scared. So are many other chief executives. Not of Al Qaeda, or the vicious Islamic State or some other evolving radical group from the Middle East, Africa or Asia. We are afraid where income inequality will lead.

title: Britain, Consumed by Sex Scandals, Focuses on Inquiries
description: Since 2012, Britain has been consumed by scandals about sexual predations and child sexual abuse by elite politicians and entertainers dating back to the 1960s. Here are some of the most prominent among them.

title: In Britain, Edward Heath Case Intensifies Debate Over Validity of Sex Abuse Claims
description: LONDON  Accusations of child sexual abuse against some prominent figures of Britains recent past have proved true. Allegations of similar wrongdoing by others, dating back decades, surface regularly now in the hothouse British press, as does talk of cover-ups by some of the nations most powerful institutions.

title: We Need Brain: Songify the G.O.P. Debate
description: As we hunkered down at Gregory Brothers headquarters in Brooklyn to songify the first debate of the 2016 election season, word broke that the Fox News team, inspired by their broadcast from Quicken Loans Arena, was considering using the Cleveland Cavaliers N.B.A. shot-clock buzzer to alert candidates that their allotted time was up. We were crestfallen when, at the first such transgression, we instead heard a polite ding. The Cavaliers claxon would have been perfect for a debate field so large it could have filled two basketball teams, qualifying in number if not by height.

title: Shooting of Unarmed White Teenager, Zachary Hammond, Enters National Debate
description: Zachary Hammond, a white teenager, pulled up to a drive-through window last week at a Hardees restaurant in Seneca, S.C. A sting operation was underway, with police officers suspecting a possible drug deal.

title: Another Secular Blogger in Bangladesh Is Killed
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  A group of men on Friday slit the throat of Niladri Chaterjee, an activist whose social media posts were often critical of Islam, in the fourth fatal attack this year against secular bloggers, the police said.

title: Headstrong Filly Will Skip Undercard and Take on Colts in Hambletonian
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Money was relatively low on the list of priorities when the owners of Mission Brief, a record-setting filly, decided to test her against males in the $1.2 million Hambletonian. They had loftier aims.

title: Biweekly Mortgage Payment Problems
description: Many lenders promote biweekly payment plans as a way to pay down mortgages more quickly. But the programs can sometimes be costly, and, as federal regulators recently found, may promise borrowers more than they actually deliver.

title: Greta Gerwig, Illustrated
description: The actress sketches her responses to personal questions.

title: Officials in Turf Fight Over Response to Legionnaires Outbreak in Bronx
description: An outbreak of Legionnaires disease in the South Bronx appeared to be ebbing on Friday, even as city and state officials jockeyed to show how they were responding to the airborne illness.

title: Kerry Speaks on Human Rights in Vietnam
description: Secretary of State John Kerry delivered a speech on Friday in Hanoi recognizing the 20th anniversary of the restoration of diplomatic ties between the United States and Vietnam.

title: Popcast: Drakes Bully Pulpit
description: For the last five years, the annual OVO Fest in Toronto has been Drakes hometown pulpit. Earlier this week, at its sixth annual installment, he turned it into a bully pulpit. After two weeks of squabbling with Meek Mill  over the ethics of ghostwriting, or maybe something deeper  Drake orchestrated an elaborate takedown that seemed to secure the victory that was already pretty plainly his.

title: Map: Marin County
description: Heres where to eat, sleep and shop in San Franciscos neighbor to the north.

title: Map: Marin County
description: Heres where to eat, sleep and shop in San Franciscos neighbor to the north.

title: Eye Shape May Help Distinguish Predator From Prey
description: Why do the eyes of some animals, including goats, have horizontal-shaped pupils, while others, such as rattlesnakes and domestic cats, have vertical slits?

title: 20 Years After Honeymoon, a Return Trip to Amsterdam
description: Twenty years ago, I traveled with my husband, Wendell, on our honeymoon to Amsterdam, where we walked hand in hand along 17th-century canals, visited museums, ate an obscene amount of cheese, and then blew a big black hole into the middle of our trip by eating hash-laced space cakes.

title: 6 Strategies to Extend Savings Without Working Longer
description: Karen Arndt, 60, has tinkered with several retirement calculators, and they all generate the same finger-wagging advice: Keep working, they seem to warn. Youre not even close.

title: Female Visibility Matters
description: A few weeks ago, I taught a social-justice workshop for African-American teenage girls from Chicagos West Side. They all attend school in North Lawndale, one of the citys most impoverished neighborhoods, and many of them have experienced hostile or violent interactions with the police. But because they are girls, not boys, theyve told me, most people in their community do not take those interactions seriously.

title: Republican Debate Draws 24 Million Viewers
description: Fox Newss telecast of Thursday nights Republican debate drew a staggering 23.9 million viewers, making it the highest-rated presidential primary debate ever and among the most-viewed events in cable TV history.

title: I Am Cait Ratings Drop Nearly 50 Percent
description: Ratings for the second episode of I Am Cait, E!s reality series about Caitlyn Jenner, fell almost by half from its July 26 premiere. The second show drew 2.1 million viewers, according to Nielsens live-plus-three-days data, which accounts for delayed viewing; 3.9 million total viewers watched the first episode of I Am Cait within three days of its first airing.

title: Abercrombie & Fitch to End On-Call Shifts for Workers
description: Abercrombie & Fitch said on Friday that it would no longer require workers to be on call for shifts that may be canceled with little notice, after a regulators inquiry into the practice.

title: Jets Dee Milliner Expected to Miss 6 to 8 Weeks With Wrist Injury
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  A week into training camp, the Jets have already endured injuries to four prominent players. The latest came Thursday, when cornerback Dee Milliner hurt a tendon in his right wrist.

title: On the Campaign Trail With Hillary Clinton
description: Amy Chozick, a politics reporter, has been covering Hillary Rodham Clinton for years. Some people have called her obsessed.

title: Debate Was Highest-Rated Program Ever for Fox News
description: Fox Newss telecast of Thursday nights Republican debate drew 23.9 million viewers, making it the highest-rated program ever for Fox News and among the most-viewed events in cable TV history.

title: Out on the Prairie
description: A group of six high school students from New York City won grants to visit the American Prairie Reserve in Montana, where they met bison and learned how to roast marshmallows.

title: New York High School Students Trade Skyscrapers for Big Sky
description: MALTA, Mont.  On a late July day 2,000 miles west of the Bronx, Vaughn Minott, a tall and soft-spoken aspiring biochemist who was born in Jamaica, bounced with five other New York teenagers in the bed of a 4X4 pickup through a Montana bison range as vast as the bright dome of sky above.

title: Sparks Flew: Assessing the Republican Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Activist Hedge Fund Takes Significant Stake in American Express
description: ValueAct Capital Management, a prominent activist hedge fund, has taken a significant stake in American Express, which is grappling with a number of recent challenges.

title: Lessons of Yonkers From David Simons Show Me a Hero
description: In the second hour of Show Me a Hero, David Simons long-awaited HBO miniseries about a crisis of race and class that erupted in Yonkers in the 1980s and reverberated for years, a crazed mob floods City Hall to denounce a plan, mandated by a federal court, to residentially desegregate the city. Yonkers is vertically divided by the Saw Mill River Parkway: The east side had traditionally been home to white middle-income earners, many of whom were Italian-American; the west side was poor, and black and Hispanic. In 1988, close to 98 percent of Yonkerss public housing stock was located in the southwest section, which contained 81 percent of the citys minority population.

title: Think Like a Doctor: A Knife in the Ear Solved!
description: On Thursday we challenged Well readers to solve the mystery of a 39-year-old man with an earache and asymmetrical pupils. More than 200 of you wrote in with your thoughts on his diagnosis, but only a handful got the two part answer completely right.

title: Brazils Vice President Sees Influence Grow as Scandal Engulfs Dilma Rousseff
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Few Brazilians gave much thought until recently to their vice president, a 74-year-old scholar of constitutional law with a bearing so formal that a political rival once compared him to a butler from a horror movie.

title: 49ers Release Star Defender Aldon Smith, Adding to Their Recent Turmoil
description: The San Francisco 49ers released linebacker Aldon Smith on Friday after his arrest on accusations of hit and run, driving under the influence and vandalism, a move that continues the extraordinary foundering of an organization that reached the Super Bowl just three seasons ago.

title: Factors Unrelated to Driving Can Affect Car Insurance
description: ARE you married or single? Have you been widowed or divorced? Is your credit history less than stellar? Your answers to those questions can affect the rates you pay for car insurance.

title: Roots of Reaganolatry
description: Noah Smith suggests that Reagan worship reflects a misunderstanding of how the economy works  that those who idolize Reagan believe in the Green Lantern theory of presidential power, that presidents can make stuff happen, in the economy and elsewhere, though sheer force of will.

title: Scene City: Hamilton Opens on Broadway
description: Jake Gyllenhaal, Anna Wintour, Susan Sarandon, Sarah Jessica Parker and other stars attend the Broadway opening.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Playing With Light
description: Abandon all worries, ye who enter here.

title: The Exclusive | 24 West 71st Street
description: A townhouse on an historic Upper West Side block is about to enter the market at $29 million.

title: Upper West Side Townhouse for $29 Million
description: A historically significant granite-and-iron-spot-brick townhouse with fanciful terra-cotta embellishments and distinctive interior millwork is poised to enter the market at $29 million.

title: Jon Stewart Signs Off With Second-Most-Watched Episode in The Daily Show History
description: Jon Stewarts final appearance as host of The Daily Show on Thursday drew 3.5 million viewers, making it the second-most-watched episode in the series history.

title: Shenanigans, Heartache and a Lot of Laughter
description: The July 18 marriage of Andrew Gregory, a comedian, and Casey McIntyre, an associate publisher, followed a courtship with, of course, a lot of laughter  but a few tears as well.

title: Court Forbids F.D.A. From Blocking Truthful Promotion of Drug
description: A federal judge said on Friday that the Food and Drug Administration could not prohibit the truthful promotion of a drug for unapproved uses because doing so would violate the protection of free speech.

title: Candidates Continue to Plead Their Cases After First Republican Debate
description: The stage lights have dimmed, the spin room has been shuttered, but for Republican presidential candidates, the debate goes on.

title: A Once-Flourishing Pima Cotton Industry Withers in an Arid California
description: FRESNO, Calif.  Up and down the San Joaquin Valley, vast fields that once grew cotton lie fallow, remnants of a boom and bust fueled by a worldwide demand for premium T-shirts and linens.

title: Life Sentence for James Holmes, Aurora Theater Gunman
description: CENTENNIAL, Colo.  In a decision that surprised many in this community, a jury sentenced James E. Holmes on Friday to life in prison with no chance of parole, rejecting the death penalty for the man who carried out a 2012 shooting rampage that killed 12 people in a Colorado movie theater.

title: Court Says 4 Catholic Nonprofits Must Allow Workers Access to Contraception
description: Four Roman Catholic nonprofits in New York must allow employees access to contraception, a federal appeals court panel ruled on Friday, reversing a decision by a lower court that allowed the organizations to get around a requirement in the Affordable Care Act.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Afghanistan and More  Pictures of the Day

title: August 7, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Afghanistan, Taiwan, France and Ukraine.

title: Italian Police Charge 5 in Shipwreck That Killed Migrants
description: ROME  The Italian police arrested two Libyans, two Algerians and a Tunisian on Friday in connection with a shipwreck that left at least 25 confirmed deaths and probably as many as 200.

title: Linda Sarsour Is a Brooklyn Homegirl in a Hijab
description: Behind schedule as usual, Linda Sarsour rushed into the Times Square office of the civil rights group the Gathering for Justice last month, 40 minutes late for a meeting with its founder, Harry Belafonte. On the way in from Brooklyn, the Uber driver she had hired made a wrong turn and wound up in New Jersey. Now, wearing her head scarf and hungry from fasting for Ramadan, Ms. Sarsour scurried into an auditorium packed with some of the citys most prominent social-justice warriors.

title: A Republican Broadside on Immigrants
description: Latinos of America, there you have it. The Republican presidential campaign has nothing good to offer you on immigration.

title: Jon Stewart, Patron Saint of Liberal Smugness
description: IT shows how gifted Jon Stewart is that his best moment happened on someone elses show. He appeared in 2004 on Crossfire, a CNN yelling program, and asked the hosts to take seriously their responsibility to public understanding by having useful conversations instead of shouting matches.

title: What I Love | John Miller
description: John Miller, a bass player who assembles musicians for theater productions, lives with his wife, Constance Barron, on the Upper West Side.

title: For Public Morals, Edward Burns Exhumes the 60s From Manhattan Streets
description: Tourists walking in New York look up at the skyscrapers and blinding billboards. Locals look down to avoid stepping in gum or whatever. Edward Burns lately has been looking here, there and everywhere when he strolls the city: at stoops, windows, cornices, railings. He has been looking for the 1960s.

title: The Best Paternity Leave Policies
description: Heres our working list of the United States employers that offer at least 10 weeks of paid parental leave to new fathers.

title: Bringing Paternity Leave Into the Mainstream
