description: This week, two companies joined in an unfolding race to provide ever more generous paid parental leave. Netflix said it planned to offer unlimited leave in the first year after a childs arrival to many (though not all) of its employees, while Microsoft said it would substantially increase the paid leave that it will provide.

title: A Musician on the Upper West Side
description: I think every home should have an upright bass, said John Miller, walking into his music room and nodding at the instrument in the corner. It adds a certain je ne sais quoi. The shape of the bass, the contours, the gestalt of the bass only adds to a room.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: New Releases From La Luz, Chelsea Wolfe and Ossia
description: La Luz

title: Bernie Sanders, After Call From Obama, Announces Support for Iran Deal
description: A day after Senator Chuck Schumer of New York announced his decision to vote against President Obamas deal to curtail Irans nuclear program, he and the president each placed a call to Bernie Sanders.

title: The Week in Political Pictures
description: The first debate of the 2016 presidential campaign, lobster rolls, jello, a Brooklyn beer hall and more in this weeks political pictures.

title: Mostly Mozarts Big Tent Embraces George Benjamin, Dai Fujikura and More
description: The big news this week at Mostly Mozart is George Benjamins opera Written on Skin, to be performed Tuesday Thursday and Saturday. But theres also plenty of interest elsewhere at the festival.

title: Ebola Survivors Face Lingering Pain, Fatigue and Depression
description: The Ebola outbreak that started more than a year ago seems to be waning at last. But now, West Africa faces another difficulty: More than 13,000 people survived the virus, and many have lingering health problems, psychological troubles like depression and post-traumatic stress disorder, and worries about returning to work to feed themselves and what is left of their families.

title: Drive East Festival Spins to a Bigger Stage at La MaMa
description: This year Drive East, the South Asian performing arts festival, has grown up or, rather, into La MaMas largest space, the Ellen Stewart Theater, where it will host more than 20 programs of Indian music and dance. Presented by the organization Navatman, performances include Archana Joglekar, an esteemed dancer and actress who specializes in Kathak, and Ashwini Ramaswamy, of Ragmala Dance Company, in a Bharatanatyam solo featuring music by an all-female orchestra.

title: German TV Anchor Denounces Online Hate
description: In a commentary broadcast on public television in Germany, Anja Reschke, a journalist, blamed a recent spate of hateful Internet tirades for inciting real-world violence against foreigners.

title: Van Halen and Mtley Cre, Stylists of Hair Metal, Play Area Shows
description: Here was one thrilling route to whiplash in the 1980s: Mtley Cre, Too Fast for Love (1981); Van Halen, Diver Down (1982); Mtley Cre, Shout at the Devil (1983); Van Halen, 1984 (1984); Mtley Cre, Theatre of Pain (1985); Van Halen, 5150 (1986); Mtley Cre, Girls, Girls, Girls (1987); Van Halen, OU812 (1988); Mtley Cre, Dr. Feelgood (1989). It was a rich decade for headbanger decadence, toggling between Mtley Cres devil-may-care Dionysian pop-metal and Van Halens howling blue-collar arena aerobics  competing approaches, both demanding copious amounts of hair spray.

title: At Sea With Joseph Conrad
description: THE tall ship Corwith Cramer stumbled into the Celtic Sea, engine roaring, 7,500 square feet of sail furled up mute. Its two masts ticked against the horizon like a metronome set to allegro. I joined a row of pallid sailors crouched at the leeward rail. Foam-lathered swell swung for my face, then reeled abruptly away. By the third time I threw up over the side, the wine-dark sea of Homers poetry just looked like the basin of a billion vomits.

title: In Shared Dining, a Table of Heroines at the Brooklyn Museum
description: The Dinner Party, Judy Chicagos sumptuous, vulva-themed table with places for 39 historical female figures (Susan B. Anthony to Mary Wollstonecraft), has been permanently set at the Brooklyn Museum since 2007. Through Sept. 13, it will be joined in the museum by another womens table, inspired by Ms. Chicagos but made under far different circumstances.

title: On Kevin From Work, an Office Romance Built for One
description: Kevin (Noah Reid), an earnest young office worker, finally gets to quit the worst job in history. Every bit of it stinks, except for the colleague with whom he has shared a cubicle wall for three years: Audrey (Paige Spara), perpetually backlit, her hair tousled by a magical breeze and the wings of the animated bluebirds that suddenly appear every time she is near. And like them, Kevin longs to be close to her. If only she didnt have a lunk of a boyfriend  which is why Kevin has banished himself and his shredded heart to Italy, but not before pouring his passion into a love letter and mailing it. After all, hes never going to see her again.

title: T City Guides: Milan
description: Five leaders in creative fields share their favorite places to eat, drink, shop and play.

title: The Three Musketeers, the Richard Lester Treatment
description: Countless directors have taken on Alexandre Dumass The Three Musketeers, but none have matched Richard Lesters adaptation, so rambunctious it took The Three Musketeers (1973) and The Four Musketeers (1974) to contain it. The Film Society at Lincoln Center screens both Sunday and Tuesday. (Also on Sunday: Mr. Lesters The Return of the Musketeers, from 1989.) The novels action and humor play to Mr. Lesters gifts for the same, and working from George Macdonald Frasers script, the director attracted an unsurpassable cast, including Faye Dunaway as the lethal Milady de Winter; Christopher Lee as an eyepatched Rochefort; Raquel Welch as Constance; Michael York as DArtagnan; Oliver Reed as Athos; and a peerless Charlton Heston as Cardinal Richelieu.

title: How Mitchell J. Silver, New York City Parks Commissioner, Spends His Sundays
description: A lot of New Yorkers spend their weekends frolicking in the citys 1,700 parks, but Mitchell J. Silver takes his visits more seriously than most. As the New York City parks commissioner, Mr. Silver picks a different borough every Sunday, packs his beloved camera and sets off to observe and document how a select few parks are being used and how they could be improved. A born-and-bred New Yorker, the 55-year-old urban planner recently returned to the city after serving for nearly a decade in North Carolina as the planning director for its capital city, Raleigh. Mr. Silver lives with his wife, Mary, 48, an administrator for the nonprofit Brooklyn Community Services, and his daughter, Rachel, 17, in Downtown Brooklyn.

title: New York Review of Books Fills a Niche by Reviving Forgotten Works
description: In 1882, the writer Anton Chekhov, just 22 and beginning his literary career, submitted a dozen short stories to Czar Alexander IIIs censors, who discerned a subversive intent and promptly forbade publication of the collection, called The Prank. The satirical tales then languished in official archives for more than 130 years  until last week, when they were finally published, in English, by New York Review Books.

title: Hillary Clinton Has Her Own Celebrity Moment After Debate
description: Just as one reality television star upended the first debate of the Republican presidential race in Cleveland, another posed for a selfie with Hillary Rodham Clinton in Los Angeles.

title: Frances Oldham Kelsey, Who Saved U.S. Babies From Thalidomide, Dies at 101
description: The sedative was Kevadon, and the application to market it in America reached the new medical officer at the Food and Drug Administration in September 1960. The drug had already been sold to pregnant women in Europe for morning sickness, and the application seemed routine, ready for the rubber stamp.

title: Revenue Down Slightly at Sothebys, a House in Transition
description: Sothebys, the upscale auction house that appointed a new chief executive in March, reported weaker results on Friday than analysts had expected.

title: The Great Victorian Weather Wars
description: THE history of todays climate change debate may have begun on Feb. 7, 1861. That day, an Irish physicist named John Tyndall, a professor of natural philosophy, delivered the annual Bakerian Lecture to the Royal Society in London.

title: Slide Show: Scene City: Hamilton Opens on Broadway
description: Jake Gyllenhaal, Anna Wintour, Susan Sarandon, Sarah Jessica Parker and other stars attend the Broadway opening.

title: Ferguson One Year Later
description: The Times revisited the community to see what has and has not changed in the year since Michael Brown was killed.

title: Rapper and Model Chynna Rogers Straddles Two Worlds With Ease
Returning to a Rebuilding Nepal
description: As soon as Kevin Bubriski learned of the earthquake that devastated Nepal, he knew he had to return to the land he has documented since 1975.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
Friday Night Music: San Fermin, Parasites
description: One of the pleasures I wasnt expecting back when I discovered, to my surprise, that I liked a lot of indie music was that of following the progress of favorite bands. In general, when I become aware of them  often, I have to say, via Bob Boilens Tiny Desk concerts  they already have a following but are still playing to small venues and havent fully worked out their persona. Over time, however, they visibly develop.

title: Celebrities Flock to Hamilton Broadway Opening and Party
description: It was a big night for American politics and entertainment.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: A Debate With Substance. No, Not That Debate.
description: Last night, I watched a really interesting political debate, in which the candidates engaged one another substantively about their vision for the countrys future.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Bill Cunningham | Park Avenue on Wheels
description: The annual closing of Park Avenue to automobiles brings New Yorkers on in-line skates, bikes, scooters, CitiBike unicycles and everything you can think of.

title: Evening Hours | An Elegant Affair
description: Several hundred guests attended Southampton Hospitals 57th annual summer party.

title: Bill Cunningham |Park Avenue on Wheels
description: The annual closing of Park Avenue to automobiles brings New Yorkers on in-line skates, bikes, scooters, CitiBike unicycles and everything you can think of.

title: Common Yellowthroat Warbler: A Bandit in the Bramble
description: Though tiny, the common yellowthroat warbler is no church mouse. Unlike many of their beautiful warbler relatives, these birds shun the treetops for a life amid the tangled brambles and vines of wetland edges and dense thickets. Highly inquisitive  even aggressive while protecting a breeding territory  the birds are animated subjects for anyone with even a passing interest in bird-watching. A lengthy view of the three- to four-inch warbler is measured in seconds.

title: The Hole in the Middle of the Jobs Report
description: The jobs report for July, released on Friday, showed steady if unspectacular job growth. The economy created 215,000 jobs, in line with average job creation so far this year.

title: Mussolini Slept Here: Unearthing a Roman Villas Uneasy Past
description: ROME  Deep beneath the historic Villa Torlonia, where Benito Mussolini lived for nearly two decades, a wine cellar repurposed in 1941 as a bunker to protect the Fascist leader was recently opened to the public. Even in a city stratified with centuries of history, where archaeologists are digging up the remains of an ancient empire, the damp underground space is a telling sign of how deeply Italys relatively recent past can stay buried.

title: The Clash of New Yorks Irish and Italians, and the Citys First Black Firefighter
description: Among the most overlooked racial problems in the country, the columnist Jimmy Breslin wrote in 1970, is the division between Irish and Italians.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted on @nytimes this week took us from Rand Pauls campaign headquarters to the cockpit of a Boeing 747.

title: An Influential Debate? Not if You Trust Prediction Markets
description: Thursday nights Republican primary debate was watched by a record-shattering 24 million people, and some pundits lauded it as the best, classiest debate ever. But for all the fireworks, nothing seems to have changed.

title: Review: Santa Fe Opera Offers The Daughter of the Regiment, Rigoletto and Salome
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  The appeal of the Santa Fe Opera, with its history of presenting the most distinguished American summer festival of its kind, is obvious. Taking in the mountain vistas from the terraces before performances may alone be worth the price of admission, though perhaps not at a top rate of $300 on weekends.

title: The Bobbed-Hair Bandit of Brooklyn
description: Q. My stepdaughter, a hairdresser who is interested in old styles, was telling me about a young woman in the 1920s known as the Bobbed Hair Bandit. Can you tell me more?

title: Photographs of Train Riders Idle Hands, on Way to Work
description: For a project called Strangers in Common, Alvaro Keding has discreetly captured images of New Yorkers on their commutes.

title: A Photographer Puts Subway Riders Idle Hands to Work
description: A young mans puffy coat on an overstuffed No. 4 train. The slick semi-oasis of an empty seat. The distressing warm patch of a vertical pole  which fellow traveler made it so, and what is his recent medical history?  tethering riders to their transit fate.

title: Falling All Over Trump
description: There was a moment at the Republican debate in Cleveland on Thursday night  actually, there were several moments, but this one in particular lingered, and lingers, as an illuminating episode. Youll never guess who was in the middle of it: starts with T and ends with rump.

title: Review: In Pimms Mission, Seeking Clues to a Deadly Blast
description: Pimms Mission takes place on a Sunday afternoon in an empty bar across the street from the Manhattan headquarters of a Big Pharma company, Zincorp, where an explosion has just killed 15 people. F.B.I. agents are questioning Robert Pimm, a Brit who was outside the building when the blast went off, and is nursing a head injury.

title: Colorado: Heavy Metals Spill Into River
description: Environmental officials are working to clean up one million gallons of wastewater containing heavy metals that spilled from an abandoned mine, turning an adjoining river a mustard yellow. The Environmental Protection Agency caused the spill on Wednesday while it was investigating a leak at the Gold King Mine. The wastewater flowed into Cement Creek, a tributary of the Animas River in southwestern Colorado, and snaked through the river toward New Mexico. E.P.A. officials said the wastewater included lead and arsenic, but said it was too early to know whether there was a health risk. The river was closed for recreational and other uses, but officials said water sources should be safe. The orange color is alarming to people, but that is not an indication in any way of a health risk, said Joan Card, an official with the E.P.A. Testing continues, she said.

title: Vice Media Staff Latest to Choose Unionizing
description: Some staff members at Vice Media have voted to unionize, according to two people familiar with the matter, joining other digital media outlets that have recently moved to organize.

title: Prince Plans to Make New Album a Tidal Exclusive
description: Prince announced on Friday that he had signed an exclusive deal with the music-streaming service Tidal to release his new album, HITNRUN. A longtime advocate for artists rights, Prince recently began removing his music from most streaming services. But he has left his music on Tidal, the subscription service owned by Jay Z and more than a dozen other artists (Prince is not thought to be among them). Last month, Prince released a new single, Stare, on Spotify, another streaming service.

title: Her Son Was Safe Behind Bars, but Then He Came Home
description: The wall had been covered in photographs of smiling children and grandchildren. Now there were gaps where pictures of a son used to hang, leaving behind bare nails.

title: Judge Rules New York Teacher Exam Did Not Discriminate Against Minorities
description: A federal judge on Friday ruled that a new licensing exam for teachers given by New York State did not discriminate against minorities, saying that even though they tended to score poorly, the test evaluated skills necessary to do the job.

title: German Journalist Wades Into Online War Over Refugees
description: Given two minutes to air her views on Germanys response to the refugee crisis in Europe during a newscast on Wednesday night, Anja Reschke, a respected broadcaster, blamed a recent spate of what she called hateful Internet tirades for inciting real-world violence against foreigners, and she called on the public to speak up in favor of decency.

title: Nuns of a New Generation Forge Their Own Path
description: Mechanical bulls, rock-climbing walls, bounce houses, go-karts: Before becoming a nun, Sister Virginia Joy helped insure them all.

title: Brazilian Implicated in FIFA Case Remains Free, Unlike Many Others
description: Some are sitting in jail in Switzerland, while others are under house arrest in places including New York and Asuncin, Paraguay. But of the 14 people indicted in May in a far-reaching corruption case within world soccer, only one remains a free man.

title: Murder of Brazilian Journalist Furthers Alarming Trend
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Gleydson Carvalhos radio program was on the air in the provincial beach city of Camocim when two gunmen burst into his studio. During a musical interval, they subdued the receptionist and told a technician to stay quiet. Then they did their work, unloading three rounds and killing Mr. Carvalho, a journalist known for crusading against political corruption.

title: Guantnamo Hunger Strikers Petition Divides Officials
description: WASHINGTON  Obama administration officials are divided over what to do about a detainee at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, who has been on a hunger strike since February 2007 and now weighs less than 75 pounds, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations.

title: Jon Stewarts Legacy
description: It seems unfair, cruel even, that Jon Stewart would end his tenure as a national court jester the very night the absurdist circus kicks off Indecision 2016.

title: Blackhawks Patrick Kane Facing Criminal Investigation
description: BUFFALO  The police in nearby Hamburg, N.Y., confirmed Friday that Patrick Kane, one of the N.H.L.s most high-profile players, was under criminal investigation.

title: Day After Debates, Carly Fiorina Finds Receptive Audience
description: ATLANTA  The final question to the candidate was from Diane: What can people in this room who like what theyre hearing do to help the campaign?

title: Peace Activists Descend on Los Alamos, but Residents Remain Indifferent
description: LOS ALAMOS, N.M.  Ellie Voutselas, 78, pulled from a cardboard box the sacks she had fashioned into ponchos, slicing holes in the burlap for the head and arms. Cayla Turain, 22, grabbed hers, smudged ashes on her face, and joined a silent march for peace.

title: Coleen Gray, Who Played Film Noir Nafs, Dies at 92
description: Coleen Gray, an actress who dreamed of playing femmes fatales but was repeatedly cast as innocents in noir films like Stanley Kubricks The Killing, died on Monday at her home in the Bel Air neighborhood of Los Angeles. She was 92.

title: The Perils of Probation
description: To the Editor:

title: Shackling of Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Ecuadors Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: Refugees on Greek Shores
description: To the Editor:

title: Fears of Lasting Rift as Obama Battles Pro-Israel Group on Iran
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama had a tough message for the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, or Aipac, the powerful pro-Israel group that is furiously campaigning against the Iran nuclear accord, when he met with two of its leaders at the White House this week. The president accused Aipac of spending millions of dollars in advertising against the deal and spreading false claims about it, people in the meeting recalled.

title: Louise Suggs, Golf Pioneer, Dies at 91; Helped Found the Womens Pro Tour
description: Louise Suggs, a Georgia-born founder of the womens professional golf tour and one of its most successful and outspoken players, died on Friday in Sarasota, Fla. She was 91.

title: Dozens of Syrian Christians Missing From Town Attacked by ISIS
description: ISTANBUL  Dozens of Christian civilians are missing and are believed to be captives of the Islamic State extremist group after it seized their town in central Syria this week, according to conflict-monitoring groups and the Syrian Orthodox Church.

title: Children Caught in a Racist System
description: The Justice Department cast the St. Louis County, Mo., law enforcement system in a harrowing light in March when it documented entrenched racism and unconstitutional policing in the town of Ferguson, which erupted in riots last year after a white police officer killed Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager.

title: A Stronger Web of Care for the Mentally Ill in New York
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a plan on Thursday for a coordinated attack on mental illness, violence and homelessness. It involves having more caseworkers, clinicians and police officers working in shelters and on the streets, and having the mental health and criminal justice systems work together more closely to find and protect people who might pose a danger to themselves or others.

title: Remembering Hiroshima, and How It Changed the World
description: After 70 years, the memory may be fading. Survivors are in their 80s, and many young Japanese can no longer give the dates when American atomic bombs incinerated Hiroshima and Nagasaki. But at every anniversary the debates resurface, as impassioned and complex as ever.

title: Jury Reads Holmes Verdict
description: James Holmes was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole in a Colorado courtroom Friday. The jury was unable to reach the unanimous verdict required for the death penalty.

title: Cuomo Rejects Federal Offer to Lend Money for New Hudson River Tunnels
description: When it comes to paying for new train tunnels under the Hudson River, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo wants the federal government to send, not lend, money to New York.

title: Nagasaki, the Forgotten City
description: ON Aug. 9, 1945, the United States dropped a nuclear bomb on Nagasaki, situated on a long, narrow bay on Japans southernmost main island, Kyushu.

title: The Other Mushroom Clouds
description: Hundreds of atomic bombs have been tested since the one dropped on Nagasaki on Aug. 9, 1945.

title: Some Parisian
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Lets just put our grids on the table and say it: People are scared of the Saturday puzzle, and with good reason. Its hard.

title: Producer Acquitted of Top Sexual Assault Charge; Mistrial on Other Counts
description: A former producer for the Wu Tang Clan hip-hop group who served as his own lawyer was acquitted on Friday of the top sexual assault charge he faced, but the judge declared a mistrial on several other counts on which a jury said it was deadlocked.

title: When Jon Stewart Took Down CNBCs Jim Cramer
description: It began, youll perhaps recall, with the Santelli rant.

title: Wastewater Spill in Colorado Turns a River Yellow
description: Environmental officials in Colorado are working to clean up one million gallons of wastewater containing heavy metals that spilled from an abandoned mine, turning an adjoining river a murky, mustard shade of yellow.

title: Fear That Debate Could Hurt G.O.P. in Womens Eyes
description: After Senator Marco Rubio of Florida insisted at the Republican presidential debate that rape and incest victims should carry pregnancies to term, aides to Hillary Rodham Clinton could barely contain their delight at his unyielding stance, rushing to tell reporters at her headquarters that those remarks would hurt Mr. Rubio with female voters.

title: Blue Jays Draw First Blood in Most Meaningful Series
description: Toronto Manager John Gibbons said he considered it the most meaningful series the Blue Jays have played at Yankee Stadium in 20 years. But the atmosphere in the visitors clubhouse before Fridays game hardly attested to that proclamation.

title: Wilmer Flores Again Shows Flair for Theater in Comeback Victory
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The rookie and the folk hero are from different countries, speak different first languages and stood on opposite sides of the clubhouseon Friday. One is an outfielder; the other plays the infield. One just completed his third series in the major leagues; the other is playing in his third season.

title: How to Save a Sinking Coast? Katrina Created a Laboratory
description: NEW ORLEANS  Ten years ago, the neighborhood hard by the 17th Street canal in this city was water-blasted. The surges from Hurricane Katrina swept into the canal, broke through its flood walls and forced homes off their foundations. Much of New Orleans remained steeped in brackish filth for weeks until the sodden city could be drained.

title: A Look Back at the Outcry in Ferguson
description: A retrospective on the events that put Ferguson, Mo., in the national spotlight and spurred discussion on race relations nationwide.

title: Ferguson: A Shooting That Caused the Nation to Shudder
description: For days after the shooting death of Michael Brown on Aug. 9, 2014, protesters faced off with the police as racially charged demonstrations gripped the streets of Ferguson, Mo. Protesters knelt with their arms raised, signifying hands up, dont shoot, which became their plea for justice and change. Other residents, however, just wanted their neighborhood to return to normal.

title: Rebuilding Nature in Wake of Katrina
description: Several projects have been undertaken to restore wetlands in Louisiana to provide flood protection and wildlife habitat.

title: How the 14 Indicted FIFA Defendants Currently Stand
description: Updating the legal status of the 14 soccer and sports marketing officials charged in the FIFA corruption case.

title: What Is Nature Worth to You?
description: THE United States government recently announced an $18.7 billion settlement of claims against the oil giant BP in connection with the Deepwater Horizon oil rig explosion in April 2010, which dumped millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico. Though some of the settlement funds are to compensate the region for economic harm, most will go to environmental restoration in affected states.

title: Whats On TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE HOBBIT: THE BATTLE OF THE FIVE ARMIES (2014) In Peter Jacksons conclusion to the tale of Bilbo Baggins (Martin Freeman, above), the hobbit and his companions become mired in a war that threatens to destroy Middle-earth. Ian McKellen returns as Gandalf, who finds himself at the heart of the story after his imprisonment; Richard Armitage is Thorin Oakenshield, the headstrong leader with a lust for treasure; Evangeline Lilly is the elf Tauriel, who pursues a forbidden love; and Benedict Cumberbatch lends his voice to the dragon Smaug. What this adaptation of The Hobbit cant avoid by its final installment is its predictability and hollow foundations, Nicolas Rapold wrote in The New York Times. Its been said before, but Mr. Jackson himself is still haunted by the past. He added: Its especially a shame since Mr. Jacksons original knack for world building (not to mention the sense of humor in his early films) is often missing in the ever-proliferating superhero-franchise worlds that his own vastly successful endeavors no doubt helped encourage. Bilbo may fully learn a sense of friendship and duty, and have quite a story to tell, but somewhere along the way, Mr. Jackson loses much of the magic.

title: Corrections: August 8, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Theres a difference between pandering and vote-courting: Thursday night, G.O.P. candidates did neither for women weary of the Republican brand.

title: Father of Palestinian Toddler Killed in West Bank Arson Attack Dies in Hospital
description: DUMA, West Bank  The severely burned father of a Palestinian toddler who was killed in an arson attack died of his wounds early Saturday, and thousands of Palestinians came to bury him in this West Bank village gripped by grief, anger and fear.

title: Chinese Human Rights Lawyer Is Unexpectedly Freed a Day After Being Detained
description: PINGYAO, China  A Beijing human rights lawyer said Saturday that he had been released from police custody, a day after being detained in a raid on his apartment.

title: Andrew Gregory and Casey McIntyre: A YouTube Comedy Star and the Woman Who Keeps Him Laughing
description: In love, as in comedy, impeccable timing is everything. Yet there is something to be said for the offbeat, and even the missed beat, when it comes to great romance.

title: Conservative Forum Rescinds Donald Trumps Invitation Over Remark About Megyn Kelly
description: ATLANTA  Donald J. Trumps suggestion that a Fox News journalist who questioned him during the Republican debate was aggressive because she was menstruating led a conservative group on Friday night to disinvite the real estate mogul from a prominent conservative forum.

title: Im Too Old for This
description: There is a lot that is annoying, and even terrible, about aging. The creakiness of the body; the drifting of the memory; the reprising of personal history ad nauseam, with only yourself to listen.

title: A Masters Degree in ... Masculinity?
description: Michael Kimmel stood in front of a classroom in bluejeans and a blazer with a pen to a whiteboard. What does it mean, the 64-year-old sociology professor asked the group, most of them undergraduates, to be a good man?

title: Typhoon Soudelor Kills 6 in Taiwan and Leaves Millions Without Power
description: HONG KONG  A powerful typhoon dumped rain on China on Sunday, a day after it pummeled Taiwan, toppling trees and leaving millions without electricity as strong winds ripped across the island.

title: City Tours Becoming More Children-Friendly
description: Adults might find organized city tours interesting and informative, but for children they can be yawn inducing. Fortunately, for hard-to-please young travelers, companies are creating interactive and entertaining versions for those between the ages of 6 and 12.

title: Farhad and Mikes Week in Review: Netflixs Not So Unlimited Benefits
description: We are trying something new. Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the industry.

title: Twisting Words to Make Sharing Apps Seem Selfless
description: I have trouble with the sharing economy. Ditto the peer economy, the people economy and the collaborative economy.

title: Dealing With a Possible Hoarder
description: A Bad Odor Next Door

title: Hand-Wringing in G.O.P. After Donald Trumps Remarks on Megyn Kelly
description: Donald J. Trumps suggestion that a Fox News journalist had questioned him forcefully at the Republican presidential debate because she was menstruating cost him a speaking slot Saturday night at an influential gathering of conservatives in Atlanta. It also raised new questions about how much longer Republican Party leaders would have to contend with Mr. Trumps disruptive presence in the primary field.

title: Mornings in America
description: Just a further thought about Reaganolatry: consider the track of unemployment under two presidents. One is lauded as the ultimate economic hero and savior; the other reviled as an economic failure, who killed jobs by being nice to poor people and insulting job creators. The chart compares their records.

title: Kevin E. Lofton of Catholic Health Initiatives: Designate a Devils Advocate
description: This interview with Kevin E. Lofton, chief executive of Catholic Health Initiatives, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: 29 U.S. Scientists Praise Iran Nuclear Deal in Letter to Obama
description: Twenty-nine of the nations top scientists  including Nobel laureates, veteran makers of nuclear arms and former White House science advisers  wrote to President Obama on Saturday to praise the Iran deal, calling it innovative and stringent.

title: 4 Years After Fukushima Nuclear Calamity, Japanese Divided on Whether to Return
description: IITATE, Japan  For four years, an eerie quiet has pervaded the clusters of farmhouses and terraced rice paddies of this mountainous village, emptied of people after the disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, 25 miles away, spewed radiation over a wide swath of northeastern Japan.

title: Variety: A Flighty Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  If you happen to be a BIRDWATCHER, you will like this acrostic. Even if youre not, its still an excellent puzzle, because its by Cox and Rathvon.

title: Katie Ledecky Wins 800 in Record Time, Completing World Championships Sweep
description: KAZAN, Russia  Ask Katie Ledecky to name what she believes is the most amazing athletic feat in her lifetime, and she will talk about Michael Phelpss eight-gold-medal performance at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, helped along by the anchor leg that Jason Lezak unleashed in the 4x100-meter freestyle relay to deliver Phelps his second gold.

title: California Effort to Issue Drivers Licenses to Immigrants Receives Surge of Applicants
description: LOS ANGELES  When Alberto Fraire drives past a police car these days, he no longer worries about steep fines, or perhaps being hauled to jail and tangling with the immigration system. When California began issuing drivers licenses to undocumented immigrants this year, he was one of the first in line.

title: Conservative Forums Leader Says Donald Trumps Language Will Lose G.O.P. the White House
description: ATLANTA  After rescinding an invitation to Donald J. Trump over his misogynistic comments about a Fox News reporter, the leader of a conservative conference said on Saturday morning that his email box filled with vitriolic messages.

title: Dick Costolo Is Said to Plan Departure From Twitters Board
description: Dick Costolo, the former chief executive of Twitter, plans to leave the companys board of directors by the end of the year or when a new chief executive is appointed, according to two people familiar with Mr. Costolos plans.

title: Many Minority Families Stuck in Poor Neighborhoods Despite Housing Voucher Program
description: Where families receiving housing choice voucher live.

title: A Year After Ferguson, Housing Segregation Defies Tools to Erase It
description: ST. LOUIS  When she tore open the manila envelope on a sweltering morning in early June, Crystal Wade thought she had unlocked her ticket to freedom.

title: In Handling Barrage of Attacks, Afghan Forces Show Training Is Paying Off
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The unprecedented wave of attacks here  three major bombings in less than 24 hours that killed at least 65 people and wounded hundreds of others  was arguably a major victory for Taliban forces, who proved they could mount simultaneous operations with devastating effect, including on an American military base.

title: Pain of Puerto Ricos Debt Crisis Is Weighing on the Little Guy, Too
description: To Lev Steinberg, it seemed like a good place to park his nest egg.

title: For the Cubs and the Mets, a Whiff of the Past and a Tantalizing Glimpse of the Future
description: CHICAGO  It was a lets-play-two jewel of an evening at Wrigley Field, the shadows of summer long and sharp as the Cubs and the Giants gathered for a showdown.

title: Andrew Zirm: An Astrophysicist With a Down-to-Earth Calling
description: Andrew Zirm, 41, is a data scientist at Greenhouse Software in New York.

title: Regulators Should Develop Rules to Protect Cars From Hackers
description: The recent revelation that hackers have found ways to remotely take control of cars made by Fiat Chrysler and Tesla is alarming. This is a danger that most drivers had not even imagined. And it comes on the heels of the recalls of millions of cars for dangerous defects.

title: Exposing Abuse on the Factory Farm
description: While most Americans enjoy eating meat, it is hard to stomach the often sadistic treatment of factory-farmed cows, pigs and chickens.

title: Is India Selling Out Its Tigers?
Africas Scramble for Europe
description: THIS summer, a striking, often tragic story has been playing itself out on the outskirts of Calais in France, at the entrance to the tunnel that connects the European mainland to Great Britain. Thousands of migrants, African and Middle Eastern, have been trying to sneak onto the trucks and trains that traverse the tunnel, cutting through wire fences and evading the police along the way. Ten have died, but enough have succeeded for many more to keep trying, while politicians on both sides of the Channel point fingers and a refugee camp outside Calais remains swollen with would-be subjects of Elizabeth II.

title: Congress and Obama Are Too Timid on Marijuana Reform
description: Even as support for ending marijuana prohibition is building around the country, Congress and the Obama administration remain far too timid about the need for change.

title: Suicide on Campus
description: Responses to an Education Life article about pressure on students and the rising rate of suicide on college campuses.

title: Trump the Disrupter
description: Washington  IVE been hesitant to start writing about Donald Trump.

title: U.S.A., Land of Limitations?
description: YAMHILL, Ore.  We like to boast of America as the land of opportunity, and historically there is truth to that.

title: A Prudent College Path
description: EVERY year the frenzy to get into highly selective colleges seems to intensify, and every year the news media finds and fawns over the rare students offered admission to all eight Ivy League schools. This year Ronald Nelson, from the Memphis area, was one of those who sopped up that adulation.

title: Do the Amazons Last Isolated Tribes Have a Future?
description: HIS name is Shuri, but everyone calls him Epa, which means father in the indigenous Pano language family. His wizened face and bare, gnomish feet are familiar to the villagers who live along the Curanja River, which flows through some of the densest rain forest of Perus vast Amazon region.

title: A Cheer and a Half for Cheap Commodities
description: Commodities markets have taken a beating this summer. Oil, coal, coffee, soybeans, copper, iron and nearly every other commodity has fallen sharply in price, upending currency markets and inflicting pain in large parts of the world economy.

title: Afghan Forces Display Effectiveness in Fending Off Attacks
description: Officials noted that in none of the three bombings on Friday, scattered across Kabul, did the insurgents manage to breach their targets inner defenses.

title: What Do the Poor Need? Try Asking Them
description: FOR decades, policy makers have treated poverty as a sign of helplessness and ineptitude. The worse off the neighborhood  the higher the rate of poverty, crime, and juvenile delinquency  the less influence it would have over its future. Social service agencies conducted needs assessments rather than asking residents what would strengthen their community. Government agencies or private entrepreneurs then delivered brick-and-mortar solutions  a new school, medical clinic or housing.

title: Congolese See No End to Presidents Final Term
description: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo  To take the political pulse of this sprawling, mineral-rich country, head to the busiest stretch of Lumumba Boulevard, one of the capitals main roads. On weekdays, a large crowd gathers here to peer at the newspapers posted on an eight-foot-high wall and loudly trade opinions on the news of the day.

title: Giants Cant Give Big Hits for Now, and That Hurts, Some Players Say
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In 2011, a new N.F.L. labor agreement did away with a staple of summer pro football workouts since the 1950s. Gone was the punishing two-a-day practice regimen.

title: What Selfie Sticks Really Tell Us About Ourselves
description: CREMATED remains, xylophones and lawn chairs are not allowed in the Magic Kingdom, and now selfie sticks arent either. Disneyland banned the so-called narcisticks this summer following similar prohibitions at the Roman Colosseum, Palace of Versailles and Sydney Opera House. The cited reason was public safety concerns as well as basic propriety.

title: Margrethe Vestager
description: Margrethe Vestager is a Danish politician who last year was appointed the European Unions commissioner for competition and promptly took to task several powerful interests including Google, Russias gas behemoth Gazprom and European Union countries state-owned utilities.

title: Key Events in the Hillary Clinton Email Controversy
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton's email account has become a significant early chapter in her presidential run, and a new stroke in the portrait of the Democrats' leading candidate.

title: Hillary Clinton Emails Take Long Path to Controversy
description: WASHINGTON  Earlier this summer, the inspector general of the nations intelligence agencies contacted the longtime lawyer for Hillary and Bill Clinton with a pointed question. Classified information had been found in a small sample of 30,000 messages from the former secretary of states private email account. The inspector general, I. Charles McCullough III, wanted to know from the lawyer, David E. Kendall, where copies of the message collection might still be stored.

title: Caregiving: A Burden So Heavy, Until Its Gone
description: Marry an orphan, my mother used to say, and you can always come home for Christmas. What she should have said was: Marry an orphan, or youll have four parents to nurse through every torment life doles out on the long, long path to the grave.

title: Kazan, a Russian Cultural Hub, Finds Its Good at Sports
description: KAZAN, Russia  In his first trip abroad, Michael Weiss visited a place he had a hard time locating on a map. Was Kazan a sports destination or an exclamation popularized by the television character Gomer Pyle?

title: Mother Is Charged With Murder After Infants Fall From a Window in Queens
description: The mother of a 3-week-old boy who died after plummeting from a fourth-floor window in Queens was charged on Saturday with intentionally killing her child.

title: A Minor League Home Run King Without Major Fanfare
description: When Mike Hessman entered professional baseball, as a 15th-round draft choice in 1996, he fixed his mind on reaching an annual statistical benchmark.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Australian Brothers Cherish Their Reunion at P.G.A. Championship
description: The last time that Matt and Brett Jones played a competitive round in the same field was nearly a decade ago at the Jacobs Creek Open Championship in Adelaide, Australia, a regular stop on the PGA Tour of Australasia. The event was co-sanctioned by the Nationwide Tour in the United States, meaning that those who finished in the money had a chance to move up to the PGA Tour.

title: Scientists Letter to Obama on Iran Nuclear Deal
description: Twenty-nine of the nations top scientists wrote to President Obama on Saturday in support of the deal, which calls for Iran to curb its nuclear program and allow inspections in return for an end to sanctions.

title: Iris DeMent Returns, Via Russia
description: Iris DeMent, a songwriter and singer of country and gospel music, emerged in the 1990s. And if you listened a lot to the New York City radio station WFUV back then, you could hear her voice every day, plaintive and joyous, lonely and quite unforgettable, singing tunes that felt brand new and many generations old.

title: Manuel Contreras, Chilean Spy Chief Under Pinochet, Dies at 86
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Gen. Manuel Contreras, Chiles intelligence chief during the military dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, died on Friday in the military hospital in Santiago while serving 526 years of multiple prison terms for human rights violations. He was 86.

title: Ditching Honky-Tonk for Chic
description: Its a sign of the times: Barons Cove, for many years a mainstay among local family motels, reopened this spring as an upscale resort and restaurant. The old space had grown a little honky-tonk over the years, and the results of the upgrade  overseen by the hotelier, Curtis Bashaw, and his designer sister, Colleen Bashaw  are ravishing.

title: With Seventh Straight Win, Blue Jays Creep Closer to Yankees
description: Taped to David Prices locker was a self-written message on yellow notebook paper, pronouncing in all capital letters, If You Dont Like It, Pitch Better, with the last two words underlined three times for emphasis.

title: Restaurant Review: Charritos in Weehawken Is a Family Affair
description: One ideal place to be this summer is the slender terrace overlooking Manhattan at Charritos, a restaurant in Weehawken specializing in the colorful dishes of Oaxaca, a region in southern Mexico. For those unfamiliar with Oaxacan cuisine, it is known for chocolate-infused moles, which Charritos does serve, and grasshoppers, which it does not.

title: Amid an Inquiry, Patrick Kane Cancels Stanley Cup Events
description: BUFFALO  Under increasing scrutiny as the subject of a criminal investigation, Patrick Kane, one of the N.H.L.s highest-profile players, kept a low profile here in his hometown Saturday rather than celebrate publicly with the Stanley Cup, as he had in the past.

title: Hanoi Through a Parisian Lens
description: The vision for Everett and Linda Reids new restaurant began, like so many dreams, over a meal in Paris. But it was not a traditional French cafe that sparked the couples imagination, during that visit more than 20 years ago. Rather, it was the City of Lights most famous Vietnamese eatery, Tan Dinh, still a fixture on the Seventh Arrondissements Rue de Verneuil.

title: Everything for a Summer Picnic at Westchester County Markets
description: August, in my book, is picnic month. As summer and mosquitoes wane, a simple meal spread over a checkered cloth among tall grasses and Queen Annes lace reminds us that we are part of the natural order of things.

title: A Duo, in Jazz and in Love
description: By her own account, Carla Bley was operating outside her comfort zone when at a ceremony honoring her and three other new National Endowment for the Arts jazz masters in April, she was obliged to deliver an acceptance speech to a packed house at Lincoln Center.

title: Douglas LeVien, New York Detective Who Infiltrated the Mafia, Dies at 68
description: Douglas A. LeVien Jr., a former undercover police detective who in 1972 infiltrated the meeting ground used by New Yorks five Mafia families, a landmark operation that produced scores of convictions, died on July 30 while vacationing in Saratoga, N.Y. He was 68.

title: Documentary Explores Struggle of New Jerseys Ramapough Tribe
description: Corey Bobker was an accomplished 30-something adult when he took his first drive into the Ramapo Mountains in 2010. But the 12-year-old version of him still had knots in his stomach.

title: Cecils Kin?
description: What a tour group saw.

title: Review: The Cottage in Northport Is a Saucy Farce
description: The Cottage, a saucy farce about infidelity set in 1923 England, was written  contrary to any expectations that description might conjure  very recently by Sandy Rustin, a young American playwright who lives in Maplewood, N.J. Compounding its lack of British pedigree, the play was first produced at the Astoria Performing Arts Center in 2013 before spawning regional productions in Colorado, Massachusetts and Arizona. In 2014, the Astoria production enjoyed another run in the borough where it had its world premiere, this time at Queens Theater in the Park.

title: 299 Connecticut Museums and One Special Child
description: When Steve Wood arrived at the Ukrainian Museum and Library of Stamford on a recent Sunday afternoon, in his head were the number 299 and a sense of uncertainty.

title: Help Wanted
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE If a HELP WANTED ad ran for test crossword-puzzle solvers, what do you think it might say?

title: Benton Becker, Ford Aide, Dies at 77; Negotiated Nixon Pardon
description: Benton L. Becker, who as President Gerald R. Fords personal emissary negotiated the pardon of Richard M. Nixon in 1974 and preserved his White House papers and tapes from what Mr. Becker predicted would have otherwise been a hell of a bonfire in San Clemente, where Nixon lived, died on Aug. 2 in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 77.

title: India Warns TV Stations Over Criticism of Hanging
description: NEW DELHI  Indias government on Friday accused three television networks of violating broadcasting regulations by showing interviews that criticized the execution of Yakub Memon, hanged last month for bombings that killed 257 people in Mumbai in 1993.

title: Did Roger Stone Jump, or Was He Pushed From Donald Trumps Campaign?
description: Both Donald J. Trump and political strategist Roger Stone agree they have parted ways. What they dont agree on is when and how they did it.

title: On the Defensive, the S.E.C. Quietly Pursues High-Profile Cases
description: Wall Streets chief regulator, the Securities and Exchange Commission, appears to some to be in need of a makeover.

title: Poor E.U. Migrants Test Limits of Swedish Tolerance
description: STOCKHOLM  After begging through the night outside bars and nightclubs, Gheorghe Rancu, a homeless migrant from Romania, was asleep one morning this summer in a Stockholm park when he woke with a start and felt a sharp pain on his face.

title: Medicare, Reversing Itself, Will Pay More for an Expensive New Cancer Drug
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has decided that Medicare will pay for one of the newest, most expensive cancer medications, which costs about $178,000 for a standard course of treatment.

title: 70 Years After Nagasaki Bombing, Atomic Debate Yields Little Consensus
description: Did the United States have to drop the bomb?

title: Daughter Honors Seau Onstage at a Celebration Under a Cloud
description: CANTON, Ohio  At a dinner and ceremony Thursday night as part of the Pro Football Hall of Fame induction weekend, Sydney Seau received a standing ovation after Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, presented her with a gift honoring her father, Junior, one of the games most celebrated linebackers.

title: A Year On, Ferguson Killing Is Recalled
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  As demonstrators shouted, Hands up, dont shoot, and marched toward West Florissant Avenue, the scene here on Saturday morning looked in many ways like a flashback to the protests that followed the police killing of Michael Brown a year ago.

title: Man Dies After Being Shocked With a Taser by a Hartford Police Officer
description: The Connecticut State Police are investigating the death of a man who was shocked with a Taser by a Hartford police officer after a call for medical assistance.

title: Final Hearing for Reporter Held in Iran Is Scheduled for Monday
description: The final hearing in Irans espionage trial of Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post correspondent whose yearlong incarceration has helped worsen tensions with the United States, has been scheduled for Monday, the newspapers executive editor and Mr. Rezaians brother said Saturday.

title: Marco Rubio: Wont Comment on Everything Donald Trump Says
description: Senator Marco Rubio praised Megyn Kelly, the Fox News debate moderator who has come under fire from Donald J. Trump, but said he was not going to comment on Mr. Trumps latest remarks.

title: Tom Coughlin Finds Little New in a Talk With Jason Pierre-Paul
description: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin had a telephone conversation Friday afternoon with Jason Pierre-Paul, the Giants defensive end who has stayed away from the teams training camp after a serious fireworks accident on the Fourth of July weekend. Coughlin said Pierre-Paul, whose right index finger was amputated, did not indicate when he planned to rejoin the team, but it did not sound as if it would be soon.

title: Jeb Bush Gets Applause at Conservative Forum
description: ATLANTA  Jeb Bush, who has fought the perception of conservatives that he is not one of them, journeyed into the lions den on Saturday. While he may not have converted every skeptic at the RedState Gathering, a conclave of anti-establishment Republicans, he persuaded more than a few to give him a second look.

title: Jefferson-Jackson Dinner Will Be Renamed
description: An Iowa Democratic Party panel voted on Saturday to change the name of the popular Jefferson-Jackson dinner, joining several state parties in distancing itself from the legacies of the two former slave-owning presidents for whom the dinner is named.

title: Measuring the Legacy of Ferguson: Readers Respond
description: Reflections on the legacy of the fatal shooting of Michael Brown by a police officer last year in Ferguson, Mo., that set off protest movements and sparked a nationwide conversation about race.

title: Officials Expand Efforts to End Legionnaires Disease Outbreak
description: New York City and state officials continued to step up efforts on Saturday to thwart the spread of Legionnaires disease, even as an outbreak of the airborne illness in the South Bronx appeared to be waning.

title: An Excerpt From Sydney Seaus Speech
description: Before his suicide, Junior Seau told his daughter to speak on his behalf if he entered the Hall of Fame. But she was not allowed to give the speech. Heres an excerpt from Sydneys speech.

title: The Hall of Fame Speech You Didnt Hear
description: Before his suicide, Junior Seau told his daughter to speak on his behalf if he entered the Hall of Fame. But the Hall didnt allow her to speak at the ceremony. Heres what Sydney would have said.

title: The Hall of Fame Speech Junior Seaus Daughter Couldnt Give
description: In his 20-year N.F.L. career, Junior Seau established himself as one of the games greatest linebackers. He committed suicide in 2012 at age 43 and was subsequently found to have had a degenerative brain condition linked to repeated hits to the head. Before his death, Seau told his daughter Sydney that she should speak on his behalf if he made it into the Pro Football Hall of Fame. But the Hall, citing a five-year-old policy of not letting others give full speeches for deceased inductees, did not allow Sydney to deliver her speech.

title: Noah Syndergaard Struggles as Rays End Mets 7-Game Winning Streak
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Amid the clang of cowbells, Noah Syndergaard stalked off the mound, his face buried in his glove and hanging toward the ground.

title: A Moscow of Dancing Feet, Under an Iron Fist
description: MOSCOW  Russias capital city has worn many outfits since the fall of the Soviet Union.

title: Answers Sought in Police Shooting of Unarmed Christian Taylor
description: The police in Arlington, Tex., asked the F.B.I. to help investigate the shooting death of an unarmed black college student who was killed by a police trainee early Friday morning inside a car dealership.

title: Quotation of the Day: Sunday, August 9, 2015
description: Its not the end of the world; she didnt give away the crown jewels. But this is not how things are supposed to be done.

description: Nicole Marie Gill, a daughter of Patricia Dunsmore Gill and Robert L. Gill of Jackson, Wyo., was married there Saturday to Robert Flinn Ottaway Jr., a son of Anne Galvin Scruggs of Cashiers, N.C., and Mr. Ottaway of Birmingham, Mich. The Rev. Carl Beavers, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the home of the brides parents.

The bride will take her husbands name.

Malcolm and John F. Malcolm of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Rev. Jo Forrest, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Kenilworth Union Church in Kenilworth, Ill.

Nussbaum and Dr. Monte J. Nussbaum of Oceanside, N.Y. Rabbi Andrew Scheer is to officiate at the Sheraton Parsippany.

description: Kathryn McManmon Collins and Matthew Eugene Kaelin were married Saturday at the Weekapaug Chapel in Weekapaug, R.I. David Collins, an uncle of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

Frommer of Scarsdale, N.Y. Linda Gates, a justice of the peace in Westport, Conn., officiated at Rolling Hills Country Club in Wilton.

description: Mackenzie Wilson Condon and Alexander Daley Roussos were married Saturday at Maritime Gloucester, a museum in Gloucester, Mass. The officiant was Frederick M. Daley III, an uncle of the groom who received a one-day designation to officiate from Massachusetts.

description: Darla Michelle Murray and Matthew Louis Zander were married Saturday evening at the Museum of Vancouver in British Columbia. Rabbi Dina-Hasida Mercy officiated.

description: Elizabeth Gregg Hendee and James Hart Canner were married Saturday in Stonington, Conn. The Rev. Ryan Fleenor, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Calvary Church.

description: Sara Lynn Lipka, the daughter of Ellen R. Lipka and George S. Lipka of Framingham, Mass., is to be married Sunday to Alberto Behar, a son of Marta Behar and Leon Behar of Cape Town. Rabbi Donald M. Splansky is to perform the ceremony at the Sixth & I Historic Synagogue in Washington.

description: Saul Mitchell Olyan and Frederik Schockaert are to be married Sunday at their vacation home in Fitzwilliam, N.H. Daniel T. Moran, a celebrant of the American Humanist Association, is to officiate.

description: Alexandra Lynn Gaudiani and Tracy Alexandra Bjelland were married Saturday. Canon Elizabeth S. Berman, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Harvard Memorial Church in Cambridge, Mass.

description: Leah Marie Zimmerman and Peter Wesley Lord were married Friday evening at the Greenpoint Loft, a warehouse space in Brooklyn. The officiant was the Rev. Tyler C. Staton, who was ordained by Trinity Grace Church, where he is pastor of the Williamsburg parish.

title: Emelyn Northway,  Ely Kahn IV
description: Emelyn Claire Northway and Ely Jacques Kahn IV were married Saturday evening at Liberty National Golf Club in Jersey City by Matthew Mitchell, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion.

title: Marie Aberger,  Andrew Nesi
description: Marie Elizabeth Aberger and Andrew William Nesi were married Saturday afternoon at St. Augustin's Catholic Church in Newport, R.I. The Rev. Christopher M. Rehagen, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Di Hu,  Adam Webb
description: Di Hu and Adam Kempton Webb were married Saturday at the Church of Our Lady in Upton Pyne, Devon, England. Canon Michael A. Hall, an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Priya Sethi,  Nimish Verma
description: Priya Sethi and Nimish Dev Verma were married Saturday. Pandit Dwejendra Doobay performed a Hindu ceremony at the Hyatt Regency in Princeton, N.J.

description: Rebecca Shari Levine and Barry Mitchell Eisenberg were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Joshua Goldstein at the Brooklyn Winery in Brooklyn.

description: Nora Barnard Murphy, the daughter of Laura Barnard Murphy and Raymond G. Murphy of Rockville, Md., was married Saturday to Robert Frank Massimi, a son of Maria G. Massimi and Frank A. Massimi of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Scott R. Pilarz performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Dahlgren Chapel of the Sacred Heart at Georgetown University in Washington.

description: Dr. Rose Heather Weiner, a daughter of Lois M. Weiner and Dr. William A. Weiner of East Rockaway, N.Y. , is to be married Sunday to Marc Ari Held, the son of Suzanne Held of Lynbrook, N.Y., and Bruce C. Held of Wellington, Fla. Rabbi Sholom Stern is to officiate at Oheka Castle, a hotel and estate in Huntington, N.Y.

description: Nicole Marie Teibel, a daughter of Gail M. Teibel and Mitchell C. Teibel of Wilmington, N.C., was married Friday to Taylor Leslie Boyd, a son of Cynthia S. Boyd and Frank L. Boyd of Raleigh, N.C. The Rev. Kate Dunn performed the ceremony at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

description: Emily Sarah Fabre and Robert Alexander Gomez were married Saturday at the Central Park Conservatory Garden in New York. The officiant was Judge Barbara S. Jones, formerly of the United States District Court of the Southern District of New York, for whom the groom was previously a law clerk.

title: Analisa Andry,  Heriberto Rodriguez
description: Analisa Andry and Heriberto Rodriguez were married Friday. The Rev. Paul M. Ybarra performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Basilica of the Sacred Heart in Notre Dame, Ind.

title: Jessica Tannenbaum and Jeffrey Berger: Hey Sis, He Likes Me (Not You)
description: Jessica Kara Tannenbaum and Jeffrey Scott Berger were married Saturday. Rabbi Benjamin H. Spratt officiated at the JW Marriott Essex House in New York.

title: In Case You Missed It: Top Articles of the Week
description: Catch up with the most-read sports stories in The New York Times from July 31 to Aug. 6.

title: Corrections: August 9, 2015
description: MAGAZINE

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know to start your week.

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here are the weeks top stories.

title: I Love to Watch You Play but Not Every Game
description: I couldnt help but be a little relieved when the thunder rolled in. Baseball was canceled, one of five games scheduled in a nine-day span. The weekday games are precisely at dinnertime, and I have two other children and a husband with a commute.

title: Similarities Aside, Bernie Sanders Isnt Rerunning Howard Deans 2004 Race
description: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa  It was a summer Friday night in Iowa, and a high school auditorium here was overflowing, as more than 1,000 people, holding signs and collecting names, spilled out into the lobby and onto the sidewalk. Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont strolled onstage  tieless, his white hair askew, his shoulders stooped  and stopped at the sight in front of him.

title: Teacher Shortages Spur a Nationwide Hiring Scramble (Credentials Optional)
description: ROHNERT PARK, Calif.  In a stark about-face from just a few years ago, school districts have gone from handing out pink slips to scrambling to hire teachers.

title: Do You Have Change for a Bowie? The Advent of Artisanal Cash
description: LONDON  Though paper money here typically bears the visage of Queen Elizabeth, the Brixton district of the city last month released a new 5-pound note designed by Jeremy Deller, an artist who won the prestigious Turner Prize in 2004. It features a fuzzy, psychedelic image of an androgynous face surrounded by rainbow clouds and coruscating, swirling etchings.

title: More Cohesive Australian Team Shows a Harder Edge
description: Any notion that Australia would not be a serious threat at the Rugby World Cup was dispelled as the Wallabies underlined their credentials with a 27-19 victory over New Zealand in Sydney on Saturday night.

title: 1890: Power Struggle in Guatemala
description: NEW YORK  Despatches to the HERALD from Guatemala say that conspiracies are breaking out in all quarters. Senor Sobrol, Minister of Foreign Relations, suspected of being a traitor, is confined in the penitentiary and the imprisonment of other prominent men is expected.

title: True Detective Season 2, Unexplained
description: Fans of the HBO television show True Detective attempt to explain what the second season of the series is about.

title: African-American Stage Stars to Join Audra McDonald in Shuffle Along
description: Four of the American theaters leading African-American singer-actors will join Audra McDonald next spring in a musical that seeks to reintroduce one of the first all-black shows on Broadway.

title: Lollapuzzoola 8: On a Saturday in August
description: Administrivial Lollapuzzoola Alert! We are thrilled to have Oliver Roeder of FiveThirtyEight.com as our guest blogger covering Lollapuzzoola 8, the most fun you can have with a sharp pencil on a Saturday in August. Warning: If you are playing the Home version of the game, you might want to avert your eyes until you submit your answers. We have taken precautions, using power tools and advanced chemistry, not to spoil any of the answers, but you never know what could spill out of Olivers mouth. Thats how much fun he had.

title: Premier Haider al-Abadi, Facing Protests, Proposes Iraqi Government Overhaul
description: BAGHDAD  Facing widespread protests against government corruption and poor services, as well as a crucial call for change from the countrys top Shiite cleric, Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi proposed on Sunday to radically reshape the dysfunctional political system of Iraq that has been entrenched since the American-led invasion in 2003.

title: Email Requesting Another Date for Taking Sergeants Exam
description: Police Officer Akema Thompson sent an email to the Department of Citywide Administrative Services requesting other options for taking the test because Oct. 19, 2013 was the same day as her due date.

title: Email Details Make-Up Exam Date Guidelines
description: An officer giving birth or recovering from childbirth on the exam date is not among the instances in which an individual can reschedule taking the sergeants exam.

title: Pregnant Officer Denied Chance to Take Sergeants Exam Fights Back
description: Police Officer Akema Thompson felt the energy in the air the moment she walked into the Manhattan precinct station. And as soon as she stepped into the womens locker room, she knew why.

title: Shots Are Fired as Anniversary Is Marked in Ferguson
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  A day of peaceful protest commemorating the killing of Michael Brown, an unarmed black 18-year-old, by a white police officer one year ago ended in gunfire late Sunday as multiple shots rang out on West Florissant Avenue, the commercial district hit by rioting last summer.

title: Hannibal Recap: Did He Who Made the Lamb Make Thee?
description: Season 3, Episode 10: And the Woman Clothed in Sun

title: Knitting History (Trivial)
description: Via Brad DeLong, a great history of socks. But somehow it misses the economic geography story, where there once was a great hosiery center in Cohoes, near Albany, thanks to one Egbert Egberts, who invented the first power knitting frame. In England the comparable complex was in Nottingham.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 7 P.M. (Travel) AMERICA. THE BEAUTIFUL. Robert Redford narrates this exploration of some of the countrys most breathtaking landscapes in advance of the National Park Services centennial celebration in 2016. The journey begins in California, as the pilots Chris Bolfing and John Heiney, above, hang glide through Yosemite; the arborist Chad Brey climbs 200 feet into the branches in Redwoods National Park; and the marine biologist Alana Osaki dives into kelp that can grow 90 feet tall in the Channel Islands. At 7:30, the series moves to Utah, where the adventurers Faith Dickey and Andy Lewis slack-line in Mineral Canyon, and Heidi Redd herds cattle in Indian Creek Canyon.

title: Donald Trump Remains Defiant on News Programs Amid G.O.P. Backlash
description: A defiant Donald J. Trump suggested on Sunday that he had been singled out for attacks by the hosts of last weeks widely watched Republican presidential debate and again threatened a third-party White House bid if he was not treated reasonably fairly by party leaders.

title: 1965: Friction Between Singapore and Malaysia Intensifies
description: SINGAPORE  The bitter friction between Singapores government and the predominantly Malay federal government intensified during recent weeks and led to predictions that the federation would be torn apart by racial and political bitterness. But no one expected it to happen so soon, with so little warning.

title: 29 Are Killed in Afghanistan as Bombing Targets Militia
description: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan  At least 29 people were killed and 19 others wounded in a suicide bombing targeting a militia in the northern province of Kunduz, Afghan officials said Sunday.

title: A Hive of Activity Atop the Barclays Center
description: We have a bee, Ashley Cotton said, in a we-have-liftoff voice.

title: Warren Buffetts Berkshire Hathaway Said to Be Near Deal to Buy Precision Castparts
description: Warren E. Buffett has long spoken about his elephant gun, the huge pile of cash at Berkshire Hathaway that is reserved for big deals, and his itchy trigger finger.

title: Man Charged After 8 Members of Texas Family Are Found Dead
description: Eight members of a Texas family, including six children, were shot to death over the weekend and the mothers former domestic partner was arrested and charged with the murders on Sunday, the authorities said.

title: Change in Militant Tactics Puts Tunisians on Edge
description: MONASTIR, Tunisia  A dozen police officers, one with an assault rifle across his knees, guard the presidential mausoleum in this seaside resort, easily outnumbering the foreign visitors on a recent morning.

title: Rocky Horror at Lincoln Center, With Headphones
description: It is a cinematic ritual that unconventional film fans have shared in for nearly 40 years, but it has probably never been presented quite so unconventionally.

title: After Sydney Seau, Football Hall of Fame Policy Will Be Tested Again
description: When Sydney Seau spoke briefly Saturday at the Pro Football Hall of Fame induction for her late father, Junior, she proved emphatically that the relatives of deceased inductees deserved to deliver full speeches at their enshrinement ceremonies. Who would have thought otherwise?

title: Frank Gifford, Star for Giants and in the Broadcast Booth, Dies at 84
description: Frank Gifford, a gleaming hero of sports and television in an era when such things were possible, who moved seamlessly from stardom in the Giants offense to celebrity in the broadcast booth of Monday Night Football, died on Sunday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 84.

title: Fantastic Four Lacks Superpowers at Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES  20th Century Foxs big-budget Fantastic Four went down in flames at the weekend box office, adding to fears about superhero fatigue and calling into question Hollywoods willingness to hire novice directors for major films.

title: After Nokia Layoffs, Tech Workers in Finland Regroup and Refocus
description: Kimmo Kalliola knows the feeling that thousands of Finns have been dealing with over the last couple of years. He spent more than a decade working on geolocation positioning at Nokia, a highly technical job, but the Finnish tech giant hit hard times. In late 2012, Mr. Kalliola and 10,000 others at the company were laid off.

title: As South Korean Villages Empty, More Primary Schools Face Closings
description: NOGOK, South Korea  The post office pulled up stakes and moved away years ago. The police station is long gone. And so is the bank. Over the years, the residents of Nogok have watched almost every major institution disappear, victims of an exodus of young people that is emptying villages and towns across much of rural South Korea.

title: Behold the Deep Bench
description: NBC has the first post-debate poll; its an online poll, but using a methodology that worked very well in the midterm elections. And it does not, it turns out, show the predicted Trump collapse and rise of the establishment candidates.

title: Mets Lose Early Lead and Fall to Rays
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  On his final pitch of Sundays game, Tampa Bay starter Chris Archer threw an 88-mile-an-hour slider to Wilmer Flores. Flores swung and missed. Archer, the Rays young All-Star pitcher, pumped his arms, let out a yell and strutted off the mound. He had allowed three runs and four hits while striking out 10 in six innings.

title: Malaysias Prime Minister and 1MDB
description: The Prime Minister of Malaysia, Najib Razak, is mired in a scandal over billions of dollars that his critics say are missing from a sovereign wealth fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad, known as 1MDB.

title: Yankees Shut Out by Blue Jays for Second Day in Row
description: Of the three hits that Masahiro Tanaka allowed in six innings Sunday, two were home runs. The damage was minimal, but it supplied the Toronto Blue Jays with just enough offense to send the Yankees off winless in this important three-game series between teams jockeying for supremacy in the American League East.

title: Abrons Announces Premieres for New Season
description: Seven world-premiere theater pieces are in store for the coming season at Abrons Arts Center, the 100-year-old home to avant-garde theater and dance at the Henry Street Settlement.

title: KCON
description: Scenes from the festival of K-Pop music.

title: At Salzburg Festival, Musicians Tap Their Inner Mozarts and Schuberts
description: SALZBURG, Austria  The six-week calendar of this summers Salzburg Festival is, as usual, packed. Among the offerings are seven staged opera productions (three of them new), and three operas in concert, as well as dozens of programs by the Vienna Philharmonic, nine guest orchestras, chamber groups, contemporary ensembles and more.

title: Coca-Cola Funds Scientists Who Shift Blame for Obesity Away From Bad Diets
description: Coca-Cola, the worlds largest producer of sugary beverages, is backing a new science-based solution to the obesity crisis: To maintain a healthy weight, get more exercise and worry less about cutting calories.

title: Its Not the First Time Donald Trump Has Flirted With a Third-Party Run
description: Over nearly two decades, Donald J. Trump has given more than a little thought to a third-party presidential candidacy. How serious he is about it for 2016 is about to be tested.

title: Review: In Deliriums Daughters, Dad Wrestles Daughters Suitors, One Dead
description: Things turn complex and lovely when the ghost appears in Deliriums Daughters. Its not a real ghost. Giovio isnt dead; he has cleverly faked his own demise so that everyone will think kindly of him, especially his girlfriends father, who has rejected him as a prospective son-in-law. So he visits the man in the middle of the night.

title: Israel Continues Crackdown on Jewish Extremist Network in West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli authorities on Sunday continued their crackdown against the young Jewish zealots believed to be associated with the Revolt, a shadowy network described by its members as an anarchistic vision of redemption.

title: Review: Stately Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra, a Brave Danish String Quartet
description: In recent summer seasons, Jane Moss, the artistic director of Lincoln Center, has successfully transformed the Mostly Mozart Festival. What was once a stodgy diet of Classical-era hits and occasional novelties has become a varied festival that includes a valuable platform for contemporary music. This week, for example, the festival presents the American stage premiere of George Benjamins acclaimed opera Written on Skin, with Alan Gilbert conducting the Mahler Chamber Orchestra, a major event.

title: Review: Steven Osborne Is Joined by 2 Collaborators at Kaplan Penthouse
description: One of the most attractive innovations of the Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center in recent decades has been A Little Night Music, a series of intimate concerts in a nightclub atmosphere (with free wine) at the Kaplan Penthouse. The 10 oclock start typically allows patrons a leisurely stroll from the evenings orchestral concert, where, as often as not, they will have heard some of the same performers.

title: Widespread Child Sexual Abuse Case Rocks Pakistan
description: HUSSAIN KHAN WALA, Pakistan  Pakistani officials have initiated an investigation into allegations that a gang of men sexually abused more than 200 children and sold videos of the abuse.

title: New York, Combating Worker Abuse, Requires Salon Owners to Secure Wage Bonds
description: For nearly six years, Silvia Gonzalez opened the doors of Romys Nails in Brooklyn at about 8:45 a.m. and left more than 12 hours later, six days a week. She performed manicures and pedicures with no lunch break, making $55 a day, or about $4.50 an hour. After Ms. Gonzalez had worked there four years, her pay increased to $80 a day, which was still below minimum wage. She recalled hearing her employer often proclaim to workers, many of whom were working illegally in the country, that no one could win against him in court.

title: Another Sunday Dominated by Donald Trump
description: Donald J. Trump may have found himself on the defensive this weekend for his remarks criticizing the moderators of Thursdays Republican presidential debate. But even under attack, Mr. Trump seems to be dominating the Republican primary campaign.

title: Review: In A Moon for the Misbegotten, Audra McDonald Is Front and Center
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.  She may be wild-eyed, dusty and barefoot, and wearing a dress that looks like it doubles as a heavy-duty cleaning rag. But from the moment you set eyes on her at the beginning of the Williamstown Theater Festivals production of Eugene ONeills A Moon for the Misbegotten, you never for a second doubt the supreme, comforting competence of the rowdy farm gal named Josie Hogan.

title: K-Pop Fans Swoon During East Coast KCON
description: NEWARK  The tears began as soon as Teen Top waved hello.

title: Review: Celebrating Partnership, Mostly Apart, in Solo for Two
description: On Friday, the Russian dynamos Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev zipped into City Center for Solo for Two, a program intended to highlight an artistic partnership that was once personal as well as professional.

title: Smile!
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Even on a Monday, there has to be a mental separation between the solving of a puzzle and the full understanding of the theme. That gap is where your brain takes all of the theme clues, digests them and then delivers that Aha! moment that we all know and love. The gap cant be too short, because that would mean that the theme is too obvious, and thats no fun. It cant be too long, because then it wouldnt be a Monday puzzle. Its an art to get it just right.

title: Scenes From Fergusons Protests
description: A year after the death of Michael Brown, protesters marched in Ferguson to mark the anniversary of the shooting of the black teenager by a white police officer.

title: Instagram Takes on Growing Role in the Art Market
