description: Anyone in the art market who was not already paying attention to the social media platform Instagram had to sit up and take notice in April after the actor Pierce Brosnan visited the showroom of Phillips auction house in London. Mr. Brosnan snapped a selfie in front of a work he admired: the Lockheed Lounge, a space-age aluminum chaise longue by the industrial designer Marc Newson. Then he added the words let the bidding commence, and posted it to the 164,000 followers of his Instagram feed.

title: Harper Lee and Truman Capote: A Collaboration in Mischief
description: One summer about 85 years ago in a small Alabama town, a scrappy tomboy named Nelle met her new next door neighbor, Tru, a bookish, dapper dresser with a high-pitched voice and a mischievous streak.

title: Review: On Writing, a Charles Bukowski Collection of Rants and Musings in Letters
description: Charles Bukowskis 95th birthday would have been this Sunday. And, inevitably, here comes On Writing, a selection of letters, and a scattering of drawings, by that prolific and bellicosely opinionated author, from 1945 to 1993. According to the news release from Ecco, the book is the first in a series of at least three Bukowski anthologies. Batten down the hatches, folks  as surely everyone must know by now, this wasnt a man inclined to edit himself.

title: Frank Gifford, Giants Icon and Broadcaster, Dies at 84
description: Gifford personified the Giants glory years of the late 1950s and early 60s, then became the low-key play-by-play voice of Monday Night Football on ABC.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Aug. 10
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Tyler Drumheller, Ex-C.I.A. Official Who Disputed Bush, Dies at 63
description: Tyler S. Drumheller, a former senior American intelligence official who publicly asserted that President George W. Bushs administration had knowingly hyped fabricated evidence of Iraqs arsenal of biological weapons to justify the 2003 invasion, died on Aug. 2 in Falls Church, Va. He was 63.

title: Vogue Ads Skip a Step, Linking Readers to Target
description: Iconic images from the pages of Vogue are getting a makeover, courtesy of Target.

title: Carolyn Kaelin, Breast Cancer Surgeon, Patient Advocate and Patient, Dies at 54
description: Dr. Carolyn M. Kaelin, a breast cancer surgeon who continued her research and advocacy for patients after her own diagnosis of breast cancer ended her surgical career, died on July 28 at her home in Charlestown, Mass. She was 54.

title: Black Lives Matter and the G.O.P.
description: Only one candidate in last weeks Republican presidential debate was asked to directly address the Black Lives Matter movement and that candidate was Gov. Scott Walker.

title: Chobanis Founder Sees Opportunity in a Coffee Insurgent
description: Having shaken up the yogurt world, Hamdi Ulukaya, the founder of Chobani, now has his sights on a much tougher target  coffee.

title: N.F.L. to Weigh Three Teams Proposals on Moving to Los Angeles
description: SAN DIEGO  For two decades, N.F.L. owners in search of public funding for their stadiums have often played a trump card: threatening to move to Los Angeles. In a few months, that ultimatum may ring hollow.

title: Will It Rain? Umbrella Man Knows When
description: Dear Diary:

title: Sean Price, Rapper With Deep Brooklyn Roots, Dies at 43
description: Sean Price, a rapper who for two decades embodied the rugged essence of peak-era Brooklyn hip-hop, died in his sleep on Saturday morning at his home in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. He was 43.

title: Argentines Vote in Presidential Primary
description: BUENOS AIRES  Argentines voted to select presidential nominees on Sunday in a primary election that will gauge the nations desire for change after 12 years of the current presidents governing party.

title: Department Store Earnings, Alibabas Results and July Retail Sales
description: The Department of Labor will hold four days of public hearings this week to discuss its proposed rule that would require a broader group of financial professionals to put their clients interests ahead of their own when handling the clients retirement money. The hearings will be held from Monday through Thursday. The White House has estimated that the lack of consumer protection costs investors as much as $17 billion annually, or 1 percent of their assets, and perhaps more. But the rule has faced strong and well-funded opponents in the financial services industry. Those stakeholders, along with consumer advocates including AARP, will have the opportunity to make their arguments to regulators this week. Tara Siegel Bernard

title: Cuomo Says Hudson Tunnels Need Grants, Not Loans to States, From U.S.
description: Two weeks after the federal governments top transportation official urged the governors of New York and New Jersey to meet with him about how to solve the problems plaguing rail service between their states, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said on Sunday that such a meeting would be pointless unless federal officials offered grants, not loans, to finance new tunnels under the Hudson River.

title: Fan Throws Back Homer, Leaving Brett Gardner Welted
description: Jose Bautistas deep home run in the fourth inning of Sundays game came back to hurt the Yankees in more ways than one.

title: Mtime Helps Hollywood Clear Chinas Marketing Hurdles and Reach Fans
description: LOS ANGELES  Now that Hollywood has mostly figured out how to get its biggest movies approved for release in China, studio marketers here are grappling with a new puzzle: What is the best way to woo Chinas ticket buyers?

title: Vainglory Breaks Through in E-Sports on a Tablet
description: Under everyones noses, the competitive video game scene has gotten huge, with more than 113 million fans globally by some estimates.

title: A 12-Year-Old Girl, a Rape and a Bronx Neighborhood Left Unsettled
description: In the chill of a February evening, he pulled on a hat that matched his dark blue coat and approached the girl on the Bronx sidewalk caked in snow. She was 12 and, it appeared, not much younger than he was.

title: Jets Hope Brandon Marshalls Catches Fix a Snag
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  It was second-and-goal, and the Jets had the ball at the 1-yard line. Lined up to the outside was their hulking new receiver, Brandon Marshall, who feinted right and then broke inside, beating his defender. Quarterback Geno Smith rifled a quick slant, and Marshall grabbed the ball in the end zone.

title: Investors Find Ways to Indirectly Profit From Valuable Start-Ups
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Airbnbs valuation has ballooned over the last few years as large financial firms like Fidelity Investments and T. Rowe Price have rushed to invest in the start-up. But a small San Francisco-based hedge fund called Pier 88 Investment Partners has decided that the fervor for Airbnb shares creates a different kind of opportunity.

title: Rethinking an Olympic Format in Light of Katie Ledeckys 1,500 Feat
description: KAZAN, Russia  On the eighth day, Katie Ledecky was supposed to rest. So the text message she sent in the hours after her fifth gold-medal swim of the 16th world championships caught its recipient, Scott Leightman, by surprise.

title: Winning Mantra of Im Not Sick Propels Victoria Duval
description: When Victoria Duval learned last year that she had cancer, the only thing she knew to do was win.

title: Yankees New Look: Over Their Shoulders
description: First, there were no expectations for the Yankees.

title: Frantic Struggle Leaves Unfamiliar Name, Shane Lowry, Atop Leaderboard
description: AKRON, Ohio  The final round of the Bridgestone Invitational was supposed to unfold as a spirited duel between Jim Furyk and Justin Rose, playing partners who entered the day tied for the lead. Instead, a humid afternoon at Firestone Country Club devolved into a frantic scramble at the top.

title: Celebrating Dominican Pride
description: The annual Dominican Day Parade made its way through Manhattan on Sunday.

title: U.S. Air Power and Kurdish Fighters Team Up to Inflict Losses on ISIS
description: But Turkey is nervous about the coordination between the United States and the Kurds, who are seeking autonomy in parts of Turkey and elsewhere.

title: 3 Men Are in Custody in a String of Rapes and Robberies
description: All three women had placed ads online looking to exchange sex for money, and had arranged to meet with an interested party this summer. Each reported afterward that she had been raped and robbed by three men.

title: An Eviction to Make Way for an Ex-Convicts Return
description: For the last three and a half years, Tomoko Watabe, 49, has made Apartment 1C at 46 Downing Street in Manhattan her home, and it shows.

title: Prostitution Charge Dropped in Case an Albany Journalist Called Retaliation
description: ALBANY  In March 2012, just blocks from the State Capitol, several law enforcement officers stormed into a second-floor spa and arrested a woman, accusing her of soliciting money for sexual acts. An invasive strip search was done, thousands of dollars were seized and the woman, Min Liu, was soon charged with prostitution.

title: Masters of Sex Recap: Bill Waxes On About Love, but Does He Sound Believable?
description: Season 3, Episode 5: III-A

title: Red Bulls Finish Season Sweep of New Rival New York City F.C.
description: HARRISON, N.J.  Just before kickoff at Red Bull Arena on Sunday night, an enormous banner rose above a cloud of red smoke in the stands. On it were caricatures of Frank Lampard and Andrea Pirlo, the veteran international superstars who joined the expansion club New York City F.C. halfway through the M.L.S. season.

title: One Year After Michael Browns Death
description: Protesters returned to the spot where Michael Brown Jr., an unarmed 18-year-old, was killed by a white police officer, setting off local unrest and a national debate on race and policing.

title: For a Villa Full of Artists, a French Chef Masters His Italian
description: While many Parisians travel to Tuscany in August to enjoy their requisite monthlong holiday, chef Guillaume Rouxel, the former head chef at Inaki Aizpitartes smart 11th Arrondissement bistro Le Dauphin, has packed up his cooking knives and traveled to Italy to work. Rouxel has taken on a chef residency at the hip hotel and artist retreat Villa Lena, a sprawling 500-hectare estate perched high up in the hills, just a 50-minute drive from Pisa.

title: A Sculptors Assistant Whose Canvas Is Cake
description: Georgia-Rose Fairman makes desserts that are delicious, beautiful and a little gross: a miniature human figure fashioned after the bold, imperfect beauty of a Lucian Freud nude; a fruits de mer banquet commissioned by the French fashion label Carven. So convincing  and tasty  was the flower-festooned pigs head that she made for the restaurant critic A. A. Gills 60th birthday party, that the chef Heston Blumenthal jokingly threatened to dismiss his own pastry chef. Fairman, an assistant to the sculptor Phyllida Barlow, started baking two years ago in her London studio, when she decided to make something for her boyfriends birthday. Rather than the usual chocolate gateau, she got ambitious, precision-carving blocks of marzipan-covered sponge cake before painting them with edible watercolors to create what looked exactly like a roast chicken complete with carrots, potatoes and peas. Its a weird cross between food and sculpture, she says. The main thing for me is that they look like still-life paintings.

title: Word of the Day | egotistical
description: egotistical  \e-g-tis-ti-kl\  adjective

title: Study of Ad-Blocking Software Suggests Wide Use
description: Guillermo Beltr spends a lot of time surfing the web.

title: Hillary Clinton to Offer Plan on Paying College Tuition Without Needing Loans
description: With Americans shouldering $1.2 trillion in student loan debt, and about eight million of them in default, Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday will propose major new spending by the federal government that would help undergraduates pay tuition at public colleges without needing loans.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 6 A.M. (Animal Planet) WORLD LION DAY In remembrance of Cecil (above), who was illegally killed last month in Zimbabwe, and others, Animal Planet presents some of its most memorable lion programming, starting with Last Lion of Liuwa, about the sole survivor of a massacre that destroyed the rest of the pride. The lineup continues with Big Cat Diary, which tracks lions, cheetahs and leopards roaming the Masai Mara National Reserve in Kenya, at 7; Into the Lions Den, which follows Dave Salmoni, a large-predator expert, into lion territory as he tries to prove that the creatures are more likely to accept people than attack them, at 10; Into the Pride, in which Mr. Salmoni works to save rogue lions from elimination, at noon; and A Lion Called Christian, about the story behind the Internet phenomenon depicting the emotional reunion between two men and their 300-pound captive lion a year after it was released into the wild, at 5 p.m. Nat Geo Wild also commemorates big-cat conservation from noon through 8 p.m.

title: Top 10 Fantasy Football Quarterbacks
description: Jason and Justin Sablich, who provide fantasy football analysis for The New York Times, pick their 10 favorite quarterbacks for 2015.

title: 2015 Fantasy Football: Quarterback Preview and Rankings
description: For anyone who played fantasy football last season, it should be no secret that the quarterback position is deep and loaded with value ripe for the picking.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 10, 2015
description: Its crazy. Six years ago, this would not have happened, but now that is the landscape we are in.

title: True Detective Season 2 Finale: In Search of a Better World
description: This post contains spoilers for the season finale of True Detective.

title: South Korea Accuses the North After Land Mines Maim Two Soldiers in DMZ
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korean soldiers sneaked across the heavily guarded border with South Korea and planted land mines near one of the Souths military guard posts, and two southern soldiers were maimed after stepping on them, the South Korean Defense Ministry said Monday.

title: Corrections: August 10, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Returning to a Rebuilding Nepal
description: As soon as I heard the news of Nepals earthquake last April, I knew I had to get back there as soon as possible. Ever since I first arrived there as a Peace Corps volunteer in 1975, I have lived and traveled throughout the country, including in three of the districts devastated by the quakes. Now, deeply saddened and dismayed, I needed to continue documenting life after the devastating 7.8 magnitude quake.

title: Student Crossword | Units of Measure
description: Test your knowledge of units of measure by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: Women, Men and the Office Thermostat
description: To the Editor:

title: The Meeropol Brothers: Exonerate Our Mother, Ethel Rosenberg
description: OUR parents, Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, were executed on June 19, 1953, after being convicted of conspiracy to commit espionage. That was the formal legal charge, but in the publics mind they were executed for providing our archenemy, the Soviet Union, with the ability to destroy our country with atomic bombs. Theirs was the most sensational case of the McCarthy period.

title: Keep the Internet Free of Borders
description: One of the great things about the Internet is that it does not have national borders. When a company in Tokyo sends a digital file to a company in New York, the data does not have to clear customs. But the outcome of  a federal appeals court case could hinder that free flow of information.

title: The Pentagons Dangerous Views on the Wartime Press
description: The Defense Department earlier this summer released a comprehensive manual outlining its interpretation of the law of war. The 1,176-page document, the first of its kind, includes guidelines on the treatment of journalists covering armed conflicts that would make their work more dangerous, cumbersome and subject to censorship. Those should be repealed immediately.

title: Failing Patients With Heart Failure
description: HEART disease is the worlds No. 1 killer, despite advances in medical technology, as well as public health initiatives that have eased the burden of heart disease drastically. While one marvels at the progress, we often ignore how heart-disease patients die.

title: G.O.P. Candidates and Obamas Failure to Fail
description: What did the men who would be president talk about during last weeks prime-time Republican debate? Well, there were 19 references to God, while the economy rated only 10 mentions. Republicans in Congress have voted dozens of times to repeal all or part of Obamacare, but the candidates only named President Obamas signature policy nine times over the course of two hours. And energy, another erstwhile G.O.P. favorite, came up only four times.

title: When the Police Shoot, He Defends Them
description: To the Editor:

title: California Is Proving That Health Reform Works
description: Californians got a double dose of good health care news late last month. The number of Californians who have trouble finding a doctor or paying their medical bills has sharply declined since the Affordable Care Act took effect. And premiums charged by private insurers have risen only modestly, contrary to warnings that insurers were likely to get double-digit premium increases.

title: When Prostitution Is Nobodys Business
description: Moral and political philosophers distinguish among different forms of privacy: physical, informational and decisional. When it comes to sex, we tend to have a strong expectation that well be granted all three.

title: Inside Syria: Kurds Roll Back ISIS, but Alliances Are Strained
description: HASAKA, Syria  Green drapes were drawn against the sun, cloaking the room where members of a Syrian Kurdish militia huddled around walkie-talkies, assiduously taking down GPS coordinates.

title: Emergency Declared in Ferguson After Shooting
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  The St. Louis County executive declared a state of emergency here on Monday as officials and activists sought to regain control of the volatile streets after plainclothes police officers shot and critically wounded an 18-year-old black man who they said was firing on them late the night before.

title: Stampede in India Kills 10 Pilgrims Attending Hindu Festival
description: NEW DELHI  A stampede outside a temple early on Monday morning during a Hindu religious festival in eastern India left 10 pilgrims dead, government officials said.

title: News Qs | In the Eyes of Animals
description: Note: Weve updated 6 Qs About the News for the new school year. This feature, now known as News Qs, will be a daily mini-lesson, with both Before Reading and After Reading questions, and a suggested activity for going further. Let us know what you think.

title: Is College Divestment Worthwhile?
Mens Studies Redux: Readers Respond to a Masters Program in Masculinity
description: Readers wonder about the necessity of a masters program focusing on masculinity, suggest a more general study of gender as an alternative and discuss how maleness is perceived in society today.

title: Protest Marks a Year After Michael Browns Death
description: Protesters returned to the spot where Michael Brown Jr., an unarmed 18-year-old, was killed by a white police officer, setting off local unrest and a national debate on race and policing.

title: Models Are Raising Their Voices, and Their Profiles, Online
description: In late July, Behati Prinsloo lent her voice to a chorus of protests when she took to Instagram to vent her outrage at the killing of Cecil the lion by an American hunter in Zimbabwe.

title: Help for Delayed Travelers Loath to Leave Money on the Runway
description: Ricardo Vice Santos, chief executive of an app start-up, missed a meeting with prospective investors in Stockholm this spring because his SAS flight from Paris was canceled.

title: When Tenants Cant Be Evicted, Building Around or Over Them
description: Two years ago, while walking his familys new puppy, Paul Boardman had the kind of epiphany only a real estate entrepreneur can have.

title: Gunfire at Ferguson March
description: Gunfire was heard Sunday night in Ferguson, Mo., during a protest commemorating the death of Michael Brown, an unarmed black 18-year-old who was shot by a white police officer last year.

title: Jason Rezaian of Washington Post May Soon Get Verdict in Iran, Lawyer Says
description: TEHRAN  An Iranian court could hand down a verdict in the trial of Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post correspondent charged with espionage, within a week, his lawyer told reporters on Monday, as a fourth and possibly final hearing in the case was held in Tehran.

title: Need a Taxi to the Airport? Options Expanding Beyond Uber
description: Hailing a taxi nowadays can feel downright old-fashioned. New ride-sharing alternatives  such as Via, Bandwagon, Tripda and RideWith  are springing up in major cities and at airports. At the same time, established car services like Uber and Lyft are continuing to expand to more corners of the world while adding bells and whistles like Starbucks rewards points, free beach bags and on-demand water taxis.

title: Mondays Digest: Alaska and American Expand Partnership and Other Airline and Airport News
description: Our weekday morning digest that includes information about airlines and airports, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Body Report Cards Arent Influencing Arkansas Teenagers
description: It is one of the boldest and most controversial tactics in the battle against childhood obesity: A growing number of schools are monitoring their students weight and sending updates home, much like report cards.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Embarrassed by Coupons, but Learning How to Save to Splurge
description: My middle child unwraps the red wax wrapping and bites into a chunk of cheese. That cost 9 cents, I tell him. Unimpressed, he eats another. It was supposed to cost almost 50 cents, I explain. It comes in a pack of five, which normally costs $2.49. This week the package cost $1.99, less my 55-cent coupon, taking it down to 89 cents, and thats before a 50-cent rebate. Divide that by five cheeses and you just ate 18 cents, My son looks at me as he unwraps another cheese circle. Youre scary, he says at last. But the cheese is pretty good for 9 cents.

title: Not Vaccinating Children Is the Greater Risk
description: After more than 50 years as a medical and science writer, Im pained to see that childhood immunizations, perhaps the most important health and lifesaving advance of the last century, are being seriously eroded by misinformation and scaremongering.

title: New York Today: Whats That Smell?
description: Good morning on this temperate Monday.

title: Alibaba to Buy 20% Stake in Electronics Retailer Suning
description: HONG KONG  E-commerce companies like Alibaba have changed the way people shop in China and made things tough for brick-and-mortar retailers.

title: Today in Politics: Donald Trumps Comments Follow Other Candidates on the Trail
description: Good Monday morning from Washington, where Congress is on recess, President Obama is on vacation, and the debates hurly-burly is done, the battle lost and won. Among those claiming victory is Donald J. Trump, whose subsequent online confrontation with the Fox News moderator Megyn Kelly was widely seen as sexist, and has prompted hand-wringing among the other candidates about what should be done with him.

title: After Kabul Attack, Afghan Leader Points Finger at Pakistan for Failing to Stop Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Under pressure after a wave of deadly bombings in the Afghan capital, President Ashraf Ghani on Monday accused Pakistan of turning a blind eye to mass gatherings of Taliban fighters in its territory, where such attacks are planned.

title: Labels Like Alternative Medicine Dont Matter. The Science Does.
description: The University of Toronto recently stirred up a bit of controversy by offering an uncritical class on Alternative Medicine. A variety of bloggers and journalists brought up many valid concerns about the curriculum, but there is a much larger problem: No one is sure how best to teach that subject.

title: The Roanoke Island Colony: Lost, and Found?
description: MERRY HILL, N.C.  Under a blistering sun, Nicholas M. Luccketti swatted at mosquitoes as he watched his archaeology team at work in a shallow pit on a hillside above the shimmering waters of Albemarle Sound. On a table in the shade, a pile of plastic bags filled with artifacts was growing. Fragments of earthenware and pottery. A mashed metal rivet. A piece of a hand-wrought nail.

title: Attackers in Istanbul Open Fire Outside U.S. Consulate
description: ISTANBUL  Attackers opened fire outside the United States Consulate here on Monday morning, setting off a brief gun battle with the police as violence in Turkey continued to escalate nearly two weeks after the government began what it called a major counterterrorism effort, including increased cooperation with the United States in the fight against the Islamic State.

title: Indonesian Court Rejects Sex Abuse Suit Against International School
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  An Indonesian court on Monday dismissed a $125 million lawsuit filed against one of the countrys most prestigious international schools by the parents of a former student who claimed their child was repeatedly sexually assaulted by educators and school janitors.

title: Morning Agenda: S.E.C. Ready to Make a Splash
description: S.E.C. READY TO MAKE A SPLASH | The Securities and Exchange Commission is pursuing high-profile cases while fending off criticism that it is not aggressive enough in forcing wrongdoers to admit liability, Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein report in DealBook. It is poised to file charges soon in an investigation that combines insider trading with cybersecurity, according to people briefed on the investigation, but not authorized to speak publicly. The case centers on whether overseas hackers broke into the networks of American companies to secure inside information about corporate deals, later passing on that information to traders.

title: Europes Deepest Debt
description: From time to time I am reminded of all that Europe lost. It can happen in the most unlikely places, like in San Diego for example.

title: Warren Buffetts Berkshire Hathaway to Buy Aerospace Supplier for $37.2 Billion
description: When a lieutenant to Warren E. Buffett first invested in Precision Castparts three years ago, the billionaire had hardly heard of the metal parts manufacturer.

title: Pakistan, the Next Software Hub?
description: KARACHI  Pakistan isnt usually considered one of the worlds information technology powerhouses; its share of global I.T. sales is only $2.8 billion, of which $1.6 billion represents tech and I.T. services and software exported abroad. This is a tiny percentage of the expected $3.2 trillion global market for 2015, and is dwarfed by Indias $100 billion worth of software exports per year.

title: As Print Fades, Part 1: Live Journalism at The Times
description: With its announcement last week that one million digital-only subscribers now pay for its journalism, The Times hit a major milestone, and one worth celebrating. Just a few years back, as various pay wall efforts were tried and put on the shelf, that eye-popping number was close to unimaginable.

title: Environmental Agency Uncorks Its Own Toxic Water Spill at Colorado Mine
description: DURANGO, Colo.  The Animas River is the cultural soul of this patch of southwestern Colorado, a sort of moving Main Street that hosts multiple floating parades a year and is typically bustling with rafters and kayakers. Schoolchildren study the river. Sweethearts marry on its banks. Its former name, given by Spaniards, is el Ro de las nimas, the River of Souls.

title: Trash Talk and the Macroeconomic Divide
description: Paul Romer continues to maintain that Chicagos inward turn, the rejection of all salt-water macroeconomics that left it so hapless in the face of the Great Recession, was a defensive reaction to the sarcasm of Robert Solow. Brad DeLong points out that Solow was, as it turns out, right. Beyond that, as Brad notes and Paul actually acknowledges, what was actually going on at MIT was nothing like the implacable opposition of Chicago fantasies.

title: MallinckrodtPharmaceuticals to Acquire Therakos for $1.33 Billion
description: LONDON  Mallinckrodt Pharmaceuticals, a maker of drugs and medical devices, said on Monday that it had agreed to buy Therakos from the American private equity firm Gores Group for about $1.33 billion.

title: Why Smart Objects May Be a Dumb Idea
description: A FRIDGE that puts milk on your shopping list when you run low. A safe that tallies the cash that is placed in it. A sniper rifle equipped with advanced computer technology for improved accuracy. A car that lets you stream music from the Internet.

title: Algorithms and Bias: Q. and A. With Cynthia Dwork
description: Algorithms have become one of the most powerful arbiters in our lives. They make decisions about the news we read, the jobs we get, the people we meet, the schools we attend and the ads we see.

title: 1915: German Intellectuals Manifesto
description: The German intellectuals, according to the Figaro, have just signed another egregious manifesto which bids fair to rival the notorious one they issued at the outset of the war in defence of the war. Naturally, says the manifesto, we do not want to dominate the world, but we demand the possibility of extending our culture and our industrial and commercial power all over the earth. This is the firm determination of the German people. To this end we must remove the French menace and danger. We must modify our western frontier from Belfort to the coast. We must, if possible, conquer the French Channel coast in order to fortify ourselves against Great Britain.  The New York Herald, European Edition, August 11, 1915

title: Daily Report: How to Play the Valuation Gap Between Start-Ups and Public Tech Companies
description: One of the most notable trends in Silicon Valley over the last five years has been the emergence of a group of highly valued start-ups, all valued at more than $1 billion, and known as unicorns. Only a small set of deep-pocketed investor, typically venture capitalists and hedge funds and mutual funds, has been able to participate in the run-up in valuations of these companies.

title: German Journalists Celebrate as Treason Inquiry Is Dropped
description: BERLIN  The German bloggers who were being investigated on suspicion they committed treason by publishing confidential government materials had multiple reasons to celebrate on Monday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Behind Bars, All Alone

title: Many Older Women Dont Need Vitamin D Supplements
description: Vitamin D supplements may be ineffective in improving bone density or bone strength in postmenopausal women, a clinical trial has found.

title: Thermal Imaging of Blast in DMZ
description: A video provided by the South Korean Defense Ministry shows a land mine explosion last week in the Demilitarized Zone dividing the two Korean armies.

title: Gear Dispute Costs Nick Symmonds a Trip to Track Worlds
description: Nick Symmonds, the American national champion at 800 meters, was left off the United States team for the world track and field championships in a dispute involving athletes individual endorsements and requirements to wear official team gear.

title: Ikea to Replace All Lighting on Shelves With LED Bulbs
description: For years, lighting companies have been predicting a time when LED bulbs will become the standard, replacing not only traditional incandescent lights, but halogen and compact fluorescents as well.

title: #BlackTwitter After #Ferguson
description: On the anniversary of Michael Browns death, three prominent activists read their tweets from the past year and reflect on the challenges and legacy of the Black Lives Matter movement.

title: Photos and Video Show Protests in Ferguson Turning Violent
description: On Sunday afternoon, it looked as if the anniversary of the death of Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager shot by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., was going to be remembered for forceful but peaceful protests.

title: Jack Dorsey and Other Twitter Insiders Make Show of Support
description: Twitter has had a tough year. It has been slow to attract more users and has been battered on the public markets.

title: Ex-Officer in Chinese Army Receives Suspended Death Sentence in Graft Case
description: BEIJING  A Chinese military court has handed down a suspended death sentence to a former senior officer who was accused of bribery, embezzlement and abuse of power in his role handling huge sums of money for the armys logistics department, the state news media reported on Monday.

title: Jason Rezaians Mother Speaks Out
description: Mary Rezaian, the mother of the Washington Post journalist held in Iran, said that her son had done nothing wrong, and that his trial resulted from political issues between the United States and Iran.

title: They Helped Make Twitter Matter in Ferguson Protests
description: A year ago, these three activists were ordinary Americans: a teacher, a school administrator and a temporary government employee. Like many others, they found a voice on social media to comment on the news, describe their personal experiences and relate the everyday struggles of blacks in America.

title: Times Critics Guide: What to Do This Week
description: Need to break out of a cultural rut?

title: Blue Jays Record Catches Up to Expectations
description: On the morning of July 29, the Toronto Blue Jays had a losing record and were eight games out of first place in the American League East.

title: Cold Sesame Noodles: Without the Wait for Takeout
description: Cold sesame noodles are a mainstay of Chinese takeout menus in New York City. They have been so since at least the 1970s, when Chinese chefs trained in the banquet arts introduced the dish to diners at new-style Sichuan restaurants like Hwa Yuan on East Broadway, the Empire Szechuan chain uptown and Tang Tangs near Gramercy Park.

title: A Ukrainian Border Town Once Fenced by Soviets Blossoms Into a Shoppers Paradise
description: MALI SELMENTSI, Ukraine  The main street is a lovely ribbon of asphalt these days, a far cry from the rutted moonscape that once prevented even buses from bouncing into the tiny, decrepit village.

title: The Watts Riots
description: A look back at how The New York Times covered the Watts riots over the years.

title: Confederate Flag Debate Reaches New York County Fairs
description: NEW PALTZ, N.Y.  Under a white tent at the Ulster County Fair  wedged between a homemade fudge stand and a basketball toss, and near an array of Save the Hooters shirts and I  Mommy bibs  hung a black extra-large T-shirt emblazoned with the Confederate battle flag.

title: A Quiet Revolution in the Treatment of Childhood Diarrhea
description: Far from the worlds fears about Ebola and MERS, a quiet revolution is taking place in the diagnosis of a disease much more prosaic but far more threatening: childhood diarrhea. After pneumonia, diarrhea is the deadliest threat to infants worldwide, killing about 700,000 every year.

title: Suspect Arrested After Shooting in Texas
description: David Conley III, 48, was charged with murder in the deaths of eight family members, including six children, in Houston.

title: Witnesses Describe Kabul Attack
description: Witnesses gave their accounts of the suicide attack at the airport in Kabul, Afghanistan, that took place on Monday, killing at least four people.

title: Benedict Cumberbatch to Fans: No Cellphones, Please
description: The battle against cellphone use has another front along with Broadway  the West End.

title: Ta-Nehisi Coates: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of Between the World and Me is a fan of the late E. L. Doctorow. The Waterworks is one of the most thrilling books Ive ever read. And I still believe in that, you know? That stories should sometimes thrill people.

title: Los Angeles Is a Frugal, if Not Flashy, Option for the 2024 Games
description: LOS ANGELES  With no shade from the Southern California sun, the 90,000 plastic seats inside Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum have faded almost to white in some places. The handrails have rusted, and the steps have grown treacherous where concrete has been patched countless times.

title: I Am Cait Episode 3 Recap: Some People Want to Be Seen as Heroes
description: Season 1, Episode 3: The Road Trip: Part 2

title: John Conways Wizard Puzzle
description: This week we continue to acknowledge the whimsical brilliance of John Conway, the British mathematician featured in the newly-released biography by Siobhan Roberts (in case you missed it, see John Horton Conway, the Genius at Play). Our Conway challenge is a rather famous one in math circles, and wassuggested by Laura Feiveson, an M.I.T.-trained economist. Dr. Feivesonwarms us up with a rock and a hen before getting to themain event:

title: When Mom Is Part of the Bachelorette Party Debauchery
description: Traveling to a resort city like Miami with a handful of girlfriends for a pre-wedding weekend of debauchery  with drinking, pricey dinners, high-end hotels and male strip clubs  is the norm these days for a bachelorette party.

title: Setting Up a Budget Based on Your Values
description: At a recent breakfast, a friend shared the process he and his wife use in place of traditional budgeting. It takes them less than 15 minutes a month, and after the first month, its already had a massive impact on the way they use money. Think of this as a little case study, one that shows exactly how easy it can be to align your spending with what you say is important to you.

title: Milans Expo 2015 Finds Success, but With a Muddled Message
description: Milan  At the New York Crystal Palace Exhibition in 1853, the potato chip made its big debut. The Pan-American Exposition of 1901 in Buffalo introduced the X-ray machine.

title: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch This Week
description: As you settle in for another week of soccer viewing in your comfiest chair, spare a moment to think about the soon-to-be-weary legs of the players at Barcelona, which will soon be the latest victim of the clubs success. The soccer editor Andrew Das tells you what to watch.

title: 1940: Rush to Marry Ahead of Draft
description: The effects of the Burke-Wadsworth bill for compulsory selective military training, which exempts married men, were noticeable yesterday at marriage license bureaus throughout New York. Records were established in the Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens offices, even though they were not open for the full day. At the Brooklyn bureau, on the second floor of Borough Hall, ten policemen were needed to keep a long line of applicants in order. Julius J. Brosen, chief clerk, said: This is the biggest day weve had this year.  New York Herald Tribune, August 11, 1940

title: NBC Retains Rights to Premier League in Six-Year Deal
description: Two years of success broadcasting Englands Premier League proved a basic truth to NBC Sports: It would have to pay a lot more to keep carrying the leagues games.

title: Unpredictable Work Hours, Chaotic Life
description: The tyranny of erratic work schedules is obvious to employees who dont know what their schedules will be tomorrow or have to call in to see if there is work. And the effects have been well documented in articles and oral histories. Increasingly, the anecdotal evidence is being confirmed by research.

title: Cumberbatch Makes Plea to Hamlet Fans
description: The actor Benedict Cumberbatch asked a group of fans in London not to film his performances of Hamlet on their mobile phones, as the red lights are distracting.

title: A Searing First Encounter With David Lynchs Blue Velvet
description: And then the young man picked up the severed ear and stared deeply into its ant-encrusted whorls.

title: A Republican Agitator in the Senate Makes Friends Across the Aisle
description: WASHINGTON  As meetings among congressional colleagues go, the one last month in which Republican senators confronted Mike Lee, a freshman from Utah, was among the most contentious in years.

title: 2 Sayreville Football Players Cleared of Serious Charges in Hazing Case
description: Two of the high school football players charged in a 2014 hazing case in Sayreville, N.J., have been acquitted of all serious charges, their lawyers said on Monday.

title: Witness Videos of Shootout in Istanbul
description: Amateur videos show a gun battle between attackers and Turkish police outside the United States Consulate in Istanbul.

title: Marco Rubio and Jeb Bush Pan Hillary Clintons Student Loan Plan
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton is readying a $350 billion plan to address Americas student loan debt crisis, but to her Republican rivals the idea sounded like something familiar: a tax hike.

title: You Will See the Doctors Fallibility Now
description: I was not present for the incident in radiology, but I heard all about it. The patient with the swollen ankle watched with increasing puzzlement as the technician prepared to X-ray his other foot.

title: Nusra Front Announces Withdrawal From Front Line Against ISIS in Syria
description: GAZIANTEP, Turkey  The Syrian affiliate of Al Qaeda has announced its withdrawal from front-line positions against the Islamic State extremist group in northern Syria, saying that it disagrees with plans by Turkey and the United States to clear the extremists from an area along the Turkish border.

title: A Tanqueray Gin With a Past
description: An unmistakable whiff of juniper rises from the glass holding the latest iteration of Tanqueray gin. Called Bloomsbury, the gin is named after the location of the companys English distillery in the late 19th century. It is a limited-edition spirit that the companys former distiller Tom Nichol based on a recipe created by Charles Waugh Tanqueray. Though it is in the bracing style of London dry gin, it also has spicy, licorice and floral notes. Sip it on the rocks with a subtle touch of lime, or let it loose in a gimlet or a southside: Tanqueray Bloomsbury gin, $33 at reservebar.com.

title: Vu Trans Dragonfish
description: Contrary to all protestations, America is a nation not of immigrants but of refugees. Trauma, displacement and fanatical hope have marked all new Americans from the occupants of the Mayflower through every subsequent group who came to these shores (or who were brought here by force). This is the unspoken and sometimes unacknowledged fear and fact of being American: These unkind ghosts of our pasts, these specters of previous selves and previous nations that will not be dismissed so easily, always attend our daily negotiations around identity. They cause a torment that can turn us violent, hateful and self-destructive, and the uneasy grace we win is in itself a remarkable thing. The longer our stay in the United States, the fainter the ghosts get, until they are not much more than a vague unsettled feeling that itself causes even more confusion. Novels by recently arrived Americans have tried to negotiate the struggle to fit into a new home that doesnt always want them, and the nostalgia for all that has been lost. In this way new immigrant literature mimics its antecedents.

title: Stylish Synthetics
description: Life in plastic? Its fantastic.

title: Climate Change Could Harm British Butterflies
description: Six species of butterflies in Britain will face local extinction by 2050 because of climate change, a new study reports.

title: Ivan Doigs Last Bus to Wisdom
description: By the time he died in April at age 75, Ivan Doig had created a body of work that helped shape our understanding of rural working-class life in the postwar American West. Raised by Montana ranchers in the 1940s and 50s, Doig lived most of his adult years in Seattle but never really left Big Sky Country. From his early memoir, This House of Sky, to this final novel, Last Bus to Wisdom, Doig often gave Montana a leading role. Partly because of this emphasis, his work has been hit or miss for me. Ive pounded the table in favor of some novels (once literally, as an award juror, for Bucking the Sun), and Ive abandoned others halfway through, bored with the relentless Montanana.

title: Landlord of Three-Quarter Homes Faces Criminal Charges
description: Prosecutors have filed criminal charges against a notorious landlord of cramped flophouses in Brooklyn, taking what housing advocates described as unusually forceful action against an operator of so-called three-quarter homes.

title: Preventing Suicide in Americas Jails
description: Suicide has long been a problem in the corrections system, where a considerable portion of inmates suffer from mental illness. But new federal data show that suicide has reached crisis proportions in local jails, where psychiatric care appears to be particularly poor. This situation is especially alarming, given that 12 million people  many with mental illnesses  will cycle through local jails this year.

title: Truffles Travel Well for DArtagnan
description: The move was just six miles. But the cargo  63 truckloads of pt, truffles, Wagyu beef and even whole pigs  required extraordinary attention, as well as refrigeration.

title: If Mosquitoes Disappeared
description: Its only natural that human beings, who do the itching and suffering from mosquito-borne diseases, want to imagine the insects gone.

title: Donald Trump Reacts to Criticism by Staying on the Offensive
description: After a weekend of criticism about his contentious debate performance and verbal attacks on the Fox News anchor Megyn Kelly, Donald J. Trump showed no signs of backing down on Monday.

title: Around the World in One Memoir
description: Geoffrey Kent, the founder and CEO of the luxury travel company Abercrombie & Kent, is adding, coincidentally albeit poignantly, to the discussion about big-game hunting. The Kenya-raised Kent led his inaugural safari in 1962 under the slogan hunt with a camera, not with a gun, and expanded his program over the years, even attracting a post-Liz-Taylor-breakup Richard Burton. In Safari: A Memoir of a Worldwide Travel Pioneer ($35, Harper Collins), out tomorrow, Kent recounts these anecdotes and more from places as far-flung as the North Pole and the Galpagos Islands. I wanted this book to inspire people to travel, he says. You can find out more about yourself and find out more about others.

title: Growing Vegetables in Space, NASA Astronauts Tweet Their Lunch
description: The local food movement has now reached outer space.

title: tk
description: tk

title: Frogs With a Venomous Head Butt
description: There are many poisonous frogs  eat the wrong frog legs at a Paris bistro, and youre in trouble. Now researchers have discovered two venomous frogs that deliver potent toxins through bony spines on their heads.

title: Body Found in Hudson Is That of Ian Jones, Tali Lennoxs Boyfriend
description: The search for Ian Jones, the artist and model missing since a kayak accident on Saturday, ended on Tuesday with the confirmation that the body found in the Hudson River on Monday was that of Mr. Jones. The findings of an autopsy conducted by the Dutchess County Medical Examiner were consistent with drowning, and Mr. Joness death is considered to be an accidental drowning with no criminal charges expected, according to a statement by Capt. John Watterson of the Dutchess County sheriffs office. Results of toxicology tests performed during the autopsy will not be known for several weeks.

title: F.D.A.s Off-Label Drug Policy Leads to Free-Speech Fight
description: It certainly seems odd that speaking the truth can violate the law. Yet the Food and Drug Administration takes the position that when it approves a drug for a particular treatment, the manufacturer of that drug cannot promote it for other uses even if those statements are true.

title: Deadly Stampede at Indian Temple
description: Additional forces have been deployed to eastern Jharkhand State in India, after a stampede broke out at a local temple, leaving at least 10 people dead and more than 20 injured.

title: Jonathan Ollivier, Dancer Featured in Matthew Bournes Work, Dies in Crash
description: LONDON  Jonathan Ollivier, a British dancer who played a starring role in Matthew Bournes work, died here on Sunday after a car struck his motorcycle. He was 38. Mr. Ollivier, who had been performing the leading role in Mr. Bournes The Car Man at Sadlers Wells, was on his way to the theater, where he was set to appear that night in the companys final performance of the season. The BBC reported that paramedics and an air ambulance tried to save Mr. Olliviers life but pronounced him dead at the scene shortly before midday. It also reported that the driver of the vehicle that collided with Mr. Ollivier had been arrested.

title: Police in Bangladesh Kill 6 Suspected of Tiger Poaching in Shootout
description: NEW DELHI  The police in Bangladesh announced that they had killed six men suspected of tiger poaching during a shootout Sunday in the Sundarbans, a mangrove forest, in what they described as the beginning of a larger crackdown.

title: When Dams Come Down, Salmon and Sand Can Prosper
description: When people urge the removal of dams they say are strangling rivers in the West, its usually fish theyre worried about. Studies of dam-removal projects show that migratory species like salmon respond quickly to improved conditions once a dam is removed.

title: Armani/Silos
description: Scenes from inside the exhibition space (dont call it a museum) in Milan.

title: Watts,50 Years On, Stands in Contrast to Todays Conflicts
description: LOS ANGELES  Donny Joubert watched the boy round the corner of the housing project holding what looked like a handgun. The barrel was pointed at him and the two officers from the Los Angeles Police Department. The boy was 10 or 11 years old, Mr. Joubert figured, and had more gleam than anger in his eyes. Mr. Joubert, a community activist who grew up in the project, shouted and lunged for the gun.

title: Armanis Four-Story Wardrobe
description: MILAN  In a former Nestl granary in the Zona Tortona of Milan, Giorgio Armani has opened a temple to Giorgio Armani. Armani/Silos, his new exhibition space (he prefers not to call it a museum) is stocked four floors high with his clothes, about 600 pieces in all.

title: Judd Apatow and Trevor Noah Among New York Comedy Festival Performers
description: Judd Apatow,Trevor Noah, Margaret Cho and Sarah Silverman are among the performers taking part in this years New York Comedy Festival, which will run from Nov. 10 through Nov. 15.

title: Republican Attack on Voting Rights
description: Editorial page editor Andrew Rosenthal on what he says is a partisan effort to keep minorities from voting.

title: The Donald and Decadence
description: I tried to avoid the coals-to-Newcastle phenomenon that is Trump coverage this weekend by writing my Sunday column on immigration politics in Europe instead, with a particular focus on how the widening population differential on either side of the Mediterranean, already roiling European politics, is likely to create a kind of sweeping Eurafrican interaction over the next fifty years, with truly unknowable results. Its a big topic, a lot bigger even than the yugeness of Trump  but there are, yes, links between the two phenomena, which my old friend Reihan Salam teased out a bit for Slate last week:

title: 2 Who Parachuted Off World Trade Center Tower Avoid Jail Time
description: Two men who parachuted off 1 World Trade Center avoided jail time when they were sentenced on Monday, but a judge fined them $2,000 each and ordered them to perform hundreds of hours of community service.

title: A Disco-Driven Track Inspired by a Near-Death Experience
description: The story of the Greek pop singer Monikas upcoming album, Secret in the Dark, begins in 2012, when, fresh from a trip stateside, she found the courage to end a rotten relationship. Everyone feels imprisoned at one point in their life. Coming to New York really let me breathe, she says. My first two releases were pretty much just ballads. I was known in Greece for my deep, emotional side. (Shes picked up significant steam in her homeland for her Florence Welch-reminiscent vocals, appearing on a spate of magazine covers and headlining each of its major music festivals.)

title: Drawings of Police Torture Seize Chinas Attention
description: BEIJING  The hand-drawn images are bizarre and disturbing. One shows a man locked in a cage while a police officer pours boiling water on his head. Another shows him suspended from the ceiling by handcuffs as an officer jabs his side with an electric baton.

title: Astronauts Eat Lettuce Grown in Space
description: On Monday, astronauts aboard the International Space Station harvested and ate the first lettuce to have been grown in space.

title: Travel Diary
description: Richard Christiansen and Vanessa Holden share images from India, the second stop in their three-week trip around the world.

title: Hotel That Enlivened the Bronx Is Now a Hot Spot for Legionnaires
description: The arrival of the Opera House Hotel in the South Bronx two years ago was a turning point for a poor corner of New York City.

title: For Many in Spain, a Heralded Economic Recovery Feels Like a Bust
description: ZARAGOZA, Spain  He used to be an interior designer, outfitting shops for one of Spains biggest clothing store chains.

title: 1947: Flying Saucers Land in The Times
description: This feature looks at some of the earliest mentions of famous names or terms in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Leave a suggestion in the comments section.

title: Ferlinghetti on Nagasaki
description: The horror of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki blasts, 70 years ago this month, is receding in human memory. With distance comes the peril of ignorance and indifference.

title: Buffetts Diverse Deals
description: The businesses Warren Buffett likes to acquire are also leaders in their industry, have stable management, and reliably produce lots of cash. Here are Berkshires five biggest deals, which all fit the mold.

title: Black Chronicles II Exhibition in Cambridge Set for September
description: Black Chronicles II, an exhibition of photographs of black subjects in Britain in the late 1800s to early 1900s, will be shown to an American audience for the first time starting Sept. 2 at the new Ethelbert Cooper Gallery of African American Art in Cambridge, Mass.

title: De Blasio Gives Legionnaires Update
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio announces that no one has gotten sick from Legionnaires disease since Aug. 3, called it a promising sign while saying the death toll from the outbreak had reached 12.

title: Review: Ayn Rands Ideal Presents a Protagonist Familiar in Her Superiority
description: The movie-star heroine of Ayn Rands Ideal is a legendary, enigmatic beauty named Kay Gonda, paid a fortune by Hollywood for her work and worshiped by the faceless multitudes. Her press agent writes: Kay Gonda does not cook her own meals or knit her own underwear. She does not play golf, adopt babies, or endow hospitals for homeless horses. She is not kind to her dear old mother  she has no dear old mother. She is not just like you and me. She never was like you and me. Shes like nothing you rotters ever dreamt of.

title: U.S. Air Power and Kurdish Fighters Team Up to Inflict Losses on ISIS
description: But Turkey is nervous about the coordination between the United States and the Kurds, who are seeking autonomy in parts of Turkey and elsewhere.

title: Review: In Kevin From Work, Caricatures Are the Rule
description: Its O.K. to make a deliberately dumb comedy; some people like them. But when your deliberately dumb comedy is populated by dimwitted, sex-obsessed women and its premiere is broadcast days after Donald Trumps incendiary comment about Megyn Kelly of Fox News, it suddenly seems not just dumb but also regressive.

title: No Trick: Penn & Teller a Broadway Hit
description: In one of their onstage illusions, Penn & Teller make coins appear in a fishbowl and hand them to an audience member.

title: Frances Stark
description: No subject is off-limits in her uncompromising oeuvre, from sex chats to work anxieties.

title: Warren Buffett Bucks Trends With Precision Castparts Acquisition
description: It could be said that Berkshire Hathaways latest multibillion-dollar deal  its biggest ever  lacks precision. Berkshire, Warren Buffetts industrial empire, is paying $37.2 billion, including debt, for the aircraft components maker Precision Castparts. The acquisition fits Mr. Buffetts mold, but coincides with cyclical highs in plane orders, stock valuations, and mergers and acquisitions.

title: Shake Shack Reports Higher Quarterly Sales and Profits
description: Shake Shack, one of the many upstart burger chains that are redefining the American fast-food hamburger, reported  quarterly  sales on Monday that surpassed Wall Streets expectations.

title: A Guide to Museums Dedicated to Fashion Designers
description: There are shrines to Saint Laurent, Ferragamo, Gucci, Valentino Balenciaga and Dior.

title: New Jersey Man Charged With Plotting to Support ISIS
description: A New Jersey man who prosecutors said tried to organize support for the Islamic State was arrested on Monday.

title: Housing for Homeless Veterans Is Planned for Ex-Walter Reed Site
description: WASHINGTON  The hallways of the former Walter Reed Army Medical Center, which cared for generations of soldiers, have been quiet since the hospital closed in 2011 and merged with the nearby Bethesda Naval Hospital. But a deal being negotiated by the Army and the city of Washington might give the historic hospital a renewed purpose: housing veterans who might otherwise be homeless.

title: Review: In Unknown Soldier, a War Echoes Through Generations
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.  About 10 million soldiers never came home from World War I. Many who did left something behind on those battlefields  skin, bone, spirit. In Michael Friedman and Daniel Goldsteins affecting new musical, Unknown Soldier, which just closed a brief run at the Williamstown Theater Festival, an amnesiac in military dress (Derek Klena) is found in 1918, wandering around Grand Central Terminal without identifying papers. (The story seems inspired by an actual case that captivated postwar France.)

title: Google to Reorganize as Alphabet to Keep Its Lead as an Innovator
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google was founded as a company that did Internet search. Over time, it has broadened into areas as varied as drones, pharmaceuticals and venture capital, none of which make much money, and some of which have spooked investors.

title: Ferguson Anniversary Protesters Arrested
description: Police in St. Louis arrested dozens of protesters, including the scholar and author Cornel West, as they gathered outside a courthouse on the one-year anniversary of the death of Michael Brown.

title: Donald Trump Makes Up With Roger Ailes of Fox News
description: Donald J. Trump appears to be ready to let bygones be bygones  with Roger Ailes.

title: Diors Exquisite New Bracelet
description: The very idea of a cuff can seem constraining, but Victoire de Castellane, the iconoclastic designer of Dior Fine Jewelry since 1998, has spun an exquisitely supple one. De Castellane spent her childhood admiring the sumptuous plisss and chiffons of her grandmothers evening gowns, and this bracelet, from the Soie Dior collection  a play on the French for silk as well as on the words be Dior  captures the fluidity of fabric falling in folds. Platinum, pink and yellow gold and five sorts of precious stones undulate like silken ribbons; threads of gems cinch and bunch, loosen and flow; and stitches of baguettes give way to dazzling purple and pink sapphires that unfurl from the cushion-cut Mozambique ruby centerpiece, which clasps the strands. In the hands of the fearlessly quirky de Castellane, who has in the past riffed extravagantly on themes from Disney to Bollywood, something hard looks soft, something inert looks alive  a cuff deep with pleats and creases, as delicate as a charm bracelet in motion.

title: Plan to Redraw Internal Districts in Nepal Prompts Violent Protest
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  Protests broke out across Nepal on Monday after four major political parties signed an agreement to divide the country into six provinces, a significant but contentious step toward creating a new constitution.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Our nightly rundown will get you caught up on the days big stories.

title: Pictures of the Day: The United States and Elsewhere
description: The United States and More  Pictures of the Day

title: August 10, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from the United States, Portugal, Greece and Nepal.

title: Indias Enduring Creative Spirit
description: Richard Christiansen, the founder of Chandelier Creative and Vanessa Holden, former senior vice president of West Elm, document their three-week trip around the world searching for creative inspiration exclusively for T.

title: Born to Make Photos
description: Harry Gruyaerts father made film. He makes pictures. His credo: I just physically jump into a situation and react to it, and see how things are working out.

title: Yodlee, a Hub for Financial Apps, Sells Itself to Envestnet
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Last fall, Yodlee, an online hub for consumer financial apps, went public after 15 years as a private company.

title: Guggenheim Partners Pays $20 Million to Settle S.E.C. Charges
description: The investment arm of Guggenheim Partners has agreed to pay $20 million to settle charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it failed to disclose a $50 million loan by a client to one of its senior executives.

title: Haruki Murakamis Virtual Desk Tour, Lennys Head Start and an Instagram That Marries Art and Eats
description: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: The Moon Passed in Front of the Earth. Why Wasnt There an Eclipse?
description: NASA explains why an animated image of the Moon crossing over the Earth wasnt just someone being creative with Photoshop.

title: From Hemingway to Miles Teller, a Brief History of the Tough Celebrity Profile
description: One can imagine the gatekeepers of Hollywood emailing the September Esquire cover article about the actor Miles Teller to their clients with a cautionary warning: This is what happens when you run your mouth to a reporter.

title: Vail International Dance Festival Sets Itself Apart With an Enchanting Lineup
description: VAIL, Colo.  After Fridays International Evening of Dance here, a California friend, visiting Colorado for a few days, texted me to say: Cant believe I just saw that lineup! Amazing ballerinas Sara Mearns, Yuan Yuan Tan, Isabella Boylston, Linda Celeste Sims, and Tiler Peck on the same stage in one night!

title: With Kill the Lights, Luke Bryan Downshifts a Country Party
description: Luke Bryan turned 39 last month, and its safe to surmise that his hips are getting tired. For the last few years, hes been playing a young mans game  his brand of country music is dynamic, attitudinal, a little goofy. There are flickers of hip-hop in his phrasing; at his shows, he struts atop a tricked-out pickup truck. His most successful single is called Country Girl (Shake It for Me).

title: Man Charged in Bitcoin Scheme Appears in New York Court
description: Anthony Murgio, a Florida man who was charged last month by federal prosecutors in Manhattan with running an illegal bitcoin money exchange firm and is thought to have information about last summers hacking attack against JPMorgan Chase, seemed to be taking the unfolding criminal case against him in stride during a court appearance on Monday morning.

title: Review: Tanglewood Orchestra Celebrating Its 75th
description: LENOX, Mass.  In the late 1930s, when the Boston Symphony Orchestra started playing concerts in the open-air environs of Tanglewood in the Berkshire Mountains of western Massachusetts, Serge Koussevitzky, the ensembles visionary music director at the time, thought that presenting symphonic programs in an idyllic setting was a valuable enterprise.

title: Style at the Apollo
description: Men discussed their fashion choices before a show in Harlem.

title: Black Activists Arrested in Ferguson Protests
description: Two activists widely known on Twitter were among 57 people arrested Monday during a protest at the federal courthouse in downtown St. Louis.

title: Review: The Academy of Ancient Music Tackled Mendelssohn at Mostly Mozart Festival
description: Was that really the Academy of Ancient Music, playing so roughly, almost raucously at times, in Mendelssohns Scottish Symphony on Sunday? Yes, it was, and it was thrilling.

title: Review: Diane Coburn Bruning and Ashley Bouder Stretch the Rules of Classicism at the Joyce
description: Diane Coburn Bruning, a choreographer based in Washington, has long been a proponent of stretching the definition of classicism in contemporary ballet. Ashley Bouder, the prodigious New York City Ballet principal, is just getting started on that path as the producer (with Phil Chan) of the Ashley Bouder Project. Both are part of the Joyce Theaters Ballet Festival, which continues through Sunday.

title: La MaMa Announces Season of Premieres and Reimagined Classics
description: A production of Euripides Medea, performed by actors with disabilities, as well as the world premiere of the last work from Mabou Miness founder are part of the coming season at La MaMa.

title: Rand Paul Compares Donald Trump to the Emperor With No Clothes
description: Lagging in the polls, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky set aside his right to privacy agenda on Monday afternoon to take up another cause: derailing Donald J. Trump.

title: Gus Mortson, Scrappy All-Star for Toronto N.H.L. Champions, Dies at 90
description: Gus Mortson, a pugnacious All-Star defenseman who played on four Stanley Cup championship teams with the Toronto Maple Leafs in the late 1940s and early 50s, died on Saturday in Timmins, Ontario. He was 90.

title: Review: Bard Festival Salutes Carlos Chvez
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  In an article in 1940 in The New York Times the Mexican composer Carlos Chvez wrote that the folk-music of a country influences in one way or another, but always substantially, the individual creations of great learned composers. The degree to which Mr. Chvez (1899-1978) integrated native and local traditions into his own works was a major theme of the Bard Music Festival, which opened last weekend at Bard College here.

title: Descendants Soundtrack Tops a Chart of Descending Sales
description: The soundtrack to Descendants, Disney Channels latest television movie, tops the Billboard chart this week, the latest example of music from TV and the movies going to No. 1. But its sales were the lowest for any No. 1 in 24 years.

title: Chinese Christians Resist Government Plan to Remove Crosses
description: Resistance is growing among Chinas expanding Christian community to a government campaign to remove crosses from churches in a wealthy coastal province.

title: Police Groups Darren Wilson Day Is Condemned
description: A police officers group in Columbia, Mo., proclaimed Darren Wilson Day on Sunday, the one-year anniversary of the officers fatal shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo.

title: Verbatim: I Thought It Would Be Fun
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, speaking in Exeter, N.H., after being asked at a news conference why she attended Donald J. Trumps wedding in 2005.

title: Rory McIlroySays Hes 100 Percent for P.G.A. Championship
description: HAVEN, Wis.  After he arrived at Whistling Straits for practice rounds last week, Rory McIlroy said he expected to play in Thursdays first round of the P.G.A. Championship, despite rupturing ankle ligaments while playing soccer with friends July 4.

title: Billy Sherrill, Producer, Dies at 78; Promoted a Countrypolitan Sound
description: Billy Sherrill, who as a songwriter, record producer and executive helped kick-start the career of Tammy Wynette, breathed new life into a declining George Jones and was an architect of the so-called countrypolitan sound, which applied the tenets of 1960s pop maximalism to country music, died on Aug. 4 at his home in Nashville. He was 78.

title: Democrats Offer Ways to Make College Affordable
description: A college education is a basic requirement for many middle-class jobs, but it is increasingly harder to afford. That is why every presidential candidate needs to explain what he or she will do to make higher education attainable for more Americans without them having to take on crippling amounts of debt.

title: Test Yourself: 6 Questions From a Third-Grade Reading Test
description: Read a passage from the third-grade reading test called Secrets Are Hard to Keep and answer the six questions that students were tested on.

title: New York State Test Questions Tricky for 3rd Graders, and Maybe Some Adults
description: The East African fable goes like this: A man frees a snake that is trapped between two rocks, and as a reward the snake gives him a charm that will allow him to hear what animals say, but only if the man keeps it a secret. The man betrays his new power by giggling at the things he hears, arousing his wifes curiosity. He eventually tells her about the charm, and it stops working.

title: Want a Real Old White House Memento? Warning: It Wont Be Cheap
description: WASHINGTON  When Theodore Roosevelt hired an architecture firm to renovate the dark, cramped White House in 1902, much of the structural interior was thrown into piles of trash on the lawn outside: 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue had become a construction site. Wood, plaster, glass and even old curtains were strewn about, leaving the once stately grounds in a heap of dirt and confusion, as an article in The New York Times put it.

title: The Big Five: Africa's Most Sought-After Trophy Animals
description: The Big Five animals hunted for sport, their conservation status according to the International Union for Conservation of Natures Red List and the market rates that a trophy demands in South Africa, home to the biggest hunting industry on the continent.

title: Outcry for Cecil the Lion Could Undercut Conservation Efforts
description: OLIFANTSVLEI, South Africa  Before the two hunters from Texas had breakfast, Stewart Dorrington drove through his 12,000-acre game ranch. As the early-morning sun cast a soft glow on the landscape, turned a wintry pale brown, buffalo wandered in the tall grass and giraffes appeared in a cluster of trees.

title: Delays for N.J. Transit Train Riders May Become Norm, Amtrak Official Warns
description: TRENTON  Train problems like those that stranded commuters several days last month may become the norm, an Amtrak executive told state legislators here on Monday, as aging tunnels increasingly require repairs, passenger demand grows and lawmakers cannot agree on how to pay for a new tunnel under the Hudson River to ease the burden.

title: Hillary Clinton Says Donald Trumps Outrageous Comments Are Part of a Republican Theme
description: EXETER, N.H.  Hillary Rodham Clinton had planned to spend her campaign stop at a high school here on Monday focusing mainly on her plan to make college more affordable. But, like most candidates for president, she also had to take questions about the latest headline-grabbing comments from Donald J. Trump.

title: Separate Briefings, and Findings, on Legionnaires Disease Outbreak
description: The outbreak of Legionnaires disease in the South Bronx continued to show signs of waning on Monday. But the maneuvering between state and city officials seemed far from over.

title: With Google as Alphabet, a Bid to Dream Big Beyond Search
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Shortly after its founding, Google posted a document on its site called Ten things we know to be true, an effort to distill its unusual corporate culture into a succinct list of prescriptions  the 10 commandments of Googliness. Among the most-quoted of Googles big thoughts has been that corporations should do one thing really, really well. Googles one thing, the document said, was obvious: We do search.

title: Game Publishers Lawsuit Against Oculus Moves Forward
description: A federal judge has refused to throw out a lawsuit filed by a games publisher accusing Oculus VR of stealing trade secrets and code in the creation of the Oculus virtual-reality headset.

title: At Whistling Straits, Golfers Will Have to Go Against the Grains
description: HAVEN, Wis.  The notorious Dustin Johnson bunker at Whistling Straits is gone. The rule that made the bunker famous five years ago remains.

title: Primaries in Argentina Point to a Close Presidential Race
description: BUENOS AIRES  The future of Argentine politics was fuzzy on Monday after an all-party presidential primary, billed as a measure of the nations desire for change, proved close enough to cast doubt on who would prevail in general elections.

title: Arrested in Ferguson Last Year, 2 Reporters Are Charged
description: Two reporters who were arrested while covering the protests in Ferguson, Mo., last August, were charged with trespassing and interfering with a police officer, their outlets said on Monday.

title: Sundar Pichai Will Lead Google With Users in Mind
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The technology industry is partial to dramatic, sometimes blustery, often larger-than-life top executives. Sundar Pichai will have to work hard to be ranked among that colorful crew. He sent news of his ascension to the top slot at Google  he is just the third person to officially run the search company  on Twitter, very obliquely.

title: Marin Cilic Struggles to Get Back Into Zone AfterU.S. Open Success
description: WASHINGTON  After two hours of intense practice in the lingering afternoon heat here last week at the Citi Open, Marin Cilic finished with a series of sprints. From one baseline to the other, he went faster when fading away would have made more sense.

title: Lawrence Lessig to Explore a Run for President as a Democrat
description: Some people land gyrocopters on the lawn at the Capitol to protest big money in politics. Lawrence Lessig, the Harvard professor and democratic theorist, is thinking of running for president.

title: David Nobbs, Novelist and Creator of Reginald Perrin, Dies at 80
description: David Nobbs, a British novelist and comedy writer best known for The Fall and Rise of Reginald Perrin, the dark BBC sitcom of the 1970s that won an ardent following on both sides of the Atlantic, died on Saturday in Harrogate, England. He was 80.

title: A French Couples Love for the American West Ends in Tragedy
description: PARIS  The family from France was so enthralled by their last visit to the American West that they started planning another almost immediately. On Facebook, they posted pictures of the vast blue skies, the rugged ocher canyons and the endless strips of asphalt that had captivated them.

title: Alphabet Wordplay, a Hooli Easter Egg and More on Googles Name Change
description: On Monday, Google announced that it was changing the name of the company to Alphabet, creating a structure that would encompass multiple parts. The search engine division will be separate from some of the more futuristic parts of the company, such as an anti-aging biotech firm and the lab that builds self-driving cars.

title: Stock Buybacks Draw Scrutiny From Politicians
description: Should corporate stock buybacks be regulated? Or made illegal?

title: Review: Cymbeline Unspools Its Many Plot Twists at the Delacorte Theater
description: Not one but two gilt prosceniums currently adorn the normally proscenium-free Delacorte Theater in Central Park, where the Public Theater is presenting Cymbeline, Shakespeares weird and wonder-filled late romance, as its second offering of the free summer season. Piled around the outer proscenium are crates, boxes and odd bits of statuary, vaguely suggesting that we are in a disused theater of some advanced age, filled with odd props.

title: Messy Sandwich Filler
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  If you are at all suggestible and you happen to be on a diet, you might want to skip this puzzle. There be calories galore ahead.

title: Mets Top Rockies as Michael Cuddyer Comes Off D.L., and Sits
description: Michael Cuddyer arrived at work Monday as an active member of the Mets for the first time in about two and a half weeks, and found that his old position had been effectively filled. In that time, the Mets had acquired three veteran position players, the top prospect Michael Conforto had earned their trust, and they had propelled themselves into the playoff race.

title: Megyn Kelly Says She Wont Be Cowed by Donald Trump
description: Megyn Kelly opened her Fox News program on Monday night by addressing the uproar over Donald J. Trumps personal attacks on her, her first comments since he made a remark that many interpreted as a reference to her menstrual cycle.

title: David Wright Looks Good in First Rehab Start
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Standing in the St. Lucie Mets clubhouse on Monday night, with a large pack of ice pressed against his lower back, David Wright kept glancing at a television. It was showing the Mets game against the Colorado Rockies at Citi Field, and the Mets were leading, 4-2.

title: China Devalues Its Currency as Worries Rise About Economic Slowdown
description: HONG KONG  As China contends with an economic slowdown and a stock market slump, the authorities on Tuesday sharply devalued the countrys currency, the renminbi, a move that could raise geopolitical tensions and weigh on growth elsewhere.

title: Stephen Colberts Plans for His New Show, and a Prayer for Trump
description: LOS ANGELES  Stephen Colbert discussed his plans for his new late-night show for the first time Monday  as well as his restlessness about being off the air and the challenges of breaking from the satirical character hes played for years.

title: Big Game Hunting Is Also Big Business for Wealthy Few
description: An American dentists recent killing of a lion named Cecil in Zimbabwe sparked public outrage, but it largely obscured the fact that big game hunting is also a big business in which animals are regularly pursued.

title: All Emails Were Provided, Hillary Clinton Says in Statement
