description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said in a statement filed under oath in federal court on Monday that she had provided to the State Department all of the work-related emails that were on the personal email account she used exclusively while she was secretary of state.

title: Back in Black
description: This season, theres more than one way to wear a smoky eye.

title: Square-Toed Heels With Broad Appeal
Lizzy Caplans Long, Embroidered Valentino Skirt
description: The Star: Lizzy Caplan

title: A Summery Sashimi Salad and Chrysanthemum Cocktail From New Jersey
description: Earlier this summer, the New Jersey chef Scott Anderson opened the doors to Princetons Mistral Bar, the spirituous neighbor of his year-old Witherspoon Street bistro Mistral. Inside, university professors and foodie types congregate for effervescent cocktails fizzy with homegrown kombuchas and irreverent bar snacks like beef tendon chicharrones dappled with marrow creme. And this evening, in a hidden corner of Mistral Bar, a newly installed elevator will deliver diners to a relocated Elements, the acclaimed haute seasonal restaurant Anderson and co-owner Steve Distler had operated on nearby Bayard Lane since 2008.

title: In Japan, History Has No Place
description: Despite its reverence for tradition, Japan has an ambivalent  and unsentimental  relationship with its Modernist architecture. Why preparing for the future sometimes means destroying the past.

title: High Tech Hope for Repelling Mosquitoes
description: In Alaska, where I grew up, mosquitoes outnumber people some 24 million to one. That makes it a great place to test the very latest in mosquito shields.

title: Word of the Day | bantering
description: bantering  \ban-t-riN\  adjective

title: Japan Restarts Reactor, Lifting 2-Year Ban Prompted by Fukushima Accident
description: TOKYO  Japan took a decisive step on Tuesday toward ending a two-year freeze on the use of nuclear power, as an electric utility restarted one of the dozens of reactors in the country that were taken offline after meltdowns at a plant in Fukushima in 2011.

title: U.S. Requests Lower Bond for Palestinian Appeal of Terror Case
description: The Obama administration, citing the potential for economic and political harm to the Palestinian Authority and the broader peace process, asked a judge on Monday to carefully consider the size of the bond he requires for the authority to appeal a huge damages award for its role in six terrorist attacks in Israel that killed and injured Americans.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, August 11, 2015
description: Theres always a sense things can boil over, but theres a sense of maturity here.

title: Whats On TV Tuesday
description: 6:05 P.M. (Encore) BUTCH CASSIDY AND THE SUNDANCE KID (1969) Does it get any prettier than this? Robert Redford and Paul Newman (above right, with Mr. Redford) star as the famous Wild West outlaws on the lam (destination: Bolivia), with Katharine Ross as the woman who sets their hearts aflutter. The soundtrack to their lives: Burt Bacharachs Oscar-winning score, featuring Raindrops Keep Fallin on My Head, which won for best original song, written with Hal David. Much of the movie is very funny in a strictly contemporary way  the last exuberant word on movies about the men of the mythic American West who have outlived their day, Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. And while there are some bothersome technical things about the movie (the camera is all zoom, zoom, zoom), he added, the overall production is very handsome, and the performances fine, especially Newman, Redford and Miss Ross, who must be broadly funny and straight, almost simultaneously. They succeed even if the movie does not.

title: Corrections: August 11, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Born to Make Photos
description: Harry Gruyaert, the Belgian photographer and member of Magnum, has been taking pictures for a long time. Long enough to have been friends  and colleagues  with Henri Cartier-Bresson, with whom he shared a philosophy of photography.

title: Student Crossword | Academic Skills
description: Test your knowledge of academic skills by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: 50 Years Later, We Still Havent Learned From Watts
description: ON AUG. 11, 1965, a California highway patrolman in the Watts section of Los Angeles pulled over an African-American man, Marquette Frye, for drunken driving. When another officer began hitting Mr. Frye and his mother, who had rushed to the scene, onlookers started throwing stones and bottles.

title: The Vulgarity of Donald Trumps Remark
description: To the Editor:

title: Concern Over Proposed Power Lines at Jamestown
description: To the Editor:

title: Housing for Addicts
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor de Blasios Plan for Affordable Housing
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio has unveiled another part of his ambitious plan to save New York City  a proposal to use land-use regulations to spur the creation of large amounts of permanently affordable housing. He wants to use a tactic called mandatory inclusionary zoning  in which as neighborhoods or specific parcels are rezoned, developers who want to build there would have to set aside at least 25 to 30 percent of new apartments for people of low and moderate incomes. They could not opt out, and the affordability would be permanent.

title: A Debate Over Hiroshima and Nagasaki, 70 Years Later
description: To the Editor:

title: Ban Selfie Sticks at the 9/11 Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L.s Bogus Settlement for Brain-Damaged Former Players
description: Thanks to the ham-handedness of the National Football Leagues Hall of Fame, the inane deflategate scandal, which has been the dominant N.F.L. headline this off-season, was pushed to the sidelines this weekend and replaced by a genuinely important issue facing the countrys dominant sports league and its players. That issue is the serious cognitive impairment that appears to affect so many former professional football players.

title: Time to Reassess Sinai Peacekeeping Force
description: Shortly after Washington brokered a landmark peace treaty with Egypt and Israel in 1979, the United States and allied countries deployed peacekeepers to Egypts Sinai Peninsula to ensure that the two nations, which fought several wars, adhered to the terms of the pact.

title: Footage of Live Whale Shark Being Sawed Prompts Outcry in China
description: Read in Chinese |

title: Why Group Therapy Worked
description: I first entered individual therapy in the late 1980s, in Manhattan. Once a week for six years I strolled happily northward up Columbus Avenue from my apartment to my therapists office in the West 90s. Our sessions were a high point of my week. And why not? I got 50 minutes of undivided attention from a smart, empathetic professional, there to help me find out who I was and to address the old malaise that brought me to her door. Narcissistic injury, I learned to call it.

title: Climbing the Sharks Fin
description: The mission of professional mountain climbers is almost impossibly difficult by design: Their very livelihood is based on achieving the unprecedented. Their expeditions are complicated, exhausting, often life-threatening. Risk is the fuel that keeps them going.

title: Climbing the Sharks Fin
description: This short documentary chronicles the ordeal of three mountain climbers attempting one of the most elusive first ascents in the Himalayas.

title: Terex Corporation and Konecranes of Finland Agree to Merge
description: LONDON  The American crane and heavy equipment maker Terex Corporation and Konecranes of Finland said on Tuesday that they planned to merge in an all-share deal.

title: News Qs | A Year Later, Ferguson Sees Change, but Asks if Its Real
description: Note: Weve updated 6 Qs About the News for the new school year. This feature, now known as News Qs, will be a daily mini-lesson, with both Before Reading and After Reading questions, and a suggested activity for going further. Let us know what you think.

title: The Hairdresser of Harare, by Tendai Huchu
description: Warning of the dangers of what she calls the single story about any given place or people, the Nigerian novelist Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie says that it creates stereotypes, and the problem with stereotypes is not that they are untrue, but that they are incomplete. Too often in the United States, we have created a single narrative about foreign countries, particularly African countries: Theyre impoverished and war-torn and beset by disease or, more benignly, simply teeming with exotic animals.

title: In the Language of Miracles, by Rajia Hassib
description: What happens to a family when one of its members perpetrates an unspeakable act of violence? How do you grieve for a loved one who has committed both murder and suicide? How does the local community react? What if the family in question is Muslim? Is that a game changer? Are you wondering if Islamic ideology, extremists and terrorists are at the heart of this story? You are not alone.

title: State by State, Democratic Party Is Erasing Ties to Jefferson and Jackson
description: WASHINGTON  For nearly a century, Democrats have honored two men as the founders of their party: Thomas Jefferson, for his visionary expression of the concept of equality, and Andrew Jackson, for his populist spirit and elevation of the common man.

title: Hiplife at the Apollo
description: What can you say? Its Africa time! the legendary music promoter Sparkie Martin remarked on Saturday evening, as he surveyed a modest crowd lining up outside the Apollo Theater for an evening of Ghanaian and Nigerian acts sharing the bill with the hiplife superstar Sarkodie.

title: A Remade Medelln, Colombia, Shows Off Its Style
description: The Colombian city of Medelln has gone through a drastic transformation from drug capital to forward-looking metropolis. This is especially true of the chic El Poblado neighborhood, where the streets are crowded with designer boutiques, cafes and restaurants with ample outdoor seating  because, well, theres no reason to sit inside. Locals are extremely proud of the neighborhoods progress in bringing global style to Colombia while maintaining local flair. The citys perennially comfortable weather and luscious natural habitat have a decided influence on the way people dress, from airy fabrics to colorful prints. The way people dress in this part of Colombia is all about layers, said Amelia Ochoa, who was recently spotted in the neighborhood. This interview has been edited and condensed.

title: Intersection | Medelln, Colombia
description: Elisa and Amelia Ochoa, twins and founders of the website Sisterly Style, discuss fashion in Medellns Poblado neighborhood.

title: Nebia, a Shower Head Start-Up, Receives Funding From Timothy Cook of Apple
description: When Nebia woos investors, it invites them to take a shower.

title: In Chinese Media, a Rebuff to Officials Who Wont Fully Retire
description: Read in Chinese |

title: Tentative Greek Debt Accord Might Do Little to Revive Economy
description: ATHENS  The Greek government on Tuesday appeared to be on the verge of clinching a deal for a new international bailout worth as much as $95 billion in exchange for accepting harsh austerity terms and making sweeping changes to the way the country does business.

title: Hotel Digest: A Four Seasons in Seoul, Spa News and More
description: Our weekday morning digest that includes information about hotels and resorts, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: In Quebec, Creativity Fuels Neighborhood Revivals
description: The undying love for the Old City of Quebec is understandable. Stroll the only walled city north of Mexico and its cobblestone streets, reads the citys tourism website. Discover 400 years of history. (The city celebrated its 400th anniversary in 2008.)

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: New York Today: Remarkable Plots
description: Good morning on this sopping Tuesday.

title: When Phone Encryption Blocks Justice
description: In June, a father of six was shot dead on a Monday afternoon in Evanston, Ill., a suburb 10 miles north of Chicago. The Evanston police believe that the victim, Ray C. Owens, had also been robbed. There were no witnesses to his killing, and no surveillance footage either.

title: Authorities Say Video Shows Teenager in Ferguson Had Gun
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  St. Louis County police investigators released surveillance video on Tuesday that they say shows an 18-year-old man who was shot by their officers pulling a gun out of his waistband and pointing it as he ran toward the street late Sunday.

title: Today in Politics: Donald Trumps Busy Week Aligns With His Opponents Growing Unease
description: Good Tuesday morning. It is indeed the thick of the August lull, but with candidates fighting either to build on momentum from the debates or to make up for any lost ground, there is still work to do. Of course, it remains hard to be heard when one voice continues to rise above the rest, especially when that voice enters its most packed stretch of the campaign so far.

title: DealBook: Stock Buybacks Draw Scrutiny
description: STOCK BUYBACKS DRAW SCRUTINY | Debate over buybacks has grown and corporate America is worried, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. The buyback bug, which has bitten big companies from Apple to General Electric, has led to a backlash from investors and government officials. They doubt that using profits like that is a productive way to deploy capital compared with reinvesting in businesses and jobs.

title: Nine Charged in Insider Trading Case Tied to Hackers
description: It was a symbiotic relationship that brought together the underbelly of Wall Street and the dark reaches of the online world.

title: Marijuana Legalization in Colorado Leads to First Weedery
description: Wineries and breweries should brace themselves for some unusual competition. Colorado, which legalized marijuana for recreational use in 2012, will get its first weedery in early 2016.

title: Welcome to Liberland, the Worlds Newest Country (Maybe)
description: Along the western bank of the Danube, more or less halfway between Zagreb and Belgrade, there rests in historic obscurity a three-square-mile teardrop of no mans land. It is an artifact of a border dispute of long standing, and neither Serbia nor Croatia expresses a desire to rule over this unprepossessing Gibraltar-size property. The land, marshy and prone to seasonal inundation, is choked with unregulated scrub, with here and there the lone tongue of a poplar or the gentle shag of a willow. The only road is a rutted single-lane dirt track, the only existing dwelling a flimsy hunting hovel, its provenance unknown.

title: How Rock Star Became a Business Buzzword
description: Once, a long time ago, a rock star was a free-spirited, convention-flouting artist/rebel/hero/Dionysian fertility god who fronted a world-famous band, sold millions of records and headlined stadium concerts where people were trampled in frenzies of cultlike fervor. Someone who smashed guitars, trashed hotel rooms, developed Byzantine drug problems and tried to mask evidence of his infidelity with the strategically applied scent of breakfast burritos. Despite what his Behind the Music episode would invariably reveal, a rock star  or the Platonic ideal of a rock star  was not just a powder keg of charisma and unresolved childhood issues, but a revolutionary driven by a need to assert the primacy of the self in an increasingly alienating commercial world.

title: How to Cut the Prison Population (See for Yourself)
description: When President Obama, the Koch brothers, the American Civil Liberties Union and Newt Gingrich all agree on an issue, you know that something important may be happening.

title: Japan Restarts Nuclear Reactor
description: A reactor at the Sendai Nuclear Power Plant on Tuesday was the first to be brought back online since a shutdown after the Fukushima disaster in 2011.

title: Lacking Cash, Rick Perry Cannot Pay Campaign Staff Members
description: After raising only a little over $1 million for his campaign by the end of June, Rick Perry has stopped paying campaign staff members, aides said, an indication that his funds have all but dried up.

title: Australia Sets Emissions Goal, but Climate Experts Say It Falls Short
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Prime Minister Tony Abbott on Tuesday announced a greenhouse gas reduction goal for Australia that he said struck the right balance between economic concerns and the need to address climate change, but scientists and environmental groups said the plan fell short of what was needed.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Aug. 4-10, 2015
description: Have you been following the news?

title: Donald Trump, Pivoting Toward Policy, Urges Simpler Tax Code
description: Donald J. Trumps feud with Fox News came to a close on Tuesday morning when the billionaire tycoon called into the network for a friendly interview, declaring weve always been friends.

title: Dance This Week: India Dance and Ashtons Monotones
description: Indian Dance in New York

title: Why Do We Always Proclaim That the Novel Is Dead?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Liesl Schillinger and Benjamin Moser talk about why the novels demise so regularly looms.

title: House Republicans, Seizing on Health Law, Challenge Executive Branch
description: WASHINGTON  Angry at what they saw as the Obama administrations frequent flouting of congressional authority, House Republicans last year began casting about for a way to fight back.

title: Tricky Little Things
description: [PLEASE NOTE: After Deadline will be on vacation for the next two weeks, returning on Tuesday, Sept. 1.]

title: Charges in Hacking and Insider Trading Scheme
description: Indictment unsealed Tuesday by federal prosecutors in New Jersey.

title: Japan Takes Step Toward Reviving Nuclear Industry as It Restarts Reactor
description: TOKYO  For more than four years since the nuclear meltdowns in Fukushima in 2011, Japan has been debating whether it should permanently abandon a technology that went so disastrously wrong but that for years was seen as essential to its economy.

title: 1890: Sky Streaked With Meteors
description: A rain of meteors that streaked the sky with hundreds of fiery trails kept thousands of Parisians on the rooftops last night. It was a strange and fascinating sight. The absence of moonlight lent greater brilliancy to the huge bodies as they flashed through the starry sky and vanished. Many persons had provided themselves with telescopes after reading that the August shower of the Perseid group could be seen, but no lens, however powerful, could add to the silent grandeur of what could be seen with the naked eye. The New York Herald, European Edition, August 12, 1890

title: The Butchers Chickens
description: Dear Diary:

title: Carlyle Group and Other Investors to Acquire Veritas Technologies for $8 Billion
description: A consortium of investors led by the private equity firm the Carlyle Group has agreed to acquire the data storage company Veritas Technologies from Symantec for $8 billion in cash.

title: Harry Reid: Avoiding the Next Budget Crisis
description: LAS VEGAS  Over the past five years, Washington has lurched from one crisis to another  the 2011 debt ceiling crisis, the 2012 fiscal cliff, the 2013 government shutdown  spooking markets and rattling Americans faith in our nations democratic institutions.

title: Rural Wisconsin Community Laments Nuclear Power Plants Closure
description: CARLTON, Wis.  Sprawled over 900 acres, the Kewaunee nuclear power plant in this corner of northeastern Wisconsin is an 18-story blue and white tangle of concrete buildings, metal pipes and  deep inside  racks containing spent radioactive fuel. It is big, ugly and stocked with toxic waste.

title: Readers Turn: Canadas Quick Election
description: Josh Barro argued last week that the debate among Canadian political leaders on Thursday was far more substantive than the Republican debate held on the same night.

title: New Route to Conversion Challenges Israels Ultra-Orthodox Establishment
description: JERUSALEM  The newest combatants in Israels raging battle over ultra-Orthodox control of Jewish law and institutions are six children, ages 1 to 11, who were converted to Judaism on Monday by Orthodox rabbis operating outside the official system.

title: Daily Report: Google Remakes Itself as Alphabet
description: In a major reinvention of one of the worlds most influential technology companies, Google announced Monday evening that it is reorganizing itself in the Berkshire Hathaway model. The new company, essentially a holding company, will be called Alphabet, and it will be run by Google co-founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin.

title: Greece Says New Bailout Deal Is Reached
description: Annika Breidthardt, a spokeswoman for the European Commission, said on Tuesday that the technical agreement has been reached in principle.

title: Give Fast Food Workers a Raise, Already
description: Nearly three-fourths of New York City voters (73 percent) support raising the minimum wage for fast food workers to $15 an hour, according to a recent Quinnipiac University Poll. Only about one fourth (24 percent) oppose the increase, which was recommended last month by a wage board appointed by Gov. Andrew Cuomo. The states acting labor commissioner, Mario Musolino, is expected to approve the increase soon.

title: New Greek Bailout, Same Old Woes
description: ATHENS  Greece is in a deep hole, and everyone involved seems determined to keep digging. As the country bids for a third bailout since 2010, the momentum from economic damage inflicted during the last five years threatens to undermine the latest agreement.

title: Sumitomo Life of Japan to Buy Symetra Financial for $3.8 Billion
description: The Sumitomo Life Insurance Company of Japan said on Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire Symetra Financial Corporation, an American provider of insurance and financial products, for about $3.8 billion.

title: Toronto International Film Festival: Aretha Franklin Tale, Delayed Four Decades, Headlines Documentary Section
description: LOS ANGELES  Among the new documentaries set for the Toronto International Film Festival, which opens Sept. 10, is a very old one: Sydney Pollacks long-shelved film about the making of Aretha Franklins Amazing Grace album, recorded live at a Los Angeles church in 1972.

title: Voting Rights Under Republican Attack
description: 50 years after the passage of the Voting Rights Act, voting is under attack.

title: Migrants Attempt to Cross English Channel on Foot Raises Asylum Questions
description: LONDON  The African man who risked death to reach Britain by walking nearly the entire length of the Channel Tunnel last week now faces another potential challenge: prison. But legal experts say that being charged with a crime should not preclude him from being granted asylum.

title: Malaysia Airlines Crash Investigators May Have Found Missile Clues in Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  Prosecutors in the Netherlands revealed on Tuesday that they had found what could be pieces of a Russian-made surface-to-air missile system in eastern Ukraine, in the area of the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17.

title: Dreams of a Hip, High-Tech Sacramento Hinge on Kings New Home Court
description: SACRAMENTO  When it opens for the Sacramento Kings first home basketball game, the Golden 1 Center  which will have the capacity to hold 17,500 fans and is designed with online graphic and social media interfaces  will be more than the newest and most technologically advanced arena in the National Basketball Association.

title: Moments Before Texas Dealership Shooting
description: In this edited video released on Monday, Christian Taylor, an unarmed football player from Arlington, Tex., is seen in the moments before he was shot dead by a police officer at a car dealership.

title: Neighborhood Car Service Companies Adopt Their Own Apps to Fend Off Uber
description: The chatty, frenetic dispatch hubs of neighborhood car services are getting quieter.

title: With Roll of the Dice, Buddy Baker Got Lone Daytona 500 Win
description: Buddy Baker, the folksy storyteller of Nascar broadcasts, was known as the Gentle Giant. But during his racing career he was famed for his daring, notably in his only win in the Daytona 500.

title: Why Did China Devalue Its Currency? Two Big Reasons
description: HERE are two things that Chinas government wants very badly: first, for its economy to remain on an even keel, keeping growth and employment high. Second, for its currency, the renminbi, to become globally pre-eminent, helping promote the countrys diplomatic goals and solidifying the countrys centrality to the global economy.

title: Alphabet? Google Might Get Some Letters
description: One can only assume that before Larry Page and Sergey Brin chose Alphabet as the name for their new holding company, they Googled it.

title: Struggling to Stay Connected When a Spouse Deploys
description: Six minutes. We had my husband on the phone for six minutes. Long enough for our 4-year-old to tell him about the pet caterpillar she adopted and for our 3-year-old to answer a few questions about swim lessons. Before it was my turn, it was time for him to go. Slightly defeated, I heard myself pouting, I didnt even get to talk to you! He offered a rushed, albeit sincere apology, and just as quickly, he was gone.

title: Clinton Details Plan for Student Loans
description: At an event in Exeter, N.H., on Monday, Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton outlined her vision for making college more affordable.

title: Runion, Once a Surfers Paradise, Finds Only Sharks in Its Waters
description: ST.-LEU, Runion  To see the perfect wave and not be able to surf, Nicolas Dantec said, shaking his head. It is too difficult.

title: Jeb Bush Says Hillary Clinton Stood By as Iraq Descended Into Violence
description: LOS ANGELES  Jeb Bush is planning to issue a full-throttle attack Tuesday night on the Obama administrations handling of Iraq and terrorism issues, asserting that Hillary Rodham Clinton stood by as secretary of state when the situation in Iraq deteriorated, creating the conditions that led to the rise of the Islamic State as the Obama administration reduced its troop level in Iraq.

title: Building the Next New York Times Recommendation Engine
description: The New York Times publishes over 300 articles, blog posts and interactive stories a day.

title: Beckham Defends Daughters Pacifier, Stirring Parenting Debate
description: The Daily Mail, a British tabloid, published a photograph over the weekend of David Beckhams 4-year-old daughter, Harper, with a pacifier in her mouth in an article questioning whether it was appropriate for a child to still be using one at that age.

title: Michael Brown Protesters Block I-70
description: The police arrested dozens of people on Monday after protesters blocked a highway in Missouri during demonstrations organized to remember Michael Browns death at the hands of an officer a year ago.

title: Australias Leader Details Climate Goals
description: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia outlined his countrys plans to reduce greenhouse gas emissions between 26 and 28 percent from 2005 levels by 2030.

title: Iraqi Parliament Backs Overhaul of Government
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs Parliament unanimously passed measures on Tuesday that are meant to transform the countrys corrupt political system. Yet by eliminating several high-level positions and doing away with sectarian quotas in political appointments, the measures risk further alienating the countrys Sunni minority while the government is struggling to defeat the Sunni militants of the Islamic State.

title: Additional Charges in Insider Trading Scheme
description: A federal grand jury in Brooklyn charged four people with using stolen news releases to profit on information before it was made public.

title: In a Shift, Rite Aid to Accept Apple and Google Mobile Payments
description: Rite Aid, the nationwide pharmacy and retail chain, announced on Tuesday it would accept smartphone payments from Apple and Google, two of the largest players in mobile wallet technology, beginning this weekend.

title: She May Be Small, but Kaci Lickteig (the Pixie Ninja) Is a Giant in Ultrarunning
description: OMAHA  Kaci Lickteig, in her creative efforts to mimic various mountain ranges that are not native to Nebraska, does some of her most important training here on a nondescript stretch of road that she calls Pacific Hill.

title: Tea and Trumpism
description: Memo to pollsters: while Im having as much fun as everyone else watching the unsinkable Donald defy predictions of his assured collapse, what I really want to see at this point is a profile of his supporters. What characteristics predispose someone to like this guy, as opposed to accepting the establishment candidates?

title: Chevalier
description: A brasserie fit for Bruce Wayne in Midtown.

title: Donald Trump Gets Mixed News in New Iowa Poll
description: Donald J. Trumps erratic debate performance last week did not undo his standing as the favorite in Iowa, according to a poll released Tuesday from Suffolk University, but it did damage the confidence that potential Republican caucusgoers have in his ability to bepresident.

title: Restaurant Review: Chevalier in Midtown
description: Whats the matter? my dinner companion asked one night at Chevalier, the luxurious new French restaurant in Midtown at the base of the Baccarat Hotel & Residences New York. You look like you just saw a ghost.

title: Martha Graham Dance Company Will Revisit Classics for 90th Anniversary
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company will celebrate its 90th-anniversary season next year by dancing some of Grahams most celebrated works, including Appalachian Spring, as well as new choreography by Marie Chouinard, Mats Ek, and Pontus Lidberg, the company said Tuesday.

title: TKTK
description: TKTK

title: Marco Rubio,Amid Soaring Moments, Sticks to Steady Course
description: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida earned glowing praise and predictions about how formidable a contender he would be when he announced his run for the White House in April. Then he disappeared on a two-month fund-raising trip.

title: Data on Use of Force by Police Across U.S. Proves Almost Useless
description: WASHINGTON  When the Justice Department surveyed police departments nationwide in 2013, officials included for the first time a series of questions about how often officers used force.

title: 1940: British Fight Off 400 Raiders
description: LONDON  Out of a cloud-checked Sabbath sky over the English Channel, 400 Nazi warplanes struck yesterday at the British south coast naval bases of Portland and Weymouth, at balloon defense on the southeast coast in Kent and at a convoy. Two hundred German craft attacked Portland and Weymouth at one time. At 11:30 p.m., the Air Ministry said reports received up to 9 p.m. showed that sixty enemy planes had been shot down, five of them by anti-aircraft fire. The Ministry also raised the total of British losses from its first report of nineteen fighter planes lost to twenty-six, but said the pilots of two were saved. New York Herald Tribune, August 12, 1940

title: Workers Stage Strike at National Gallery in London
description: LONDON  Around 200 staff members at the National Gallery here went on an indefinite strikeTuesdayin a dispute over the gallerys plans to privatize some of its services.

title: S.E.C. Complaint in Hacker-Insider Trading Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said that defendants made trades based on illegally obtained information and reaped over $100 million in unlawful profits.

title: NBC Nightly News Holds Lead in Fight for Viewers
description: Six months after Brian Williams was suspended without pay from his position as the anchor of NBCs Nightly News show, the broadcast has held its lead in the fierce battle for viewers.

title: Grilled Halloumi for a Light Summer Meal
description: Halloumi is a firm, white, brined cheese traditionally made from a mixture of goats and sheeps milk. (Though today, cows milk is often used.) Like other low-fat cheeses, it is perfect for grilling. It sears and colors quickly when it hits the hot grill. The interior softens, but the cheese doesnt melt; it just warms up invitingly.

title: From Underarm Hair to Summer Turtlenecks, Styles Trends Are Hot
description: At the end of last year, I published a list of what I would like to see happen at The Times in 2015. Because I was having a little fun with the listicle format, which seems to require an odd, preferably prime, number in its title, I called it 17 Hopes and Dreams for The Times in the New Year.

title: Seth Meyers Decides to Take a Seat to Deliver His Late Night Monologue
description: When audience members at Mondays broadcast of Late Night finished applauding and took their seats, the host Seth Meyers did something unusual: He sat down, too.

title: Geno Smith Is Sucker-Punched in the Latest Bizarre Blow to the Jets
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  It had been nearly two weeks since absurdity befell the Jets, an epoch in their tormented history.

title: Chinas Currency Dilemma
description: Chinas decision to devalue its currency, the renminbi, by 2 percent against the dollar on Tuesday is intended to give its slowing economy a boost. But the decision is likely to be seen by lawmakers in the United States and elsewhere as currency manipulation to increase Chinese exports at the expense of producers in other countries.

title: Palestinian Prisoners Case Tests Israeli Force-Feeding Law
description: ASHKELON, Israel  The first Palestinian prisoner who could be forced to stay alive under a new Israeli law lies shackled to a hospital bed, vomiting bile and blood after 57 days of drinking only water to protest his indefinite incarceration without charges.

title: Competitiveness and Class Warfare
description: For reasons not entirely clear to me, recently I found myself thinking about Lester Thurows Head to Head: The Coming Economic Battle Among Japan, Europe, and America. For those too young, or who dont remember, Thurows book was a monster best-seller in the early 1990s; it resonated with many people who feared that America was losing its economic edge, that Japan was an unstoppable juggernaut, and so on. And it also played into the general notion of global economics as a struggle for competitive advantage, which is a perennial popular favorite.

title: Leaf Bar and Lounge Joins the Asian Rush in Flushing
description: Leaf Bar and Lounge Flushing, Queens, is already chockablock with Asian restaurants and bars, but this new rooftop enclave is notable for its inventive drinks, like a chrysanthemum old-fashioned. Leaf Bar and Lounge, which opens Wednesday, is on top of a Hyatt hotel at One Fulton Square. It is the latest in the growing collection of Asian restaurants in this new multistory complex. The bar offers a menu of small plates like pork-belly buns, yellowtail collar, dumplings and popcorn chicken. The chef is Henry Lin, a Taiwan native. Already open at One Fulton Square are the Coop, a bar and restaurant specializing in Korean fried chicken; Good Harvest, a branch of a big hot-pot chain in China; Rong Restaurant, for Chinese regional cuisine; and Iki, a Japanese restaurant with a variety of dishes and wagashi sweets: One Fulton Square, 39-16 Prince Street, (Roosevelt Avenue), Flushing, Queens, onefultonsquareflushing.com.

title: The Latest Snapchat Update, Explained
description: Snapchat released its newest update for Android and iPhone. Heres a review of the new features. Find us on Snapchat, username: thenytimes

title: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 7 | On Why Is It So Hard to Get a Great Bagel in California?
description: Every week, a rotating group of judges helps choose our Summer Reading Contest winner, runners-up and honorable mentions. A few of the judges, however, have now been on the panel all seven weeks, and they agree that this weeks crop of essays was, overall, the strongest yet.

title: Amnesty International Votes for Policy Calling for Decriminalization of Prostitution
description: PARIS  After days of emotional debates and intense lobbying, delegates from Amnesty International voted on Tuesday to support a policy that calls for decriminalization of the sex trade, including prostitution, payment for sex and brothel ownership.

title: Ikemefuna Enemkpali, the Backup Who Broke Geno Smiths Jaw
description: With one punch, Ikemefuna Enemkpali transformed himself from a little known third-string linebacker into a figure of infamy for the Jets.

title: Easiest Vanilla Ice Cream
description: Julia Moskin makes Philadelphia-style vanilla ice cream.

title: Homemade Ice Cream, Without All the Heat
description: Heres what most people say when you brag to them about your recipe for no-cook ice cream:

title: After 2 Killers Fled, New York Prisoners Say, Beatings Were Next
description: Night had fallen at the Clinton Correctional Facility in far northern New York when the prison guards came for Patrick Alexander. They handcuffed him and took him into a broom closet for questioning. Then, Mr. Alexander said in an interview last week, the beatings began.

title: Showtime To Produce Series Based on Patti Smiths Just Kids
description: LOS ANGELES  Showtime announced Tuesday that it had acquired the rights to Patti Smiths memoir, Just Kids and would adapt it into a limited TV series.

title: Why Misleading Americans About Climate Change Is Dangerous
description: Even as the Pope and some conservatives call for action on climate change, it remains common among Republican politicians to claim that the science on the issue is murky or inconclusive. The latest to take this position is Gov. John Kasich of Ohio.

title: Labour Party, Leaning Left, Looks to Outsider Jeremy Corbyn
description: LONDON  A working-class hero, John Lennon wrote in 1970, is something to be.

title: Ted Cruz Gets a Boost in Mississippi From a Tea Party Stalwart
description: OLIVE BRANCH, Miss.  Perched on a barstool at Sweetpeas Table here was a Tea Party favorite whose political rise alarmed the Republican leadership last year. And pacing the stage in front of him and delivering a rousing speech was Senator Ted Cruz.

title: Swing House Seat in New Hampshire May Have Another Rematch
description: New Hampshires First Congressional District is one of the nations dwindling number of genuine swing districts  and, in recent elections, it has bounced back and forth between the same two candidates, with the incumbent losing each time.

title: Colorado Governor Visits Polluted River
description: Governor John Hickenlooper of Colorado announced that the Animas River is beginning to improve after an accidental spill of toxic wastewater by Environmental Protection Agency workers.

title: Tracy Morgan Crash Largely Result of Truck Drivers Fatigue, Regulators Say
description: Federal transportation regulators on Tuesday cited a Walmart truck drivers fatigue as the chief cause of a crash last year that killed the comedian James McNair and critically injured Tracy Morgan, a star of the television series 30 Rock.

title: Youll Love What Were Doing With the Place
description: SPECIAL POST  Human nature loves a routine, but sometimes change is necessary. Change can bring vast improvements to how you get your crossword puzzle, from keeping track of streaks and statistics to easily accessing the more than 8,000 crossword puzzles in our Archive. Youve given us your feedback and we listened.

title: Tech Breakups Show Bigger Is Not Necessarily Better
description: Symantec is revealing the truth about tech mergers and acquisitions. Offloading its data storage and recovery business Veritas for $8 billion to the buyout firm Carlyle and GIC of Singapore ends a decade-long disaster of a deal. Like Hewlett-Packard, Microsoft and others, Symantec discovered that it can be harder to buy than to build. The resulting carve-ups and write-downs, though, have a tendency to perpetuate the problem.

title: Kickstarter Campaign Aims to Fund Kids Documentary
description: LOS ANGELES  Some of Larry Clarks Kids became stars. Others committed suicide or died of drug overdoses. A couple more, 20 years later, are still trying to make sense of a movie, a place, a time and themselves.

title: Liftoff
description: Flight time: 10 seconds.

title: Mystery Over Jury Notes in Manhattan Psychics Trial Is Solved
description: A mystery over two jury notes sent during a 2013 larceny trial of a Manhattan psychic has been resolved, dampening the hopes of the psychic, who has appealed her conviction.

title: Buying Car Insurance for Teenagers Can Be a Balancing Act
description: Adding a teenager to a familys auto insurance policy is a sure way to raise the premiums, but its usually less expensive than buying a separate policy, according to new research.

title: Philosophers Jrgen Habermas and Charles Taylor to Share $1.5 Million Prize
description: The German philosopher Jrgen Habermas and the Canadian philosopher Charles Taylor will share this years $1.5 million John W. Kluge Prize for Achievement in the Study of Humanity. The prize, inaugurated in 2003 and awarded by the Library of Congress, is intended to recognize work in disciplines not covered by the Nobel prizes.

title: Review: Clarice Lispectors The Complete Stories Sees Life With Existential Dread
description: On the very first page of the Brazilian writer Clarice Lispectors The Complete Stories, she signals that hers was never an ordinary sensibility, but one capable of perceiving anxiety and menace in even the most routine phenomena. The story in question was her debut as a writer, published in 1940 when she was just 19. Called The Triumph, it begins with a woman awakening to a bright stain of sunlight that leaves her motionless in bed, crucified by lassitude.

title: Review: Archana Joglekar Presents a Dazzling Solo at Drive East
description: In the last couple of years, the Drive East festival, a celebration of classical Indian music and dance, has packed the small First Floor Theater at La MaMa. Opening night of the third edition, on Monday, seemed more sparsely attended than usual, perhaps because there were more seats to fill. This years festival has moved to the cavernous Ellen Stewart Theater, and the Kathak dancer Archana Joglekar, in a vibrant solo program, made the extra space work to her advantage.

title: In El Salvador, Gangs Hold on to Power
description: Murder rates have soared as the government has struggled to rein in criminal organizations.

title: El Salvador Cracks Down on Crime, but Gangs Remain Unbowed
description: SAN SALVADOR  Seven bus drivers are killed in four days. A morgue worker slowly counts 224 stab wounds on a murder victim. Police officers post memorials to slain comrades and photographs of eliminated suspects on Facebook.

title: New York Citys Responsible Banking Act Is Unconstitutional, a Judge Rules
description: A law passed by New York City three years ago that required banks to make public their efforts to be socially responsible, particularly in low-income neighborhoods, is unconstitutional, according to a federal court ruling.

title: Birdland Club to Open a Theater Next Spring
description: The Birdland jazz club announced that the Birdland Theater, a 100-seat space that will occupy the lower level of the club at 315 West 44th Street in Manhattan, would open in the spring. The programming will include cabaret, jazz, dance, burlesque and comedy.

title: Are Times Readers Smarter Than a 3rd Grader?
description: You might remember the reading passage about an anthropomorphic pineapple that appeared on New York States eighth-grade tests a few years ago. Some of the accompanying questions were so confusing that the state decided not to count the answers in students scores.

title: Kodaks First Digital Moment
description: In the mid-1970s a young engineer invented the digital photographic process. Some of his bosses were not impressed. His employer? Eastman Kodak.

title: Review: How to Smell a Rose, Ricky Leacock at His French Farmhouse
description: Through its subject and its maker, How to Smell a Rose puts us in the vibrant presence of documentary history. Ricky Leacock  the films twinkly man of the hour  helped pioneer the documentary approach called direct cinema in the 1960s, using portable cameras and synchronized sound to record everyone from John F. Kennedy to a mother of quintuplets. But in his nine decades on earth, Mr. Leacock also apprenticed with Robert J. Flaherty, director of the silent classic documentary Nanook of the North; shot combat photography in World War II; taught rising filmmakers at M.I.T.; and embraced shooting on video.

title: Plaxico Burresss Game-Winning Super Bowl Catch
description: Arlo White calls Plaxico Burresss touchdown catch that won Super Bowl XLII for the Giants against the Patriots.

title: David Tyrees Memorable Super Bowl Catch
description: Arlo White calls the David Tyrees catch that helped the Giants win Super Bowl XLII.

title: Curiae Veteres Sanctuary in Rome Attracts the Curious
description: ROME  Archaeologists working on the Palatine Hill here this summer excavated parts of sixth-century B.C. foundations connected to a sanctuary of a cult that ancient sources trace back to Romulus, Romes mythic founder  a rare find from such an early period.

title: Facts & Figures: Change Could Keep Thousands of Kansans From Voting
description: A proposal by Secretary of State Kris Kobach of Kansas could cancel the voter registration applications of over 30,000 Kansans who havent yet provided proof of citizenship. Under current regulations, they have until Election Day to do so  the new proposal would void their applications if they dont provide the necessary documents within 90 days.

title: Review: UPs Ties That Bind
description: Many have tried, but when it comes to making television that is both family- and faith-friendly, few have produced anything other than unwatchable mush. The UP network, though, has shown signs of being the exception, and its first original scripted series, which begins on Wednesday night, is another respectable offering.

title: Classical Playlist: Siegfried Idyll, Rachmaninoff and I Have Set My Hert So Hy
description: SIEGFRIED IDYLLWorks by Liszt, Wagner and Brahms; David Deveau, pianist (Steinway & Sons)

title: Jets Coach Todd Bowles on Fight
description: Coach Bowles of the Jets said Tuesday that the quarterback Geno Smith will be out six to 10 weeks after a punch from a teammate left him with a broken jaw.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Trading Scheme Tied to Ukraine
description: Paul J. Fishman, the United States attorney for New Jersey, said that nine people were charged after stealing corporate news releases and using the information to make over $100 million.

title: Why This Movie Now? Planning Release Dates, From Straight Outta Compton to Meru
description: Each week brings with it dozens of new cinematic offerings, and this one is no different.

title: An Apollo Debut and a Balanchine Celebration at Vail International Dance Festival
description: VAIL, Colo.  The Vail festival spoils dancegoers. We start to feel that every theater should be surrounded by pine-clad mountains and approached by a path featuring a rushing river (and at least one hummingbird).

title: Five Difficult Characters that Delight Billy Eichner
description: The comedian famous for yelling at people on the street rounds up five misanthropic characters he adores abhorring.

title: Chinas Currency Move Clouds Its Policy Goals
description: HONG KONG  As President Xi Jinping of China prepares for a state visit to Washington next month to smooth over troubled relations, his government has just turned the spotlight back on a recurring issue: the value of his countrys currency.

title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
description: Greece and More  Pictures of the Day

title: August 11, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Greece, Myanmar, Portugal and Germany.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know.

title: Is the New Google More Like Berkshire Hathaway, General Electric or AT&T?
description: Googles decision to restructure is the strongest signal yet that it intends to be a 21st-century innovator, a bold creator of new products, not simply a harvester of profits from its lucrative search engine business.

title: A Conversation With John C. Tashjian
description: Mr. Tashjian, 45, is a founder and principal of Centurion Real Estate Partners, a New York-based company that develops, acquires and manages commercial property. Centurions most recent project is River & Warren, a condominium conversion it is developing in partnership with Five Mile Capital Partners.

title: How China Is Trying to Stabilize Its Economy
description: Chinas devaluation of the renminbi was the latest in a series of moves over the past two months to help boost the slowing Chinese economy.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Heck of a Class Project: An Affordable, Robust, Compact Fusion Reactor Design, Buildable in a Decade
description: Its a sure bet that the best known arc reactor in the world is the glowing energy source in the chest of Tony Stark, the inventor with a superhero complex at the heart of the Iron Man film franchise.

title: A Milestone in Africa: No Polio Cases in a Year
description: It has been one full year since polio was detected anywhere in Africa, a significant milestone in global health that has left health experts around the world quietly celebrating.

title: Moments Before Ferguson Shooting
description: St. Louis County investigators posted a surveillance video on Tuesday that they say shows Tyrone Harris pulling out a handgun. The man, wearing a white shirt, appears near the end of the video.

title: G.E. Continues Sell-Off With Health Care Lending Business
description: General Electric continued its campaign to shrink its huge finance arm, announcing on Tuesday that it will sell its health care lending business to Capital One for about $9 billion.

title: King Lear With Sheep. Yes, Sheep.
description: LONDON  A new adaptation of King Lear, will open at the Courtyard Theater here on Wednesday.

title: Arlington, Tex., Officer Is Fired in Fatal Shooting of Christian Taylor
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  A white rookie police officer who shot and killed an unarmed black college football player after the youth had broken into a car dealership in this Dallas suburb was fired on Tuesday for inappropriate judgment in his handling of the situation, officials said.

title: Showtime Reveals Twin Peaks Details
description: LOS ANGELES  Showtimes revival of Twin Peaks is back on track  after a dispute over the shows budget this spring between the network and the co-creator of the series, David Lynch, led to uncertainty over its return.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,346 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: How Hackers Made $1 Million by Stealing One News Release
description: A scheme, announced by federal authorities on Tuesday, to hack into three news wire services to steal copies of corporate news releases went on for years, and required a good deal of patience and persistence. For a while, it seemed to pay off.

title: One Year Later, Bouncy Bridge in Brooklyn Remains Closed
description: After missing a number of reopening dates, the so-called bouncy bridge of Brooklyn Heights reached a dubious milestone on Tuesday: It has now been closed for repairs for exactly one year.

title: John Riggi, Who Led New Jersey Crime Family, Dies at 90
description: John Riggi, a convicted New Jersey labor racketeer who was often mistakenly cited as an inspiration for the acclaimed HBO series The Sopranos, died on Aug. 3 at his home in Edison, N.J. He was 90.

title: Google Goal in Restructuring as Alphabet: Autonomy
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For a glimpse of how Larry Page might envision the way a newly restructured Google will work, take a look at Nest Labs, the companys Internet-connected thermostat business.

title: Newlyweds Are Accused of Planning to Join ISIS
description: A newlywed Mississippi couple who were arrested on the way to the airport for a trip to Syria to join the Islamic State were ordered held without bail on Tuesday.

title: Serena Williams Recovers After Another Middling Start
description: TORONTO  Given its beginning, Serena Williamss hardcourt season may well look like the clay and grass-court campaigns that preceded it. And her march toward a calendar-year Grand Slam will most likely require stepping into potholes along the way.

title: Global Selling Shows Concerns About Chinas Weakness
description: After China shocked investors on Tuesday by devaluing the countrys currency, a wave of selling swept the globe. The price of oil plunged, the currencies of other countries tumbled and stock markets skidded on every continent.

title: Ann McGovern, Author, Is Dead at 85; She Made Stone Soup a School Staple
description: Ann McGovern, a prolific author for children whose work ranged over womens history, adaptations of folk tales and her own exploits as a globe-trotting adventurer, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 85.

title: Donald Trump Defines His Style: Deal-Making Flexibility
description: BIRCH RUN, Mich.  Donald J. Trumps plan to combat the Islamic State? We go in, we knock the hell out of em, we take the oil, he told Fox News on Tuesday.

title: New Diplomacy Seen on U.S.-Russian Efforts to End Syrian Civil War
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  With President Bashar al-Assad of Syria facing battlefield setbacks, diplomats from Russia, the United States and several Middle Eastern powers are engaged in a burst of diplomatic activity, trying to head off a deeper collapse of the country that could further strengthen the militant group Islamic State.

title: Schumer Says Corporation Should Oversee Hudson Tunnels Project
description: Senator Chuck Schumer, seeking an end to the standoff over financing new Hudson River rail tunnels, proposed on Tuesday creating a nonprofit corporation to oversee the project and to assemble the billions of dollars needed to build new tunnels.

title: Any Sexual Abuse by Guards May Violate Inmates Rights, Court Says
description: Any malicious sexual contact by prison guards against inmates may amount to a constitutional violation, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday, noting how standards of decency have changed in the past two decades.

title: Head of Group Opposing Iran Accord Quits Post, Saying He Backs Deal
description: WASHINGTON  When the bipartisan advocacy group United Against Nuclear Iran decided last week to mobilize opposition against the nuclear deal with Tehran, Gary Samore knew he could no longer serve as its president.

title: E.P.A. Treating Toxic Water From Abandoned Colorado Mine After Accident
description: DENVER  Nearly a week after the Environmental Protection Agency accidentally breached a store of chemical-laced water from an abandoned mine in southwest Colorado, toxic water continues to spill at a rate of 500 to 700 gallons a minute, E.P.A. officials said Tuesday.

title: Puerto Rico to Issue $750 Million in Revenue Bonds for Construction
description: Eight days after it defaulted on bond payments for the first time, the government of Puerto Rico said on Tuesday that it planned to issue $750 million more in bonds for an array of construction and maintenance projects.

title: Hillary Clinton Directs Aides to Give Email Server and Thumb Drive to the Justice Department
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has directed her aides to give the Justice Department an email server that housed the personal account that she used exclusively while secretary of state, along with a thumb drive that contained copies of the emails, her presidential campaign said on Tuesday.

title: Jeb Bush Blames Hillary Clinton and Obama for Iraqs Decline
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  The war in Iraq, which dominated American presidential politics in 2004 and 2008, has returned as an issue in 2016. This time, the argument is not over whether the United States should have gone to war, but rather how the Obama administration sought to end it.

title: Handling of Donald Trump Puts Fox News on the Spot
description: It started with Megyn Kellys interrogation of Donald J. Trump at Thursday nights debate on Fox News. Mr. Trump wasted no time responding, in less than presidential terms. The networks chief executive, Roger E. Ailes, intervened, placating Mr. Trump while also defending his star anchor, Ms. Kelly.

title: An Aging Nomad, Jose Reyes Longs for a Team in the Hunt
description: It was around midnight, and Jose Reyes was sleeping in his Toronto home when his wife received a call from a Toronto Blue Jays trainer summoning him to the ballpark. Reyes had spent the off day mostly hanging around the house. At 32, he needed ample rest and recovery.

title: In Former Hummer Plant in Indiana, Mercedes Turns Out S.U.V.s for China
description: MISHAWAKA, Ind.  The steady comeback of the American auto industry has brought new life to underused factories, as carmakers across the country add shifts of workers to meet growing demand for new vehicles.

title: Police Officer With U.N. Force in Central African Republic Is Accused of Rape
description: UNITED NATIONS  In the latest allegation of child sexual abuse by peacekeepers in the Central African Republic, a United Nations police officer is accused of raping a 12-year-old girl in the capital, Bangui, during a nighttime house-to-house search, according to Amnesty International.

title: Questions of Focus Hover Over Tiger Woods
description: HAVEN, Wis.  Tiger Woodss new, and first, sports bar and restaurant opened Monday night in Jupiter, Fla. About 18 hours later, Woods was on the practice range at Whistling Straits, preparing for his 18th P.G.A. Championship.

title: Straight Outta History, the Rage That Makes Movies
description: LOS ANGELES  Universal Pictures took on one of its more delicate challenges on Tuesday: making sure that the studios film Straight Outta Compton heals more wounds than it reopens.

title: Review: In John, Pondering Lifes Mysteries From Gettysburg
description: If chintz could speak, Im sure it would sound like Georgia Engel, whose girlish purr must be the most comforting voice possessed by man or woman. The comparison springs to mind because Ms. Engel is presiding over a virtual museum of chintz  and cute tchotchkes, and stuffed animals, and dainty figurines  in the new Annie Baker play, John, which opened on Tuesday night at the Signature Center.

title: Glaxo Closes Plant After Legionnaires Bacterium Is Found
description: GlaxoSmithKline temporarily shut down a major pharmaceutical manufacturing plant in North Carolina on Tuesday after the bacterium that causes Legionnaires disease was discovered in a cooling tower.

title: Looking Within
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  When there are starred clues in a puzzle, I immediately scan the list to see if there is a revealer that will help me guess the theme. Its not always successful, but occasionally it pays off. Today was not one of those days, but thats on me: I forgot that Tom McCoy tends to see things through a mathematical lens.

title: Carmelo Anthony Takes Step in Test of Knee
description: Carmelo Anthony took part in a light, noncontact workout on Tuesday in Las Vegas, where U.S.A. Basketball convened a three-day training camp this week involving more than 30 N.B.A. players. It was a small but noteworthy step for Anthony, 31, who has not played basketball since February, when he underwent surgery to repair a damaged tendon in his left knee.

title: Matt Harvey Proves Stellar in Shutout as Mets Defeat the Rockies
description: On Tuesday, with about eight weeks remaining in the season, the Mets sent their season-ticket holders directions for buying tickets for potential postseason games at Citi Field. As part of the package, the Mets were selling hypothetical seats to the World Series  and it was not a cruel joke.

title: Donald Trump Lashes Out at Bush
description: While speaking at a campaign event in Michigan Tuesday, the Republican presidential candidate called Jeb Bushs comments on womens health issues a disaster.

title: Rikers Inmate Has Legionnaires Disease; Officials Find No Link to Outbreak
description: A Rikers Island inmate has Legionnaires disease, New York City officials said on Tuesday, quickly adding that it was unlikely the case was connected to an outbreak in the South Bronx that has killed 12 people since early July.

title: Arlington Police Chief Addresses Media
description: Will D. Johnson, the Arlington, Tex., police chief, said the officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager at a Dallas-area car dealership had been fired.

title: China Weakens Its Currency Further
description: HONG KONG  China weakened its currency, the renminbi, for a second straight day on Wednesday, jolting markets across Asia and raising concerns about the path of the giant economy.

title: Own a Piece of Le Corbusiers Tree
description: At Le Corbusiers Villa Le Lac near Geneva  one of the architects first projects, which he designed for his parents in 1924  a felled giant Paulownia tree has been turned into a series of collectible objects by the Spanish designer Jaime Hayon. In partnership with the Italian furniture manufacturer Cassina, Hayon has fashioned birds, birdhouses and swing-shaped shelves from the wood of the ancient tree, whose branches once created a canopy over the propertys waterfront terrace.

title: A New Tuscan Spa in a Centuries-Old Granary
description: Tucked away in the Siena region of central Tuscany, the idyllic Hotel Monteverdi has opened a heavenly new spa in partnership with Santa Maria Novella, the cult skin-care and fragrance label (and one of the most storied apothecaries in the world). Housed in a centuries-old granary, the space offers an extensive menu of treatments including olive- and grapeseed-oil massages and outdoor mineral baths overlooking the rolling countryside.

title: The Art of the Sculpturally Unfinished Updo
description: On the fall runways, hair was elaborate but undone  like your grandmothers hair, only crazier.

title: Camilla Guinness and the Importance of Not Being Earnest
description: From troll dolls to the queen, the interior designer blends Old World elegance and British charm.

title: Number of Uninsured Has Declined by 15 Million Since 2013, Administration Says
description: WASHINGTON  The number of people without health insurance continues to decline and has dropped by 15.8 million, or one-third, since 2013, the Obama administration said Tuesday.

title: Word of the Day | pigment
description: pigment  \pig-mnt\  noun and verb

title: The Girl on the Train Chugs Past 3 Million in Sales
description: When Riverhead Books acquired a thriller from an unknown British novelist last year, it seemed like a bit of a gamble. Foreign suspense novels dont always resonate with American readers, and the author, Paula Hawkins, was new to writing crime fiction. But the book had a lot going for it, mainly a mesmerizing plot fueled by three unreliable narrators, and Riverhead planned a healthy first print run of 40,000 copies.

title: Yankees Loss in 16th Shrinks Their Lead to Half a Game
description: CLEVELAND  After last weekend, when simply pushing a runner across home plate seemed like such a monumental task for the Yankees, the sight of much-maligned Stephen Drew hitting a home run that ended a 31-inning scoreless streak inspired a sigh of relief Tuesday night.

title: Whats on TV Wednesday
description: 8 P.M. (ABC Family) KEVIN FROM WORK Kevin (Noah Reid), an earnest young office worker, finally gets to quit the worst job in history. Every bit of it stinks, except for the colleague with whom he has shared a cubicle wall for three years: Audrey (Paige Spara), perpetually backlit, her hair tousled by a magical breeze and the wings of the animated bluebirds that suddenly appear every time she is near. And like them, Kevin longs to be close to her. If only she didnt have a lunk of a boyfriend  which is why Kevin has banished himself and his shredded heart to Italy, but not before pouring his passion into a love letter and mailing it. After all, hes never going to see her again, right? With a whisper of (500) Days of Summer in its DNA  those bluebirds again, and a younger sister (Jordan Hinson) to inflict pain  Kevin From Work heralds the return of the single-camera comedy to ABC Family. It also packs a secret weapon in Amy Sedaris, as Kevins monster of a boss.

title: Corrections: August 12, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Its something we dont tolerate; its something we cant stand. And you dont walk up to another man and punch him in the face.

description: Test your knowledge of financial matters by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: Kodaks First Digital Moment
description: Imagine a world where photography is a slow process that is impossible to master without years of study or apprenticeship. A world without iPhones or Instagram, where one company reigned supreme. Such a world existed in 1973, when Steven Sasson, a young engineer, went to work for Eastman Kodak.

title: Keep the Tax on High-End Health Plans
description: Congress is under pressure to repeal an impending tax on the so-called Cadillac health plans offered by many employers. Scores of legislators from each party have endorsed separate bills to repeal it, and candidates for office, pressed by lobbyists from labor unions, business groups and insurers, may join the call for repeal. The tax should probably be adjusted by Congress to eliminate inequities, but outright repeal would be a mistake that would undermine the viability of the Affordable Care Act.

title: If I Were an Israeli Looking at the Iran Deal
description: With the U.S. and Israel openly arguing over the Iran nuclear deal, Ive asked myself this: How would I look at this deal if I were an Israeli grocer, an Israeli general or the Israeli prime minister?

title: Pearsons Stake in Economist Group to Be Sold to Other Shareholders
description: The British education company Pearson agreed on Wednesday to sell its 50 percent stake in the Economist Group, the publisher of The Economist, to other shareholders of the group for $730 million.

title: Living in New Dorp, Staten Island
description: The beaches are a major recreational draw in New Dorp, but living near the waterfront has become more costly because of pricier flood insurance.

title: New Dorp, Staten Island: Still Recovering From Sandy
description: Its name comes from the Dutch words for new village. But today, New Dorp, a middle-class area on Staten Islands eastern shore, exudes a spirit that seems to have more to do with the past than anything contemporary or trendy.

title: President Obamas Letter to the Editor
description: For the cover story of our Aug. 2 issue, Jim Rutenberg wrote about efforts over the last 50 years to dismantle the protections in the Voting Rights Act of 1965, the landmark piece of legislation that cleared barriers between black voters and the ballot. The story surveyed a broad sweep of history and characters, from United States Chief Justice John Roberts to ordinary citizens like 94-year-old Rosanell Eaton, a plaintiff in the current North Carolina case arguing to repeal voting restrictions enacted in 2013. The magazine received an unusual volume of responses to this article, most notably from President Barack Obama.

title: Obama Urges Defense of Voting Rights in Letter to the Editor
description: President Obama wrote on Wednesday that voting rights must be vigorously defended and called on Congress to restore the Voting Rights Act in the wake of a Supreme Court ruling that invalidated central parts of the historic 1965 law.

title: Nine Years Ago, Republicans Favored Voting Rights. What Happened?
description: On July 20, 2006, the United States Senate voted to renew the Voting Rights Act for 25 more years. The vote was unanimous, 98 to 0. That followed an overwhelmingly bipartisan vote in the House of Representatives, which passed it by a vote of 390 to 33. President George Bush signed the renewal with apparent enthusiasm a few days later.

title: Jane Lynch Cant Resist the Call of the Stage
description: Jane Lynch was holding it in.

title: As Drug Kingpins Fall in Mexico, Cartels Fracture and Violence Surges
description: CHILAPA, Mexico  For nearly a week, gun-toting masked men loyal to a local drug gang overran this small city along a key smuggling route. Police officers and soldiers stood by as the gunmen patrolled the streets, searching for rivals and hauling off at least 14 men who have not been seen since.

title: Soccer Broadcaster Pairs Proper English Accent With Unbridled American Verve
description: LEICESTER, England  The voice of English soccer in the United States did not hesitate  not even for a second  when asked for his favorite broadcasting memory.

description: An unlikely new beacon is glowing in the claustrophobic canyon of Lexington Avenue.

title: A Floating Arsenal to Combat ISIS
description: Fighter jets from the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt are supporting Iraqi troops approaching Ramadi, a city overrun by the Islamic State.

title: U.S. Jets Meet Limit as Iraqi Ground Fight Against ISIS Plods On
description: ABOARD U.S.S. THEODORE ROOSEVELT, in the Persian Gulf  Navy fighter jets roar off this nuclear-powered aircraft carrier in support of Iraqi troops approaching Ramadi, a city in Anbar Province overrun by Islamic State fighters in one of the worst defeats for the American-led coalition.

description: What happened? Is he all right?

title: Ultimate Frisbee at the Olympics?
The Right Dose of Exercise for the Aging Brain
description: A small amount of exercise may improve our ability to think as we age, but more may not be better, according to a new study of exercise and cognition.
