title: The Plight of Refugees, the Shame of the World
description: The world is facing the biggest refugee crisis since World War II, a staggering 60 million people displaced from their homes, four million from Syria alone. World leaders have abdicated their responsibility for this unlucky population, around half of whom are children.

title: Stop Stealing From Strippers
description: TODAY I am a two for one. This is how it works: the first lap dance is free. The second one is 20 bucks. Tenner Tuesday is a weekly special, offering a bargain for customers on an otherwise sluggish day where I work, the only strip club for miles.

title: Is Hillary Clinton Really in Danger of Losing the Primary?
description: Bernie Sanders is said to be surging, Joe Biden is considering jumping in the race, and Hillary Rodham Clintons unfavorable ratings are the worst theyve been in her 23-plus years in national politics  worse than they were in 2007 or 2008.

title: Daily Report: Alibaba Disappoints Amid a Slowdown in China
description: For a while, Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce giant, looked as if it was making a retail push into the United States and, just maybe, could directly compete with Amazon.com. But in June, after just a year, Alibaba sold the online marketplace 11 Main as well as three other small companies it had acquired to compete for American customers.

title: Brazils Vigilante Lynchings
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Last month, a man was beaten to death by a mob after being accused of trying to rob a bar in So Lus do Maranho, in northern Brazil. The man, Cleidenilson Pereira da Silva, was stripped naked by the crowd, tied to a pole, kicked, punched and hit with stones and bottles. He died at the scene.

title: Blast at Baghdad Market Kills About 60
description: A witness described a deadly truck bombing that struck a market in the neighborhood of Sadr City in the Iraqi capital early Thursday morning.

title: 1940: Britain May Lift Blockade
description: LONDON  In spite of the chill with which London has greeted reports of Herbert Hoovers latest appeal to the warring nations of Europe to permit food from America to be distributed to the 27,000,000 civilians in Norway, Belgium, Holland and Poland, an American source here said today that limited relief might be expected in the not too distant future. Earlier reports of Mr. Hoovers statement were taken to indicate that Britain was, in effect, being asked to raise her blockade to allow American foodstuffs to get through to peoples recently taken under the German wing.  New York Herald Tribune, August 14, 1940

title: Getting Rowdy: Keith Ape and Real Rap in Korea
description: By the time the South Korean rapper Keith Ape made it to the nightclub S.O.B.s in April for his first New York show, just three months had passed since the release of It G Ma, his breakout single.

title: China 2015 Is Not China 2010
description: If there is a central policy theme to Donald Trumps candidacy other than immigration  actually, there isnt, but there are some particular things he bellows about  its China-bashing. The unifying principle is probably xenophobia; but anyway, Chinas currency moves are about to become a US political issue. And pretty soon, I expect, people will point out that some liberals also used to complain about Chinese currency manipulation.

title: Devastation in Tianjin, China
description: The death toll in the port city has hit 50 after two overnight explosions, which burned countless cars, shattered windows for blocks and injured hundreds of people.

title: Doctors Fail to Address Patients Spiritual Needs
description: My patient, a woman in her 20s with cancer, was doing poorly on chemotherapy. The disease had spread throughout her body. We were doing everything we could to help her, but didnt know how long she would live  probably only a few months, at most. Her mother came regularly to visit, and sat by her side. Around their necks, they both wore gold crosses on tiny gold chains. Taped on the wall, near the foot of her bed, was a greeting card with a picture of Jesus, in a red cloak with pointy gold beams radiating from his head.

title: Using a Chat Tool to Cover the Republican Debate
description: Last week, The Timess political team experimented with live-blogging the first Republican debate by using the increasingly popular chat tool, Slack. Times Insider talked to Paul Volpe, editor in the Washington bureau, and Marc Lavallee, editor of Interactive News, about how it went, using, of course  a Slack chat room!

title: Winning in the N.F.L. Preseason Could Be a Bad Sign
description: N.F.L. preseason games, which began in earnest on Thursday night, are regularly derided as meaningless. A tedious method to sort out the future backups from the soon-to-be-cut. A chance for top players to be injured. A cash grab with high-priced tickets, food and parking for an inferior product.

title: In Praise of Sensible Panties
description: Germanic undergarments have their own brand of sex appeal.

title: Europe Gives Google More Time to Respond to Antitrust Charges
description: BERLIN  Europe has spent years investigating Googles alleged antitrust activities. Now the search giant wants a little more time to respond to the charges.

title: Unpaid Intern Quits United Nations Post
description: David Hyde, a 22-year-old from New Zealand who could not afford rent in Geneva, quit a prestigious internship at the United Nations after it was revealed that he was sleeping in a tent.

title: Kentucky Clerk Defies Court on Marriage Licenses for Gay Couples
description: MOREHEAD, Ky.  Nearly two months after the Supreme Court declared a constitutional right to same-sex marriage, a county clerks office here  in defiance of a federal court order  turned away several gay couples seeking marriage licenses on Thursday, taking a stand that has infuriated gay rights advocates but buoyed Christian conservatives who insist their religious freedoms are being violated.

title: Age-Defying Athletes
description: In masters track and field, athletes 35 and older compete in various divisions. At the World Masters Championships in France, competitors in the top age groups provided many of the highlights.

title: Samsung Introduces New Phones and Mobile Payments System
description: Heavy lies the crown for any leader in the smartphone market, and Samsungs plan to stay in the lead is tointroducenewphones alongside a new mobile payments system.

title: Maps, Videos and Photos of the Explosions in China
description: Maps and videos showing the extent of damage from two explosions that ripped through an industrial area in the coastal city of Tianjin, China.

title: Sesame Street to Air First on HBO for Next 5 Seasons
description: The letters of the day on Sesame Street are H, B and O.

title: John Kasichs Appeal to Moderates Gains Traction in New Hampshire
description: DERRY, N.H.  Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio unabashedly promotes his expansion of Medicaid under Obamacare, shows little appetite for relitigating culture-war battles like same-sex marriage and offers not much more than a shrug when asked about Hillary Rodham Clintons turning over her email server to the F.B.I.

title: Racing a Clock While Scoffing at Time
description: LYON, France  Flo Meiler, an 81-year-old from Shelburne, Vt., recently broke the world record in the heptathlon for the womens 80-84 age group with an age-graded score of 5,730 at the World Masters Athletics Championships here.

title: Greek Island of Kos, Overwhelmed With Migrants, Tries to Move Them Along
description: KOS, Greece  The Greek government moved on Thursday to speed up the evacuation of Syrians and other migrants who have overwhelmed the picturesque harbor of this southeastern Aegean island in recent days.

title: A Breakup and a Makeup, Without You
description: My husband and I were best friends with another couple. They were an integral part of our lives, and Id like to think we were important to them, too. Sadly, they broke up. We did our best to keep in touch separately, but we drifted apart and happy birthday texts became the extent of our relationship. Recently, we saw on Facebook that they are back together and engaged. Should we approach them? We are very disappointed that they have not gotten in touch with us.

title: A New Class of Ferrari Takes a Bow at Pebble Beach: Unrestored
description: ON Sunday, a rare Ferrari will take its place among a special group of cars at the Pebble Beach Concours dElegance, there to be admired by the worlds most discerning car collectors.

title: Waitress Musical Sets the Table for Broadway
description: The singer-songwriter Sara Bareilles has sold more than two million albums and served as a celebrity judge on the NBC a cappella competition show The Sing-Off. Next spring, she will add Broadway composer to her list of credits when the new show Waitress opens at the Brooks Atkinson Theater.

title: Team From New York Education Dept. to Study Troubled East Ramapo Schools
description: After the Legislature rejected a move to give the New York State Education Department enhanced powers over the troubled East Ramapo school system in Rockland County, the department is taking a more modest step: It has appointed three experts to study the districts operations and offer recommendations to the school board and the Board of Regents, the agency said on Thursday.

title: Jeans Made for Walking Down Memory Lane
description: Seventies fashion again feels of the moment, with denim styles as loose and freeing as they were in the disco era. For inspiration, look no further than to three stylish women of the period.

title: Turkish Coalition Talks End Fruitlessly, Making New Elections Likely
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys two largest political parties ended talks on Thursday without agreeing to form a coalition government, setting the stage for likely new elections and threatening further political instability.

title: Reaching Back
description: Vu Tran, whose novel Dragonfish is reviewed this week, was born in Saigon in 1975 and escaped the country in 1980. He is one of a number of writers in his generation with Vietnamese roots, including Viet Thanh Nguyen and Nam Le, who have recently met with literary success.

title: For Evolving Brains, a Paleo Diet of Carbs
description: You are what you eat, and so were your ancient ancestors. But figuring out what they actually dined on has been no easy task.

title: Emery LeCrone in the Studio
description: The 28-year-old choreographer debuts new work at the Ballet Festival this week.

title: Wayne Brady Will Step Into Kinky Boots
description: Billy Porter, who won a Tony Award for playing Lola in Cyndi Lauper and Harvey Fiersteins hit musical Kinky Boots, will leave the production on Nov. 20, and be succeeded by the actor and comedian Wayne Brady, producers announced Thursday.

title: Can a Hotel Robot Read a Do Not Disturb Sign?
description: Giving a new meaning to robotic service, several hotels and at least one cruise ship have been experimenting with machines that can handle guest check-in, store bags, deliver extra towels or mix a drink at the bar.

title: Letters: The Conservative Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: Review: Show Me a Hero Focuses on a Mayor in the Maelstrom of Desegregation
description: You can see why the tale of Nick Wasicsko and the decades-long battle to desegregate Yonkers, in which he played a short but crucial role, would appeal to David Simon. Like Baltimore in The Wire and New Orleans in Treme, Yonkers symbolizes the tortured metamorphosis of the post-industrial American city. And in Wasicsko, elected mayor at 28 and caught in a vortex of racism and fear, it would seem to have a classic tragic hero: an impetuous young man who grows into leadership, is cast out and doesnt live to see the full fruit of the seeds he planted.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Man From U.N.C.L.E.
description: Guy Ritchie narrates a sequence from The Man From U.N.C.L.E.

title: How a Kitten Eased My Partners Depression
description: When his depression was at its worst, my partner, Joe, would wake up in the morning engulfed in a fog so palpable that its presence would sometimes startle me awake, as if I had smelled something burning.

title: Pouilly-Fuisss With an Identity Crisis
description: The Mconnais, a tranquil, hilly, picturesque region near the southern end of Burgundy, just to the north of Beaujolais, has long been a source for inexpensive white wines. Like almost all white Burgundies, they are made of chardonnay. And, as has been true all over the wine-producing world, the last 20 years have been incredibly exciting because of the tremendous rise in quality from the Mconnais.

title: A World War and Clashing Architecture Foil a German Arts District
description: BERLIN  Twenty-five years after German reunification, the capital is still trying to fill the lingering gaps in its urban fabric as it vies to be considered alongside Paris and Rome as one of Europes pre-eminent cultural centers.

title: HBO, Brought to You by Sesame Street
description: Starting this fall, new episodes of the childrens television series Sesame Street will appear exclusively on the cable network HBO and its streaming outlets. After nine months, the episodes will be available free on PBS, the shows longtime home.

title: The Man From U.N.C.L.E. (With Movie Trailer): Guy Ritchie Narrates a Scene
description: The 1960s television spy series The Man From U.N.C.L.E. gets a big screen update from the director Guy Ritchie. Henry Cavill and Armie Hammer take the lead roles of Napoleon Solo and Illya Kuryakin, CIA and KGB agents forced to join forces, with an assist from Alicia Vikander. This early scene pits the two against each another in a divided Berlin. In an interview, Mr. Ritchie spoke about the sequence and ideas for the movie. Following are excerpts from that conversation.

title: Review: The Man From U.N.C.L.E. Resurrects a Glossy, Action-Packed 60s
description: Guy Ritchie makes the kind of enjoyably disreputable movies that are fun to watch until theyre not. Hes a talented flimflam artist and, for the industry, I imagine, a useful one because of how he glosses up schlocky, sketchy projects (his Sherlock Holmes movies and other hyperkinetic baubles), making them seem as if theres more to their slick surfaces than naked commercialism, agency fees and facile pleasure. It works for him (he keeps getting hired), and sometimes also for us. Pleasure is, after all, rarely overrated, including in the often mind-bludgeoning arena of franchise cinema, and theres a lot to be said for watching beautiful people doing very silly stuff on screen.

title: Families of Virginia Tech Massacre Victims Start Program to Improve Campus Safety
description: Eight years after the Virginia Tech massacre, survivors and families announced a program on Thursday intended to make colleges and universities safer, hoping it will serve as a legacy for the 32 people killed.

title: Drone Videos Show Ancient Peruvian Sites
description: Perus Ministry of Culture is using drones to survey the countrys archeological sites as part of conservation efforts.

title: Connecticut Death Penalty Law Is Unconstitutional, Court Rules
description: Casting the death penalty as an outdated tool of justice at odds with todays societal values, Connecticuts highest court on Thursday spared the lives of 11 men on death row by ruling that capital punishment violated the State Constitution.

title: Exploring the Dolomites in Italy
description: In summer, hiking trails through forests and flower-filled meadows beckon, and enticing meals are never far away.

title: Adam Johnsons Fortune Smiles
description: Late one night not long ago, when I was losing an ugly bout with insomnia and everyone in my family was snoring in syncopated swing, I read a story in Harpers Magazine that made me wake my husband up and insist that he read it, no, read it right now. The story is from the point of view of a very sick woman, the wife of a writer, and it speaks about family love and grief and jealousy and guilt and rage and illness with a power that took my breath away. That story, Interesting Facts, has now been published with five others, all of them so long they could almost be called novellas, in a new collection titled Fortune Smiles. Its author is Adam Johnson, who won the 2013 Pulitzer Prize for his novel about North Korea, The Orphan Masters Son.

title: Lindsey Vonn Fractures Ankle While Training
description: Lindsey Vonn crashed while training on Coronet Peak in New Zealand on Thursday and sustained an ankle fracture that forced her to fly back to the United States for treatment, the United States Ski Team said. Vonn first announced the injury on her social media accounts.

title: Toronto Film Festival Announces First TV Lineup
description: Keith Richards, French zombies and a quirky set of siblings are among the subjects to be explored in a new television section of the Toronto International Film Festival.

title: Bookshelf: Board Book Treats for Toddlers
description: New books include a chunky guide to dinosaurs and some big laughs in small packages.

title: For Mercury Fur Writer Philip Ridley, a Macabre Vision Takes Many Forms
description: When Philip Ridley was a child he suffered from severe asthma. When he wasnt in the hospital, he was often kept at home. Alone in his bedroom, in a tower block in Londons East End, he would draw pictures and write stories, make up poems and sing songs. He would disappear into a world of his own making.

title: Colorado Court Rules Against Baker Who Refused to Serve Same-Sex Couples
description: A state appeals court in Colorado ruled Thursday that a baker could not cite religious beliefs in refusing to make wedding cakes for same-sex couples.

title: Chinas Central Bank Backs Currency
description: Officials for the Peoples Bank of China insist that the yuan remains strong, despite the recent currency devaluation.

title: 1965: Dr. King to Appeal for Peace
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  The Rev Martin Luther King Jr. will appeal personally to North Vietnamese President Ho Chi Minh to carry the war in Vietnam to the conference table, he said last night. The Negro integration leader said he would send a letter to the North Vietnamese leader as well as to those of South Vietnam, Russia and the United States. Dr. King told his Southern Christian Leadership Conference convention that each side must end the cycle of mistrust, violence and war. Dr. King suggested that the United States seriously consider halting its bombings.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 14, 1965

title: Sky Lights
description: Last nights Perseid meteor shower was one of the most spectacular in years.

title: The Heat Is On to Score the Next Big Summer Song
description: It was still spring when the ultimate New York summer song was written.

title: Top Hillary Clinton Donor Clarifies Stance on Iran Nuclear Deal
description: Haim Saban, a top donor to Hillary Rodham Clinton who came out last week against the nuclear agreement between Iran and six world powers, says his comments about the deal were taken out of context.

title: Mary Jo Heath Will Be New Radio Host for Metropolitan Opera
description: There have been many voices at the Metropolitan Opera, but only a few voices of the Metropolitan Opera. Now the mantle, or microphone, is being passed to Mary Jo Heath: she will become the fourth full-time radio host in the companys history in September.

title: After Ferguson, California Orders Police Shooting Cases Into Open Court
description: After a tumultuous year of nationwide protest, California has become the first state to ban the use of grand juries to decide whether a police officer should face criminal charges in using deadly force against civilians. Criticism of the secret grand jury process has become a flash point in a series of civilian deaths at the hands of police that began with the shooting of Michael Brown, a black teenager in Ferguson, Mo., last summer.

title: Sir Kensingtons, Condiments Maker, Receives $8.5 Million Investment
description: Sir Kensingtons, a small but growing company in the condiments business, has received a $8.5 million from some individual investors and Verlinvest, the family-owned private equity group that is snapping up stakes in some of Americas most popular new food companies.

title: P.G.A. Championship 2015: Dustin Johnson Is Calm Before Storming to the Top
description: HAVEN, Wis.  Dustin Johnson started his first round of the 2015 P.G.A. Championship on the 10th hole, a short, downhill 361-yard par 4. Most players in the field Thursday used irons off the tee, strategically positioning themselves on a serpentine fairway so they could be aggressive with their second shots.

title: Narcotic Drugs Can Be Coaxed From Yeast
description: In a widely expected advance that has opened a fierce debate about home-brewed heroin, scientists at Stanford have created strains of yeast that can produce narcotic drugs.

title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Looking for something fun to do?

title: Shinzo Abes Bid to Redefine Japan and Its Military Has Echoes of Family History
description: In a famous photograph from his childhood, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan is seen perched on the knee of his smiling grandfather, Nobusuke Kishi, the influential postwar prime minister. There is no sign of the turmoil just outside the family home, where thousands were protesting Mr. Kishis plan to extend Japans military alliance with the United States.

title: El Nio May Bring Record Heat, and Rain for California
description: This years El Nio weather pattern could be the most powerful on record, federal forecasters said, while warning that the effects of the weather system are never certain.

title: Japans Apologies for World War II
description: Here is a look at major statements on Japans war legacy by monarchs and senior officials since its defeat in 1945.

title: Donald Trump Is Officially Off The Celebrity Apprentice
description: LOS ANGELES  The Celebrity Apprentice will return to NBCs lineup at some point in the 2016-17 television season, but Donald J. Trump will not.

title: Age-Defying Athletes
description: In masters track and field, athletes 35 and older compete in various divisions. At the World Masters Championships in France, competitors in the top age groups provided many of the highlights.

title: Mets Overcome Shaky Start and Complete Sweep of Rockies
description: Noah Syndergaard gritted his teeth and punched his glove, watching a solo home run sail over Yoenis Cespedess head in center field. Five pitches later, there was another home run to left. It was only the first inning, and the unimpressive Colorado Rockies were the opponent, but, still, Syndergaard looked vulnerable.

title: Venezuela Releases Two Prominent Government Critics From Prison
description: Venezuela released two prominent government critics from prison this week, including a former defense minister who had been a confidant of President Hugo Chvez.

title: Donald Trump Video Juxtaposes Obama Playing Golf With ISIS Violence
description: Donald J. Trump may be new to politics, but he has already demonstrated a mastery of the dark art of creating haunting campaign videos packed with imagery of violence and war.

title: Works Sighted: Iranian Life Under Sanctions
description: As a vote on the nuclear deal that would lift sanctions against Iran approaches in Congress, Pedestrian, an Iranian writer, offers a look at what those sanctions mean to Iranians day-to-day lives. Via Vox:

title: U.N. Faces Scrutiny Over Unpaid Intern Who Slept in a Tent in Geneva
description: United Nations officials are facing pressure to revisit their unpaid internship policy after an intern who had been living in a tent near Lake Geneva resigned and called for interns all over the world to unite in a fight for their rights.

title: The Roller Rink Origins of N.W.A.
description: Craig Schweisinger opened the doors to Skateland U.S.A. on Saturday, Nov. 16, 1984. High schoolers mingled with gangbangers and roller skaters who took their choreography seriously. A sign reading NO CAPS  NO COLORS greeted attendees at the door.

title: 'Everyone Just Stood Around in Horror': Readers React to Moms at Bachelorette Parties
description: Readers discuss inter-generational partying, helicopter parenting and ageism.

title: States With High Gun Ownership See More Officers Killed
description: The higher the rate of gun ownership in a state, the higher the likelihood of a law enforcement officer being killed, a new study has found.

title: For Lenovo, Cost-Cutting Is Not Enough to Stem Losses
description: Lenovos turnaround will take more than cost-cutting. The PC and smartphone maker will slash $1.35 billion from annual expenses after earnings fell 51 percent in the second quarter. Revamping may halt losses at the Motorola handset unit that Lenovo bought last year. But any return to growth depends on a demand pickup.

title: The High Price of Rejecting the Iran Deal
description: WASHINGTON  THE Iran nuclear deal offers a long-term solution to one of the most urgent threats of our time. Without this deal, Iran, the worlds leading state sponsor of terrorism, would be less than 90 days away from having enough fissile material to make a nuclear bomb. This deal greatly reduces the threat of Irans nuclear program, making Irans breakout time four times as long, securing unprecedented access to ensure that we will know if Iran cheats and giving us the leverage to hold it to its commitments.

title: John A. Nerud, Hall of Fame Thoroughbred Trainer, Dies at 102
description: John A. Nerud, a Hall of Fame trainer of thoroughbreds who named his greatest horse, Dr. Fager, after the Boston neurosurgeon who saved his life, died on Thursday at his home in Old Brookville, N.Y. He was 102.

title: Google Unveils New Chrome Operating System for Business Customers
description: Google figured out something important: You can sell businesses the future, but theyll show up with lots of the past.

title: Review: One & Two Exposes Dangers of Trying to Control Teenagers
description: In One & Two, an isolated family of four is about to go nuclear. Dad (Grant Bowler) runs a very tight ship on a very tidy homestead in a rural paradise, walled off from the outside world and apparently lacking any technology more recent than kerosene lamps. Mom (Elizabeth Reaser) pretty much goes along, except to try to soothe her husband when he rages about their teenagers, Zac (Timothe Chalamet) and Eva (Kiernan Shipka). They have powers, you see, that must be shunned.

title: On View
description: Auto Bodys sixth art exhibition of the season, Scapes, opened this past Saturday.

title: Review: In Return to Sender, Rosamund Pike Connects With Her Attacker
description: For most of the way, Return to Sender merges creepy and sexy to good effect, thanks to a close-to-the-vest performance by Rosamund Pike, the missing wife of Gone Girl. The story works an old and distasteful trope  the rape victim who falls for the attacker  but the treatment is restrained rather than salacious.

title: Chinas Renminbi Devaluation May Initiate New Phase in Global Currency War
description: For years, China looked like the principled noncombatant. As other countries, seeking to secure an economic advantage, let the value of their currencies slide on international markets, China held firm on the value of its money.

title: Review: Rosenwald, on a Philanthropist Who Created Schools for Blacks in the Jim Crow South
description: In the first half of the 20th century, Julius Rosenwald was not only a leading businessman  the chairman of Sears, Roebuck & Company, one of the countrys wealthiest men  but a leading philanthropist and civil rights advocate as well. With challenge grants, he spurred the building of Y.M.C.A.s that would accept blacks as residents; his Rosenwald Fund dispensed fellowships for a whos who of black artists and academics, from W. E. B. Du Bois to James Baldwin.

title: Copy of Postal Service Audit Shows Extent of Mail Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON  In what experts say is the first acknowledgment of how the United States Postal Services mail surveillance program for national security investigations is used, the services internal watchdog found that inspectors failed to follow key safeguards in the gathering and handling of classified information.

title: Why You Cant Get There From La Guardia
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is reconsidering a longstanding rule that limits flights in and out of La Guardia Airport in Queens to a 1,500-mile radius. The authority should repeal the anachronistic policy, which was introduced decades ago to force airlines and travelers to use Kennedy Airport.

title: Second Stage Adds Dear Evan Hansen To Spring Season
description: A new musical about suicide, social media and a group of angsty high school students will be presented at Second Stage Theater next spring after a production at Arena Stage in Washington received strong reviews.

title: Emery LeCrones Intimate (and Often Emotional) Dance
description: You havent said anything yet, the choreographer Emery LeCrone tells the dancers Shane Ohmer and Izabela Szylinska in rehearsal. They face each other, each with a hand on the others shoulder, and move closer. LeCrone pauses. Now you have the conversation. Its the intensity of this movement  a silent yet intimate exchange between the dancers  that is emblematic of LeCrones choreographic style. While working within the classical vocabulary, LeCrone incorporates pedestrian movements  touching hands, hugging  that are strikingly tender. The steps look like ballet, but theyre less formal, more rugged and athletic  and her dancers are certainly not afraid of the floor. When you go to a big theater and watch 20 dancers on a huge stage, it can feel very distant, says LeCrone. But ballet doesnt have to be that way. It can be more approachable and emotional, less stark and refined.

title: Review: In Air, Norman Reedus and Djimon Hounsou Keep Hope, and Themselves, Alive
description: We cant just decide who lives and who dies! one character says in Air.

title: Review: In Big Sky, Starring Bella Thorne, Mortal Fears Collide
description: The actress Bella Thorne (The Duff; MTVs Scream) dips her toes into grown-up desert noir with Big Sky, a lean exercise that leaves her over her head. Ms. Thorne plays Hazel, a teenager with acute agoraphobia and obsessive-compulsive disorder. Her lonely, mildly disheveled mother, Dee (Kyra Sedgwick), is accompanying her to a treatment center when the van carrying Hazel, Dee and four others is violently ambushed in a sandy wasteland. (The film was shot in New Mexico.) Their assailants are kidnappers (Aaron Tveit and Frank Grillo) who believe they have killed all the passengers save their quarry (Jodi Lynn Thomas), whom they stick in a car trunk. But Dee, though shot, is still alive, and Hazel, who has witnessed the carnage from a concealed spot, must surmount her fears to seek help in the wilderness.

title: Review: Fort Tilden, a Comic Odyssey to the Beach
description: Take the potty-mouthed, woman-centric millennial sensibility of HBOs Girls, turn down the drama and turn up the comic amorality, and you have Fort Tilden, the highly amusing debut feature from Sarah-Violet Bliss and Charles Rogers. Rarely has a movie so humorously illustrated the meaning of frenemy.

title: Mike Huckabee Offers 6 Percent Economic Growth, and Food Tips, at Iowa State Fair
description: DES MOINES  As the first of more than a dozen presidential candidates to drop by the Iowa State Fair, Mike Huckabee mixed the serious with the jovial on Thursday, promising economic growth of 6 percent if elected president, but beginning a speech with a culinary tip.

title: Review: Ten Thousand Saints, a Coming of Age in the East Village, Circa 1980s
description: If you are one of those people who romanticize the East Village in New York when it was at its grungiest, Ten Thousand Saints might be the movie of your dreams. Even if youre not, its still a very fine film, full of quietly impressive performances and young characters who register as authentic.

title: Viewfinder
description: Portraits by Delphine Diaw Diallo.

title: Message Believed to Be From Qaeda Leader Pledges Support for Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The leader of Al Qaeda, Ayman al-Zawahri, broke nearly a year of radio silence on Thursday to pledge allegiance to the new leader of the Taliban, but his audio message made no mention of the Talibans two-year delay in acknowledging that their former leader was dead.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Review: Tango Negro Explores the Roots of a Dance and Musical Genre
description: An interesting idea is overexplained in the documentary Tango Negro: The African Roots of Tango. Here, theories that are worth voicing are apparently worth repeating, and beats that sound catchy are sure to be replayed many times.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, Aug. 16 to 22, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Review: Sarasota Ballet, With Ashton as the Beating Heart of a Triple Bill
description: BECKET, Mass.  There is just one place I visit in America that seems a true dance-only haven: Jacobs Pillow. People dont come here to see theater or attend concerts, but hundreds drive every day to this secluded spot to attend performances of dance, dance, dance. Their interest in an extremely wide range of work makes the atmosphere one of singularly generous appreciation.

title: In China, Single Women Live by Their Own Rules
description: Single women past a certain age are called leftover women, though some are pushing back against such traditional Chinese strictures.

title: Review: In Sophie Hannahs Woman With a Secret, Mysteries Multiply
description: If anyone in Sophie Hannahs latest book deserves to die, its Damon Blundy, a repellent British tabloid columnist who cannot write a sentence without making an enemy. And while his murder is annoyingly nasty  he is bound and gagged, a knife taped across his mouth  an intriguing clue lingers on the wall behind him, daubed in lurid red paint resembling blood: HE IS NO LESS DEAD.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Comedy Listings for Aug. 14-20
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: In People Places Things, Jemaine Clement Navigates Life as a Newly Single Dad
description: The fleeting pleasures of People Places Things, Jim Strouses winsome trifle of a comedy, derive almost entirely from the charm of its star, Jemaine Clement, the New Zealand-born actor best known in America as one-half of the musical comedy duo Flight of the Conchords.

title: On Long Island, an Artists Collective Takes Shape
description: The common good may seem like an elusive political ideal  or a naive one. But for a group of eight young creatives on Long Island, banding together to form a collective to promote the arts has revitalized a small, sleepy surf town. Auto Body, as both the crew and its community space are known, formed last summer when sisters Georgia and Claire Read (whose father, Howard, founded the blue-chip gallery Cheim & Read) and their photographer friend Johnny Knapp pushed our way, as Claire puts it, into a vacant auto body shop (hence the name) in Bellport, N.Y. The space came first, in a way, she explains. We knew it had been vacant for years and years, and we wanted to exhibit art and design and hold events, create a space for everyone in the village, bring a creative energy to Main Street,because it was lacking before.

title: Movie Listings for Aug. 14-20
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Women Who Surf, New Yorkers Who Sand-Sculpt
description: This weekend, women who surf will step into the spotlight in Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Aug. 16 to 22, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Aug. 14-20
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Finding the Other, Cheaper Side of Bali
description: It was about five miles from the Kudesa Homestay guesthouse in Kemenuh village to the Gianyar Night Market, on the Indonesian island of Bali. So I asked my host, Mangku, whether I could make it on the bike he had available for rent. No problem, he said, he knew people who do it all the time.

title: Jazz Listings for Aug. 14-20
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Classical & Opera Listings for Aug. 14-20
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Samsung Unveils Two New Smartphones
description: Company executives discussed the addition of two Galaxy phones, the Note 5 and S6 Edge Plus.

title: Review: Meru Follows an Expedition Up Sharks Fin Peak in the Himalayas
description: To dedicated mountaineers, an unconquered  and believed unconquerable  peak is an irresistible, insistent taunt on their to-do lists. Meru is the story of one such peak, the notorious Sharks Fin atop Mount Meru in India and the pea beneath the mattress of the climber Conrad Anker.

title: Dance Listings for Aug. 14-20
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Pictures of the Day: China and Elsewhere
description: China and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Things to Do on Long Island, Aug. 16 to 22, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Aug. 14-20
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Aug. 13, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from China, Greece, India and Taiwan.

title: Spare Times for Aug. 14-20
description: Museums and Sites

title: Love for Jimmy Carter in Plains, Ga., Where He Stands Tall
description: PLAINS, Ga.  Here, just beyond the welcome signs with the presidential seal, people still call him Mr. Jimmy.

title: Review: Galactic, Paying Tribute to New Orleans and Its Sounds
description: For its encore at Brooklyn Bowl on Wednesday night, Galactic dug into Africa, a flag-waving funk classic recorded by the Meters just over 40 years ago. That song choice suggested a genuflection; an acknowledgment of influence, if not a pledge of allegiance.

title: Review: We Come as Friends Explores Potential Exploitation of South Sudan
description: In Darwins Nightmare (2005), a searing Oscar-nominated documentary about economic exploitation in Tanzania, the director Hubert Sauper found a perfect microcosm for colonialism in the invasive Nile perch. The fish was artificially introduced into Lake Victoria in the 1950s and 60s, ate all the other fish and then was exported as food for Europe and Japan. In the meantime, Tanzania suffered from a famine, and as the film repeatedly sought to demonstrate, the planes arriving to pick up the fish sometimes brought in weapons for use in the continents civil wars.

title: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 14-20
description: International Contemporary Circus Festival

title: NBC Extends Jimmy Fallons Tonight Show Contract Into 2021
description: LOS ANGELES  A few weeks before NBC faces a new challenge in late night, the network is doubling down on Jimmy Fallon as the host of the Tonight show.

title: Review: In Prince, a Restless Teenagers Risky Bid for Acceptance
description: For a boy of a certain age and income, the most potent instrument of seduction may well be a pair of ultramarine Zanotti shoes. They can carry him toward his dreams of joining the royal family of the streets, conquering the thugs who torment him and winning the heart of Laura (Sigrid ten Napel), the fairest of the girls at the Dutch housing project where he and his posse dwell.

title: Study Links Polluted Air in China to 1.6 Million Deaths a Year
description: BEIJING  Outdoor air pollution contributes to the deaths of an estimated 1.6 million people in China every year, or about 4,400 people a day, according to a newly released scientific paper.

title: Take a Ride on a SeaGlass Carousel
description: A carousel designed as an underwater garden teeming with fish is opening in Lower Manhattan.

title: New Yorks New Carousel Puts You in a Whirling School of Mechanized Fish
description: COME with me to the Battery, to the tip of Manhattan, where the sea meets the city, where the sea once was, where the sea may be again someday.

title: Christies to Sell Collection of Arthur and Anita Kahn Beginning This Fall
description: There was a Calder sculpture on a tabletop, a Calder on a bookcase, and a Calder mobile hung from the ceiling.

title: Even in the New Alphabet, Google Keeps Its Capital G
description: G is for Google, as the companys chief executive, Larry Page, put it this week in a blog post introducing Alphabet, Googles new corporate name.

title: Review: In The Great Man, Friendship and Politics in a War Zone
description: A pocket-size pleasure, the French movie The Great Man opens with a fairy-tale flourish as a child narrator winds up the once-upon-a-time. The movie then takes a break in a war zone, where a monster with glowing eyes briefly sends it into fantasy and a wounded soldier yanks it back to terra firma. Not long after, swells of emotion seep in like low-rolling fog and suddenly you are watching a drama about real people wrestling with life blow by blow.

title: Photos That Celebrate  and Challenge  Feminine Ideals
description: The photographer Delphine Diaw Diallos Highness series originated a few years ago as a collaboration with the hairstylist Joanne Petit Frere, who creates fantastical, sculptural styles with real hair. Frere asked Diallo, a graduate of the Academie Charpentier of Visual Arts in Paris, to photograph her work, and the two started working togetheron a series of increasingly revealing portraits. Diallo, who was born to a Senegalese father and a French mother in Paris, was attracted to the idea of women recreating themselves  and wanted to challenge traditional notions of femininity and eminence. What kind of queen can I create? she says. How can I redefine what highness means to a womans experience? To her, the true highnesses are warriors.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, Aug. 16 to 22, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Review: Robert Seydel: The Eye in Matter Looks at an Artists Traces
description: Robert Seydel is growing on me. This artist, who rarely exhibited during his lifetime, but worked as a curator and taught photography and film at Hampshire College in Amherst, Mass., died at 50 in 2011. He left behind an odd body of work  mostly notebooks, little collages and drawings  that are now on view in Robert Seydel: The Eye in Matter at the Queens Museum.

title: With $350 Billion Plan, Hillary Clinton Prods Rivals on Student Debt
description: When Hillary Rodham Clinton unveiled her plan this week to make higher education more affordable, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida promptly dismissed it as Obamacare for college. Jeb Bush, the former Florida governor, asserted that she would burden taxpayers by throwing more federal money at the problem.

title: Review: Bada Shanren, Chinese Art Superstar, Takes a Bow at the Freer
description: WASHINGTON  Beginning in January, the Freer Gallery of Art here will go dark for a year and a half while its 1923 building gets an overhaul. Some museums might take a shutdown as an opportunity to send its collection on the road, to generate institutional advertising and earn rental fees. But the Freer doesnt have that option.

title: Dan Flavins Icon Constructions on Display in Bridgehampton
description: Dan Flavins early works have come home again.

title: Review: In A Rare Earth Magnet at Derek Eller, a Focus on Repurposed Materials
description: A RARE EARTH MAGNET

title: Review: In The Architectural Impulse, Art Aspires
description: THE ARCHITECTURAL IMPULSE

title: For Fitz Henry Lane and Other 19th-Century Painters, Catalogues Raisonns Go Digital
description: New technology and fresh perspectives are jumpstarting efforts to assemble exhaustive lists of works by 19th-century American painters, sometimes in progress for decades. Next month a consortium of museums interested in the Massachusetts maritime painter Fitz Henry Lane (1804-65) will introduce a website, fitzhenrylaneonline.org, documenting about 320 paintings, drawings and prints at various institutions. Much of the material is being drawn from the Cape Ann Museum, in Mr. Lanes hometown, Gloucester, Mass., and images on the website will be linked to infrared paint analyses, biographies of Mr. Lanes clients, newspaper ads for his suppliers, maps of harbors where he sketched and portraits of owners of the ships moored there.

title: Mastodons Remembered at Staten Island Show
description: Mastodons, while tramping around what is now New York, shed teeth and tusks, and dinosaurs, wandering along riverfronts in Massachusetts, left footprints in mud that hardened into sandstone. Remnants of these prehistoric creatures and artifacts from the Americans who discovered them are heading to museum galleries in the region.

title: Review: The Writer Raymond Roussel and His Legacy, at Galerie Buchholz
description: RAYMOND ROUSSEL

title: Review: Cy Gavin Employs Unusual Canvas Ingredients in Overture
description: CY GAVIN

title: Review: Mistress America, a Noah Baumbach Comedy on Getting By in a Backbiting World
description: Noah Baumbachs Mistress America advertises itself as a screwball comedy. But this smart, fast-paced film is not really the zany, lighter-than-air divertissement that the term usually conjures. There are scattered sharp one-liners, but not enough to infuse the movie with a sustained bonhomie. Its fair to say that Mistress America revises and subverts this most buoyant of genres with a steady undertow of anxiety, dread and anger.

title: Review: In Tom at the Farm, Psychosexual Games Down at the Farm
description: Tom at the Farm, the fourth film from the 26-year-old French Canadian wunderkind Xavier Dolan, is a teasing exercise in unfettered narcissism that sticks its out tongue out and goes, Nyah, nyah, nyah as if it were a 5-year-old running wild on a sugar high. I should add that the movie, completed in 2013 and just now being released, is wildly entertaining, sexy and beautifully shot in the Canadian heartland.

title: One Year Later, Fringe Festival Shows Measure Their Success
description: A Fringe festival can be a real boon for theatergoers, offering the chance to binge on a variety of new plays, musicals and other performances. Best of all, in most cases you can gluttonously feed your theater addiction without spending a ton of money: Tickets for shows at the forthcoming New York International Fringe Festival, for example, are just $18.

title: 10 Shows to Watch for at This Years New York Fringe Festival
description: Will participants in the 2015 New York International Fringe Festival be glad they performed, once this years frenzy is over? First they need audiences. Using methods mostly instinctual, editors and writers for The New York Times put their heads together for a list of 10 shows theyre anticipating among the 200 productions. (Dates, times and sites are at fringenyc.org.)

title: Outsider Art Under One Roof at Katonah Museum of Art
description: In the almost 70 years since the term was first coined, outsider art  a somewhat dismissive designation for the work of self-taught artists  has been steadily finding its way inside the mainstream art world. These days, it is no longer unusual to see pieces by artists with no formal training displayed in even the most prestigious venues; just the past two years have seen such works included in exhibitions mounted by the Venice Biennale, the Museum of Modern Art, the Philadelphia Museum of Art and the Brooklyn Museum, among others.

title: Tiger Woods Blames His Putting After a Disappointing 75
description: HAVEN, Wis.  Tiger Woodss first-round score at the P.G.A. Championship on Thursday was a disappointing three-over-par 75. But in a measure of how far Woods has fallen, it was his second-best result in the opening round of a major championship this year.

title: Missing Historical Marker Resurrects Debate Over Photographers Birthplace
description: JOHNSBURG, N.Y.  Publicity surrounding the mysterious disappearance, last August, of a sign commemorating a famed Civil War photographer, Mathew B. Brady, has generated more than enough money for its replacement.

title: Theater Listings for Aug. 14-20
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: A Review of Misalliance at the Shakespeare Theater in Madison
description: The setting for Misalliance, which depicts an elegant conservatory in a baronial country house in England, may briefly mislead some theatergoers into expecting a genteel comedy. But its ever-devilish author, George Bernard Shaw, packs plenty of craziness into this 1909 play, now receiving a very smart revival by the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey in Madison.

title: Review of La Cage aux Folles at Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam
description: Just what makes the campy musical La Cage aux Folles work so well? (As it does, delightfully, in the production now deep into a run at the Goodspeed Opera House.) I was moved to ponder that question after overhearing a couple of intermission conversations, both of which used this phrase:

title: Goldman Expands Retail Banking by Taking On GE Capitals Deposits
description: Goldman Sachs is broadening its effort to offer banking services to people with a wider array of incomes than it has traditionally served.

title: Restaurant Review: Regulars Say R.S.V.P. Does Everything Wrong, Except for the Food
description: R.S.V.P., in West Cornwall, offers one of the most unusual dining experiences in the Northeast. So unusual, in fact, that some of the restaurants regular customers have accused it of doing everything wrong. Everything, that is, except for the food.

title: Restaurant Review: At Picnic on the Square in Ridgewood, Balancing Rich and Light
description: When Christine E. Nunn, the executive chef and co-owner of Picnic on the Square in Ridgewood, was 16 years old, her boyfriend made fun of her for burning a pot of Campbells soup and told her she didnt know how to cook.

title: Review: Lillys in White Plains Finds Room for Chandeliers and Sundaes
description: Mamaroneck Avenue in White Plains can be something of a scene, with restaurants competing for wandering singles with thumping music and standard pub fare. When I first entered Lillys, which opened in April, I feared I had found another example of the trend. Pop music was blasting and, despite the airy, attractive space, I braced myself for an uncomfortable meal with little conversation because no one could hear anyone speak.

title: A Reading of Later in the Garden by Sandra Lim
description: The poet reads her verse on Adam and Eve.

title: Review: A Classically Italian Menu at Restaurant Joanina in Huntington
description: Was this downtown Huntington or a town in Tuscany? I counted nine restaurants with outdoor seating within a one-block radius. One of the most appealing spots was Restaurant Joanina. While most of the competition had sidewalk seating in front of a noisy street, Joanina faced a parking lot (a slight improvement) and its tables were separated from that lot by planters overflowing with flowers.

title: Colorado: Water Near Mine at Pre-Spill Toxicity
description: The water just below a Colorado mine that poured three million gallons of toxic waste into nearby waterways has returned to pre-spill levels of toxicity, officials said Thursday. The Environmental Protection Agency is still analyzing water farther along the spills path  in New Mexico, the Navajo Nation and Utah. Officials in Utah said waste from the mine had probably reached Lake Powell, a major water storage facility for the region. E.P.A. officials have said they will have to monitor the spills path for years to understand its full effect. The Gold King Mine, near Silverton, burst on Aug. 5 while workers contracted by the E.P.A. were conducting a field investigation of the mine, which had leaked for years. The agency has said it was responsible for the spill. Levels of metals including arsenic and lead jumped in local waterways as the contamination flowed down the Animas River and into the San Juan, angering many who use these rivers for drinking, irrigation and recreational activities. Colorado, New Mexico, Utah and the Navajo Nation declared states of emergency. The rivers remained closed Thursday.

title: Bangladeshi Women, Isolated in New York City, Need More Support, Advocates Say
description: A 3-week-old baby ended up dead in the courtyard of an apartment building in Queens. The police arrested the mother, Rashida Chowdhury, a 21-year-old Bangladeshi immigrant, on charges of second-degree murder. They said she confessed to throwing the baby out the bathroom window of her fourth-floor apartment because she thought the child was possessed by an evil spirit.

title: Former Editor of Time Inc. to Lead Yahoo Magazines
description: Martha Nelson, a former editor in chief of Time Inc., will join Yahoo as its global editor in chief, the company said Thursday, overseeing its portfolio of digital magazines. Ms. Nelson, the founding editor of InStyle and a former editor of People magazine, had taken the top editorial job at Time Inc. in 2013. But she left later that year in a shake-up that eliminated her position and had editors of the companys 21 magazines reporting to the business side. She will be based in New York when she starts her new job next week, Yahoo said, and will focus on developing Yahoos 13 domestic digital magazines and 30 international magazines.

title: Tom Brady Unexpectedly Starts for Patriots
description: A day after the N.F.L. and Tom Brady faced off in federal court over his suspension for his role in the deflation of footballs used in last seasons A.F.C. championship game, he started in the New England Patriots preseason opener Thursday against the Green Bay Packers.

title: New York Council Passes Bill Aimed at Limiting Future Legionnaires Outbreaks
description: With New York Citys largest ever outbreak of Legionnaires disease apparently waning, the City Council passed a bill on Thursday intended to thwart future spread of the illness.

title: Biff Liff, Broadway Manager and Powerhouse Agent, Dies at 96
description: When My Fair Lady opened on Broadway in 1956, there was Alan Jay Lerners book, and there was Biff Liffs book. Mr. Liffs book, the log he kept as the production stage manager, swelled to several volumes over the shows long run, and the entries were not just about each performance.

title: Washington State Faces $100,000-a-Day Fine Until Schools Plan Is Reached
description: SEATTLE  Washington States highest court, which has threatened, cajoled and pleaded with the state Legislature and governor for years to close the gap in spending between rich and poor schools, said on Thursday that it had finally lost its patience. In a unanimous decision, the nine-member Supreme Court imposed a fine of $100,000 a day on the state until a plan to reduce the gap was accepted, and in a written order encouraged Gov. Jay Inslee to call the Legislature into a special session.

title: Freddie Mac Yields
description: Average for some Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. securities.

title: In Good Times or Bad, Brazil Banks Profit
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Political parties whose symbol is a red star tend to be unfavorable for bankers, but Brazils ruling party has been a lucrative exception.

title: In Latin America, Quiet Diplomacy Bears Fruit
description: Nearly seven years ago, President Evo Morales of Bolivia expelled the American ambassador, denouncing him for conspiring against democracy and seeking the division of Bolivia. Months later, Mr. Moraless government kicked the Drug Enforcement Administration out of La Paz, in a rebuke of Washingtons approach to counternarcotics in the region. In 2013, Bolivia ejected the American governments international aid agency, which Mr. Morales accused of working secretly to destabilize his government.

title: U.S. and Turkey Face Questions in Anti-ISIS Effort
description: GAZIANTEP, Turkey  The United States and Turkey have taken preliminary steps to carry out a plan to push the extremists of the Islamic State from the last strip of Syrian territory along the Turkish border controlled by the jihadist group.

title: Joe Biden Wades Further Into 2016 Bid
description: WASHINGTON  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is vacationing on Kiawah Island off South Carolinas coast, riding bikes and walking the beaches with his family. But on Wednesday night, he called one of his most outspoken political supporters and wrestled with the question looming over his future: Should he run for president?

title: Breakdown at BP Refinery Strains Midwest Gas Prices
description: A breakdown at a BP refinery outside Chicago is sending jolts across the energy markets of the Midwest and Canada, pushing up gasoline prices even as oil prices over all reached a six-year low.

title: The End of Prison Days, the Start of Something New
description: Rudolph Norris, 58, is out of prison and trying to piece together a new life after his sentence for drug offenses was commuted by President Obama.

title: They Look to the Sky
description: People gathered in Inwood Hill Park in Upper Manhattan on Wednesday for an unobstructed view of the Perseid meteor shower, an annual occurrence during which burning specks of cosmic dust race zoom through the heavens at 36 miles per second. The meteor activity is expected to drop sharply after this weekend.

title: Stores Suffer From a Shift of Behavior in Buyers
description: As Americans spend more money on doing things, not buying things, department stores are losing out.

title: The Yen, Won and Renminbi: A Triangular Guide to the East Asian Currency Wars
description: These charts show the relative currency strength of East Asias three largest economies over the last 15 years.

title: A Secretive Path to Raising U.S. Flag in Cuba
description: WASHINGTON  Before the United States and Cuba could seal a historic diplomatic rapprochement brokered in 18 months of secret talks, they first had to hide a pregnancy.

title: Marco Rubio Frustrates Those Taking a Zero-Abortion Stand
description: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida surprised some Democrats and moderate Republicans last week when he said during the Republican presidential debate that he opposed abortion even in cases where rape or incest were involved: He had previously backed legislation allowing those exceptions. Though many abortion opponents applauded the bill, some groups were frustrated with Mr. Rubio for what they saw as compromised values.

title: Rory McIlroy Returns, and Is Tested Immediately
description: HAVEN, Wis.  The next great rivalry in golf broke slowly out of the gates Thursday, which just shows the folly of treating golfers as if they are heavyweight boxers or world champion sprinters. Rory McIlroy and Jordan Spieth may have shared a tee time in the first round of the 97th P.G.A. Championship, but they were not each others main adversary.

title: Storys Opening
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  The Jewish Association Serving the Aging, or J.A.S.A. as its popularly known, provides services for people age 55 and up in new York City, and one of the classes taught there is the fine art of crossword puzzle construction. The class has been taught by a variety of familiar constructor names, including Ian Livengood, Finn Vigeland and now Natan Last and, if the puzzle passes muster, it is published in The New York Times. If you live in New York City and would like to join the constructing class, the Fall 2015 catalog can be downloaded here.

title: Before Texas Killing, Officer Took Unusual Path to Police Work
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Officer James Bradley Miller was not a typical rookie in the Police Department here. At 49, he was six years older than the chief. He discovered law enforcement relatively late in life, after struggling for decades in an array of jobs and careers.

title: Egypt: 2 Groups Handled Hostage, Croatia Says
description: A Croatian expatriate worker believed to have been beheaded by the Islamic States Egyptian affiliate was initially abducted by a different group that demanded a ransom, Croatias foreign minister said Thursday. The worker, Tomislav Salopek, 30, was kidnapped on July 22 on the outskirts of Cairo, and on Wednesday, the affiliate, Sinai Province, released a picture of what it claimed was Mr. Salopeks body. Foreign Minister Vesna Pusic said it was very likely that two separate organizations were involved in Mr. Salopeks abduction, one which kidnapped and the other which presented itself as ISIS, Sinai Province. Sinai Province released a video of Mr. Salopek on Aug. 5, in which he conveyed the militants threat to kill him if Muslim women were not released from Egyptian jails. Ms. Pusic said that Egypt and Croatia had not yet been able to confirm Mr. Salopeks death.

title: Smelly Visit to New Yorks Sewer System Ends With 3 Men Under Arrest
description: The sewer system of New York  the more than 7,500 miles of it  exists to move the slush left behind in a city of millions. Still, for a branch of infrastructure, it has done a remarkable job of inspiring the publics imagination into believing it is so much more.

title: Man Killed in a Shooting in Brooklyn
description: One man was killed and two more were injured in a shooting in Brooklyn on Thursday night, the police said.

title: Ryan Fitzpatricks First Start for Jets Is Brief, but Hes Happy
description: DETROIT  The Jets did something normal on Thursday: They played a football game without incident or swirling drama. Alas, they opened the preseason in underwhelming fashion, losing by 23-3 to the Lions at Ford Field.

title: Obama Is Set to Discuss Rights Issues With China
description: WASHINGTON  A top State Department official said Thursday that there was a growing sense of alarm in the United States about human rights developments in China, vowing that the issue would feature prominently in summit talks between President Xi Jinping of China and President Obama in Washington next month.

title: New York Schools With Many Opting Out of Tests May Be Penalized
description: A drastic increase this year in the number of students sitting out New Yorks standardized exams has created another kind of test, one for state and federal education officials who must decide whether to punish school districts with low participation rates.

title: Fresh Face Arrives, and Yankees Bats Awake From a Slumber
description: CLEVELAND  In the movie Major League, the first baseman for the Cleveland Indians, a character named Pedro Cerrano, makes offerings to Jobu, his voodoo totem, to drive the fear out of his bats. A cup of rum is the preferred sacrament, though sacrificing a chicken is also a consideration.

title: The Illustrated Interview: Greta Gerwig
description: In this series for T, notables from the worlds of fashion, art, design and entertainment sketch their responses to a brief questionnaire.

title: Imagining Life After Eden
description: For Ts ongoing series, the poet Sandra Lim and the artist Lionel Estve consider life for Adam and Eve after the fall, as a banal reality begins to crystallize.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Michael Stipe
description: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next installment in the series comes from Michael Stipe, the artist and former frontman of the band R.E.M., who shares his picks exclusively with T.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | bombastic
description: bombastic  \bm-bas-tik\  adjective

title: Indonesia Frees 2 Educators After Court Overturns Sex Abuse Convictions
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Two educators at a prestigious international school in Indonesia were freed from prison on Friday after an appeals court overturned their convictions and 10-year prison sentences on charges of sexually assaulting kindergartners, in a case that the school said was fabricated and that led to international concern about the competence of the countrys judicial system.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 9:15 A.M. (Cinemax) SWEENEY TODD: THE DEMON BARBER OF FLEET STREET (2007) Johnny Depp, his skin pale and his eyes odd, stars as the vengeful barber (and earned a best actor Oscar nomination) in Tim Burtons film of the Stephen Sondheim-Hugh Wheeler musical. Helena Bonham Carter is Mrs. Lovett, the pie maker who disposes of Sweeneys victims. And Alan Rickman is the malevolent judge who had Sweeney transported to Australia, stole his wife (Laura Michelle Kelly) and now has guardianship of his teenage daughter. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film as dark and terrifying as any motion picture in recent memory, not excluding the bloody installments in the Saw franchise, adding, It is also something close to a masterpiece, a work of extreme  I am tempted to say evil  genius. In Charlie and the Chocolate Factory (2005), Mr. Burtons sugar-rush adaptation of the Roald Dahl book, at 8 p.m. on ABC Family, Mr. Depp portrays an oddly sinister candy maker, and Freddie Highmore is a boy who wants nothing more than to swim in chocolate. Well, who wouldnt? Despite burdening Willy Wonka with a psychological back story, there is simply too much pleasure to be found in Wonkas world to get too hung up about his relationship with his dad, A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. The real lesson of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is  or should be  that pleasure and curiosity are their own rewards.

title: Quotation of the Day: August 14, 2015
description: He said that raping me is his prayer to God. I said to him, What youre doing to me is wrong, and it will not bring you closer to God.

title: Corrections: August 14, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Chinas Currency Stabilizes After 3-Day Slide
description: HONG KONG  Chinas currency stabilized on Friday, ending a three-day plunge that shook markets globally during the renminbis steepest devaluation in decades.

title: In China, Single Women Live by Their Own Rules
description: Read this article in Chinese |

title: Student Crossword | Tales of Mystery and Suspense
description: Test your knowledge of tales of mystery and suspense by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: The Iran Nuclear Deal: Defeat or Diplomacy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Trumps Economic Muddle
description: DONALD TRUMPS economic views may not have garnered as much attention as his misogynistic statements, but they are equally unpalatable, evincing a lack of understanding of basic economics that is startling for a billionaire businessman.

title: Coke Tries to Sugarcoat the Truth on Calories
description: The Coca-Cola Company, which has suffered a large decline in consumption of sugary sodas as consumers worry about obesity, has formed a new organization to emphasize exercise as the best way to control obesity and to play down the importance of cutting calories.

title: A Multiple-Choice Question: Which Answer Is Correct?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bungling Beijings Stock Markets
description: China is ruled by a party that calls itself Communist, but its economic reality is one of rapacious crony capitalism. And everyone has been assuming that the nations leaders are in on the joke, that they know better than to take their occasional socialist rhetoric seriously.

title: Liberals, Conservatives and Jon Stewart
description: To the Editor:

title: This Weeks Movies | August 14, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Straight Outta Compton, Mistress America and The Man From U.N.C.L.E.

title: Zen and the Art of Dying Well
description: What is the right way to die? Were experiencing a zeitgeist moment about that. Being Mortal: Medicine and What Matters in the End, by Atul Gawande, is a best-selling book. Videos by Brittany Maynard, a 29-year-old who wanted to die in a way of her own choosing, went viral last year. And in more than 20 countries, thousands of people have dined and discussed dying through a project called Death Over Dinner.

title: As Greek Bailout Deal Passes, Alexis Tsipras Faces Rebellion
description: ATHENS  The Greek Parliament and eurozone ministers approved an international loan deal on Friday that the Greek government needs to avoid defaulting on a debt payment next week. But an all-night debate required in Greece, and a growing rebellion within Prime Minister Alexis Tsiprass leftist Syriza party, seemed to have pushed his coalition closer to spinning apart.

title: Summer in the City: Some Like It Loud
description: Every Sunday morning at 10:30, Ingrid Erickson comes to rapt attention as the choir at Macedonia Baptist Church in Hamilton Heights launches into full-throated renditions of Glory to His Name, Lift Him Up and Hold to Gods Unchanging Hand.

title: Kerry Strikes Delicate Balance in Havana Trip for Embassy Flag-Raising
description: HAVANA  John Kerry, the first secretary of state to visit Cuba in 70 years, said on Friday that the Cuban government could not expect the United States to lift its trade embargo unless it moved to improve its record on human rights.

title: With a Letter From the President, a New Day for Rudolph Norris
description: Mr. Norris, who was granted clemency by President Obama along with several other prisoners, has the potential to turn his life around. He responded to the president with gratitude and a promise, writing that it feels as if the chains that I have been wearing for a long time have suddenly been released.

title: With Clemency From Obama, Drug Offender Embraces Second Chance
description: MORGANTOWN, W.Va.  Rudolph Norris walked out of Morgantown federal prison two weeks ago carrying a duffel bag like no other. First, he had spent six months hand-stitching it himself from dozens of mottled leather scraps, symbolizing the shards of his life he longed to piece back together. Then he unzipped it and pulled out his invitation to try.

title: Decades After Pearl Harbor, a Mission to Honor the Unknowns Gains Urgency
description: HONOLULU  As the sun broke from behind the billowy clouds hanging over Oahus Koolau mountains, a seven-member detail of military personnel transferred five coffins one recent morning, disinterred from two grave sites marked unknown, at the Punchbowl, the National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific here in the shallow crater of an extinct volcano.

title: Nick Symmonds, a Sidelined Track Star, Continues to Break From the Pack
description: SEATTLE  Nick Symmonds sat at a desk in his modest apartment, equipped with a laptop, a printer, a scanner, a cellphone and caffeine-infused gum. If he could not run at the world track and field championships, at least he could talk nonstop about why he was not running.

title: A New Style for a New Havana
description: The dandies of the Cuban capital embrace a reggaeton-inspired look.

title: Forget Retro. The Men of Havana Embrace the Reggaeton Look.
description: HAVANA  On a recent evening, tourists in banded hats and guayabera shirts climbed out of pink 1950s-era American cars to puff cigars, drink mojitos and listen to Buena Vista Social Club classics at the Hotel Nacional. It was one of those frozen-in-time Havana scenes that Americans, enticed by their flag once again flying over the U.S. embassy and the promised easing of a 50-year embargo, cant wait to witness.

title: News Qs | A Museum Exhibit on Cats and the Internet
description: Note: Weve updated 6 Qs About the News for the new school year. Let us know what you think.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Aug. 14
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of summer love, the Dominican Day Parade and meteor watchers.

title: Donald Trump, Moderate Republican
description: Donald Trump may be the post-policy candidate, but when you strip away the bluster and the outrageous commentary that have defined his campaign to find his occasional, substantive statements about public policy, a surprising fact emerges: Mr. Trump is a moderate Republican.

title: Fridays Travel News: An Eco-Trip in Borneo and Other Tours
description: Our weekday morning digest that includes information about outdoor activities and events, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: A Grief So Deep It Wont Die
description: She had taken care of her husband for the last eight years of his life, through his blindness, through cancer and heart failure. After he died in 2002, she sold the Long Island house theyd loved and shared, finding it too filled with memories, and moved to their country home in upstate New York.

title: New York Today: A Starry Show
description: Good morning on this warmer Friday.

title: Eurozone Finance Ministers Approve Greek Bailout
description: BRUSSELS  Eurozone finance ministers on Friday backed a Greek bailout plan approved earlier in the day by lawmakers in Athens, overcoming months of bitterness.

title: Statement by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan
description: On the 70th anniversary of the end of the war, we must calmly reflect upon the road to war, the path we have taken since it ended, and the era of the 20th century. We must learn from the lessons of history the wisdom for our future.

title: Today in Politics: Democrats Gather for Chicken Wings in Shadow of Iowa State Fair
description: Good Friday morning, as the United States reopens its embassy in Cuba and Senator Marco Rubio of Florida travels to New York to condemn the move. But most of the campaigns are in Iowa, where the State Fair offers soapboxes to speak from, and where the Democrats will gather to chow down as they press the flesh.

title: The 8.2.15 Issue
How to Brush a Gorillas Teeth
description: Even 400-pound silverbacks will fear a toothbrush. You have to desensitize them, says Jodi Carrigan, the lead keeper of primates at Zoo Atlanta, which is home to the largest collection of gorillas in North America. At first, place the toothbrush at a safe distance, somewhere out of reach but visible. Every day, inch it closer until you can hold the brush in your hand while you teach the gorilla to open its mouth. To do this, reward it with grapes, slices of apple, popcorn or juice (Crystal Light is an ape favorite). The first time an animal completes the desired behavior, jackpot it, offering 10 grapes instead of one. Then theyre like, Oh, whatever I just did I should do it again, Carrigan says.

title: More Than Once
description: So much depends on the precision of language. In this seemingly plain-spoken poem, tears suggests not only a literal image but also an abstract one. In that trick the eye plays on the mind, I see at once the rips in the fence and a glimpse at the emotion such a crossing  a little dangerous  can engender.

title: The Island of Decades Before
description: Our first family vacation in 33 years began with a suicide.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Uzbek
description: Four years ago, the federal government paid me a large sum  a year of graduate-school tuition, plus a stipend  to study Uzbek at the University of Chicago. Uzbek is among the least commonly taught of the so-called Less Commonly Taught Languages, or L.C.T.L.s. So uncommonly is it taught, in fact, that without federal largess it would hardly be taught at all. Because I happened to speak decent Turkish, a cousin of Uzbek, and because I spent a week in Uzbekistan when I was 22, and because life is nothing if not a sequence of odd choices vaguely considered, for two years I sat in a room with two other students and produced some extremely literal translations.

title: Why Did He Feel Like a Knife Was Stabbing His Head?
description: A patient worries about his painful earaches and asymmetrical pupils.

title: Ramiro Gomezs Domestic Disturbances
description: Ifirst noticed the work of the young Los Angeles artist Ramiro Gomez across a series of recent art fairs, on account of those Hockneys of his: that is, paintings that were dead ringers for Hockneys  same scale, same colors, same composition  except that something was always just slightly off. Take Gomezs large-scale version of Hockneys iconic American Collectors double portrait, for example, which Gomezs Los Angeles dealer, Charlie James, exhibited at the most recent Expo Chicago. It looks almost exactly like the original portrait of the couple in question, clenched in a grim rictus amid the sculptures in their backyard garden, except that Gomez replaced the two collector protagonists with a pair of dark-skinned gardeners of the sort who regularly do the actual tending of such gardens. Into another Hockney, of one of those nondescript West Los Angeles apartment buildings with its wide front lawn, Gomez slotted a groundskeeper, rake extended. That was the genius of the whole series: how in much the same way that, back in the 60s, the English transplant Hockney first opened our eyes to so much that we had previously overlooked in Los Angeles, rendering all sorts of things visible to us as if for the first time (those boxy apartment buildings, the distinctive street signs, the moderne furniture, that light), so Gomez seemed to be allowing us, indeed forcing us, to notice the very groundskeepers and housemaids and pool cleaners who make that look, the look of Los Angeles, possible, rendering visible a whole world of people, our fellow humans, who often go unseen (and who, for that matter, because they are sometimes illegal, often strive not to be seen).

title: Taliban Present Gentler Face but Wield Iron Fist in Afghan District
