description: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan  As they have captured more territory in Afghanistan this year, the Taliban have twinned their military offensive with a publicity push. Their pitch goes something like this: Weve learned the lessons from our time in power, and were ready to moderate a bit.

title: Morning Agenda: A New Global Currency War
description: A NEW GLOBAL CURRENCY WAR | China held firm on the value of its money for years, as other countries tried to secure an economic advantage by letting the value of their currencies slide on international markets. Some analysts see its jump into the fray as a new phase in a long-raging global currency war, Peter Eavis writes in DealBook. The plunge paused on Friday, but the renminbi was still down 4.4 percent against the dollar this week, a huge drop for China and the steepest drop since the countrys modern exchange system was set up, Neil Gough reports in The New York Times. The move could leave the United States exposed and undermine efforts to pull the world economy out of the doldrums.

title: Searching for Missing After China Blast
description: Friends and relatives hoped to find their loved ones in a local hospital after a warehouse blast killed at least 50 in Tianjin.

title: Death Toll in Chinese Fire Rises, Along With Anger at Apparent Safety Lapses
description: BEIJING  The high-rise apartment complex closest to Tianjins toxic chemical storage inferno was only 2,000 feet away, despite Chinese laws requiring a 3,200-foot minimum distance from hazardous sites.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 10 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: Our Summer Reading Contest is in its final week, and were sad to see it go.

title: Daylight Killing Brings Beijing District of Sanlitun Under Scrutiny
description: The killing of a young Chinese woman and the wounding of her French husband by a man with a sword in Beijing on Thursday refocused the countrys attention on one of the Chinese capitals most famous districts, an increasingly upscale place known for shopping, eating and drinking, but sometimes tinged with an edge of crime and violence.

title: North Korea Denies It Laid Mines That Maimed Soldiers From South
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea denied on Friday planting land mines that maimed two South Korean soldiers near their guard post last week.

title: Israel Treats Palestinian Prisoner on Hunger Strike After Health Deteriorates
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  A Palestinian prisoner on a hunger strike for 60 days was placed on an artificial respirator and given fluids intravenously on Friday after his lungs stopped working and he had seizures.

title: Well Be Back, They Vowed, and They Are
description: COWES, England  In hindsight, Jerry Kirby and the other members of Rambler 100s crew were not sailing in a maxi yacht destined to win races and shatter offshore records.

title: Tom Harkin Endorses Hillary Clinton as She Appears in Iowa
description: Former Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa gave Hillary Rodham Clinton a big endorsement Friday, writing an opinion piece in The Des Moines Register saying that she will keep fighting to provide opportunities for Iowans.

title: 2 Arrested in Killing of Secular Blogger in Bangladesh
description: NEW DELHI  Two men suspected of belonging to the extremist Islamic group Ansarullah Bangla Team have been arrested in Bangladesh in connection with the murder of a secular blogger this month, the police said on Friday.

title: What Eating 40 Teaspoons of Sugar a Day Can Do to You
description: Soda has been a major target in the debate over sugar and its role in the obesity crisis. But high levels of added sugars can be found in many seemingly healthful foods, from yogurts to energy bars and even whole-grain bread.

title: A Conversation With Glenn Lurie, Chief of AT&T Mobility
description: Even as AT&T has been busy expanding its wireless empire into other markets, like cars and home security, it remains at its heart a phone carrier. The company said Friday that it made some minor revisions to some of its most popular phone plans, offering more mobile data per buck.

title: Shinzo Abe Echoes Japans Past World War II Apologies but Adds None
description: TOKYO  Using the carefully chosen words that govern reckonings with Japans militarist past, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe reiterated his countrys official remorse for the catastrophe of World War II on Friday, the eve of the 70th anniversary of the wars end.

title: Eurozones Economic Growth Falls Short, Even as Greeks Shopped
description: FRANKFURT  Eurozone economic growth disappointed on Friday, but dont blame Greece.

title: Movie Review: Straight Outta Compton
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Straight Outta Compton.

title: Movie Review: The Man From U.N.C.L.E.
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews The man from U.N.C.L.E.

title: Its a Book, O.K.?
description: Dear Diary:

title: Movie Review: Mistress America
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Mistress America.

title: Russia Denies Reports of Iranian Generals Visit to Moscow
description: MOSCOW  Russia has rejected statements by the United States that a senior Iranian general subject to a United Nations travel ban visited Moscow in late July, a senior Foreign Ministry official told reporters on Friday.

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Singapore

title: On Location | Croton-on-Hudson
description: Deborah Hayn and Phil Grunes left Queens 16 years ago for a bucolic life in Croton-on-Hudson.

title: A Magical Farmhouse in Croton-on-Hudson
description: The story of Deborah Hayn and Phil Grunes is one of a great love affair. With each other, to be sure. But more important, with a house.

title: Jeb Bush Says He Wont Rule Out Waterboarding in Interrogations
description: ANKENY, Iowa  Jeb Bush said on Thursday that, as president, he would not rule out waterboarding in interrogations, another instance of how his plans to fight Islamic terrorism have drawn comparisons to his brothers administration.

title: Bernie Sanders, an Outlier? The Senator Begs to Differ
description: WASHINGTON  One recent afternoon, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont gave another of the populist speeches that have drawn the largest crowds of the 2016 campaign to his rallies around the country and have made him the unexpected rival to Hillary Rodham Clinton for the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: Man Who Shot Firefighter in Staten Island Standoff Has Died
description: The fugitive, barricaded in his basement apartment, had shot a firefighter  the first time a New York City firefighter had been hit with gunfire in the line of duty in more than 20 years. The man had then kept negotiators on the phone for hours, and in three instances, he had fired his gun.

title: Readers Turn: SoulCycles Mysterious Allure
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Daily Report: Google Stays in the News with Chromebooks and Antitrust Issues
description: Someone at Google did not get the memo about August being a sleepy month.

title: Carly Fiorina Says Parents Should Choose on Child Vaccinations
description: Carly Fiorina waded into the politics of vaccinations on Thursday, explaining to a group in Iowa that she believes parents should have the option not to vaccinate their children.

title: Politics and Pork at the Iowa State Fair
description: For decades, presidential candidates have gone through the ritual of visiting the Iowa State Fair to mingle with potential caucus voters.

title: Where to Find Symbols on Tablets
Stuff We Liked: Women and Movies, and Interactive History
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: 1915: Roumania Readies for Attack
description: Events are moving in the Balkans and there are indications that the attitude of Roumania will not remain in doubt much longer. According to the Bucarest correspondent of the Secolo, the intervention of Roumania on the side of the Entente Powers is certain.

title: Shinzo Abes Remarks on War Anniversary
description: The Japanese prime minister delivered a statement on the 70th anniversary of the announcement of the countrys surrender in World War II, expressing profound grief at the loss of life.

title: Ameer Abdullah Draws Praise in His Detroit Lions Debut
description: The first full slate of preseason games brought a surprise appearance from the recent litigant Tom Brady and a touchdown for Johnny Manziel. But the name that created the most excitement seemed to be Ameer Abdullah of the Detroit Lions.

title: Elaine Wynn Eyes the Bigger Picture in Los Angeles
description: At the Los Angeles County Museum of Art on an unusually humid day last month, the museums director, Michael Govan, was consulting the new co-chairwoman of his board of trustees about another sticky situation  of the public relations variety.

title: Effective Altruism: Where Charity and Rationality Meet
description: You are lucky enough to have some money to give away: It could be $100 or $1 million. Whether you are prepared to make a small donation or a big one, you would like to accomplish something good with it.

title: Singapores History Put to Song
description: SINGAPORE  When two Singaporean businessmen began pitching the idea for a contemporary opera about Singapores founding father to local theater companies about three years ago, they met with no shortage of skepticism.

title: Doubt Starts Chipping Away at the Markets Mind-Set
description: In the stock market, until recently, just about any news was good news.

title: Seeking Privacy for Prince George, Royal Family Asks Photographers to Keep Their Distance
description: In a letter issued from Kensington Palace on Friday, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge expressed concern that members of the news media were going to increasing extremes to photograph their 2-year-old son, Prince George.

title: Florida Legislators Deny Gerrymandering as They Slouch Back to the Drawing Board
description: In 2010, 63 percent of Florida voters approved a Fair Districts amendment to the state constitution designed to end the partisan dirty pool that is as old as Congress itself  the gerrymandering of congressional boundaries to favor one party over the other. Patrick Henry tried it first in Virginia in 1788, having lines drawn to block James Madison from a congressional seat, but Madison prevailed before the voters.

title: 1940: France Gets a 2nd Guillotine
description: VICHY  The partition of France into two zones, occupied and unoccupied, has had the unfortunate consequence of depriving the French government of the services of the official executioner, known as Monsieur Paris, who is in Paris. So the civil authorities have had to call on Monsieur Algeria, who in civilian life goes by the name of Henri Roch, to behead criminals guilty of capital offenses. Monsieur Algeria has arrived in Nimes from North Africa with three assistants and a guillotine. There he will discharge the duties of his gruesome office until the French government is permitted by the Germans to return to Paris.  New York Herald Tribune, August 15, 1940

title: British Trader Charged in Flash Crash Released After Bail Reduction
description: LONDON  Navinder Singh Sarao, the British futures trader charged by United States authorities with contributing to a sudden plunge in American stock markets five years ago, was assigned a reduced bail at a court hearing on Friday, allowing him to be released from custody.

title: Video Reviews of Straight Outta Compton, Mistress America and The Man From U.N.C.L.E.
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Straight Outta Compton, Mistress America and The Man From U.N.C.L.E. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: An Ode to Diving Boards
description: Remember the summertime thrill of leaping off a diving board? Since the 1970s it has gotten harder to find in New York, as diving boards have steadily disappeared from the citys pools.

title: Readers Share Back-to-School Tips for Incoming Freshmen
description: Freshman year can be a challenge. Between choosing the right classes, meeting new people and navigating tricky roommate relationships, theres plenty of room for error.

title: First Draft Focus: Its Heigh-Ho, Come to the (Iowa) Fair!
description: Every presidential election cycle, candidates face a big test at the Iowa State Fair: Can they fit in with the locals at the ultimate down-home event in the state with the first nominating contest? Knowing what to eat is part of the challenge: corn dogs, fried butter, and apple pie on a stick are just some of the cholesterol-filled favorites.

title: Eileen, by Ottessa Moshfegh
description: I looked like a girl youd expect to see on a city bus, begins Eileen, Ottessa Moshfeghs seductive novel, reading some clothbound book from the library about plants or geography, perhaps wearing a net over my light brown hair. This is the eponymous Eileen, and we quickly learn that any assumptions we might make about her from her appearance would be dead wrong. I didnt really read books about flowers or home economics, she tells us a few pages later. I liked books about awful things  murder, illness, death.

title: Why We Need Fetal Tissue Research
description: Hidden-camera videos showing Planned Parenthood staffers discussing fetal tissue donations have led not just to efforts to defund the organization, but to calls for an end to the use of fetal tissue in research. In an article in The New England Journal of Medicine, the law and bioethics professor R. Alta Charo explains why these calls are misguided.

title: The 19th Century in Fiction
description: A SLANT OF LIGHTBy Jeffrey Lent357 pp. Bloomsbury, $27.

title: Make Your Home Among Strangers, by Jennine Cap Crucet
description: Elin Gonzlez, the 6-year-old boy at the heated center of the international custody battle that tore apart Miami and the Cuban-American community in 2000, has resurfaced in the news. Fifteen years after the predawn raid by American agents that led to his return to his father in Cuba, he has announced that he would like to visit the United States again. With the thaw in relations between the two countries, the times are vastly different. But as we are expansively reminded in Make Your Home Among Strangers, Jennine Cap Crucets heartfelt first novel about a Cuban-American family entangled in a fictionalized account of the Gonzlez affair, no amount of change erases the past. With history onboard, Crucet shows us how journeys between cultures are almost impossible to navigate and family relationships are bound to dump us in choppy waters.

title: The Popes Daughter, by Dario Fo
description: Last year, at the venerable age of 88, the Italian comic Dario Fo took on a new creative challenge. The veteran of more than 60 years as an actor, painter, director, stage designer and playwright (as well as the recipient of the 1997 Nobel Prize in Literature), he had in recent years begun to deliver delightful public lectures on artists  Giotto, Leonardo, Raphael, Caravaggio, Picasso  and architecture, including the Romanesque cathedral of Modena. But up to 2014, he had never written a novel. That changed with The Popes Daughter, now translated into English, although needless to say for this wild man of the theater, the word novel is not quite enough to encompass his lightly fictional labor of love for, of all people, Lucrezia Borgia. The Popes Daughter is also a picture book, illustrated with some of Fos own colorful paintings, most based on Renaissance originals. It has since become a full-blown theatrical script. (Meanwhile, Fo has finished a second illustrated novel, inspired by an 18th-century Danish prince, Christian VII.)

title: The Marriage of Opposites, by Alice Hoffman
description: For a period of her young life, Virginia Woolf wrote while standing at an elevated desk poised near her sister Vanessas easel. The writing tables curious height enabled Virginia to peer at the world from the same viewpoint as her artist sister, to witness all at once the world itself, the world transcribed in ink and the world brushed onto a canvas. Later, when Woolf created the character of the painter Lily Briscoe in To the Lighthouse, she knew the mix of delicacy and passion that collide to create a great work, and she was schooled in the fine craft of transforming daubs of paint into strings of words.

title: Mystery of Baby Doe Troubles Massachusetts Investigators
description: For nearly eight weeks, investigators in Massachusetts have been struggling to solve a mystery: the identity of a little girl whose remains were found on a Boston Harbor shoreline.

title: Brief Loves That Live Forever and A Woman Loved, by Andrei Makine
description: As a child growing up in a Soviet orphanage, the narrator of Andrei Makines memoiristic novel Brief Loves That Live Forever recalls being completely in thrall to the idea of a dazzlingly white city where everything would be abundant and free, and people would help themselves only to as much as they needed. The harsh realities of daily life under Communism being what they are, disillusionment sets in quickly. Even so, the novels dreamy and impressionistic linked episodes, which take the narrator from his boyhood under Brezhnev to his adulthood, offer up this essential truth: Fleeting moments of beauty and love are to be treasured above all else. Carved out of even the most dreary and oppressive circumstances, theyre the sum of a life, a means of triumphing over brutality, a more powerful form of resistance than dissident whisperings.

title: Jeff Bartschs Two Across
description: Right before college-age Vera Baxter disappears from Stanley Owenss life for the second time, she wakes up in the middle of the night, wondering whether she should leave him. Maybe, she thinks, it was better to make important decisions in the misty neverland of a tired mind, when she might be closer to her real desires, than using all the well-rested but suspect might of logic. Its one of many moments in Jeff Bartschs new novel, Two Across, where were reminded that brainpower can be vastly overrated, especially in matters of the heart.

title: The Dust That Falls From Dreams, by Louis de Bernires
description: Enviously noting the insatiable public appetite for television dramas like Downton Abbey, writers often lament the prospects for their historical novels, which have faint hopes of attracting anything resembling such sizable audiences. Not Louis de Bernires, who charges straight at them with The Dust That Falls From Dreams, a sprawling story about the members of a wealthy English family and the neighbors, friends and servants who constellate around them at their grand house in London during the first few decades of the 20th century.

title: Sophie and the Sibyl, by Patricia Duncker
description: In 1863, George Eliot received the largest advance that had yet been offered for a novel; the 7,000 paid for Romola were well-earned. Her previous books had captured a zeitgeist. They received rave reviews, sold enviably well and were even quoted in debates in Parliament. Her stories were much talked about, but Eliots authorship and life were also subjects of gossip and speculation; writing under a pen name, the journalist and translator Marian Evans was also scandalously cohabiting with a married man. Evans was a social pariah, but Eliot was now a success.

title: The Dressmaker, by Rosalie Ham
description: Rosalie Hams novel The Dressmaker was published in Australia in 2000 and later this year will be presented as a movie starring Kate Winslet. Whats surprising is that a film version took so long to appear. From the moment the book opens, with a long shot of wheat-yellow plains around the dark blot of a hill in the small country town of Dungatar, we sense that were on our way to quirky-indie-movie land; and once the camera closes in on the tumbling brown house of Mad Molly, leaning provocatively on the grassy curve, its clear were visiting a small 1950s town not of history but as imagined by Tim Burton: the gothic, polarized world of Edward Scissorhands.

title: Inside the List
description: The Dolphin Whisperer: One of the more entertaining figures in Voices in the Ocean, Susan Caseys look at dolphin intelligence  new at No. 13 on the hardcover nonfiction list  is the neurophysiologist John C. Lilly, who before his death in 2001 did as much as anyone to promote the image of dolphins as a nearly alien superspecies that might speak English someday. In the 1960s, Lillys unfettered enthusiasm caught on big with a certain segment of the public, but his fellow scientists were less enthralled: As Casey notes, the trade reviews of his 1961 book, Man and Dolphin, were scathing. Scientifically unsound and nave, Natural History fumed, judging the book a perfect example of how not to do scientific research. The biologist E.O. Wilson called it borderline irresponsible, and a Navy researcher snarked: I find Dr. Lillys work very interesting. I like Dr. Seuss, too. Not that the reviews hurt the books prospects: Man and Dolphin hit the New York Times best-seller list at No.15. But Lillys reputation as a scientist never quite recovered. Lilly is so fascinating because hes so polarizing, Casey told Fresh Air this month. He was pretty freewheeling about the things he did and the things he said. Or, as she clarifies in Voices in the Ocean, The real damage occurred when Lilly began a run of experiments that involved LSD and interspecies sex.

title: Mom, I Know Youre Doing that Gift of Failure Thing, But Could You Please Just Not?
description: In an earlier post, Six Things Parents Need to Send Kids Back to School (That We Cant Buy), I mentioned that I needed time to read, because books like The Gift of Failure by Jessica Lahey are inspiring me to push my children, not toward conventional school and other successes, but toward the kind of independence that leads them to find their own way.

title: In Another Country, by David Constantine
description: More than a century ago, in England during the late-Victorian and Edwardian eras, the god Pan made something of a comeback. In The Wind in the Willows, the Mole and the Water Rat encountered him piping at the gates of dawn. E.M. Forster located him in the Italian countryside in The Story of a Panic, and presiding over a secluded English pond in A Room With a View. Arthur Machens brilliant novella The Great God Pan emphasized the orgiastic horror as well as the freedom associated with the deity. And Peter Pan himself, that eminent Edwardian, recalled the god both in his name and in his occasional habit of blowing on the panpipes.

title: Yes, Succotash Has a Luxurious Side
description: Succotash, that savory mlange of corn and beans, is a noble dish with a long history. We have 17th-century Native Americans to thank for it; they introduced the stew to the struggling colonial immigrants. Composed of ingredients unknown in Europe at the time, it gradually became a standard meal in the settlers kitchens.

title: Fumbling in the Dark
description: There are authors who keep writing the same book, over and over. Michael Koryta is not one of those authors. An inventive storyteller whos also a skilled stylist, hes constantly experimenting, which explains why his private eye novel LAST WORDS (Little, Brown, $26) doesnt read like one. Mark Novak conducts investigative work for a team of Florida defense lawyers who take on pro bono cases for clients on death row. But hes been unraveling for more than a year, ever since his wife, who worked for the same firm, was murdered. With his job hanging by a thread, Mark is given the mercy assignment of investigating a cold case in Garrison, Ind., noteworthy because Ridley Barnes, the man who has asked for help, was never charged but has been condemned by the whole town.

title: Jos Mourinho Says Chelsea Doctor Wont Be on Bench This Week, but May Return
description: Chelsea Manager Jos Mourinho pivoted on Friday under persistent criticism of his demotion of the clubs team doctor this week, confirming that the doctor would miss Sundays match against Manchester City but leaving open the possibility of her return to the bench.

title: How California Is Winning the Drought
description: FOR California, there hasnt ever been a summer quite like the summer of 2015. The state and its 39 million residents are about to enter the fifth year of a drought. It has been the driest four-year period in California history  and the hottest, too.

title: Iowa Democratic Leader: Complaints on Debate Timing Have a Point
description: The chairwoman of the Iowa Democratic Party appeared to acknowledge this week that complaints about the partys compressed presidential debate calendar from candidates trailing in the polls are understandable.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE MAGICIANS LAND, by Lev Grossman. (Plume, $16.) At the outset of Grossmans novel, a satisfying end to his Magicians trilogy, Quentin Coldwater has been exiled from Fillory, the enchanted land he once helped rule, and dismissed from his teaching post at Brakebills College, where he first learned magic. Charting Quentins growth as both a magician and a man, the book considers complex questions about identity and selfhood as profound as they are entertaining, our reviewer, Edan Lepucki, wrote.

title: Editors Choice
description: KATRINA: After the Flood, by Gary Rivlin. (Simon & Schuster, $27.) A former Times reporter examines the personalities and process behind New Orleanss reconstruction, including the often corrupt horse trading of the early days.

title: Greek Parliament Approves Bailout Deal
description: Greek lawmakers spoke on Friday after its parliament approved the countrys third bailout in a vote relying on opposition party support.

title: Versatile White Button-Downs
description: The seasons ubiquitous staple is a sartorial blank canvas.

title: Remembering Beatlemania, 50 Years On
description: The Beatles, those four engaging Englishmen, whose rock n roll singing and long hair have stirred strong emotions in youngsters, proved yesterday that their mere presence in town can create more commotion along the Avenue of the Americas than the months of subway construction, read the lead of a Times article about the groups arrival in New York City.

title: Kerry Speaks as Flag Is Raised in Havana
description: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke in Havana on Friday before the American flag was raised over the recently reopened American Embassy in Cuba.

title: With an Eye to Impact, Investing Through a Gender Lens
description: ELLEN REMMER had wanted to align her investments with her values for years, seeking to put her money into stocks and bonds that would have an impact beyond the returns. For her, this meant investing in organizations that either improved the lot of women and girls or helped the environment.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Vu Trans Dragonfish
description: This week, Vu Tran discusses his debut novel, Dragonfish; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Ruth Franklin talks about Lucia Berlins stories; listeners share what theyve been reading; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: The Downside of Labor Mobility
description: The theory of optimum currency areas is one of those old-fashioned pieces of macroeconomics  like IS-LM, the concept of the liquidity trap, and the theory of secular stagnation  that has turned out to be extremely relevant and useful to the world since 2008. So this is a version of Mark Thomas dictum that new economic thinking involves reading old books (or in this case articles). Still, we do learn some new things. And what weve learned lately, Id argue, is that labor mobility  which was supposed to be good, and a prerequisite for currency union  is actually much more problematic than we knew.

description: This weeks properties are located in Harlem, the Upper West Side and Prospect Heights.

title: A Scotsmans Mission Ends in a Fishing Bay Restored
description: HOLY ISLE, Scotland  HOWARD WOOD, round-faced and jolly, was happily counting the lobsters being pulled, measured and tagged out of the coastal waters he has worked for years to protect. One weighed close to four pounds, its huge right claw dwarfing its left, which was growing back after what must have been quite a battle.

title: Low Oil Prices Pose Threat to Texas Fracking Bonanza
description: KARNES CITY, Tex.  No place in Texas produces more oil than Karnes County, but suddenly the roaring economy here is cooling fast, chilled by the plunging price of crude.

title: State of Emergency in Ferguson Is Lifted as Protests Ease
description: The St. Louis County executive, in a formal indication that tensions in Ferguson, Mo., had eased since an outbreak of gunfire on Sunday night, rescinded on Friday the emergency declaration that he had issued because of criminal unrest.

title: Related C.E.O. Sells Co-op for $30 Million
description: Jeff T. Blau, the chief executive of the Related Companies, one of the citys largest private developers, sold the co-op he had bought more than seven years ago in an exclusive Rosario Candela-designed apartment house on Fifth Avenue to an unidentified buyer for $30,000,000 in the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Friday named a hawkish political rival who opposes a Palestinian state as his next ambassador to the United Nations.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week by @nytimes took Instagram followers from the shores of a Minnesota lake to the Milan Expo 2015.

title: The Listener
description: Don Kent, the blues scholar and founder of more than one obscure yet influential record label, died last week of cancer at the age of 71. For anyone who knew the man or cared at all about prewar American music, the loss is palpable. Last year, when I was working on The Ballad of Geeshie and Elvie  a story about recovering the identities and lives of two lost singers from that early period  Kent proved the most illuminating and generous of sources. He was, to borrow a Barry Hannah line, a hell of a sweet genius guy.

title: The Closing of the Canadian Mind
description: THE prime minister of Canada, Stephen Harper, has called an election for Oct. 19, but he doesnt want anyone to talk about it.

title: The Junk Politics of 2015
description: When you eat a bowl of Simply Granola in the morning, you may think youre making a healthy start to the day, courtesy of Quaker Oats. But youre taking in the amount of sugar in almost four Oreo cookies.

title: Oliver Sacks: Sabbath
description: MY mother and her 17 brothers and sisters had an Orthodox upbringing  all photographs of their father show him wearing a yarmulke, and I was told that he woke up if it fell off during the night. My father, too, came from an Orthodox background. Both my parents were very conscious of the Fourth Commandment (Remember the Sabbath day, to keep it holy), and the Sabbath (Shabbos, as we called it in our Litvak way) was entirely different from the rest of the week. No work was allowed, no driving, no use of the telephone; it was forbidden to switch on a light or a stove. Being physicians, my parents made exceptions. They could not take the phone off the hook or completely avoid driving; they had to be available, if necessary, to see patients, or operate, or deliver babies.

title: Popcast: Straight Outta Compton
description: The N.W.A. biopic Straight Outta Compton arrives in theaters Friday. In some ways, its the final symbol of the success N.W.A. had in redefining hip-hop, and over time, the shape of American pop culture. Thats true in terms of music, and also in terms of politics: the tales N.W.A. specialized in ended up being the stories that would define the news cycle, both in its era and for decades to come.

title: Popcast: Straight Outta Compton
description: Jon Caramanica and Reginald C. Dennis, a founding editor of XXL magazine, discuss N.W.A. and the film.

description: If the scale in your private hotel room feels confrontational, consider being weighed publicly at airline check-in.

title: Young Mississippi Couple Linked to ISIS, Perplexing All
description: STARKVILLE, Miss.  She was a cheerleader, an honor student, the daughter of a police officer and a member of the high school homecoming court who wanted to be a doctor.

title: The Desnudas of Times Square, Topless but for the Paint
description: Mey Ovalles ignored the snickers of gawking boys and the smartphones snapping photos as she clutched her bra to her chest and her bare skin became an opaque shade of blue with white sparkles.

title: The City Council Stands Up for Day Laborers
description: The New York City Council has just struck a blow for fair wages and decent pay, and against illegal activity. It contributed $500,000 to support day-laborer hiring sites across the city. City Council Speaker Melissa Mark-Viverito and her colleague Carlos Menchaca went to one site on Bay Parkway in Brooklyn this month to make the announcement.

title: Passing Grade for Quarterback Vernon Adams Jr. Means He Can Join Oregon
description: The highly regarded quarterback Vernon Adams Jr. passed one of the most consequential math tests in Oregon football history on Thursday, clearing the way for him to replace Marcus Mariota, last years Heisman Trophy winner, as the Ducks starter.

title: South Street Seaport Museum Gets $10.4 Million in Federal Aid
description: Three years after its building was damaged by Hurricane Sandy, the South Street Seaport Museum has been granted $10.4 million in funds from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, RepresentativeJerroldNadler, Democrat of New York,has announced.

title: Obama Operative in Florida Is Ready to Work for Joe Biden
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. would have to create much of his campaign organization on the fly if he decides to enter the presidential race, but one Democratic operative from a crucial state is not waiting to be asked.

title: Arab Bank Reaches Settlement in Suit Accusing It of Financing Terrorism
description: Three days before a first-of-its-kind damages trial was supposed to start, a Middle Eastern bank has reached a settlement with hundreds of American plaintiffs, including victims of terrorist attacks around Israel, who had filed a lawsuit against the bank accusing it of supporting terrorism.

title: A New Vodka Distillery That Subsidizes Artists
description: Whether its a flute of champagne above the High Line or a can of medium-cold beer in Bushwick, beverages play an essential role in the social ritual of art consumption. Plenty of brands have cashed in on this association, commissioning elaborate bottle labels and other decorative schemes from artists  often with the effect of watering down their profiles. Enter a new vodka distillery called Material, expressly founded on flipping the script and diverting boozy profit margins back to makers.

title: President Obamas Eleventh-Hour Conservation Efforts
description: Shortly before leaving town for the summer, Congress approved  and President Obama happily signed into law  three bills that, taken together, will preserve as permanent wilderness roughly 275,000 acres of spectacular mountain terrain in Idaho known as Boulder-White Clouds. This was a rare moment for a Congress that has been far more interested in party infighting than environmental stewardship, and a tribute to the perseverance of one person, Congressman Mike Simpson, Republican of Idaho, who spent years engaging with local officials, ranchers, hunters, tribes, off-road vehicle enthusiasts and other stakeholders.

title: How Mortgage Problems Unravel Home Deals
description: On the road to homeownership, the stretch between an accepted offer and the closing is fraught with detours that can leave buyers in a ditch. While no deal is a certainty until the last signature is applied, buyers can take some preventive steps to help ensure their purchase stays on track.

title: King of the Sand Castle
description: It looked like some futuristic civilization poking up out of the footprinted sand on Rockaway Beach in Queens. A lifeguard walked over to inspect it, then some surfers. A group of dripping children stopped, transfixed.

title: A Palestinian Prisoners Hunger Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: Charlotte Officer Says He Had No Choice in 2013 Shooting of Unarmed Black Man
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  The police officer said he had no choice but to shoot the unarmed man. But prosecutors pushed back hard on Friday as the officer, Randall Kerrick, took the witness stand, challenging his credibility and account of the night he killed Jonathan Ferrell.

title: Queens Rental Tower WithEasy Highway Access
description: Sites that New Yorks luxury residential developers once shunned but now seem eager to embrace are numerous: in office districts, across from public housing complexes or along industrial waterfronts. And now a spot by a major highway can be added to the mix.

description: A government official in Dhaka, Bangladesh, announced on Friday that two suspected members of a Muslim militant group had been charged with the murder of a secular blogger.

title: Bucks Owners Win, at Wisconsins Expense
description: MILWAUKEE  To own a professional sports team is so often to achieve your hearts desire.

title: How Jesse Eisenberg Makes Cup of Noodles a Weapon in American Ultra
description: Weed is not the only thing that is smoked in the violent action-comedy American Ultra, due Friday. Jesse Eisenberg plays Mike Howell, a stoner who works at a convenience store and who has, without his knowledge, been programmed by the C.I.A. to be a lethal sleeper agent. His dormant killer instincts are activated in the middle of a government operation, letting Mike transform whatever items he has at hand into weapons. An early scene, from which this frame is taken, shows Mikes skills when, in a 10-second burst of action, he takes down two men sent to kill him by using a cup of noodles, a spoon and the gun they pull on him. Its a quick but energetic scene that will probably shock the viewer as much as it does the character. Here is a closer look at that scene with commentary from the films director, Nima Nourizadeh, and its stunt coordinator, Robert Alonzo.

title: At Iowas State Fair, Candidates Brave Cholesterol and Hecklers
description: DES MOINES  There are 75 foods on a stick, including apple pie and gluten-free corn dogs. There is a cow sculpted from butter. And there are 18 presidential candidates in a bipartisan stampede to the Iowa State Fair  bringing their stump speeches, of course, but more important, aiming to prove their common touch in the ultimate venue for retail campaigning.

title: Nelson Peltz Buys 7.1% Stake in Sysco for $1.6 Billion
description: The activist investor Nelson Peltz has emerged as the biggest shareholder in the food service company Sysco after buying a $1.6 billion stake in it.

title: Sephoras Box, the People vs. the Olsens and Presenting Uber Returns
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: P.G.A. Championship 2015: Before the Rain Clouds, a Less Familiar Name Hovers
description: HAVEN, Wis.  David Lingmerth comes across as the mildest-mannered of men, a golfer who walks with more of a waddle than a swagger. He blends into the background in the alpha-male world of professional golf, which is lousy with risk takers.

title: How John Hatfield, Executive Director of Socrates Sculpture Park, Spends His Sundays
description: As the executive director of Socrates Sculpture Park, a public art space in Long Island City, Queens, John Hatfield keeps an eye on the weather: The clearer the skies and the warmer the temperature, the busier he is. Late spring, summer, early fall  we have so many events, Mr. Hatfield said. The schedule often keeps him away from his familys TriBeCa apartment, so on Sundays, Mr. Hatfield, 51, focuses on spending time at home  taking in art with his wife, Amy Wolf, 57, an art dealer; catching up with their son, Otis, 18; and caring for the familys new puppy, Babs Kramer.

description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

description: The Iowa State Fair is the center of the political world this week, and lines are drawn in a presidential library speech.

description: Hundreds gathered on Friday to re-enact the famous picture of a sailor kissing a nurse in celebration of Japans surrender to Allied forces in 1945.

title: Russian Publisher Rewrites Books on Putin Without Western Authors Consent
description: MOSCOW  In the original 2012 form of Expelled: A Journalists Descent Into the Russian Mafia State, the British journalist Luke Harding gives a personal account of the harassment he and his family experienced at the hands of the F.S.B., the chief successor agency to the K.G.B. It covers his time in Russia as he reported on such stories as the radiation poisoning of the former F.S.B. officer Alexander V. Litvinenko and the murder of the human rights activist Natalya Estemirova.

title: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Suspended on Saturday
description: Because of the Feast of the Assumption, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Saturday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Hillary Clinton Details More of Her Plans to Help Students Pay for College
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday unveiled the next prong of her plan to raise taxes on the wealthy and use the increased revenue to help undergraduates pay for college and ease the $1.2 trillion in debt they collectively face.

title: From the Vault of the Museum of Sex: Macauras Pulsocon
description: For 15 years, the Museum of Sex, at 233 Fifth Avenue (an address, appropriately enough, near the former site of an early-20th-century red-light district known to vice enthusiasts as the Tenderloin), has been educating, by way of titillating, age-appropriate tourists and locals alike. While those who visit for a bit of blushing will no doubt find an array of X-rated artifacts capable of getting the job done, the true lessons to be learned from the one act with which every culture is consumed are many. And, oftentimes, a little gross.

title: Goldman Courts Risk With Expansion of Its Deposit Base
description: Goldman Sachs is swapping one too-big-to-fail problem for another. The Wall Street company is buying an online banking platform and $16 billion of deposits from GE Capital. The deal has a number of advantages for Goldman, but it carries plenty of risk.

title: Friday Night Music: Quilt, Secondary Swan
description: Im at a conference, and wont have an opportunity to post later. Also havent seen much new music lately. But for some reason Ive been going back to this performance quite a lot, and Ive only featured Quilt once. So heres the 60s, reimagined:

title: A Night Out With Rose McGowan, Now Behind the Camera
description: Rose McGowan cuts her own hair, trimming it into a punkster crop every 10 days. She grew up in a string of Christian communes. She divorced her parents. She knew as a child she would be famous. She sold her engagement ring, one of three, to finance the film she just directed.

title: U.S. Allows Limited Oil Exports to Mexico
description: HOUSTON  The Obama administration on Friday gave oil companies temporary permission to export a limited amount of oil to Mexico at a time when a glut is cutting into domestic petroleum profits and employment.
