title: Help From the Obama Administration for Community Health Centers
description: The Obama administration last week announced a big increase in support for community health centers in the latest expansion of a program that has a long bipartisan history and robust bipartisan support today.

title: Cultural Isolation
description: To the Editor:

title: Building a Chair Simple Enough for a Pope
description: Simple, simple, simple were the Vaticans instructions to the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, which is getting ready for a visit from Pope Francis next month.

title: Jeb Bushs Slog: The Tortoise and the Hair
description: In politics, the smallest things often turn out to be the most telling ones, and so it is with the man who was supposed to be the Republican front-runner, who once inspired such rapture among party elders and whose entrance into the presidential race they yearned and clamored for.

title: The Questionable Legality of Military Aid to Egypt
description: Egypts rising authoritarianism has been met with a collective shrug in Washington, which sends Cairo $1.3 billion in military aid each year.

title: The Worlds Hot Spot
description: Heres my bet about the future of Sunni, Shiite, Arab, Turkish, Kurdish and Israeli relations: If they dont end their long-running conflicts, Mother Nature is going to destroy them all long before they destroy one another. Let me point out a few news items you may have missed while debating the Iran nuclear deal.

title: Stop Universities From Hoarding Money
description: SAN DIEGO  WHO do you think received more cash from Yales endowment last year: Yale students, or the private equity fund managers hired to invest the universitys money?

title: For My Father, Resurrecting the Ancient Rituals
description: Even after the Parkinsons diagnosis, my father seemed invincible. When a truck sideswiped his car, flipping it over, he hung upside down by his seat belt, his glasses on and intact. Hed taken a taxi home from the hospital, rather than calling my mother for a ride and upsetting her. And hed survived falls, cracked one kneecap, and then the other, bruised his face, and healed each time. Iron bones, to match an iron will.

title: Living in Amityville, N.Y.
description: Amityville, with its small-town feel and variety of housing options, is also a haven for water lovers.

title: Amityville, N.Y., Laced With Canals
description: After Sage and Eric Meyer were married in 2009, they stepped up their saving for a house. They were renting in Amity Harbor, N.Y., bordering the village of Amityville; avid swimmers and boaters,they knew they wanted to buy on the water. The couple also wanted to live near Amityville Memorial High School, where Ms. Meyer was an English teacher.

title: Rebecca Steads Goodbye Stranger
description: Its really no wonder 12-year-olds appear frequently not only in novels written for children but also in those written for adults. Taken together, the characters of some classic literature might give the appearance of a middle-school class trip  with the likes of Carson McCullers, William Golding and Vladimir Nabokov in charge, making use of the power of being 12, which is essentially the power of the threshold. If you write a book about characters of this age, you get to document that fleeting moment of change from childhood to not-childhood, when the only person looking out for you might well be you. McCullerss brilliant 1946 novel The Member of the Wedding used a spiky, soulful 12-year-old girl, Frankie Addams, as a vessel for ideas about, among other things, aloneness  both the day-to-day kind and the mortality kind. Frankies yearning to be part of something bigger consumes her. As she describes her brother and his bride, They are the we of me.

title: A Window Opens, by Elisabeth Egan
description: Early on in Elisabeth Egans debut novel, A Window Opens, the narrator and main character, Alice Pearse  part-time magazine editor, full-time wife and mother of three children under the age of 12  self-consciously invokes that familiar cultural catchphrase, work-life balance, admitting shes the tiniest bit smug about her own equilibrium. I wasnt part of the high-powered commuter set and I wasnt a PTA insider, Alice says, but I got to dip into both worlds. Think of it as the Chekhovs gun of chick-lit: If, in Chapter2, a character appreciates her tidily arranged life, you can bet shes on the verge of losing her sanctimonious footing.

title: The Prize, by Dale Russakoff
description: In America, education was long seen as the great equalizer, but that has become mostly myth. So, over the past decade, there has been a vigorous effort to fortify and rebuild our schools, and in this there is a recognition that we have failed our children, especially those living in poverty, those for whom education could  and should  be transformational. From Chicago to New Orleans, school reform has been engineered by the well heeled and well connected  from hedge fund managers to corporate heads to directors of foundations  who believe that with the right kind of teachers and pedagogy, and with a business-like administration, schooling can trump the daily burdens and indignities of growing up poor. No excuses has become the rallying cry of the reformers.

title: Runion Island, Linked to Malaysian Plane, Makes Most of Moment
description: Playing any part in one of modern aviations most enduring mysteries  even if its a small side role  may not make the best tourism advertisement.

title: Ad Blockers and the Nuisance at the Heart of the Modern Web
description: The great philosopher Homer Simpson once memorably described alcohol as the cause of and solution to all of lifes problems. Internet advertising is a bit like that  the funder of and terrible nuisance baked into everything you do online.

title: Longtime Critic of Modi Is Now a Target
description: MUMBAI  One of Indias best-known human rights activists, Teesta Setalvad, was brewing her morning tea on July 14 when she got a telephone call from her security guard.

title: Extended 2nd Life for a Mosaic Mural That Was Lost for Years
description: Its the kind of thing youd expect to happen in Rome.

title: A City Embraces Growth Amid a Drought
description: With its sole water source perilously low, Folsom, Calif., plans to build 10,200 homes and expects 25,000 new people.

title: News Qs | Red Pandas Are Adorable and in Trouble
description: Note: Weve updated 6 Qs About the News for the new school year. Let us know what you think.

title: Losing Water, California Tries to Stay Atop Economic Wave
description: FOLSOM, Calif.  Evert W. Palmer has a vision for this city famous for its state prison: 10,200 new homes spread across the rolling hills to the south, bringing in a flood of new jobs, new business and 25,000 more people.

title: The Middle Easts Morality Police
description: CAIRO  At the end of June, Egypts notoriously backlogged criminal justice system found time to try and convict Reda al-Fouly on charges of inciting debauchery. Less than a month later, two other women were jailed pending investigation on the same charge. They were arrested after complaints filed by lawyers acting privately accused them of outraging public decency.

title: Hotel and Cruise News: A Riverfront Resort in Bali, Discounts in Orlando
description: Our Wednesday morning hotel and cruise digest, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Train, and Recover, Like a U.S. Soccer Star
description: It has been a triumphal summer for womens soccer in the United States. Although the U.S. Womens National Team began their march through the 2015 World Cup field somewhat haltingly, with narrow wins during the group stage over teams that they were expected to thump, they rapidly gained confidence, cohesion and dominance.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Israeli Court Approves Release of Fasting Palestinian
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The Israeli Supreme Court cleared the way on Wednesday for the temporary release of a Palestinian prisoner whose two-month hunger strike might have left him with brain damage.

title: New York Today: The Mayor and the Media
description: Good morning on this mottled Wednesday.

title: Alibaba Joins Forces With Chinese Arms Maker
description: HONG KONG  Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce titan, has always had a capricious streak when it comes to strategic investments and acquisitions.

title: Schuble Urges Yes Vote on Greece Plan
description: The German finance minister Wolfgang Schuble told Germanys Parliament that approving the Greek bailout proposal would give Greece a chance at a new start, but with no guarantee it would work.

title: Today in Politics: Republicans Look to Turn Conversation to Education
description: Good Wednesday morning from Washington. Democrats are quietly counting their Iran votes, and President Obama remains on vacation, hoping things stay as unexciting as possible. Senator Marco Rubio of Florida is getting some attention for his throwing arm, while several other Republicans are heading to New Hampshire to talk education.

title: Myanmars Many Funks and Flavors
description: All Ive ever known about Myanmar has been from the news: democracy advocates silenced with bullets; opposition politicians imprisoned by the government; soldiers opening a new campaign to oppress ethnic minorities. But in June, eating noodles with lemongrass broth at a rented high-school cafeteria in Queens, I finally got to see Myanmar as something else: a homeland, a people. Myo Moe, a photographer who grew up in Yangon, when its name was Rangoon, when the country was still Burma, invited me to the Moegyo Burmese Food Fair, a fund-raiser for Burmese orphans. Here, our community is very tight, she said. We come from different backgrounds, but the food connects us  its how were related to each other. We cant get it in any store, so when we have our food, we dont even care about our backgrounds anymore. It was a lovely, hopeful thing to hear about people who come from a place in the midst of a 60-year ethnic conflict.

title: The New Making It
description: Six creatives in the Los Angeles area are supporting themselves with gigs that would have been impossible 15 years ago.

title: The Creative Apocalypse That Wasnt
description: On July 11, 2000, in one of the more unlikely moments in the history of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Senator Orrin Hatch handed the microphone to Metallicas drummer, Lars Ulrich, to hear his thoughts on art in the age of digital reproduction. Ulrichs primary concern was a new online service called Napster, which had debuted a little more than a year before. As Ulrich explained in his statement, the band began investigating Napster after unreleased versions of one of their songs began playing on radio stations around the country. They discovered that their entire catalog of music was available there for free.

title: Shadows in So Paulo
description: Are they gangsters? Are they bankers? There are certain photographs that seem to have been pulled out of the world of dreams. Men on a Rooftop, by the Swiss photographer Ren Burri (19332014), is one such picture. The photograph, taken in So Paulo in 1960, shows four men on a rooftop, seen from the vantage point of an even higher building. Far below them, stark in black and white, are tram lines and cars, and tiny pedestrians so perfectly matched with their long shadows that they look like miniaturized sculptures by Giacometti.

title: How Texas Could Set National Template for Limiting Abortion Access
description: Efforts to defund Planned Parenthood and calls for tighter abortion laws at the Republican presidential debate have moved abortion rights back into the national spotlight. But the real fight is at the state level. The next big Supreme Court case involving abortion is expected to come from Texas [Update: The Supreme Court is hearing the case], where a 2013 law led to the closing of many clinics and inspired abortion opponents around the country to propose similar restrictions.

title: Handling a Racist Remark in the Workplace
description: I represent a real-estate developer in Florida. Recently an employee of one of the developers commercial tenants confided to me that he overheard an administrator at his company tell another employee that she had just read a book called The Protocols of the Elders of Zion and thought it contained excellent points. The person with whom she was speaking, a department manager, responded that it was a great book and that it must be legitimate because it was endorsed by Henry Ford. Im uncomfortable that this type of conversation might reflect a negative aspect of our tenants company culture. Im tempted to raise this with the general counsel of the company, with whom I negotiated the lease  but for what purpose? I cant betray the confidence, so what am I trying to accomplish? I cant get over that employees working in a respected chain could really accept any premise in that anti-Semitic rant. I thought the reach of the book was limited to uneducated neo-Nazis, but these are educated people in positions of authority. Something just feels wrong here, and I would appreciate some guidance on where to go with this. NAME WITHHELD

title: Morning Agenda: China Keeps Investors Guessing
description: CHINA KEEPS INVESTORS GUESSING  | China continues to enchant Wall Street, despite its tumultuous and uncertain nature, Alexandra Stevenson writes in DealBook. You could be dead right in the thesis and you wont make money, said Troy Gayeski, a senior portfolio manager at SkyBridge Capital, an investment firm that has $9.4 billion invested in hedge funds.

title: An Architect of the Latest Greek Bailout Navigates Germanys Dual Roles
description: BERLIN  When the German Parliament set aside its objections and voted on Wednesday to approve a bailout for Greece, the chief proponent was both an architect of the deal and one of those raising fundamental questions about it: Germanys finance minister, Wolfgang Schuble.

title: Hotels Bring Live Music in Unexpected Places
description: Music  either live or recorded  is a common feature at many hotels, but some properties are getting more creative by offering instrumentalists and singers in unexpected places.

title: Greek Rescue Package Passes in Berlin
description: Lawmakers in Germany voted 454 to 113 in support of the proposal for a third bailout plan.

title: Patrick Stewart, in Starzs Blunt Talk, Plays a TV Journalist
description: SANTA CLARITA, CALIF.  In a career spanning more than six decades, Patrick Stewart has played kings and murderers and one-legged whalers. He has led an international team of superpowered mutants and has captained a starship. Hes played Prospero with the Royal Shakespeare Company and performed A Christmas Carol on Broadway  starring as Scrooge, Tiny Tim and every other character in the story.

title: Syrian Expert Who Shielded Palmyra Antiquities Meets a Grisly Death at ISIS Hands
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  For decades, he was the bespectacled caretaker of some of Syrias greatest archaeological treasures. He explored the sprawling ruins in his hometown, named a daughter Zenobia after its ancient queen, and became so intertwined with its development that one historian called him Mr. Palmyra.

title: Big Hearts in Chelsea
description: Dear Diary:

title: Cirque du Soleil Show Is Broadway Bound
description: Cirque du Soleil, the Canadian circus behemoth that has wowed audiences around the world but has struggled to establish a steady foothold in New York, is planning to take over a Broadway stage for a long-running production that combines musical theater and acrobatics.

title: Chinese Report Details Role of Political Connections in Tianjin Blasts
description: BEIJING  The mayor of the northern Chinese city where huge explosions killed more than 100 people last week took responsibility for the disaster on Wednesday, as the authorities sought to contain growing public anger about the accident. Mounting evidence has suggested that political malfeasance and rampant safety violations played significant roles in the accident.

title: Menorca, the Ibiza Antidote
Is California Really Winning the Drought?: Reader Q. & A.
description: In a Sunday Review article last weekend, How California Is Winning the Drought, Charles Fishman, author of The Big Thirst: The Secret Life and Turbulent Future of Water, argued that despite the severe ongoing drought conditions, Californias economy, job market and population are finding ways to thrive. Hundreds of readers responded, posing questions and ideas for the author on Facebook and The Times site. Here, Mr. Fishman addresses some of their comments.

title: What You Get for  $950,000
description: A stone house in New York, a modern house in Missouri and river views in Michigan

title: $950,000 Homes in New York, Missouri and Michigan
description: CANAAN, N.Y.

title: 2 Women Set to Graduate From Ranger School Are Experienced Officers
description: FORT BENNING, Ga.  With the military poised to expand combat roles to women, the first two female soldiers who will graduate from the Armys grueling Ranger School have already served in the kind of jobs that have been part of the de facto integration of women into front-line combat in the last decade.

title: One Week After the Tianjin Blasts: What We Know
description: One week after a fire and huge explosions tore through the Chinese port city of Tianjin on the night of Aug. 12, the scale of the disaster is beginning to emerge  not only in terms of lives lost and injuries, but also concerning environmental pollution, property destruction and economic costs.

title: Yvonne Craig, Actress Who Played Batgirl, Is Dead at 78
description: Yvonne Craig, the actress best known as Batgirl on the hit 1960s television series Batman, died on Monday at her home in Pacific Palisades, Calif. She was 78.

title: Daily Report: In Silicon Valley, Start-Up Recruiting Battles Heat Up
description: Recruiting top talent in Silicon Valley is always tough. But you know theres a boom under way when the hiring gets even tougher.

title: 1915: German Corruption Fund Bared
description: LONDON  The enormous corruption fund which Germany has been using for her underhand campaign against the Allies in America is the subject of disclosure in the New York edition of the Herald. The Washington correspondent of the Morning Post quotes the Herald as stating that Germany has raised $20,000,000 in the United States since March. Five thousand dollars, the Herald says, was spent in promoting the Bryanite meeting held in New York, a couple of months ago, and $100,000 in getting up the so-called peace conference meeting in Chicago.  The New York Herald, European Edition, August 20, 1915

title: An Estate on a Private Island in the Scottish Highlands
description: The property, which includes a 28,000-square-foot mansion and a sporting lodge, is on the market for $4.68 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Scotland
description: AN ESTATE ON A PRIVATE ISLAND IN THE SCOTTISH HIGHLANDS

title: The Smells of Summer
description: On certain summer days, simply walking down a New York City block means being assaulted by smells. How would a true expert describe the scents of summer in the city?

title: From Revolution to Rangers, Meet the Women Whove Pushed the Militarys Boundaries
description: Two female soldiers are set on Friday to graduate from the Armys Ranger School, the grueling nine-week training and leadership course that just two out of every five candidates pass.

title: Hillary Clinton, Pressed on Race, Issues Her Own Challenge
description: The video is visceral and raw: Hillary Rodham Clinton  the presidential candidate so often faulted for insulating herself from voters and critics alike  in a tense, awkward, unscripted moment.

title: Max Posner, a Playwright With an Absurdist Style, on the Lure of Basements
description: In Max Posners melancholy comedy Judy, set in the year 2040, the theater no longer exists. Whats a play? an 11-year-old girl asks her aunt. The aunt struggles to remember. People recited words to each other in the same order, in the same outfits, night after night, she offers.

title: Fashions Gender-Free Era
description: Is gender flux a trend with legs or just a passing fancy?

title: Jared Fogle, Ex-Subway Pitchman, to Plead Guilty to Child Sex and Pornography Charges
description: Jared Fogle, the former pitchman for Subway sandwich restaurants, notified a federal court on Wednesday that he would plead guilty to sex acts with minors and distribution of child pornography.

title: How Not To Be Read (Trivial)
description: A public service announcement for those who want a hearing: if you send me an email with an attached letter, which says Please read attached letter without any indication of what its about, you should know what will (or actually wont) happen. Life is short, and if you cant be bothered to take the time to say more, I cant be bothered to open an attachment.

title: In Israel, Huckabee Criticizes Iran Deal
description: Mike Huckabee, the Republican presidential candidate, said during a news conference in Jerusalem on Wednesday that Iran intends to bring death to America.

title: Thai Police Seek Foreign Man in Bombing of Bangkok Shrine
description: BANGKOK  The Thai authorities on Wednesday issued an arrest warrant describing the person sought in the bombing of a Bangkok shrine this week as a foreign man, and said they believed that he had at least two accomplices.

title: Trump and the Charisma Premium
description: Having used my Sunday column to double down on one 2016 prediction that Hillarys still a mortal lock to be the Democratic nominee let me use this post to quickly hedge a more recent bet: Namely, that the rise of Donald Trump might be a much-needed gift to Jeb Bushs struggling frontrunner campaign. I offered various arguments three weeks ago for why this might be so, and mostof them might yet bevindicated once we leave the preliminary phase of the campaign, Jeb starts spending ad dollars in earnest, the establishment field gets winnowed andvoters get serious about the nominating process. But heres one passage from my column that I want to revisit, because Im not sure the first debate was kind to it:

title: Police: More Suspects in Bangkok Bombing
description: Thailands national police chief said on Wednesday that there is likely more than one person involved in the fatal explosion at a Bangkok shrine on Monday.

title: Uber Raises $100 Million From Tata of India
description: Uber has picked up another strategic investor.

title: Pension-cutters and Privatizers, Oh My
description: I wrote Monday about the strange phenomenon of Republicans lining up to propose cuts to Social Security, a deeply unpopular policy that is, however, also a really bad idea. How unpopular? Lee Drutman has the data: only 6 percent of American voters support Social Security cuts, while a majority want it increased. I argued that this apparent act of political self-destructiveness probably reflected an attempt to curry favor with wealthy donors, who are very much at odds with the general public on this issue:

title: Bombs at 3 Churches in Las Cruces, New Mexico, Confound the Authorities
description: LAS CRUCES, N.M.  Two homemade bombs exploded early this month during busy Sunday services at Roman Catholic and Baptist churches here, while a third, undetonated explosive was discovered on Friday near a leaking sprinkler valve at a Presbyterian church, fueling unease in this placid city in southern New Mexico, the second largest in the state.

title: Alongside a Doctors Care, a Dose of Traditional Healing
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  The first thing Manuel Lincovil does is take a look at the urine. A machi, or spiritual leader and healer of the indigenous Mapuche people, he watches the liquid settle as he shakes the glass jar, learning of his patients experiences, ailments and sorrows.

title: Ccile McLorin Salvant, With Refined Power, Performs at the Jazz Standard
description: When Ccile McLorin Salvant released her sanguine debut album, Woman Child (Mack Avenue), she represented something new in jazz singing, even in those moments (and they were many) when newness seemed to be the furthest thing from her mind. That was two years ago, and she has only strengthened her art since, growing more expressive with her vocal gift and more beguiling in her handling of an audience.

title: A Dance-Theater Work Explores the Life of Pearl S. Buck
description: Come fall, you can expect an avalanche of biopics jockeying for awards consideration; Hollywood loves dramatic life stories. Dance, on the other hand, has never been particularly interested in biographical narrative. So Pearl, an ambitious dance-theater work exploring the life of the Nobel- and Pulitzer Prize-winning writer Pearl S. Buck, is a rare breed in both form and content. Buck was born in West Virginia and spent decades in China. She was a prolific writer (best known for the 1931 novel The Good Earth), an adoption advocate and a feminist  an intriguing muse for a dance spectacle.

title: From Holding a Clipboard to Carrying a Franchises Hopes
description: N.F.L. teams are completing their depth charts, but for the most part, they know who will be the starting quarterback, the most important slot.

title: A Pianist Returns to Le Poisson Rouge, and LoftOpera Heads to Brooklyn
description: Playing with suavity and nuance, Taka Kigawa took the stage at Le Poisson Rouge last August with a daunting program: all of Pierre Boulezs works for piano solo. On Aug. 24, Mr. Kigawa returns to the same space with pieces in the Boulez orbit, by one of his great precursors and by two whove been influenced by him. The concert includes both books of Debussys Images alongside Marco Stroppas Traiettoria ... deviata for piano and live electronics and Tristan Murails Territoires de loubli. (7:30 p.m., lepoissonrouge.com.)

title: The Imperfect Wim Wenders: Touring Films by the German Director
description: The German director Wim Wenders has a pile of awards from Cannes and other festivals as well as three Oscar nominations, but American moviegoers who stick to blockbusters probably remain unfamiliar with him. Perhaps a touring retrospective organized by Janus Films that begins a monthlong run on Aug. 28 at the IFC Center will serve as a small corrective.It features 12 of his films, including early works and some of his better-known movies from the 1980s. Among those is the haunting Wings of Desire, a fantasy about angels who eavesdrop on and sometimes comfort inhabitants of Berlin.

title: On the Town Is Pulling Up Anchor Soon
description: New York wont be quite the same helluva town after Sept. 6.

title: In TNTs Public Morals, Ed Burns Is on the Vice Beat in 60s New York
description: Prostitution, gambling, after-hours clubs, gay bars  you name it, residents crave it. And everything is against the law in the 1960s. But who wants to make arrests for crimes that arent really hurting anyone? Not Terry Muldoon, an officer with the New York Police Departments public morals division. So, then, what exactly do we do here? asks Jimmy Shea, the handsome newcomer. We do what has been done for the last hundred years: We manage it for the city, Muldoon says. Think of us as the landlords, and if you want to be in business, you got to pay your rent. Do you understand what I am telling you? Shea does. Now Im only going to ask you this this one time, Muldoon says. Are you in?

title: Target Reports Stronger Earnings After Cost Cuts and Job Losses
description: In a season dotted with notable earnings misses among retailers, Target bucked the industry trends by reporting strong earnings on Wednesday, its bottom line lifted by brisk sales of apparel and home goods as well as intensive cost-cutting.

title: Pimp C in a Journalists Back Pages
description: I can tell you about the moment I heard Pimp C was dead  Dec. 4, 2007; at work in my office at Vibe; nervously refreshing TMZ, which had broken the news; feeling nauseous. The room hummed with the white noise that takes over when you no longer register whats happening around you. Minutes later, a colleague knocked on my door, disrupting the quiet, and we looked at each other wordlessly, our jaws quivering but holding firm. My boss came by to ask if I was all right. I wasnt.

title: Destroyer Takes Another Sharp Turn Toward the Fringe
description: Dan Bejar is proudly, defiantly out of touch.

title: Spinning Heartache Into Humor: Tig Notaro on Cancer, Her HBO Special and Going Topless
description: Next time you have a terrible year, feel free to call it a Tig Year. Because the comedian Tig Notaros 2012 was one for the ages.

title: In Jerusalem, Mike Huckabee Calls West Bank Part of Israel
description: JERUSALEM  Staking out the most extreme position on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in the crowded field of Republican candidates  one to the right of even Israels conservative government  former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas said Wednesday that the entire occupied West Bank was part of Israel, leaving no room for a Palestinian state there.

title: Watch Your Language
description: But why is it a bad word? Thats a question parents reliably face as a former toddler enters the world of bigger kids, where a curse word can fly into the room like some confused baby bat, thrilling the kids and rattling the grownups. Curses are one of the great mysteries of human society, a testament to the weird and wonderful power of language. Hearing a small child cuss can be extremely funny but also, I suspect even for the most relaxed and mellow parent, unsettling.

title: Assemble: Making Things Happen
description: For this renegade architecture collective, what goes on in and around a space is just as important as the space itself.

title: Obama to Visit New Orleans forHurricane Katrina Anniversary
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will travel to New Orleans next week for the 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, one of the costliest disasters in United States history.

title: What I Learned From a Disgraced Art Show on Harlem
description: Some first-time art encounters are life-changers, and you know it instantly. They zap you, cast a spell, send you back out with your eyes and mind rewired. Other encounters are just as deep, but dont seem to be, because youre not ready for them. You dont know what youre looking at, though some day you will, and youll wish you could be back there again, equipped with all youve learned. Harlem on My Mind at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was that kind of show for me.

title: 1965: Okinawa Visit Prompts Riot
description: NAHA, Okinawa  Nightlong leftist demonstrations tore this Pacific Island capital today and forced visiting Japanese Prime Minister Eisaku Sato to take refuge in a U.S. military camp. Mr. Sato came to emphasize Japanese ties with the Ryukyu Islands. Two thousand rioters fought with sticks and bottles against club-wielding, steel-helmeted police. Police said 17 demonstrators, mostly students and unionists, were hurt. The leftist mobs oppose Mr. Satos support of U.S. Vietnam policy, and his lukewarm position on reversion of Okinawa and the Ryukyu islands to Japan. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 20, 1965

title: Hillary Clinton Asks to Have Donors Pay for Food and Drinks at Her Fund-Raisers
description: All those pigs-in-a-blanket can get pricey.

title: Hard Climb Awaits Sebastian Coe, New President of I.A.A.F.
description: PARIS  If Sebastian Coe thinks beating Steve Ovett to the finish line or running a successful London Olympics was tough, he is now about to embark on something that looks a great deal more daunting.

title: Watch Live: Trevor Noah on Race and Identity
description: Trevor Noah shares his perspectives on race and identity with John Eligon, a New York Times reporter, and an audience of students.

title: Gun Laws Associated With Lower Suicide Rates
description: A new study has found that four gun laws are significantly associated with lower rates of firearm suicide.

title: The Big Picture on the Mini-Movie in Sinister 2 and Others
description: Somewhere in an alternate universe, a multiplex is playing a curious slate of motion pictures: The Dogwalker, Habeas Corpus, Mant! and Camp Bloodbath. If you dont recognize any of these titles, theres a good reason: All of them are imaginary films that pop up in actual movies. We catch a glimpse of these fake flicks when characters watch them in Trainwreck, The Player, Matinee and The Final Girls.

title: Carly Rae Jepsen Moves on From Call Me Maybe
description: Joe Coscarelli and Jon Caramanica discuss Ms. Jepsens new album on this weeks Popcast.

title: Mexican Worker in Trump Hotel Criticizes Donald Trumps Views, on Video
description: Ricardo Aca knew he could be fired. But he wanted the camera to roll anyway.

title: In Clintons Town, a Call to Move a Prom Over Donald Trumps Politics
description: First there was Univision and the beauty queens, then NBC, then the top chefs. Now, in the heart of Clintonland, another one of Donald J. Trumps business interests is under pressure because of his remarks about Mexican immigrants: his Westchester County golf club, which hosts high school proms.

title: David Ortiz Not an Easy Choice for the Hall of Fame
description: David Ortiz has often seemed like a giant among men. His larger-than-life personality, his reputation for significant home runs, his three World Series rings with Boston (after more than 80 years of Red Sox futility) and his nickname (Big Papi) have made him an integral part of baseballs narrative over the last 13 seasons.

title: Kasich Discusses His Record on Education
description: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, a presidential candidate, attended a Republican summit meeting on education in New Hampshire on Wednesday.

title: Mike Huckabee Misses the Point of Black Lives Matter
description: When dominant racial, ethnic or religious groups are challenged by minorities who still suffer from discrimination, intolerance, hatred and violence, those dominant groups sometimes respond by saying that everyones rights should be respected and that it breeds division to single out the treatment of specific groups.

title: Verbatim: John Kasich Takes On Teachers Attitudes
description: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, a Republican presidential candidate, discussing fear-mongering done by teachers unions at an education forum in New Hampshire.

title: No Suspension of Arguments as Tom Brady Case Becomes a Test of Wills
description: Tom Brady appeared to get the upper hand in his seven-month dispute with the N.F.L. on Wednesday when a judge peppered a lawyer for the league with questions at a hearing.

title: Jared Fogles Guilty Plea
description: Mr. Fogle, who is best known as a Subway spokesman, pleaded guilty to distributing and receiving visual depictions of minors engaging in sexually explicit conduct.

title: George Pataki, in Presidential Bid, Fights to Jog Voters Memories
description: WINDHAM, N.H.  As former Gov. George E. Pataki of New York strolled through the luncheon for seniors, bending his 6-foot-5 frame downward to make small talk over a soundtrack of square-dance music, he earned a rare smile of recognition. A retired high school teacher, Raymond Harmacinski, began to praise Mr. Patakis record when a note of uncertainty crept into his voice.

title: Making the New East Village Old Again in Ten Thousand Saints
description: The East Village aint what it used to be. Its a lament heard from many New Yorkers who knew the neighborhood in the 1980s, before gentrification replaced abandoned storefronts and artists squats with luxury condos and banks.

title: Robert Menendez Offers Unrealistic Plan for Iran
description: It was disappointing, although not unexpected, that Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, the senior Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has declared his opposition to the Iran nuclear deal. He has been skeptical, bordering on hostile, from the start.

title: La Monte Young Is Still Patiently Working on a Glacial Scale
description: The question is, who decides what music should be? the composer La Monte Young asked during a recent interview. What is music, and why is it music, and how did music start? Sitting in his cluttered loft in TriBeCa, Mr. Young had just been ruminating on the creation myths of Indian music, and continued on to briefly address marches, bagpipes and Dizzy Gillespie before arriving at the conclusion to this circuitous historical trajectory: his own Trio for Strings, from 1958.

title: Chinas Carbon Dioxide Emissions May Have Been Overstated by More Than 10%
description: HONG KONG  Scientists may have been overestimating Chinas emissions of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas driving global warming, by more than 10 percent, because of inaccurate assumptions about the countrys coal-burning, according to a study published on Wednesday.

title: Chromebooks Gaining on iPads in School Sector
description: As school districts across the country increasingly invest in technology for their students, the volume of personal computers in the classroom is surging.

title: Wall Street Journal Criticizes Iranian Reports on Its Reporter
description: The Wall Street Journal on Wednesday criticized what it described as false Iranian state media reports that accused the newspaper and one of its veteran correspondents of conspiring against Irans government.

title: Jeb Bush Uses Caution on Dicey Subject of School Standards
description: Common Core is Jeb Bushs Achilles heel when it comes to courting many conservatives, and on Wednesday the former Florida governor treaded carefully over the subject.

title: How to Style Falls Victorian Look for 21st-Century Girls
description: If high-neck collars and loads of ruffles and black lace smack of period drama, consider that the Old World look is easily styled for this fall. Heres how.

title: Pastis Plans to Open in Gansevoort Market in 2017
description: Keith McNallys crowd-pleasing brasserie-style restaurant Pastis, which anchored the meatpacking district from 1999 and closed last year because of building construction, has found a new home in the Gansevoort Market, a collection of stands selling foods that opened about a year ago at 52 Gansevoort Street, near the new Whitney Museum.

title: Trump in a Box
description: As pundits are discovering to their horror, theres probably more to the Trump phenomenon than mere celebrity. The fact is that the central planks of modern conservatism  slashing taxes on the rich and benefits for the public at large  are deeply unpopular. Republicans have won elections only by wrapping these policies in other stuff; its about cutting benefits for welfare queens and strapping young bucks (thats a Reaganism, in case youre wondering) buying T-bone steaks with food stamps. And this in turn means that there is a sort of empty box in U.S. politics waiting to be filled.

title: Low-Income Housing Goals Set for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
description: The federal agency that regulates the mortgage finance companies Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac on Wednesday set goals for the next two years to nudge them to provide mortgages to more low-income borrowers and to landlords who offer low rents to poor people.

title: Bill de Blasio Addresses Outrageous Remarks by Donald Trump
description: Oil and water, meet de Blasio and Trump.

title: Fed Minutes Show Caution in Discussion on Rates
description: WASHINGTON  Federal Reserve officials are struggling to get comfortable with the persistent sluggishness of price inflation as they move toward raising interest rates later this year.

title: Soaring Along With the Worlds Tallest Roller Coasters
description: I have been intrigued by roller coasters since riding the Mini Mine Train at Six Flags Over Texas as a child. What started out as a fear turned into a discovery and then a passion. These days, I regularly seek out the tallest, fastest and most innovative thrills at parks around the country.

title: Crash in Southern New Jersey Kills Boy, 2, and Injures 3 Others
description: A car struck a young woman and a group of children on a road in southern New Jersey this week, killing a 2-year-old boy riding in a red wagon, the New Jersey State Police said.

title: Health Officials Investigating Second Plague Case in California
description: For the second time this summer, health officials in California are investigating a case of plague that a camper most likely contracted while visiting Yosemite National Park.

title: Germany Announces Plan to Cope with Migrant Influx
description: BERLIN  Germany expects as many as 800,000 asylum seekers or refugees this year, four times the number who came last year, Interior Minister Thomas de Maizire said on Wednesday in announcing new actions to cope with the biggest influx since the aftermath of World War II.

title: App Smart | Golf Like a Pro
description: Apps can improve your golf game, from helping you understand the rules of the game to factoring the wind into a swing.

title: Video Feature: Golfing Apps That Improve Play From Tee to Green
description: HERES a conversation topic for you and your golfing buddies as you kick back at the 19th hole on a summers evening and look back over your day on the course: all the apps that can help with your golfing game.

title: Conquering Androids Stagefright Bug
description: Conquering

title: The Alternatives: Designers Subverting Fashions Status Quo
description: As high fashion becomes an increasingly commercial business, a group of rebellious young designers has emerged, challenging the unwritten codes of design, from gender stereotypes to whats even considered clothing.

title: Elisabeth Egans A Window Opens Has Echoes of Her Amazon Odyssey
description: Im an oversharer, Elisabeth Egan said before an interview had even begun.

title: 36 Hours in Burlington
description: Burlington has long embodied the earthy progressivism and can-do independence that define the states spirit. Lately that ethos has taken on a sophisticated sheen.

title: Social Security Benefits in Limbo for Some Same-Sex Couples
description: Same-sex couples may have won marriage equality, but some gay and lesbian individuals have been left wondering if their unions are still less than equal in the eyes of the government.

title: 36 Hours in Burlington, Vermont
description: Burlington, home of the University of Vermont and the birthplace of Phish, Ben and Jerrys and Seventh Generation, has long embodied the earthy progressivism and can-do independence that define the states spirit. Lately that ethos has taken on a sophisticated sheen, as chefs apply Vermonts longtime obsession with local ingredients in exciting new directions. There are still plenty of Birkenstocks about; theyre just parked under tables spread with confit duck poutine, braised leek crepes and crisp, complex Vermont craft brews like Alchemists Heady Topper, a beer of near-mythic reputation among hops aficionados.

title: In Girls Account, Rite at St. Pauls Boarding School Turned Into Rape
description: CONCORD, N.H.  The 16-year-old girl sat on the witness stand, her hair pulled back. She tried to speak steadily as she told a jury about the night when a ritual at St. Pauls  an elite boarding school here  turned into what she described as a shocking sexual assault.

title: Louis Stokes, Congressman From Ohio and Champion of the Poor, Dies at 90
description: Louis Stokes, who as the first African-American congressman from Ohio helped focus federal attention on the nations poor and led a special House investigation into the assassinations of President John F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., died on Tuesday at his home in a Cleveland suburb. He was 90.

title: In Bribery Law, a New Tool to Scrutinize Wall Street
description: If you want to succeed on Wall Street, you have to build relationships. So firms will do almost anything to please clients, catering to their wishes in the hope of winning the next underwriting assignment or new assets to manage.

title: First Draft Focus: Striking Up the Band in New Hampshire
Time Warner PromotesPriya Dogra to Deals Chief
description: Time Warner announced Wednesday that it had elevated Priya Dogra to lead the media conglomerates global deal activity as its new senior vice president for mergers and acquisitions.

title: Scott Walker on His Education Reforms
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin defended his education reforms at a Republican education summit meeting in Londonderry, N.H.

title: 2007 Case Against Kenyan Leader Is Under Scrutiny
description: PARIS  The failed case against President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya moved into the spotlight again on Wednesday when judges demanded a fresh inquiry into whether the Nairobi government obstructed access to crucial evidence against him.

title: Jared Fogle Guilty in Child Sex Charges
description: Mr. Fogle, the former pitchman for Subway sandwich restaurants, pleaded guilty to sex acts with minors and to distributing child pornography.

title: Food Matters
description: Lunch with the Four Horsemens family and friends.

title: London Theater Journal: Maximally Minimal
description: LONDON  Even fictional holidays, it seems, are subject to shrinkage in these days of austerity measures and arts cuts, subjects much on the minds of pundits (and taxpayers and theatergoers) here. On my first night in London this summer, I found myself spending only Three Days in the Country, as opposed to the usual full month, at the National Theater.

title: Kids in the Kitchen: Broiled Fish With Chermoula
description: The master plan? Raising children who can be independent in the kitchen, able to prepare a few healthy meals and snacks and with the confidence to tackle a new recipe or task. In our Kids in the Kitchen series, Motherlodes KJ DellAntonia and Cookings Margaux Laskey move their very differently aged families toward that goal. Margaux finds ways for her 3-year-old and toddler to help cook, while KJ stands back and coaches her two 9-year-olds and her 11- and 14-year-olds in cooking on their own.

title: Bobby Jindal on Louisiana Schools
description: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana appeared at a Republican education summit to discuss reforms to the school systems in New Orleans and throughout the state.

title: Glencore Tripped Up by Faith in Rational Markets
description: Glencores shtick has long been that it is the master of the commodity markets. It knows when to take risks, it can shift supply to where its most wanted and it tweaks its own mines to maximise profit. Or at least it can do all that when everyone else behaves rationally. That thinking has come unstuck, and the British-Swiss commodities traders earnings have gone with it. They halved in the first six months of 2015.

title: How Trump Might Help Reform Conservatives
description: We havent been talking very much about intra-conservative policy debates since the G.O.P. primary campaign, and especially the Trump boom, began in earnest. Over at Bloomberg Politics, Peter Gosselin has a piece up quoting some members of my own reform conservative tribe expressing dismay at this, and particularly at the way that Trump is killing offserious policy arguments and turningthe G.O.P. primary into an exercise in substance-free showmanship. To one degree or another, Gosselin writes, virtually everyone in [the reformocon] circle of mostly 30-something conservatives interviewed in recent days expressed apprehension that the Republican contest could degenerate into the negative, policy-light brawl of four years ago, something party officials and policy advocates had sought to avoid.

title: Simpsons Memorabilia to Be Auctioned From Sam Simon Collection
description: This fall ardent fans of The Simpsons can buy a Simpsons pinball machine at Sothebys. (Barts voice will berate you, Hey, man, Im an underachiever, too. Homers taunts: Dont you know how to use the flippers?)

title: With an Eye on Fintech, Andreessen Horowitz Adds a New General Partner
description: The leaders of Andreessen Horowitz believe that experience is the best teacher. So the best venture capitalists are ones with first-hand experience founding companies, people who have been through the war, as Marc Andreessen puts it.

title: Yankees Greg Bird Steps In for a Slugger and Breaks Into a Trot, Twice
description: When Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman made inquiries into acquiring a starting pitcher before the July 31 trading deadline, he told his counterparts on other teams that three prospects were off-limits: pitcher Luis Severino, outfielder Aaron Judge and first baseman Greg Bird.

title: Tattoos on and off the Runway
description: Twelve models and their tattoos.

title: Opening Statements in N.H. Rape Case
description: Lawyers for the prosecution and the defense made their opening statements in the trial of Owen Labrie, a graduate of the St. Pauls School who is accused of raping a freshman girl.

title: A Variety Show for the Apollo in the Hamptons
description: Captains of industry arrived in Maseratis and Porsches. The East Hampton lawn was filled with artworks by Robert Indiana, Anish Kapoor and Richard Serra. And celebrities like Christina Aguilera, Jamie Foxx and Jimmy Fallon were there not only as guests, but also as performers.

title: Rare Sand Kittens Born in Israeli Zoo
description: A sand cat at the Ramat Gan Safari Park became pregnant after a mate was brought in from Sweden. The cats were previously considered extinct in Israel.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thailand, North Korea and Elsewhere
description: France, Bulgaria, Thailand and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Vintage Looks at Morphew Offer Fresh Take on Fashion
description: Were every designers dirtiest secret, said Jason Lyon, while sitting on a leather ottoman in the Midtown Manhattan showroom of Morphew, a vintage clothing archive for which he is a co-owner.

title: August 19, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photographs from Thailand, North Korea, South Korea and France.

title: Treasure Discovered From 1715 Shipwreck
description: A treasure-hunting crew found $4.5 million worth of gold coins off Floridas coast in July. The site is known as the resting place of a fleet of Spanish ships that sank in a hurricane 300 years ago.

title: A Hawaii Food Festival Goes Local
description: The fifth annual Hawaii Food & Wine Festival runs from Aug. 29 to Sept. 13 on the islands of Hawaii, Maui and Oahu.

title: Two-Headed Calf Born in Peru
description: The rare calf was born in northern Peru on Tuesday at Edward Villegas Rubios stable in the countrys Cajamarca region.

title: An Itsy Bitsy Teenie Bikini? This Year. Maybe Not.
description: It was almost a decade ago that Nora Ephron famously instructed anyone young to go put on a bikini and not take it off until age 34.

title: Baby Boomers Ready to Sell Businesses to the Next Generation
description: Dan Bizzarro and Bill Jordan were still in college when they went to work at the Bimac Corporation, a castings manufacturer in Dayton, Ohio. After graduation, they joined full time as manufacturing and engineering executives. And eventually they teamed with a third employee to buy the business.

title: Panti Bliss, the Accidental Activist of Ireland
description: How does a once-conservative Catholic country embrace not only equal rights for gays, but an outspoken H.I.V.-positive drag queen as a national icon?

title: Ballet Life, Unfiltered and Uploaded to Instagram
description: Deformed toenails, eating disorders and backstabbing jealousy  thats a quick survey of ballet stereotypes. But with Instagram, dancers have found a way to break through the tulle and tiaras by presenting backstage life on their terms.

title: Home is Where the Work Takes Him
Justice Dept. Presses Civil Rights Agenda in Local Courts
description: WASHINGTON  Burlington, Wash., was a small city fighting what seemed like a local lawsuit. Three poor people said that their public lawyers were too overworked to adequately represent them in municipal court cases. The dispute went mostly unnoticed for two years, until the Obama administration became involved.

title: Ex-Executive Pleads Guilty in Toxic Spill in West Virginia
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va.  The former president of a company whose toxic chemical spill contaminated the drinking water of more than 300,000 people last year pleaded guilty Wednesday to environmental crimes.

title: Review: The Battery Dance Festival Evokes Courtship Rituals Amid Flying Hats
description: The Battery Dance Festival, presented by the Battery Dance Company in Lower Manhattan for 34 years, has become known for its international roster. This year artists from India, Norway and Poland are among those appearing along the Hudson River  routinely backed by stunning, if blinding, sunsets  at Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park in Battery Park City.

title: Review: At Mostly Mozart, Joshua Bell Plays a Rejiggered Bach Novelty
description: Increasingly, classical artists are realizing that audiences appreciate hearing performers speak about a piece they are about to play. Of course, the performer had better be personable and have something helpful to say.

title: Review: Everybody Rise, Stephanie Cliffords Debut Novel, Features That Old-Money Scent
description: At an Ivy League varsity team dinner in a college dining hall, I was once chastised by a teammate for not passing the pepper along with the salt. The rule was familiar to me, but the insistence on it in these raucous surroundings surprised me. Oh, but that was just the point, said my Miss Manners; in her circle these rules mattered always and everywhere. Having nothing to do with actual courtesy or consideration, a ritual like this one was, it seemed to me, part of a code by which people were meant to recognize one another as belonging.

title: Chris Christie on a Teaching Revolution
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey appeared at a Republican education summit meeting on Wednesday and said that if there were to be a revolution in teaching, the revolutionaries should be better armed.

title: A Hoarders Tale of Redemption
description: Barry Yourgrau collects shopping bags and stationery from grand hotels, cocktail napkins and coasters from European cafes and more esoteric souvenirs like sponge shoe polishers, a calendar put out by Italian policemen, a tissue paper Day of the Dead banner tucked inside a Mexican newspaper, soccer club scarves. His girlfriend, Anya von Bremzen, is a food writer who travels half the year for her work and Mr. Yourgrau, a fiction writer and performer, accompanies her on all her trips, so hes been able to feed his collection with a constant stream of new treasures.

title: Martin OMalley Calls Hillary Clinton Email Issue a Huge Distraction
description: Standing in front of a hotel emblazoned with Donald J. Trumps name in Las Vegas, Martin OMalley on Wednesday said that the constant questions about Hillary Rodham Clintons email use was a distraction for the entire Democratic Party.

title: Jane the Virgin Narrator on His Role and His Emmy Nomination
description: When nominations for this years Emmy Awards were announced in late July, CWs Jane the Virgin, one of the most warmly received shows of the 2014-15 TV season, was nearly absent. Despite raves for its star Gina Rodriguez and expectations that it would vie for best comedy, the freshman series was the recipient of only a single nomination.

title: Beyonc Is Seen but Not Heard
description: The biggest Vogue of the year, the vaunted September issue (832 pages, four pounds, three ounces), is now on the stands. On its cover is arguably the biggest star of the moment, Beyonc.

title: The Artists Behind the Exhibitions
description: The Contemporary Arts Center and the New Orleans Museum of Art put on shows tied to Hurricane Katrina, 10 years after the storm.

title: Ten Years After Katrina, New Orleans Museums Reckon With Recovery
description: NEW ORLEANS  How well do you remember the last days of August 10 years ago? Asked that question, a 23-year-old New Orleanian writes of seeing a dead alligator on the highway, having nowhere to sleep and crying every night. This anonymous recollection, printed neatly on a card, is part of a growing number pinned to the basement walls of the Ogden Museum of Southern Art here.

title: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
description: Saturday from noon to 4 p.m., Intermix will host a fall denim event. Shoppers can enjoy free tailoring and the help of an Intermix stylist to pick the perfect pair of on-trend jeans, like very 70s J Brand velvet kick flares ($298) and Frame high-waist denim trousers ($250). At 125 Fifth Avenue.

title: Uber Missed Criminal Records of Drivers, Prosecutors Assert
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For more than a year, regulators in various cities have questioned whether Uber, the ride-hailing service, vets its drivers for criminal backgrounds as carefully as traditional taxi companies.

title: In Fashion, Gender Lines Are Blurring
description: Each time Kimberly Wesson sheds her customary trousers and button-front shirt to put on a flowery dress, she suspects something is off.

title: Review: Liberty Ellman Releases Radiate
description: LIBERTY ELLMAN

title: Review: Royal Headache Releases Its Second Album
description: ROYAL HEADACHE

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Call Carly Rae Jepsen a Pop Star With Depth (Maybe)
description: The year is 2015, yet surly clouds of shame still hover over those fortunate enough to have had one spectacular pop hit. How many streaming services must die before these blessed artists understand that their one calling-card hit is a wonder not to escape, but to embrace?

title: The Instagram Archive of Celebrity Summers
description: Celebrities and fashion folk have been having a grand old summer this year. For those who dont keep up by turning to the usual methods  tabloids, gossip websites and blogs  theres Instagram, where many well-known users post personal photos from their adventures in locales near and far.

title: On Instagram, the Summer Youre Not Having
description: And how has your summer been so far?

title: Russia Sentences Estonian to 15 Years in Disputed Spy Case
description: MOSCOW  A Russian court convicted an Estonian security police officer of espionage on Wednesday and sentenced him to 15 years of hard labor in a case highlighting tensions between Russia and its Baltic neighbors, which have escalated along with the conflict in Ukraine.

title: Eli Manning Disputes Report That He Wants to Be N.F.L.s Highest-Paid Player
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In a rare display of annoyance, Eli Manning on Wednesday disputed a report that he wanted to be the N.F.L.s highest-paid player. Manning, who is negotiating a new contract with the Giants, said that neither he nor his agent had made such a demand.

title: Researchers Link Longer Work Hours and Stroke Risk
description: People who work 55 hours or more per week have a 33 percent greater risk of stroke and a 13 percent greater risk of coronary heart disease than those working standard hours, researchers reported on Wednesday in the Lancet.

title: Cornel West: The Fire of a New Generation
description: This is the 15th in a series of interviews on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This weeks discussion is with Cornel West, one of the most prominent and provocative intellectuals in public life. He is a professor of philosophy and Christian practice at Union Theological Seminary and professor emeritus at Princeton University. He is the author and editor of more than 30 books, including Black Prophetic Fire and The Radical King.  George Yancy

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Grandma
description: Paul Weitz narrates a sequence from his film Grandma, featuring Lily Tomlin and Sam Elliott.

title: Paul Weitz Narrates a Scene From Grandma
description: A woman visits an old flame to ask for a favor, and a fire burns. Thats the crux of this scene from Grandma, written and directed by Paul Weitz and featuring Lily Tomlin.

title: Review: In Grandma, Lily Tomlin Energizes an Intergenerational Road Trip
description: In need of cash  well get to why in a minute  Elle Reid, a poet and sometime professor in her 70s, decides to sell some precious old books. She figures that even though theyre a bit worse for wear, her first editions of Betty Friedan and Simone de Beauvoir should fetch a few hundred dollars at the local feminist bookstore-cafe. Her outrage when shes grudgingly offered a lot less than that compounds her dismay at her teenage granddaughters cluelessness about the authors of The Feminine Mystique and The Second Sex. Whats wrong with the world these days?

title: The Icelandic Composer Anna Thorvaldsdottir, Searching for Beauty Amid Brokenness
description: Listening to a recent album of Icelandic music from the chamber ensemble Nordic Affect is a bit like driving across the country from which its composers hail: The terrain changes radically every few minutes, but a sense of the uncanny unifies the landscape. Clockworking, released last month on the Sono Luminus label, forms an absorbing and persuasively performed snapshot of Icelandic composition today. The album brims with compellingly quizzical sounds, from Thuridur Jonsdottirs INNI  in which electronic samples of a babbling baby accompany a shimmering Baroque violin  to Hafdis Bjarnadottirs From Beacon to Beacon, which draws on recordings made at lighthouses to create twitchy grooves.

title: Russias Pitch to Vacationers: Crimea Is for Patriots
description: SAKI, Crimea  Tamara Tsetlayana stood on a narrow stretch of gray beach, rinsing off a thick layer of the black, ostensibly therapeutic mud that has drawn visitors to the salty lake here for more than a century.

title: Lebanese Police Beat You Stink Activists in Beirut
description: Simmering tensions between protesters and the authorities over Lebanons continuing trash crisis erupted into violence on Wednesday as the police used force on demonstrators rallying outside the seat of government in Beirut.

title: Early Prison Release Delayed for Oscar Pistorius
description: South Africas justice minister on Wednesday intervened to delay the early release of Oscar Pistorius, the imprisoned Olympic athlete convicted of killing his girlfriend  48 hours before he was scheduled to begin serving the rest of his five-year term under house arrest.

title: Oil Companies Sit on Hands at Auction for Leases
description: HOUSTON  With oil prices collapsing and companies in retrenchment, a federal auction in the Gulf of Mexico on Wednesday attracted the lowest interest from producers since 1986.

title: British Study Says Electronic Cigarettes Curb Smoking Risks
description: British health officials on Wednesday reported the results of a government-funded study concluding that the use of electronic cigarettes can reduce the health risks of smoking by 95 percent and may also help smokers quit the habit.

title: Arkansas Governor Wants to Keep Medicaid Expansion, but With Changes
description: WASHINGTON  Gov. Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas on Wednesday told an advisory group weighing the future of the states alternative Medicaid expansion that he favored keeping it  but only if the federal government allowed changes that seemed intended to appeal to conservative legislators who continue to oppose the program.

title: Rude Boy Style Cant Fail
description: A recent book and exhibit showcase the suave street style of rude boy style, which transcends mere fashion to embrace a fierce sense of self-worth.

title: Jets Sign Matt Flynn, Adding Experience to Backups at Quarterback
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Concerned about the inexperience of their backup options at quarterback, the Jets signed the veteran Matt Flynn on Wednesday.

title: City Council Stands in Way of Carriage Horse Ban, de Blasio Tells Activists
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio made a promise as a candidate to animal-rights activists that he would end the Central Park horse-carriage industry on the first day of his administration.

title: 3 Peacekeepers Accused of Rape in Central African Republic
description: UNITED NATIONS  In the latest in a series of sexual abuse allegations against United Nations peacekeepers in the Central African Republic, the families of two women and one girl under the age of 18 have accused three peacekeepers of rape, the United Nations announced Wednesday.

title: Syria: Typhoid Threatens Refugees
description: A typhoid outbreak is threatening displaced Palestinian residents from the Yarmouk refugee camp outside Damascus, Syria, the United Nations reported Wednesday. Christopher Gunness, a spokesman for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, said that medical teams had confirmed six typhoid cases on Tuesday among Palestinians in the Yalda district near Yarmouk, and that five more cases had been confirmed on Wednesday. We fear this is the tip of the iceberg, Mr. Gunness said. The agency has been unable to gain access to Yarmouk since March 28, just before Islamic State militants seized control of part of it, but has been able to help some residents who have fled.

title: The Ashley Madison Data Dump, Explained
description: The release of stolen data from Ashley Madison, a dating website marketed at would-be adulterers, promises to roil the marital lives of its members.

title: Union Takes a McDonalds Challenge Overseas
description: McDonalds long ago went global. Lately, the anti-McDonalds campaign has started following it around the world.

title: Activists Confront Hillary Clinton
description: A newly released video from Good magazine, showing Hillary Clinton in a meeting being confronted by young activists from the Black Lives Matter movement, thrilled me to no end. It also depressed me just as much.

title: G.O.P. Hopefuls Display Differences on Education
description: In saying on Wednesday that he supported annual standardized tests for public school students, Jeb Bush invoked his brother.

title: Oh, the Stories He Could Tell
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic  Ever since Pedro Martinez entered the Baseball Hall of Fame in July, Emilio Cordova, the Dominican Republics most celebrated baseball historian, has been carrying copies of stat sheets with him all over town. On one side of the pages are Martinezs career numbers; on the other are those of Juan Marichal, the countrys other legendary pitcher.

title: Momentum Slipping Away in Iowa, Scott Walker Adopts a Trump-Like Stance
description: DES MOINES  On a three-day tour of Iowa after declaring his candidacy for president last month, Scott Walker wore the same rolled-sleeves uniform, told the same sports joke and answered questions with verbatim passages from his announcement speech, whether he was in Davenport, Cedar Rapids or Sioux City.

title: Review: In Philip Ridleys Mercury Fur, Its the Worlds End, and the Partys Here
description: Even those who binge on apocalyptic splatter movies are going to be rattled by Mercury Fur, Philip Ridleys pitch-dark portrait of the day after tomorrow in the big city. Granted, this blistering production from the New Group, which opened on Wednesday night at the Pershing Square Signature Center, doesnt have the big-screen special effects associated with cinematic gore fests about the end of the world.

title: Gas Station Supply
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  This may sound odd, but I have nostalgic feelings for the COMPRESSED AIR machines at gas stations. For most, reinflating ones tires is a mundane chore, but for me, its a symbol of personal growth. Stay with me on this one.

title: Cuomo Joins Call to Curb Topless Women in Times Square
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Wednesday joined the call for a crackdown on the nearly naked women in body paint who pose for photos in Times Square.

title: The Best-Selling Sports Books
description: There is still plenty of time to enjoy the beach weather and get in some reading before fall. Here are the best-selling sports books in July 2015, according to the New York Times best-seller list.

title: Activist Shaun King Denies Claims He Lied About Race and Assault

title: Whats On TV Thursday
description: 10:50 A.M. (Starz) MR. TURNER (2014) A growling, sputtering Timothy Spall, above, stars as J. M. W. Turner (1775-1851), the man the Victorian critic John Ruskin called the greatest painter of all time. Mike Leighs biographical masterpiece juxtaposes the vexing genius of Turners later years and his ramshackle personal life. Turner the painter divined luminously stormy seascapes and placid river scenes that inspired the praise of critics and the envy of colleagues  until his work fell out of fashion. Turner the man lived with his father (Paul Jesson), copulated with his longtime housekeeper (Dorothy Atkinson) and ignored his daughters by his semi-estranged wife (Ruth Sheen) while keeping company with a kindhearted widow (Marion Bailey) whose last name he adopts. Mr. Turner is a mighty work of critical imagination, a loving, unsentimental portrait of a rare creative soul, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this Oscar nominee in cinematography, costume and production design, and original score. But even as it celebrates a glorious painter and illuminates the sources of his pictures with startling clarity and insight, the movie patiently and thoroughly demolishes more than a centurys worth of mythology about what art is and how artists work. He added, It might be risking Ruskinesque folly to take Mr. Turner as a self-portrait of its director, but Turner shares with Mr. Leigh an ability to travel the circuit between the sublime and the ordinary, to bring into view aspects of reality that had been somehow invisible in plain sight.

title: Rude Boy Style Cant Fail
description: At the heyday of colonial conquest, Charles Baudelaire, the French poet and lover of the Haitian-born artist Jeanne Duval, wrote that dandyism is a setting sun; like the declining star, it is magnificent, without heat and full of melancholy. Diasporic Africans, whose bodies were reduced to mere commodities for centuries, have long used stylin out to subvert racial order, perform their identities far from a lost homeland, and redefine blackness and cosmopolitanism, as the historian Monica Miller noted in Slaves to Fashion: Black Dandyism and the Styling of Black Diasporic Identity.

title: Mr. Cuomo Should Get on Board
description: After thousands of irate New Jersey commuters were again delayed in their morning commutes this week, Gov. Chris Christie finally got serious about doing something to help them. On Tuesday, the governor sat down with the secretary of transportation, Anthony Foxx, and a group of New Jersey officials to address what has become a major issue not only for commuters but also for the regional economy: the alarming deterioration of the existing rail tunnel under the Hudson River and the urgent need to build a new one.

title: How Not to Think About Bears
description: Amicalola Falls State Park, Ga.  IVE been vacationing in western North Carolina and northern Georgia since I was a kid. I arrive, marvel at the mountains and put on an unconvincing Southern drawl. In recent summers Ive brought my own kids, too (picture tiny people saying yall in a faintly French accent).

title: What Donald Trump Could Learn From the Korean DMZ

title: Talking About the Death Penalty, Court to Court
description: The Connecticut Supreme Court could have taken an easy route to finding the states death penalty unconstitutional in the decision it issued last week. The State Legislature repealed the death penalty in 2012, but it made the repeal prospective, leaving 11 men on death row. The reason for the prospective-only repeal was obvious to all: Two of the death-row inmates, Joshua Komisarjevsky and Steven Hayes, had committed a horrific home-invasion triple murder that shocked the state in 2007, and the prospect of barring their execution was unpalatable to Connecticut politicians and many members of the public.

title: G.O.P. Candidates Follow Trump to the Bottom on Immigration

title: A Regulators Deal With Promontory Skirts a Big Problem
description: New York States Department of Financial Services announced this week that Promontory Financial Group, a top bank consultant, would pay $15 million to settle allegations that it purposely obscured evidence of wrongdoing it uncovered at Standard Chartered, the big British bank penalized for money laundering in 2012.

title: When a River Runs Orange
description: Durango, Colo.  THE recent mining pollution spill in my corner of Colorado  La Plata County  is making national news for all the wrong reasons. Beyond the spill and its impact on everyone downstream, the underlying causes are far more worrisome and dangerous than just a mistake made by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Abandoning the Work I Hated
description: I was the envy of my 30-something friends in Palo Alto, Calif. I had my own law office right on California Avenue. People charged with crimes handed me cash, in advance, over a big oak desk. Occasionally, Id make a couple of grand in an afternoon.

title: The Upper West Side for a Lifestyle Change
description: Gail Reiken Tuzman grew up in Canarsie, Brooklyn, but spent most of her adult life in Montclair, N.J. Thats where she and her husband reared their two sons, in a three-story four-bedroom colonial-style house.

title: Shadows of Sherwood: A Robyn Hoodlum Adventure, by Kekla Magoon
description: Modernizing legends can be a tricky business. One must find the resonance between ancient and contemporary, blending incongruous elements in a way that seems not only right but inevitable: telling the story of a founding father with hip-hop lyrics, as in Hamilton, or presenting the myth of Theseus in the milieu of reality television as in The Hunger Games. Kekla Magoon manages a similar feat of legerdemain in Shadows of Sherwood, her compelling reboot of the Robin Hood myth.

title: In Kosovo, a Thirst for Progress, and Beer, Too
description: On weekends, Kosovos millennials dance to Smiths and New Order songs from the 1980s as if they were hearing them for the first time at the new Irish pub Miqt (facebook.com/MIQT.NET) in Pristina. The bar is by turns trendy and louche and hidden down one of the many bumpy, half-paved roads in Kosovos capital.

title: The Road Not Taken, by David Orr
description: David Orr has written the best popular explanation to date of the most popular poem in American history.

title: In Indonesia, Many Islands and Many Faces
description: In the second grade, I spent many hours with a World Book Encyclopedia, an opaque projector and a vast stretch of butcher paper tacked to the classroom wall. My goal was to trace a map of Indonesia. It was for a report, which probably mentioned that Indonesia was the worlds fourth most-populous country and the one with the most Muslims, and that it was covered in rice paddies and exports oil. But what I remember was the map itself: There were so many islands that even a professional tracer would have found the job taxing.

As for the Democrats, Hillary Rodham Clintons email remains the saga of the summer.

title: Federal Intervention in Schools? It Happens Less Than Critics Think

The House and Senate have both passed new versions of the No Child Left Behind Act of 2001, the controversial law that mandated standards, testing and accountability in public schools nationwide. In the coming weeks, lawmakers will try to forge a compromise that can pass the fractious House without drawing a veto from President Obama.

At the end of the lane, a ramshackle hut contains reverse osmosis pumps to concentrate the harvest. A stainless steel evaporator, about the size of a truck, finishes the conversion into maple syrup.

title: Baseballs Last Cuban Escapees
description: For foreign baseball players hoping to make it in America, just about every conceivable journey  the 1,300 miles from Venezuela, the 5,000 miles from Japan, the 7,000 miles from Australia  has been easier than the 90 short miles from Cuba. That trip, over the last 50 years, has involved almost mythic hardships: improvised rafts, drug lords, ransoms, death threats, forgery, machine guns on the high seas. And yet the Cuban players have come, drawn by the promise of freedom, glory and outrageous capitalist paydays.

title: Review: Fear the Walking Dead, a Show About a Plagues Start (What Zombies?)
description: Its either surprising or completely logical that The Walking Dead has become the most popular drama on television (by some measures) while also being one of the most unusual. The all-bets-are-off gore and violence made possible by its post-zombie-apocalypse scenario set it apart, of course. But even more distinctive are its dawdling rhythms, laconic performances and willingness to turn down the sound. Few shows, if any, are as quiet as The Walking Dead.

Once, we were great, inventive and nimble, always pressing fearlessly ahead in the name of progress. Eradicating polio, inventing the airplane, the chicken nugget, the music video. Going to the moon.

title: Egyptians Adapt as Cairo Is Redefined by a String of Bomb Attacks

Commuters say they have grown accustomed to changing their routes to avoid traffic snarled by the inevitable security cordons after each new explosion.

title: Gloria Steinem Marches On
description: A journalist from Ohio who once went undercover at Hugh Hefners Playboy Club for a story, Gloria Steinem emerged in the 70s as the aviator-shaded face  and de facto voice  of the womens movement. Her magazine, Ms., which she co-founded in 1971, was notable for being owned and operated entirely by women, and was one of the first mainstream publications to directly address the issues of reproductive rights and domestic violence. And while many of her detractors (Richard Nixon, Rush Limbaugh) have fallen by the wayside, Steinem remains relevant. Her forthcoming memoir, My Life on the Road, documents her travels as an activist, and, at 81, she is an icon for a new wave of celebrity feminists that includes Lena Dunham and Emma Watson. Here, a front-line look at Steinems legacy.

title: New Concerns in Tianjin Blast After Dead Fish Are Found

description: The Board of Transportation has taken the first step toward eliminating the unspeakable feminine disaster of runs in stockings caused by frayed strands and slivers in the woven rattan covering of subway seats, it was learned yesterday [Aug. 20]. A new type of seat, made of spongy plastic material that cannot fray, has been installed experimentally on car 1,208 of the Independent subway, and if it proves successful it may be used in all new subway cars and installed in old cars whenever they are reconditioned.  New York Herald Tribune, August 21, 1940

title: Ton-Caf Brings Georgian Cuisine to Gramercy Park
