title: Bama vs. Gators
description: BAY MINETTE, Ala.  When alligator season began last Thursday night in Alabama, those lucky enough to receive one of the states 260 prized hunting permits wondered if they might do what Mandy Stokes did last year. She and four others captured and killed the largest American alligator on record.

title: Trump Hotel Goes Up, and His Latino Views Barely Raise Eyebrows
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The Peruvian Nobel laureate Mario Vargas Llosa calls Donald J. Trump a racist imbecile. In Mexico, people are gleefully bashing Trump piatas after his caustic remarks about Latino immigrants in the United States. In Guatemala, a liquor company is putting up posters of Mr. Trump using a term that, when translated charitably, describes him as a jackass.

title: Doubt Is Raised Over Value of Surgery for Breast Lesion at Earliest Stage
description: As many as 60,000 American women each year are told they have a very early stage of breast cancer  Stage 0, as it is commonly known  a possible precursor to what could be a deadly tumor. And almost every one of the women has either a lumpectomy or a mastectomy, and often a double mastectomy, removing a healthy breast as well.

title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Looking for something fun to do?

title: The Rise and Fall of Shooting-Star Candidates
description: The G.O.P. presidential contest, barely a few weeks old, has been described in dizzying fashion. In Rolling Stone, Matt Taibbi called it Western civilizations very own car wreck. Roger Simon, writing for Politico, described it as Donald Trump mooning America while the Republican clown car careens around the country with no driver. And in The New York Times, Ross Douthat hoped the antics would produce more than just crazy cable-news entertainment.

title: Cafe Carlyle Kicks Off Season With Brian Stokes Mitchell
description: Caf Carlyle, the venerable cabaret in the Carlyle Hotel, has announced its fall season. It starts on Sept. 15 with the Broadway baritone Brian Stokes Mitchell, who is returning to nightclub performance in an all-new show. His residency, through Sept. 26, will be his first appearance in the room.

title: Reporter Joins Reddit Conversation on Prison Beating
description: The article Michael Winerip and I wrote this week about the death of an inmate at Fishkill Correctional Facility had a huge following on social media. For a while on Tuesday it was the top item on the Reddit home page, which Im told is a very big deal. It was another indication of how closely people pay attention to criminal justice issues these days.

description: In my outpatient exam room, we had arrived at that moment of silence that often marks the crossroads of unwelcome news and a difficult decision.

title: As Chase Utley Departs for Dodgers, a Look at the Phillies Fall
description: Not long ago, the Philadelphia Phillies were a formidable team. In 2008, they won their first World Series in 28 years and made the playoffs the next three seasons as well. They had power hitters, slick fielders and a strong rotation.

title: Brooklyn Man Convicted of 2003 Murder of Fairfield Student Will Get a New Hearing
description: John Giuca, the Brooklyn man convicted of the 2003 murder of a college football player, will receive a hearing in which prosecutors and his lawyers can revisit the evidence in the case, a judge ruled Thursday.

title: David Sweat, New York Prison Escapee, Is Arraigned
description: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y.  A New York prison escapee who was at the center of a three-week manhunt faced charges on Thursday in his first public appearance since his capture.

title: Banksys Latest: Dismaland Theme Park
description: LONDON  The graffiti artist Banksy has unveiled his latest exhibition, a haunted, anti-theme park called Dismaland, featuring his art and works by about 60 other artists.

description: ATHENS  Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece called Thursday for new national elections in a bid to consolidate his power and press ahead with the 86 billion euro bailout plan he agreed to with European creditors.

title: Can Black Art Ever Escape the Politics of Race?
description: For 18 months, the writer Richard Wright, late of Harlem and Biloxi, Miss., lay sick, then convalescent, then sick again, then dying, in France, writing thousands of haiku. This lasted from 1959 to 1960, years of chaos and promise and growth around the world, especially in Africa, where nation after nation threw off its colonial oppressors.

title: Thwarted in Russia, Gross Indecency: The Three Trials of Oscar Wilde Will Be Read at a Benefit in New York
description: Efforts to stage a gay-themed play about Oscar Wilde in Moscow foundered in June on the Russian governments hostility toward homosexuality and the use of foreign funds for artistic productions. Now, the New York-based theater company that was partnering in that project will hold a one-night-only, impressively cast benefit reading of the play in October in Manhattan to focus attention on what it calls Russias suppression of the rights of gays and lesbians.

title: 1965: Auschwitz Judge Weeps
description: FRANKFURT Twenty months to the day after it started, Germanys marathon Auschwitz trial came to an end this afternoon in a highly emotional heart-gripping tone.

title: David Baileys Latest Muse: a Tods Handbag
description: The prolific photographer David Bailey, known for capturing the likes of the Beatles and Andy Warhol in the 60s, turned his lens recently to an inanimate subject: the classic leather Tods Cape Bag. Tods asked me to imagine the bag in whatever way I wanted, says Bailey, whose summer photo exhibition, Stardust, was sponsored by the Italian house. For the first time in my career, a bag is the lead character in my work. Its not a fashion shoot, and its not editorial. Its really a portrait. Above is an exclusive first look at one of Baileys images, which he says show a womans intimate and profound connection with this very special object. The rest will debut online at tods.com beginning Aug. 31.

title: Uncertainty Looms Over The Undefeated, ESPNs Site on Sports and Race
description: More than two years into the gestation of The Undefeated, ESPNs website about sports and race, the site exists in digital limbo.

title: Viewfinder
description: Markus Brunettis painstakingly assembled photos of sacred spaces.

title: The Learning Network Offers Topical Crossword Puzzles For Students
description: SPECIAL POST  The Learning Network, a free blog about teaching and learning with The New York Times, has updated their student crosswords section. Teachers who have a subscription to the New York Times Crossword will enjoy sharing these topical puzzles, made by veteran Times constructor Frank Longo, with their students.

title: Jeffrey Ubben Buys Minority Stake in United Talent Agency
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywoods third-largest talent agency has sold a minority stake to the activist hedge fund operator Jeffrey Ubben and will use the money for expansion, including the immediate acquisition of a music agency.

title: Birmingham Bounce: Raising the Minimum Wage in the South
description: By a vote of 7 to 0 with one abstention, the city council of Birmingham, Ala. adopted a citywide minimum wage this week of $10.10 by 2017, with increases for inflation every year after that.

title: Nail Salon Sweeps Continue as Violations Are Found in Queens
description: The four investigators holding clipboards and clad in navy New York State jerseys descended on Lyns Nail Salon I on Thursday morning. The owner, Andy No Tran, scrambled to show his papers, and stammered when explaining just how many employees he had.

title: Overcoming Love Addiction: One Apple Martini at a Time
description: I appeared as a love addict on a live morning television talk show in Detroit in the late 1980s, when I was 28. The producer, whom I knew through my job as a New York City book publicist, arranged for me to fly out to be a guest, along with an author who had written a book on love addiction.

title: An Ashley Madison Recession? Or an Ashley Madison Stimulus?
description: The revelation of who opened accounts on the Ashley Madison site for adulterers got the attention of curiousity seekers and suspicious spouses. Josh Barro and Justin Wolfers had a different impulse. They wondered whether a surge in marital trouble resulting from the Ashley Madison hack could hurt the economy  or even, surprisingly, make it grow faster.

title: Two Sisters, Two Weddings, Too Much
description: My sister and I have both been in long-term relationships. She got engaged in February, and I in May. We are both planning weddings for next year. She picked her date, then I picked one two months before it. She is unhappy about this. She told me I should not get married within three months of her date, before or after, which blocks out six months of the year. But my fianc and I want the time of year we chose. Shouldnt more happy events make people happier?

title: Female Soldiers in Combat
Britain to Reopen Embassy in Iran, Nearly 4 Years After It Was Ransacked
description: LONDON  In a significant indication of warming Western relations with Iran after a deal limiting its nuclear program, Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond will reopen Britains embassy in Tehran, probably on Sunday, British officials said Thursday.

title: Tesla Stations at Airbnb Locations
description: Airbnb and Tesla Motors are starting a partnership to bring Tesla car charging stations to 30 Airbnb properties along the West Coast in cities such as Los Angeles, Palm Springs and Healdsburg, Calif. Tesla has donated and installed the stations that are meant to give travelers freedom on their road trips, according to Chip Conley, head of global hospitality and strategy at Airbnb. When considering accommodations, Tesla drivers are limited by how far they can get on their cars battery charge, but this partnership alleviates that constraint, he said.

title: 1895: Churchill in Cuba
description: This feature looks at some of the earliest mentions of famous names or terms in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Leave a suggestion in the comments section.

title: Escaped Prisoner Appears at Arraignment
description: David Sweat, an inmate who escaped in June, appeared in court on Thursday, charged with two counts of escape in the first degree, and one count of promoting prison contraband in the first degree.

title: Painstakingly Assembled Images of Sacred Spaces
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: A Day in the Life | Neville Jacobs
description: Marc Jacobss bull terrier spends a day at the office, where he goes on set with the stylist Carlyne Cerf de Dudzeele and works out with his French bulldog pal Charlie.

title: Accuser in St. Pauls Rape Case Defends Account in Cross-Examination
description: CONCORD, N.H.  The days cross-examination began with questions about oral sex, emails and uncomfortable laughter.

title: Marco Rubio Gives Hillary Clinton Staunch Challenge in Bellwether States, Poll Shows
description: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida could be the toughest Republican challenger for Hillary Rodham Clinton in three crucial swing states if the two were to face off in the general election, a new poll from Quinnipiac University has found.

title: Hytner and Starrs London Theater Company Chooses Site on the Thames for Its Home
description: LONDON  The London Theater Company  a commercial venture by Nicholas Hytner and Nick Starr, the former artistic director and executive director of the National Theater here  will open in the spring of 2017 in a 900-seat venue on Londons south bank, the company announced Thursday.

title: Who Is Marc Jacobs?
description: HI, IM MARC, says a smiling, shortish, muscular man in a very white shirt and black trousers with even whiter socks. He has a housekeeper (This is Reisa) and a personal chef (This is Lauren), but he answers the door of his West Village townhouse himself, at least when reporters come over. He looks 38 or 39 and is definitely Jewish, but maybe he could also be Greek. I thought it was so strange this morning, says Marc, who is not going to say anything stranger than the fact that hes actually 52, but Nick said, I left you a folder with Sarah, a picture of Sarah, and I was like, Why, so I wouldnt let someone else in the building? But no, the press office just did it. They put a picture of you, and like, who you wrote for. Like, as if that would change anything.

title: Can You Spot the Mimic?
description: Many species in nature mimic other organisms or features of their environment. Can you figure out which is the original and which is the mimic?

title: Evolving a Defense, Mimics Save Themselves
description: The Canadian tiger swallowtail caterpillar is a plump green creature that spends all its time munching leaves. It ought to be an easy meal for a bird, yet many birds pass it by.

title: Neither Rain Nor Snow Nor Gloom of Night Stays Amazon Deliveries
description: The giant e-marketeerAmazon may not have delivery drones in the air yet, but it does have letter carriers from local post offices busy delivering its packages to customers. In an innovative venture into e-commerce by the hard-pressed United States Postal Service, letter carriers in major cities have been making deliveries since October not only of the usual Amazon products but also of fresh milk, eggs,fish and other perishable commodities as Amazon continues its insatiable spread into the nations commercial aisles.

title: Universal Conquers the Box Office, Without a Superhero
description: No capes.

title: Palestinian Ends Hunger Strike, and His Condition Improves
description: A Palestinian hunger striker whose deteriorating health has posed a challenge to Israels policy of indefinite incarceration has agreed to give up his fast, one of his lawyers said Thursday as doctors said his condition had improved significantly.

title: Mayor de Blasio Raises Prospect of Removing Times Square Pedestrian Plazas
description: When New York City installed pedestrian plazas in Times Square six years ago, replacing traffic-choked streets with beach chairs and picnic tables, the move prompted civic controversy, late-night monologue jokes and, eventually, widespread praise as an influential innovation in urban design.

title: London Theater Journal: A Nonstop Carnival of Culpability
description: LONDON  Wine was very much on the menu on the third night of my summer visit to this city. Not for me. (Im still sticking to my anti-jetlag regimen of gallons of water and coffee.) But the juice of the grape was being extolled as absolutely essential to our daily diet at the Almeida Theater in Islington, where a riveting production of Euripidess Bakkhai was hypnotizing a packed house.

title: Jean-Marie Le Pen, Co-Founder of National Front, Is Ousted From French Far-Right Party
description: NANTERRE, France  Jean-Marie Le Pen, a co-founder of Frances far-right National Front, was expelled from the party on Thursday after he repeatedly angered its current leader, his daughter Marine, by reviving the partys anti-Semitic past, which she is eager to shed.

title: Once Voters Get the Narrative, Jeb Bush Says, Theyll Turn to Him Over Donald Trump
description: KEENE, N.H.  The day after dueling New Hampshire town-hall-style meetings left Jeb Bush the recipient of snide attacks from Donald J. Trump, Mr. Bush offered some not-so-friendly fire of his own.

title: Airstrikes Kill 43 Militants in Northwestern Pakistan, Military Says
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani military said Thursday that its ground troops had begun moving into Shawal, the last area in the North Waziristan tribal region to feel the force of the militarys offensive against militants.

title: Exploring Assisi in Italy
description: A new kind of tourist is being drawn by the same mystical essence that more traditional religious pilgrims believe can be felt in the woods around Francis hometown.

title: Bad Singing and Fire Eating: Actors on Their Special Skills
description: Look past the eyes, hair and height. Keep scanning down, after the college Hamlet and the regional Little Shop of Horrors. There, at the bottom of almost any actors rsum, in small letters, is a list of tricks that reads like an especially manic night at The Ed Sullivan Show. Acrobatics, martial arts, hula hoop: just some of the unusual and quirky kinds of expertise found under the category of Special Skills.

title: Request for Grand Jury Records in Eric Garner Case Is Rejected
description: A Staten Island judge on Thursday rejected a request from the Civilian Complaint Review Board for grand jury records related to the case of Eric Garner, who died last year after a police officer used a chokehold while trying to arrest him on suspicion of selling loose cigarettes.

title: Jeb Bush Cites Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio in Defending Birthright Citizenship
description: NEW LONDON, N.H.  Jeb Bush invoked the names of two rivals for the Republican presidential nomination as he waded into the debate over birthright citizenship and immigration on Thursday, saying that Senators Ted Cruz of Texas and Marco Rubio of Florida might not be able to run for president if some in the conservative wing of the Republican Party had their way.

title: Coca-Cola to Disclose Its Spending on Research Into Soft Drinks and Health
description: Coca-Cola says it will begin disclosing its investments in scientific research and advocacy about the impact sugary soft drinks have on public health.

title: Drought Brings Soul-Searching to California Winemaking
description: St. HELENA, Calif.  At the rustic Smith-Madrone Vineyards high up on Spring Mountain, nobody has been thinking about the drought, which has absorbed so much of the conversation about California this year.

title: Movie Review: Grandma
description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews Grandma.

title: Seventeen Transgender Killings Contrast With Growing Visibility
description: The brutal death of a 36-year-old transgender woman in Kansas City, Mo., is the latest in what activists are calling an alarming rise in anti-transgender violence.

title: Pictures of the Day: The United States and Elsewhere
description: The United States and More  Pictures of the Day

title: August 20, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photographs from The United States, Indonesia, Egypt and Spain.

title: Daughter-in-Law of Senator Skelos Is Arrested in Domestic Dispute on Long Island
description: The family of State Senator Dean G. Skelos, who was arrested on federal corruption charges in May with his son Adam, has some new legal troubles, though of a different order of magnitude.

title: Top 15 Fantasy Football Running Backs
description: Jason and Justin Sablich, who provide fantasy football analysis for The New York Times, pick their 15 favorite running backs for 2015.

title: Tracking a Rare Nautilus in Papua New Guinea
description: These ancient creatures with big shells are so good at hiding from researchers that they went decades without a definitive sighting.

title: Investors Hope to Ride Swell of SoulCycle Fever in Coming I.P.O.
description: Early on a summer morning in Manhattans Upper East Side, dozens of mostly young, svelte women file into a quiet, candlelit studio where they mount gleaming stationary bikes. Soft clicks can be heard as they fasten their shoes to the pedals.

title: Spokesman for Hillary Clinton Offers New Take on Email Issue
description: As Brian Fallon, Hillary Rodham Clintons press secretary, defended her on Wednesday during a conference call about her email use, he made a novel argument that got lost in the haze of questions.

title: Recipes From the Four Horsemens One-Month Anniversary Staff Meal
description: Earlier this summer, at noon on what may have been the hottest day of the year, the buzzy new Brooklyn restaurant and wine bar the Four Horsemen hadnt yet opened its doors for service  they usually serve from the late afternoon until late at night  but three tables had been pushed together and were being set for a feast. The restaurant, which debuted in June, is a collaboration between the consultant Justin Chearno and partners Randy Moon, Christina Topsoe and her husband, the musician James Murphy  who invited the rest of their staff and collaborators to celebrate something of a milestone: making it past the one-month mark and finally having a moment to breathe.

title: Breast Cancer Treatment and D.C.I.S.: Answers to Questions About New Findings
description: Q. What is D.C.I.S.?

title: HP Profit Falls in Last Report Before Company Splits
description: Hewlett-Packard said on Thursday that its profit fell 13 percent in the third quarter, a reminder of the grim challenges prompting a breakup of the company in the coming months.

title: Greek Prime Minister Resigns
description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece announced Thursday that he would resign after less than a year in office and that new elections would be called.

title: Review: In Guidance, a High School Counselor as a Rotten Role Model
description: Stay out of the sun, a doctor warns David (Pat Mills) early in Guidance, a ferociously black comedy about growing older without growing up. On the heels of a diagnosis of Stage 3 melanoma, David makes a beeline for the tanning salon, cigarette in hand. Hes not in shock, hes in denial.

title: Royal Hawaiian Featherwork, a Glimpse at Island Splendors
description: Since at least the 15th century, collectors have competed for feathers sewn and glued onto fabrics, jewelry, fans and statues. New books and exhibitions have reunited widely scattered feathered objects made in Latin America and the Pacific islands, and growing archival evidence shows that the birds used for raw materials were treated relatively well  that is, plucked sustainably.

title: A Rich Lode of American Ceramics Discoveries
description: The Industrial Revolution drove countless American ceramics workshops out of business. Traces of these wares, whether well-preserved porcelain cups or smashed storage jars, are inspiring lectures and exhibitions.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Review: Aaron Flint Jamisons Craft of Technology
description: AARON FLINT JAMISON

title: Review: Portraiture Now, a Group Show of Latino Artists
description: PORTRAITURE NOW

title: Cadillac Has New Boss, New Address and Big Plans
description: Can a South African-born former Audi executive, who recently spurned Japanese masters in Hong Kong, lead a Detroit luxury brand back to greatness  and from a new base in Manhattan?

title: Review: Empty House Casa Vazia Highlights Brazilian Artists
description: EMPTY HOUSE CASA VAZIA

title: Review: Tamuna Sirbiladze Combines Art and Decoration at Half Gallery
description: TAMUNA SIRBILADZE

title: FanFest, for Yankees Stalwarts of All Ages
description: The Yankees are taking over Little Italy. And not just on TV screens in bars and restaurants. Mulberry Street, from Canal to Broome Streets, will become a pop-up village for Yankees devotees as part of the annual FanFest, presented by the radio station WFAN.

title: Podcast: Inside The Timess Political Coverage
description: What presidential candidates warrant what kind of coverage?

title: Review: Faile Mines the Dark Depths of Modern Youth With Two Exhibitions
description: The title of an exhibition by the two-artist team Faile at the Brooklyn Museum is certainly promising: Savage/Sacred Young Minds. Considering American societys neurotic preoccupation with youth and the hugely profitable exploitation of that obsession by a vast array of commercial enterprises, its a potentially rich vein for imaginative mining. In recent decades, artists like Mike Kelley and Jim Shaw have fruitfully excavated the weird, dark side of adolescent consciousness to reveal its narcissism, hypersexuality, grandiosity, and penchants for magical thinking and instant gratification.

title: First Draft Focus: Throwback Thursday, With Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter
Things to Do in Connecticut, Aug. 23 to 29, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Aug. 23 to 29, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Coming Up Red
description: A 1908 exhibition series introduced the Cincinnati Reds to its first class of baseball players from Cuba, and the team has had an eye for the islands talent ever since.

title: Western Wildfires Consume Manpower and Acreage
description: CHELAN, Wash.  Firefighters often talk about wildfires as living things, each one different in its inherently dangerous behavior and fickle shifts of temper. They are so unpredictable that even a seemingly mundane part of the day  getting to the job  can turn deadly.

title: Jets Reserve Lineman Suspended One Game
description: Oday Aboushi, a reserve offensive lineman for the Jets, was suspended one game for violating the N.F.L.s substance-abuse policy and program. He was the second member of the team to receive a drug-related ban, joining Sheldon Richardson, who was docked four games after testing positive at least twice for marijuana.

title: Review: In Sinister 2, a Murderous Being Returns for More Mayhem
description: In Sinister, from 2012, a true-crime writer (Ethan Hawke) moved his family into a house that had been the site of a multiple murder. In the attic he discovered grainy home-movie-like films of other killings. He also met a pagan entity, Bughuul, who in whisking the souls of children to a nether realm, creates minions who do his homicidal bidding.

title: Review: L.A. Dance Projects Tale of Murder, Sprightly and With Sneakers
description: BECKET, Mass.  L.A. Dance Project came east to Jacobs Pillow here on Wednesday with three works in tow and a new associate artistic director: the exceptional, recently retired Pacific Northwest Ballet principal Carla Krbes. The companys Pillow performance also coincided with the final appearances of another esteemed dancer, Charlie Hodges, who served as the groups rehearsal director.

title: Movie Review: Sinister 2
description: The Times critic Andrew Webster reviews Sinister 2.

title: Egon Bahr, Who Laid Groundwork for German Reunification, Dies at 93
description: Egon Bahr, a prominent Social Democrat whose efforts to improve West Germanys relations with the Soviet bloc helped pave the way for German reunification 45 years after World War II, has died, the party announced on Thursday. He was 93.

title: Credit Scores Are Rising, and Becoming More Visible
description: Consumers appear to be better these days at managing their use of credit: Average scores have reached new highs and delinquent payments have dropped.

title: Afropunk Festival Brings Music, Dancing and Haute Street Fashion to Brooklyn
description: Eleven years in, Afropunk Fest, Brooklyns weekend-long blowout celebration of the diaspora of black music and culture, is more wide-ranging than ever. Its now possible to imagine the skate kids and fashion bloggers who populate the scene coming with their parents to catch headliners including Grace Jones, Lenny Kravitz and Gary Clark Jr. Up-and-coming acts like Raury, rap stars (Danny Brown) and punkers (Death Grips) are also on the bill for the festival, with doors opening Saturday at noon at Commodore Barry Park in Fort Greene; expect food trucks, on-site mural painting, interactive art and a dance-friendly D.J. stage.

title: Review: Kamasi Washington and the West Coast Get Down Are Blowing Through Town
description: WOODSTOCK, N.Y.  Kamasi Washington blew his tenor saxophone in heavy gusts  rangy and intemperate, or clipped and urgent  throughout the exultant sprawl of his concert at the Bearsville Theater here on Wednesday night. His sound assumed an almost tactile force in the room, an extension of his burly and stoic presence onstage. And yet that sound wasnt the most impressive facet of the performance, which ran a little over two hours, with an intuitive, almost constant ebb and flow. What really drove the agenda was the smart, hurtling fury of Mr. Washingtons band, the West Coast Get Down, a Los Angeles demolition crew partway through its first tour. Among the remaining dates are two at the Blue Note in New York City, on Monday and Tuesday.

title: Review: In American Ultra, Jesse Eisenberg Is a Stoner and a Target
description: Some of the many, many promotional spots for American Ultra make it seem like more of a comedy than it is. Thats not said as a criticism, just a warning. If you go, expect a diverting summer action adventure with occasional laughs, not a diverting stoner comedy with occasional action.

title: In His First New York Show in Five Years, Shepard Fairey Is Still Questioning Everything
description: On Sept. 18, the street artist Shepard Fairey will open his first solo show in New York since 2010s Mayday  the suitably colossal closing exhibition at the now-defunct Deitch Projects. Faireys latest offering, a series of new mixed-media paintings titled On Our Hands, will serve as his inaugural exhibition at Jacob Lewis Gallery, effectively consummating a 10-year friendship between the artist and Mr. Lewis, the gallerys owner and the first director of the influential Pace Prints in Chelsea. Jacob looks at every aspect of what the artist is doing, not just the genre, the price or how in fashion you are, notes Fairey from his studio in Los Angeles, where he continues to finalize the collection. If you look at the other artists hes worked with, whether its Ryan McGinness or How and Nosm, theyre the only people doing what they do.

title: Movie Review: American Ultra
description: The Times critic Neil Genzlinger reviews American Ultra.

title: A German Artist Colony, Suspended in Time, Stakes a Place in the Contemporary Scene
description: How large the eyes become here! They want at all times to possess the whole sky, wrote the young poet Rainer Maria Rilke in 1900. He had just arrived at Worpswede, the fabled artist colony on a stretch of German moorland so flat it becomes almost round as the view curves along the earths surface with scarcely a foothill, mountain or other perpendicular obstruction in sight.

title: Review: Can I Go Now?, a Biography of the Hollywood Agent Sue Mengers
description: The biographer Brian Kellow, whose last subject was Pauline Kael, writes in Can I Go Now? that even he had doubts about whether the Hollywood agent Sue Mengers would make a good subject. The idea of doing a book about her came from his agent. And even allowing for any prejudices an agent might have about how interesting agents are, it was still a stretch. Ms. Mengers may have been the most glam, powerful, status-conscious, star-snuggling Hollywood power broker of the 1970s, but both she and her way of doing business had gone the way of the dinosaurs by the end of that decade. Now she is Sue Who? to the world at large.

title: This Weeks Movies | August 21, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review American Ultra, Grandma and Sinister 2.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, Aug. 23 to 29, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Theater Listings for Aug. 21-27
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: One Wall, Two Germanys
description: Before the fall of the Berlin Wall, Rudi Meisel spent a decade photographing East and West Germany with a subtle take that made it hard sometimes to tell one side from the other.

title: New Surge of MERS Infections Hits Saudi Arabia
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Saudi Arabia is facing a new surge in cases of Middle East respiratory syndrome, a viral disease that has infected more than 1,100 people and killed more than 480 in the kingdom since it appeared in 2012.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, Aug. 23 to 29, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Migrants in Kos Inspire Both Hospitality and Anger in Greeks
description: KOS, Greece  Dawn was breaking over a beach near Kos harbor, and the first swimmers threaded their way between orange beach umbrellas into the sea.

title: 2 Graduating Rangers, Aware of Their Burden
description: FORT BENNING, Ga.  First Lt. Shaye Haver, an Apache attack helicopter pilot who on Friday will be one of the first women to graduate from the Armys elite Ranger School, wants to remain an aviator. But she takes away weighty lessons from her grueling Ranger training: Your mind can take a whole lot more than your body, she said.

title: Classical & Opera Listings for Aug. 21-27
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Aug. 21-27
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: A Place to Nap After Wine Tasting
description: Visitors to Italian vineyards are often treated to lavish wine-tastings, four-course lunches and, sometimes, a walk around 15th-century grounds. But soon after a big meal, one is faced with a challenge: How to drive back to the hotel? Now, three famous vineyards in Tuscany and Abruzzo have solved this quandary by opening hotel rooms  newly refurbished, and often little-advertised  on the vineyard grounds.

title: Jazz Listings for Aug. 21-27
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: Digging for Fire, a Comedy by Joe Swanberg
description: Digging for Fire, Joe Swanbergs new feature is, like many of his previous movies, a case study in heterosexual ethics. Its scope is narrow and, the title notwithstanding, it plumbs no great depths. But like Mr. Swanbergs Drinking Buddies and Happy Christmas, the film has an appealing honesty and an enjoyably low-key comic style.

title: Natures Lesson on Understanding Ellsworth Kelly
description: Ellsworth Kelly, renowned maker of abstract, odd-shaped monochromatic paintings, has said that he developed his eye for color and form as a bird watcher when he was a child in rural New Jersey. You can see evidence of this history: in the indigo bunting blue of Blue Panel I from 1977; in the pointed angles, like crests on northern cardinals, of Red-Orange Panel from 1980; and in the snowy span, like egret wings, of Memorial from 1993. Or at least you can start to see it once youve come to grips with other, more obvious features of Mr. Kellys art: its radical simplicity, its merger of painting and sculpture, its romance with architecture, its contribution to the history of modernism. But all of this absorbing takes time, the way bird watching does.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: Comedy Listings for Aug. 21-27
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: New York Police Sergeant Commits Suicide After Sex-Crime Charges
description: A New York police sergeant who was arrested this month on charges that he had sex with an underage girl he met online committed suicide on Thursday, the police said.

title: Bronx Legionnaires Outbreak Is Over, Health Officials Say
description: New York City health officials on Thursday declared an outbreak of Legionnaires disease in the South Bronx officially over, saying that no new cases had been reported since Aug. 3.

title: Movie Listings for Aug. 21-27
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Review: Rupert Friend and Zachary Quinto in a Pas de Bullets, Hitman: Agent 47
description: Dumb as dirt and just as generic, Hitman: Agent 47 trades brains for bullets and characters for windup toys. So its all the more shocking that honest-to-goodness actors like Zachary Quinto and Rupert Friend have signed on to play the films two leads; maybe the director, Aleksander Bach, told them they could have a lifetime supply of their smoking-hot suits.

title: Dance Listings for Aug. 21-27
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Aug. 21-27
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Spare Times for Aug. 21-27
description: Museums and Sites

title: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 21-27
description: 239th Anniversary of the Battle of Brooklyn

title: First Female Ranger School Graduates
description: First Lt. Shaye Haver and Capt. Kristen Griest attended a news conference alongside fellow students who will graduate from the Armys grueling Ranger School.

title: Judge Says Hillary Clinton Didnt Follow Government Email Policies
description: A federal judge on Thursday said that Hillary Rodham Clinton did not comply with government policies in her exclusive use of a personal email account while she was secretary of state, challenging her longstanding position that she abided by the rules.

title: Force Majeure Explores Couples Expectations as Gender Roles Shift
description: The ever-shifting expectations of husbands and wives has rarely been explored with more depth than in the Swedish director Ruben Ostlunds scalding, satirically edged 2014 film, Force Majeure. In this drama of marital disruption during a luxurious ski vacation in the French Alps, the fragile male ego is subjected to relentless microscopic examination.

title: The Merode Altarpiece at the Cloisters Represents Time Immemorial
description: The Merode Altarpiece,  a triptych at the Cloisters, ranks among the worlds most beautiful paintings. Produced in the South Netherlands workshop of Robert Campin between 1427 and 1432, its also a time machine that shuttles the mind across millenniums while orchestrating a convergence of the natural and the supernatural.

title: Review: The Iron Ministry Uses Train Passengers to Tell Chinas Story
description: If a pop culture web publication ever asked me to make a list of the most cinematic forms of transportation, the train would be at the top, probably followed by the horse. Car chases are cool and everything, but the very first publicly shown movie (at least according to legend) was about a train. Trains on film are both sublime and intimate: The camera can trace the muscular movement of railway cars across the land or venture inside to observe the complicated actions of people in motion.

title: Vintage Sax Solo Improves With (Listeners) Age
description: Charlie Parker, the matchless alto saxophonist and bebop exemplar, had few better days in a recording studio than March 28, 1946. He was in Hollywood, leading his first session under an exclusive contract with Dial Records. His handpicked sidemen included the well-seasoned tenor saxophonist Lucky Thompson and a young trumpeter named Miles Davis, and by the end of the date they had recorded several of Parkers most canonical tracks, including A Night in Tunisia and Yardbird Suite.

title: A Shakespeare for All Seasons
description: For many theatergoers, summer is the season of Shakespeare, in the way its the season of corn and tomatoes for those who want these foods fresh from the garden. Like such comestibles, Shakespeare can be devoured in hearty single sittings  and often alfresco  what with a crop of productions that present the theatrical equivalent of a jolly picnic. For New Yorkers, an abundance of movable feasts is available, from city parks and parking lots to more sylvan environs upstate. (On my August schedule: yet another Hamlet, this one starring Benedict Cumberbatch, in London.)

title: Frederick Wisemans Documentaries Defy Straightforward Plot
description: The closer it hews to the conventions of journalism, the more documentary filmmaking becomes an art of compression and acceleration. You know the drill. A social problem is explored, a famous or obscure persons life story is told, a historical episode is illuminated, in a familiar rhythm and pace. Talking-head interviews alternate with archival clips or re-enactments, all in the service of an argument or a plot. Usually its all over in about 90 minutes, and you take away a neat little package of outrage, empathy or enlightenment. Even long-form documentaries, like The Jinx, Andrew Jareckis mini-series on the alleged crimes of Robert Durst, follow this formula, in that they depend on the quickening of the viewers attention.

title: Holding Off Emily Dickinsons Complete Poems
description: Im embarrassed by how long I resisted Emily Dickinsons Complete Poems, and Im struck by how much my copy means to me now. As a daft young punk I too often sought out reckless emotion and vulgar effects, the same way one sometimes wants, when callow and feckless, to date a person with obvious physical attributes. Dickinsons famous line  Im nobody! Who are you?  is not what you want to hear when you are younger than 30, or, in my delayed maturity, closer to 40. It should have helped, but did not, when one of my favorite high school English teachers, Donald Glancy, explained that you could sing nearly all of Dickinsons verse to the tune of The Yellow Rose of Texas.

title: Eliane Radigue, Mining Wisdom From 11th-Century Buddhism
description: I came pretty late to Jetsun Mila, by the French composer Eliane Radigue, but it may be one of those things a lot of people will feel fine about coming to pretty late. Turn it on, and it just keeps teaching.

title: Awakening to the Joys of The Sleeping Beauty
description: At the age of 35, I tried counting. I found Id seen the ballet The Sleeping Beauty 200 times. That was 1990, precisely a century after the composer Tchaikovsky and the choreographer Marius Petipa had first presented it in St. Petersburg. Since then, Ive watched it on many more occasions  10 so far in 2015 alone.

title: Another Definition for Extended Play
description: I like a short show. A 90-minute play means more time to write, more time to relax, a chance to see my husband before he goes to sleep, no tedious intermission. But I also have a sneaking fondness for longer plays. Much, much, much longer ones.

title: Mondrians Paintings and Their Pulsating Intricacy
description: The longer I look at Mondrians paintings, the more I see in them. This applies to lots of art, but I think Mondrian built real time into his paintings. They unfold with unusual deliberation in a semblance of symmetry and order that is actually precarious, even volatile. This is especially true of his mature works from the late 1920s to the early 1940s, with their tensile fusions of glowing white backgrounds, black scaffoldings and blocks of bright primaries. Everything about them, the tiniest decision, is evident and has visual repercussions.

title: Revisiting The X-Files, a Series Worth Another Watch
description: Television is not an art of slow contemplation. Watching it in real time is more or less a requirement. (My DVR offers slow-motion playback, which has its uses, but theyre not artistic.)

title: Its Always Sunny in Philadelphia Converts a Skeptic
description: For years I was put off by the unrelenting crudeness of the television comedy Its Always Sunny in Philadelphia. In 2011 I wrote a minute-by-minute comparison of its Season 7 premiere with the Season 3 premiere of another crass show, Blue Mountain State, assessing which was more vulgar. It was a tongue-in-cheek article, but the tsk-tsking undertone was undeniable.

title: For Bruckners Seventh Symphony, a Long Delayed Appreciation
description: By the time I was a music major in college, with all the composers of the past competing for my attention, I had decided I could take a pass on Anton Bruckner. Many great artists, including the conductor Bruno Walter, whom I idolized, championed Bruckner (1824-1896) as a master Austrian symphonist. But from my impatient samplings of those symphonies, Bruckner struck me as a kind of ponderously monumental Brahms, or an inert and stretched-out Mahler.

title: Running the Alps
description: A Swiss mountain guide crossed five 4,000-meter peaks in less than eight hours this month.

title: Review: Learning to Drive Charts a Culture-Bridging Friendship
description: Among the charms of Learning to Drive, a small, observant dual portrait of a New York book critic and her Indian-American driving instructor, are the detailed, lived-in performances of its stars, Patricia Clarkson and Ben Kingsley. The film belongs to a school of grown-up, low-drama two-handers, of which the most famous example is Driving Miss Daisy, but Learning to Drive isnt half as sentimental. As this movie, directed by Isabel Coixet, tracks the deepening friendship between people from different cultures and backgrounds, it acquires an unforced metaphorical resonance.

title: Kazakhstans Currency Plunges
description: MOSCOW  Kazakhstans currency, the tenge, plunged by about a quarter on Thursday after the central bank stopped managing the exchange rate, prompting fears that a wider emerging market currency rout could be coming.

title: Review: Hapless Brothers and Their Lovers Intersect in The Mend
description: Funny, rugged and raw, The Mend fits its story together from rough patches in the lives of two nose-diving New York brothers. Mat (Josh Lucas) is a freeloader (and sometime jerk) who is thrown out of the house by his girlfriend, Andrea (Lucy Owen). The slow-burning Alan (Stephen Plunkett) is treading water with his girlfriend, Farrah (Mickey Sumner), and hopes to take a big step when they are on a planned trip together. Directing his first feature after some shorts, John Magary digs into his characters with fresh eyes and a sly sense of adventure.

title: The Art of Slow
description: Cultural critics of The New York Times suggest works that reward long and leisurely contemplation.

title: Writers Room: Jeanette Winterson
description: Inside the novelists rustic writing studio in Glouchestershire, England.

title: Female Viagra Poses Challenges for Buyer Valeant
description: Valeant Pharmaceuticals is popping a risky $1 billion libido pill.

title: Review: Shes Funny That Way Offers Tomfoolery Amid the Floodlights
description: If only the title of Shes Funny That Way were true, then maybe this creaky throwback padded with Hollywood names and fake accents could be forgiven its many failings. But theres barely a whiz-bang punch line or smoothly executed setup to be found in a movie that longs to be a sparkling bedroom comedy and winds up a tortured, fizz-free farce.

title: Gay Couples Are Eligible for Social Security Benefits, U.S. Decides
description: Same-sex married couples who were living in states that did not recognize their unions and who previously filed claims for Social Security benefits will be able to collect those payments, the government said on Thursday.

title: Review of Saltbox Restaurant & Bar in Montauk, in the OMurphys Pub Space
description: At first glance, Saltbox Restaurant & Bar in Montauk would seem to be an easy target for local skeptics.

title: Ornithology, From The Complete Dial Modern Jazz Sessions
description: A track including a tenor saxophone solo by Lucky Thompson.

title: Human Resources: Reality TV About a Recycling Company
description: If viewers who tuned into the second season of the workplace reality show Human Resources on Pivot this month came away feeling vindicated for Tony Rossi, the new guy who proved himself on trivia night, or relieved for Dan Harris, the sales director who scored an important new account, Tom Szaky, their boss, wouldnt mind.

title: Jarryd Hayne, Australian Rugby Star, Gives 49ers a Needed Jolt of Optimism
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  For a franchise in need of distraction, the Australian Jarryd Hayne arrived just in time.

title: New York Schools With Many Students Who Skipped Tests Wont Lose Money
description: School districts will not be penalized for having large numbers of students refuse to sit for the New York State standardized tests this year, education officials said on Thursday, ending months of uncertainty over how they would respond to a growing antitesting movement.

title: Review: Axia Taverna in Tenafly Is Home to Old-School Greek Dishes
description: The scene at Axia Taverna is so lively that its easy to forget that the mood in Greece  the country that inspired the restaurants cuisine and relaxed, joyous atmosphere  is probably more strained because of the current economic crisis. Everyone at Axia, including staff members, many of whom are from the Mediterranean country, seems to be in celebration mode. The crowds of regulars coming through the oversize wooden front door and the lively traditional music add to the energy.

title: Brazil: House Speaker Is Charged
description: Prosecutors on Thursday filed corruption charges against Eduardo Cunha, the speaker of the lower house of Congress and one of Brazils most powerful political figures. Investigators said that Mr. Cunha, 56, a conservative evangelical Christian radio commentator who broke from President Dilma Rousseffs governing coalition, was involved in a money-laundering operation that was part of a graft scheme at Petrobras, the national oil company. His problems intensified in July when a consultant for a Petrobras contractor testified that Mr. Cunha had solicited and accepted a $5 million bribe. Mr. Cunha says that he is innocent and that he will remain in his post. The Supreme Court will decide whether he will stand trial.

title: The Painted Ladies of Times Square Are Part of an Old New York Tradition
description: One Saturday afternoon this past winter, when my family and I were having lunch at the Metropolitan Museum of Art during a ritual viewing of mummies and armor with our 5-year-old son, I noticed a young man a few tables away staring at us. He had a notebook and began to sketch; he drew intensely and quickly. I was flattered and vaguely unsettled; he looked like someone in a Todd Solondz movie perhaps up to something not entirely sane.

title: Two New Cosby Accusers Step Forward in New York
description: Two new accusers came forward on Thursday to add their names to the list of women with allegations of drugging or sexual assault against the entertainer Bill Cosby. They spoke at a news conference in New York held by the lawyer Gloria Allred, who is representing more than 20 other Cosby accusers.

title: Review: Some Kind of Beautiful Stars Pierce Brosnan as a Serial Seducer
description: The execrable romantic comedy Some Kind of Beautiful is the kind of embarrassment a studio dumps into the market in August while hoping no one will notice. Directed by Tom Vaughan from a screenplay by Matthew Newman, this witless, offensively sexist farrago stars a flabby Pierce Brosnan as Richard Haig, a self-satisfied professor of English romantic poetry at Cambridge and a serial womanizer who sleeps with his students. When his latest girlfriend, Kate (Jessica Alba), an American, informs him shes pregnant, he promptly throws up.

title: George Houser, Freedom Rides Pioneer and a Founder of CORE, Dies at 99
description: The Rev. George M. Houser, a founder of the Congress of Racial Equality who was believed to be the last living member of the inaugural Freedom Ride  the volatile, sometimes violent bus trip through the South by a racially mixed group in 1947  died on Wednesday in Santa Rosa, Calif. He was 99.

title: The Scene of a Nail Salon Sweep
description: Investigators from a New York State task force went through nail salons checking for health, safety and wage violations.

title: Review: In Youth, Strains of Family and Country Fall on Brothers Shoulders
description: Yaki and Shaul Cooper, teenage siblings played by the brothers David and Eitan Cunio in the Israeli film Youth look almost identical but for the fact that the 18-year-old Yaki, the older of the two, has scruffy facial hair. Their bond is so primal that when embracing, they resemble wrestlers standing head-to-head before trying to throw each other to the floor. You have the eerie sense of observing two halves of a severed whole struggling to reunite and break apart at the same time.

title: Review: A Despairing Librarian Is Ready to Check Out in After Words
description: In September, television viewers will have a chance to see Marcia Gay Harden play a brusque, decisive, rule-bending doctor in the new CBS drama Code Black. Anyone who wants to see her play more or less the polar opposite of that character is hereby referred to After Words, a romance novel of a movie featuring the worlds most stereotypical librarian.

title: Review: Being Evel Examines the Life of a Notorious Stuntman
description: Theres something fundamentally American about the stunt motorcyclist Evel Knievel, as this latest informative documentary by Daniel Junge (a director of the Oscar-winning Saving Face) demonstrates. Robert Craig Knievel (1938-2007)  police officers tired of his persistent minor offenses created his nickname when he was growing up in Butte, Mont.  was determined to transcend humble origins.

title: Nelson Peltz Picks Up Seats on Syscos Board Days After Buying a Stake
description: Less than a week after emerging as a big investor in Sysco, the activist investor Nelson Peltz has gained seats on the food service companys board.

title: Review: In The Boy, an Unnerving 9-Year-Old Makes His Move
description: There are engrossing elements in Craig William Macneills The Boy, the tale of a creepy motel (no, its not Psycho) and a child sociopath (no, not The Bad Seed). Building on their Sundance short Henley, Mr. Macneill and his co-screenwriter, Clay McLeod Chapman, have developed a feature stunning to behold if somewhat unpersuasive in narrative.

title: In Letter, Obama Tells Congress U.S. Will Still Press Iran
description: WASHINGTON  In his most comprehensive effort to assure wavering Democrats, President Obama wrote in a letter to Congress that the United States would unilaterally maintain economic pressure and deploy military options if needed to deter Iranian aggression, both during and beyond the proposed nuclear accord.

title: China Woes Send Stocks Into Tailspin
description: Stock markets around the world plummeted on Thursday, signaling that investors have not gotten over the shock of Chinas devaluation last week and remain nervous about the health of the global economy.

title: Searching for Home, a Cross-Generational Look at Military Veterans
description: The oddest thing about Searching for Home: Coming Back From War is how often the military men interviewed talk about having been surprised that real war wasnt like the movies. They make a Korean War veteran seem like a master of emotional distance and control when he sticks to real-life parallels in a speech about his memories.

title: Frederick Payne, Decorated Fighter Ace in the Pacific, Dies at 104
description: Frederick Payne, a retired Marine Corps brigadier general who was honored for his exploits as a fighter pilot in the Pacific in World War II, died on Aug. 6 at his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 104 and the oldest of Americas surviving fighter aces.

title: Dropping Mild Tone, Jeb Bush Assails Donald Trump as Leaning Democratic
description: KEENE, N.H.  After weeks of parrying Donald J. Trumps derisive thrusts with elliptical, indirect and sparing responses, Jeb Bush aggressively attacked Mr. Trump here on Thursday, portraying him as a Democratic-leaning poseur in the Republican field and expressing confidence that voters would come to the same conclusion.

title: Deez Nuts for President? Why Not, Says Iowa Farm Boy
description: The presidential candidate Deez Nuts was surging on Wednesday in a poll, albeit unscientific, in North Carolina.

title: New Methods for Cancer May Benefit Jimmy Carters Fight
description: President Jimmy Carter, who disclosed Thursday that he has metastatic melanoma, is in a position to benefit from promising new approaches to attacking cancer, including a drug approved less than a year ago.

title: Responding to Rocket Fire, Israeli Forces Carry Out Strikes in Syria
description: JERUSALEM  Four rockets fired from Syrian territory landed in the Israeli-held part of the Golan Heights and in Israels Upper Galilee on Thursday, prompting Israeli retaliatory strikes against more than a dozen Syrian posts, according to the Israeli military.

title: U.N. Details Sexual Abuse Claims Against Troops
description: The United Nations disclosed new details on Thursday about a series of sexual abuse allegations against its peacekeepers in the Central African Republic, saying that nine of the 13 cases reported in the past year involved children as young as 11 and that no one had yet been convicted.

title: B&H Dairy in the East Village Reopens After Months of Red Tape
description: At lunchtime Thursday, there wasnt an empty stool or seat to be had at B&H Dairy, a venerable 400-square-foot restaurant in the East Village that survived the Second Avenue gas explosion in March but appeared doomed when it was bound and gagged in red tape. The place managed to reopen a few days ago, and everyone has come back. To go from the front door to the back, you had to walk sideways.

title: Gas Line Explodes During Construction at a Manhattan High School
description: A gas line exploded during construction at John F. Kennedy High School in the Marble Hill section of Manhattan on Thursday night, critically injuring three workers and heavily damaging three floors, the authorities said.

title: Concussion Deal Is Challenged in Court as Insufficient
description: According to a friend-of-the-court brief filed Thursday, the settlement between the N.F.L. and the 5,000 retired players who accused the league of hiding the dangers of concussions is flawed because it does not cover the full range of physical and psychiatric disorders linked to brain trauma.

title: Topless in Times Square: A Legal View
description: The young women approach tourists in Times Square and pose for photos, wearing nothing but a thong and a feathered headdress, their bare breasts painted with patriotic colors in a thin simulation of a bikini top. Then they ask for a tip.

title: Odell Beckham Jr. Created a Trend, Single-Handedly
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Scores of fans assembled in the bleachers overlooking the fields while waiting for the Giants training camp practice to start Thursday night. The children in the crowd, often accompanied by their parents, gathered behind the grandstands, throwing footballs back and forth.

title: Internet Outcry Over Diversity Leads Manhattan Theater Club to Announce Season Details Early
description: The outrage began before Manhattan Theater Club had unveiled its full 2015-16 season. Seven of its planned eight plays had been announced, all of them written by white men. The Internet was not amused.

title: The Heart of the City
description: Costumed characters and visitors said the pedestrian plazas in Times Square were a great place to relax and people watch. Removing them would be sad, they said.

title: Bernie Sanders Draws Big Crowds to His Political Revolution
description: DUBUQUE, Iowa  As 1,800 mad-as-hell supporters jumped out of their seats and pumped their fists last Sunday, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont delivered the message they had come to hear.

title: Banksys Dismaland
description: The graffiti artist Banksy has unveiled a dystopian take on Disneyland.

title: That Lucky Old Sun
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  David Steinberg is back, and his puzzle today made me realize what an impact his Pre-Shortzian Puzzle Project has had on him: Mr. Steinberg has a charming tendency to look to the past for interesting entries and bring them back again.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Aug. 21
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of dancing, summer love and Legionnaires disease.

title: Trial of Testosterone Supplements Sought
description: The Food and Drug Administration called on Thursday for drug makers to conduct a clinical trial of testosterone products marketed to older men to combat diminished levels of the hormone. While marketers call the often-normal decrease low T; the F.D.A. calls it age-related hypogonadism and describes it as controversial. In a commentary in The New England Journal of Medicine, agency officials cited concerns over cardiovascular risks of testosterone treatment and suggested that the benefits claimed in ads are unsupported by substantial evidence. The supplements are approved by the F.D.A. for treating classic hypogonadism, which includes well-recognized medical conditions like testicular damage. But most men prescribed testosterone do not appear to have this condition, agency officials wrote, calling the trend troubling. To date, no randomized, controlled trials have been designed to evaluate cardiovascular outcomes in men taking supplemental testosterone.

title: Seven Die as Planes Carrying Parachutists Collide Over Slovakia
description: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia  Two small planes collided over western Slovakia on Thursday, killing seven people, while 31 were able to parachute to safety.

title: General Electric Comes Back to Utica, and Brings Jobs Along With It
description: ALBANY  General Electric, once one of the biggest employers in Utica, one of New Yorks hardest-luck towns, is coming back.

title: Obama's Letter to Congressman Nadler
description: The letter reflects a shift in emphasis, to steps the administration could take outside the nuclear agreement with Iran to enforce the deals provisions.

title: Yankees Deliver a Ninth-Inning Outburst, but It Comes From Their Manager
description: Joe Girardi was ejected in the ninth inning Thursday as soon as he confronted the plate umpire, Dan Iassogna, about balls and strikes. But Girardi, the Yankees manager, was in no hurry to leave the field. He tried some performance art first.

title: Military Prisons Considered for Guantnamo Detainees
description: Secretary of Defense Ashton Carter said on Thursday that the Obama administration was assessing two military bases that have prisons  Fort Leavenworth in Kansas and Joint Base Charleston in South Carolina  as possible places to bring detainees from the prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. Since 2009, when the Obama administration first began trying to close the Guantnamo prison, the executive branch has studied the logistical capacity of several bases to handle such prisoners. President Obama wants to close Guantnamo Bay before he leaves office in January 2017. Of the 116 detainees remaining there, 52 are recommended for transfer if security conditions can be met in the receiving country. But even if all of those lower-level detainees can be resettled, the United States would be left with 64 prisoners who are not approved for release.

title: A New Park for Greenwich Village
description: A $10 million park opens Friday on the triangular lot opposite Seventh Avenue from what used to be St. Vincents Hospital.

title: Europa Editions Objects of Desire
description: How a small Italian press managed to turn works in translation into a form of social currency.

title: Martin OMalley Unveils His Plan to Expand Social Security
description: Martin OMalley will lay out a plan on Friday for expanding Social Security, an issue on which he has common cause with another Democratic presidential hopeful, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | insubstantial
description: insubstantial  \in(t)-sb-stan(t)-shl\  adjective

title: Tony Bennett: The Way You Look Tonight
description: Listen to an exclusive clip of a song from The Silver Lining.

title: Tony Bennett Releasing New Album of Jerome Kern Songs
description: Tony Bennett, who has rarely missed an opportunity to celebrate the Great American Songbook, will release a new album in that vein this fall. The Silver Lining: The Songs of Jerome Kern (RPM/Columbia), due out Sept. 25, will feature Mr. Bennett in close collaboration with Bill Charlap, a jazz pianist and diligent songbook steward.

title: Whats On TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) NATIONAL GALLERY (2014) In his 39th documentary, Frederick Wiseman tours the National Gallery in London (above). Docents decode the work of Leonardo, Rembrandt and Turner; restorers use magnifying glasses, eyedroppers, scalpels and cotton swabs to repair a tiny chip in a painting; senior executives politely battle younger ones, who believe the museum is too stodgy; and connoisseurs discuss the underpinnings of masterpieces by Vermeer, Caravaggio, Titian, Velzquez, Pissarro and Rubens. Mr. Wiseman also makes the point that art is the story of human relationships  in labor, commerce, patronage and even the exploitation of bodies. Mr. Wisemans touch is deft but light here, and the experience of watching National Gallery is pleasurable and immersive because hes a wonderful storyteller, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this three-hour movie. It is also unexpectedly moving. Because his other great theme is how art speaks to us, one he brilliantly expresses in the relay of gazes that finds us looking at museumgoers looking at portraits that look right back  at artists, art lovers and moviegoers  even as Mr. Wiseman, that sly old master, looks at all of us in turn.

title: Corrections: August 21, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday August 21, 2015
description: Now I feel that its in the hands of God.

title: One Wall, Two Germanys
description: Before the Berlin Wall came down, what did the Western world know of East Germany? Stereotypes, mostly. It was the Germany that drew the short straw, a Soviet puppet state that needed a concrete barricade patrolled by soldiers to keep its citizens from fleeing.

title: Student Crossword | Asian-American History
description: Test your knowledge of Asian-American history by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: Little Pink Pill for Women Comes With Risks
description: The Food and Drug Administrations approval on Tuesday of a marginally effective drug to enhance the sexual drive of women with low libido came with appropriate safeguards to protect the safety of patients. We will probably never know whether the agency made a purely scientific judgment or whether it was unduly influenced by a campaign, partly financed by the manufacturer and organized with the help of one of its consultants, to depict the agency as gender-biased for never having approved a drug to treat sexual dysfunction in women while approving numerous drugs for men.

title: Using Artificial Intelligence in New War Weapons
description: To the Editor:

title: Presidential Libraries
description: To the Editor:

title: Mothers Arent the Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Preparing for Life After Cable
description: In recent years, a lot of media and telecommunications executives dismissed the idea that Americans would stop subscribing to cable and satellite TV services. But the cord-cutting phenomenon can no longer be ignored.

title: Defending the Opt-Out Movement
description: To the Editor:

title: Putin vs. Parmesan
description: In the Soviet era, the political joke was the first line of defense against the machinery of repression. The jokes are cropping up again, many over Vladimir Putins zany crackdown on European flowers and food imports, like the satirical video Death of a Parmesan, in which the destruction of foreign cheeses becomes a ballad about a heroic military campaign. This song is about the unusual stupidity of todays Russia, reads the caption.

title: Can Our Transit System Get Any Worse?
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  THIS has been a tough season for commuters in the New York region: the Amtrak crash in May, trains stuck in Hudson River tunnels in June, subway service disrupted by never-ending summer construction. Still, more than 5.6 million people take the subway each weekday, the most since 1949; New Jersey Transits ridership into the city has risen 75 percent in the past 15 years, and Amtraks Northeast Corridor carried a record of nearly 12 million riders last year.

title: Debt Is Good
description: Rand Paul said something funny the other day. No, really  although of course it wasnt intentional. On his Twitter account he decried the irresponsibility of American fiscal policy, declaring, The last time the United States was debt free was 1835.

title: Stocks Plunge Sharply for a Second Day on Wall Street
description: Stock prices around the world continued to plunge on Friday, threatening to end one of the longest bull runs in the history of the United States stock market.

title: Uber to Provide Free In-Car Wi-Fi in India
description: HONG KONG  In India, a country notorious for city-snarling traffic jams, Uber is hoping free in-car Wi-Fi will lure customers who dont want long transit times to take them offline.

title: Novartis to Buy Multiple Sclerosis Drug From Glaxo
description: Novartis bolstered its portfolio of multiple sclerosis treatments on Friday by agreeing to buy an experimental drug from GlaxoSmithKline for up to $1 billion, the company said.

title: Pros and Cons ofReclaimed Kitchens
description: Renovating with recycled fixtures and building materials can offer a distinct set of rewards and challenges.

title: Recycled Kitchens, Salvaged Splendor
description: When Jonathan and Barbara Pessolano began renovating an 1850s three-family house on Staten Island earlier this year, they didnt intend to make it a model of recycling. But a search for a deal on a Miele dishwasher led them in an unexpected direction.

title: Gingerly Tattling on the Office Boor
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: David Denson, Gay Baseball Prospect, Achieves a Key Victory: Being Himself
description: After David Denson left home more than two years ago to embark on a career as a professional baseball player, he and his mother, Felisa Gomez, began a nearly daily ritual. No matter where he went, traveling from one small town to another, Denson found time to phone his mother.

title: Joe Bidens Role in 90s Crime Law Could Haunt Any Presidential Bid
description: WASHINGTON  When Joseph R. Biden Jr. became the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee in 1987, a few months ahead of his first and ultimately unsuccessful presidential campaign, he told aides his goal was to enact legislation that would take a comprehensive approach to reducing crime.

title: As Another Club Closes, Sunset Strips Evolution Continues
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  The House of Blues stood by the Sunset Strip for 21 years strong, another rock n roll outpost on a curvy boulevard renowned for its music, comedy, celebrity, glamour and a bit of sleaze. But this month the clubs run came to an end, announced with a Thank you, L.A.! message on its billboard and workers carting out computer screens and folding chairs. The bulldozers  and a new high-rise luxury hotel-condominium  are on the way.

title: Iran Prepares to Lure Foreign Investors After Nuclear Deal
description: ZARRINABAD, Iran  When Irans Revolutionary Guards Corps took over the nations telecommunications monopoly in 2009, the move was denounced as another dark step in the hard-line military groups seizure of the levers of power.

title: Crystals Galore and a Devotion to Harley
description: While the contemporary style game for motorcycle riders is all about wearing whats sturdy, when it comes to wedding attire at the annual Sturgis Motorcycle Rally, keep it simple has been the general rule.

title: A Bride, a Groom and a Bike
description: When 800,000 bikers traveled to South Dakota this month, some left on their Harley-Davidsons as newlyweds.

title: Leather, Lace and Boots Mix at Sturgis Motorcycle Rally Weddings
description: When motorcyclists gather, they come to party, as they do each year for the Sturgis Motorcycle Rally in the Black Hills of South Dakota.

title: News Qs | Rape Case Puts Focus on Culture of Elite St. Pauls School
description: Note: Weve updated 6 Qs About the News for the new school year. Let us know what you think.

title: Head of Russian Railways, Close to Putin, Resigns
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia accepted on Friday the resignation of the head of the state rail company, formalizing the first significant shake-up in the countrys inner circle of power since a recession began last winter.

title: Parks and Recreation News: R.V.-Sharing Website Launches and More
description: Our Friday morning parks and recreation news digest, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Ask Well: Fighting Bags Under the Eyes
description: Question:

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get the briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: North and South Korea on Alert Over Loudspeakers Blaring Propaganda
description: SEOUL, South Korea  After a period of calm  or relative calm, at least  along the heavily militarized border between North and South Korea, both sides were back on alert Friday. The unlikely cause: Loudspeakers.

title: A Racial Gap in Attitudes Toward Hospice Care
description: BUFFALO  Twice already, Narseary and Vernal Harris have watched a son die. The first time  Paul, at 26  was agonizing and frenzied, his body tethered to a machine meant to keep him alive as his sickle cell disease progressed. When the same illness ravaged Solomon, at 33, the Harrises reluctantly turned to hospice in the hope that his last days might somehow be less harrowing than his brothers.

title: New York Today: Bust a Move
description: Good morning on this mucky Friday.

title: What Is Britains Labour Party For?
description: LONDON  The Jeremy Corbyn phenomenon may be as baffling for those who follow British politics as the Donald J. Trump phenomenon is to those who keep an eye on American politics. Both were regarded as joke candidates when they first entered their respective leadership races. But both have emerged as front-runners, to great consternation in their parties.

title: 2 Who Attacked Hong Kong Journalist Are Sentenced to 19 Years
description: HONG KONG  Two men who attacked a Hong Kong journalist with a cleaver last year were sentenced to 19 years in prison on Friday, the public broadcaster RTHK reported.

title: 1926: Lenin Predicted Bitter Leadership Struggle for His Country
description: Seventy-five years ago today, in 1940, Leon Trotsky was killed in Mexico City when a Stalinist struck him with a pickax.

title: Tear Gas Fired at Migrants in Macedonia
description: The move came as the police tried to disperse a crowd of migrants at the border with Greece on Friday morning.

title: In a Twist, Europe May Find Itself Relying on Success of Alexis Tsipras of Greece
description: ROME  Europe spent months trying to crush Alexis Tsipras. But now that Greeces leftist prime minister has called a snap election and is seeking a mandate for the tough new bailout program he negotiated with his countrys creditors, Europe, oddly enough, may find itself invested in his success.

title: Today in Politics: Rivals Can No Longer Ignore Donald Trumps Long Shadow
description: Good Friday morning. Even on vacation, President Obama seeks to reassure on-the-fence supporters of the Iran nuclear deal that he will take a hard line in enforcing it. And as Donald J. Trump continues to drive both the polls and the news cycles, the ripples extend to his rivals camps as they can no longer base their response on simply waiting for him to go away.

title: The 8.9.15 Issue
description: RE: ISSA RAE

title: How to Be Naked in Public
description: Begin by practicing in private. Sure, you can be nude in your own shower, Stphane Deschnes says, but how about sitting in the living room watching TV? How about having dinner?

title: Beaux Arts
description: Its a delight to see the way that poems (and poets) engage in conversation with other works of art. Chana Blochs poem is layered in its ekphrastic references, not only to a painting but also to Muse des Beaux Arts, a poem by W.H. Auden that has long been one of my favorites. Echoing the language of Audens poem (About suffering they were never wrong,/The Old Masters: how well they understood), Beaux Arts extends the meditation on art, myth and the representation of human emotion.

title: The Great Pileup of 1998
description: Considering that even in 1998 a Formula One car might have been an assemblage of at least a million dollars worth of parts, in the first few seconds of the Belgian Grand Prix that year at least $13 million washed away with the rainwater on the inundated track in the series biggest multiple-car crash, involving 13 cars at the first corner.

title: At Las Cabras in Santiago, Pedigree Is All
description: The fuente de soda is Chiles particular take on the soda fountain, a culinary institution along the lines of the American diner  friendly, familiar, old-fashioned. You go to one to tuck your tie into your shirt and wolf down a churrasco completo (imagine a comically large hamburger, but made with sliced meat, mashed avocado, tomatoes and mayonnaise). Throw back a freshly made juice or a beer and youre ready to get back to work.

title: Getting Creative With Small Hotel Rooms
description: One of the few female top executives in the hospitality business, Niki Leondakis, the chief executive of Commune Hotels and Resorts, knows a thing or two about running hotels.

title: Hotel Review: Hotel Croydon in Miami
description: From $138.

title: Code Red
description: I started out dyeing my hair a few years ago with a color they call chocolate. Then I went blond, then platinum blond, then blond with green, then burgundy red, then cherry red, which is even stronger, and then intense red. I had it that way for two years. Until a few months ago, when I got on a bus route I never shouldve taken, and this girl sat next to me.

title: Jerrold Nadler, New York Congressman, Endorses Iran Nuclear Deal
description: Representative Jerrold Nadler was being pulled hard from all sides.

title: Kevyn Aucoins Making Faces
description: I was 14 when I discovered I have an oval face. I learned this from reading Kevyn Aucoins Making Faces, a glossy volume published in 1997 that quickly became a kind of sacred text among teenage girls.
