We all trekked to the Borders at Winrock mall in Albuquerque to buy a copy, using the savings we had built up by babysitting or halfheartedly frothing lattes for minimum wage. We lugged the book home (all 160 oversize pages of it) to commune in private with its thick, creamy paperstock full of wisdom about lip shapes, brow bleaching and false eyelashes. We propped it against the bathroom sink as we mashed our fingers into our cheekbones, feeling for deep bone structure. We pored over close-ups of celebrity pores, eager to claim affinity with the actress or supermodel whose skin most matched our own. The girls who learned from Aucoin that they had heart-shaped faces let everyone at school know about it in the nasal braggadocio common to a certain breed of adolescent queen bee. They were special; the rest of us could only dream of possessing jawlines that ended in a point like valentines.

title: Morning Agenda: Investors Get Fitness Fever
description: INVESTORS GET FITNESS FEVER | The self-help therapy pedaling session held in dim lighting to the sound of a primal dance beat has developed a cultlike following. Now the craze has spread from Victorias Secret models and hedge fund wives to Wall Street financiers, who want to ride to big bucks on the back of SoulCycles initial public offering, Julie Creswell reports in DealBook.

title: As Workers Delay Retirement, Some Bosses Become More Flexible
description: Corliss Fanjoy is turning 65 this year, but she is not ready for retirement. And at a small handbag maker in Maine, where Mrs. Fanjoy spends her working hours cutting intricate patterns in leather, she is not alone.

title: From Nicole Kidman to A Delicate Ship, a Big Season for the Playwright Anna Ziegler
description: The playwright Anna Ziegler is not exactly decisive.

title: Video Reviews of American Ultra, Sinister 2 and Grandma
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on American Ultra, Sinister 2 and Grandma. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Trans Deaths, White Privilege
description: IT was snowing in Maine on Jan. 9. Id been to the dentists the day before. The staff there were pleasant enough when I changed genders 12 years ago. Well just change your forms, the receptionist had said, cheerfully. Its no problem.

title: T City Guides: Los Angeles
description: Five leaders in creative fields share their favorite places to eat, drink, shop and play.

title: Its Been Fun, butIm Going On Vacation
description: Its late August and as usual, Im exchanging my laptop and iPhone for a tennis racquet and a kayak paddle. My excellent assistant, Joumana Khatib, will be in the office, responding to reader mail. Ill be checking in and consulting with her regularly. (But, then again, not too regularly.)

title: Macedonian Police Clash With Migrants on Border With Greece
description: SKOPJE, Macedonia  Tensions at the Greek-Macedonian border erupted into clashes on Friday, when the Macedonian police used stun grenades to try to disperse a large group of migrants trying to cross the border into their country.

title: Israel Carries Out 2nd Round of Airstrikes in Syria
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The Israeli military mounted a second round of airstrikes in Syria on Friday morning, killing all of the passengers traveling in a vehicle and intensifying the most serious conflict in the area in months.

title: Finding a Roommate on Craigslist
description: Dear Diary:

title: Three Teacher-Tested Ways to Encourage Your Students to Follow Current Events This School Year
description: Over 7,500 mini-essays answering the question What interested you most in The Times this week? flooded into our Sixth Annual Summer Reading Contest this June, July and August, and so far we have crowned eight winners, 79 runners-up and many, many honorable mentions. (And stay tuned: There are still winners to be named on Aug. 25 and Sept. 1., as well a special opportunity for honorees.)

title: Art for Arts Sake. Then Brick it Over.
description: Pajtim Osmanaj helps to tile over a mural he created in his spare time as a worker at a condo being completed in West Chelsea.

title: Construction Site as Canvas
description: Pajtim Osmanaj turned an under-construction West Chelsea condo into a creative playground.

title: Art Hidden Behind a Condos Walls
description: Two years ago, Pajtim Osmanaj moved to New York from Kosovo after working toward a degree in fine art. To pay his bills, he took a job in construction laying tile. By happenstance, earlier this year, he ended up working at 560 West 24th Street, a boutique condominium in West Chelsea near the High Line. Surrounded by art galleries, in the heart of New Yorks contemporary art scene, he couldnt help expressing himself.

title: Freedom, Finally, After a Life in Prison
description: WHEN she was 15 years old, Paula Cooper and three high school classmates in Gary, Ind., decided to cut school and steal some money to play games at a local arcade. They drank some cheap wine, smoked some pot and walked to the nearby home of a 78-year-old Bible teacher, Ruth Pelke. They figured she might have a jar of money somewhere.

title: Stuff We Liked: Baby Names, Livable Cities and Chartreuse
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: An Insider's Guide to Paris's Alternative Beauty Scene
description: Thanks to French fashion folk, alternative treatments are starting to thrive in the conservative city.

title: Female BFFs: The New Power Couples
description: Lately, weve been inundated with images of real-life best friends, triumphantly displayed. Are we happy about that?

title: Fairy Tales
description: Brad DeLong is searching for the origins of the phrase confidence fairy. Im pretty sure  you can never be completely sure, because things can stick in your mind  that it was an original coinage on my part, a snappy way to characterize the deep implausibility of the Alesina-Ardagna stuff that was sweeping Brussels and other corridors of power in 2010. Since then, a lot of further evidence has come in  and all of it confirms the original critique.

title: Parents Parting Ceremony at Morehouse College
description: Parents affirm their love and acknowledge the importance of letting go; freshmen thank the elders for their support and vow to honor the family name.

title: Parents Ceremony Serves Up Elements of Morehouse Gospel
description: ATLANTA  For the previous 364 days, the carved wooden chest rested unobtrusively atop a bookshelf in a deans office here at Morehouse College. Then, on a recent Wednesday afternoon, the dean, Lawrence E. Carter Sr., reclaimed the vessel for its annual duty as the repository of Morehouses hope and history.

title: Daily Report: The Stock Market Carnage Cometh for Tech
description: Nearly everything on the stock market fell on Thursday, with some tech companies taking particularly hard hits.

title: Tyrod Taylor Is Wild Card in Buffalo Bills Three-Way Quarterback Race
description: Quarterback controversies are nothing new in the N.F.L. But they usually involve two candidates. The Bills find themselves this year with a legitimate three-way quarterback battle.

title: Getting Workaholics to Stop and Recharge
description: Anthony Hitt, chief executive of Engel & Vlkers North America, a luxury property company, spends at least one week each quarter at his home in Maui, Hawaii. At this point, three years into the top job, he said he talks to his top lieutenants only 15 minutes a day when hes there. The rest of the time he reads, practices yoga, rides his bicycle or otherwise tries to disconnect from the responsibilities of his job.

title: Readers Turn: Dont Ignore Trump
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: On Reading
description: BIBLIOTECHWhy Libraries Matter More Than Ever in the Age of GoogleBy John Palfrey280 pp. Basic Books, $26.99.

title: Cultural Anxiety
description: This week, Joshua Cohen reviews Mario Vargas Llosas Notes on the Death of Culture. The Nobel Prize winner Vargas Llosa begins his book by citing a 1948 essay about high culture by a fellow Nobel winner, T.S. Eliot.

title: Letters: New Orleans, 10 Years Later
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Row
description: WHAT IS VISIBLE, by Kimberly Elkins. (Twelve, $15.) As a young child in the 1830s, Laura Bridgman suffered a bout of scarlet fever that left her without sight, hearing, taste or smell. She rose to prominence after learning language, despite being both deaf and blind, at the institute that Annie Sullivan and Helen Keller would later attend. Her story is the basis of Elkinss biographical novel, which imagines Bridgmans inner life.

title: Editors Choice
description: EILEEN, by Ottessa Moshfegh. (Penguin Press, $25.95.) Through her fascinatingly twisted heroine, Moshfegh explores a womans relationship to her body  the disconnection, the cultural claims, the male prerogative.

title: Machines of Loving Grace, by John Markoff
description: Technologists rarely question technology in public. Yet last fall Teslas chief executive, Elon Musk, suggested we might need to regulate the development of artificial intelligence just to make sure that we dont do something very foolish.

title: Everybody Rise, by Stephanie Clifford
description: A quarter-century ago, Harpers published an essay by Tom Wolfe titled Stalking the Billion-Footed Beast: A Literary Manifesto for the New Social Novel. Wolfe, whose best seller The Bonfire of the Vanities had been published two years earlier, called for a revival of the sort of novel that emerged during the 19th century: realist fiction that was wide in its scope and accurate in its detail, grounded in the kind of reporting that journalistic nonfiction demands.

title: The Shape of the New, by Scott L. Montgomery and Daniel Chirot
description: The world has been horrified but also puzzled by the rise of ISIS. How does one comprehend its brutality and success? What is its likely path? In March 2015, The Atlantic offered an answer, in an analysis by Graeme Wood that quickly became the most widely read essay in the magazines 158-year history. Titled What ISIS Really Wants, it focused on the ideology that animates the group. Understand its ideas, Wood suggested, and you will understand the phenomenon and how to fight it. Many other, more polemical explanations of jihadi terrorism today  from Bill Maher to Sam Harris  also shine a spotlight on the ideas behind the mayhem.

title: Young Eliot, by Robert Crawford
description: In an unheroic age, T.S. Eliot was poetrys ideal antihero. Shy, indecisive, gangly, he essayed the Parnassian heights not baroquely turbaned like a Byron but buttoned down and gray-flanneled like a Walter Mitty. By day, he was a Lloyds banker in a four-piece suit, as Virginia Woolf reportedly described him; by night, a visionary poet, whose lyric fragments harmonized with the malaise troubling Europe after World War I. The Scottish poet Robert Crawfords assiduous Young Eliot follows Tom from his earliest poetic finger exercises to the ineradicably insinuating music of The Waste Land (1922), in which April cruelly breeds lilacs as well as a bramble of textual notes.

title: Palimpsest: A History of the Written Word, by Matthew Battles
description: When an author assigns himself the task of compiling a history of the written word, a reader is likely to wonder: How well written is it? Palimpsest is a serious, well-researched book. Matthew Battles evokes the flexibility of human consciousness and the ability of the written word to absorb and deploy new technologies even though, as he explains, writing has always had its supposed shallows, from penny dreadfuls to propaganda and pornography. However, Palimpsest puts up a dull defense of its subject. Its elliptically organized and full of workmanlike, hackneyed prose. Its a history of the written word, but its also a repository of literary missteps.

title: Faith Ed., by Linda K. Wertheimer
description: What should you do in a house of worship of another faith? This is a question that vexes many who write about religion and many who do not. Should non-Jewish men don kipas in synagogues? Should non-Muslim women cover their heads in a mosque? Should non-Catholics kneel during Mass? When everyone at an evangelical church holds hands and prays, should I keep mine by my side? Does not participating imply rudeness or does it simply say, I respect your faith enough not to pretend I am a part of it?

title: We Believe the Children, by Richard Beck
description: In the summer of 1983, a California woman named Judy Johnson took her 3-year-old son Matthew to a hospital near her home in Manhattan Beach. She pointed the doctors attention to her childs anus, which, she said, looked redder than it had that morning, before he had gone to his day care center. Whether out of genuine concern about foul play or to salve a worried mother, the doctor filed a suspected child abuse report. Johnson, who later received a diagnosis of paranoid schizophrenia, took her own suspicions to the police, who soon alerted parents whose children attended the McMartin Preschool to a possible abuser in their midst.

title: Whose Side Are You On?
description: When I was 15, I was playing with my 2-year-old sister and our 19-month-old cousin by a fountain in Amherst, Mass. Someone smiled and said, Theyre yours? and I was shocked. Even if Id had them in middle school, it was mathematically impossible to have given birth to both of them.

title: What Alexis Tsiprass Announcement Means for Greece
description: A tumultuous summer in Greece could lead to an uncertain autumn as voters may have to decide who would best navigate the next phase of the countrys financial struggle.

title: Inside the List
description: The Kings of Comedy: The director Judd Apatow began interviewing his comedy idols while still in high school. In Sick in the Head, No.17 on the extended hardcover nonfiction list, he compiles almost 30 years of conversations with legends like Mel Brooks, Steve Martin, Jerry Seinfeld and Chris Rock into a master class of the form  of why people come to comedy (Roseanne Barr: My dad wouldnt hit me if I got him with humor right between the eyes) and how to do it well (Amy Schumer: The stuff youre copping to and the saddest, worst moments of your life  thats the stuff people connect to and appreciate).

title: 1940: Britain Bans Import of Notes
description: LONDON  Great Britain gave the economic screw another twist today by declaring worthless in the home market for the wars duration the millions of pounds of British currency in non-sterling countries. Persons residing in the United States were given six days in which to cash into dollars whatever British currency they may hold, but the inhabitants of France and other European countries invaded by the Germans or living next door to them were allowed only a twenty-four-hour notice.

title: Aging Extremist Laments Violence Now Used Against Palestinians
description: OFRA, West Bank  YEHUDA ETZION does not regret, exactly, helping plant bombs in the cars of Palestinian mayors and plotting to blow up the Dome of the Rock in the 1980s, nor does he express remorse. But he has reconsidered the role of violence in the quest for a Messianic kingdom of Israel, particularly as he contemplates a new generation of radicals he sees as bastardizing their shared ideology.

title: The Very Bad Picture Book
description: Its colors are dull and it teaches an important lesson.

title: Aggressive Treatment for Early Breast Cancer: Reporters Notebook
description: On Tuesday, I got an e-mail from JAMA Oncology, a leading medical journal, saying that it planned to publish a paper and editorial on ductal carcinoma in situ, or D.C.I.S., a condition that has become increasingly controversial over the years. As many as 60,000 women are told each year that they have it: tiny clusters of abnormal breast cells, confined to a milk duct and too small to be felt. Its often called stage 0 cancer, and it almost never was detected before the early 1980s when mammograms came into widespread use.

title: The Person Behind Those Bad Lip Reading Videos Has a Favorite Politician (No, Its Not Donald Trump.)
description: For years, an anonymous producer of Bad Lip Reading, a popular series of dubbed-over YouTube videos, has added absurdist humor to our already fairly absurd political process.

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Ruhr Region, Germany

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Hit Count, by Chris Lynch
description: Its one thing when a novel about a meaningful subject gets published at a time when a media storm surrounding that subject is beginning to brew. But add to the mix an author who can really get the crosswinds blowing and there is truly cause to marvel. Thats the case with Chris Lynchs Hit Count, a powerful story that illuminates both the dangers of head trauma in athletes and the psyche of football players.

title: What This Story Needs Is a Pig in a Wig, and More
description: A childrens books editor once asked me what kind of books were needed most in libraries. My immediate response was, Beginning readers! Then I had a question: Why arent there more available? The editors reply was just as fast: Because theyre too hard to write.

title: Mamas Nightingale, by Edwidge Danticat, and More
description: Picture books have long been concerned with helping children transition to an unfamiliar place. A childs first day in a new school or a familys move to a different neighborhood are by now classic subjects. But since the dawn of the 21st century, with the number of immigrants in the United States continuing to increase markedly, childrens authors and publishers have begun to take on a far more challenging task  helping immigrant children settle into a new cultural environment, one that even their parents may find inexplicable. Since the principal obstacle to understanding a culture is, of course, the language that expresses it, language can loom large in these books; and a language divide is a concept difficult to express pictorially. Given all this, a childs experience of immigration is a subject matter that requires some inventive tactics, as four new books ably demonstrate.

title: A Gay Baseball Player, in Statistical Perspective
description: Until this week, no active baseball player associated with a Major League Baseball team had ever publicly come out as gay. David Denson, a prospect playing for the Helena Brewers in one of baseballs rookie leagues, has finally ended that streak.

title: Kevin Henkess Waiting, and More
description: As both subjects and protagonists, animals seem to rule the world of childrens books, and its easy to see why. They are cute, recognizable and fun to imitate. They play a part in every childs life, sometimes a big one. But what about the toys and tools children use every day? These make more occasional literary appearances  in, for instance, classics such as Corduroy, about a stuffed bear alone in a department store, or even The Little Engine That Could, with its dolls and small clown  but they really deserve to be more frequent stars. Children have immediate associations with their treasured belongings in a way they might not with, say, a capybara. Three new books, all by prominent picture book authors, artfully use worldly possessions to approach larger themes, to varying degrees of success.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Coffee, Sugar and Sex Drive
description: Take the Quiz

title: Banksy Opens Dismaland Theme Park
description: The British graffiti artist Banksy, in collaboration with other artists, has opened what he calls a bemusement park near his hometown, Bristol.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are co-ops in Chelsea, Midtown West and Midwood.

title: Pyongyang Reacts to Souths Loudspeakers
description: A senior official from North Korea criticized the Souths use of loudspeakers to blare propaganda messages across the demilitarized zone, but the South Korean defense minister defended the broadcasts.

title: Maggie Thrashs Honor Girl
description: At the start of every summer session deep in the Kentucky Appalachians, Camp Bellflower celebrates one camper chosen to be the Honor Girl. She is the female ideal, representing the noble qualities the camp aims to foster in its generations of girls. Fifteen-year-old Maggie Thrash is a Bellflower veteran, an old hand at the hokey traditions of the camp. She doesnt bat an eye at the candlelit Honor Girl ceremony, or the daily Civil War re-enactments (which consist of two groups of girls screaming GRAY! and BLUE! at each other). She has her friends, her ankle leash to keep from sleepwalking, her entire pleasantly familiar summer stretching out ahead of her. Until one fateful lice inspection by an older counselor triggers a romantic awakening, in the last location she would have chosen.

title: Why Jeff Bezos Should Care More for Amazons Employees
description: Dear Jeff Bezos,

title: House Tour | Scholten & Baijings
description: The Amsterdam-based designers Stefan Scholten and Carole Baijings invite T into their colorful home, which they describe as a living still life.

title: Vague Disclosures by Highflying Mutual Funds May Put Investors in Peril
description: Desperate for richer yields on their portfolios, individual investors have thronged in recent years to mutual funds promising higher-than-usual income. The question is: Do these investors understand the higher-than-usual risks involved?

title: Holly Holm, a Top Boxer, Will BeRonda Rouseys Next Opponent
description: The mixed martial arts superstar Ronda Rousey announced Friday that her next opponent would be Holly Holm on Jan. 2 in Las Vegas.

title: Scholten & Baijingss Bright Ideas
description: A husband-and-wife team is brightening up the sober Dutch design world.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a beach house in New Rochelle, N.Y., and Tudor in Fairfield, Conn.

title: This Weeks Market Sell-Off May Not Be Such a Bad Thing
description: It has been a frantic week on Wall Street and in other financial centers, with stocks and other risky assets experiencing their worst week in years.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: Review: Becoming Dr. Ruth in Stony Point Is a Meditation on Home
description: Five countries, three husbands, four names. The one most people know her by, Dr. Ruth, has become synonymous with frank talk about sex, but in Becoming Dr. Ruth, the first-rate Mark St. Germain play now at Penguin Rep in Stony Point, sex is perhaps the least scintillating of the subjects under discussion. This 90-minute, one-woman show, set in 1997, finds our heroine, born Karola Ruth Siegel in 1928, preparing to move from the New York apartment she has shared with Fred Westheimer for 36 years.

title: How the Social Mission of Ben & Jerrys Survived Being Gobbled Up
description: Big food companies have an endless appetite for smaller brands that make local, organic and socially responsible products. Over the years, Danone acquired Stonyfield Farm yogurt, General Mills bought Annies Homegrown and Campbell Soup swallowed up Plum Organics.

title: A Reunion Screening of O Brother, Where Art Thou? and More at the New York Film Festival
description: All you men of constant sorrow can shed one less tear. The New York Film Festival will present a 15th anniversary screening of the Coen brothers comedy O Brother, Where Art Thou?, festival organizers announced today. In addition, the festival unveiled their special events lineup, which includes a screening of new work from Paul Thomas Anderson, the Holocaust drama Son of Saul, a documentary about Brian De Palma and a revival screening of his 1981 film Blow Out.

title: On Edge
description: It was Cate Blanchetts second time climbing the Sydney Harbour Bridge. She couldnt really say why she wanted to do it, or what it is about heights that appeals to her. She has no interest in skydiving or bungee jumping or parachuting. Shes not especially sporty or athletic. Its not thrills she likes; its control. She once drove her children to the edge of Mount Yasur, an active volcano on the island of Tanna.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: The Flying Spaghetti Monster
description: A team of BP drill workers discovered this deep sea creature off the coast of Angola.

title: Bookshelf: Schooling
description: New picture books include Music Class Today! and Dads First Day.

title: Carly Rae Jepsen Grows Up
description: With Emotion, the singer known best for Call Me Maybe embraces a seductive side to her music.

title: Feeling the Bass Deep in His Body
description: Houzaifa Konditamd, a native of Burkina Faso, became deaf at age 6, but that did not stop him from dancing. And dancing has helped him begun to carve out a niche since arriving in New York last year.

title: Big Ticket | 42 West 71st Street
description: A five-story townhouse sold for $18,355,000 was the weeks second-largest residential real estate transaction.

title: Bookshelf: By the Numbers
description: New picture books include Two Mice and The Great and Mighty Nikko!

title: For $28 Million,Another Perch at One57
description: A sprawling aerie on the 67th floor of One57, Extell Developments glassy-blue skyscraper, where the citys priciest transaction for a single residence took place earlier this year, sold to an undisclosed buyer for $28,005,375 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Dr. Dre Apologizes to the Women Ive Hurt
description: For Dr. Dre, this summer was meant to be a victory lap in a successful career. Straight Outta Compton, a biopic about his hip-hop group, N.W.A., topped the box office last week with a $56.1 million opening. Compton, his first album in 16 years, debuted at No. 2 on the Billboard chart. Last year, the music company that Dr. Dre helped establish, Beats, was sold to Apple for $3 billion, making him the self-proclaimed first billionaire in hip-hop.

title: Winner Take Less? (In Music)
description: I very much liked Steven Johnsons piece on the failure of the feared creative apocalypse to materialize. I do have a bone to pick, however: you do not write things like this:

title: On Assignment: Exploding a Cherry Pie
description: New York Times staff photographer talks about his process photographing an exploding cherry pie for the May 21 cover of the Wealth and Finance section.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: NeuroTribes
description: This week, Steve Silberman talks about NeuroTribes and autism; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Elisabeth Egan discusses A Window Opens; questions from readers; Maria Russo talks about the seasons childrens books; and Parul Sehgal has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: NeuroTribes
description: This week, Steve Silberman, Elisabeth Egan and Maria Russo.

title: Attracting Young, Diverse Mortgage Bankers
description: The Radius Financial Group, a mortgage lender in Norwell, Mass., recently made a $1 million investment in its future. The outlay wasnt for technology, marketing or even office space. Rather, the company executives decided the future well-being of Radius depends upon its ability to attract younger employees from more diverse backgrounds.

title: Track and Field Returns to Center Stage, as Do Doping Concerns
description: BEIJING  In less troubled times, the eve of the world track and field championships would have been all about the return of Usain Bolt and his sport to the Birds Nest.

title: Popcast: Carly Rae Jepsen Grows Up
description: Carly Rae Jepsen arrived in the world like a hailstorm. Her song Call Me Maybe invaded from Canada in 2011 and by summer 2012, it had completed its assault on the country, a virus that infected Americas youth, its elderly, its sports teams and even its political leaders.

title: A Deaf Dancer From Africa Makes a New Life in New York
description: Growing up in the small country of Burkina Faso in West Africa, Houzaifa Konditamd could not hear. But that did not stop him from dancing.

title: The Matisse of Mufflers
description: Lenny Prince sculpts objects far more elaborate than the usual stick figures fashioned from car parts that one sees outside some muffler shops.

title: The Time Is Right to Make Tomato Sauce
description: Tomatoes are now at their ripest and reddest, just right for a batch of fresh tomato sauce.

title: Into the Teeth of the Storm
description: Walter Baranger, senior editor for news operations, shares photos from his time coordinating The Timess Hurricane Katrina coverage 10 years ago.

title: The Companies That May Be the Next 50 Start-Up Unicorns
description: It used to be a rare thing when start-ups were valued at $1 billion or more by their investors. Now its become so common that there are at least 131 start-ups boasting such valuations and a term  unicorns  to refer to the companies.

title: 1890: Panic on Wall Street
description: This has been the most exciting day Wall Street has seen since the assassination of President Garfield. The stringency in the money market reached such a degree that it precipitated a panic among borrowers and carried the rate of call loans to nearly 190 per cent, the highest rate on record since the chaos resulting from the tragedy of 81. The demand for funds at this anomalous rate of per cent per day, in addition to the regular rate of interest, cannot honestly be attributed to mere bear manipulation. The eagerness with which long stock was thrown on the market fully attested to the general need for money that prevails in Wall Street. While Wall Street was howling, stocks were tumbling out of sight. The threatened state of affairs on the Vanderbilt railroad system did not improve matters. Heavy liquidation in the entire group was one of the first conspicuous features of the session.  The New York Herald, European Edition, August 22, 1890

title: Challenging Mayor de Blasio Over Times Square Plazas
description: It was bad enough when the New York City police commissioner, William J. Bratton, reacting to tabloid headlines about topless women and costumed panhandlers in Times Square, suggested digging up the pedestrian plazas. That brought back memories of the 1980s, when New York officials refused to install benches in some city parks because they couldnt figure out how to manage public space.

title: A Staten Island Mechanic Turns Tailpipes Into Artwork
description: No one can teach you to be an artist, Lenny Prince likes to say. The mufflers themselves trained me.

title: Doctors Behaving Badly
description: What really goes on in an operating room?

title: Mistrial for Charlotte Police Officer in Death of Unarmed Black Man
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  After nearly four days of jury deliberations, a judge declared a mistrial on Friday in the trial of a white Charlotte police officer who killed an unarmed black man almost two years ago.

title: In Hombre and Kid Blue, the Antiheroes Wear Stetsons and Ride Tall on a Rebellion Frontier
description: From the advent of the Cold War to the fall of Saigon, no American movie genre was more relevant than the western, with its allegorical echoes of race, crime, conquest and American exceptionalism.

title: Restaurant Reviews: Little Drunken Chef in Mount Kisco and Little Mumbai Market in Pleasantville
description: There are already a lot of Little restaurants in Mount Kisco, but there was still room for one more.

title: Usain Bolt vs. Justin Gatlin: Showdowns Await in Sprints
description: For years, one of the few certainties at major international track meets was that Usain Bolt would outsprint everyone.

title: Groups Press Hillary Clinton on Protecting Social Security
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton pleased progressives this week when she came out in opposition against drilling in the Arctic Ocean. Now they want to hear from her on Social Security.

title: The Film Fatales Collective Trains a Lens on Gender Inequality
description: Hollywoods prehistoric attitude toward female directors, the filmmaker Leah Meyerhoff said, was epitomized by the recent Jurassic World.

title: Restaurant Review: Lithos in Darien Is Built on a Greek Tradition
description: Lithos may sound like a Greek island in the Aegean or Ionian seas, or maybe one of the less Trumpian of the gods on Mount Olympus, but not so.

title: A Hofstra Museum Exhibition Offers Views of the Past Through a Softer Light
description: Even though all the art works in Enduring Images, an exhibition at Hofstra University in Hempstead, address themes like war, genocide, oppression and natural disasters, several of the paintings, prints and drawings use pastels or bright colors to illuminate the dark subject matter.

title: The (Other) Sounds of Summer: Musical Scenes That Make Movies Sizzle
description: Savvy filmmakers know that when their releases are scheduled during the summer, it helps to include a musical sequence or set piece. This year, Trainwreck took appropriate precautions, with a cheerleader-dance finale set to a medley that included 2 Unlimiteds Get Ready for This (known for its appearance in Space Jam) and Billy Joels resilient Uptown Girl. Its part of a long tradition  Are you ready for the summer? a chorus of excited children once inquired in Ivan Reitmans sunbaked 1979 masterpiece, Meatballs. Here are a few highlights that have helped make hits and cultural milestones of hot-weather fare through the years.

title: Facts & Figures: Carly Fiorina on Vaccines
description: Last week, Carly Fiorina said that school districts should be able to deny admission to children who havent been vaccinated against highly communicable diseases. But, she added, when were talking about some of these more esoteric immunizations, then I think absolutely a parent should have a choice and a school district shouldnt be able to say, sorry, your kid cant come to school for a disease thats not communicable, thats not contagious, and where there really isnt any proof that theyre necessary at this point.

title: Fafsa Follies: To Gain a Student, Eliminate a Form
description: Many smart students forgo college in the mistaken belief that they cannot afford it. The financial aid system, which is intended to increase opportunities for low-income students, is largely to blame.

title: London Theater Journal: Inside, Vodka and Stilettos; Outside, the Revolution
description: LONDON  Is it possible to achieve a contact high from alcohol? If so, I should be reeling. Strong drink is flowing freely  and damagingly  on this citys stages. The night after I saw the Almeida Theaters wine-soaked production of Euripides Bakkhai, I spent an evening at the Donmar Warehouse with four mutually contemptuous women who kept filling shot glasses with undiluted vodka.

title: A Deadly Sin at the Aldrich, From the Comfort of an Armchair
description: Strollers along Main Street in Ridgefield, Conn., will encounter a curious signpost planted in front of the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum. Each of its prongs is inscribed with one of the seven deadly sins followed by mileage information. Six aim westward: Lust, Gluttony, Greed, Wrath, Envy and Pride. The other points east, directly at the museum. It reads Sloth 0.01 miles.

title: Study Finds Surprising Byproduct of Middle Eastern Conflicts: Cleaner Air
description: Civil unrest and humanitarian crises can now be detected from space  because of, somewhat surprisingly, cleaner air.

title: Classification Follies
description: The Clinton email scandal goes on  still no sign that she broke any rules, no sign that she sent or received anything labeled classified, but she may have received and even forwarded items that were later classified or should have been classified. By normal human standards this is a big nothing; but Clinton Rules apply, under which malign behavior is the default assumption and where theres smoke there must be fire even if everyone knows that the usual suspects are operating big smoke machines. How many people still think that there really was a Whitewater scandal, or for that matter that Hillary is the subject of a criminal investigation?

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Caitlin Moran
description: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next installment in the series comes from Caitlin Moran, the comedian and author, who shares her picks exclusively with T.

title: Enthusiastic Crowd Will Greet Donald Trump in Alabama Stadium
description: MOBILE, Ala.  By midday Friday, with the temperature in the high 80s, Keith Quackenbush and Bill Hart decided it was time to buy an $89 pop-up tent from a nearby Walmart. It was how, they said, they were going to endure the wait outside a football stadium ahead of an appearance by Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential candidate.

title: Silent Beyonc, a Bloomingdales Blunder and Lagerfelds Eye
Tianjin Blasts Expose the Dangerous Proximity of Toxic Chemicals in China
description: The warehouse in Tianjin that exploded was just one of many buildings across China that store toxic chemicals near residential areas.

title: Rafael Nadal Accepts Another Early Loss, but Looks Ahead
description: MASON, Ohio  It used to be that Rafael Nadals crashing out of a tournament in an early round would prompt the biggest headlines in tennis. But in a year in which Nadal has consistently fallen short of the high standard he has set for himself, each subsequent loss seems less newsworthy.

title: The Writer's Room
description: Under the canopy of a tree, near a closet full of sweets, with the ghost of a famous painter, six authors on the spaces where they work.

title: Have You Cut the Cable Cord?
description: Friday mornings editorial on the growing number of Americans who are giving up cable- and satellite-TV service resonated with many readers. A number of them said in comments on the piece and on Facebook and Twitter that they, too, had happily given up cable.

title: President Erdogan of Turkey to Call for New Election
description: ISTANBUL  President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey said on Friday that he would call a snap election for Nov. 1 to break the impasse among the countrys four main political parties, an impasse that opponents say is partly of his own making.

title: Pension Advisers Learn the Folly of Trying to Beat the Market
description: CARSON CITY, Nev.  The Carson Nugget casino takes up the better part of a downtown block in this state capital, and a sign on the side beckons bettors with a promise of Extremely Loose Slots.

title: Jacob deGrom, a Met Known for His Hair, May (Gasp!) Cut It
description: Just before each spring training, Jacob deGrom has his hair cut in the kitchen of his parents house in DeLand, Fla. His older sister, Jessica, a former hairdresser, styles it. The whole scene has become something of an event for the deGroms. They find it funny to watch a major league pitcher squirm.

title: Unseen Burdens in Chrome That Can Lead a Mac to Lag
description: Q. I noticed my Mac was acting a little sluggish. When I opened the OS X system monitor to see what was going on, I found all these things called Google Chrome Helper listed. Is that a legitimate piece of software?

title: A Lawyer Quit Her Job to Start a Climate Museum in New York
description: Miranda Massie may not be the most obvious candidate to create a museum in New York City devoted to the subject of climate change. As a child growing up in the Hudson Valley in the 1970s, she rebelled against her fathers early efforts at recycling. Later, after flirting with getting a Ph.D. in history, she became a lawyer specializing in civil rights and took a job in Detroit.

title: What I Love | John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey
description: The husband and wife cabaret team rehearse their act and record their weekly podcast in an Upper West Side brownstone.

title: John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskeys Brownstone Rental
description: The couple known to uptown sophisticates as the Nick and Nora of the cabaret world  and to the rest of us as John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey  rent the parlor and garden floors of a brownstone on the Upper West Side.

title: Trading Barbs, India and Pakistan Seem on Verge of Canceling Talks
description: NEW DELHI  Talks between India and Pakistan, scheduled for next week in New Delhi, appeared on the brink of collapse Friday after the foreign ministries on both sides traded tough statements over Pakistans plans to meet with Kashmiri separatist leaders while in India.

title: Carter, Reagan, and Machiavelli
description: Rex Nutting has a very nice article about the reality of Jimmy Carters presidency, which has been distorted out of recognition by the myth of Saint Reagan. As he points out, Carter presided over faster average job growth and lower unemployment than Reagan; unfortunately for Carter, his timing was bad, with vigorous growth for most of his presidency but a recession at the end.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The History of Autism
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Jennifer Senior reviews Steve Silbermans NeuroTribes: The Legacy of Autism and the Future of Neurodiversity. Ms. Senior writes:

title: Revisiting Issue, Donald Trump Calls Attack on Homeless Man Terrible
description: Donald J. Trump said on Friday that he would never condone violence and that an attack on a homeless Hispanic man in Boston by two men who said they supported him was terrible.

title: Review: Martha Grahams Embattled Garden, Deconstructed
description: In the August heat, Janet Eilber, the artistic director of the Martha Graham Dance Company, apologized for the breathless and sweaty conditions in the Martha Graham Studio Theater, a storied spot cooled only by fans. She also joked with the audience that the steamy atmosphere was exactly right for the work being performed on Wednesday evening, Grahams Embattled Garden, from 1958.

title: Bernie Sanders Speaks at a Rally in S.C.
description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination, spoke to a large crowd in Greenville, S.C., on Friday, stressing the benefits of his agenda to minorities.

title: Ex-Heavyweight Champion Riddick Bowe Steps Into a New Arena
description: Three men stood on a street in Harlem, handing out fliers and pointing to a big man sitting alone inside a small restaurant with four tables called Bowes. He looked around, eager for company.

title: Bill Cunningham | It Bag
description: A molded rubber bag is a style mixture of the Birkin and Kelley bag details and a hit of the summer.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
A New Day
description: IT SEEMS ONLY FITTING that an issue kicking off the fall season should be rife with stories about transformation. Yet while it wasnt actually our intention to thread together features on that theme, neither is it really a coincidence. Change  whether emotional, sartorial, intellectual, artistic or stylistic  is what this magazine seeks to understand and to celebrate. And so, a small sampling of what lies ahead: a renegade collective that is shifting the practice and conception of architecture from a focus on the grandeur of a building to its actual everyday use; an artist who turns the stuff of daily life (which is more compelling than most, as she collects male muses and creates avatars to reproduce her Internet sex chats) into challenging work; a successful garden designer who wanted to bust out of his formal clipped-hedge-and-boxwood box and apprenticed himself at one of Englands most revered flower gardens; a group of avant-garde young designers who are reimagining fashion: luxury and craftsmanship take on a different meaning when they involve slicing and reweaving T-shirts bought in bulk at Kmart; a foreign-born press that is turning artfully designed books of fiction into status symbols.

title: Bill Cunningham | It Bag
description: A molded rubber bag, designed by Robert Verdi and the Great Bag Co., mixes style details from the Birkin and Kelly bags from Herms and is a hit of the summer. At $120, the bag is offered in vibrant primary colors, plus black, gray and white. A young man was observed this month on his way to work, carrying the bag in a different color on different days. Another young manwas seen with black and gray versions. Several times, women carrying the same bag stopped to show them off. Other bag news this August: red bags brightening black clothes. Other times, both during the day and evening, the bags were taxicab yellow and gave a new vitality and zip to black clothes.

title: Ellen Page Confronts Ted Cruz at the Iowa State Fair
description: As he flipped pork on a large grill at the Iowa State Fair, Senator Ted Cruz was engaged in an active discussion over same-sex marriage and gay, bisexual and transgender rights with a hat-and-sunglasses-clad attendee.

title: Five Mystery Birds Among Audubons Paintings
description: Q. I recently saw a TV program that said several of the birds painted by John James Audubon in The Birds of America never existed. Could that be true?

title: ABN Amro Nearly Doubles Earnings
description: ABN Amro, the state-owned Dutch bank that was the poster child of the financial crisis, has almost grown up.

title: In Questions Over Shaun Kings Race, Activists See Challenge to Black Lives Matter Movement
description: A prominent Black Lives Matter activist who has been accused of lying about his race was forced to discuss deeply personal issues after reporters pointed out that the father named on his birth certificate is white.

title: Living in the Ring of Fire
description: THE West has been on fire all month, with dream homes falling to a combustive punch, wild horses seared by flame and suffocated by smoke, even a rare firenado dancing across a landscape in which seven million acres have been burned this year.

title: New Condos in AstoriasKaufman Arts District
description: A 24-block section of Astoria, Queens, known as the Kaufman Arts District and home to Kaufman Astoria Studios  one of the worlds oldest continuously active movie studios  will soon see the addition of its first major new apartment building in years.

title: Your Brain, Your Disease, Your Self
description: WHEN does the deterioration of your brain rob you of your identity, and when does it not?

title: Airstrikes Kill Dozens of Civilians in Yemen, Doctors Without Borders Says
description: Doctors Without Borders said Friday that Saudi-led airstrikes on a residential district in Yemens southwestern city of Taiz had killed more than 65 civilians, including 17 people from one family.

title: Karen Stives, Acclaimed Olympic Equestrian, Dies at 64
description: Karen Stives, a fiercely gifted horsewoman who helped lead the American equestrian team to an Olympic gold medal in the sport known as three-day eventing, barely missing out on an individual gold medal herself, died this month at her home in Dover, Mass. She was 64.

title: A Day Out in the Boxing Gym With John Leguizamo
description: Accidents happen. Few people know better than John Leguizamo, who was sparring the other day at the Church Street Boxing Gym in Lower Manhattan with his longtime trainer, Jenaro Diaz.

title: Bill Cunningham | Jazz Age Lawn Party
description: Some of the core participants dressed in the authentic flapper style.

title: 1965 | A Half Century of Civil Rights Coverage Begins
description: To those who grew up reading The Timess coverage of civil rights, the byline over the front-page obituary of Julian Bond on Monday was almost as familiar a name as Mr. Bonds: By Roy Reed.

title: Evening Hours | Jazz Age Lawn Party
description: The tenth annual Jazz Age lawn party on Governors Island concluded its two-weekend run. For the first time, it ended in a brief but dramatic thunder shower with many of the more than 20,000 participants taking cover under their picnic blankets. The original event was the idea of Michael Arenella and his Dreamland Orchestra, as part of an effort to popularize the century-old military island after its reopened as a public park.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: How Bentley Meeker, Lighting Designer, Spends His Sundays
description: In 2010, Bentley Meeker left an anonymous note in the temple of the Burning Man festival, concerning his relationship with his son, who is now 15 and lives in California. After the temple burned down  as is the ritual at the annual Nevada event  he found resolution. Grateful, Mr. Meeker, 47, a lighting designer whose regular gigs include White House state dinners, approached festival organizers about contributing his skills to future temples. This summer, he plans to illuminate the Temple of Promise in collaboratoration with Scooter Wilson and Adam Crocker. His method: Edison tungsten spots, which he has also installed in the converted warehouse in East Harlem where he lives with his girlfriend, Alicia Boyes, 38, a restaurant consultant.

title: Airstrike Kills a Deputy to ISIS Leader, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON  A deputy to the leader of the Islamic State was killed in an American airstrike in Iraq this week, the White House announced Friday.

title: Breast Cancer Treatment and D.C.I.S.: Readers React
description: An article Thursday on the results of a study indicating that aggressive surgical treatment of a possible precursor to breast cancer may be unnecessary prompted a wide range of responses from readers, among them anger, sadness and relief.

title: Summer Berry Buckle
description: Melissa Clark makes a buckle with copious amounts of fruit and just enough batter to bind it together.

title: The Buckle Makes Great Use of Summer Fruit
description: Its easy to see how the crumble and the crisp got their names. Just look at their toppings. But for me at least, the buckle was more of a mystery.

title: 2 American Service Members Foil Gunman in Train Attack
description: PARIS  The two American service members who tackled a suspected terrorist on a high-speed train traveling from Amsterdam to Paris rushed him even though he was fully armed, then grabbed him by the neck and beat him over the head with his own automatic rifle until he was unconscious, one of them said in television interviews here on Saturday.

title: Social Chatter: Deez Nuts For President
description: The presidential candidate Deez Nuts was surging on Wednesday, polling at 9 percent in North Carolina.  Here are a few of the reactions to his campaign.

title: Candis Cayne, From Chelsea Drag Queen to Caitlyn Jenners Sidekick
description: Long before Laverne Cox made the cover of Time magazine as a transgender tipping point, and long before Caitlyn Jenner made global headlines as a former Olympian transitioning from male to female at age 65, there was Candis Cayne.

title: Ted Cruz Takes Up Iowa Couples Cause as He Courts Evangelicals
description: DES MOINES  When Senator Ted Cruz speaks to as many as 2,000 conservatives at a Rally for Religious Liberty on Friday night, he will feature on stage Iowas equivalent of the Christian bakers and florists who became cause clbres by refusing to provide services for same-sex weddings.

title: Thousands Stop to Smell a Flower (and Hope Not to Gag)
description: DENVER  It felt as if all of Denver was there, clutching their souvenir motion sickness bags and taking selfies as they waited for hours  and hours  for a glimpse and a whiff of this citys celebrity of the moment: the corpse flower.

title: Turning Puerto Ricos Lament Into Hope
description: A photographer and writer return to the island to find both resentment and resilience among the middle class.

title: N.Y.C. Nature: The Charming Pill Bug
description: As cute as anything found under a log, pill bugs, or roly-polies, are often the first bugs a child invites to play. My brother and I spent many hours in Canarsie poking them into little balls and rolling them around at the bottom of bottles, impatiently waiting for them to unfurl. Pill bugs are gentle, completely harmless creatures, and are often a childs first invitation to nature in the city.

title: New York Bookshelf: The Last Big Colony and the First Suburb
description: Puerto Rico has been a United States possession for 117 years, or almost as long as the Eastern Seaboard was under British domination until Americans declared independence in 1776.

title: Womens Fashion, Fall 2015
description: The latest issue from T celebrates emotional, sartorial, intellectual, artistic and stylistic transformation.

title: Friday Not Music: Talking New York
description: Somehow not feeling musical this week. But I recently took a relative to the wonderful Tenement Museum, where we listened among other things to a recording of someone who lived in the building just before it was condemned; it was fascinating, but what got my companion going was the accent, which she found hilarious and I found comforting. After all these years, its the sound of home:

title: Cuba: The Conversation Continues and Live in Cuba Expand a Musical Dialogue
description: As the American flag was raised over the United States Embassy in Cuba last Friday, the pianist and composer Arturo OFarrill could be found in the immigration area at Jos Mart International Airport in Havana. Footage of the ceremony, symbolizing the restoration of diplomatic relations severed in 1961, was being piped into the room.

title: A Russian Solider Story
description: As the tensions between Russian and Ukraine have continued, Pavel Volkov has explored the lives of young Russian conscripts with mixed reactions to the conflict.

title: Review: On Blunt Talk, Patrick Stewart Is Far From Home and Caught With His Pants Down
description: Its not accurate to say that Patrick Stewart hasnt done comedy. He was funny playing himself as a poker-faced pervert in an episode of Extras, or dancing with Kelsey Grammer and telling him how sexy he looked in a tux on Frasier. And hes lent his plummy voice to a raft of animated shows from Family Guy to Robot Chicken.

title: Bobby Jindal Calls for Holding Mayors of Sanctuary Cities Responsible for Crime
description: Not to be outdone by his Republican presidential rivals on immigration, Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana said Friday that he could secure the Southern border within six months of becoming president and called for prosecuting officials in sanctuary cities when their undocumented residents commit crimes.

title: Season 2 of Survivors Remorse Handles Touchy Topics
description: Season 2 of the Starz comedy Survivors Remorse opens the same way Season 1 did: with a joyous family checking out its new digs, laughing and shouting and dancing through the rooms. In the first season, the setting was a lavish penthouse apartment; in the second (which begins Saturday night) the clan has moved on out to an imposing suburban mini-mansion.

title: Cuba, Cuba! 65 Years of Photography at the Southampton Arts Center
description: Since the announcement of a thaw with the United States, Cuba seems suspended between potentially very different histories: what was, what is and whats to be. Of the three, the knowable one is, of course, the past, and a substantial and dramatic part of the record is in the form of photographs. The International Center of Photography has a collection deep enough to tell that visual story, and is doing so, with some outside additions, in Cuba, Cuba! 65 Years of Photography at the Southampton (N.Y.) Art Center through Sept. 7.

title: Two Good Reasons to Visit St. Albans, Queens
description: Household names and tastemakers  Fats Waller, Count Basie, Ella Fitzgerald, Lena Horne, John Coltrane, James Brown, Billie Holiday, Jackie Robinson, Joe Louis, Milt Hinton, Cootie Williams, Illinois Jacquet and Brook Benton  all lived at one time or another in Addisleigh Park, a stately enclave just north of Kennedy International Airport. The historic district is part of St. Albans, Queens, a predominantly black, middle-class neighborhood where another sort of nostalgia can be indulged at the MARIA ROSE INTERNATIONAL DOLL HOUSE, which opened in July.

title: Gunman Kills Guard Then Himself at a Federal Building in Manhattan
description: A New Jersey man walked into a federal building near the SoHo neighborhood of Manhattan on Friday afternoon and fatally shot a security guard before killing himself, the authorities said.

title: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
description: Greece and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Breast Cancer Confusion
Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: August 21, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photographs from Greece, the West Bank, Japan and Malaysia.

title: First Draft Focus: Plenty of Seats, Plenty of Time
Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Good evening. Heres the latest.

title: In the Jacobs Pillow Dance Archives, a Magical Past and Present Unite
description: BECKET, Mass.  Jacobs Pillow, the oldest dance festival in the United States and always eclectic and international in taste, began in the early 1940s. But its founding director, Ted Shawn, had been here since 1931, and when he died in 1972, still at the helm, he left the festival with archival materials that went back to his own early days in dance.

title: Nearly 51,000 Madewell Sandals Are Recalled
description: Madewell, J. Crews smaller but fast-growing hipster brand, is recalling about 50,900 pairs of sandals in the United States and Canada because they may cause wearers to trip and fall.

title: Native American Artists Display Works in Santa Fe
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  Native American artists converged here this week to sell their work in the Indigenous Fine Art Market, an artist-led initiative that formed last year as an alternative to the Santa Fe Indian Market, produced by the Southwestern Association of Indian Arts.

title: Jacob Bekenstein, Physicist Who Revolutionized Theory of Black Holes, Dies at 68
description: Jacob Bekenstein, a physicist who prevailed in an argument with Stephen Hawking that revolutionized the study of black holes, and indeed the nature of space-time itself, died on Sunday in Helsinki, Finland, where he was to give a physics lecture. He was 68.

title: Review: Pericles, Lashed by Sorrows, at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival
description: ASHLAND, Ore.  Even among the beleaguered heroes and heroines of Shakespeares late romances, the title character of Pericles stands out for the weight of strange misfortunes that chase him around the Mediterranean, and more than once dump him in it when the ships hes traveling aboard founder. (A favorite stage direction: Enter Pericles, wet.)

title: Home Care Workers Prevail in Court
description: A unanimous three-judge panel on the United States Court of Appeals in Washington, D.C. ruled on Friday that for-profit home care agencies must pay their employees at least the minimum wage and time-and-a-half for overtime.

title: Black Man Shot by Police in St. Louis Died From Bullet to Back
description: An 18-year-old St. Louis man whom the police said they shot after he pointed a gun at officers died from a bullet that entered the middle of his back and lodged near his rib cage, the citys chief medical examiner said Friday. The shooting, the latest killing of a black man by officers, has raised tensions in the region.

title: Israel Came Close to Attacking Iran, Ex-Defense Minister Says
description: JERUSALEM  A former Israeli defense minister, Ehud Barak, revealed new details to his biographers about how close Israel came to striking Irans military facilities in 2010, 2011 and 2012 and why it did not despite his and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahus desire to do so, according to interview excerpts aired on Israeli television Friday night.

title: Canadas Leader and His Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: A Constitutional Question About Innocence as a Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: John Correnti, Steel Industry Executive, Dies at 68
description: John Correnti, who was a leader in the American steel industry during its heyday and clung to it even as it faded, died on Tuesday in Chicago while on a business trip. He was 68.

title: Shirtless Bodies in Pointless Times Square War
description: In New York politics, as in Newtonian physics, there is action and reaction and, too often, overreaction.

title: F.B.I. Releases Documents About 2012 Shooting in Queens
description: In response to Freedom of Information Act requests by The New York Times, the F.B.I. has released three internal federal government reports about a July 2012 incident in Queens in which an off-duty agent shot a man apparently trying to burglarize his car. The F.B.I.s shooting incident review group deemed the shooting unjustified, making it the first such bad shoot in decades in a case involving an intentional shooting of a suspect.

title: F.B.I. Shooting Incident Reviews, 1993-2013
description: Under the Freedom of Information Act, The New York Times obtained this collection of internal reports by the Federal Bureau of Investigation reviewing shootings by F.B.I. agents. In late 2013, for the first time since at least 1993 and likely longer, this administrative review process deemed an intentional shooting by an agent of a suspect to be a bad shoot.

title: In Rare Case, F.B.I. Tries to Fire Agent Who Shot Queens Suspect
description: WASHINGTON  For the first time in decades, the F.B.I. is trying to fire an agent for intentionally shooting a suspect, after finding that the agent violated bureau policy when he wounded an unarmed man who had apparently helped break into his Lexus outside his home in Queens.

title: Man Killed and Woman Badly Hurt in Knife Fight on Harlem Sidewalk
description: A man in his 30s was fatally stabbed and a woman he was with was seriously injured when they faced off against two other people in a knife fight on a busy Harlem street on Friday, the police said.

title: Expanding Web of Scandal in Brazil Threatens Further Upheaval
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The charges are nothing less than sweeping: Prosecutors say that Eduardo Cunha, the speaker of Brazils lower house of Congress, took as much as $40 million in bribes for himself and his allies, plundering Petrobras, the government-controlled oil company, while laundering money through an evangelical megachurch.

title: Americans Foiled Train Attack
description: Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve spoke after a shooting on a train left three people wounded, saying two United States citizens helped disarm the attacker.

title: Shatterproof Window Foils Effort to Steal Fake iPhones in a Manhattan Shop
description: The sign on the Upper East Side street looks so realistic, people stop and lean closer.

title: Decades of Data Fail to Resolve Debate on Treating Tiny Breast Lesions
description: More than 30 years after the widespread use of mammograms set off a surge in the detection of tiny lesions in milk ducts, there is still debate about how  or even whether  to treat them. In an era when there has been so much study of how to treat more advanced cancer, it might seem odd that there is so much uncertainty about these minute sprinklings of abnormal cells, often called Stage 0 cancer, which some say are not cancers at all.

title: Times Square Painted Ladies Take a Pause
description: On Friday afternoon, John and Kathie Watts of Hanover, Pa., were sitting at one of the tables on the pedestrian plaza on Broadway between 43rd and 44th Streets, drinking a soda and taking in what was the very ordinary tableau of Times Square on a summer day.

title: U.S. Court Reinstates Home Care Pay Rules
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Friday reinstated regulations drawn up by the Obama administration to extend minimum wage and overtime protections to almost two million workers who provide home care for the elderly and disabled.

title: Hillary Clinton Will Interrupt Vacation to Campaign in Midwest
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton had planned to spend the last two weeks of August on vacation, unwinding and fund-raising on the exclusive shores of Long Island. But, as it turns out, this is no time for a vacation.

title: Advice After Stock Market Drop: Take Some Deep Breaths, and Dont Do a Thing
description: The impulse when the stock market falls hard for a few days in a row is to do something. Anything. Our life savings are often on the line, after all.

title: Match Lit at Manhattan School Exploded a Laboratory in Renovation
description: The renovated laboratory was hailed as state of the art. One teacher even said it would be a crown jewel of the campus shared by several high schools in Marble Hill, its unveiling so eagerly anticipated that, one mother said, paper had been put up over windows to keep students from peeking inside.

title: Inequality in Hollywood
description: To the Editor:

title: Spreading Social Capital to Close the Racial Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Hillary Clintons Woes Pushing Joe Biden to Reach Out to Those Who Could Back a Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  As Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign struggles with sliding poll numbers, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.s exploration of a presidential candidacy is taking on a new seriousness.

title: Sasha Petraske, 42, Dies; Bar Owner Restored Luster to Cocktail Culture
description: Sasha Petraske, who helped restore lost luster to the venerable cocktail as the founder of the New York cocktail bar Milk & Honey and other polished drinking spots around the world, was found dead on Friday morning at his home in Hudson, N.Y. He was 42.

title: A Perilous Moment at the Korean Border
description: The enduring, familiar tensions between North and South Korea are usually considered background noise by a world focused on other international crises. That was no longer possible after the two countries traded rocket and artillery fire across their heavily militarized border. Given North Koreas nuclear weapons arsenal and its erratic leader, Kim Jong-un, any such confrontation must be taken seriously and managed carefully, with the United States and China playing key roles in urging restraint.

title: Florida Legislators Fail to Agree on Congressional Districts
description: MIAMI  Floridas House and Senate on Friday failed to agree on a new congressional map mandated by the states Supreme Court, bringing to a futile close a legislative special session created to redraw congressional districts the court said were unconstitutionally gerrymandered.

title: Investigation Lifts a Cloud Over President of Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  A seven-month conflict-of-interest investigation into the purchase of luxury homes by President Enrique Pea Nietos wife and his finance minister from a government contractor found no wrongdoing, Mexicos comptroller said Friday.

title: Liz Perle, Writer and Former Publishing Executive, Dies at 59
description: Liz Perle, a writer and former publishing executive who co-founded Common Sense Media, a nonprofit organization dedicated to helping families navigate the complex worlds of entertainment, media and technology, died on Thursday at her home in San Francisco. She was 59.

title: Daily News Struggles to Find Its Identity After Sale Is Called Off
description: The news at The Daily News  that the owner, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, had done an about-face and decided not to sell  brought consolation to the publications newsroom, at least for now. But questions remain about The Newss long-term prospects, and about its place in both the city and the turbulent media world.

title: Microbeads, the Tiny Orbs Threatening Our Water
description: Plastic is believed to be the main contaminant in the huge garbage gyres that pollute the oceans. Now researchers, led by Sherri Mason of the State University of New York at Fredonia, have found a stunning amount of plastic in the largest freshwater ecosystem on earth, the Great Lakes. And an increasing amount of it consists of the tiny plastic orbs used as abrasives in products like toothpaste and anti-acne lotions.

title: Prospect of Self-Inspections by Iran Feeds Opposition to Nuclear Deal
description: To the most strident opponents of President Obamas nuclear deal with Iran, the suspicious behavior at a military base about 12 miles southeast of Tehran has become a rallying call to defeat the accord, especially as it now appears that Iranian officials may be allowed to take their own environmental samples at the site and turn them over to inspectors.

title: Three Killed in Washington Wildfire Are Mourned
description: CHELAN, Wash.  Tom Zbyszewski, 20, won a poetry-reciting competition but was studying physics at Whitman College, the small liberal arts school in southeastern Washington where he was about to enter his junior year. He also studied Mandarin Chinese and dabbled in theater, and got into firefighting to help pay for school.

title: For @UKLabour, RT = Endorsement, Apparently
description: Until this week, Grace Coles, a 24-year-old student in Wales, had never heard of Ken Loach, the great English filmmaker born five decades before her, whose social-realist dramas about the struggles of the British working class are more acclaimed at Cannes these days than in the multiplexes of Cardiff.

title: Jeff Bezos and the Amazon Way
description: The best thing about Jeff Bezos, the founder, chairman, president and chief executive of Amazon, is that he doesnt give a hoot what anybody else thinks. The worst thing about Jeff Bezos is that he doesnt give a hoot what anybody else thinks.

title: Flipping on the Couch
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  I had a hard time making up my mind as to whether I liked this puzzle by Barry C. Silk or not. Typically, I really enjoy solving Mr. Silks puzzles, but I just wasnt on his wavelength with this one.

title: Gay and Marked for Death
description: AS he tried to concentrate on his final college exams, he couldnt erase the terrifying images in his head, an endless replay of a video hed seen. It showed two men being killed  their necks noosed, their bodies dragged through the streets and set on fire.

title: The Trucks Are Killing Us
description: ACCIDENTS like the one that critically injured the comedian Tracy Morgan, killed his friend and fellow comedian James McNair, known as Jimmy Mack, and hurt eight others on the New Jersey Turnpike last year are going to continue to happen unless Congress stops coddling the trucking industry.

title: Readers Address the Escalating Violence in Cairo
description: For decades Cairo was considered safe for residents and visitors. Not anymore. Nearly two years of escalating bombings in and around Cairo are gradually changing the feel of the city. Neighbors are becoming more suspicious of strangers asking questions, and commuters are getting used to changing their routes to avoid police cordons after each bombing.

title: The Keys to Trumps Appeal
description: Donald J. Trump is leading the polls in the Republican presidential race, and he does well with nearly every voter demographic. But pollsters still struggle to define what drives his supporters.

title: Donald Trump Fails to Fill Alabama Stadium, but Fans Zeal Is Undiminished
description: MOBILE, Ala.  Before Donald J. Trump arrived at a college football stadium here on Friday evening, the colorful guessing games that often accompany his campaign were very much in the air.

title: After a Promise to Keep in Touch, Obama and Modi Get a Hotline
description: When President Obama and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India hugged and said their goodbyes in January after Mr. Obamas state visit to India, the two leaders promised to keep in touch.

title: New Rules on Crowding for the Hamptons Express
description: The track number appeared on the train board at Pennsylvania Station, and the beachgoers wasted no time.

title: Shaky Defense Creates Familiar Feeling for Jets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It was still early in the game, a preseason game, the first one at MetLife Stadium this season, but already the boos were building. Already the Jets trailed by two scores. The offense was scuffling; the defense seemed hapless; even the special teams suffered. It looked all too familiar.

title: Yoenis Cespedess Three Homers, One a Grand Slam, Lead the Mets Over the Rockies
description: DENVER  Yoenis Cespedes crossed home plate, mouthed Wow and flashed a smile. He had just golfed a low curveball to the opposite field, over the wall in right-center field, and everyone at Coors Field seemed to have the same reaction as him.

title: Escaping a Meeting With the Indians Ace, the Yankees Cant Take Advantage
description: Masahiro Tanaka is not recognized as a superstitious pitcher. There is no rabbits foot or unusual talisman in his locker. Unlike some players, he freely walks on the first-base line when entering and exiting an inning.

title: Trump Rebukes Obama on Bergdahl
description: At a campaign event in Mobile, Ala., the Republican presidential candidate Donald J. Trump criticized President Obamas handling of the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who is charged with desertion.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) DUMB AND DUMBER TO (2014) Jim Carrey and Jeff Daniels reprise their roles as the dimwitted Providence pals Lloyd Christmas and Harry Dunne, who set out once again on a cross-country road trip in their tongue-wagging puppy-mobile  this time to find Harrys biological daughter. Both Mr. Carrey and Mr. Daniels have slowed down without cleaning up their act, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this comedy from Peter and Bobby Farrelly, which was a critical flop but a box-office success. To that end, as it were, this sequel is just, uh, packed, or perhaps smeared, with a whole lot of poop jokes. There are diaper gags, lots of them, mostly pretty funny, and a couple of peekaboo looks at a feline rear end. But, she added, the Farrellys are still not much interested in film as a visual medium, and when Lloyd and Harry arent smacking each other or dropping their pants, you might as well be listening to a radio play.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 22, 2015
description: I apologize to the women Ive hurt. I deeply regret what I did and know that it has forever impacted all of our lives.

title: Corrections: August 22, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Turning Point: Mark Kauzlarich
description: Mark Kauzlarich, a New York Times photography intern this summer, has previously worked for Reuters and The Chronicle of Higher Education, and his work has been published by Time. Mr.Kauzlarich, 25, participated in the 2013 Eddie Adams Workshop and the 2015 New York Portfolio Review. His conversation with Elijah Walker has been edited.

title: South and North Korea Hold Talks to Defuse Border Tensions
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South and North Korea held a high-level meeting on their border on Saturday and agreed to meet again on Sunday, South Korean officials said, apparently easing, at least temporarily, a tense standoff that has prevailed since the countries exchanged artillery fire two days ago.

title: Who Owns Helen Gurley Browns Legacy?
description: From the apartment of Helen Gurley Brown  No. 22D, a turreted quadruplex in the Beresford building on Central Park West  one can glimpse among the sleek modernist skyscrapers in the Manhattan skyline the Norman Foster-designed Hearst Tower directly to the south, a little over a mile away. Famously thrifty, Ms. Brown, the legendary editor of Cosmopolitan magazine, commuted there on the M10 bus well into her 80s.

title: All In Good Taste
description: After a series of heartbreaks and long distance dating, the couple find they complement each other perfectly.

title: Valerie Masten and Jon Bonn: Brought Together by a Shared Love of Wine
description: For many years Valerie Masten dated men whose idea of dining out was a burger and milkshake downed in the front seat of a car.

title: Vaccinations Bring Hope, Bracelets Deliver Reminders
description: Because of the vaccine alliance Gavi, United Nations agencies, the World Bank, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and other donors, immunizations have soared in developing countries over the last 15 years. As a result, an estimated seven million children have survived infancy who before the year 2000 would have died young.

title: Ted Cruz, Seeking Converts to His Campaign, Rallies Iowa Evangelicals
description: DES MOINES  Senator Ted Cruz on Friday night drew one of the largest crowds in Iowa of any candidate this year: some 2,300 Christian conservatives, who turned out for an unusual program featuring people Mr. Cruz called victims of government persecution.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted by @nytimes took followers to a shrinking lake in California, and Rockefeller Plaza in 1944.

title: Fading Economy and Graft Crackdown Rattle Chinas Leaders
description: HONG KONG  The start to the day was hardly unusual for a senior Chinese leader in a country grappling with an economic slowdown. On the morning of July 24, Zhou Benshun attended a meeting to promote one of President Xi Jinpings signature projects, a plan to boost growth by building a supercity that would integrate Beijing with the region around it.

title: Farhad and Katies Week in Tech: Amazon and Ashley Madison Exposed
description: Farhad: Hey, Katie! Mike is off snorkeling in Hawaii, so Im thrilled that youre free to help me make sense of this weeks tech news. You have some small shoes to fill!

title: Hold the Burger Smell, Please
description: The Burger Stench

title: Judge Increases Pressure on U.S. to Release Migrant Families
description: A federal judge in California has given the Obama administration two months to change its detention practices to ensure the rapid release of children and their parents caught crossing the border illegally.

title: A Shot, a Glimpse of an AK-47, and U.S. Servicemen Pounced on Gunman on Train to France
description: PARIS  It was 5:45 p.m., a normal Friday afternoon on the sleek high-speed train that takes high-level European diplomats, businesspeople, tourists and ordinary citizens between Amsterdam, Brussels and Paris.

title: After 70 Years of Men, Some Say It Is High Time a Woman Led the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS  The bearded diplomat in a striped tie addressed a roomful of his peers the other morning on the subject of how the next United Nations secretary general should be chosen.

title: Passengers Tell How They Subdued Gunman
