description: Two American passengers and a British businessman describe how they subdued a gunman on a high-speed train traveling from Amsterdam to Paris.

title: Variety: A Starry Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Samuel L. Clemens, who wrote under the nom de plume MARK TWAIN, is one of my favorite fiction authors, and so it was a very pleasant surprise to find a quote from his novel HUCKLEBERRY FINN as todays acrostic.

title: Why Donald Trump Wont Fold: Polls and People Speak
description: In the command centers of Republican presidential campaigns, aides have drawn comfort from the belief that Donald J. Trumps dominance in the polls is a political summer fling, like Herman Cain in 2011  an unsustainable boomlet dependent on megawatt celebrity, narrow appeal and unreliable surveys of Americans with a spotty record of actually voting in primaries.

title: Investors Race to Escape Risk in Once-Booming Emerging-Market Bonds
description: The large mutual funds that helped fuel rapid growth in developing countries have begun hastily retreating from those investments, contributing to the recent sharp decline in global markets.

title: Merl Reagle, January 5, 1950  August 22, 2015
description: SPECIAL POST  It is with great sadness that we announce the death of ber-constructor Merl Reagle on Saturday, August 22, 2015. Mr. Reagle was 65 years old.

title: Kabul Suicide Bombing Kills 12, Including 3 Americans
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Three foreigners working for the American-led military coalition were among 12 people killed Saturday when their vehicle was targeted by a suicide car bomber, according to Afghan and American military accounts.

title: Bernie Sanders Courts Black Voters in South Carolina After Criticism on Racial Issues
description: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.  After activists with Black Lives Matter disrupted his campaign appearances this summer, Senator Bernie Sanders, the surging if still long-shot candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination, added a new section to his hour-plus stump speech, explicitly addressing racial injustice.

title: Surprise Star of 2013 U.S. Open Receives No Break in Comeback
description: MASON, Ohio  Though the distribution of wild cards into the United States Open is often scrutinized, rarely have so many agreed that one player was treated unfairly by the United States Tennis Association.

title: Obama on the Vineyard? Been There, Seen That
description: CHILMARK, Mass.  In 2009, this island buzzed with excitement as President Obama, then still a newcomer to the Oval Office, arrived here for his first presidential summer vacation.

title: Mark Toro of North American Properties: Who Will Do What by When?
description: This interview with Mark Toro, managing partner and chairman of North American Properties  Atlanta Ltd., was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Looming Confrontation of Usain Bolt and Justin Gatlin Would Be a Morality Play
description: BEIJING  The 100-meter race billed as a morality play will not come, if it comes, until Sunday nights final in the Birds Nest stadium.

title: Currency Devaluation Is a Short Step in Chinas Long Advance
description: When Chinas currency, the renminbi, fell against the dollar on Aug. 11, it set off a furor.

title: Pirates Slugger Savors a Legacy of Consistency
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates have been so successful lately that the culture change at PNC Park is old news. After breaking a streak of 20 consecutive losing seasons, the Pirates have started a new streak: This will be their third playoff season in a row, barring a collapse down the stretch.

title: Donal OConghaile: Shepherd of Free Samples
description: Donal OConghaile, 27, is an online community manager at Social Media Link, a marketing agency in New York.

title: After a Long Absence, a Return to the Game Can Be Tough
description: It is one of the most famous numbers in sports. Ted Williams had a .406 batting average for the Boston Red Sox in 1941, which was the last time a batter reached the .400 mark for a full season. But technically it was not the last time Williams hit .400. It was not even the highest batting average of his career.

title: Profile Emerges of Suspect in Attack on Train to Paris
description: LONDON  The young man who emerged from a Thalys train bathroom on Friday with a Kalashnikov assault rifle, pistol and box cutter is believed to be Ayoub El Kahzani, 26, of Moroccan origin, who was known to the Spanish and French security services and is reported to have traveled to Syria last year.

title: The States Show Up Congress on Road Repairs
description: As the nations bridges and roads deteriorate and Congress dawdles over a serious solution, statehouse politicians have been stepping up at a surprising rate to make some difficult choices.

title: The Push for a Woman to Run the U.N.
description: The United Nations has had eight secretaries general. All have been men. Each has been selected through back-room dealing dominated by the five world powers that hold permanent seats on the Security Council.

title: The Myth of the New Orleans School Makeover
description: WAS Hurricane Katrina the best thing that happened to the education system in New Orleans, as Education Secretary Arne Duncan once said? Nearly 10 years after the disaster, this has become a dominant narrative among a number of school reformers and education scholars.

title: How Changeable Is Gender?
description: THANKS to Caitlyn Jenner, and the militarys changing policies, transgender people are gaining acceptance  and living in a bigger, more understanding spotlight than at any previous time.

title: The Ghost House of My Childhood
description: THE distant earth bristles with tiny imitations of houses and roads as I slide through the air in the silver ghost, a miracle of science. Now that my second parent has passed away, all things seem strange. Am I awake or asleep? I am flying back to Memphis, the place of my childhood, to settle the last of my fathers affairs and to see one final time the house where we all lived.

title: A Look Inside Amazon
description: Readers discuss the demanding, competitive environment promoted by Jeff Bezos.

title: Ospreys: The Birds of Summer
description: THE other morning, as I sat on the porch having my coffee, an osprey came plummeting down toward me out of a smoky, overcast sky, with a fish caught in his talons. He was screeching, See, see, seeeee! over and over. I suppose there must have been another osprey in the neighborhood. The males can be shameless at showing off their catch, but its mainly for other birds, not me.

title: Taking My Parents to College
description: IT was a simple question, but we couldnt find the answer in any of the paperwork the college had sent. How long was my family supposed to stay for orientation? This was 1999, so Google wasnt really a verb yet, and we were a low-income family (according to my new school) without regular Internet access.

title: Target Shooters Bring Mayhem to National Forests
description: Recreational target shooters call it trigger trash  tons and tons of refrigerators, car parts, televisions, sofas, bowling pins and other unwanted junk that shooters haul onto pristine federal woodlands and shred with gunfire for sheer enjoyment.

title: Jonathan Sumption
description: Jonathan Sumption, called by some the brain of Britain, is a justice on the British Supreme Court and author of several highly regarded books on medieval history.

title: Gay Rights and the Race Analogy
description: Now that same-sex couples can marry in all 50 states, controversies are erupting over clerks who dont want to issue same-sex marriage licenses, bakers who dont want to bake cakes for same-sex weddings, photographers who dont want to take our pictures and so on.

title: Donald Trump Struts in His Own Pageant
description: Washington  SOME blondes have all the fun.

title: Hybrid-Powered Megayachts Come With Green Bragging Rights
description: In the new arms race of conspicuous environmentalism, the wealthy have been building green mansions, driving hybrid supercars and buying carbon offsets for their private jets. But now the eco-conscious rich have reached a new high-water mark: the hybrid megayacht.

title: In a Data-Driven N.F.L., the Pings May Soon Outstrip the Xs and Os
description: When 80,000 fans pack MetLife Stadium each time the Giants and the Jets play this season, they are unlikely to notice the 22 new radio receivers placed discreetly around the building. Nor will they see the radio frequency chips embedded in every players shoulder pads.

title: What the Psychic Showed Me
description: LOS ANGELES  When I was 21, I made two promises to my best friend, Julie, who was dying. They were youthful vows, born of deep love and deeper grief. The first was that I would name a child after her, if I ever became a mother. The second was that I would visit a psychic medium after she was gone and attempt to find out how she was.

title: Migrants Rush Across Border in Macedonia
description: SKOPJE, Macedonia  Hours after several hundred migrants bypassed a line of baton-wielding police officers on Saturday to enter Macedonia from Greece, nearly all those remaining on the Greek side of the border were allowed in, according to video footage and human rights activists at the scene. By Saturday evening, only around 200 people were left behind a fenced area on the line that separates the two countries.

title: An Internet Mortgage Provider Reaps the Rewards of Lending Boldly
description: You have substantial assets, but your income is erratic and your finances are what in polite company would be called complex. Your credit history may contain a smudge or two. Yet you would like to buy one more luxury apartment.

title: Chaos at the Macedonian Border
description: Hundreds of refugees managed to get past a police cordon set up to prevent them from crossing into the country from Greece.

title: Dinner and Deception
description: ITS 4:25 p.m. I make my way through the kitchen, past the prep cooks, up to the locker room on the second floor. Getting dressed takes 10 minutes. That leaves 20 to get family meal before the porters break everything down. At 4:55, Im ready. Lineup is in five minutes  live at five. I double-check my uniform, an expensive-looking suit issued by the restaurant, before I join the rest of the wait staff downstairs.

title: Movement Builds to Honor Greg Louganis on a Wheaties Box
description: When Julie Sondgerath learned from the premiere of the HBO documentary Greg Louganis: Back on Board this month that Louganis, the transcendent Olympic diver, had never been on the cover of a Wheaties cereal box, she started a petition drive on Change.org to demand that General Mills correct an omission that has lasted more than 30 years.

title: A New Racing Star From Nazareth, Pa.
description: Sage Karam, an IndyCar rookie who hails from the same town as the Andretti family, will compete Sunday at Pocono.

title: The New Face of IndyCar Racing Has an Audacious Style
description: NAZARETH, Pa.  Past the cornfields and a small industrial plant, past the Brazilian steakhouse and the Latin fusion restaurant, among the rolling hills and quiet streets of this quaint Pennsylvania town, Sage Karams racing career took root.

title: Macedonias Border Breached
description: Riot police couldnt hold back a tide of of refugees and migrants massed at the border with Greece.

title: A British House Overflowing With Lords Draws Scorn
description: LONDON  Britains unelected and overcrowded House of Lords lost one of its members last month, when a newspaper expos prompted the resignation of Lord Sewel of Gilcomstoun in Aberdeen, a former university lecturer who was accused of snorting cocaine with a prostitute and pictured wearing an orange bra.

title: A Racket Maestro Makes His Yearly Migration
description: Many people who love tennis and play regularly within New Yorks five boroughs know Woody Schneider. At one time or another, they need him. And so do their rackets.

title: 7 Dead as Fighter Jet Crashes Into Highway at British Airshow
description: LONDON  A fighter jet taking part in a British airshow on Saturday crashed into a highway, killing seven people.

title: In Case You Missed It: Top Articles of the Week
description: Catch up with the most-read sports stories in The New York Times from Aug. 14 to Aug. 20.

title: Joe Biden, Considering White House Bid, Meets With Elizabeth Warren
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Saturdaysummoned Senator Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts, to his Washington residence for a meeting, the latest indication that he is seriously considering a presidential bid.

title: 3 Who Stopped Train Attack Were Boyhood Friends
description: By May, it was decided: Three friends who met as middle-schoolers in California would take a European vacation.

title: Serving Up New Return, Roger Federer Advances to Final
description: MASON, Ohio  Despite the adage about old dogs, Roger Federer is still learning new tricks at 34.

title: On Day Filled With Yankees Pomp, Luis Severino Earns First Win
description: As a cadre of Yankees greats were being introduced  Bernie Williams, Andy Pettitte, Derek Jeter and so forth  Luis Severino casually jogged in the outfield, occasionally glancing toward the ceremony taking place in front of the pitchers mound, which would soon become his stage for the afternoon.

title: Train Attack in Europe Puts Focus on Vulnerability of U.S. Rail
description: WASHINGTON  The attempted attack by an armed man aboard a high-speed train in Europe has raised new concerns in the United States about the vulnerability of rail passengers and whether current security measures are adequate.

title: Will Shortz on Merl Reagle
description: SPECIAL POST  I first met Merl at Stamford in March 1979, at Year 2 of the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. He competed for his only time and finished third, behind Miriam Raphael and Nancy Schuster. Everyone knows how great a constructor Merl was. Who knew he was such a good solver, too?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Forget a Settlement, Just Make a Ruling

title: Rand Paul Can Seek Re-Election and White House Run, Kentucky G.O.P. Decides
description: Senator Rand Paul, averting what would have been a blow to his waning presidential hopes, engineered a vote by the Kentucky Republican Party on Saturday to change the states presidential nomination contest from a primary to a caucus.

title: Unraveling of Gunman Began Long Before Killing a Guard and Himself in Manhattan
description: The foundations of Kevin Downings life had begun to crumble long before he opened fire at a federal building in Manhattan on Friday.

title: Yankees Retire Jorge Posadas No. 20, With a Nod to No. 15
description: It has been 36 years now, Diana Munson said on Saturday, so very long since her world changed forever and the Yankees lost their captain. She is grateful that fans still revere her husband, Thurman, part of a proud line of Yankees catchers with retired numbers and plaques in Monument Park.

title: Speaker of Pakistan Assembly Is Removed in Election Dispute
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  The speaker of the Pakistani National Assembly, Sardar Ayaz Sadiq, was unseated on Saturday after an election tribunal declared that his victory in the 2013 general election was marred by irregularities. The election tribunal ordered a new election in Mr. Sadiqs district in the eastern city of Lahore.

title: Ieng Thirith, Khmer Rouge Minister in Cambodia, Dies at 83
description: Ieng Thirith, the sister-in-law and close collaborator of the genocidal Cambodian leader Pol Pot, died on Saturday in Pailin, Cambodia. She was 83.

title: Ohio Bill Would Ban Abortion if Down Syndrome Is Reason
description: CLEVELAND  Opening a new front in the abortion wars, abortion opponents are pushing Ohio to make it illegal for a doctor to perform an abortion if a woman is terminating her pregnancy to avoid having a baby with Down syndrome.

title: One Killed in Explosion at China Chemical Site
description: BEIJING  A fatal explosion at a chemical factory in eastern China on Saturday night has jangled nerves a little more than a week after a series of blasts killed more than 120 people at a chemical storage facility about 200 miles away, Chinese news media reported.

title: Musical Remixes
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Well, this one kept me humming for quite a while. I do like a musical theme, particularly one as well thought out as this one by Joel Fagliano.

title: Shabab Bombing Kills at Least 11 at Somali Army Camp
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  At least 11 people were killed, including two attackers, and scores were wounded Saturday in a suicide bombing against a military training camp in Kismayo, about 300 miles south of the Somali capital, Mogadishu, Somali and African Union officials said.

title: Pakistan Cancels Talks With India, Citing Restrictions
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan announced Saturday that it was pulling out of talks with India scheduled to begin Sunday in New Delhi, saying the conditions set by India for the meeting were not acceptable.

title: Svetlana Boym, 56, Scholar of Myth and Memory, Dies
description: Svetlana Boym, a scholar and artist whose work illuminated the haunting, quicksilver counterpoint of myth, memory and identity, died on Aug. 5 in Boston. She was 56.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Giant Panda Gives Birth to Two Cubs at the National Zoo
description: Panda lovers, rejoice. Mei Xiang, a giant panda at the National Zoo in Washington, gave birth to healthy twin cubs on Saturday, just three days after the zoos staff discovered that she was pregnant.

title: One Year After War, People of Gaza Still Sit Among the Ruins
description: GAZA CITY  The men of Shejaiya still come daily to sit vigil in the desolate ruins of their neighborhood, drinking tea and playing chess. But these days, there are also clusters of construction workers on Shejaiyas dirt paths, finally pouring a few cement foundations and hammering together wood planks.

title: Year After Death, Business as Usual at Arizona Gun Range
description: WHITE HILLS, Ariz.  Antonio Nrdiz, a Spanish tourist from Bilbao, said he had chosen a family vacation to America for one specific reason: to fulfill his sons dreams of firing real machine guns. In Spain, he noted, 10-year-old Jon and 12-year-old Toni, like all other civilians, are forbidden to use automatic weapons.

title: Soaring Art Market Attracts a New Breed of Advisers for Collectors
description: Amy Cappellazzo jolted New Yorks art world recently when she left her powerful position as chairwoman of Christies postwar and contemporary department to become a private art adviser, quickly brokering sales like Christies $82 million sale of a Rothko painting this spring.

title: Mets Bats Give Traveling Fans Plenty to Cheer
description: DENVER  More than 1,600 miles from New York, several hundred Mets fans gathered down the left-field line at Coors Field on Saturday night, forming a block of orange. They waved flags and towels and banners, and they chanted, Lets go, Mets! whenever the Mets scored, which was so often it became a chorus of the night.

title: Mahmoud Abbas to Resign P.L.O. Leadership Position, Officials Say
description: JERUSALEM  Mahmoud Abbas on Saturday declared his intention to resign from his position as head of the executive committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization, according to two members of the committee, in a political maneuver apparently designed to boost his legitimacy within the organization.

title: Joan Rivers Dies at 81
description: Ms. Rivers, known for a wit that some critics saw as comic genius and others dismissed as downright nasty, died on Thursday.

title: Giants First-String Offense Trips Again
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants are expecting major production from their offense, and from Odell Beckham Jr. in particular, as they try to rebound from last years 6-10 record and snap a string of three consecutive seasons without a playoff berth.

On Sunday morning, Pandit Prasad Sharma is to lead a Hindu ceremony at the Four Seasons Resort the Biltmore, also in Santa Barbara.

title: Walking in Wars Path
description: Meet a wounded Israeli soldier, a 5-year-old stuck in Gaza and a 24-year-old in Gaza who finds comfort in horse-jumping. For them and many others, daily life is full of reminders of last years Israel-Gaza war.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 23, 2015
description: Even if he doesnt win, hes teaching other politicians to stop being politicians. He comes on strong. He could say it gently. But I think no one would listen.

title: Corrections: August 23, 2015
description: SPORTS

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know to start your week.

title: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here are the weeks top stories.

title: World Athletics Championship 2015 Opens
description: Beijing celebrated the opening of the World Athletics Championship at the Birds Nest stadium on Saturday, Aug. 22.

title: Community Policing, Tested in Far Rockaway
description: The 101st Precinct, a low-income and former beach resort community wary of police, is one of four city neighborhoods part of a trial of problem-solving-focused police work.

title: In New York, Testing Grounds for Community Policing
description: Residents on the street rarely return the greetings of the precinct commander. Officers complain that their overtures are usually rebuffed, but they travel even short distances by car and drive down pedestrian paths in housing developments, cruising past staring faces. Many leave the Queens precinct for meals, some crossing into Nassau County for coffee at Starbucks.

title: From Whitewater to Email: the Clintons Dogged Lawyer
description: WASHINGTON  At first, he had to worry about a remote piece of land in Arkansas that no one wanted. Then there were billing records that went missing before mysteriously reappearing in the White House. And of course there was the blue dress.

title: North Korea Moves Forces Amid Talks With South
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea had deployed twice as many artillery pieces as usual along the border with South Korea on Sunday, and most of its submarines had departed from their bases, as high-level talks between the two Koreas aimed at breaking a tense military standoff stretched into a third day on Monday.

title: Immigration Crisis Shifts From Border to Courts
description: Wearing Vans shoes and rubber-band bracelets, hair gel and shy smiles, the brothers Brayan and Jos looked like typical teenagers.

title: 1940: Vichy Curbs Aperitif Drinking In Law Against Drunkenness
description: VICHY  Drastic measures to suppress alcoholism and drunkenness in France are embodied in a law which will be published in the Journal Officiel tomorrow [Aug. 24]. According to the terms of this law, consumption of aperitifs (drinks before meals) containing more than 16 per cent alcohol will henceforth be prohibited. Furthermore, drinking of aperitifs will be limited to four days a week, namely Mondays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Sundays. The sale of these drinks is also forbidden to minors under twenty years of age.

title: After a Fathers Heart Attack, a Well-Meant Lie Backfires on the Playground
description: When my pilot husband had a heart attack overseas, I lied to our 11-year-old son. At the time, I thought it was the right decision. I was wrong.

title: Usain Bolt Holds Off Justin Gatlin to Win World 100-Meter Title
description: BEIJING  A night at the world championships that many had feared would become a cautionary tale for track and field turned into a tale of two stumbles instead.

title: A Basketball Life, Shown From a High School Locker Room
description: The stage, such as it is is a phrase that has appeared in connection with at least one of Ed Schmidts critically acclaimed shows. It might have stung someone who was less determined, because the theater was his apartment in Brooklyn. For one production, the stage, such as it was, was his kitchen and dining room. For the other, it was his living room.

title: Much at Stake in Academys Hunt for a 2016 Oscars Producer
description: LOS ANGELES  Will the next Academy Awards ceremony be street smart, like the House Party movies? Digitally savvy, with a BuzzFeed twist? Or as grandly mainstream as, oh, almost anything Tom Hanks has ever done?

title: People Sought in Bangkok Bombing May Have Fled Country, Police Say
description: BANGKOK  Thailands chief of police said Sunday that those responsible for the deadly attack on a Bangkok shrine last week may have already fled the country, apparently trying to lower public expectations that the main person being sought would be caught anytime soon.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (AMC) FEAR THE WALKING DEAD In this prequel to The Walking Dead, a blended family  a tough-love mom (Kim Dickens), a nice-guy stepdad (Cliff Curtis) and their rebellious daughter (Alycia Debnam-Carey) and heroin-addicted son (Frank Dillane)  find themselves outmaneuvering zombies after a flu epidemic in Los Angeles turns out to be so much more, above. But if The Walking Dead is one of televisions quietest shows, this one  with the sirens, helicopters, news reports and cellphones of a functioning society  raises the decibels to amp up the suspense. It feels like a crutch, and also a sign that the shows creators, who include Robert Kirkman, the impresario of the Walking Dead graphic novel and TV franchise, arent nearly as sure of their footing this time around, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. And the domestic-drama tropes  teenage rebellion, the messiness of divorce, dealing with addiction  seem tired in this context, he added. Theres a point being made about the dissolution of everyday society, but watching it being made is like eating your vegetables  youd rather skip ahead to the flesh.

title: Hannibal Recap: Do You See?
description: Season 3, Episode 12: The Number of the Beast Is 666

title: Myanmar Striking Rohingya From Voter Rolls, Activists Say
description: YANGON, Myanmar  As an elected lawmaker and member of Myanmars governing party, U Shwe Maung attended dinners with the president and made speeches from the floor of Parliament. But this weekend, the countrys election commission ruled that despite more than four years in office, he was not a citizen and thus was ineligible to run for re-election in landmark voting in November.

title: 1965: Bubble Gum Blows Into Art World
description: NEW YORK  For those who feel the Theater of the Absurd has had it, theres a whole new world of absurdities coming up strong in the field of art. Bubble-gum art, for example. Only a few weeks ago, an elaborate announcement extolled its possibilities. Attached to the announcement  and wrapped in hygienic cellophane  were six gaily colored pellets of bubble-gum, not to be chewed and loudly popped, but to be chewed, gingerly removed from the mouth and stuck on a blank canvas.

title: Compton Spends Second Week at Top of Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES  Despite growing dismay that Straight Outta Compton glosses over Dr. Dres history of physical abuse toward women, that Universal Pictures drama was again the No. 1 movie in North America, easily defeating three R-rated newcomers.

title: Clashes Break Out During Protests Over Trash Crisis in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Thousands of protesters streamed into downtown Beirut for a second day on Sunday to demand that the government resign over its inability to remove enormous heaps of garbage from the citys streets. The demonstrations led to clashes with the police, who turned fire hoses and tear gas guns on the crowds.

title: As Rivals Snipe, Donald Trump Dodges Questions on Details of Immigration Plan
description: Donald J. Trump repeatedly side-stepped questions on Sunday about how he would pay for his new plan to deport undocumented immigrants, and he also faced criticism from several rivals for the Republican presidential nomination about his call to end so-called birthright citizenship for children of those immigrants.

title: Wiz Khalifa Arrested for Refusing to Get Off Hoverboard
description: The rapper Wiz Khalifa was handcuffed and forced to the ground by law enforcement officers at Los Angeles International Airport on Saturday night for, he said, refusing to get off a hoverboard.

title: Obamas Quiet Vacation Will Yield to a Noisy September
description: WASHINGTON  Like April for accountants or December for flying reindeer, September in recent years has become an especially challenging month for presidents and congressional leaders.

title: New York City Films Czar Resigns
description: Cynthia Lopez, the commissioner of the Mayors Office of Media and Entertainment in New York City, announced her resignation over the weekend. Ms. Lopez has held the post for 16 months. Luis Castro, the first deputy commissioner of the office, will serve as acing commissioner once she departs in October to pursue new opportunities in the production industry.

title: Stone Speaks on Taking Down Gunman
description: Spencer Stone, a United States airman, recounts how he and his two American friends stopped the gunman on the high-speed train traveling to France.

title: Americans Resist Hero Label After Foiling Train Attack
description: PARIS  Looking awed by the sumptuous gilded surroundings of the United States ambassadors residence here, the three young American men who thwarted an attack on a Paris-bound express train appeared at a news conference on Sunday, brushing aside suggestions that they were heroes.

title: La MaMa to Open New Theater
description: La MaMa, an experimental performing arts space in the East Village, will open a new venue called The Downstairs in November. The Downstairs is La MaMas fourth theater, and will be at the same address as the groups Ellen Stewart Theater.

title: German Town to Add Security After Anti-Refugee Protests
description: FRANKFURT  The German police planned to step up security measures in a small town outside Dresden on Sunday after two nights of sometimes violent demonstrations by right-wing extremists near a temporary shelter for refugees.

title: 2 Bodies Found After Fire in a Debris-Filled Home in Far Rockaway
description: Two people were found dead on Sunday afternoon after a fire in a home in Far Rockaway, Queens, that was cluttered with debris, the Fire Department said.

title: Letters: Mario Vargas Llosa Responds
description: To the Editor:

title: Al Qaeda Fighters Try to Seize Yemeni Military Base in Aden
description: MAHRA, Yemen  Dozens of fighters belonging to Al Qaedas Yemeni affiliate briefly tried to seize control of a military base and the presidential palace in the port city of Aden before suddenly withdrawing on Sunday, according to local fighters and a senior military official in the city.

title: Baffert Makes It Official as American Pharoah Allays Anxiety
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  They take their Midsummer Derby seriously here in this old horse town. So shortly after noon Sunday, when the track announcer Larry Collmus ebulliently said, Yes, hes coming  hell be here at the Spa, racegoers knew exactly what he was talking about.

title: Review: Helen Phillips Tweaks Corporate Culture in The Beautiful Bureaucrat
description: Helen Phillipss unusual and deeply interesting third book, The Beautiful Bureaucrat, looks at first to be a piercing little satire (its just 180 pages) about the horrors of contemporary corporate culture. After a spell of unemployment, a young woman named Josephine Newbury gratefully snaps up the first job she can find: an entry-level, data-input position at a soulless behemoth of a company named AZ (or is it ZA?) in a place that may or may not be Brooklyn.

title: Roger Federer Beats Novak Djokovic to Win Western & Southern Open
description: MASON, Ohio  As he tries to reach new heights amid the crowded landscape of tennis history, Novak Djokovic keeps finding the same immovable objects blocking his path.

title: Donald Trump Pays a Visit to His Not-So-Poor Relations
description: Recent days this summer have found Donald J. Trump, the current leader among Republican presidential candidates, drawing crowds of voters in New Hampshire or Iowa, even Alabama or Michigan.

title: Review: Haydns Creation: The Birth of All, With High Hopes at Mostly Mozart
description: Three angels preside over George Benjamins 2012 opera, Written on Skin, the highlight of this years Mostly Mozart festival at Lincoln Center. And, in a neat bit of symmetry, three angels also serve as narrators in Haydns sunny oratorio masterpiece The Creation, which closed the monthlong festival on Friday and Saturday at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Explosions Rock U.S. Army Storage Depot Near Tokyo
description: WASHINGTON  Explosions of still-undetermined origin rocked a United States Army storage depot early Monday near Tokyo, the Pentagon said. No injuries were reported.

title: Review: Grace Jones Headlines a Bold Afropunk Festival Lineup
description: Maybe I should take off my shoes and go totally tribal, Grace Jones said.

title: Ohio State Is First Unanimous No. 1 in Preseason A.P. Poll
description: Ohio State, the defending national champion, became the first unanimous No. 1 selection in the 65-year history of The Associated Presss preseason college football poll on Sunday.

title: Chinas Disaster Management
description: Explosions in Tianjin have set off a national debate about the hazards of storing toxic chemicals close to residential areas.

title: Comedy Festivals in New York That Focus on the Eclectic
description: After a stand-up show a few years ago, the Brooklyn comedians Julian Kiani and Chris Nester hit upon a seemingly obvious question: Is there a Brooklyn Comedy Festival? We realized there wasnt, and that there should be, Mr. Nester said.

title: Sarah Sze Aims for Precise Randomness in Installing Her Gallery Show
description: It is morning in Manhattan. Most of the art world is still asleep or out of town for an August vacation. But at the Tanya Bonakdar Gallery on West 21st Street in Chelsea, the artist Sarah Sze debates the placement of dried paint strips.

title: Another Drama in Harper Lees Hometown
description: MONROEVILLE, Ala.  Its been just over a month since the release of Go Set a Watchman, the long-awaited second novel from Harper Lee. The book has been the publishing sensation of the year, but the literary world has largely moved on now, focused on new releases for the fall and winter.

title: Banksys Dismaland in England: Its a Strange World, After All
description: WESTON-SUPER-MARE, England  Rain pelted down for much of Sunday afternoon on this drooping beachside resort town where Dismaland, the gloomy anti-Disneyland created by the artist Banksy, opened this weekend.

title: Injury to C.C. Sabathia and Another Yankees Loss Cast Shadow on Day Honoring Andy Pettitte
description: Shortly after the clutch left-hander Andy Pettitte saw his No. 46 retired and a plaque dedicated to him at Yankee Stadiums Monument Park on Sunday, another onetime Yankees ace trudged off the mound toward an uncertain future.

title: Protesters and Police Clash in Lebanon
description: In downtown Beirut, Lebanon, the garbage crisis took a violent turn on Sunday when protesters and the police clashed.

title: Nobody Could Have Predicted, Interest Rates Edition
description: Sorry about sparsity of posts; on the road for family reasons, with real life getting in the way of digital. But I did see a number of people praising remarks from Charlie Munger declaring himself flabbergasted by low interest rates, with a sideswipe at anyone who claims to have had some inkling:

title: Ill Defer On This One
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  At first, I thought Lynn Lempel had lost it. That might not be so unusual, considering her prolific constructing record. Spending a lot of time with black and white squares does something to a person.

title: The Unicorn Club, Now Admitting New Members
description: SAN FRANCISCO  One hallmark of the current technology boom is a generation of start-ups valued at $1 billion or more by investors. Now meet the start-ups-in-waiting that may be next to reach that mark, if the white-hot market continues.

title: 50 Companies That May Be the Next Start-Up Unicorns
description: It used to be a rare thing when start-ups were valued at $1 billion or more by their investors. Now its become so common that there are at least 131 start-ups boasting such valuations and a term  unicorns  to refer to the companies.

title: ISIS Blows Up Ancient Temple at Syrias Palmyra Ruins
description: Militants from the Islamic State set off explosions at a temple in the ancient ruins of Palmyra in Syria, activists and government officials said on Sunday, continuing a pattern of destruction that they have visited upon historical sites across the territory they control there and in Iraq.

title: Misty Copeland, the Under Armour Star
description: Misty Copeland, who in June became the first African-American woman to be named a principal dancer in the 75-year history of the American Ballet Theater, joins Under Armours roster of professional athletes.

title: Tom Brady Still a Key Part of Under Armours Broader Ad Push
description: Under Armour has not given up on Tom Brady.

title: Full Bellies Are the Measure of Afghan Influence and Hospitality
description: SHEBERGHAN, Afghanistan  It is an unassailable truth of Afghan politics, particularly after the advent of a democratic system here, that influence is gained one stomach at a time.

title: Mets Rest Matt Harvey and Get Their Sweep, Too, as Logan Verrett Stands Out
description: DENVER  Matt Harvey looked comfortable sitting near the top of the Mets dugout Sunday, wearing a sweatshirt, with sunglasses perched atop his hat, as he leaned over to get a closer look at Logan Verrett striking out Carlos Gonzalez swinging on a nasty slider.

title: Big Investors Are Finding Ripe Start-Up Targets in Europe
description: Klaus Hommels has invested in some of Europes most successful start-ups. That includes Spotify, the music-streaming service, and Klarna, a Swedish online payments company valued at more than $2 billion. He has also backed several American tech giants like Facebook and Airbnb, the vacation-rental site.

title: 9 Opposition Candidates Barred From Venezuelas December Ballot
description: SAN DIEGO, Venezuela  When he handily won a primary to run for the National Assembly, Enzo Scarano hoped to be part of a wave carrying the opposition to a legislative majority that would alter the political balance in Venezuela.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Aug. 24
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Europe Facing New Uncertainty in Terrorism Fight
description: PARIS  Two days after a young Moroccan man was thwarted from an apparent plan to cause carnage on a Paris-bound express train, European officials confronted the deepening quandary of what additional steps they could take in the face of such attacks on soft targets, short of paralyzing public spaces or even more intrusive surveillance.

title: Construction Chirpers
description: Dear Diary:

title: Guatemala President Balks at Calls for Resignation
description: MEXICO CITY  Guatemalas president, Otto Prez Molina, angrily rejected calls for his resignation on Sunday, denying any involvement in a far-reaching scheme to defraud the government of customs revenue in exchange for bribes.

title: Sillermans Failed Bid, Debts and Growing Losses Test SFX Investors Patience
description: Robert F. X. Sillerman didnt start the dance-music festival promoter SFX Entertainment out of a love for the music. Instead, he acted with cold logical reasoning backed by demographic marketing.

title: A Sprawl of Ghost Homes in Aging Tokyo Suburbs
description: YOKOSUKA, Japan  Ever since her elderly neighbor moved a decade ago, Yoriko Haneda has done what she can to keep the empty house she left behind from becoming an eyesore. Ms. Haneda regularly trims its shrubs and clips its narrow strip of grass, maintaining its perfect view of the sea.

title: Doudou Ndiaye Rose, 85, Senegalese Drummer and Human Treasure, Dies
description: Doudou Ndiaye Rose, a master drummer and bandleader from Senegal who became an emissary of his native cultures joyous and complex rhythms to the rest of the world, touring with percussion orchestras in Europe, Asia and the United States, died on Wednesday in Dakar, Senegal. He was 85.

title: Seeking Equality, Not Tips, Topless Marchers Draw a Crowd in Manhattan
description: It was not all that surprising that a march of a few dozen topless women (and fewer men) through Midtown Manhattan on a sunny Sunday afternoon would attract perhaps thousands of gawkers, bemused tourists, leering loafers, journalists and passers-by  every single one, it seemed, carrying a camera.

title: Rhode Island Church Taking Unusual Step to Illuminate Its Slavery Role
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  One of the darkest chapters of Rhode Island history involved the states pre-eminence in the slave trade, beginning in the 1700s. More than half of the slaving voyages from the United States left from ports in Providence, Newport and Bristol  so many, and so contrary to the popular image of slavery as primarily a scourge of the South, that Rhode Island has been called the Deep North.

title: Future Risks of an Iran Nuclear Deal
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama begins his three-week push to win approval of the Iran nuclear deal, he is confronting this political reality: His strongest argument in favor of passage has also become his greatest vulnerability.

title: Los Angeles, With New Star, Far Eclipses City F.C.
description: CARSON, Calif.  M.L.S. has long relied on former European club stars to promote its game. Two of them, Steven Gerrard and Frank Lampard, graced the cover of the program in Sundays game between the Los Angeles Galaxy and New York City F.C.

title: Rolling Stone Moves Beyond the Fray
description: Gus Wenner is 25, not much older than his father, Jann S. Wenner, was when he started Rolling Stone in 1967.

title: As Minimum Wages Rise, Restaurants Say No to Tips, Yes to Higher Prices
description: SEATTLE  Restaurant owners, customers and staff have long railed against the tyranny of tipping, but like a love affair gone bad, it has proved difficult to quit.

title: Debating Value of Pedestrian Plazas Beyond New York City
description: The open-air malls in Mayor Bill de Blasios New York may be filled with an unusual number of aggressive performers  heavily or barely costumed  but he is not the first mayor to wrestle with the consequences of turning streets into pedestrian spaces.

title: Data on Home Prices and the F.D.A.s Decision on a Cholesterol-Lowering Drug
description: Several important data points on the United States housing market will be released this week. On Tuesday, a Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller index is likely to show that home prices in 20 cities rose over the year ending in June. Demand for homes is building, pushing up prices. Also on Tuesday, a report from the Commerce Department will probably show that purchases of new homes increased in July after a surprise decrease in June. More good news is expected from the National Association of Realtors on Thursday as the group reports pending sales of existing homes for July. Sales were unexpectedly down in June, but may well have bounced back. Dionne Searcey

title: A Plunge in China Rattles Markets Across the Globe
description: Stocks around the world tumbled in volatile trading on Monday, leaving investors to wonder how much government officials can and will do to insulate the global economy from the turmoil.

title: Fear the Walking Dead Premiere Recap: The World Starts to Crumble
description: Season 1, Episode 1

title: In Baseball, the Times Are Changing
description: TRENTON  On the first day that minor league baseballs new rules to speed up the game went into full effect this season, a home-plate umpire ejected the manager of the Class AA Trenton Thunder for arguing.

title: Ryan Hunter-Reay Wins at Pocono
description: Before the Belgian Grand Prix in Spa-Francorchamps on Sunday, expectations of chaos were high because of a new rule designed to liven up the track action by giving full technical responsibility over clutch settings to the drivers at the start of the race, instead of having them take precise instructions from their team engineers over the radio. But the start went off practically without a hitch, and the explosive action came in the penultimate lap of the race, when the right rear tire of Sebastian Vettels Ferrari blew out while he was in third place. That handed Romain Grosjean and his Lotus team their first podium finish since the 2013 United States Grand Prix.

title: Masters of Sex Recap: With an Ape, the Show Jumps the Shark
description: Season 3, Episode 7, Monkey Business

title: Changing the Pace of a Leisurely Game
description: Minor league stadiums have become a laboratory to examine the effects that clocks have on the speed of play.

title: Letitia Jamess Ease in the Courtroom Informs Her Role as Public Advocate
description: Several months ago, Letitia James, the New York City public advocate, stepped into a dispute between the city and eight low-income tenants threatened with eviction. Her office tried to broach a resolution, but ultimately decided that an escalation of tactics was required: She sued the citys Department of Finance.

title: Forest Whitaker Will Make Broadway Debut
description: Forest Whitaker, the Academy Award winning film star, will make his Broadway debut next spring in a revival of Hughie, a short play by Eugene ONeill. Mr. Whitaker, who won an Oscar for playing Idi Amin in The Last King of Scotland, will play Erie Smith, a hustler who confides in a hotel night clerk. The play, set in Manhattan in 1928, was written in the 1940s but was not staged on Broadway until 1964, when Jason Robards played Erie Smith; a 1975 revival starred Ben Gazzara and a 1996 revival starred Al Pacino. This new revival will be directed by Michael Grandage, the former artistic director of the Donmar Warehouse in London, who won a 2010 Tony Award for his direction of Red. The Hughie revival will be produced by Darren Bagert along with the Michael Grandage Company and the Shubert Organization. The producers did not announce a date or theater for the opening, but said it would be next spring at a Shubert theater and would have a limited run.

title: Member of De Blasios Protective Detail Hit by Pellet or BB
description: A member of Mayor Bill de Blasios security detail received a minor injury on Sunday night when she was shot in the back by either a pellet or a BB gun, the police said. Two people were detained and were being questioned on Sunday night.

title: Intel to Invest Heavily in Software That Enhances Cloud-Computing Capabilities
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Intel, the worlds biggest maker of computer chips, has seen its future. There may not be room for some of Intels old friends in it.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | conception
description: conception  \kn-sep-shn\  noun

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 9 P.M. (Cinemax) MAPS TO THE STARS (2015) Havana Segrand (Julianne Moore, above), an actress on the verge of unraveling at any moment, has seen the apparition of her mother  a more famous actress, who died in a fire when she was young  and seeks therapy from a self-help guru (John Cusack). He happens to be the father of Benjie Weiss (Evan Bird), an obnoxious young star, and his older sister, Agatha (Mia Wasikowska), who was banished from the family after setting a fire that may have been intended to kill her brother, and which badly burned her. Eventually Agatha befriends a limo driver (Robert Pattinson) and turns an Internet acquaintanceship with Carrie Fisher into a job as Havanas personal assistant. Suavely directed by David Cronenberg from an elegantly waspish script by Bruce Wagner, it belongs to the venerable tradition of movieland self-loathing, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. It takes a perverse effort of will to love Maps to the Stars. Its a little too chilly, and in some places too easy. But you may find yourself drawn back to it, and retracing its route from the familiar to the uncanny, from entertainment to revulsion, from dream to nightmare.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 24, 2015
description: He seemed like he was ready to fight to the end, and so were we.

title: A Russian Soldier Story
description: After the Ukrainian revolution and Russias annexation of Crimea, Pavel Volkov wondered how young Russian Army conscripts felt about becoming part of the turmoil they  and the rest of the world  saw play out on television and in newspapers. Mr. Volkov traveled for eight months around military bases in Russia, taking photographs and asking questions. The resulting body of work is a portrait of Russian youth with mixed feelings.

title: Student Crossword | Biomes
description: Test your knowledge of biomes by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: The Case for Teaching Ignorance
description: IN the mid-1980s, a University of Arizona surgery professor, Marlys H. Witte, proposed teaching a class entitled Introduction to Medical and Other Ignorance. Her idea was not well received; at one foundation, an official told her he would rather resign than support a class on ignorance.

title: Ensuring Social Securitys Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Clashing Views on E-Cigarettes
description: A British government agency has issued a bullish assessment of the value of electronic cigarettes in helping people to quit smoking. It found that e-cigarettes can reduce the health risks of smoking by 95 percent because they deliver nicotine to satisfy an addiction, but far fewer harmful chemicals than regular cigarettes. It also found little evidence that large numbers of consumers who had never smoked were taking up e-cigarettes. That seemed to challenge the notion that e-cigarettes would be a gateway to more dangerous products.

title: Keep La Guardia Local
description: To the Editor:

title: Staying With Airbnb Hosts
description: To the Editor:

title: College Honors Programs in Various Forms
description: To the Editor:

title: The Workplace Culture That Flying Nannies Wont Fix
description: A PRIVATE equity firm announces it will pay for both your baby and a nanny to fly with you when you travel for business until the babys first birthday. IBM plans to ship home breast milk pumped on a work trip. Facebook and Apple will reimburse the costs for employees who want to freeze their eggs. It seems that businesses are falling over themselves these days to cater to women who want to be or are mothers.

title: An Opening for Diplomacy in Syria
description: The beheading by Islamic State militants of the Syrian archaeologist Khalid al-Asaad, who gave his life protecting some of Syrias greatest treasures, was a grisly reminder of how a conflict that has ripped Syria apart for over four years has been greatly complicated  and exploited  by the Islamic State and its savage doctrinal and territorial rampage.

title: A Moveable Glut
description: What caused Fridays stock plunge? What does it mean for the future? Nobody knows, and not much.

title: Let Sudans President Come to New York. Then Arrest Him.
description: THE fugitive president of Sudan, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, plans to attend a United Nations gathering later this month in New York City on the future of global development. To travel here, he needs a visa. His application for a visa gives President Obama an opportunity to take a landmark stance in the slow evolution of international efforts to prevent genocide.

title: Cuban Dissidents Buoyed in a New Era
description: Critics of President Obamas decision to normalize relations with Cuba have accused him of abandoning dissidents on the island, a marginalized group that had been at the heart of American policy toward Havana.

title: Human Rights Lawyer Prevented From Flying Out of Beijing
description: Read in Chinese |

title: How Has Your Family Helpedor HinderedYour Transition to a New School?
description: Over the next few weeks, schools, colleges and universities across the United States will be back in session, and in all of them, new students will be finding their way around.

title: There Is Something Eerie About a Person Who Doesnt Participate: Readers Debate Beyoncs Silence
description: Readers defend the singers choice to avoid much of the media, wonder whether her silence is beneficial to her brand and express disappointment that she has not taken a stand on certain social justice issues.

title: The Shock of Full Ankle Nudity
description: As perversions go, hows this? Socks in summer.

title: Speak, by Louisa Hall
description: A less artful title for Speak, Louisa Halls sidereal novel on artificial (and thus human) intelligence, might be What We Talk About When We Talk About Computers. This starfish of a book, five voices waving gracefully around a core of philosophical questions, wants to explore the nature of memory; the borders of personhood; how words can illumine and obscure and hoodwink and rescue.

title: Sects Death Ritual Clashes With Indian Law
description: PUNE, India  All week, people streamed in and out of the handsome bungalow where the Lodha family lives, eager to witness for themselves the amazing event that was occurring there.

title: The Incarnations, by Susan Barker
description: Traveling in China back in the early 1990s, I was waiting for my westbound train to take on water at a lonely halt in the Taklamakan Desert when a young Chinese woman tapped me on the shoulder, asked if I spoke English and, further, if I knew anything of Anthony Trollope. I was quite taken aback. Trollope here? A million miles from anywhere? I mumbled an incredulous, Yes, I know a bit  whereupon, in a brisk and businesslike manner, she declared that the train would remain at the oasis for the next, let me see, 27 minutes, and in that time would I kindly answer as many of her questions as possible about plot and character development in The Eustace Diamonds?

title: Inspector Critiques U.S. Spending in Afghanistan, to Dramatic Effect
description: WASHINGTON  When the Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction, an American government watchdog, requested information in June about health clinics in that country funded by the United States Agency for International Development, the aid agency handed over a database with the locations of more than 600 facilities.

title: American Barbecue in Paris
description: American food used to be a goofy novelty to the French, but now theyre tucking into ribs, pork belly and wings, with all the sides.

title: News Qs | Tragedy Averted on Paris-Bound Train
description: Note: Weve updated 6 Qs About the News for the new school year. Let us know what you think.

title: Science-Fiction Prize Is Awarded to Chinese Writer for First Time
description: Read in Chinese |

title: Gaza, Gulag on the Mediterranean
description: GAZA CITY  At this time last year, as the missiles and bombs rained down in Israels lopsided seven-week war against Gaza, I wrote about our struggle to survive during the holy month of Ramadan. This year, another Ramadan has passed, Eid al-Fitr is over and the reality on the ground has changed very little.

title: Should 'Birthright Citizenship' Be Abolished?
Air Travel News: Star Wars Planes Take Flight and More
description: Our Monday morning air travel news digest, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

description: Recent attention to long-term brain damage linked to multiple concussions among professional football players has prompted a much closer look at how children and adolescents who participate in sports can be protected from similar consequences.

description: Good morning on this sticky Monday.

description: Its pretty obvious that boa constrictors squeeze the life out of their prey.

title: Walter Munk, the Einstein of the Oceans
description: SAN DIEGO  In 1942, with World War II in full swing, a young military scientist learned of the Allies plans to invade northwestern Africa by sea to dislodge the nearby Axis forces.

title: Koreas Agree on Deal to Defuse Tensions
description: SEOUL, South Korea  In a deal to defuse tensions on the divided Korean Peninsula that were rapidly escalating toward armed conflict, South Korea agreed early on Tuesday to switch off its propaganda loudspeakers on the border, while North Korea agreed to stand down from its semi-war state, a high level of military alert.

title: Americans and Briton Receive Top French Honor for Stopping Train Gunman
description: PARIS  President Franois Hollande of France on Monday awarded the Legion of Honor, Frances highest award, to three Americans and a Briton for their role in stopping a gunman on a high-speed train traveling to Paris from Amsterdam on Friday.

title: Morning Agenda: Global Markets Continue to Plunge
description: GLOBAL MARKETS CONTINUE TO PLUNGE | Stocks continued last weeks slide, led by a rout in Asia, David Jolly and Neil Gough report in DealBook. Shanghais stock market closed down 8.5 percent, erasing its gains so far this year.

title: Today in Politics: A New Character Joins a Rapidly Expanding Storyline
description: Good Monday morning, as President Obamas vacation comes to an end and as Donald J. Trump continues to drive the discussion on the trail and on the Sunday talk shows. But, as the August lull winds down, another political intrigue, filled with whispers, speculation and a seemingly significant private meeting, deepens.

title: No, You Do Not Have to Drink 8 Glasses of Water a Day
description: If there is one health myth that will not die, it is this: You should drink eight glasses of water a day.

title: The Sidewalk Shed, a Ubiquitous New York Eyesore, Gets a Makeover
description: Zaha Hadid has designed some of the most remarkable buildings of this generation. Whether a striking factory for BMW, daring Olympic venues or museums in Rome, Glasgow and Cincinnati, the work of the Iraqi-born, London-based Ms. Hadid has brought her global renown and a Pritzker Prize, considered architectures Nobel Prize.

title: Train Heroes Honored in France
description: Three Americans and a Briton received the Legion of Honor for disarming an attacker aboard a high-speed train headed to France.

title: Rate Hike Fever
description: Larry Summers argues that a Fed rate hike would be a big mistake; I completely agree. Yet he also suggests that the Fed seems set to do this foolish thing. Why?

title: Lawyer for Huma Abedin, a Hillary Clinton Aide, Strikes Back at Accuser
description: A lawyer for Huma Abedin, a top adviser to Hillary Rodham Clinton, has accused Charles E. Grassley, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, of damaging Ms. Abedins reputation through unfounded allegations about her time at the State Department.

title: Black Markets in China Still Driving Worlds Tiniest Porpoise to Extinction
description: Heres a sobering update on efforts in Mexico, Hong Kong and mainland China to stave off the extinction of the vaquita, a critically endangered porpoise inhabiting Mexican waters at the north end of the Gulf of California that is the worlds smallest, and rarest, cetacean.

title: U.S. Marine Testifies in Killing of Transgender Woman in Philippines
description: MANILA  A United States Marine accused of killing a transgender woman in the Philippines acknowledged on Monday that he had choked her until she was no longer moving, but he stopped short of saying that he had killed her, according to the prosecutor assigned to the case.

title: If You Want to Be a Famous Fashion Designer, Here Are the Best Colleges
description: It had to happen sooner or later. Theres a ranking for everything these days, after all, and August is a pretty slow news month (At least in fashion terms, hence the desire to create interest with idle speculation such as the Is Phoebe Philo leaving Cline? rumors. O.M.G.! O.M.G.! The brand, not surprisingly, says no).

title: Israeli Villages Near Gaza Rebound Warily Year After the War
description: KIBBUTZ SUFA, Israel  Looking out across the perimeter fence of this small rural community in southern Israel, along the border with Gaza, Eyal Shalev, 23, sees a battlefield.

title: 1890: Cholera Epidemic Hits Spain
description: MADRID  Reports received to-day from the cholera-infected districts show a heavy increase of the epidemic in Toledo, where there are fifty-one new cases in the city and twenty-seven in the suburbs and in Valencia. In the other provinces the epidemic is stationary. The official record for the 22nd was seventy-one new cases and fifty-one deaths and for the 23rd it was 139 new cases and sixty-six deaths. The total figures for the whole of Spain since the commencement of the epidemic are: Number of cases 2,393, number of deaths 1,203. The fumigation to which travelers arriving at Seville are subjected is so severe that many have been made seriously ill.  The New York Herald, European Edition, August 25, 1890

title: Selfies in Voting Booths Raise Legal Questions on Speech and Secrecy
description: People post selfies with their strawberry daiquiris and their calico kittens, with strangers and friends, with and without clothes. So it was inevitable, perhaps, that some might take photographs inside the voting booth to show off their completed ballots.

description: Looking for something new to check out this week?
