description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea insisted on Monday that North Korea apologize for planting land mines. Otherwise, she vowed, anti-Pyongyang propaganda broadcasts will continue.

title: 36 Hours in Nashville: The Food Scene
description: 36 Hours, a television program inspired by The Timess 36 Hours column, airs Mondays at 8 p.m. Eastern on Travel Channel. The second episode, Rockin Nashville, dovetails with our column from last September.

title: Panda Cub Gets First Examination
description: Veterinarians on Sunday examined a cub born on Saturday to Mei Xiang, a giant panda at the Smithsonians National Zoo in Washington.

title: As Stock Market Plunges, Donald Trump Takes a Worldview
description: Plunging stocks have rattled investors on Monday, but Donald J. Trump sees them as one more reason he is needed in the Oval Office.

title: I Am Cait Episode 5 Recap: We v. Them
description: Season 1, Episode 5: Take Pride

title: Stephen Colbert Announces Guest Lineup for First Week of Late Show
description: In a sign of how its new hosts eclectic tastes are already having an effect at CBSs The Late Show, Stephen Colbert has unveiled the roster for his first weeks worth of guests and the list not only includes film, TV and music stars, but notable figures from the worlds of politics, business and literature.

title: College Football Preseason No. 1s Have Gone 10 Years Without a Title
description: Ohio State is the defending national college football champion. The Buckeyes return 15 starters and have such depth at quarterback that the player expected to lead the team last season has been converted to a receiver.

title: A Reluctant Teenager, a Barbershop Quartet and a Revelation
description: The memory is hazy, but I cant imagine that I went enthusiastically into a concert hall in Portland, Maine, on May 18, 1974. The groups on the bill were not the kind that most 19-year-olds were flocking to see. Yet my mind was blown just as thoroughly as if Id seen Kiss or Queen. It was blown by a barbershop quartet named the Gentlemens Agreement.

title: Obama Flies to the Nevada Desert to Promote Solar Energy
description: LAS VEGAS  President Obama flew west into the blistering sun of this desert oasis on Monday not so much to issue a dour warning about the dangers of climate change  moralizing does not become this freewheeling city  but to speak with great hope about solar and other renewable forms of energy.

title: Italian Neighbors Build a Social Network, First Online, Then Off
description: BOLOGNA, Italy  When Laurell Boyers, 34, and her husband, Federico Bastiani, 37, moved in together in Bologna in 2012, they did not know any of their neighbors. It was a lonely feeling.

title: Daily Report: Potential Unicorns, Meet a Rough Market
description: Stock markets around the world plunged last week, capped off on Friday when some benchmark indexes had their biggest losses in years, partly from turmoil in China. Tech stocks did not escape the fall, with some companies being hit particularly hard, including Netflix, which tumbled more than 16 percent over the course of the week. Twitter, which has been on a slide for a few weeks, ended the week below its I.P.O. price. The selloff in global markets continued on Monday.

title: Turkey Announces Anti-ISIS Operation
description: Turkeys foreign minister, Mevlut Cavusoglu, speaks on a new agreement with the United States to flush Islamic State fighters out of northern Syria.

title: Shelf, iPad, Bed Table: An End-of-Summer Reading List
description: August was (and is) a great month for books.

title: Jordy Nelson Injury May Not Ruin Packers Season
description: When N.F.L. fans watch their favorite team play its exhibition games, they seldom care too much about winning and losing. Instead, they hope to see veterans look sharp and rookies look promising. But most of all, they hope the key players come out unscathed.

title: Huma Abedin's Lawyer Responds to Suggestions of Conflict
description: The lawyer for Huma Abedin, a longtime confidante of Hillary Rodham Clinton, wrote a letter to the State Department disputing concerns that Senator Charles E. Grassley raised about a possible conflict of interest involving her.

title: The Inexorable Forces of Nail Growth
description: Q. What is the mechanism that moves growing nails forward?

title: At WWEs SummerSlam, Jon Stewarts Chair-Throwing Incites Fans
description: Hard on the heels of his retirement from The Daily Show, Jon Stewart hosted World Wrestling Entertainments 28th annual SummerSlam on Sunday, and divided wrestling fans by influencing the outcome of a key match.

title: NASAs Cassini Takes a Last Look at Saturns Moon Dione
description: The spacecraft, in orbit around Saturn since 2004, has two more years of work before it runs out of fuel. Last week it made its final flyby of Dione.

title: Why the Stock Market Is So Turbulent
description: Last week, global financial markets were churning, but it really only mattered if you were an oil trader, a Chinese bureaucrat or a hedge fund manager.

title: No Comment Necessary: Donald Trump on Black Lives Matter
description: Asked about the Black Lives Matter movement during a Fox News appearance, Donald Trump responded, I know nothing about it. However, he did have some thoughts about Martin OMalleys apologyfor his response to Black Lives Matter demonstrators. He apologized, Mr. Trump said, like a little baby, like a disgusting little weak pathetic baby, and thats the problem with our country.

title: Apple Stock Reacts After Tim Cook Email Praises China Sales
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Last week, Jim Cramer, the boisterous host of CNBCs Mad Money, had a company called Skyworks Solutions on his show. The company, a chip supplier for Apple, said its sales were strong in China, but its stock plummeted afterward anyway, following the global markets into the red.

title: Ellie Baker and the Seamstresss Conundrum
description: This weeks puzzle was suggested by Ellie Baker, a freelance computer scientist and artist who beautifully combines the disciplines of sculpture and mathematics to bring us a counter-intuitive 3D challenge. Lets try our hands at

title: 1915: Britain Shells Belgian Coast
description: ROTTERDAM  This morning a British squadron of considerable strength carried out a great bombardment of the German positions on the Belgian coast. The attack was the most important in the number of ships engaged and the fierceness of the fire since the enemys occupation of the littoral. It is reported that great damage was done, principally to the military works at Zeebrugge. The thunder of the fleets guns was heard all over Zeeland, where the windows of houses at places miles inland rattled. The sound carried distinctly to Flushing.  The New York Herald, European Edition, August 25, 1915

title: Hot Tech Start-Ups May Face a Long and Bumpy Fall
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As stock markets have tumbled, public company shareholders were not the only ones wondering what would become of their portfolios. Venture capitalists also began fretting about whether the plunge  which resulted last week in the worst week for American stocks since 2011 and a renewed sell-off on Monday  would cool the heady market for shares of private companies, especially in Silicon Valley.

title: Divorcing a Narcissist
description: Is there a narcissist in your life?

title: Travel Diary: Tokyo
description: Richard Christiansen and Vanessa Holdens travels in Tokyo.

title: How Do You Talk to a 3-Year-Old About a Divorce You Dont Want?
description: In our occasional parenting Quandaries, we pull from the comments, the weekly open thread or email a question that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You  the readers  provide the advice. Todays question comes from a commenter many will recognize as a long-time member of the communityRamona, from Toronto. If you have advice, and particularly if youve been where she is and come through it, please help.

title: Two Panda Cubs at the National Zoo Present Special Problems
description: Two tiny giant panda cubs, each weighing about as much as a stick of butter, are the focus at the National Zoo in Washington of an intense, round-the-clock effort to keep them alive, but the odds are against them.

title: Small Food Brands, Big Successes
description: Everyone knows someone who has dreamed of starting a food business. That next-door neighbor who thinks his chocolate chip cookies are better than Tates Bake Shops. The niece whose friends beg for her homemade hot sauce and who wonders how it would stack up against Trappeys or Texas Pete.

title: Inside the Maple Syrup Beat: Reporters Notebook
description: While reporting from the Tour de France in July, I encountered a rare reminder of Canada one morning. In the hotels breakfast room there was a bottle of Maple Joe Absolutely Pure Maple Syrup. Just as prominent on the label was the English phrase Produce of Canada and, presumably to drive home that point, a drawing of broad-shouldered Joe, who has an improbable beard and wears a plaid shirt and red hunters cap. It was a vivid reminder of the article I wrote about Quebec maple syrup, a barrel of which is worth more today than a barrel of crude oil.

title: Videos: How ISIS Recruits Around the World
description: In this series of videos, The New York Times reports on young people in the Middle East, Europe and the United States who have been lured by the group, also known as ISIS or ISIL.

title: Racially Disparate Views of New Orleanss Recovery After Hurricane Katrina
description: NEW ORLEANS  As the 10th anniversary approaches of Hurricane Katrina and the catastrophic levee breaches in New Orleans, a new survey finds a stark racial divide in how residents here view the recovery.

title: As Turkey Targets Militants, War Grips Kurdish Lands Once Again
description: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey  Across the Kurdish lands of southeast Turkey, a bitter war that had long been stilled by a truce has suddenly come roaring back, threatening to undo a hard-won economic turnaround here and adding a new battlefield to a region already consumed by chaos.

title: Avoid Worrying About a Future That May Never Happen
description: I love spending time in the mountains. So a few weeks ago, I jumped at the opportunity to join a friend, my son and seven of his friends on a trip into the Uinta Mountains. This range sits about an hour east of our home in Park City, Utah.

title: Palestinian Authority Is Ordered to Post $10 Million Bond in Terror Case
description: In a widely watched terrorism lawsuit that drew the attention of the Obama administration, a federal judge in Manhattan ruled on Monday that the Palestinian Authority would have to post $10 million and an additional $1 million monthly to appeal a huge damages award for its role in six terrorist attacks in Israel that had killed and injured Americans.

title: Luke Bryan Stays at No. 1, and N.W.A. Enters Top 5
description: The country singer Luke Bryans grown-up new album, Kill the Lights, notched a second straight week at No. 1  the first country album to do so in two years, according to Billboard. But whats happening lower on the chart may be more notable.

title: Video Shows Palmyras Ruins Before ISIS
description: The ruins of the ancient Syrian city of Palmyra are shown in a video from March 2014, before the Islamic State took control.

title: A New Way to Charge Insider Trading
description: An acquittal in an insider trading case is no longer much of a man bites dog story, even when the United States attorney hailed the indictment, proclaiming that sooner or later, you will be brought to justice. But the jury verdict last week in Atlanta in favor Steven E. Slawson, co-founder of the hedge fund Titan Capital Management, may be much more important for signaling a new way of charging those who receive tips that may avoid requirements thought necessary to prove insider trading.

title: New Orleans Residents Opinions of Recovery
description: Ten years after Hurricane Katrina, a survey by Louisiana State University found a stark divide among black and white residents over various issues.

title: Duke Kahanamoku, Legendary Surfer and Swimmer, Gets Google Tribute
description: If youre one of the billion or so people who use Google.com, you no doubt spotted the tribute to Duke Kahanamoku on what would have been his 125th birthday.

title: Square Root of Kids Math Anxiety: Their Parents Help
description: A common impairment with lifelong consequences turns out to be highly contagious between parent and child, a new study shows.

title: Inside Andrew Paulson and Sean Dougalls Watts, Los Angeles Home and Studio
description: The furniture designers and artists live and work in a former light bulb factory.

title: Review: Purity, Jonathan Franzens Most Intimate Novel Yet
description: In a very funny passage in his dynamic new novel, Jonathan Franzen draws a very funny portrait of a writer struggling to write a novel that would secure him his place in the modern American canon. Once upon a time, this writer named Charles thinks, it had sufficed to write The Sound and the Fury or The Sun Also Rises. But now bigness was essential. Thickness, length.

title: Do You Have Math Anxiety?
description: You may not like taking a quiz to measure your math anxiety. But dont worry. There are no right answers, and you dont have to show your work.

title: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
description: Yes, the summers almost over. The upside? Nearly all of the worlds top soccer leagues are now up and running. The downside? Theres an unwatchable number of hours of soccer to watch every week. This weeks highlights:

title: Man Charged in Pellet Shooting of Officer Outside Gracie Mansion
description: The pop of an air gun came from above as two members of Mayor Bill de Blasios security detail stepped from an unmarked Ford Interceptor sedan outside Gracie Mansion at about 7:15 on Sunday evening. A pellet struck one in the back, causing a minor injury.

title: A Childhood Obsession Leads to a Cereal Bar at Kith
description: New York has its first dedicated cereal bar. A small white-tiled alcove just inside the renovated Kith clothing and sneaker store in Brooklyn has 24 brand-name cold cereal varieties, with toppings. The cereals come packaged in single-serving Mylar bags that fit into small shoe boxes, from which the cereal can be eaten. The boxes are designed by sports figures  Andre Agassi has done the first one. There is no salad-bar-style display because the owner Ronnie Fieg does not like food out in the open. Milk, coffee and cereal-flavored soft-serve are also sold. Mr. Fieg says he has been obsessed with cereals since he was a teenager, mainly because he was not allowed to have sweet ones. Before the store opens, there is an express window to the street for cereal: Cereals from $6 with milk, ice cream from $5.50, Kith Treats, 233 Flatbush Avenue (Bergen Street), Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, 347-889-6114, kithnyc.com.

title: My Generation Will Never See One Dollar From Social Security
description: The sense of doom expressed in one younger readers comment about the Social Security system opened an intergenerational conversation about the programs actuarial predicament.

title: Migrants Race North as Hungary Builds a Border Fence
description: TISZASZIGET, Hungary  Roiling everything in its path, a wave of tens of thousands of migrants and refugees  many fleeing wars in Iraq, Syria and Afghanistan  has worked its way up the length of the Balkans in recent days.

title: In Watts, Turning an Old Light Bulb Factory Into a Home
description: Were making the sprawl work to our favor, says Andrew Paulson, a self-taught weaver and one half of the Los Angeles-based design duo Dougall Paulson. Paulson and his partner in life and work, the ceramist Sean Dougall, live in Watts, a neighborhood thats recently begun to show signs of a renaissance 50 years after the 1965 riots, thanks to chefs like Roy Choi and Daniel Patterson, who are opening a new restaurant there later this year, and Frank Gehry, who is set to collaborate on a local community center for the Childrens Institute Inc. People ask us, Is that the new neighborhood? says Dougall, noting the 75 blocks that separate Watts from downtowns flourishing arts district. Were not feeding off of an existing art scene. Were trying to build our own visual language, on an island.

title: Water Parks Add High-Tech Thrills
description: Water parks are getting a technological upgrade. Great Wolf Lodge in the Poconos and the Wet n Wild park in Las Vegas have both introduced a ride called Slideboarding, which its inventors describe as Guitar Hero inside a water slide.

title: New Cinema Planned for Lower East Side
description: A new two-screen arthouse cinema, capable of playing 35 millimeter and digital films, is set to open on the Lower East Side of Manhattan early next year, flying in the face of doomsday reports that independent theaters are in steep decline.

title: How Emotion Hurts Stock Returns
description: As investors watched global stock markets tumble, the behavioral economist Richard Thaler, who is also an occasional contributor to The New York Times, offered the following advice: Inhale, exhale. Repeat. Then watch ESPN.

title: Details Released in Ashley Madison Hack
description: A spokesman for the Toronto Police Service said that the company behind the website Ashley Madison was offering a reward for information leading to the arrest of the sites hackers.

title: Mutation Reduces Pregnancy Complications for Africas Khoe-San People
description: The Khoe-San people of southern Africa carry a genetic mutation that reduces pregnancy complications, according to a study in the journal PLOS Genetics. The gene variant can alter the formation of the placenta during the early stages of pregnancy, resulting in larger, healthier babies and reducing the likelihood of pre-eclampsia, a disorder that can be fatal. The click-speaking Khoe-San are thought to have broken off from other African groups 100,000 years ago and, like other sub-Saharan populations, have high genetic diversity.

title: Jet Lag Cures Aplenty, but None That Work for All
description: Rita Gunther McGrath, a Columbia Business School professor, is one of those business travelers who do not care about delays, cancellations or navigating a new location. What does concern her is the seeming inability to conquer jet lag, and the accompanying symptoms that leave her groggy, unfocused and feeling, she says, like a dishrag.

title: A Stock Slide That Started in Asia
description: Mondays wild ride in the markets began in Asia, where indexes opened lower and continued slipping through the day. Shanghais composite index closed 8.5 percent lower, erasing all of the gains it had made this year.

title: Louisiana State Trooper Is Killed in Shooting at a Traffic Stop
description: A Louisiana state trooper died on Monday after being shot in the head a day earlier during a traffic stop, and the authorities said the man charged in the shooting was being investigated in connection with another fatality.

title: Bigger Hospital Rooms for Bigger Patients
description: When the revamped Parkland Hospital in Dallas opened recently, each of the 862 single-patient rooms in the sprawling new 17-story tower was ready to accommodate the growing number of obese patients that hospitals across the country increasingly care for.

title: Plan for New Nepal Districts Draws Deadly Protests and Attacks on Police
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  An angry protest against a draft constitution in Nepal turned deadly on Monday when demonstrators broke a curfew and attacked police officers with knives, spears and sickles.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: After Ashley Madison Hack, Police in Toronto Detail a Global Fallout
description: Canadian officials are bracing for long-term fallout from the unauthorized release of user data from the adultery website Ashley Madison, they said at a news conference on Monday.

title: New Luxury Cruise Through France
A Piece of the Earliest Baboon Ever Found
description: A two-million-year-old skull fragment comes from the earliest baboon ever found, a new study reports. The fossil was found in Malapa, a cave in South Africa and a Unesco World Heritage site where specimens of Australopithecus sediba, an early ancestor of modern humans, were discovered in 2010.

title: U.S. Army Reopens Criminal Inquiry Into Afghan Civilians Deaths
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The United States military has reopened a criminal investigation into a series of at least 17 murders of civilians in 2012 and 2013 for which Afghan officials blamed an Army Special Forces team, a senior Western official here said on Monday.

title: John Kasich Balances His Blue-Collar Roots and Ties to Wall Street
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  As the people of Ohio already know  and Republican voters elsewhere are just beginning to find out  Gov. John R. Kasich grew up in working-class McKees Rocks, Pa., the son of a postal worker and the grandson of a coal miner. His grandfather was so poor, Mr. Kasich recently told voters in New Hampshire, that he would bring home scraps of his lunch to share with his children.

title: Heroes Thwart a Train Attack, Yet Europe Remains Vulnerable
description: The four men  three American and one British  who received Frances highest honor, the Legion of Honor, on Monday from President Franois Hollande richly deserved it. Their courage in tackling an attacker wielding an AK-47 and other weaponry inside a packed high-speed train traveling from Brussels to Paris last Friday prevented a possible blood bath.

title: Asia Society Names New Museum Director
description: The Asia Society has appointed a new director of its museum to replace Melissa Chiu, who left last year to become director of the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington.

title: Richard Christiansen and Vanessa Holdens Travels in Tokyo
description: Richard Christiansen, the founder of Chandelier Creative and Vanessa Holden, former senior vice president of West Elm, document their three-week trip around the world searching for creative inspiration exclusively for T.

title: A Way to Make Depth-Sensing Cameras Better
description: Depth-sensing cameras can detect how far away a person or object is. Though these cameras have broad applications  in self-driving cars and navigation tools for the blind, for instance  they do not work well in bright sunlight.

title: White House on Bidens Potential Run
description: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, sidestepped questions on Monday about whether President Obama wants Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to enter the 2016 presidential race.

title: European Leaders React to Chinas Slump
description: Government leaders and representatives from Europe expressed optimism about the state of Chinas economic health as the countrys stock market plunged on Monday.

title: From Governor Cuomo: Build a New Rail Tunnel
description: To the Editor:

title: The Widening World of Hand-Picked Truths
description: Nearly half a century ago, in what passed as outrage in pre-Internet times, people across the country became incensed by the latest edition of Time magazine. In place of the familiar portrait of a world leader  Indira Gandhi, Lyndon B. Johnson, Ho Chi Minh  the cover of the April 8, 1966, issue was emblazoned with three red words against a stark black background: Is God Dead?

title: Southern Company to Pay $12 Billion for AGL Resources
description: Southern Companys acquisition of AGL Resources could yet find its true north. The power producer is buying its crosstown Atlanta rival for $12 billion, including $4 billion of debt. Although the premium looks rich for the utility sector, there is at least a chance that the price can be justified.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Syria and More  Pictures of the Day

title: August 24, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photographs from Syria, Serbia, Malaysia and Britain.

title: Rich in History, Metropolitan Open Will Celebrate a Milestone at Winged Foot
description: The course where the first Metropolitan Open was held in 1905, Fox Hills Golf Club on Staten Island, is long gone. It has been 75 years since the tournament  won by nine players who were eventually inducted into the World Golf Hall of Fame  regularly attracted the sports best.

title: Review: Dancing Through the Bronx Allows Local Artists a Moment in the Sun
description: Owen F. Dolen Park in the Bronx is not the sort of public green that would normally warrant a visit by anyone outside the neighborhood. Despite a $5 million renovation in 2013, its still just a few plots of grass and trees amid busy streets in the shadow of the elevated No. 6 train. On Friday evening, though, some dancers attempted to spruce up the place a bit.

title: Scott Walker Joins Growing Chorus in Attacking China
description: With Chinas currency devaluation and stock market downturn rattling American markets, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin on Monday called on President Obama to cancel the visit of Chinas leader, President Xi Jinping, to Washington next month.

title: Steroid Shots No Better for Back Pain Than Placebo
description: Steroid shots are commonly used for back pain, but evidence that they work no better than placebos is mounting.

title: Womens Project Will Present 2015-16 Season in a New Home
description: The Womens Project Theater will begin its coming season in a new home, at the McGinn/Cazale Theater on Broadway, at 76th Street. This Off Broadway company dedicated to promoting female artists announced its three-year residency at the theater along with its 2015-16 season, which includes two New York premieres.

title: Can Data Capture the True Health of the Creative Economy?
description: On Friday, the Future of Music Coalition, a musicians advocacy group, published a blog post taking issue with some of the arguments and data from my Aug. 23 cover story in the magazine, The Creative Apocalypse That Wasnt. I take their comments very seriously for several reasons: First, their concerns  that musicians be appropriately compensated in this digital age  are my concerns. Second, they have assembled some important studies of the new economics emerging in the music business, many of which I drew upon in writing the article. And finally, theyre a terrific organization doing important work.

title: Potential Joe Biden Run Puts White House in a Bind
description: How awkward would it be for President Obama and the White House if Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. challenged Hillary Rodham Clinton for the Democratic nomination?

title: Book Review: The Butterflies of North America; Titian Peales Lost Manuscript
description: To most of us, butterflies are charming ephemera that flutter in and out of our lives. But for a certain species of 19th-century gentleman, the stalking and archiving of butterflies was the very height of outdoors adventure.

title: Ts Five to Follow: Monday, Aug. 24
description: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

title: Joylynn Holder of Brooklyn Forest and Her Steadfast Batter Bowl
description: Joylynn Holder is wandering in the wilderness, or as much wilderness as New York City parks allow. As a founder of Brooklyn Forest, she runs classes for parents and children in the glades of Central and Prospect Parks, going outdoors whatever the weather, with exceptions made for thunder, hurricanes, snowstorms and February.

title: Rick Perrys Campaign Takes a Hit With Departure of Iowa Chairman, Sam Clovis
description: Rick Perrys scuffling presidential bid has suffered another blow.

title: Atop Medal Table at Worlds, Kenya Is Also Under a Cloud
description: BEIJING  It appeared to be business as usual for Kenya at the world track and field championships Monday night.

title: Victims Family Testifies in Holmes Case
description: Rena Medek, whose daughter Micayla was killed by James E. Holmes at a Colorado movie theater in 2012, described in the sentencing phase for Mr. Holmes how the shooting changed her life.

title: Fear the Walking Dead Premiere Draws Record Viewers
description: AMCs new spinoff series, Fear the Walking Dead, drew 10.1 million viewers on Sunday night, making it the most viewed series premiere in cable TV history. The show also drew 6.3 million viewers in the 18- to-49-year-old demographic, another record.

title: Review: Drop Dead Perfect, Winking Melodrama, Returns to St. Clements
description: Drop Dead Perfect, which opened at the Theater at St. Clements last year, reopened there on Sunday night. Following is Anita Gatess review, which appeared in The New York Times on July 23, 2014.

title: A Volcanic Eruption That Reverberates 200 Years Later
description: In April 1815, the most powerful volcanic blast in recorded history shook the planet in a catastrophe so vast that 200 years later, investigators are still struggling to grasp its repercussions. It played a role, they now understand, in icy weather, agricultural collapse and global pandemics  and even gave rise to celebrated monsters.

title: Style at the Afropunk Festivals Fancy Ball
description: Revelers turned out for the kick-off night of the 11th annual music festival, featuring a performance by Grace Jones.

title: Euro Leaders Back Cease-Fire in Ukraine
description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Franois Hollande of France stood alongside President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine to call for greater security on the Ukraine-Russia border.

title: Scenes From the Afropunk Festivals Fancy Ball
description: Rules rarely spark a good time. Yet upon entering Commodore Barry Park for the Afropunk Festivals inaugural Fancy Ball on Friday night  a fundraiser which opened the 11th annual music spectacle in Fort Greene, Brooklyn  attendees were greeted by eight commandments: no sexism, no racism, no ableism, no ageism, no homophobia, no fatphobia, no transphobia, no hatefulness. Its like the most polite people Ive ever met, said Manzell Glover, a male bartender in a sleeveless vintage dress who identified as a QPOC (Queer Person of Color). There was a crowd, but when people have their tapestries down or their blankets down, nobody stepped on anyones anything. Ive never heard excuse me so many times, he said. A retail fashion stylist seated on one of those blankets, Ramie Mitchell, said, It feels like a no-judgment zone. Amy Van Doran, a professional matchmaker in a Tang-colored wig, was more blunt in her assessment: Everyone here is super kind because there is less white privilege, she said. Headliner Grace Jones took the stage a very civilized 10 minutes early, though she did tell the crowd, drolly and with an expletive appended, Put down your phones and clap your hands. Put it between your legs if you have to.

title: European Leaders Make a Show of Support for Ukraine on Its National Day
description: BERLIN  Clinging to a deal on Ukraine that has never been fully enacted, the leaders of Germany, France and Ukraine called on Monday  the 24th anniversary of Ukraines independence  for the bloodshed to end.

title: Louisiana State Police Discuss Shooting
description: The state police said Monday that a Louisiana trooper, Steven J. Vincent, had died after being shot in the head Sunday night during a traffic stop.

title: Elisabeth Moss on Her Emmy Nomination and How to Follow Success of Peggy Olson
description: Over seven seasons, the character Peggy Olson on Mad Men grew from mousy secretary to advertising dynamo. While that AMC show may have started out focusing on the man in the corner office, in the end it was Peggys journey that captivated and compelled many viewers. While Don Draper battled inner demons, Peggy battled society, pushing the boundaries of what women could achieve in the work force of the 1960s.

title: Scene City: A 24-Hour Party at the Guggenheim
description: Downtown artists including Agathe Snow, Dan Colen and Nate Lowman relive a fabled party from 10 years ago.

title: China, Japan and Europe Are Flashing Economic Warning Signs
description: Even before the recent plunge in commodity and stock markets, the world economy was weak. But recent data from China, Europe, Japan and other countries suggest that growth is slowing more sharply than many analysts had anticipated. That puts the burden on policy makers in these countries to come up with more credible ways to bolster their economies.

title: Scene City: A 24-hour Party at the Guggenheim
description: Last Thursday, the artist Agathe Snow hosted a 24-hour dance party at the Guggenheim Museum that commemorated an epic party that took place 10 years ago. An electric crowd of artists, fashion insiders, downtown scenesters and teenagers participated.

title: In Fight for a Stretch of the Rockaways, Surfers and New Residents Collide
description: The growing popularity of surfing in the Rockaways has created a resurgence, attracting large beach crowds, fueling new businesses and generating other economic boosts.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Taking Another Look at the Reconstruction Era
description: BEAUFORT, S.C.  Growing up in Kingstree, S.C., in the 1960s, Michael Allen never knew the town had elected a black mayor in the years after the Civil War. There was no monument dedicated to the mans memory. He was never mentioned in school.

title: Review: Edward Burnss Public Morals on TNT
description: Edward Burnss new series, Public Morals, is set in Hells Kitchen in the 1960s and filmed in New York, at Silvercup Studios and at locations like the Russian Tea Room, the Park Lane Hotel and Barrows Pub in Greenwich Village. It doesnt seem to take place anywhere in the real world, though. Its in an imaginary American neighborhood  around the corner from Runyon, down the block from Scorsese, within sight of Mamet  where characters are nicknamed Beantown and Specs and say things like, I get a one-way ticket to Palookaville.

title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Viewing Copenhagen Bridges Construction
description: Time-lapse footage showing construction of the Cirkelbroen (Circle Bridge), which was designed by Olafur Eliasson and opened Monday.

title: Review: Charlie Parker Jazz Festival Subtly Recalls Its Inspiration
description: The Charlie Parker Jazz Festival comes by its name with a blissfully casual reverence. The festival, whose 22nd edition ran over the weekend, involves free outdoor concerts in Harlem and the East Village, neighborhoods where Parker, the pioneering alto saxophonist and bebop lodestar, once lived. It always falls near his birthday. (Born on Aug. 29, he would have turned 95 this year. He died at 34.)

title: Son House Inspires a Rochester Blues Festival
description: ROCHESTER  A sign about eight miles east of this citys storied Corn Hill neighborhood points out a historical landmark, the rail yard where the blues musician Son House worked as a porter in the 1940s. The vowel in Houses nickname (he was born Eddie) is an odd size, rising about a half inch above the letters on either side. An explanation of sorts can be seen in the abrupt curvature at the top of the first O: The original sign misspelled his name as SUN, and the U was rounded off after the fact.

title: New Report of ISIS Using Poison Gas in Syria
description: ISTANBUL  The Islamic State may have used chemical agents in an attack against civilians and rival insurgents in northern Syria late last week, according to local rebels and an international aid group.

title: Punchless Yanks Squeak By on a Sacrifice Fly
description: The Yankees had gone eight fruitless innings without scoring a run, their swooning offense looking mostly lifeless and unimposing. Then, in the ninth, the Houston Astros called on a familiar face: Oliver Perez.

title: Wild Cards Remain as Democrats Add Supporters on Iran Deal
description: WASHINGTON  With Senator Harry Reids undiluted endorsement Sunday of the Iran nuclear accord, followed by Senator Debbie Stabenow of Michigan on Monday, supporters of the deal are closing in on the number they need to ensure it goes into force.

title: Puppies Unrewarded at Sci-Fi Book Awards
description: This years Hugo Awards, given to the best in science fiction, turned into a referendum on the genres politics. Two blocks of conservative authors and fans, calling themselves the Sad Puppies and the Rabid Puppies, have argued that the Hugos have become a litmus test of political correctness, valuing the racial and sexual identities of authors over their storytelling skills. This year, the groups used their leverage to fill categories with their own preferred nominees.

title: The 60s: In and Out of the Limelight
description: David Hurns celebrity photos helped shape popular memories of the 1960s. But he was more drawn to the stuff of daily life.

title: The Stock Market Loses 5 Percent In a Week: What Happens Next
description: A look at the last five times the stock market lost 5 percent in a week.

title: Uncertainty in the Market May Imperil Deal-Making
description: Even as stock markets again tumbled across the world, deal makers  among the most optimistic lot on Wall Street  arent ready yet to call an end to one of the biggest waves of mergers and initial public offerings in recent memory.

title: Stupid China Stories
description: So a stock crash in China triggered a big decline around the world, while I was trying to have a personal life (and succeeding, actually). Leaving aside whether this really made sense, why should events in China matter for the rest of us?

title: Netflix to Add Films and TV Series for Teenagers
description: Netflix is entering the awkward teenage years, at least with its latest programming push.

title: Reform Chief Questions United States Involvement in FIFA, Defends Sepp Blatter
description: Somebody needs to tell Franois Carrard, the Swiss lawyer recently named to lead  FIFAs reform committee, that he should really stop being so annoyingly impartial and tell the public how he really feels.

title: Analysis Finds Higher Expulsion Rates for Black Students
description: With the Obama administration focused on reducing the number of suspensions, expulsions and arrests in public schools, a new analysis of federal data identifies districts in 13 Southern states where black students are suspended or expelled at rates overwhelmingly higher than white children.

title: Lebanese Activists Mock Beirut Wall Meant to Block Protest
description: Supporters of Lebanons You Stink protest movement  who were confronted with water cannon and tear gas over the weekend when they took to the streets to demand a solution to the trash crisis in Beirut  ridiculed the authorities online Monday for trying to stifle dissent by erecting a concrete blast wall around the seat of government.

title: Jeb Bush Talks About Immigration
description: The Republican presidential candidate responded to Donald J. Trumps immigration proposals, as well as his own use of the term anchor baby.

title: From Venezuela to Iraq to Russia, Oil Price Drops Raise Fears of Unrest
description: Oil, the lifeblood of many countries that produce and sell it, appears to be rapidly turning into an ever-cheaper economic curse.

title: One Direction Says It Is Taking a Break, but Not Splitting Up
description: After more than 24 hours of fan panic, members of the British boy band One Direction have addressed tabloid chatter that said the group would go on an indefinite hiatus  or worse, break up  next year.

title: Jeb Bush Takes a Cue From Donald Trumps Playbook: Punch Back
description: The schoolyard taunts from Donald J. Trump arrive on a daily basis, raining down on Jeb Bushs sober, careful and policy-minded campaign with growing acerbity.

title: ISIS Speeds Up Destruction of Antiquities in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Islamic State militants have razed a fifth-century Roman Catholic monastery and blown up one of the best-preserved first-century temples in Palmyra, the ancient Syrian city that is one of the worlds most important archaeological sites, according to government officials and local activists.

title: Merl Reagle, Whose Crossword Puzzles Delighted Clued-In Solvers, Dies at 65
description: Merl Reagle, a playfully irreverent crossword puzzle constructor whose clues set off spirited cerebrations from his fans rather than frustrated surrenders to dictionary arcana, died on Saturday in Tampa, Fla. He was 65.

title: G.O.P. Candidates Take Aim at China as U.S. Markets Tumble
description: Republican presidential candidates began shifting their focus on Monday from the dangers posed by illegal immigrants to a new target: China, whose currency devaluations and stock market plunges are starting to hurt the savings of American investors.

title: Cynthia Macdonald, Poet Known for Humor and Ability to Shock, Dies at 87
description: Cynthia Macdonald, whose idiosyncratic blend of humor and the grotesque made her a distinctive voice on the American poetry scene, died on Aug. 3 in a nursing home in Logan, Utah. She was 87.

title: Jordan Spieth Reassesses a Career Path From the Top, Where Time Is Short
description: JERSEY CITY  Four rows of young golfers, all active in local chapters of the First Tee, a youth development group, fidgeted in their seats in the midday sun. Filling out the rows behind them were grown-ups wearing belts and shirts bearing the names of some of the countrys most prestigious courses. On the dais, Paul Fireman  a founder, with his son, Dan, of one such place, Liberty National  was answering a question about personal legacies.

title: A Warning on China Seems Prescient
description: Kenneth Rogoff has long warned of a potential financial crisis in China.

title: Ferguson Announces an Amnesty on Warrants
description: The City of Ferguson, Mo., announced Monday that it was withdrawing thousands of arrest warrants for municipal violations and taking steps to prevent the incarceration of people who cannot pay fines and fees, a response to the sharp criticism of its court system that emerged after the killing of Michael Brown last year.

title: Advisers Work to Calm Fearful Investors
description: Even a pep talk from the chief executive of Apple, the single biggest American company by market value, did little to soothe investors on Monday.

title: Loved Ones Recount Their Pain at Hearing for Aurora Gunman
description: CENTENNIAL, Colo.  The family members of the people killed and injured by a gunman in an Aurora, Colo., movie theater in 2012 took the stand on Monday to give some of their most emotional testimony yet, approaching a lectern in a courtroom here and delivering searing accounts of the depression and loss they felt after the massacre.

title: Puerto Ricans Seeking New Lives Put Stamp on Central Florida
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  When Manuel Hernandez, a teacher in Puerto Rico, looked at the reasons to stay home or to take a chance on joining the ever-growing Puerto Rican diaspora in Central Florida, it was not a hard call.

title: Government and Protesters in Lebanon Weigh Next Move in Trash Dispute
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Demonstrators regrouped and the government tried to get a handle on events on Monday in Beirut, where weekend protests over uncollected garbage boiled over into violence that left scores of demonstrators and police officers injured.

title: A Stock Market Rout in a Month That Hedge Funds Would Sooner Forget
description: From his getaway cabin deep in the woods, an experienced adviser to wealthy hedge fund investors was hopping from one conference call to another to manage clients mounting anxiety.

title: David Wright Quickly Sets Tone in Return to Mets
description: PHILADELPHIA  Imagine if David Wrights leadership powers worked this way all the time. With his first swing Monday after coming off the disabled list, Wright launched a home run into the second deck of Citizens Bank Park. His teammates followed his example to absurd lengths: They set single-game Mets records for homers and extra-base hits in a 16-7 thrashing of the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Bus Slams Into House in Queens, Injuring Six
description: A bus shuttling people from the Resorts World Casino in Queens veered off a busy road in the Rego Park neighborhood on Monday afternoon and slammed into a three-story house, injuring six people and leaving a gaping hole in the building, officials said.

title: Review: In A. R. Gurneys Love & Money, a Grandson Materializes to Claim His Fortune
description: The money is vividly apparent as soon as the lights go up on Love & Money, the slender new play by A. R. Gurney that opened at the Pershing Square Signature Center on Monday. The sumptuous but tasteful set, by Michael Yeargan, depicts the parlor floor of a brownstone on the Upper East Side, stocked with expensive-looking furniture, paintings and books. And one expensive-looking person, Cornelia Cunningham (Maureen Anderman), who owns the townhouse and all those mouthwatering goodies.

title: The Art of Punning
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  No one  not the constructor John E. Bennett, and certainly not Will Shortz  meant for this to happen, but this was a tough puzzle for me to solve. Not from a solving point of view, but from an emotional one. This is the first crossword Ive solved since I learned of Merl Reagles death, and it haunts me for a couple of reasons.

title: Jeb Bushs Campaign Takes Steps to Rein In Spending
description: Jeb Bushs presidential campaign has asked various divisions to be mindful of their spending, in a reminder that despite his giant super PAC bankroll, campaign dollars are ultimately more valuable.

title: Prosecutors Rebuke Menendez Over Request to Dismiss His Corruption Case
description: Justice Department prosecutors scolded Senator Robert Menendez and his lawyerson Monday, rebuking the indicted lawmaker for what they described as a disingenuous attempt to have corruption charges against him thrown out in federal court.

title: Ouster of Disruptive Book Club From Napa Train Prompts Racial Bias Charge
description: A group of women, almost all of them black, was kicked off a Napa Valley Wine Train over the weekend for making too much noise, in an incident that prompted accusations of racial bias.

title: Vibrantly Original Style at Afropunk Fest
description: Assorted swarms of students, grandmas and grandpas, designers and musicians, skaters, and bloggers of every stripe gathered to celebrate the diaspora of black music and culture.

title: British IndyCar Driver Justin Wilson Dies of Injuries From Pocono Crash
description: Justin Wilson, a British racecar driver who was struck by debris from another car during the closing laps of the penultimate race in the IndyCar Series season, died Monday, racing officials said. He was 37.

title: Jamaican Wins 100 Meters Again
description: Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce won her third straight world title in the womens 100 meters on Monday at the world championships in Beijing. She finished in 10.76 seconds, followed by Dafne Schippers of the Netherlands and Torie Bowie of the United States.

title: Stocks Deepen Their Slide After Early Gains Evaporate
description: A sudden reversal in United States stock prices late in trading on Tuesday produced a sixth consecutive session of losses and heightened uncertainty about the challenges facing global markets.

title: Mets Rout Phillies, Bashing 8 Homers and 15 Extra-Base Hits
description: PHILADELPHIA  David Wright lay flat on his back, on a mat in a hallway outside the Mets clubhouse here Monday afternoon, going through a series of stretches. He looked vulnerable as he tried to loosen up his back. But as his teammates and coaches passed him, stopping to chat, they went on laughing from the gut, and Wrights familiar cackle echoed throughout the clubhouse.

title: Obama Pushes Clean Energy Plan
description: At a conference in Las Vegas, President Obama called for increased use of renewable energy, in part through a new solar power initiative.

title: Kentucky Stays Alive in Little League World Series
description: Eli Burwash scored the go-ahead run in the bottom of the fifth inning, then earned the save as Kentucky avoided elimination at the Little League World Series in South Williamsport, Pa., beating South Carolina, 4-3. Kentucky will next face California, which defeated Rhode Island, 10-3.

title: With Mergers, Concerns Grow About Private Medicare
description: As some of the nations largest health insurers plan to merge, a new report raises fresh concern over the lack of competition in the private Medicare market. The analysis, released on Tuesday, concludes there is little competition anywhere in the nation.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (Cinemax) DALLAS BUYERS CLUB (2013) A fiercely gaunt Matthew McConaughey, in an Oscar-winning role, portrays Ron Woodroof, a Texas electrician and rodeo rider who, after learning in 1985 that he is H.I.V.-positive, decides to treat himself by hunting down medication that is not then legal in the United States. He eventually begins a subscription service, selling contraband medicine for a monthly fee. Jared Leto, in another Oscar-winning performance, plays Rayon, a transgender woman who becomes Rons business partner. And Jennifer Garner is the doctor who turns into an ally. What is largely missing from this drama, directed by Jean-Marc Valle and inspired by real events, is the sense that Rons efforts are part of a larger movement, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Rons bravery and determination are entirely credible, thanks to Mr. McConaugheys disciplined, high-spirited performance and the filmmakers interest in the complexity of the character. But his actions unfold in something of a vacuum.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: The 60s: In and Out of the Limelight
description: At this late date, what do we want from a portfolio of photographs calling itself The 1960s? Everyone already knows what the period looked like, sounded like, what it meant and what it led to. Especially, we know what pictures of it look like  or are supposed to look like.

title: The Big Decisions

Your friends who have undergone the transformation say the experience is incredible. They drink animal blood, not human blood, and say everything about their new existence provides them with fun, companionship and meaning.

title: Jimmy Carters Unheralded Legacy
description: WASHINGTON  AS Jimmy Carter moves into the twilight of his life, it is enormously frustrating for those of us who worked closely with him in the White House to witness his presidency caricatured as a failure, and to see how he has been marginalized, even by his fellow Democrats, since he left office in 1981.

title: The Man Who Got China Right
description: In the fall of 2009, Jim Chanos began to ask questions about the Chinese economy. What sparked his curiosity was the realization that commodity producers had been largely unaffected by the financial crisis; indeed, they had recorded big profits even as other sectors found themselves reeling in the aftermath of the crisis.

title: Dreading My Patient
description: I didnt want him to show up.

title: News Qs | Stock Markets Tumble as Upheaval Continues
description: Note: Weve updated 6 Qs About the News for the new school year. Let us know what you think.

title: Give Us the Ballot, by Ari Berman
description: Fifty years ago, when President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act on Aug. 6, 1965, he felt, his daughter Luci said, a great sense of victory on one side and a great sense of fear on the other. According to Ari Berman, a political correspondent for The Nation, he knew the law would transform American politics and democracy more than any other civil rights bill in the 20th century, but he also feared that it would deliver the South to the Republican Party for years to come. Both predictions proved to be accurate. The revolution of 1965 spawned an equally committed group of counterrevolutionaries, Berman writes in Give Us the Ballot. Since the V.R.A.s passage, they have waged a decades-long campaign to restrict voting rights. Berman argues that these counterrevolutionaries have in recent years, controlled a majority on the Supreme Court and have set their sights on undoing the accomplishments of the 1960s civil rights movement.

title: At Afropunk Fest, a Kaleidoscope of Fashion
description: Afropunk encompasses music, sociocultural politics and a kaleidoscopically colorful wardrobe. But to hear it from its earliest champions, its way more than that.

title: Eli Gottliebs Best Boy
description: When Robert Faggen interviewed Ken Kesey for The Paris Review in the early 1990s, he asked about the origins of the authors most famous merry prankster, Randle P. McMurphy from One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest. Heres Keseys response:

title: In Syria, Potential Allys Islamist Ties Challenge U.S.
description: ANTAKYA, Turkey  A rebel group with thousands of fighters, political clout and close ties to key regional powers has emerged as one of the most powerful opposition forces in Syria in recent months. It has vowed to fight the Islamic State and called for engagement with the West.

title: What Is a Hero?
description: We often talk about soldiers, firefighters and fictional characters with supernatural powers as heroes. Recently, the news media have used the term to describe three Americans who helped foil an attack on a speeding train in Europe.

description: They say a mother should be primally attuned to her childs cries. That would come a few days later for me, because I dont remember our childs first cry at all.

description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: New Wave of Migrants Reaches Hungary
description: An influx of people, many of them fleeing wars in Iraq, Syria and Afghanistan, arrived at the Hungarian border on Monday, where a fence is being built to deter them.

title: Stocks in China Continue to Fall
description: Shanghai stocks closed 7.6 percent lower on Tuesday.

title: New York Today: Serving Up a Treat
description: Good morning on this muggy Tuesday.

title: 4 State Parties Sign Fund-Raising Pacts With Clinton Campaign
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign has received commitments from four Democratic state parties, including in the crucial proving ground of New Hampshire, to enter joint fund-raising agreements with the campaign just as the nomination battle is beginning.

title: Today in Politics: Obamas Delicate Spot With Joe Biden as Hillary Clinton Maneuvers
description: Good Tuesday morning. Politics can be tough on friendships, as Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is seeking to put a home-state senator in a tough spot, while President Obama might find himself in a similarly awkward position if his vice president decides to challenge his former secretary of state in a bid to replace him. And to the surprise of some in her party, Hillary Rodham Clinton is proposing joint fund-raising agreements that typically occur after the nomination has been won.

title: Moment Is Having a Moment
description: In normal everyday life, time is a liquid that flows around us all unceasingly  a kind of existential syrup. During election season, this syrup is captured, boiled down, dehydrated and separated into its constituent grains  grains that we like to call, without fail, moments. Thus Donald Trump is (according to The New York Times) the man of the moment, and although he was briefly out-Foxed (according to The Belfast Telegraph) by a Megyn moment (Jim Rutenberg's coinage in this magazine), he went on to recover with a big, symbolic moment (according to Mark Halperin on the Today show) at the Iowa State Fair. Hillary Clinton, meanwhile, might be having an Al Capone moment with regard to the legality of her private email server (The Washington Post), but she still found time to have a celebrity moment (The Times again) by taking a selfie with Kim Kardashian and Kanye West. No nexus of events is too large or heterogeneous  no geopolitical weather too swirlingly turbulent  to avoid being reduced to the shorthand of the moment.

title: Coca-Cola Says Its Close to Water Replenishment Goal
description: The Coca-Cola Company is years ahead of schedule in its efforts to replace the water that it uses around the world to make its beverages, it announced on Tuesday.

title: The Meaning of Serena Williams
description: There is no more exuberant winner than Serena Williams. She leaps into the air, she laughs, she grins, she pumps her fist, she points her index finger to the sky, signaling shes No. 1. Her joy is palpable. It brings me to my feet, and I grin right back at her, as if Ive won something, too. Perhaps I have.

title: For History-Minded Tourists, London Marks Blitz Anniversary
description: Beginning in the autumn of 1940, German Luftwaffe pilots bombed London for 57 consecutive nights. It began on Sept. 7, when 348 German bombers and 617 Messerschmitt fighters appeared in the clear skies above the British capital and began to pound the area with explosives. In the months that followed, great numbers of aghast Londoners fled to the countryside. But many more stayed put, through air raids that flattened great swaths of the city and killed 20,000 residents. When the bomb shelters filled up, tens of thousands of Londoners filed into Underground stations, where they slept, packed like sardines, on the concrete platforms.

title: Waukesha Plan for Lake Michigan Water Raises Worries
description: WAUKESHA, Wis.  This city, once famous for its bubbling natural springs, sits about 17 miles from the shore of Lake Michigan. So when the state and federal authorities began demanding that the city address a growing contamination problem in its aquifer, the answer seemed simple: Get water from the big lake.

title: Deal Between North and South Korea Defies Their Mutual Disdain
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The agreement that ended a tense military standoff on the Korean Peninsula on Tuesday taught a lesson about North-South dynamics: Though they heap verbal abuse on each others leaders, the two sides can still do a deal when it suits their interests.

title: Morning Agenda: China Cuts Rates After Stocks Plunge
description: CHINA CUTS RATES AFTER SHANGHAI STOCKS PLUNGE | Chinas central bank cut interest rates after Shanghais stock market went into free fall on Tuesday, closing 7.6 percent lower after an 8.5 percent plunge on Monday, Chris Buckley writes in The New York Times. The move brought interest rates down by 0.25 percent, lowering the one-year lending rate to 4.6 percent. The Peoples Bank of China also reduced the reserve rate requirement by 0.5 percent.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Aug. 18-24, 2015
description: Have you been following the news?

title: Donald Trump Offers Stock Market Advice: You Are Better Off Holding
description: Donald J. Trump, who is always happy to opine on matters of finance, said he possessed the prescience to unload much of his investment portfolio before the stock market took a dive in the past week.

title: Heroes in Polos and Khakis
description: The polo shirt has been linked with all kinds of iconography and stereotypes over the years, from Izod to Ralph Lauren, Nantucket prep to casual Friday, tennis to royals on horses. But as of Monday, it had another association that may trump them all: hero.

title: Part of the Problem: Stocks Are Expensive
description: The smart advice during a falling stock market is not to panic. Selling out of panic often leads investors to miss out on the market recoveries that typically follow a drop, because its all but impossible to predict when such a recovery will begin.

description: Where Are  Now and electronic dance music helped Justin Bieber sing for grown-ups. A story of how music is made today.

title: Popcast: Where Are  Now

title: Popcast: Where Are  Now
description: Where Are  Now, released last February and a contender for consensual song-of-the-summer status, was a result of a fairly typical songwriting process: piano chord changes and a sung topline, later developed through digital manipulations into a dance track. The singer was Justin Bieber (who developed the core of the song with his collaborator Poo Bear), and the digital manipulators were Skrillex and Diplo, who were putting together their Jack U collaboration album.

title: Bets That the Fed Will Delay Interest Rate Rise Could Be Premature
description: WASHINGTON  As markets quake and stock prices fall, investors increasingly are betting that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates this year.

title: The Inside History of Where Are  Now
description: On the radio, where it has been ubiquitous all summer, the million-selling single Where Are  Now by Skrillex and Diplo with Justin Bieber is four minutes of high-tech bliss: a sweet-voiced mixture of longing and recrimination, a lonely plaint with a dance beat.

title: Why Vouchers Wont Fix Vegas Schools
description: LAS VEGAS  FOR the past year, Ive lived next door to a public elementary school. With my windows open in the morning, I can hear childrens laughter on the playground, and at 9 a.m., the Pledge of Allegiance over the intercom. My afternoon commute takes me past the entrance, where I see a diverse group of parents collecting their children, from white moms in yoga pants to Muslim women in hijab guiding their kids carefully through the crosswalk.

title: 1890: Kerchief Keeper Called Insane
description: There is good news from Vienna. A man who has devoted himself to collecting ladies handkerchiefs has been decided to be insane and has been placed in an asylum. If the collector of handkerchiefs is adjudged to be a lunatic, how can the collector of postage stamps be regarded as sane? Handkerchiefs have an intrinsic value and ladies handkerchiefs may be full of poetic and sacred associations, whereas the used postage stamp is valueless, ugly and devoid of any associations worth mentioning.  The New York Herald, European Edition, August 26, 1890

title: Readers Turn: Eliminate Fafsa?
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

description: Cornel West, the influential scholar and civil rights activist, has endorsed Senator Bernie Sanders for president, bolstering a candidate who has drawn huge crowds but also skepticism from black voters.

description: Among the trove of emails released from Hillary Rodham Clintons tenure as secretary of state was this instruction to a trusted aide who needed to brief her on a matter that could not wait:

title: China Again Cuts Interest Rates as Concerns Mount Over Economy
description: HONG KONG  Chinas central bank on Tuesday cut its benchmark interest rate and freed banks to lend more, the latest signs of the governments growing distress over slumping stocks and slowing economic growth.

title: Daily Report: What a Hiccup in Start-Up Land Might Look Like
description: Another day, another sell-off in the global markets. Concerns about Chinas economic slowdown and a souring view of emerging economies dominated again on Monday. And like last week, tech stocks were not immune from the markets plunge.

description: AINABOUS, West Bank  A band of Palestinian gunmen burst into the apartment Mohammad Allan was renting while in law school in the West Bank city of Jenin a decade ago. They blindfolded him, beat him and fired their assault rifles at the floor near his feet.

title: Its Getting Tighter
description: When thinking about the market madness and its possible real effects, heres something you  where by you I mean the Fed in particular  really, really need to keep in mind: the markets have already, in effect, tightened monetary conditions quite a lot.

description: In response to a Sunday Review essay about working in a high-end restaurant, readers shared their own experiences working in the business.

description: BRUSSELS  The Belgian authorities carried out searches Monday night in an operation linked to the attack last week on a high-speed train traveling to Paris from Amsterdam. No arrests were made.

description: Some financial professionals reacted to my Aug. 19 Op-Ed article on private equity fees and university endowments by emphasizing that superior performance justifies superior fees.

title: The Cost of Lower Standards for Women in Marine Recruitment
description: The recent success of two female officers, both West Point graduates, in passing the Armys grueling Ranger School has bolstered arguments for the full integration of women into the militarys front-line combat units. In becoming the first women to receive the coveted Ranger tab, the two officers proved that women can handle not just the physical challenges but also the psychological and leadership tests posed by the nine-week course.

title: Reggie Wayne Will Try to Defy Age With Patriots
description: The Super Bowl champion New England Patriots signed the veteran receiver Reggie Wayne on Tuesday.
