Then continue reading this column to discover other apps that can help students with their studies and make the back-to-school transition smoother.

title: MoMA Presents an Exhibition on Eastern European and Latin American Art
description: Its always interesting to learn what a rich, acquisitive institution like the Museum of Modern Art has added to its collection. The latest report is the exhibition Transmissions: Art in Eastern Europe and Latin America, 1960-1980, which opens on September 5 and will present some 300 artworks in numerous mediums, many on view for the first time. Nearly all date from around 1968, a period when art radically diversified, sometimes dematerializing altogether. These works represent artists from distant regions whose efforts ran parallel in terms of strategies (largely Conceptual, frequently performance-oriented), political contexts (often oppressive) and interests (protest, mass media, popular art). Some names  Valie Export, Ana Mendieta, Edward Krasinski, Juan Downey, Fernando Botero  will be familiar; others will be much less so. The show will surely reflect the MoMAs desire for a broad global reach, but perhaps also the aesthetic narrowness of its relentless elevation of Conceptual-oriented work. (Through Jan. 3, moma.org.)

title: Virginia Governor Discusses Shooting
description: In a radio interview, Gov. Terry Mcauliffe of Virginia said the suspect in the on-air shooting of two journalists was believed to be a disgruntled employee.

title: Costume en Face Adds Sketches and English Translations to Notes on Butoh
description: Its not exactly beach reading, but Costume en Face: A Primer of Darkness for Young Boys and Girls (Ugly Duckling Presse) is one of the strangest and most beautiful dance books to come along in a while, though its not exactly a dance book either. The slender volume contains notations of Costume en Face, a 1976 work by Tatsumi Hijikata, who created the Japanese performance art Butoh. The note taker was the lead performer, Moe Yamamoto; his record of Hijikatas words, in Japanese, alternates with Sawako Nakayasus English translation, spattered with hand-drawn sketches and symbols.

title: German Leaders Visit Refugee Shelter
description: President Joachim Gauck and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany visited a former government building in Berlin that is being used to house refugees.

title: Gloria Grahame: Blonde Ambition, a Film Retrospective at Lincoln Center
description: Anyone who has seen Fritz Langs 1953 crime noir The Big Heat will never forget the image of Gloria Grahame, her face half-hidden behind a bandage and prosthetic makeup, playing Debby Marsh, an abused gangsters moll. The role gave Ms. Grahame, who specialized in portraying dangerous, damaged women, one of her most pungent lines: Youre about as romantic as a pair of handcuffs.

title: Tennis Is Big at U.S. Open, but Not on Screen
description: Hollywood has often looked to sports for inspiration. Be it the never-say-die underdogs in Hoosiers and Rocky, the championship pedigrees of Ali and Remember the Titans or the ragtag madness of Slap Shot and Major League, practically every sport has enjoyed its indelible moment on the big screen.

title: Katrina: A Turning Point at The Times
description: Walter Baranger is Senior Editor for News Operations, managing communications and logistics for Times news bureaus.

title: The Tall Blond Man With One Black Shoe: Cloak and Dagger and Farce
description: A French comedy that treats the invasion of privacy as a condition of modern life, The Tall Blond Man With One Black Shoe (on Blu-ray and DVD from Film Movement) may be even more topical now than when it was released in 1972.

title: Carl Apfel, a Textile Veteran and Husband to Iris Apfel, Dies at 100
description: He ran Old World Weavers, a company that sourced and produced fabrics, with his wife.

title: Who Threw the First Brick at Stonewall?
description: The trailer for the movie Stonewall, which dramatizes the 1969 riot that helped spark the gay rights movement, has generated consternation and anger among many lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people.

title: Glorya Kaufman School of Dance Adds a New Dimension to Arts in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  Ah, I recommend it, Jodie Gates sighed, adopting the tone of someone advocating an exotic spa treatment or sky diving. The satisfactions she meant are much harder to come by. How many people get a state-of-the-art building of nearly 55,000 square feet designed to their specifications? Ms. Gates was standing near the construction site of such an edifice: the Glorya Kaufman International Dance Center, the future home of the University of Southern Californias new Glorya Kaufman School of Dance.

title: Remembering Carl Apfel: A Style Icon in His Own Right
description: There is a moment in the film Iris  the recent documentary made by Albert Maysles  when Iris and Carl Apfel are interviewed together in their New York apartment. There was something about her that just got into me; its always there, says Carl of his wife of more than six decades. Iris cuts in, laughing: And I figured he was cool, and he was cuddly, and he cooked Chinese, so I couldnt do any better.

title: Homeowner Insurance: Your Credit Score May Raise the Premium
description: If you own a home, theres yet another reason to maintain good credit: Insurance companies may give significant weight to your credit history when setting rates for homeowner coverage.

title: Ben Brantley on London Theater, Where Characters Drink to Dull the Pain of Life
description: LONDON  Wine is very much on the menu at the Almeida Theater in Islington these days. It is served, of course, at the bar that adjoins the theater. But more important, wine is being extolled as absolutely essential to our daily diet on the Almeida stage, where a riveting production of Euripides Bakkhai is hypnotizing packed houses.

title: 36 Hours in Istanbul, Asian Side
description: The less-harried Asian side of Istanbul is a greener, cleaner swath of the city that offers its own multicultural mix of Ottoman palaces, intriguing cuisine and hipster night life.

title: Onassis Cultural Center Announces Festival
description: The choreographer Jonah Bokaer, the dance historian Jennifer Homans, the actor Paul Giamatti, and the fashion designers Mary Katrantzou and Narciso Rodriguez are some of the artists who will be featured in the first Onassis Festival NY, hosted by the Onassis Cultural Center NY. In announcing the event on Wednesday, the center said that the annual festival of arts and ideas will center on a different theme each year.

title: Jason Sudeikis Courts With Comic Flair in Sleeping With Other People
description: Four and a half years ago, Leslye Headland went on a blind date of the working variety with Jason Sudeikis, a man she knew only as that goofy guy from Saturday Night Live.

title: Flexible Venue Rules Play Important Role in Multimillion-Dollar Bankruptcy Filings
description: While many of us were enjoying some August beach time, Judge Russell F. Nelms of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Fort Worth decided to use a ruling in a local case as a chance to drop a bombshell on the restructuring community.

title: The Melting of Mark Zuckerbergs Donation to Newark Schools
description: The national debate over how to best educate our children is usually undertaken at a high level of abstraction. Constructive dialogue is often hampered by intense philosophical preconceptions that drive the perceptions and characterizations of all key players in the underlying drama: union leaders, charter operators, philanthropists, school administrators, politicians and teachers. The great strength of Dale Russakoffs heartbreaking and disheartening book, The Prize: Whos in Charge of Americas Schools, (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, 2015) is its steadfast insistence on avoiding generalities and explaining realities.

title: 36 Hours in Istanbul, Asian Side
description: The lines to enter major sites on the European side of Istanbul, Turkeys cultural capital, can stretch for hours. But just across the Bosporus lies the less-harried Asian side, a greener, cleaner and often more conservative swath of the city that offers its own multicultural mix of Ottoman palaces, artsy hotels, tasty cuisine and hipster night life. Here, at the gateway to Anatolia, hilly pine-forest trails in former fishing villages offer opportunities to burn off the baklava, while shady tea gardens abound for those who prefer relaxing with a water view. Wealthy Turks live in villas to the north, while miles to the south, party-friendly Kadikoy is bursting with vegetable and fish markets and bookstores, and is home to a street devoted to bars.

title: Questions for Syngenta as Monsanto Walks Away
description: Monsanto, the worlds largest seed maker, has abandoned its $47 billion pursuit of the Swiss agricultural chemical company Syngenta, and that may turn out to be the best thing for both sides. But Syngentas management must now show why its reluctance to entertain the offer was well founded.

title: New York Police Dept. Creates Unit to Monitor Times Square Issues
description: The New York Police Department is forming a new unit to patrol Times Square and address quality-of-life issues amid growing concerns over the jumble of costumed characters and topless women in its pedestrian plazas.

title: South Sudans President Signs Deal
description: President Salva Kiir of South Sudan expressed reservations as he signed a peace accord on Wednesday amid international pressure and threats of an arms embargo.

title: Student Accused of Rape Testifies
description: Owen Labrie, a former student of St. Pauls School in New Hampshire took the stand after being accused of rape by a fellow student, during a school tradition known as a senior salute.

title: Review: The Girl in the Spiders Web Brings Back Stieg Larssons Detective Duo
description: Fans of Stieg Larssons captivating odd couple of modern detective fiction  the genius punk hacker Lisbeth Salander and her sometime partner, the crusading investigative journalist Mikael Blomkvist  will not be disappointed by the latest installment of their adventures, written not by their creator, Stieg Larsson (who died of a heart attack at the age of 50 in 2004), but by a Swedish journalist and author named David Lagercrantz. Though there are plenty of lumps in the novel along the way, Salander and Blomkvist have survived the authorship transition intact and are just as compelling as ever.

title: On One Paris Street, Shopkeepers Specialize in Only One Thing
description: For this series, T celebrates shops around the world that sell just a single kind of product.

title: Pregnancy Apps Do Everything but Ease Labor Pains
description: Three months ago, my wife, Chrysta, and I were driving along Melrose Avenue in Los Angeles when she let out a harrowing cry.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE BOOK OF STRANGE NEW THINGS, by Michel Faber. (Hogarth, $17.) At the request of an alien population several galaxies away, a Christian missionary travels to a distant planet, leaving his wife behind on Earth. Faber, whom our reviewer, Marcel Theroux, called a master of the weird, skillfully handles the otherworldly in this speculative novel.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE PRIZE: Whos in Charge of Americas Schools?, by Dale Russakoff. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $27.) This brilliantly reported account of Newarks attempt to right its public schools stars Cory Booker, Chris Christie and Mark Zuckerberg.

title: Pope Francis May Pass Through Central Park During New York Visit
description: When Pope Francis visits New York City next month, the best place to catch a glimpse of the popular pontiff may be in Central Park.

title: Mormon Church Will Keep Ties With Boy Scouts Despite Objecting to Gay Leaders
description: The Mormon Church announced Wednesday that it would continue its close association with the Boy Scouts for now, ending speculation that it would sever ties because of the Scoutss decision last month to let openly gay men and women serve as leaders.

title: Details Revealed in Gunmans Death
description: Sgt. Rick Garletts of the Virginia State Police details the car chase and subsequent death of the shooting suspect, Bryce Williams, whose real name is Vester Lee Flanagan.

title: Allyson Felix Is Back With a Better Sense of Limits, and Schedule Is One
description: BEIJING  Allyson Felix has the sniffles: a cold during the summer and the world track and field championships. But in view of the challenges she has overcome to get back to the Birds Nest and the challenges her sport continues to face to its integrity, that seems a minor concern.

title: Official Discusses Virginia Shooting
description: Sheriff Bill Overton of Franklin County, Va., talked about the shooting on live television that resulted in the deaths of the journalists Alison Parker and Adam Ward.

title: Suspect in Insider Trading Case Granted Bail
description: A Pennsylvania man accused of being the biggest beneficiary of a brazen scheme that blended sophisticated computer hacking with old-school insider trading may be getting out of jail, more than two weeks after he and four other men were arrested by federal authorities.

title: Kids Cooking Pizza Two Ways: On the Grill and in the Oven
description: The master plan? Raising children who can be independent in the kitchen, able to prepare a few healthful meals and snacks and with the confidence to tackle a new recipe or task. In our Kids in the Kitchen series, Motherlodes KJ DellAntonia and Cookings Margaux Laskey move their very differently aged families toward that goal. Margaux finds ways for her 3-year-old and toddler to help cook, while KJ stands back and coaches her two 9-year-olds and her 11- and 14-year-olds in cooking on their own. This week, both families made pizza.

title: WDBJ Executive Discusses Gunman
description: Jeffrey A. Marks, the general manager of WDBJ, said the man suspected of shooting two employees of the Roanoke, Va., TV station was quick to take offense at co-workers comments.

title: The St. Pauls Rape Case Shows Why Sexual-Assault Laws Must Change
description: In the rape trial of Owen Labrie, unfolding this month in a county courtroom in Concord, N.H., this much is settled: When Labrie was an 18-year-old senior at the boarding school St. Pauls, he competed with other male students over who could score with or slay the most girls. In the days before his graduation in June 2014, Labrie invited a girl, then 15, via email to join him for a senior salute, which could involve anything from kissing to sex. He had a key, passed around by students, to a mechanical room at the school, and the girl went there with him.

title: Video Review: Toyota Tacoma Adds Machismo, but Retains Its Reliability
description: THE Toyota Tacomas reputation for reliability is legendary, but after a decade without major changes, the truck had become a bit long in the tooth. Yet it owned the midsize pickup market, with the Nissan Frontier and Honda Ridgeline far behind.

title: Driven | 2016 Toyota Tacoma TRD Off Road
description: The Tacomas 800-pound gorilla is new, improved and facing new competition.

title: Jonathan Franzens Purity
description: At the center of Jonathan Franzens new novel, Purity, is a young college graduate called Pip, whose full first name, bestowed by her not-quite-sane mother, is Purity. Pip is burdened by college debt, a lack of direction and a sharp intelligence; she is also burdened by her mother, who has brought Pip up alone in a tiny cabin in the Santa Cruz Mountains and now works at the checkout in a market. Pips general situation in a dead-end job is not helped by her obsession with a married man who lives with his wife in the same house in Oakland as Pip and some others. When Pip meets a nice boy in a coffee shop, a guy who seems to like her, she leaves him alone in her bedroom in a state of some sexual arousal and stays away for more than an hour while she fills in a questionnaire for a friend downstairs. She seems surprised and becomes angry when she finds a text he sends to another guy: U can have her # if you have a taste for weird.

title: Murder by Candlelight, by Michael Knox Beran
description: Murder. Dismemberment. Rape. Cannibalism. Jack the Ripper. The Newtown shooter. Why are we fascinated by murders and murderers, by acts of evil and those who perpetrate them?

title: Novels by Kathleen Alcott, Vu Tran and Alaa Al Aswany; a Memoir by David Payne
description: THE AUTOMOBILE CLUB

title: Cruising With Crosby, Stills & Nash
description: Crosby, Stills & Nash return to Europe with a Sept. 12 show in London, but fans of the band can catch David Crosby, Stephen Stills and Graham Nash on stage three times during the week leading up to their monthlong tour. The Rock and Roll Hall of Famers will be performing those shows at the Royal Court Theater aboard Cunards Queen Mary 2 ocean liner.

title: Surviving the Nazis
description: AVENUE OF SPIESA True Story of Terror, Espionage, and One American Familys Heroic Resistance in Nazi-Occupied FranceBy Alex Kershaw286 pp. Crown, $28.

title: Susan Caseys Voices in the Ocean
description: At a time when many of us might turn to religion or to mood-altering substances, Susan Casey turned to dolphins.

title: The End of Tsarist Russia, by Dominic Lieven
description: World War I was the greatest empire slayer of all time. Down went the Ottoman Empire, ruling from Bosnia to Basra. Hapsburg shrank into tiny Austria. Germany and Russia remained largely intact, but Wilhelm II ended up in exile, while the Romanovs were murdered by the Bolsheviks. Exit sultans and kaisers; enter authoritarians and totalitarians.

title: Girl Waits With Gun, by Amy Stewart
description: Amy Stewarts first novel, Girl Waits With Gun, follows her award-winning nonfiction  The Drunken Botanist, itself a dram of good cheer after her previous, excellently informative doses of bad news in the shape of rampant earthworms (The Earth Moved), poisonous bouquets (Flower Confidential), toxic vegetation (Wicked Plants) and lethal insects (Wicked Bugs).

title: U.S. to Support Sri Lanka Plan to Investigate War Crimes
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  The United States will sponsor a resolution on Sri Lanka next month at the United Nations Human Rights Council backing Colombos plans for reconciliation and to conduct an investigation into possible war crimes during the final stages of the islands civil war, a top American diplomat said Wednesday.

title: That Winter the Wolf Came, by Juliana Spahr
description: Nobody has to tell Juliana Spahr that the personal is political: She has spent her career inventing verse and prose forms that show how our intimate feelings emerge, like knots in nets or waves at sea, from systems much larger than any one persons control. This Connection of Everyone With Lungs (2005) examined the global effects of 9/11 through the metaphor of polluted air; the piled-up details in Well Then There Now (2011) looked at Spahrs years in Hawaii, and at her origins in Appalachia, as if to ask where she could call home.

title: Harriet Wolfs Seventh Book of Wonders, by Julianna Baggott
description: Many things are hidden in Julianna Baggotts intricate, tenderhearted novel about a writer, her children and a legacy of loss. Love letters, folded into origami cranes that never take flight, are tucked under a mattress. A newborn child, mute and sallow, is spirited away from her mother and secreted in an institution. A young man supports himself as a professional hider of things, until he too must go into hiding. A wife is lost, a husband is lost, a mother is lost and so is a father. Indeed, an entire book, Harriet Wolfs seventh novel, has disappeared. And, like so many precious lost things, it may be hiding in plain sight. All this sounds somber. But in groping for whats lost, Baggotts characters also stumble across pleasure, joy  and recognition.

title: Amitav Ghoshs Flood of Fire
description: To read Amitav Ghoshs Flood of Fire is to enter a world of sepoys, sahibs and rajahs, traveling with them from Assam to Calcutta to Canton, all the while learning about their pasts and dreading or hoping for their futures. It is a fictional journey both physical and temporal and, like real journeys, best appreciated when one is willing to accept detours and adventures.

title: Closing the Book
description: It didnt surprise me, when my parents were dying, that I couldnt write. But it shocked me, as a writer of fiction, that I couldnt read.

title: The 2016 China-Bashing Race
description: When it comes to foreign policy, American presidential candidates have often found it easy, even beneficial, to criticize China. In recent decades, Chinas growing economic, military and political clout has generated concern among many voters in this country. Frankly, there has been plenty to criticize, including Beijings reprehensible treatment of its own citizens.

title: Ann Beattie: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of The State Were In reads more novels and stories than anything else  except, maybe, cookbooks. I avoid mysteries, since I never understand what happens.

title: Walmart to End Sales of Assault-Style Rifles in U.S. Stores
description: Walmart said on Wednesday that it would no longer sell high-powered rifles in its stores in the United States. The decision followed years of public pressure on the retailer to stop selling some of the most lethal weapons associated with many of the nations mass shootings.

title: London After the Blitz
description: The city is marking the 75th anniversary of its time under siege during World War II. The most heavily hit areas were rebuilt in the 1960s.

title: Obama Honors 2014 W.N.B.A. Champions
description: The president praised the Phoenix Mercury womens basketball team for the W.N.B.A. championship, saying that the players served as role models for girls.

title: Obama Honors 2014 W.N.B.A. Champions
Jonathan Martin, Former N.F.L. Player, Says He Attempted Suicide
description: Jonathan Martin, the retired football player who left the Miami Dolphins in 2013 after accusing teammates of bullying, said Wednesday that he had attempted suicide on multiple occasions because of long-simmering identity struggles and the stresses of the N.F.L.

title: Facebook Tests a Digital Assistant for Its Messaging App
description: In the future, the worlds largest tech companies, like Apple, Amazon and Microsoft, want to make completing everyday chores as simple as asking a question of a digital assistant.

title: Hillary Clinton Takes Responsibility for Email Use, Saying It Wasnt the Best Choice
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said Wednesday that she understood why people had questions about her decision to use only private email while she was secretary of state and that she took responsibility for that decision, a shift from her past remarks about an issue that has dogged her since shortly before she began her presidential campaign.

title: Missing Two Key Bats, Yankees Offense Seems Adrift
description: After his teams latest hollow effort to score runs, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi could only raise his arms in mock surrender.

title: Virginia Shooting Gone Viral, in a Well-Planned Rollout on Social Media
description: In one sad sense there was nothing new, or even very unusual, about the televised killing of two journalists in Virginia on Wednesday morning.

title: Mr. Robot Finale Postponed After Virginia Shootings
description: The Season 1 finale of Mr. Robot, USAs much lauded hacker drama, will not air Wednesday night as previously scheduled. The episode contains a scene of gun violence that is particularly resonant given the shooting of two journalists in Virginia Wednesday morning.

title: A Gorilla Match (or 5) at the Bronx Zoo
description: On a bright summers day at the Bronx Zoo, four adult female gorillas nursed their babies until the little gorillas were so full of mothers milk, they fell asleep in the hot afternoon sun. In the distance, on a hill, a 5-foot-tall, 505-pound male silverback named Ernie gazed out over it all, chewing on a celery stalk.

title: Carly Fiorina Cries Foul at the GOP Debate Cutoff
description: Will Carly Fiorina manage to get on the big stage next month in the second Republican presidential debate? The question is in part a technical one involving how poll numbers are weighed in rating Mrs. Fiorina before and after the Fox News debate earlier this month, where she stood out as a considerable winner despite being relegated to the also-ran set of candidates. It is also a question of how sensitive Republican leaders are to charges that the party habitually treats women as second-class citizens. Mrs. Fiorina, despite rising significantly in recent polls, argues that the Republican National Committee and CNN, the debate sponsor, are using a mix of old and new polling numbers that could unfairly block her from the prime-time show next month.

title: Joseph F. Traub, 83, Dies; Early Advocate for Computer Science
description: Joseph F. Traub, who founded the computer science department at Columbia University and who helped develop algorithms used in scientific computing in physics and mathematics as well as on Wall Street, died on Monday in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 83.

title: A Kurdish Political Star in Turkey Confronts Escalating Violence
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Emerging from a daylong meeting with party officials, Selahattin Demirtas was anything but the dynamic Kurdish politician whose coolness and rhetorical skill have evoked comparisons to President Obama. He was frazzled as he paced back and forth, addressing his advisers before charging into his next meeting, vowing to bring an end to the reignited war between the Turkish state and Kurdish militants.

title: Business Group Assails Donald Trump for Urging Higher Taxes on Some Companies
description: His political platform is based largely on his business acumen, but Donald J. Trump is making a habit of rankling the business world with his ideas on trade and taxes.

title: Review: The Weeknd Makes a Bid for Pop Outreach on Beauty Behind the Madness
description: Abel Tesfaye, the Canadian songwriter who calls himself the Weeknd, used to be pops bleakest, creepiest Don Juan. The come-ons he sang in his high, sweet tenor  and in the scratchy moan that sometimes replaced it  were more like warning labels. They detailed how loveless, drugged-out, callous, self-destructive and self-absorbed he could be.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Review: Beach House Releases Depression Cherry
description: BEACH HOUSE

title: Review: Ccile McLorin Salvant Wields Her Power, Drawing From Her Album For One to Love
description: Ccile McLorin Salvant, the finest jazz singer to emerge in the last decade, combines the rigorous sensitivities of an artist with the wary calculation of a critic. Her whole bearing as a performer  judicious, confiding, theatrical, skeptical  suggests a watchful distance from the persona she so persuasively embodies.

title: James Holmes Gets 12 Life Sentences in Aurora Shootings
description: DENVER  In an emotional end to the court drama that has preoccupied Colorado, Judge Carlos A. Samour Jr. on Wednesday issued 12 life sentences in prison to James E. Holmes, who fatally shot 12 people in a movie theater in the Denver suburb of Aurora three years ago and wounded 70 others. The judge also imposed 3,318 years in prison on Mr. Holmes for his nonlethal crimes, including attempted murder.

title: Misty Copeland Makes Her Broadway Debut in On the Town
description: Who, me?

title: The Calming Quiet of Outer Cape Cod
description: WELLFLEET, Mass.  In flight from the bottles-and-models excesses of the Hamptons, the drag-queen hucksters of Provincetown and the hedge-funder mosh pit that Nantucket Island has become, a flock of creative types has steadily traced a route to an alternative getaway.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
description: South Korea and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Sidewalk Blackboards Offer Some Chalk n Chew
description: Phil Ashworth studied illustration at the Rhode Island School of Design. His influences include the simple graphic lines of Shel Silverstein and New Yorker cartoonists, and his work has been shown at Gallery Nucleus and Hero Complex Gallery, both in Southern California. He has designed a T-shirt graphic that Vans skateboard shoes is printing and is starting to work on a book proposal.

title: A Fame Screening in Central Park Draws Alumni Extras
description: For two and a half hours in Central Park on Tuesday night, Leslie Cohn wasnt the manager of a Twist Frozen Yogurt shop in Westwood, N.J., a 53-year-old single mom with two grown sons.

title: Director at Uzbekistan Museum Is Dismissed and Accused of Crimes
description: MOSCOW  A significant trove of modern Russian art, preserved not least by its obscure location, was engulfed in controversy on Wednesday after its longstanding director was summarily dismissed on accusations of forgery and theft.

title: Architect Sought for Obamas Presidential Library Complex
description: WASHINGTON  The foundation overseeing the development of Barack Obamas presidential library began a global competition on Wednesday to select the architect who will design the elaborate Chicago complex.

title: Op-Photo: Remembering the Ruins of Palmyra
description: Islamic State militants recently detonated explosions at the ruins of Palymra in Syria, shown here in a photograph taken between 1900 and 1920.

title: For Pearl, a 4,200-Gallon River Runs Through the Koch Theater
description: Daniel Ezralow may be a champion of dance, but hes not elitist about it. He choreographed the opening ceremony of the Sochi Olympics, Julie Taymors Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark and, in February, a version of The Rite of Spring for the Russian rhythmic gymnastics team at the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg.

title: A Crystal Healers Guide to Curing What Ails You
description: You are drawn to the one you need, says the crystal healer Azalea Lee at the end of another summer in Los Angeles. Everything is in retrograde, and the variety of soothsayers is exceeded only by the number of patients coming to them, but Lee is reluctant to recommend a crystal to cure a malady  preferring to let her clients find their own. We have spent our whole lives trusting other peoples authority, explains Lee about using crystals for healing. Its the same with intuition: I want to help people see that they know more.

title: Marcy Borders, Dust Lady Who Survived 9/11, Dies at 42
description: Marcy Borders, who became known as the dust lady from a defining picture of her covered in ash and grime on Sept. 11, 2001, died on Monday. She was 42.

title: August 26, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from South Korea, Greece, Hungary and Chile.

title: Setting a Stage for Kindness in Chinese Society
description: At the Drum Tower West Theater in Beijing last week, Circus Master was torturing Little Flower because she would not speak and was ruining the show.

title: Market Tumult Erases This Years Gains at William Ackmans Hedge Fund
description: Not even one of Wall Streets most successful investors has been spared from the recent rout in stock markets around the world.

title: A Budding Fassbinder of Fashion Videos
Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Amy Poehler on Enjoying the View From the Losers Circle and Moving On
description: At the start of a conversation about Parks and Recreation, Amy Poehler said with a sentimental laugh, Part of me is like, Is this the last time Ill ever speak of it? Im getting so nostalgic about it, even though it still feels like a very present thing.

title: Roger Stone Rides Donald Trumps Well-Tailored Coattails
The 24-Hour Party at the Guggenheim
description: Ten years ago, Agathe Snow, a darling of the downtown New York art scene, gave a 24-hour party. More than 300 artists and creative types gathered to dance in a grimy loft on Ann Street in Lower Manhattan that was still tinged by the Sept. 11 attack. Ms. Snow filmed the entire affair.

title: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
description: Lacoste has a store event at 541 Broadway on Thursday from 6 to 8 p.m. where you can meet the tennis player John Isner and shop for gear like a polo with zippered collar in striped ultradry pique ($90) and a pleated tennis skirt ($90) in support of the City Parks Foundation. On Sunday, it will host a clinic from noon to 2 p.m. with free tennis instruction by the Lacoste player Murphy Jensen, snacks and prizes; Central Park Tennis Courts, Central Park West and 96th Street.

title: El Cortez in Bushwick: Comfort Tex-Mex and Throwback Cocktails
description: With its lowbrow menu of greasy chicken and old-man cocktails, the Commodore brought a dive-bar atmosphere to a corner of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that was on the verge of rapid change. Its owners have a similar playbook at El Cortez, a Tex-Mex bar and restaurant in Bushwick, likewise in flux. On a Sunday night in July, El Cortez was flooded with refugees from Tiki Disco nearby. As Soul Makossa pulsed, revelers in Nets jerseys and shades swarmed. One woman, on her back, churned her legs like an eggbeater.

title: Clinton Urges Response to Gun Violence
description: The Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton said she was stricken after the latest shooting in Virginia, while calling for stricter controls on guns.

title: Tehran Claims U.S. Is Holding 19 Iranians
description: Turning the tables on the United States, Irans Foreign Ministry said Wednesday that the American authorities were holding 19 Iranian citizens on what it described as unfounded charges of sanctions violations and called for their release.

title: Tom Harkin Cautions Joe Biden Against Running for President
description: Former Senator Tom Harkin, a fixture in Iowa Democratic politics for over four decades, discouraged Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday from entering the presidential race, suggesting that Hillary Rodham Clinton, if elected, could name him to a top diplomatic post instead.

title: New Orleans, 10 Years After Katrina
description: The city that went under in the surging waters of Hurricane Katrina has not returned, not to how it used to be. A decade later, New Orleans is an improvisation, one that is establishing a new normal.

title: Kristof: Lessons From the Virginia Shooting
description: The slaying of two journalists Wednesday as they broadcast live to a television audience in Virginia is still seared on our screens and our minds, but its a moment not only to mourn but also to learn lessons.

title: Security Blogger May Have New Lead in Ashley Madison Hacking
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Ashley Madison is the hacking that doesnt want to go away.

title: Classical Playlist: Mahler and Killer Tuba Songs
description: Mahler: Symphony No. 1 Thierry Fischer, conductor; Utah Symphony(Reference Recordings)A cycle of Mahler symphonies was a nice way for the Swiss conductor Thierry Fischer, 57, who took over the Utah Symphony in 2009, to celebrate both its 75th anniversary (in 2015) and the memory of Maurice Abravanel, the orchestras great music director from 1947 to 1979. Abravanel, after all, recorded the first Mahler cycle by an American orchestra with the Utah Symphony Orchestra, as it called itself then, from 1963 to 1974 for the Vanguard label. (Leonard Bernsteins groundbreaking 1960s survey for Columbia, mostly with the New York Philharmonic, disqualified itself with an Eighth Symphony with the London Symphony Orchestra.) You would hope that the new performances and recordings would automatically supersede the old ones, but this first disc does not necessarily bear that out. Abravanels 1974 First Symphony, as remembered, relies perhaps a bit too much on sheer nervous energy, but it is also more respectful of the subtleties of Mahlers score.

title: Biography of Jimmy Carter Is in the Works
description: Kai Bird, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author and political biographer, is at work on a new book about former President Jimmy Carter.

title: The Czech Lute, a Baroque Masterpiece, Gets Filled In
description: Last year, the Czech musicologist Petr Danek was in the Franciscan library in Slany, about 20 miles northwest of Prague, searching for Renaissance and early Baroque musical prints. He noticed large bound volume on a high shelf and, taking it down, realized it was a special find: the bass parts for a rare collection of vocal polyphony from the beginning of the 17th century.

title: After Katrina, Man and Water in Louisiana
description: A decade after the devastating hurricane and five years after the BP oil spill, Frank Relle has been looking at how Louisiana residents coexist with water.

title: Why China Rattles the World
description: Chinas economy is faltering, prompting concerns that are now shaking global stock markets.

title: Documents Show Vester Lee Flanagans Turbulent Tenure at TV Station Before Virginia Shooting
description: In March 2012, Vester Lee Flanagan II achieved what he had been seeking: a return to television news after a long hiatus. But documents filed in a civil court case showed that soon after Mr. Flanagans arrival at WDBJ, a television station in Roanoke, Va., station executives and rank-and-file employees were deeply concerned about his conduct.

title: Frank E. Petersen, First Black General in Marines, Dies at 83
description: Frank E. Petersen Jr., who suffered bruising racial indignities as a military enlistee in the 1950s and was even arrested at an officers club on suspicion of impersonating a lieutenant, but who endured to become the first black aviator and the first black general in the Marine Corps, died on Tuesday at his home in Stevensville, Md., near Annapolis. He was 83.

title: Gap Says It Will Phase Out On-Call Scheduling of Employees
description: Facing increasing pressure to curb erratic scheduling practices, Gap announced that it would stop requiring employees to make themselves available for last-minute shifts.

title: Killings of Journalists Bring Gun Violence to Dark New Level
description: It is an increasingly horrific fact of life and death in the United States that easily available guns offer troubled Americans the power to act out their grievances in public. This trend, dramatized in recent years by macabre shootings in schools, churches, movie theaters and workplaces, was taken to a dark new level on Wednesday in southwestern Virginia by a disturbed former reporter who chose not only to murder two journalists as they reported live for a television station that had fired him, but also to record and broadcast the crime on social media.

title: Court Rules Clerk Must Issue Licenses for Same-Sex Marriages
description: A federal appeals court in Kentucky on Wednesday affirmed a ruling ordering a county clerk who objects to same-sex marriage on religious grounds to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples.

title: U.N. Says Aid Increase Would Cut Migration
description: UNITED NATIONS  The new top emergency relief official here urged the worlds rich countries on Wednesday to step up aid to war zones in the Middle East and Africa so that refugees are not forced to seek safety in Europe.

title: Testy News Conference Exchange Puts Donald Trumps Quirks on Display
description: It was Donald J. Trump at his neediest, pleading with the television anchor in front of him to acknowledge a poll that, he said, showed that Hispanics really do love him. You saw that, right? he asked. Did you see it? Wait. Did you see it?

title: San Francisco Firefighters Become Unintended Safety Net for the Homeless
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When the emergency bell sounds at Fire Station 1 here, firefighters pull on boots and backpacks, swing into Engine 1 and hurtle out the door in almost a single motion, a blast of red lights and caterwauling sirens. More often than not, there is no fire.

title: Smaller of Panda Cub Twins Dies at the National Zoo
description: The smaller of twin giant panda cubs, who faced long odds for survival after it was born at the National Zoo in Washington on Saturday, died on Wednesday despite round-the-clock efforts to help the mother with the difficult task of balancing two babies.

title: Saudi Arabia: King Plans to Visit U.S.
description: King Salman will visit the White House next week for the first time since ascending to the throne, Saudi officials said, as part of a trip intended to patch over differences with President Obama over the Iran nuclear agreement. While White House officials refused to confirm the Sept. 4 visit, John Kirby, a State Department spokesman, said Wednesday that he would not contradict an announcement on the trip by the Saudi authorities. If the Saudi government announced it, Im certainly not in any position to characterize it any other way, Mr. Kirby said. King Salman, who became king in January, pulled out of a summit meeting with Persian Gulf leaders at Camp David in May. The Saudis have been concerned about the Iran accord but endorsed it three weeks ago, along with other Gulf states, after receiving assurances from American officials. Prem G. Kumar, a Middle East expert at the Albright Stonebridge Group, said the Saudis biggest concern was how the U.S. will counter Irans destabilizing behavior in the Middle East.

title: Hong Kong Christian Groups Feel New Scrutiny From Mainland
description: HONG KONG  For years, the Rev. Philip Woo, the feisty leader of a small Protestant church here, has delighted in testing the limits of Chinas restrictive laws on religion. From his perch in Hong Kong, he has delivered fiery sermons on human rights, led seminars on social problems for mainland students, and ordained pastors in the mainland without permission from the ruling Communist Party.

title: Guatemalas Embattled President
description: A decade ago, corruption in Guatemala was regarded as an indomitable, institutionalized plague. It was possible to scrape off a few layers, but hopeless to try to root it out.

title: China Falters, and the Global Economy Is Forced to Adapt
description: HONG KONG  The commodities giant BHP Billiton spent heavily for years, mining iron ore across Australia, digging for copper in Chile, and pumping oil off the coast of Trinidad. The company could be confident in its direction as commodities orders surged from its biggest and best customer, China.

title: Viewers of Virginia TV Station Wake Up to Watch a Nightmare
description: ROANOKE, Va.  The signal from WDBJ-TV carries across hundreds of miles of southwest Virginia, and on Wednesday morning, so did the grief.

title: Amelia Boynton Robinson, a Pivotal Figure at the Selma March, Dies at 104
description: Amelia Boynton Robinson, who was called the matriarch of the voting rights movement  and whose photograph, showing her beaten, gassed and left for dead in the epochal civil rights march known as Bloody Sunday, appeared in newspapers and magazines round the world in 1965  died on Wednesday in Montgomery, Ala. She was 104.

title: A Different Kind of Yankee Rotation
description: MOOSIC, Pa.  Ruth. Gehrig. DiMaggio. Jeter. Scranton?

title: Palestinians Want to Raise Flag at U.N.
description: Palestinians want to raise their flag at the United Nations next month, a matter that could set off a diplomatic dispute in the General Assembly. Nearly 20 Arab countries, as well as Senegal and Venezuela, submitted a one-page draft resolution to the General Assembly this week calling for the organizations two nonmember observer states to be granted the right to raise their flags at the gates of United Nations headquarters. The Palestinians gained nonmember observer status in 2012. The only other entity to hold that status is the Holy See. The Vatican did not add its name as a co-sponsor of the resolution. The effort has already met with a rebuke from Jewish groups like Bnai Brith, which said in a statement that raising a flag was a privilege accorded to a member state and that part of the Palestinian territories is under the control of Hamas, which is openly committed to the destruction of an existing U.N. member state, Israel.

title: Free Tuna Being Offered After StarKist Settles Lawsuit
description: You may have free tuna waiting for you.

title: In the N.F.L., CBS Has a Thursday Night Anchor
description: When CBS began carrying Thursday Night Football in September, the network did not expect one blowout after another during the first four weeks. It had promoted its new prime-time package throughout the CBS empire and moved a durable ratings hit, The Big Bang Theory, to Monday nights. For its efforts and a $275 million rights fee, CBS was getting this?

title: Girl, 8, Dies After Being Hit by an S.U.V.
description: An 8-year-old girl died on Wednesday after being hit by a sport utility vehicle as she crossed a Brooklyn street, the police said.

title: A Showcase With Notable No-Shows
description: EDISON, N.J.  Motorists traveling southbound on Interstate 95 out of Manhattan will pass Rory McIlroy, who gazes down at them from a billboard promoting the Barclays at Plainfield Country Club.

title: Raid of Rentboy, an Escort Website, Angers Gay Activists
description: For some gay activists, it had shades of bathhouse raids and gay-bar roundups from decades ago. On Tuesday, federal authorities burst into the Union Square office of the gay-escort website Rentboy.com and arrested the chief executive and several employees on prostitution charges.

title: Review: In Ken Urbans Sense of an Ending, Lives Are Caught Between Truth and Tale
description: All I want is the truth. Thats what Charles (Joshua David Robinson), a discredited New York Times reporter, tells a potential source.

title: Birthplace of Paddington Bear
description: Administrivial Unusual Puzzle Property Alert! There is a Notepad in the Thursday, Aug. 27, puzzle which says: Seven Across answers in this puzzle have a highly unusual property for which we cant think of a single other common example. What is the property? (For answer, see 8/28 Notepad). The answers will be fully revealed here on Wordplay as well in the Friday post.

title: Charges Filed Against Long Island Man Involvedin Red-Light Camera Case
description: They have been spray-painted, burned and shot, often under cover of darkness, keeping their gaze off motorists who have called them money-grabbing machines.

title: New Jersey Police Find Sunken Fishing Boat, but Captain Remains Missing
description: Investigators found a sunken fishing boat off New Jersey on Wednesday after it was seen taking on water the day before, the authorities said.

title: College Conferences Try to Block Athletes Who Have Violent Pasts
description: As colleges struggle to control the public-relations damage caused by athletes criminal behavior, prominent conferences have begun measures to keep players with troubling pasts out of their teams nationally televised colors.

title: Hillary Clinton Speaks About Farming, and Much More, in Iowa
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa  It was a speech intended to introduce her plan to help rural America in one of the most agricultural parts of Iowa. But the framing that Hillary Rodham Clinton took to lay out her plan here drew the agricultural world into the broader messages of her campaign, touching on everything from immigration to drug addiction.

title: World Markets Jump as Investors Seek Signals in the Noise
description: Every major stock market in the world soared higher on Thursday, rebounding from the lows they had hit earlier in the week.

title: Opera in Park, Harmonizing (Mostly) With Citys Hum
description: The singers had performed underneath the Port Authority Bus Terminal. They had brought Puccini to the Times Square subway, Rossini to the depths of Union Square and Verdi to Pennsylvania Station, where they found a semicaptive audience among the beer-swilling commuters of the Long Island Railroad.

title: Arizona: State Ends Deal With Prison Contractor
description: Gov. Doug Ducey said on Wednesday that the state had canceled its contract with a private prison operator over a series of security and training lapses that set the stage for riots at a prison in July. He also ordered the Department of Corrections to assess operations of all private prisons in the state. Mr. Ducey, a Republican, described the riots, at a minimum-security prison operated by the Management and Training Corporation in Kingman, as frightening, disturbing and completely unacceptable. The riots, which began on July 1, forced the transfer of 1,100 prisoners from several housing units that were destroyed. Nine corrections officers suffered minor injuries.

title: Joe Biden Isnt Sure Family Is Ready for Run
description: In a conference call on Wednesday, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. told Democratic National Committee members that he was uncertain if his family had the emotional fuel for another presidential campaign.

title: A New Mets Outlook, and the Wins Keep Coming
description: PHILADELPHIA  When Terry Collins was hired as the Mets manager in 2010, the situation he inherited was not exactly viewed as desirable.

title: China Holds 23 Linked to Fatal Blasts in Tianjin
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese authorities, facing enormous pressure to account for catastrophic chemical blasts that killed more than 100 people two weeks ago, said Thursday that they had detained or placed under investigation 23 people in connection with the disaster.

title: Appellate Ruling on Issuing Marriage Licenses to Same-Sex Couples
description: A federal district judge in eastern Kentucky ordered Rowan Countys clerk, Kim Davis, to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples. A three judge appellate panel denied her request for a stay on Wednesday.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | riddle
description: riddle  \ri-dl\  verb and noun

title: Whats On TV Thursday
description: 1:45 P.M. (IFC) THE BLUES BROTHERS (1980) Jake (John Belushi, above left, with Dan Aykroyd) and Elwood (Mr. Aykroyd) are on a mission from God to come up with $5,000 so that the Chicago orphanage in which they were raised can pay its taxes and avoid closing. They have to get the Blues Brothers Band back together to play shows to raise the money, which leads them through a series of screwball misadventures, with appearances by John Lee Hooker, Aretha Franklin, James Brown, Ray Charles and others. John Landis (Animal House) directed this film.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 27, 2015
description: New Orleans attracted some of the best and most passionate people in the world after Katrina to help rebuild. You just had a talent influx. A lot of people saw New Orleans as the Peace Corps with better food.

title: Corrections: August 27, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: After Katrina, Man and Water in Louisiana
description: It had been raining for a few days in New Orleans earlier this month, but Frank Relle was not complaining. I like it when it rains in the summer, he said. It cools you and you dont have that heat building up into the night.

title: Student Crossword | Native American History
description: Test your knowledge of Native American history by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: Bernie Sanders, on the Campaign Trail
description: To the Editor:

title: New Orleans Schools, After Katrina
description: To the Editor:

title: Enough Is Enough
description: When Donald Trumps security escorted the Univision anchor Jorge Ramos out of a news conference on Tuesday, I decided that I was officially done.

title: Time to Fix the Fafsa
description: Is Congress finally ready to pass legislation that would make it easier for harried parents and students to apply for federal financial aid?

title: Americas Dangerous Bargain With Turkey
description: WASHINGTON  AFTER a year of intense diplomatic negotiations, the Turkish government is now permitting the United States to use Turkeys Incirlik Air Base, which will allow American aircraft to fly missions in Syria and Iraq with greater operational effectiveness and economic efficiency.

title: Let Fear Guide Early Stage Breast-Cancer Decisions
description: TWO patients, Ill call them Sara and Janine, both learned that they had ductal carcinoma in situ (D.C.I.S.), often referred to as Stage 0 breast cancer. Both underwent lumpectomies in their early 50s. Told that worrisome cells were found, both had another surgery. Then a third surgery was recommended.

title: Rethinking Warren G. Harding
description: THE last year or so has not been kind to Warren G. Harding, who was the 29th president, from 1921 to 1923. Last summer the Library of Congress released his steamy love letters to his neighbor Carrie Phillips. More recently, some of Hardings descendants had their DNA tested, to see if there was any truth to the claim of Nan Britton, the author of the tell-all book The Presidents Daughter, that she had borne Hardings child. They released the results last month. It turns out she had.

title: In California, a Thoughtful Conversation on Water
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking Back on Le Corbusiers Legacy
description: Fifty years after his death, the influence of Charles-douard Jeanneret-Gris, known as Le Corbusier, remains omnipresent in the world of architecture and urban planning. As a recent exhibition at the Pompidou Center showed, his buildings, books, and beliefs continue to stoke vigorous debates.

title: Time for Panic or Relief, Action or Patience?
News Qs | After Katrina, A City Revived but Unequal
description: A City Revived but Unequal is a multimedia presentation on the ways New Orleans has changed in the 10 years since Hurricane Katrina devastated the city. Watch the videos, analyze the maps and read the article to answer the questions below.

title: F.B.I. Memorandum From June 4, 2002, on the Possibility of Filing Prostitution-Related Charges Against Anwar al-Awlaki
description: Pasquale DAmuro, the bureaus assistant director for counterterrorism, asks James Baker for approval to use evidence gathered for intelligence purposes for a criminal prosecution.

title: Memorandum From Oct. 16, 2003, on an Interview by Staff Members of the Sept. 11 Commission With Special Agent Wade Ammerman of the F.B.I.
description: Wade Ammerman investigated Anwar al-Awlaki after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Dead, but Not Forgotten
description: It has been years since Anwar al-Awlaki was killed in an American drone strike, but online, his influence is as strong and pervasive as ever. Did killing Awlaki strengthen his message?

title: On the Upper East Side, Makeshift Bedrooms Need Not Apply
description: Last fall, Kelly Irvolino landed a job she very much wanted in the field of interior design. This was a career move for me, she said.

title: Do We Crank Up the A.C. Too High?
description: Has this ever happened to you? Its 90 degrees outside and yet youre shivering  or wrapped in a jacket or a blanket  because the air-conditioning is blasting.

title: The Lessons of Anwar al-Awlaki
description: Type Anwar al-Awlaki into YouTubes search bar, and you get 40,000 hits. Most of them bring up the earnest, smiling face and placid voice of the first American citizen to be hunted and killed without trial by his own government since the Civil War. Here is Awlaki on what makes a good marriage; on the nature of paradise; on Jesus Christ, considered a prophet by Muslims; on tolerance; on the holy month of Ramadan; and, more quirkily, on obesity and overeating in Islam. Here is Awlaki, or Sheikh Anwar, as his many admirers still call him, easily mixing Quranic Arabic with American English in chapters from his 53-CD series on the life of the Prophet Muhammad, once a best seller among English-speaking Muslims.

title: A Tour of Lake Michigan, My Inland Sea
description: We left to the south and returned from the north. In doing so, we fulfilled the grandest dream of Magellan, the dream of circumnavigation. Our compass was GPS and our logic was simple. If we kept the lake always on our left and traveled continuously, we would eventually reach the place from which we started  Chicago, with its seismic chart of skyscrapers, protracted sunsets and canyon-like streets, closing the circle by visiting every beach and port on the greatest lake of all, Michigan.

title: Defying Tradition, and Working Out, to Wear Bridal Crop Tops
description: When Cammy Hbert began planning her May wedding to Nick Miller, she knew a froufrougown would not do. Visions of Emilio Pucci danced in her head: specifically, a photo she came across years ago, in which a model wore a tight short-sleeved crop top and a long skirt reminiscent of a bunch of doilies.

title: Food and Tour News: Music in Glasgow, Seafood in New Zealand
description: Our morning travel news digest, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: New York Today: Battling for Brooklyn
description: Updated: 9:21 a.m.

title: This Year: $488 on School Supplies. Next Year Will Be Different.
description: It started with my soon-to-be sixth grader, Lily.

title: Hong Kong Protest Leader Charged
description: The Hong Kong police filed charges against the student protest leader Joshua Wong on Thursday in connection with the occupation of a government courtyard last September. The move prompted widespread pro-democracy protests.

title: Ukraine and Top Creditors Agree to Restructure $18 Billion in Foreign Debt
description: Ukraine and its main creditors agreed on Thursday to restructure $18 billion of the countrys foreign debt, in a rare deal between bond funds and a wobbly, emerging-market government.

title: Today in Politics: Ad Portrays Donald Trump and His Rivals as a Single Voice on Immigration
description: Good Thursday morning. Donald J. Trumps heated back-and-forth in Iowa on Tuesday with a respected anchor for a Spanish-language station was a clear display of Mr. Trumps quirks, but it also highlighted the rising tension his statements and policies on immigration have caused in the party. And a group with ties to Hillary Rodham Clinton is about to pounce.

title: Real Cambodian Cuisine in Siem Reap
description: One of Southeast Asias lesser-known cuisines is getting its due in Siem Reap.

title: The V.C.s of B.C.
description: One morning, just before dawn, an old man named Assur-idi loaded up two black donkeys. Their burden was 147 pounds of tin, along with 30 textiles, known as kutanum, that were of such rare value that a single garment cost as much as a slave. Assur-idi had spent his lifes savings on the items, because he knew that if he could convey them over the Taurus Mountains to Kanesh, 600 miles away, he could sell them for twice what he paid.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Brock Lesnar
description: A World Wrestling Entertainment production tends to be a ridiculous spectacle: a brash, crass, gleefully obnoxious passion play where herculean men scream, threaten and belittle at the tops of their lungs, then work through their interpersonal issues in front of millions of viewers by pretending to pummel one another senseless, all while wearing colorful spandex. Its hard to take seriously  that is, until Brock Lesnar enters the arena.

title: In Siem Reap, Cambodia, Local Fare Gets a Chance to Shine
description: On my first visit to Siem Reap a dozen years ago, I ate pizza, bibimbap and chocolate croissants. What I didnt eat much of was Cambodian food. As the jumping off point for Angkor Wat, Siem Reap (pronounced SEE-ehm REE-uhp) has long catered to international appetites. Yet its only relatively recently that visitors keen to explore local dishes have been able to do so beyond street stalls and mediocre buffets.

title: Scrutiny Falls on a Spanish Mosque After Foiled Train Attack
description: ALGECIRAS, Spain  Before he boarded a Paris-bound train last week, armed with an assault rifle and the intent, the authorities say, to carry out a blood bath, Ayoub El Khazzani had spent the final chapter of his troubled time in Spain in this gritty port city, living in a run-down apartment block with his parents within walking distance of the local mosque.

title: Bernie Sanderss Support: Even More Unequal Than U.S. Incomes
description: The supporters of Bernie Sanders keep telling me that Im wrong about their coalition, which Ive written is too narrow to succeed. At this rate, Mr. Sanders doesnt have nearly enough support among moderate, nonwhite and Southern voters to win the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: Q. and A.: Charles Yang on Greed, Gambling and Turmoil in Chinas Markets
description: Read in Chinese |

title: Morning Agenda: China Joins the Rebound
description: CHINA JOINS THE REBOUND | Shares in China rose for the first time in a week on Thursday, following on the heels of a Wall Street rebound, Amie Tsang writes in DealBook. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped into negative territory in the last hour of trading, but shot up to close 5.3 percent higher. Trading volumes were heavy during the period  an indication of state intervention.

title: First Draft Focus: Throwback Thursday  A Stampede, Before the Stampede
In Genevieve Hulme-Beamans Pondling, a Girl Who Only Looks Innocent
description: Genevieve Hulme-Beamans dark and eerily transfixing play Pondling, seen at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe a year ago, is headed to New York as part of the annual Origins 1st Irish Festival, which starts next week. The show, written and performed by Ms. Hulme-Beaman, is about a young girl who at first seems innocent enough, but soon her crush on an older boy brings out a darker side.

title: Review: Narcos Follows the Rise and Reign of Pablo Escobar
description: The small screen offers plenty of post-Vietnam, pre-Sept. 11 nostalgia these days, but dont expect a warm and fuzzy feeling from Narcos, an irresistible drama that begins streaming Friday on Netflix. Expect instead a reminder of a time when a few lawless men did a lot of societal damage by spreading cocaine far and wide.

title: London Theater Journal: Make Em Dream
description: LONDON  When a show talks about dreaming as much as Bend It Like Beckham: The Musical does, a theatergoer can start to feel drowsy. This family-friendly hit, which opened at the Phoenix Theater in June, begins with an open-faced young woman named Jess (Natalie Dew) in a soccer jersey looking, well, dreamy as she croons about how people say that Im a dreamer and that wishing for the moon will never get me anywhere.

title: Introducing Film Club: A New Teaching and Discussion Forum About Short Times Documentaries
description: You probably already know that The New York Times is increasingly publishing video to accompany its articles, but you may not know that The Times is also home to hundreds of short films that go well beyond just reporting the news.

title: After Virginia TV Shooting, Grief and Calls for Stricter Gun Laws
description: ROANOKE, Va.  Colleagues of the journalists slain a day earlier had a grief-filled return to work here on Thursday, clinging to one another for support and unsure if it was safe to venture out, while Democratic politicians and one victims father said the shooting showed the need for tougher gun laws.

title: Grisly Discovery in Migrant Crisis Shocks Europe
description: VIENNA  The legions of desperate migrants fleeing war and mayhem in the Middle East and Africa have long known they were risking harm from unscrupulous smugglers and death at sea to reach the safety of Europe. But it became shockingly clear on Thursday that they now face the same dangers within Europes own borders.

title: Hungarian Fence Doesnt Deter Migrants
description: Migrants, hoping to reach the security of wealthier European Union nations, scrambled under a barbed-wire barrier Hungary is erecting to protect its southern border with Serbia.

title: Discoveries Inside Thrift-Store Books
description: Dear Diary:

title: As Economies Gasp Globally, U.S. Growth Quickens
description: Not long ago, the United States was considered the tortoise of the world economy, at least in comparison to emerging powers like China and Brazil.

title: In L.A., a Cheaply Constructed Pop-Up Bar Thats a Work of Art
description: Its a hot August afternoon, and four artists-in-residency at the Los Angeles outpost of the Vienna-based MAK Center are surveying the damage to their collaborative art installation. Empty liquor bottles are everywhere, a banquette needs repair and the paintings lining the wall need to be straightened. This Saturday-afternoon assessment is a weekly ritual after the previous nights debauchery at Los Bar. Their project, built in the garage of the midcentury architect Rudolph Schindlers 1939 Mackey Apartments, where the artists are housed for six months, is a 0.65:1 scale replica of the famous Loos Bar in Vienna.

title: Bargemusics Here and Now Labor Day Festival
description: The week leading up to Labor Day is typically the least-scheduled stretch in New Yorks classical music season. But the intrepid Bargemusic, Brooklyns floating recital hall, always steps into the brink with a gala program. It does so this week with Here and Now Labor Day Festival, an ambitious contemporary music program, repeated four times, offering nine works in either world or New York premieres. There are premieres of two pieces by Dalit Warshaw; a solo cello Soliloquy by Andrew Rudin; David Del Tredicis Duo for Violin and Cello (To Be Sung on the Water); Richard Sussmans Trio for Violin, Piano and Laptop; and David Taylors Concertino for Bass Trombone and Trio. Works by Morton Subotnick, John Zorn and Gordon Beeferman receive New York premieres. Among the enticing roster of 11 performers are the pianist Kathleen Supov, the violinist Jennifer Choi and the bassoonist Peter Kolkay. (8 p.m., Wednesday, Friday and Saturday, with a final performance next Sunday at 4 p.m., bargemusic.org.)

title: Airbnb Appoints Chris Lehane, Former Aide to Bill Clinton, as Head of Policy
description: For years, Chris Lehane has known how to wage political war inside the Beltway. More recently, hes been focused on fighting political battles from inside of Silicon Valley.

title: Only Man Who Can Topple Usain Bolt: A Photographer on a Segway
description: BEIJING  American sprinters like Justin Gatlin? Usain Bolt keeps beating them and then beating his chest, as he did in winning his latest gold medal, in the 200 meters at the world track and field championships.

title: China Sentences 45 in Restive Region of Xinjiang
description: HONG KONG  Courts across Xinjiang, the volatile region of western China, have sentenced 45 people to prison in recent days after convicting them of supporting organizations accused of terror attacks or of helping others flee abroad, Xinhua, the main state news agency, reported on Thursday.

title: 1965: Marriage Mania in Las Vegas
description: NEW YORK  The beat-the-draft marriage mania that raged over many parts of the nation last night was best illustrated in Las Vegas, Nev., where 171 couples were married in the rush hours before midnight. By plane, bus and hot rod, the young couples poured into Las Vegas  Nevada requires neither blood test nor prewedding waiting period. In the top of their minds was one frantic thought  President Johnsons order earlier in the day that a marriage after midnight yesterday would not exempt a man from the draft.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 28, 1965

title: Daily Report: The Ugly and Antisocial Side of Social Media
description: It is pass to say these days, but maybe it bears repeating after Wednesday: Social media is a powerful thing.

title: From Indie to Franchise in a Single Bound
description: Independent film for decades has been seen as a way for directors to hold the greatest creative control over their projects. They work with meager means to create something close to their hearts, without the crushing pressure for it to be a global financial success. But having little or no cash to make art can be difficult, so many directors see indies as a steppingstone to the mainstream, a calling card to show studios how their intimate ideas could translate to big-budget projects. That may mean making a number of small films, then a climb up the studio ladder.

title: The High Bridge, a Scenic and Serene Cousin of the High Line
description: FOR as long as New York has been New York, its inhabitants have looked for ways to escape the citys frenzy. They have sought out breathable air, fresh vistas or a simple patch of greenery.

title: Exploring Hamilton and Hip-Hop Steeped in Heritage
description: In the hit Broadway musical Hamilton, Lin-Manuel Miranda tells the story of Alexander Hamilton, once the most overlooked founding father, by seamlessly weaving hip-hop into a musical theater framework. Its a novel hybridization, but is Mr. Miranda successfully paying tribute to both traditions or somehow weakening one of them? How specific are his references? How skillful is the rapping? Anthony Tommasini, the chief classical music critic of The New York Times and an avowed musical theater enthusiast, spoke with Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The Times, about technical fluency, Stephen Sondheim and Biggie Smalls. These are excerpts from their conversation.

title: Can You Match These Artists With Their Childhood Works?
description: Prominent contemporary artists shared some of their earliest works with T. Can you match the past with the present?

title: Planned Parenthood Videos Were Altered, Analysis Finds
description: WASHINGTON  Planned Parenthood on Thursday gave congressional leaders and a committee that is investigating allegations of criminality at its clinics an analysis it commissioned concluding that manipulation of undercover videos by abortion opponents make those recordings unreliable for any official inquiry.

title: Before Obamas Alaska Trip, Climate Group Charges Hypocrisy
description: President Obamas environmental critics are using his own words and images against him as they argue that his planned trip to Alaska next week is proof of what they call his self-defeating hypocrisy on global warming.

title: Business Travelers Warming Up to Car-Sharing
description: IN March, William Petz departed from his usual routine of logging on to Travelocity or Orbitz to rent a car from Budget or Hertz while traveling on business.

title: Francis Sejersted, 79, Dies; Steered Nobel Peace Prize Into Controversy
description: Francis Sejersted, a Norwegian historian who as the chairman of the Nobel Peace Prize committee presided over several controversial awards, including the one shared by the Israeli leaders Shimon Peres and Yitzhak Rabin and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, died on Tuesday at his home in Oslo. He was 79.

title: Rising Anxiety That Stocks Are Overpriced
description: Over the five trading days between Aug. 17 and Aug. 24, the United States stock market dropped 10 percent  the official definition of a correction, with similar or greater drops in other countries.

title: U.S. Open 2015: Who Will Break Out?
description: All the attention will be on Serena Williams this year, but keep an eye on these players. Vanderbilt tennis coach Geoff Macdonald sizes up their chances.

title: Catholic Exceptions and Catholic Rules
description: Its been a little while since Ive written anything about the still-percolatingissue of communion for Catholics who divorce and remarry without an annulment  with Pope Franciss visit to the U.S. in September and the synod the following month, there will be ample opportunity for Catholic argument this fallbut I didnt want to let this John Allen column slip too far into the past without highlighting its argument.

title: Williams Sisters Leave an Impact Thats Unmatched
description: For a sizable portion of nearly two transformative decades, one family surname has competitively dominated tennis and continually inundated its news. Think about how an emerging generation of female players has never known a tour without the headlining Williams sisters, Venus and Serena.

title: Donald Trumps Critics Arent Politically Correct. Theyre Outraged
description: It came as no surprise this week that Donald Trump put on a mock Chinese accent and spoke in broken English to criticize the leaders of China and (more to the point) President Obama for even talking to them.

title: The Daily Show Gets Ready to Go Viral
description: Though The Daily Show is generally consumed as a once-a-day experience, the political offenses and media misdeeds it chronicles are a 24-hour phenomenon, as any glance at your Facebook or Twitter feed will tell you.

title: Officials on Bodies in Truck Near Vienna
description: Chancellors Werner Faymann of Austria and Angela Merkel of Germany expressed sorrow on Thursday after police discovered at least 20 bodies of presumed migrants piled in a truck east of Vienna.

title: Former Hewlett-Packard Board Member Praises Carly Fiorinas Business Leadership
description: A super PAC supporting Carly Fiorina is defending her record as chief executive of Hewlett-Packard in a full-page ad in The New York Times that promotes her strength as a leader of the technology company.

title: Reflections on Virginia Shooting Victims
description: The boyfriend of Alison Parker, who was killed in a shooting on live television on Wednesday, and the husband of a woman who was injured spoke about their loved ones.

title: The Food Sermon
description: The bright flavors of the Caribbean in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.

title: At the Food Sermon, Keeping the Faith in Crown Heights
description: The cross-shape sign says, Jesus Saves, or almost: The first S has fallen away. All along this stretch of Rogers Avenue in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, battered-looking storefronts speak of miracles and end times. So the Food Sermon, standing on a corner with its windows shining and its name in letters as yellow as the noon sun, may be mistaken at first for a sleeker, more modern place of worship.

title: Tyler, the Creator Barred From the United Kingdom
description: Tyler, the Creator, a rapper in the hip-hop collective Odd Future, has reportedly been barred from the United Kingdom because of his provocative lyrical content.

title: Google Rebuts Europe on Antitrust Charges
description: Google on Thursday rejected claims from the European Unions top antitrust official that the company favored some of its own search results over those of rivals, saying there was significant competition in the regions online search market and that the companys services increased choice for local consumers.

title: Germany Urges Sharing of Migrant Burden
description: While offering aid to Balkan countries hit by the recent wave of migrants, Germanys foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, called on European Union states to cooperate to solve the crisis.

title: Sinkhole Swallows Five People in China
description: At least four were injured Saturday when a sinkhole suddenly opened at a bus stop in northern China. A surveillance camera at a nearby noodle shop caught the collapse.

title: Children React to Panda Cubs Death
description: Children visiting the Smithsonian National Zoo in Washington shared their feelings on the death of one of the twin cubs born to a giant panda named Mei Xiang.

title: On The Verge: Elizabeth Suzann
description: A Nashville-based line strives for less-is-more.

title: Outrage Over Images of TV Shooting on Newspaper Front Pages
description: Was it newsworthy or over the line? News outlets had to confront that question after Vester Lee Flanagan II fatally shot two television journalists in Virginia on Wednesday and then posted a video of the shooting to his Facebook account.

title: As Trash Piles Up, So Does Contempt for Lebanons Government
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Mohammad Rizk sat glumly in his sandwich shop on Wednesday, waiting for customers. The scent of roasting chicken mingled with the fumes of a trash pile just outside. The garbage heap, which seemed to have taken on a life of its own, now dominated the curb where his drive-by clients once idled.

title: Dark Shades for a Childrens Hamlet
description: David Habben had one man in mind when he created the eerie artwork for a new production of Hamlet at the Utah Childrens Theater in Salt Lake City.

title: A Basics Line That Strives for Less-Is-More
description: I started this company to avoid the excess I saw in clothing  to create comfort and inspire confidence through well-made garments that dont speak louder than the person wearing them, says Elizabeth Pape, the 25-year-old founder of the Nashville-based direct-to-consumer label Elizabeth Suzann.

title: Hillary Clintons Handling of Email Issue Frustrates Democratic Leaders
description: Democratic leaders are increasingly frustrated by Hillary Rodham Clintons failure to put to rest questions about her State Department email practices and ease growing doubts among voters about her honesty and trustworthiness.

title: What to Do This Weekend
description: The Times arts team is here to help.

title: Dr. James H. Duke Jr., Texas Trauma Surgeon, Dies at 86
description: Dr. James H. Duke Jr., a Houston trauma surgeon who treated Gov. John Connally of Texas on the day of the Kennedy assassination and reached a national audience through his syndicated television reports on medical topics and his frequent appearances on Today and the NBC Nightly News, died on Tuesday in Houston. He was 86.

title: U.S. Open Draw Unveils Serena Williamss Grand Slam Path
description: The first player standing between Serena Williams and a historic U.S. Open title: Vitalia Diatchenko, a Russian ranked 86th.

title: 1915: Roosevelt Calls Pacifists Sissies
description: NEW YORK  Colonel Roosevelt, addressing the New York business men who are training as soldiers at the military instruction camp at Plattsburg, N.Y., to-day, declared that America should support the President only if he was right, and denounced hyphenated Americans as enemies of their country and humanity. He also held up to scorn the professional pacifists who require other men to defend them, calling them college sissies and men with mean souls.  The New York Herald, European Edition, August 28, 1915

title: Carolyn Maloney, New York Representative, Will Oppose Iran Nuclear Deal
description: Representative Carolyn B. Maloney said on Thursday that she would vote against President Obamas proposed nuclear deal with Iran, joining Senator Chuck Schumer and other New York Democrats in opposing the White Houses top diplomatic priority.

title: Closing Remarks in St. Pauls Rape Trial
description: J.W. Carney Jr., the lawyer for Owen Labrie, the 19-year-old who is accused of raping a girl at St. Pauls School in New Hampshire last year, made his closing remarks on Thursday.

title: Insane Things Republicans Say: Bobby Jindal Edition
description: Political candidates who are trying to stave off what seems like inevitable defeat often do the kinds of desperate things that ordinary mortals would find too humiliating to contemplate.

title: MSNBC Moves Al Sharptons Daily Show to Sundays
description: The Rev. Al Sharptons PoliticsNation show on MSNBC is moving from its daily 6 p.m. time slot to a weekly broadcast on Sunday mornings at 8 a.m. starting Oct. 4, the cable news network announced late Wednesday.
